headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 18 - 24; THEATER
summary: At times it can seem as if every working solo performer is imitating either SPALDING GRAY or ERIC BOGOSIAN. These artists, who were once the epitome of downtown cool, helped invent the monologue for a generation of writer-actors who have gone on, of course, to beat the form to death. As he got older, Mr. Gray graduated from the Wooster Group to performances uptown, where he dug deeper and deeper into his personal life, and questions of fame and depression, until his suicide in 2004. Mr. Bogosian has generally moved beyond his monologues, which once made Frank Rich of The Times compare him to Lenny Bruce, Bob Dylan and Woody Allen, all in the same sentence. He has kept a lower profile and branched out into novels and Hollywood movies. In the past year there has been a revival of interest in both Mr. Bogosian and Mr. Gray, and this week you can see some of their formative work. LIEV SCHREIBER stars in one of Mr. Bogosian's breakout works, ''TALK RADIO,'' a drama about a fear monger who makes Bill O'Reilly and Howard Stern look polite. The play, which had its premiere at the Public in 1987, was the first time that audiences saw Mr. Bogosian expand past the monologue. In previews; opens on March 11, Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, Manhattan; $36.25 to $96.26. Mr. Gray has been receiving numerous tributes onstage, and Steven Soderbergh is working on a documentary about his life. But ''SPALDING GRAY: STORIES LEFT TO TELL'' is the first play with his widow, Kathleen Russo, as a co-creator (Lucy Sexton was the other creator). It is a collection of his most famous and obscure writings. The cast includes Frank Wood and Hazelle Goodman. Previews start Tuesday; opens March 6, Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village; $35 and $65. Julian Sheppard's last play, ''Buicks,'' about a deluded car salesman on the run, opened in 2003 and was one of the fresher new comedies in years, so it's not surprising that it was optioned by Paramount Pictures as a sitcom for CBS. Meanwhile Mr. Sheppard brings us ''LOS ANGELES,'' about a young woman struggling in the city of angels. Katherine Waterston stars, and Adam Rapp directs. In previews, opens March 3, Flea Theater, 41 White Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 352-3101, theflea.org; $20.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: DEMOCRATS AND MEDICARE -- Democrats, who have long charged that the drug industry is profiteering at taxpayers' expense, say they want to introduce legislation to revoke the law that bars Medicare from negotiating prices directly with drug makers for the medicines it buys. [C1.] WEB ACCESS FOR THE BLIND -- Although commercial Web sites have made considerable strides in serving the blind, there are still major difficulties on both sides of the screen. ''Web sites are more useful than they used to be, but there are still a few more hurdles than you'd like to have to go through,'' said James Gashel, above, an executive director for the National Federation of the Blind, which is based in Baltimore. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C6.] GOOGLE AND PRINT ADS -- Google is planning to start selling advertisements that will appear in the print editions of 50 major newspapers. The company will expand its computer system, which already auctions off advertisements on millions of Web sites, to take bids for newspaper ads as well. [C1.] PUTTING THE SQUEEZE ON TALENT -- Movie and television studios, which are facing escalating budgets, rampant piracy and the uncertain future of new media, are demanding concessions from their talent. And actors, directors and writers are not happy about it. [C1.] EYES ON VIVENDI -- Is Vivendi in play? That was the question being whispered among the world's media moguls over the weekend after it emerged that Vivendi had held talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company over a potential $50 billion takeover bid, which would have been the largest leveraged buyout offer in history. [C1.] ONLINE HIRE AT CBS -- In an effort to expand into the online world, CBS Inc. said it had hired Quincy Smith, formerly of Allen and Company, to oversee its interactive strategy. [C6.] NEW VIEWS ON ADVERTISING -- A widely followed annual survey of the relationships between advertisers and agencies shows some improvement from last year's results, many of which reached record 20-year lows. Even so, the survey suggests that Madison Avenue is still struggling to adjust to profound new challenges, which range from adjusting to the rapid rise of new media to the difficulty of recruiting talented employees. [C8.] ADVERTISING SHIFT IN FRANCE -- A round of musical chairs that is reshaping the upper ranks of the French advertising world continued last week when Maurice Lévy, chief executive of Publicis Groupe, named three executives to key positions in Paris. [C7.] THE MEDICATED PENGUIN -- An animated movie about a tap-dancing penguin is venturing beyond the Antarctic, with a promotional tie-in to pharmaceuticals. Characters from the family film ''Happy Feet'' appear in an extensive advertising campaign -- including national network and cable commercials, full-page magazine ads and online banner ads -- for the drug maker Roche. [C4.] THE CULTURE OF VIDEO GAMES -- The French culture minister, Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres, is seeking to have video games recognized as a cultural industry eligible for tax breaks, similar to those that movie-related business receive. [C6.]

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Jets (7-6) at Minnesota Vikings (6-7) 1 p.m. CBS CHAD PENNINGTON vs. VIKINGS' PASS DEFENSE The Vikings have given up an average of 28.2 yards rushing and 260.6 yards passing in their past five games. Matt Leinart of the Arizona Cardinals and Brett Favre of the Green Bay Packers each threw for more than 300 yards against them, mainly because their teams could not run on the league's top-ranked rushing defense. Jets Coach Eric Mangini said he would not abandon the running game. ''I think you have to be able to incorporate both,'' he said. ''During the course of the game, sometimes you throw more, sometimes you run more. Sometimes it's about the flow of the game.'' For the Jets, it always comes down to Chad Pennington, above. In their past three victories, he has averaged 239 yards passing. In their past three losses, he has averaged 151 through the air. BY THE NUMBERS 1 Rank of the Vikings' rush defense in the N.F.L. 703 Total rushing yards allowed by the Vikings this season. 54.1 Average net rushing yards allowed by Minnesota. 28.2 Average net rushing yards allowed last five games by the Vikings. 10 First downs rushing allowed by the Vikings in their last five games. KAREN CROUSE

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
summary: SIRIUS SATELLITE RADIO will pay the CBS Corporation $2 million as part of a settlement of a $218 million lawsuit asserting fraud over the talk-show host Howard Stern's jump to Sirius in January. Sirius will get rights to the recordings of Mr. Stern's CBS Radio broadcasts in return for the payment, the companies said. The companies said remaining terms of the agreement, including additional payments to settle a lawsuit against Mr. Stern, are confidential. The agreement ends a four-month battle that was ignited by Mr. Stern's move from CBS to Sirius. CBS Radio, which accused Stern of using its airtime to promote Sirius before he left last year, sued Sirius, Stern and his agent in February.

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Good 'Deal' for NBC
summary: With solid ratings for its hit game show as well as its new science-fiction series, NBC handily led Monday in the important demographic of 18 to 49 years old. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Deal or No Deal,'' with the host Howie Mandel, right, earned 18 million viewers at 8 p.m., while ''Heroes'' drew a series-best 15 million viewers at 9, finishing just short of its record one week ago in the 18-to-49 group. Meanwhile, CBS edged out NBC to win the night in total viewers, as ''CSI: Miami'' drew 18.4 million viewers, a season high of its own, easily capturing the 10 p.m. hour. In second at 10, NBC's ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' fared about average with recent weeks (7.8 million) as it concluded a two-part story line with John Goodman playing a judge. Fox ranked ahead of ABC in third for the night, buoyed by a second-place finish at 8 p.m. for ''Prison Break'' (9.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT

Tonight, Mr. Baryshnikov and Ms. Waters trade philosophies on art, food, teaching and community as they visit the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan and the Edible Schoolyard Project (above) in Berkeley, Ca., and share a meal at Ms.Waters's restaurant Chez Panisse. 4 P.M. Meanwhile Joy (Jaime Pressly) tries to get a restraining order lifted to improve her image before heading to court. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- Salma Hayek, the show's executive producer, begins a guest stint as a mysterious beauty who leaves Daniel panting. 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- The rapper Bow Wow makes a guest appearance as an escaped killer from the Phantom Zone, who takes on Clark and Raya as revenge for his imprisonment. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- Grissom (William Petersen) asks a sex offender for help in catching the abductor of two boys, but what he's really looking for is a confession. 9 P.M. This documentary looks at some of the gaping holes in America's electronic voting system, which counts about 87 percent of the votes cast in the country today, and asks how safe democracy can be when the voting process is not secure. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- Cristina helps put a patient back together again in a rare ''humpty dumpty'' procedure. 9 P.M. (Travel) JOAN CUSACK'S LOCAL FLAVOR -- Ms. Cusack goes to Greece. 9:30 P.M. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Architects Honor Vietnam Memorial Maya Lin's Vietnam Veterans Memorial, above, in Washington has been chosen by the American Institute of Architects to receive its 2007 AIA Twenty-Five Year Award. The accolade honors architectural design that has stood the test of time for 25 years. ''The memorial speaks to the power of design and resonates with all of us,'' said Richard Logan, the chairman of the association's 2007 Architecture Jury. ''It creates a magical moment of the living and the dead touching, and it is still as potent as the first time you saw it.'' The two-acre memorial on the National Mall was dedicated on Nov. 13, 1982, after having been chosen from among 1,421 entries in a public design competition held by the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund. Its principal feature is its highly reflective black-granite V-shaped Memorial Wall, inscribed with the names of more than 58,000 men and woman who died or were classified as missing in action. Angry Rockers Sue Web Site Major names in rock 'n' roll are suing the owner of a Web site that specializes in streaming rare concert recordings, Reuters reported. Grateful Dead Productions, Carlos Santana, right, and members of Led Zeppelin and the Doors filed suit in United States District Court in San Francisco against William Sagan, owner of Wolfgang's Vault, which offers thousands of recordings of rare audio and video music performances collected over 30 years by Bill Graham, a concert promoter who died in 1991. The plaintiffs argue that Wolfgang's Vault (wolfgangsvault.com), which bought the Graham collection, is illegally offering the recordings to stimulate sales of other merchandise, including T-shirts, photographs and memorabilia. Its representatives were not immediately available for comment. Joan Baez, Booker T. & the MG's, Maria Callas, Ornette Coleman, the Doors, the Grateful Dead and Bob Wills have been chosen to receive the Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Awards. These honors will be acknowledged during the 49th Grammy Awards telecast by CBS from Los Angeles on Feb. 11. After Two Centuries, A Goya Goes Public A Goya portrait never displayed in public is to be exhibited in the spring in Saragossa, Spain, after minor restoration at the Prado in Madrid, Agence France-Presse reported. ''Portrait of Luis María de Borbón y Vallabriga,'' right, depicting the cherubic 6-year-old nephew of King Charles III, was painted in 1783, when Goya was 37. The boy grew up to become a cardinal at the age of 23 and put an end to the Spanish Inquisition. The painting was recently acquired by authorities in Aragon, in northeastern Spain, for $13 million, from a branch of the royal family that has had it for 223 years. ''It is one of the masterpieces of the period,'' Gabriele Finaldi, in charge of conservation at the Prado, told The Guardian of London. ''There is a certain amount of superficial dirt. Otherwise it is in an almost virgin state.'' It is to go on view in the spring at the provincial museum in Saragossa, near Goya's birthplace, Fuendetodos. Going Back to the Village AMC is going to ask again: What is the explanation for the mysterious Village? In a new venture into old television territory, the cable channel AMC plans to remake the Kafkaesque thriller ''The Prisoner,'' which starred Patrick McGoohan, its creator, producer and sometime writer, when it was broadcast by CBS in the late 1960s, Reuters reported. The story follows a man who finds himself trapped in ''the Village'' with no memory of how he arrived. Under constant surveillance, the man, known as Number Six, sets out to learn what is going on, why he is there and how he can escape. The premiere is scheduled for January 2008. Rob Sorcher, AMC's executive vice president for programming and production, said the channel had also acquired the rights to the original ''Prisoner'' and planned to broadcast those episodes around the time the new series begins. TBS has ordered nine more episodes of its critically acclaimed series ''My Boys,'' starring Jordana Spiro as a sportswriter who is one of the guys. TBS announced that the episodes would be broadcast in the summer.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Biography) MAVERICKS: HONKY TONK ANGELS -- Their voices are sweet, their tales are not. This special looks at some of country music's feistiest women, including Patsy Cline (left), Loretta Lynn and Shania Twain, who bucked rules and roadblocks on the way to success. Ray Charles, Judy Collins, Robert Duvall, Kris Kristofferson, k.d. lang, Dolly Parton, Carl Perkins, Randy Travis, Conway Twitty and Trisha Yearwood reminisce in archival interviews about the legends left in their wakes. 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO -- Gray Anderson, just back from his explorations, gives a report on the state of the union. 8 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK -- Liz fights to keep Jack out of the writers' room and Cerie in her clothes. Meanwhile, Kenneth discovers that dealing with Tracy Jordon is a bigger job than he bargained for. 8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- As they say, beauty knows no pain. Tonight, a look back at the torture the remaining contestants have endured. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- The Soweto Gospel Choir helps Mr. Lagasse raise on the rafters on his studio kitchen. 8:30 P.M. (NBC) TWENTY GOOD YEARS -- When Jeffrey (Jeffrey Tambor) rekindles the flame with his ex (Judith Light), John (John Lithgow) fears she'll put a damper on his plans for adventure with his buddy. 9 P.M. (Fox) THE RICH LIST -- At last, a pastime for the obsessive-compulsives out there. In this new game show, strangers are thrown together at random to compete in making lists on a range of topics, all while predicting just how many answers they'll be able to come up with. If a team fails to meet that number, the other team wins. Eamonn Holmes (above) is host. 9 P.M. (CNBC) BIG BROTHER, BIG BUSINESS -- Who's watching? Almost everyone, that's who. In this two-hour documentary, David Farber investigates the ways in which average Americans are monitored -- whether shopping, driving, dining or searching the Internet -- and how spying has become a lucrative game while encroaching on ordinary lives. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- Dr. Sheldon Hawkes (Hill Harper) and Mac (Gary Sinise, near left, with Mr. Harper) investigate a woman who died after bleeding from her eyes, mouth and ears at a secret party on a subway train. Meanwhile, when a wealthy playboy winds up dead in his indoor pool, all eyes turn to his ''room maid,'' a beautiful woman hired to clean his penthouse in exchange for room and board. This one happened to be wearing a wig to suit his preference for blondes. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: A Woman Who's Man Enough
summary: WASHINGTON Things are getting confusing out there in Genderville.

headline: Set to Debate, G.O.P. Contenders Ponder What to Say About Bush
summary: As they gather Thursday night at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library for their first debate, the Republican presidential candidates are thrilled at the chance to associate themselves with Reagan. But they may not be able to escape the challenge created for them by the current president. As much as Iraq or health care or any other issue, the question of how to deal with President Bush is vexing the Republican field. Do they embrace him as a means of appealing to the conservative voters who tend to decide Republican primaries? Or do they break from him in an effort to show that they will lead the nation in a new direction? Do they applaud his policies or question his competence -- or both?

headline: WORKING MOM
summary: Two and a half months into her new job as anchor and managing editor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' Katie Couric views both her business and personal life as a balancing act. To attract more viewers, she is trying to balance a different approach to the newscast with maintaining ''a semblance of what people are accustomed to,'' she said last week at the Museum of Television and Radio in New York.

headline: Bush, at Low Point in the Polls, Will Push His Domestic Agenda
summary: Carrying some of the worst public approval ratings of any president in a generation, President Bush is heading into his State of the Union address on Tuesday night seeking to revitalize his domestic agenda but facing stiff resistance over the initiatives the White House has previewed so far. Administration officials said Monday that among Mr. Bush's proposals would be a plan to help states provide health care coverage to people who lack insurance by diverting federal aid from hospitals, especially public institutions. The provision is likely to draw loud criticism from municipalities across the nation and will significantly affect the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the nation's largest municipal health care system.

headline: Health Care for the Rest of Us
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Most Support U.S. Guarantee of Health Care'' (front page, March 2): Around kitchen tables, families are fuming over their rising premiums, uninsured relatives and unpaid medical bills. The problem of health coverage concerns all those who have insurance, those offered insurance by employers who turn it down because of the expense, and the uninsured.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Jan. 7 - 13; TELEVISION
summary: Television doesn't get much better than the first season of ''THE SOPRANOS.'' Now basic-cable subscribers who don't pay for HBO, or watch DVDs, or swap pirated videos online, can see what all the fuss is about when the series makes its premiere on A&E (9 p.m. Wednesday), eight years to the day after it first appeared. Or most of the fuss, anyway. Will the bullet-and-profanity-riddled family crime drama be a different show with fully clothed strippers at the Bada Bing, or with Tony telling Artie that he's a ''really'' great cook? Yes, slightly. But it will still be really great. PBS tackles Topic A this week with the start of the four-hour series ''CHINA FROM THE INSIDE'' (9 p.m. Wednesday, most stations; check local listings). Produced by Granada Television and the San Francisco PBS affiliate KQED, the program addresses the power of the Communist Party, women's rights, the environment and religious freedom, and the producers have rounded up the requisite complement of true believers (or fast operators) and surprisingly frank dissenters. The series's content won't be a surprise to anyone who keeps up with the news, but its pictures, crossing the country from Xinjiang to Xiamen, are fascinating and beautiful. The first round of the NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE PLAYOFFS continues on Sunday, and New York fans can enjoy -- or not -- consecutive games featuring the Jets against New England (1 p.m., CBS) and the Giants against Philadelphia (4:30 p.m., Fox). Those who prefer violence of the emotional variety can look forward to new episodes of ''GREY'S ANATOMY'' (ABC, 9 p.m. Thursday).

headline: When a Politician Doesn't Want Money
summary: What do you say when the gubernatorial campaign of Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, returns your contribution? How about: ''Uh oh.'' Often, the reasons are clear enough. Of the $250,368.57 returned by Mr. Spitzer's campaign in the first half of the year, about half went to Melvyn I. Weiss and others associated with his giant law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, which was indicted in May on charges of secretly paying plaintiffs.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (A&E) DOG: THE FAMILY SPEAKS -- Duane Chapman, aka Dog the Bounty Hunter (right, with his wife, Beth), found out what it's like to be in his prey's shoes after he was arrested on Thursday for illegal detention and conspiracy in the 2003 capture of Andrew Luster, the Max Factor heir who was later convicted of raping three women. (CBS) THE UNIT The team's South American mission is put on hold when its members have to rescue two of their own. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT -- Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) goes under cover to combat terrorist activities when a rape victim -- and F.B.I. informant -- refuses to cooperate. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- Denise (Julie Bowen) and Shirley (Candice Bergen) defend Daniel Post (Michael J. Fox) after he gets caught by police trying to buy a lung. Alan Shore (James Spader) defends a friend (Christian Clemenson) after he gets caught by police driving in the carpool lane with a lifesize sex doll. 10 P.M. (13) TWELVE DISCIPLES OF NELSON MANDELA -- In 1960, Benjamin Pule Leinaeng, a black South African, and 11 of his comrades left their home in Bloemfantein on a mission: to tell the world about the brutality of the apartheid system and their support for the African National Congress and its leader, Nelson Mandela. In this ''P.O.V.'' documentary, Leinaeng's stepson Thomas Allen Harris looks back on the life of the man who reared him, but whom he could never call father. 10 P.M. (HBO) REAL SPORTS WITH BRYANT GUMBEL -- Up for discussion: the race-car driver Danica Patrick, the weight gain of high-school football players, and a gathering at which homeless men in New York play soccer. 10 P.M. (FX) NIP/TUCK -- A nanny candidate fuels Sean's hidden desires, while Christian (Julian McMahon), having decided he's fat, puts himself in the hands of a plastic surgeon (Mario Lopez, top right, with Mr. McMahon) he thinks looks better than he does. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: MICROSOFT AND LINUX -- Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking an agreement with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows. [Page C1.] CRUISE TO HELP LEAD UNITED ARTISTS -- Tom Cruise, the film star who took a beating when Paramount ended his longstanding production deal last summer, has found not just a home, but a new career direction that could point the way for expensive actors who are struggling in cost-conscious Hollywood. Mr. Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, will take charge of United Artists, the production company started by Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford. [C1.] NEW MEDICAID POLICY -- Under a new federal policy, children born in the United States to illegal immigrants with low incomes will no longer be automatically entitled to health insurance through Medicaid, Bush administration officials said. [A1.] DISAPPOINTING RETAIL SALES -- Wal-Mart Stores was one of several large retailers, along with Target and CostCo, to post disappointing October sales totals. [C1.] UTILITY SWITCH -- On Tuesday, voters in Yolo County in California will decide whether residents will switch from Pacific Gas and Electric to the municipal utility. Supporters of the change say it will lower costs. Opponents, including P.G.&E., are afraid it will set a bad precedent. [C1.] HOME OWNERSHIP AD CAMPAIGN -- The National Association of Realtors will begin promoting the notion that buying a home is an unalloyed good in a $40 million campaign that boldly declares: ''It's a great time to buy or sell a home.'' Advertising. [C7.] EX-CHIEF SENTENCED TO 12 YEARS -- The former chief executive of Computer Associates International, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison for orchestrating a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company. He was also fined $8 million. [C3.] HINT IN EUROPE ON RATES -- The European Central Bank signaled that it would raise its benchmark interest rate for the sixth time in a year when it meets in December, as it tries to curb inflation in an expanding European economy. [C5.] RUSSIA PRESSURES GEORGIA ON OIL -- Russia intensified its economic pressure on Georgia as the state-controlled gas monopoly, Gazprom, indicated that it would seek to more than double the price it charges for natural gas, beginning in January. [A12.] ARRESTS IN ONLINE THEFTS -- At least three Americans and 11 Polish nationals have been arrested in the last month in a crackdown on an online black market in which users buy and sell credit card numbers, bank account log-ins and other information, federal investigators say. [C4.] RUNWAY ERRORS NOT UNCOMMON -- Using the wrong runway, the error that led to the crash in Kentucky that killed 49 people in August, is not so rare, a top official of the Federal Aviation Administration said at a safety conference. [A21.] INSTINET IS SOLD -- Less than a year after buying Instinet, the electronic brokerage firm, the private equity firm Silver Lake Partners has agreed to sell the company. [C3.] LOWER INCOME AT CBS -- CBS reported lower net income from a year ago, when it was still combined with Viacom, but operating earnings rose. The company also announced a share buyback of up to $1.5 billion. Investors have been pressing CBS to say what its plans are for its growing cash stockpile, which is at $3.2 billion. [C4.] JANITORS STRIKE IN HOUSTON -- More than 5,000 janitors have gone on strike because five Houston cleaning companies have rejected their proposal for a salary increase to $8.50 an hour, up from the current average of $5.25 an hour. [A18.] CHINA AND AFRICA -- China is courting Africa with both economic and political goals in mind. Its economic goal is to secure Africa's abundant supplies of oil, iron ore, copper and cotton at the lowest possible prices, analysts say. [A1.] STOCKS FALL -- Stocks continued to decline, dipping lower after the Labor Department said productivity was flat in the third quarter while wages rose nearly 4 percent. The data raised concerns that the Federal Reserve would continue to wrestle with inflation, possibly raising interest rates again. [C7.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) MADONNA: THE CONFESSIONS TOUR -- LIVE FROM LONDON Taped in London (in August, at Wembley Stadium) would be the more accurate description of this two-hour concert, filmed during Madonna's (right) 25-city world tour. The concert includes songs from her recent album ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' as well as some of her greatest hits. 8 P.M. (Travel) JAMIE'S GREAT ITALIAN ESCAPE Mr. Oliver takes his camper to Altamura, where he befriends Beppe DiGesu, a local baker. Later, he cooks a birthday lunch for Mr. DiGesu's wife and 30 members of his family. At 8:30, Mr. Oliver journeys along the Amalfi coast and celebrates his 30th birthday. 9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS After a chemical weapons device is found during a raid, Gideon (Mandy Patinkin) and his team travel to Guantánamo Bay to interrogate the leader of a terrorist sleeper cell. 9 P.M. (ABC) DAY BREAK Talk about getting up on the wrong side of the bed. In this series, new last week, Detective Brett Hopper (Taye Diggs, left) will continue to wake up on the same ugly day, on which he has been accused of the murder of an assistant district attorney, until he figures out how he wound up in this pickle. Tonight, he discovers that somebody close to him may have helped frame him and gets new information that may help him bring the day to an end. But, of course, not yet. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM Meanwhile, in a new time slot, Allison (Patricia Arquette) is merely reliving the same horrific day over and over in her dreams, giving her insight into a potential hostage situation. Joe wishes she'd give him a little more affection. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY Alert the animalcontrol people. Lindsay is bitten by a cobra hiding inside the car of a murder victim, and a parachutist is killed when dead pigeons fall from the sky. 10 P.M. (MTV) THE REAL WORLD In this 18th -- count 'em -- season premiere, seven strangers take up residence in the LoDo (for Lower Downtown) section of Denver, where during the day they work as Outward Bound counselors for adolescents affected by Hurricane Katrina while tearing up the Mile High City at night. 10 P.M. (Sundance) MYSTERIOUS SKIN (2004). In Gregg Araki's grim and tender drama, two Kansas boys are connected by the traumatic events of their childhood. One, who believes he was the victim of an alien abduction, becomes obsessed with UFO's; the other, who simply recalls being molested by his Little League coach, becomes a gay hustler. Joseph Gordon-Levitt (above left) and Brady Corbet star. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Some Major Advertisers Won't Return to 'Survivor'
summary: The controversy over the plot twist in the new season of ''Survivor'' on CBS, dividing the competing teams along racial lines, took its toll on the show's appeal to advertisers, judging by the commercial lineup in the premiere episode on Thursday. Before the episode ran, many major national marketers that had bought commercial time during previous seasons of ''Survivor'' said they would not return. The list included Campbell Soup, Coca-Cola, General Motors, Home Depot, Johnson & Johnson, Procter & Gamble and United Parcel Service. None of them attributed their withdrawals to the race-based format.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LOWENSTEIN, LARRY
summary: LOWENSTEIN--Larry, 86, October 3, 2006 in Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of Joyce, father of Barbara DuBois and Caryl Komornik; stepfather of Penny Siskin and Patsy Arnow; grandfather of 8, greatgrandfather of 4. A native New Yorker, he had a distinguished career with CBS-TV, advertising, then his own PR firm in NYC representing the broadcasting industry as well as many famous clients such as Arthur Godfrey, the Miss Universe Pageant and Leon Uris. A lengthy PR career in Atlanta followed and was marked by service on numerous charity boards. Donations may be made to American Cancer Society.

headline: Don Imus And Free Speech
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Everybody Hates Don Imus'' (column, April 15): Frank Rich and others who raise ''free speech'' or First Amendment guarantees to argue that Don Imus should not have been fired are misguided.

headline: Democrats Rush to Frame Political Debate Over Troops
summary: ''Cut and run'' versus ''stay the course'' is so 2006. This week has ushered in a new political battle over the language of the war: ''Surge,'' meet ''escalation.''

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 17 - 23; TELEVISION
summary: It just wouldn't be the holiday season without a television movie about someone who discovers the true meaning of love and family at Christmastime. This week's prime example, ''A PERFECT DAY'' (Monday, 8 p.m., TNT), stars ROB LOWE as an author who gets all carried away with himself when his first novel is a megasuccess. PAGET BREWSTER (she was Hank Azaria's wife on ''Huff'') plays his flawlessly supportive, long-suffering wife. FRANCES CONROY (from ''Six Feet Under'') is the flawlessly supportive agent whom most writers would kill to have. Needless to say, the denouement takes place in a churchyard as a light snow falls. Over on CBS, the focus is on real-life happy endings. On the eighth annual special ''A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS'' (Friday at 8 p.m.), this one with Rod Stewart's name appended to the title as host, a batch of celebrities (among them VIRGINIA MADSEN and CEDRIC THE ENTERTAINER) talk about the joys of foster care and adoption. Real families make appearances to share their happy situations. Mr. Stewart, JOHN LEGEND, KATHARINE McPHEE and other musicians perform. ''IDENTITY,'' NBC's new prime-time game show, could be much worse. At least when contestants face a dozen total strangers on this series, they're trying to guess more than how much money is in their briefcases. They're trying to match the 12 people with 12 traits (occupation, I.Q., sleeping habits, net worth and the like), and each right answer is one step closer to the $500,000 grand prize. Contestants will be called on to use perception and judgment. What a concept -- and shades of ''To Tell the Truth,'' back in the golden age of game shows! The network is showing ''Identity'' five nights in a row, beginning on Monday at 9. The celebrity host is PENN JILLETTE of the comedy-magic team Penn and Teller. (Yes, Mr. Jillette is the one who talks.)

headline: TONIGHT'S TV LISTINGS: What's on Friday Night
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER The all-too-real story of Adrienne Shelly, the 40-year-old actress and director who was founding hanging in her Greenwich Village office in November, gets ripped from the headlines in this episode, in which Detectives Green and Cassady try to prove that her death is anything but self-inflicted. Reza Salazar plays the workman who is eventually charged with her death. 7:40 P.M. (IFC) MY SON THE FANATIC (1998). Om Puri, Rachel Griffiths and Stellan Skarsgard star in this poignant, pre-9/11 drama about a Pakistani cabbie in an industrial town in northern England who finds himself falling in love with a young white prostitute at the same time his son is becoming a Muslim fundamentalist. The screenplay was written by Hanif Kureishi of ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' fame, who adapted it from one of his own short stories published in The New Yorker in 1994.

headline: With Imus, They Keep Coming Back
summary: ''Imus in the Morning'' is scheduled to start this morning like any other, with Don Imus and his crew cracking wise about the weekend's events, riffing off the news and chatting with Evan Thomas, one of Newsweek's top guns. Later Tom Oliphant, Washington author and former op-ed columnist for The Boston Globe, will check in for some political talk. Given that Mr. Imus spent part of last week describing the student athletes at Rutgers as ''nappy-headed ho's,'' you might think he'd have trouble booking anyone, let alone A-list establishment names. But Mr. Imus, who has been given a pass for this sort of comment in the past, also generously provides airtime to those parts of the news media and political apparatus that would generally be expected to bring him to account.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: CRUCIAL TIME FOR AUTOMAKERS -- The seconds are counting down in a high-pressure match of speed chess between Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, and Rick Wagoner, who runs General Motors, as the two weigh an alliance. [C1.] USE OF BACKDATED OPTIONS -- More than 2,000 companies have used backdated stock options to sweeten the pay packages of their chief executives, according to a new study that suggests the practice is far more widespread than previously disclosed. [C1.] AIRBUS'S NEW PLANE -- Airbus, desperate to pull out of the worst dive in its commercial history, plans to disclose details of a radically redesigned midsize plane -- a $10 billion project that will compete with Boeing's 787, executives said. [C1.] GOOGLE'S PAYMENT OPTION -- Late last month, Google Inc. introduced Google Checkout, which stores a user's financial information and shuttles it through checkout at retail sites. The program is still being tested, but the roster of participating merchants is growing. One of them, Fred H. Lerner, above, chief executive of Ritz Interactive, which operates the online photography store RitzCamera.com, said consumer reaction to Checkout had been good, thanks partly to a $10 rebate offer. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C8.] A NEWSPAPER'S INTERNAL BATTLE Wendy McCaw, the reclusive multimillionaire owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press, is at war with her own staff. What started as a conflict over journalistic ethics has in the past week escalated into a full-blown rebellion. [C1.] SHEDDING TRADITIONAL PHONES Alltel plans to announce that it is getting out of the traditional phone business by completing the spinoff of its local phone unit and merging it with Valor Communications. [C9.] ADS FOR BREAKFAST In September, CBS plans to start using a new place to advertise its fall lineup: your breakfast. The network plans to announce that it will place laser imprints of its trademark eye insignia, as well as logos for some of its shows, on eggs -- 35 million of them. Advertising. [C9.] CHANGES AT CBS NEWS When Katie Couric takes over on the CBS Evening News, the network is planning widespread changes, including fanning the newscast out across different media, including radio and the Web. [C4.] NEW WAY TO READ OBJECTS -- Hewlett-Packard researchers are set to introduce a wireless technology that they say enables a hand-held electronic reader to impart information about almost any physical object. [C8.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; Dan Rather's New Job
summary: Dan Rather, who said on the eve of his rocky departure from CBS News last month that he was leaning toward joining a high-definition television channel called HDNet, has formally agreed to do just that, the channel's co-founder Mark Cuban said in a telephone interview yesterday. Mr. Rather, 74, will serve as host of a one-hour weekly news program, ''Dan Rather Presents,'' beginning in October, said Mr. Cuban, who is perhaps best known as owner of the Dallas Mavericks. Initially, the program will be mostly interviews, but Mr. Cuban said he hoped Mr. Rather would eventually pursue investigative reports in the vein of ''60 Minutes.'' Mr. Cuban said he was eager to draw on Mr. Rather's 44 years of experience at CBS News, and was confident that he could contribute much to HDNet, a premium service to which, he said, nearly four million viewers subscribe. ''The part I like the best is he's got something to prove,'' Mr. Cuban said. ''There's no better person to have on your side than someone with experience, access and on a mission to prove certain people wrong.'' JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (BBC America) CLATTERFORD They're back, but you'll never recognize them. Jennifer Saunders (left), the fabulously neurotic Edina in ''Absolutely Fabulous,'' reportedly drew on her experiences living in Devon, England, to write and star in this new comedy series about life in a small English town. Ms. Saunders plays Caroline, a very busy lady of the manor whose leisure pursuits include her women's club, horseback riding and spending evenings with her neighbor Madonna. Joanna Lumley -- who played the fabulously vain Patsy in ''Ab Fab'' -- lets it all go as the decades-older Delilah, an outspoken eccentric who rides around town on a bike with training wheels. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) LAST TRAIN FROM GUN HILL (1959). When the wife of Marshal Matt Morgan (Kirk Douglas) is raped and murdered in this western from John Sturges, a saddle is left behind. Morgan recognizes it as belonging to his old friend Craig Belden (Anthony Quinn), now a cattle baron. Belden is sympathetic until he finds out his son is one of the murderers. And he'd rather kill Morgan than hand over his son. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS In the show's season finale, Mike discovers that Sam has been kidnapped by one of her whales, Danny takes drastic measures to keep a friend from being deployed to Iraq and Delinda learns that her life with Danny is about to change. 9 P.M. (Sundance) LADETTE TO LADY The three remaining ladettes practice their curtsies before coming out at a debutante ball. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Leslie H., who was born with a congenital heart defect, gets gussied up for her role as a spokeswoman for the American Heart Association. 9:30 P.M. (CMT) KARAOKE DOKEY In this new halfhour show, four contestants compete to best impersonate a country legend before a live audience and a panel of judges. First up: the songs of Dolly Parton (right). No word on whether wearing the get-up is one of the requirements. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS Charlie tries to connect a series of murders to a voter-fraud conspiracy and figure out who benefits from the rigged elections before more people die. 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) COMEDY CENTRAL PRESENTS Chelsea Handler, the youngest of six children, was born in Livingston, N.J., to a Jewish father and a Mormon mother. It's good fodder for stand-up, she says, which she performs here. Deon Cole takes the stage at 10:30. 11 P.M. (Showtime) DEBBIE DOES DALLAS AGAIN Restricted viewing: This new reality series goes in search of a star from among the stable of vixens -- including Stefani Morgan, Monique Alexander, Sunny Leone, Cassidey and the actress and winemaker Savanna Samson (above, drinking a glass of her Sogno Uno blend) --at the Vivid adultentertainment company. The winner will appear in a sequel to the classic (at least in some circles) ''Debbie Does Dallas.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Jets (4-3) at Cleveland (1-5) 4:15 p.m., CBS JETS' DEFENSE vs. BROWNS' OFFENSIVE COORDINATOR Jeff Davidson was pursued by the Jets during the off-season for their vacant offensive coordinator's position, which was eventually filled by Brian Schottenheimer. Davidson was able to parlay the Jets' interest into a new title with the Browns, assistant head coach, even though he continued to work with the offensive line. He was promoted to offensive coordinator last week after Maurice Carthon was forced to step down. Since this is Davidson's first game as the architect of the offense, the Jets have no idea what to expect. CENTER NICK MANGOLD vs. NOSE TACKLE TED WASHINGTON Mangold, a 300-pound rookie, will give up some 60 pounds and 15 years of N.F.L. experience to Washington, below, a very effective run stopper. Washington has not recorded a sack in the past one-plus seasons, but he has 24 tackles in six games. ''It's going to be a long 60 minutes,'' said Mangold, who has incurred only one 5-yard penalty. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC World News Not Just for Tonight
summary: Now that ABC's flagship evening news broadcast -- like those of NBC and CBS -- has a regular presence on the Internet, the network said yesterday that it would edit the program's name to better reflect its ubiquity. It will henceforth be known as ''World News With Charles Gibson,'' as opposed to ''World News Tonight,'' the program's name since July 1978, when it made its debut with Frank Reynolds, Peter Jennings and Max Robinson sharing anchor duties. Mr. Gibson, right, who was named the program's sole anchor in May after the brief pairing of Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff, was covering the Middle East conflict from Cyprus yesterday but took a break to appear, via satellite, at a gathering in Pasadena, Calif., of critics and reporters who cover television. Mr. Gibson said he was looking forward to pitting his broadcast against those of Brian Williams of NBC and Katie Couric of CBS this fall. He also acknowledged that for all the traveling he had done as a reporter and anchor over the years, he had a moment of forgetfulness yesterday: after leaving Israel for Cyprus, he realized that he had left his passport behind. ''I suspect Peter never did that -- forget his passport,'' Mr. Gibson said. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing With the Stars': Still the Favored Pastime
summary: Two new series made their debuts on Tuesday to middling ratings, but the final round of ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' from 8 to 9:30 p.m., drew a season high of 26.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The dance-off between Emmitt Smith and Mario Lopez, right, put ABC on top for the night even as the network's ratings dropped off considerably at 9:30 for the debut of ''Show Me the Money.'' That new game show, with William Shatner as host, averaged 12.5 million viewers from 9:30 to 11, losing more than 6 million viewers from its first half-hour to its last. Meanwhile, ''3 Lbs,'' CBS's new medical drama about two neurosurgeons, played by Stanley Tucci and Mark Feuerstein, had its premiere at 10 in third place, with 9.8 million viewers. Neither new series could knock NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' from its perch as the No. 1 show at 10 (14.7 million). Fox ranked second for the night among adults 18 to 49, although fourth in total viewers, aided by ''House'' at 9 (14.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Jets (4-4) at New England (6-2) 1 p.m., CBS LEON WASHINGTON vs. PATRIOTS' FRONT SEVEN The Jets and Leon Washington, below, will not be able to take advantage of the absence of the two-time Pro Bowl safety Rodney Harrison if they cannot win the battle at the line. The Patriots sacked Chad Pennington four times when the teams met in Week 2, with nose tackle Vince Wilfork collecting one sack and defensive end Richard Seymour receiving credit for one and a half. In the Patriots' loss last week to the Indianapolis Colts, outside linebacker Rosevelt Colvin was in Peyton Manning's face all game. He was credited with seven pressures. JETS' RUSHING DEFENSE vs. COREY DILLON and LAURENCE MARONEY Corey Dillon had his best rushing game of the season when the teams played in Week 2, gaining 80 yards on 20 carries. He has not carried the ball more than 15 times in any of the past four games, ceding the backfield, however grudgingly, to Laurence Maroney, a rookie who rushed for 125 yards against the Cincinnati Bengals. The Jets rank 30th out of 32 teams against the run. ''It's insulting when you can't stop the run and they know they're going to run on you,'' Jets linebacker Matt Chatham said. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)

headline: Arts, Briefly; Old 'Deal' Profits NBC
summary: CBS was No. 1 among total viewers on Wednesday night, but for the second night in a row a ''Deal or No Deal'' rerun on NBC was the most-watched show of the evening, with 10.21 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. That show, combined with ''Dateline'' at 8 p.m. (8.2 million) and a ''Law & Order'' repeat at 10 p.m. (8.27 million), boosted NBC into first place among adults 18 to 49. Fox was No. 2 in that age group, as its ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (8.63 million) dance-off helped push it past CBS in that demographic. CBS's new show ''Gameshow Marathon'' (8.37 million) made its debut at 8 p.m. and was followed by reruns of ''Criminal Minds'' (9.95 million) and ''CSI: New York'' (9.76 million). On ABC an original episode of the canceled ''Commander in Chief,'' once the most-watched new show of last season, drew only 5.37 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: REDSTONE FAMILY DRAMA A rift between the media billionaire Sumner M. Redstone and his daughter Shari, whom he had previously portrayed as his successor, has called into question who will eventually inherit ultimate control of the CBS and Viacom empires. A SELL-OFF ON GOOGLE SHARES Google reported another quarter of rapid revenue growth on the strength of its core Internet search and advertising business, but expenses grew faster than investors anticipated, profits fell short of analysts' expectations and shares dropped 7 percent in after-hours trading. [C1.]
