headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Leaves 'Lost' In Its Dust
summary: Elliott Yamin, below, got the short straw on ''American Idol,'' leaving the enthusiastic Taylor Hicks and the theatrical Katharine McPhee to compete in next week's final. The talent show delivered 27.12 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, giving Fox an easy win for the night. At 10 p.m., on NBC's ''Law & Order'' (13.49 million), the lawyer Alex Borgia (Annie Parisse) met a violent death. The franchise's creator, Dick Wolf, announced recently that he would be retooling the veteran series, which has flagged this season; thus poor Alex's demise. The show beat CBS's ''CSI: New York'' season finale (12.82 million) in viewers and in adults 18 to 49 for the first time since September and helped NBC slip by CBS for the night for the second-place slot. Elsewhere, ABC's ''Lost'' (14.2 million) filled in the events that turned Michael (Harold Perrineau) into a murderer. ''Lost'' squared off against a full hour of the ''Idol'' results show, and its ratings suffered, hitting a season low for an original episode. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Good Riddance to ABC Team
summary: To the Sports Editor: Re ''Faldo and Azinger Talk a Good Game'' (July 25): In stark contrast to lamenting the loss of the ABC Sports golf coverage team, I feel an enormous sense of relief.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 12 - 18; TELEVISION
summary: The broadcast networks come bearing November-sweeps presents this week. On NBC Patricia Arquette fans -- or is it really the Jake Weber fans who keep this show afloat? -- get the delayed return of ''MEDIUM'' (Wednesday, 9 p.m.). CBS offers the premiere of ''3 LBS.,'' with Stanley Tucci as a tetchy brain surgeon (Tuesday, 10 p.m.); the obvious comparison is to ''House,'' but the first episode hedges its bets by undercutting the wounded-genius solemnity with some ''Grey's Anatomy'' shamelessness. And ABC trots out its temporary replacement for ''Lost'': the new Taye Diggs vehicle, ''DAY BREAK'' (Wednesday, 9 p.m.), a k a ''Law & Order: Groundhog Day,'' in which Mr. Diggs's framed-for-murder cop keeps reliving the same very bad day. The sci-fi gimmick looks like an attempt to get the feel of ''24'' without resorting to that show's baroque plot twists, or to the endless flashbacks of ''The Nine''; time will tell. Cable has a kinder, gentler sweeps gift: the ''MONK'' holiday special (USA, Friday, 9 p.m.), a typically shaggy and sentimental mystery that introduces Dan Hedaya as Monk's father. On PBS, where the sweeps ratings don't matter, the most interesting show of the week (not counting the much-talked-about-already finale of ''Prime Suspect'') may be one decidedly lacking in comfort and joy: the ''FRONTLINE'' installment ''A Hidden Life,'' which examines the sad, strange case of James West, the former Republican mayor of Spokane, Wash. (Tuesday night on most PBS stations; check local listings). No one comes off very well in this retelling, including the editors and reporters at the local newspaper who outed Mr. West in the process of printing accusations that he had abused young men. In outlining his personal and political implosion, the documentary, almost despite itself, ends up casting its protagonist as his own greatest victim. But the creepily bland Mr. West, interviewed for the program several times before his death from cancer in July, does nothing to earn that mantle.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: New York Film Critics Honor 'United 93' The British director Paul Greengrass's ''United 93'' (with Becky London and Tom O'Rourke, above), the first Hollywood feature film to deal with 9/11, was named the year's best film yesterday by the New York Film Critics Circle. But Mr. Greengrass's account of the downing of the fourth and final plane hijacked by Islamist terrorists on 9/11 did not win the award for best director, which went to Martin Scorsese for ''The Departed,'' starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon and Jack Nicholson in a tale of cops, gangsters, power and loyalty. Helen Mirren was chosen best actress for her portrayal of Queen Elizabeth II in ''The Queen,'' and Forest Whitaker was named best actor for his depiction of the despot Idi Amin in ''The Last King of Scotland.'' The prize for best foreign film went to a 1969 French film unseen in the United States until this year: Jean-Pierre Melville's ''Army of Shadows,'' about heroism and horror in the French resistance during the Nazi occupation in World War II. Jennifer Hudson was named best supporting actress for ''Dreamgirls,'' and Jackie Earle Haley was chosen best supporting actor for ''Little Children.'' Peter Morgan was cited for his screenplay for ''The Queen.'' George Miller's ''Happy Feet,'' the dancing penguin movie, was chosen best animated film, and Amy Berg's ''Deliver Us From Evil,'' a documentary about the sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church, was named best nonfiction film. Founded in 1935, the New York Film Critics Circle, including critics from daily and weekly newspapers and magazines, will present its awards on Jan. 7 at the Supper Club in Manhattan. On Sunday, Clint Eastwood's ''Letters From Iwo Jima,'' the companion film to his ''Flags of Our Fathers,'' about the battle for Iwo Jima, was named the year's best film by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, The Associated Press reported. Prince to Sing at Super Bowl Prince, a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, will follow in the footsteps of the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney and Janet Jackson when he headlines the halftime show at the Super Bowl on Miami on Feb. 4, The Associated Press reported. The Super Bowl, to be televised by CBS, is annually television's highest-rated attraction. An estimated 141 million people watched last year's game, in which Pittsburgh beat Seattle 21 to 10.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Sweet Sweeps
summary: As sweeps continued, ABC beat all the other networks on Sunday, its strongest night of the week. ABC won every half-hour in Nielsen's estimates for the 18-to-49 demographic, beginning with ''America's Funniest Home Videos.'' In the 18-to-49 age group, ''Videos'' (8.25 million) defeated CBS's ''60 Minutes'' (11.37 million) during the 7 p.m. slot. The next hour had the same demographic split: ''Cold Case'' on CBS drew the largest audience, with 14.41 million, but ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (12.17 million) beat the crime series among adults 18 to 49. ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' (21.16 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (21.73 million) had clean victories, and were the most-watched shows of the night. ''Grey's Anatomy'' topped all of its competition, including ''Housewives,'' among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: FORD SEES A FUTURE -- Ford Motor Company executives said that a smaller loss in the first quarter was proof that their corporate overhaul was working. [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR A BIG HIT -- Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old as an investment bank, but can it deliver the headline-grabbing, blockbuster mergers that made a name for its founder, Joseph R. Perella? [C1.] SOLD ON EBAY, SHIPPED VIA AMAZON -- Amazon.com is expanding a program that allows independent sellers -- even vendors who sell through Amazon's e-commerce rival, eBay -- to use its network of distribution centers to store and ship their products. [C1.] A NEW KIND OF BUYOUT -- An $8 billion bid by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs for Harman International Industries, the maker of JBL speakers, has a potentially groundbreaking twist: The buyers have offered Harman shareholders a chance to retain a stake in the company, and share in any profit made if the company is later sold or taken public again. [C1.] STRONG QUARTER FOR MICROSOFT -- Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profits that surpassed Wall Street's expectations, suggesting that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start. [C3.] RISING PROFIT AT EXXON MOBIL -- Exxon Mobil reported another surge in profits for the first quarter of the year because of stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses. The results -- Exxon said they were its best ever for any first quarter -- were particularly noteworthy given the mixed earnings picture reported in recent days by other large oil companies. [C4.] BETTER CHANCES FOR TRADE BILL -- Prospects have suddenly improved for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation in Congress, thanks in part to a talk between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. [C3.] BRISTOL CHOOSES INTERIM CHIEF -- After an eight-month search for a new chief executive, the drug maker Bristol-Myers said it would go with the interim chief, James M. Cornelius. [C2.] PUBLIC CONCERNED OVER WARMING -- Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. [A20.] EMI'S NORTH AMERICAN UNIT -- EMI Group, the struggling British music giant, has hired the longtime industry executive Roger Ames, a former chairman of Warner Music Group, to revive its North American operation. The appointment of Mr. Ames, left, comes more than three months after a management shake-up in which EMI ousted the two senior executives overseeing its recorded music operation. [C7.] A MODEL OF CONSISTENCY, ONCE -- For 25 years, Absolut vodka ran a humorous campaign celebrating its distinctive bottle, and became renowned for the consistency of its pitches to consumers. Now the brand is changing advertising approaches for the second time in 15 months. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MORE SUSPECTED BRIBES AT SIEMENS -- A day after the chief executive of Siemens announced he would step down, the company warned that it expected to report a ''significant increase'' in the number of possible bribes identified in an internal investigation. [C7.] MYSPACE.COM HEADING TO CHINA -- Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is taking MySpace.com to China, a latecomer to China's crowded field of online social networking sites that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up. [C7.] CANADIAN RULES ON EMISSIONS -- Canadian industries must cut the rate at which they produce gases linked to global warming by 18 percent over the next three years, the federal government said. [C7.] PROFIT NEWS HAS LITTLE IMPACT -- Stocks ended mixed as strong profit reports from companies like Apple Inc. and 3M failed to galvanize Wall Street. Still, a modest advance gave the Dow Jones industrial average another record close. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The US Airways Group reported that profit edged up 2 percent in the first quarter on modest revenue growth, and repeated its forecast for a profitable year. (AP) The health insurer Aetna reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profits, pointing to membership growth as proof that consumer marketing applied to health insurance is working. (AP) The 3M Company, considered a bellwether for the economy, posted a far better-than-expected quarterly profit, sending its shares up. (REUTERS) Coca-Cola Enterprises reported a 6 percent decline in earnings but beat Wall Street estimates, helped by the introduction of Coke Zero in Europe and raw material costs that rose less than expected. (REUTERS) The Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, reported a drop in quarterly profit and revenue because of decreasing sales of classified and other advertising. (REUTERS)

headline: Anheuser-Busch Wraps Deals To Sponsor Next 6 Super Bowls
summary: Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis has completed agreements to be the exclusive sponsor in the beer category for the next six Super Bowls. The company, the exclusive beer sponsor for the Super Bowl since 1989, will announce today that it has made a deal with NBC for the games in 2009 and 2012.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (USA) NASHVILLE STAR -- Jewel and Cowboy Trent (right) are hosts of the fifth season of this competition series in which the grand prize is a recording contractwith Warner Music Group. Among the 10 contestants, chosen from 20,000 aspiring country musicians, are Angela and Zac Hacker, sibling competitors. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Whodunit? Everyone has a theory when Earl learns that some stolen treasure is no longer where he buried it. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- Just as Danny musters the strength to pop the question to Sofia, Betty discovers evidence that casts doubt on her intentions. Meanwhile, a kinder, gentler Wilhelmina emerges at the hands of her Texas beau. Did we mention he's rich? 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Tit for tat: Tori Spelling plays a gossip columnist who spills the beans when Lana confesses to Chloe that she has reservations about marrying Lex. Lois suspects that Oliver is the Green Arrow. 9 P.M. (IFC) IN THE BEDROOM -- (2001). No parent can be sure of what they would do. In Todd Field's wrenching drama Sissy Spacek (left) and Tom Wilkinson play a small-town New England couple who deal with the murder of their college-age son in an unexpected way. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- George's father has surgery for his cancer, Meredith's father arrives to see his new granddaughter. And why can't Derek sleep? 9 P.M. (Discovery Health) THE DAN HO SHOW -- What if you're 60 and single for the first time in, say, 35 years? Mr. Ho offers up stress-free tips for dating in middle age, from what to wear to where to meet people. Helpful hint No. 1: embrace your inner style. At 9:30, in an episode intended for a slightly younger generation, Mr. Ho discusses making a good first impression on your date's parents. 9 P.M. (G4) G4 PRESENTS CES 2007 -- Attention, wireheads: G4 looks at the latest products from the Consumer Electronics Show. 9:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK -- What kind of title is that? Jenna anxiously awaits the release of her independent film ''The Rural Juror.'' Meanwhile, Tracy creates his own celebrity product to endorse and dig his way out of debt. 10 P.M. (ABC) MEN IN TREES -- When Jack admits he is falling in love with Marin (Anne Heche), she can't wait for his ex-girlfriend (Justine Bateman, far right, with Ms. Heche) to get out of town. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- It doesn't get much better than this: Mr. Letterman talks with Julianne Moore. 11:35 (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Or this: Mr. Leno talks with Helen Mirren. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: MORE ON VIACOM
summary: THE LION IN WINTER -- Sumner M. Redstone, at age 83 and a billionaire several times over, had retreated from the chief executive's role at Viacom after its split at the beginning of this year from the CBS Corporation. But it was short-lived. Two weeks ago, Mr. Redstone roiled Hollywood by declaring that Viacom's Paramount movie studio would not be renewing its longstanding relationship with Tom Cruise because the actor's off-screen behavior had, in Mr. Redstone's view, damaged his box-office returns. Yesterday, Mr. Redstone abruptly replaced Thomas E. Freston as Viacom's chief executive, sending another blaring signal to the media world and Wall Street that he does not intend to fade away. PAGE C5 WORRIES AT PARAMOUNT -- For many here, Mr. Redstone's move yesterday signaled renewed instability at Paramount, which seemed only recently to have gained its footing. It also fueled speculation in Hollywood about the fate of Brad Grey, who was hired by Mr. Freston last year. But Mr. Redstone batted down suggestions yesterday that Mr. Gray would be leaving any time soon. PAGE C5

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fox Rides 'House' to a Win
summary: Kicking off its third season, Fox's medical drama ''House'' clobbered the competition on Tuesday night, with 19.41 million viewers, lifting the network to the top for the night over all. ''House,'' starring Hugh Laurie, right, made its debut an hour earlier than its regular 9 p.m. time slot, yet among adults 18 to 49, it increased its audience by 20 percent over last season's premiere. A new series, ''Standoff,'' about a romance between two F.B.I. hostage negotiators, benefited from the ''House'' lead-in and handily bested its competitors, although it garnered an unimpressive 66 percent retention of adults 18 to 49. Despite the Fox onslaught, new episodes of two CBS reality shows fared relatively well: ''Big Brother'' drew 9 million and ''Rock Star: Supernova'' 7.63 million. NBC and ABC brought up the rear with repeats, though NBC won 10 p.m. with the fan favorite ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.7 million). The newcomer MyNetworkTV also began its two telenovelas, ''Desire'' and ''Fashion House,'' which both attracted meager audiences. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: New Marathon Viewing Spot: Your Computer
summary: If you watch the New York City Marathon, the only runners among the 37,000 you are guaranteed to see on television are the elite ones. Finding a friend or relative racing along the 26.2-mile route would be purely coincidental. But Sunday's race offers a chance for online users to pay $4.99 to see five runners at three locations: the Pulaski Bridge, which connects Greenpoint to Long Island City, at the 13-mile mark; 110th Street and First Avenue in East Harlem, which is about 19 miles into the race; and the finish line.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Both Sides See Benefit In Attacking Rumsfeld With Election Day approaching, many Democrats are seeking political gain by attacking Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. And a small but growing number of Republicans are doing the same. WASHINGTON MEMO, PAGE A16 Big Oil Discovery in the Gulf Oil fields found in the Gulf of Mexico may hold 3 billion to 15 billion barrels of oil, possibly the largest find in a generation. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C7 Japan Has a New Male Heir Princess Kiko gave birth to a boy today, securing the succession of Japan's imperial throne for another generation. PAGE A3 Artificial Heart Is Approved The Food and Drug Administration gave limited approval to a Massachusetts company to sell a fully implantable artificial heart. PAGE A15 Katie Couric's First Day Katie Couric showed a commitment to foreign news in her debut as anchor of ''The CBS Evening News.'' THE TV WATCH, PAGE A15 This Tastes Familiar The New York world of restaurants, following a Broadway staple for success, is turning to revivals, with some twists. DINING, PAGE F1

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) GREASE: YOU'RE THE ONE THAT I WANT -- Then again, now that I've watched you sing and dance, maybe you're not. The Tony Award-winning choreographer Kathleen Marshall, the writer Jim Jacobs, who co-created ''Grease,'' and David Ian, a theater producer, are judges for this new competition series that follows the search for a man and a woman to play the lead roles in a Broadway production of ''Grease.'' Olivia Newton-John, who played Sandy opposite John Travolta's Danny in the 1978 film, weighs in on what it takes to fill their shoes in the first two episodes, which follow casting calls around the country. But it hardly matters what the pros think. Ultimately it's viewers who decide. 4 P.M. (NBC) LATIN ON ICE -- Brian Boitano, Rudy Galindo, Michael Weiss, Caryn Kadavy and others kick up some steam as they skate to music from Marco Antonio Solís at the Hard Rock Casino in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 7:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) JUST JORDAN -- Lil' JJ, a 16-year-old comedian, vents his teenage angst in this new series, based on his standup routine, about a ninth-grader trying to get a life after being transplanted to Los Angeles. Tonight he goes out for the varsity basketball team at his new school. 7:30 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SNY PLAYOFF BLITZ -- The former Jets quarterback Ray Lucas and the former Giants linebacker Carl Banks offer analysis of the Jets (1 p.m. on CBS) and Giants (4:30 on Fox) games. 9:30 P.M. (NBC) THE APPRENTICE: LOS ANGELES -- Carolyn Kepcher and George Ross have been replaced by Ivanka Trump and Donald Trump Jr. And their father, Donald Trump (right), seems to have dyed his tresses to match this season's sunny locale. Even the premise is slightly different: 18 candidates will compete for a job with the Trump organization. Only the winning team will get to live in a mansion for the week, while the losers will sleep in tents and use outdoor facilities. Now that's what we call incentive. 10 P.M. (MTV) I'M FROM ROLLING STONE -- Deadlines. Criticism. Nerves (make that a double). In this new reality series, six aspiring journalists fight for a job with Rolling Stone magazine and the dream of seeing their names in print. 10 P.M. (Showtime) THE L WORD -- Marlee Matlin (left) joins the series's fourth season as an artist who captures Bette's eye; Cybill Shepherd signs on as a married woman who has kept her sexuality under wraps -- and then decides to reveal it with a vengeance. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT -- Vivian Smallwood, a k a Rappin' Granny (right), and the eight other most gifted acts in the country, as judged by viewers and the show's celebrity panel -- Brandy, Piers Morgan and David Hasselhoff -- make their cases for winning $1 million in tomorrow night's finale. 5 P.M. (9) THE TYRA BANKS SHOW -- Ms. Banks uses the tough love she lavished on would-be top models to help parents tell their adult children it's time to pack their bags. Amerie performs. 7:30 (BET) ACCESS GRANTED -- Backstage with Marques Houston during the filming of the video for his single ''Favorite Girl.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Tommy Lee and his motley crew lower the axe on one of the week's worst three rockers-in-training. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) LOVE LETTERS (1945). A soldier writes them for a friend, the friend gets the girl -- and gets murdered -- and then the soldier gets the girl. Jennifer Jones at her moody best. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) PYTHON VS. GATOR -- Last fall, when a Burmese python tried to swallow a six-foot alligator in the Everglades, neither lived to, er, tell the tale. This ''Explorer'' episode takes up when their ill-fated encounter (above) left off, and examines how the appetites of these snakes, usually pets abandoned by their owners, are upsetting the region's food chain. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- The four remaining dancers have to cool their heels as the winner is revealed tonight. 8 P.M. (Sundance) MICKYBO AND ME (2004). After watching ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' two young boys in Belfast, Northern Ireland, decide to become outlaws and run away to Australia. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- Mr. Angel plays dead in front of a team of medical professionals. Pulse? What pulse? 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS -- A Type-A man, trying to chill out, turns to New Age methods for a month. Thirty days. Four weeks and two days. Seven-hundred and twenty hours. 10 P.M. (BBC America) BUMP 'N' GRIND -- The ''posh camp'' dancers go classy while the ''booty camp'' dancers get trashy. 10 P.M. (MTV) LAGUNA BEACH: THE REAL ORANGE COUNTY -- All that angst! A new season of teenagers make waves. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Mr. Letterman sits pretty with Jessica Biel (right) and Christina Aguilera. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Karin Papes, Cyril Cabral Jr.
summary: Karin Marie Papes and Cyril Cabral Jr. were married yesterday at the Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Mark Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cabral, 42, teaches English and government to immigrant students at White Plains High School, and she trains other teachers to work with recent immigrants. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in professional studies from Manhattanville College.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Basketball and Wrestling Compete for Viewers
summary: CBS won the concluding Friday of the official television season in Nielsen's estimates. Its season finale of ''Numbers'' (12.49 million) was the night's most-watched show. Another returning CBS crime show, ''Close to Home'' (9.64 million), also ended its season. For the week that ended on May 14, USA Network's ''WWE Monday Night Raw'' topped the list of the most-watched shows on basic cable, with 5.42 million viewers. But TNT's playoff basketball coverage put that channel in first place in prime time overall among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. In that age group, wrestling and basketball, also on ESPN, occupied 8 of the top 10 slots for the week. The two entertainment shows that nudged their way in were the May 9 ''Real World'' (1.83 million 18-to-49-year-olds) on MTV and the Discovery Channel's ''Deadliest Catch'' (1.61 million 18-to-49-year-olds), also on May 9. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Couric Expected to Announce Her Departure From 'Today'
summary: Katie Couric will announce her decision leave NBC's Today'' show, the program she has led to morning news dominance for the past 10 years, at 7:30 this morning during the broadcast of ''Today,'' a prelude to a formal announcement by CBS that she will join that network as its new evening news anchor. Her announcement, on the 15th anniversary of her first broadcast on ''Today,'' will bring to an end one of the most closely followed talent courtships in recent network history. CBS has sought to secure Ms. Couric's services for well over a year, and NBC made several efforts to keep her at ''Today,'' its most profitable program.

headline: Ilyssa Goldfarb, Stephen Karasik
summary: Ilyssa Goldfarb, a daughter of Ellen and Morton Goldfarb of Whitestone, Queens, was married last evening to Stephen Karasik, the son of Irene and Robert Karasik of Manhattan. Rabbi Jeffrey Saxe officiated at the Woodmere Club, a country club in Woodmere, N.Y.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Democrats Weigh Answer To Veto of War Funding Bill The Senate sent President Bush a war spending measure he has promised to veto, forcing Democrats to confront the question of what to do after the president acts. A1 Russia to Suspend Arms Treaty Russia's president said his country would stop complying with a treaty on conventional arms in Europe that was forged at the end of the cold war, underscoring the Kremlin's anger at an American proposal for a missile defense system in Europe. A1 French Rivals Exchange Barbs The Socialist candidate in the French presidential election accused her opponent of having ''apologized'' to President Bush for France's decision not to take part in the Iraq war. A10 Both candidates are members of unconventional couples. The Socialist candidate is not married to the father of her four children, and the conservative candidate and his wife are often apart. A1 Serious Charge for Ranking G.I. The American military has charged a top commander at Camp Cropper near Baghdad with violations of military law, including ''aiding the enemy,'' a serious accusation that could carry a death sentence. A16 World Bank Team Complains Members of the World Bank's anti-corruption team said the controversy over Paul Wolfowitz's conduct was undermining their work. A6 Afghanistan Infant Deaths Drop Health officials said that Afghan infant mortality has dropped by 18 percent. A12 NATIONAL A18-25 Dean at M.I.T. Resigns After Lying on Résumé The dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Marilee Jones, who became famous for urging stressed-out students competing for elite colleges to calm down and stop trying to be perfect, has resigned after admitting that she had fabricated her own educational credentials. A1 Concerns Over Warming Issues Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds. A20 Bush Criticized by Candidates The eight Democratic presidential candidates used their first joint appearance to assail President Bush for threatening to veto legislation that would set a deadline for bringing troops out of Iraq. A24 New Bill on Buying Guns The Justice Department proposed legislation that would give the attorney general discretion to bar terrorism suspects from buying a firearm, seeking to close a controversial gap in federal gun laws. A18 SCIENCE/HEALTH Genes Linked to Diabetes Researchers said they had identified seven new genes connected to the most common form of diabetes, the latest result of an intensifying race to find genes linked to a range of diseases. A22 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Slain Trooper Took Part In Another Deadly Manhunt David C. Brinkerhoff, the New York State trooper who was fatally shot by a fugitive this week, spent days tracking Ralph J. Phillips, another fugitive who had shot and killed a trooper, before Mr. Phillips was captured last September. B1 Bloomberg Proposes Budget Mayor Bloomberg proposed a $59 billion budget that maintains tax cuts he promised earlier this year and includes a record-setting $4.4 billion surplus. B1 Sincerely, George Washington A letter written by George Washington in May or July of 1787 was recently discovered in a brown leather scrapbook started by a young New Jersey girl in 1826. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Losses Shrink at Ford Ford Motor announced a $282 million loss in the first quarter. Company officials said the loss, much smaller than last year's, was proof that a restructuring plan was working. C1 Investors Get Into the Deal The $8 billion private equity buyout of Harman International Industries, the maker of speakers and home theater systems, breaks new ground by offering shareholders a chance to share in profits made if the company is sold or taken public again. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES C10-11 Jack Valenti A confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and a Hollywood institution, he was 85. C10 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: After the lawyers; crippling government from within; Corporal Tillman haunts the Pentagon; Dorothy Samuels on the new abortion ruling and the Roberts court. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Paul Krugman. Crossword E5 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E24 Weather B7

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in The Arts on Thursday about plans for the fall television season misstated the time ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' will be shown on CBS on Monday nights. It is 9:30, not 9.

headline: What's on Friday Night
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) 8TH ANNUAL A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS WITH ROD STEWART Adoption awareness is at the heart of this yearly special, which features stories of adoptive families as well as the more than half a million foster children in the United States still awaiting permanent homes. Mr. Stewart, the show's host, sings ''Have You Ever Seen the Rain,'' ''I'll Stand by You'' and ''It's a Heartache.'' John Legend, Katharine McPhee, Five for Fighting and Mary Mary also perform. Cedric the Entertainer, Miley Cyrus, Laura Dern, Angie Harmon, Melina Kanakaredes and Jeri Ryan present inspirational stories about adoption, while tissues make the rounds in the studio audience, the better to dry tears. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER (1940). Before ''You've Got Mail,'' starring Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks as rival bookstore owners who fall in love by way of e-mail, there was this gem, in which James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan play co-workers in a Budapest gift shop who, unbeknownst to each other, have been conducting a romance through the mail. Too bad they can't stand each other. At 10, Judy Garland and Van Johnson set the story to music in ''In the Good Old Summertime.'' That's a little Liza Minnelli in the finale. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Laurie Trombley, a marketing manager in New York, has been nominated by her boss for a wardrobe upgrade. Uh-oh. Stacy and Clinton help her keep her job. 9 P.M. (ABC) HEAVEN. WHERE IS IT? HOW DO WE GET THERE? There is more than one correct answer, depending on your perspective. In this ''20/20'' special, which had its premiere last December, Barbara Walters talks with religious leaders, including the Dalai Lama and the Rev. Calvin Butts; scientists; people who say they have been to heaven; celebrities like Richard Gere; and even terrorists. They discuss the meaning of heaven, their visions of an afterlife, and why they feel heaven can't always wait. 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) THE PLANET'S FUNNIEST ANIMALS Subtitle this one ''Home for the Howlidays.'' To wit, a dog tangles with a snowman, a hamster helps hang the Christmas ornaments and a reindeer goes scavenging for food in a most unusual place. 9 P.M. (USA) MONK A millionaire with leprosy comes out of hiding and hires Monk (Tony Shalhoub) to recover some papers from his estate. But soon enough, all signs point to murder, Hollywood style, as demonstrated in this special noirish black-and-white episode. A color version of the same story follows at 10. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 7 P.M. (Speed) NASCAR PRESEASON THUNDER -- Racing suit feeling a little tight? Now that the holidays are over, some 25 teams of Nascar drivers are participating in the three-day Nextel Cup Series Testing, the annual preseason mental and physical gut-check held at the Daytona International Speedway (above) in preparation for Speedweek 2007, running Feb. 14 through 19. 8 P.M. (13) NOVA SCIENCE NOW -- Next floor, outer space. Neil deGrasse Tyson, the director of the Hayden Planetarium and the show's host, investigates attempts to build a 22,000-mile-high space elevator, for which one company has already constructed a prototype, to transport cargo and passengers out of the planet's atmosphere. Other topics include aging, a new way for unearthing Mayan ruins, and a biologist who studies small-talk on a microscopic level. 8 P.M. (Discovery) REALLY BIG THINGS -- In this new technology and invention series, Matt Rogers travels the globe to prove that, in some cases, size does matter, starting with the sinking unit that places concrete mattresses along the banks of the Mississippi River to help prevent bank erosion; the rammer hammer used to break ore in the Arctic Circle, and the world's largest paper mill. 9 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE -- It's shocking, simply shocking! House (Hugh Laurie, right) reveals startling information in order to save himself from serving jail time. Meanwhile; a firefighter chooses a risky, radical brain treatment so that he can keep a secret. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: CRIMINAL INTENT -- Child's play? When the granddaughter of Lady Harrington (Doris Roberts, in a guest role), a socialite, is murdered, Detectives Goren and Eames go looking for the father of the victim's daughter. Turns out he's a married man she met at a nearby playground. And that's not the only secret the Harrington family is keeping. 9 P.M. (ABC) BIG DAY -- Places, everyone. Jane's ex-boyfriend shows up, making Steve jealous; Lorna hires a new photographer, her ex-fiancé -- who dumped her -- and Danny suddenly gets cold feet. At 9:30, the Garf learns that Steve does not want Alice to marry Danny. Is that why the bride and groom are nowhere to be found? 9 P.M. (CBS) THE 33RD ANNUAL PEOPLE'S CHOICE AWARDS -- Queen Latifah is host of this awards ceremony in which viewers do the voting. No surprises here: nominees include Jennifer Aniston for favorite female movie star and, with her former beau Vince Vaughn, favorite on-screen match-up. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- The effervescent Nia Long (left) joins the cast as Vanessa Walker, an ambitious baby eagle among the grizzled vultures of Crane, Poole & Schmidt. First stop: New Orleans, where she, Denny and Alan will defend a doctor accused of performing euthanasia on patients during Hurricane Katrina. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Cuts Down 'Idol'
summary: With Wednesday's broadcasts, the February ratings sweep came to an end. It was a peculiar one. The Olympics, once ratings champions, were good enough to put NBC in only third place in the sought-after 18-to-49 demographic, though the network won among total viewers for the first time since the May 2002 sweeps. ABC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, but excluding the Super Bowl, Fox, the ''American Idol'' network, won the all-important advertising sales measurement. CBS wasn't really in the race, as it ceded the competition by broadcasting repeats most of the month. But this week, CBS peeked out from under the covers, and on Thursday it was No. 1 among total viewers, as usual. Fox ranked first for the night among 18-to-49-year-olds. Its ''Idol'' (26.18 million estimated viewers) battered CBS's ''Survivor'' (16.24 million) for the second week in a row. But at 9 p.m., CBS's ''CSI'' (27.57 million) drew a larger audience than ''Idol,'' which no other show has done this season when ''Idol'' was on the schedule. The forensics crime series (in which Marg Helgenberger, above, stars as Catherine) beat Fox's ''Skating With Celebrities'' finale (14.15 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; The Hot Seat Beckons Couch Potatoes
summary: Four months later, the ''Prison Break'' gang is still stuck in the clink. In Monday's episode, the first since the Fox series went on hiatus, Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) was denied clemency, and the hour ended with him facing the electric chair. An estimated audience of 10.27 million welcomed this snail-paced frustration back into their lives, as ''Prison Break'' placed second among adults 18 to 49 in the 8 p.m. hour to NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' (16.6 million). Over all, Fox placed second to CBS for the night. Its ''24'' delivered 13.64 million, and a win at 9 p.m. in the 18-to-49 demographic. Opposite the second half of ''24,'' CBS's ''New Adventures of Old Christine'' (15.3 million) had a strong second week, giving the network its best ratings in the 9:30 p.m. time period this season. CBS's victory was solidified by ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 p.m. Its 19.52 million viewers buried NBC's ''Medium'' rerun (7.51 million) and ABC's sinking ''Miracle Workers'' (7.3 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Tears and Sneers
summary: Paula Abdul was moved to tears by Elliott Yamin's version of ''A Song for You'' on Tuesday's ''American Idol,'' and her fellow judge Simon Cowell laughed mockingly at her choked-up commentary. The entire spectacle brought in 27.99 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates and, coupled with the continually growing ''House'' (24.51 million), gave Fox an authoritative victory for the night. ''House'' hit another new ratings high among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds, and also retained more of the ''Idol'' audience than it ever had. CBS's ''NCIS'' (15.26 million) and ''The Unit'' (13.75 million) were, as usual, the only programs that could stand up to Fox's lineup, giving the network a distant second place ranking. At 10 p.m., with Fox out of the way, ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (9.95 million) was No. 1 among total viewers for the hour, but it achieved that against reruns on both NBC and CBS. This season's move to Tuesday nights has not benefited the legal drama. KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: VYING FOR RADIO SPECTRUM -- Some of Silicon Valley's most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers and cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals. [Page C1.] THE FUTURE OF PRINTERS -- The Internet era has been good to makers of printers so far. But looking ahead, Vyomesh I. Joshi of Hewlett-Packard is concerned that if people find printing Web pages too hard and start printing less, he will have fewer coffee talks where he crows about record revenue, profit, margins and market share. [C1.] PRESS RIVALRY IN THE HAMPTONS -- This week perhaps the biggest story in The East Hampton Star involves the paper itself. The Southampton Press, the venerable paper one town over that belongs to the Louchheim family, will introduce a direct competitor, The East Hampton Press, which will come out a day earlier than The Star and will be free. (The Star costs $1.) [C1.] NO MORE SLOW BOATS FOR BOOKS -- The post office's decision to stop transporting goods via cargo ship for individual customers may not hurt big online retailers like Amazon.com, which can qualify for discounts. But thousands of smaller used- and rare-book merchants, like Rob Stuart, above, owner of Frenchboro Books in Maine, say they will suffer, because they rely on foreign demand. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] A MERGER COMES UNDONE -- Miles S. Nadal, the chairman and chief executive of MDC Partners, hopes to get ahead in the intensely competitive advertising industry with a contrarian strategy of almost continuous change. But following that philosophy can be fraught with risk, as was demonstrated last week with the unraveling of an acquisition and merger involving two New York agencies, which Mr. Nadal orchestrated less than two years ago. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C1.] PROXIES CLEAR AS MUD -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's new disclosure rules on executive pay were supposed to make it easier for investors to understand how top managers were being paid. But piles of new data and proxy statements that are about as easy to parse as the federal tax code have even experts scratching their heads. [C4.] A NEW XBOX 360 FEATURE -- Microsoft plans to announce today that it will make its Windows Live Messenger service available on its Xbox 360 game consoles, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television. [C7.] FOUNDATION TAKES ON CLIMATE ISSUE -- The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is creating a $100 million program to support research intended to encourage policies aimed at reducing the threat of global warming. [C6.] A FAKE MYSPACE PROMOTION -- The MySpace fan page with a hot pink background, tribute to Robin Sparkles, a one-hit Canadian teenage pop star from the early 1990s, was just gushing enough to be real. But it wasn't. The MySpace page was a plant, concocted by the producers of the CBS sitcom ''How I Met Your Mother,'' to play off a storyline in the show's Nov. 20 episode. [C8.] EXCLUSIVE TO THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE -- Samuel Zell, who has agreed to buy the Tribune Company, gave his first interview exclusively to The Chicago Tribune. There was no conference call with any other Tribune Company reporters who were tracking the deal, including those at The Los Angeles Times or Newsday, or in Baltimore or Hartford. [C8.] A STOCK TIP MISSES -- Jim Cramer, host of the CNBC television show ''Mad Money,'' recommended on the March 28 episode that viewers sell shares of Dendreon, a biotechnology company in Seattle. The next day, Dendreon's shares tripled when its prostate cancer vaccine was endorsed by a Food and Drug Administration panel. Some viewers are upset. [C8.] PLASTIC DOUBLES AS FUEL -- A chemistry professor has developed a ''fuel-latent plastic'' that can be used like ordinary plastic, for packaging or other purposes, but when it is waste, can easily be turned into a substitute diesel fuel. [C5.]

headline: Don Imus, Suspended, Still Talking
summary: Don Imus was suspended. But it looked as though NBC had suspended the suspension. This scandal-harried radio host and MSNBC star was free to appear on ''Today'' yesterday and explain himself again and again: His interview with Matt Lauer and his debate with the Rev. Al Sharpton, their second, were shown simultaneously on the MSNBC show ''Imus in the Morning.'' The Rutgers University basketball players, fresh from a Rocky-like rise to the N.C.A.A. women's championship game, held a news conference to explain that the slur-heard-round-the-world robbed them of their ''moment.''

headline: What Is This Thing Called Private Equity?
summary: UPON what meat doth this our Caesar feed, that he is grown so great?'' I've been thinking about those words in the context of private equity lately. How does this business make so much money? Are there really a huge number of mispriced securities out there? Are there really a vast number of corporations whose stock is wildly underpriced so that private equity can buy them at above-market prices and then make money after a little spiffing up and wiping clean?

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Housewives' Carries ABC
summary: Half of the shows in ABC's Sunday lineup were repeats, but the network still managed to beat CBS. ''Desperate Housewives,'' in which Gabrielle (Eva Longoria, below) and Carlos (Ricardo Antonio Chavira) weeded out ugly women who might give them a baby to adopt, was the night's most-watched program in Nielsen's estimates, with 21.34 million viewers. It was flanked by reruns of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (13.04 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (15 million). ABC began its night with an original episode of ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' (9.46 million) at 7 p.m. CBS easily won that hour, as N.C.A.A. basketball spilled over into prime time on the East Coast, helping to lift ''60 Minutes'' in the preliminary ratings. CBS placed second for the night among total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. In that age group, Fox was No. 3. The network's winners were ''The Simpsons'' (10.14 million) and ''Family Guy'' (8.15 million); its losers were the soon-to-end ''Malcolm in the Middle'' (3.6 million) and its slacker comedy ''Free Ride'' (4.89 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: OXYCONTIN MAKER PLEADS GUILTY -- The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded guilty to charges that the firm misled doctors and patients when it claimed that the drug was less likely to be abused than traditional narcotics. [Page A1.] ACCORD ON TRADE PACTS -- The Bush administration reached a major accord with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other Democrats to attach environmental and worker protections in several pending trade agreements, clearing the way for early passage of some pacts. [A1.] A JETBLUE DEPARTURE -- JetBlue's service meltdown during a mid-February storm has now led its founder, David Neeleman, to heed the urgings of his board and reluctantly agree to step aside as chief executive of the airline. [C1.] SMOKING JOINS SEX AND VIOLENCE -- The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers. Films that appear to glamorize smoking will risk a more restrictive rating. [C1.] CONFLICTS AMONG PAY CONSULTANTS -- Congressional lawmakers are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise. [C1.] UNHAPPY WITH FORD'S EX-CHIEF -- A group of Ford Motor shareholders at the annual meeting took turns criticizing every decision made by William Clay Ford Jr. as the former chief executive, except one -- his decision to hire Alan R. Mulally as his successor. Mr. Mulally urged patience, and promised results ''in the months and the years ahead.'' [C3.] RETAIL SALES SAG -- From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers. [C1.] A NUCLEAR PLANT REBORN -- The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to reopen a nuclear reactor that was closed 22 years ago for safety reasons. The move, after $1.8 billion in repairs, reflects increased interest in nuclear power, and underscores how hard companies think it will be to build a new plant. [C3.] CROSS-EXAMINATION CONTINUES -- F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International. [C5.] GOOGLE'S FOCUS -- The chief executive at Google, Eric E. Schmidt, speaking to shareholders, said the company's long and varied array of initiatives was organized around three ideas: ''search, ads and apps,'' using a shorthand for applications, or software programs. [C5.] TREASURY INQUIRY ON FILMMAKER -- The filmmaker Michael Moore, below, is being investigated by the Treasury Department over a trip he made to Cuba for his new film, ''Sicko.'' At issue is whether he violated restrictions on travel to Cuba when he accompanied sick workers seeking free medical care. On Mr. Moore's Web site, the film's producer, Meghan O'Hara, called the department's actions a ''politically motivated investigation.'' [A24.] A FALL LINEUP TAKES SHAPE -- NBC took the first steps toward rebuilding its prime-time schedule by ordering five new hours of drama programs, which will be part of the fall schedule the network plans to announce to advertisers on Monday. [C2.] EUROPEAN BANK SIGNALS RATE RISE -- The European Central Bank signaled that it would lift interest rates as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation. [C7.] BOOST FOR INTERNET TV VENTURE -- Joost, a start-up that delivers television programming over the Internet, said that it had received $45 million in financing from venture capitalists and content partners including CBS and Viacom. [C7.] DOW SLUMPS NEARLY 150 POINTS -- Stocks plunged, slicing nearly 150 points off the Dow Jones industrial average after reports of weak sales at many of the major retailers. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology Inc. was sentenced yesterday to a year and one day in prison for his role in a stock options backdating scheme, becoming the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes. (REUTERS) Sara Lee Corporation, the food and household products maker, said that its third-quarter profit nearly tripled on revenue growth in its international beverage, bakery, household and body care segments. (AP) The Goldman Sachs Group said that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1, had resigned from the Goldman board. (REUTERS) EchoStar Communications, parent of the Dish Network satellite television service, said that its quarterly profit rose 7 percent as subscriber growth helped overcome higher marketing costs. (REUTERS) The American International Group, one of the world's largest insurers, said that its profit rose more than 29 percent in the first quarter on strong growth in underwriting results and investment income. (AP) The Interpublic Group of Companies posted a larger-than-expected quarterly loss yesterday as it struggled with high salary costs and weak revenue in Europe and Asia. (REUTERS) TyCo International was named in a bondholders' lawsuit filed by the American International Group, which is trying to stop Tyco's planned bond tender offer, saying the company was offering a below-contract price for its debt. (REUTERS)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Goldstein, Patti
summary: GOLDSTEIN-Patti. Author of the book Creature Comforts, a biography of the chief of night emergency at the Animal Medical Center in New York, publicist for CBS and NBC, and writer for numerous national publications, died Friday night, June 9, 2006 at her home in Bridgehampton, NY. She was 75. The cause was cancer, said her long time companion Sandra Powers. Patti Goldstein began her career as a publicist first for CBS television and later for NBC television where she was Manager of Magazine Publicity. In 1962, she became a partner in her own public relations agency, Addison, Goldstein & Walsh. She has written articles for New York Magazine, Esquire, Vogue, Ms. Magazine, TV Guide and Rolling Stone. She is the author of several screenplays, a novel, and in 1975 with master chef James Beard created ``The CookAlong Cassettes''. In 1986, she wrote the musical fable ``The Cat that Saved the Kingdom'' with score by the late Joe Raposo. The fable was performed at Lincoln Center with full symphony orchestra and six cats and reviewed by the New York Times. Ms. Goldstein also worked in television production. She wrote and produced a public service announcement with Gene Wilder after Gilda Radner's death in 1989 to inform the public about the warning signs of ovarian cancer. Ms. Goldstein was born in New York City on December 5, 1930. She earned her Bachelor of Arts degree from Hunter College. She is survived by Sandra Powers; her sister, Wini Arouty; two nieces, Lisa Lester and Meredith MacPhail; a nephew, Stefan Arouty; four grand-nieces and two grand-nephews. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall. Donations can be made to the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Night to Remember
summary: ABC won every-half hour of the night among adults 18 to 49 on the first Sunday of the May sweeps period. Its two episodes of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (7.93 million, then 14.17 million), ''Desperate Housewives'' (21.36 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (20.71 million) also gave the network a victory in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers. The good news for ABC is that ''Grey's Anatomy'' -- in which Meredith (Ellen Pompeo, above) went on a date with her new veterinarian love interest, Finn (Chris O'Donnell) -- increased its audience compared with the same time last year. The bad news is that ''Housewives'' lost more than 4 million viewers year-over-year. CBS placed second among total viewers. Its latest Tom Selleck made-for-television movie, ''Jesse Stone: Death in Paradise,'' delivered a solid 14.76 million viewers. Earlier in CBS's night, ''60 Minutes'' (12.07 million) and ''Cold Case'' (14.17 million) also helped the network's average. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (13) A TRIBUTE TO JAMES TAYLOR Last Feb. 6, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, Mr. Taylor was honored by MusiCares, the Philanthropic foundation of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, as person of the year. This ''Great Performances'' special includes renditions of Mr. Taylor's hits by David Crosby, Sheryl Crow, Carole King, Alison Krauss, Bonnie Raitt, Sting, Keith Urban, the Dixie Chicks and Bruce Springsteen. ''It's strange to be at an event like this and still be alive,'' Mr. Taylor (above) says before closing the evening with his own variation on ''How Sweet It Is.'' 8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The slender models' nerves wear thinner still in Barcelona, where one breaks down after her flamenco dancing is found to be less than provocative, or at least not provocative in the right way. Later, Tyra Banks directs a photo shoot in which the women must float in a pool of ice water. 8 P.M. (History) MODERN MARVELS Forget those apples: it's a daily glass of wine that is now said to keep the doctor away. And these days, more wine is consumed than ever before. This episode travels to France, to the Moët vineyards and the Tour d'Argent restaurant, to trace the history of wine while examining the technological advances -- like aerial imaging and infrared photography -- that enable the country's vineyards to be fruitful and multiply. 8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER Al Roker and Ann Curry help flip the switch at this 74th annual treelighting celebration (right, shown last year) in the heart of Manhattan. Christina Aguilera, Sting, Enya, Taylor Hicks, John Legend, Martina McBride, Sarah McLachlan and Lionel Richie perform current hits and holiday favorites. 9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS Gideon (Mandy Patinkin) and his team investigate murdered prostitutes in Washington. If only that congresswoman would get out of their way. 9 P.M. (Discovery) MYTHBUSTERS Jamie and Adam test three myths about guns. 9 P.M. (ABC) DAY BREAK And the day goes on, and on. Hopper (Taye Diggs) begins to figure out what his partner, Andrea (Victoria Pratt), did to get into hot water with Internal Affairs. 9 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER The contestants learn about cooking low-cal holiday dinners. The evening's challenge requires competitors (right) to race around a track carrying their original body weights. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Alcohol Fuels Much of Crime By U.S. Troops in War Zones Alcohol is involved in a growing number of crimes by troops in to Iraq and Afghanistan. Alcohol- and drug-related charges were involved in more than a third of all Army criminal prosecutions of soldiers in the two war zones, according to records obtained by The New York Times through a Freedom of Information Act request. A1 Challenges For Bush in Mexico Protesters waited to meet President Bush on his visit to Mexico in a sign of the difficulty he faces as he tries to revive what many Mexicans see as a moribund partnership. A1 French Premier Endorses Rival Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France formally endorsed his political rival, the center-right candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, for president in a statement on Europe 1 radio. A6 U.S. Envoy Hopeful For Afghans The departing American ambassador to Afghanistan, Ronald E. Neumann, said that he did not see the Taliban as the threat it previously appeared to be, and that he was feeling ''reasonably optimistic'' about the state of the insurgency and the country's progress. A8 U.N. Council Condemns Sudan A United Nations Human Rights Council mission to Darfur said that the Sudanese government had organized and taken part in human rights crimes against its own population, and that international action to stop them had been inadequate. A12 NATIONAL A13-17 Republicans Find Division And Discontent With Party After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said he would not enter the 2008 presidential race -- for the time being, at least -- so he could concentrate on domestic and global concerns, particularly helping secure an end to the Iraq war. A16 Army's Top Doctor Forced Out Lt. Gen. Kevin C. Kiley, the Army surgeon general has been forced into retirement, as the fallout continued from revelations of shoddy conditions for outpatients at the medical center. A17 College Cuts Ties With Sorority DePauw University severed ties with a national sorority that evicted two-thirds of the university's chapter members last year in what the sorority called an effort to improve its image for recruitment, but which the evicted women described as a purge of the unattractive or the uncool. A13 Guidelines for Food Handlers The Food and Drug Administration offered new, nonbinding guidelines to food packers to try to reduce the risk of food poisoning in fresh-cut produce but cannot say what caused the recent outbreaks connected to E. coli and salmonella. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Crowd Jams Bronx Mosque To Mourn 10 Killed in Fire Hundreds of people packed into a Bronx mosque to say goodbye to 10 people who died in a fire last week. The dead included the wife and four children of Mamadou Soumare, whose bodies were flown back to Mali for burial, and the five children of Moussa Magassa, who were buried in a Muslim cemetery in New Jersey. A1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Criticism for Gore's Film Al Gore's film on global warming, ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' won an Academy Award for best documentary, but part of his scientific audience is uneasy. In talks, articles and blog entries, those scientists argue that some of Mr. Gore's central points are exaggerated and erroneous. F1 Health & Fitness F5 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 The Hedge Fund Lobby While hedge funds flex their muscles in the markets and in board rooms, in Washington they have experienced awkward growing pains. Now, united by a healthy sense of competition and a desire to avoid stringent regulation -- they have created three hedge fund lobbying groups. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Wrong turn on sex offenders; the death of geography?; Verlyn Klinkenborg on California. Columns: Rory Stewart, Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E2 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

headline: The Listings: Sept. 15 - Sept. 21; 'MUSICALS ON TELEVISION'
summary: Anything Ethel Merman can do, Mary Martin can do better. Even if you don't believe that -- and what real musical theater fan would? -- it's still worth seeing Ms. Martin's different interpretation of the title role of ''Annie Get Your Gun'' in a 1957 production being presented in a series at the Museum of Television & Radio this weekend. A collection of rare live telecasts of musicals are being presented from the 1950's, that bygone era when television executives actually cared about Broadway. (The Tony Awards show hardly counts). ''Wonderful Town'' -- believe it or not -- was once in the CBS lineup, and a production starring Rosalind Russell is among the five shows preserved on kinescopes presented as part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' featuring John Raitt and Reta Shaw with Ms. Martin, will be shown tomorrow, along with the Broadway tryout production of the rarely seen ''Omnibus: The Ballad of Baby Doe'' (left) and ''A Salute to Broadway's Dorothy Loudon,'' a compilation reel of numbers featuring that brilliant comic actress, who died in 2003, including clips from ''Tonight'' and the Tony Awards. On Sunday, ''One Touch of Venus,'' a production of the Kurt Weill-Ogden Nash musical that was televised on NBC, precedes ''Wonderful Town,'' which stars Sydney Chaplin, Jacquelyn McKeever and of course Ms. Russell. (''Musicals on Television'' will run tomorrow and Sunday, Museum of Television & Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, 212-621-6800.) JASON ZINOMAN

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLDSTEIN, PATTI
summary: GOLDSTEIN--Patti. Author of the book Creature Comforts, a biography of the chief of night emergency at the Animal Medical Center in New York, publicist for CBS and NBC, and writer for numerous national publications, died Friday night, June 9, 2006 at her home in Bridgehampton, NY. She was 75. The cause was cancer, said her long time companion Sandra Powers. Patti Goldstein began her career as a publicist first for CBS television and later for NBC television where she was Manager of Magazine Publicity. In 1962, she became a partner in her own public relations agency, Addison, Goldstein & Walsh. She has written articles for New York Magazine, Esquire, Vogue, Ms. Magazine, TV Guide and Rolling Stone. She is the author of several screenplays, a novel, and in 1975 with master chef James Beard created ''The CookAlong Cassettes''. In 1986, she wrote the musical fable ''The Cat that Saved the Kingdom'' with score by the late Joe Raposo. The fable was performed at Lincoln Center with full symphony orchestra and six cats and reviewed by the New York Times. Ms. Goldstein also worked in television production. She wrote and produced a public service announcement with Gene Wilder after Gilda Radner's death in 1989 to inform the public about the warning signs of ovarian cancer. Ms. Goldstein was born in New York City on December 5, 1930. She earned her Bachelor of Arts degree from Hunter College. She is survived by Sandra Powers; her sister, Wini Arouty; two nieces, Lisa Lester and Meredith MacPhail; a nephew, Stefan Arouty; four grand-nieces and two grand-nephews. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall. Donations can be made to the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF DAVID POGUE: Enchanting TED
summary: Last week, I attended my second TED conference, which stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. During the four-day conference, you hear 50 speakers, who are given 18 minutes each. They are the most compelling, passionate, informed speakers you've ever heard (all right, maybe 45 of them are). Some bring back reports from the edge of medicine, archaeology, nanotech, neurology, psychiatry or the Web. Some, like Paul Simon, Tracy Chapman, and They Might Be Giants, perform live.

headline: FLEXIBLE SUNDAY NIGHT SLOTS
summary: Get ready for some flexibility mixed with some inconvenience. The N.F.L. unveiled yesterday how it would determine which games will be carried on NBC's Sunday night schedule in seven of the last eight weeks of the season, starting Nov. 12. The flexible schedule is intended to give NBC a better shot at competitive games in prime time and to showcase teams on the rise.

headline: The Basics; Just 18 Short Months to Go
summary: This early on, the 2008 presidential race has so many unknown candidates it has dark horseflies on its dark horses. But maybe you're among the fully one-quarter of Americans who, in a CBS News poll last month, said they were actually paying a lot of attention to this stuff. If so, the quiz below should be a snap. Right? TOM KUNTZ 1. Here are the lower-tier Republican presidential hopefuls. Match names with faces: Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas John H. Cox, Chicago businessman Former Gov. Jim Gilmore of Virginia Rep. Duncan Hunter of California Former Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas Rep. Ron Paul of Texas Rep. Tom Tancredo of Colorado (One point for each correct match -- potential 8 points.) 2. A lot of people know that Mitt Romney, the Republican who was governor of Massachusetts, is a Mormon, but did you know that six candidates are Roman Catholic? Who from the list below isn't? A. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut B. Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York C. Former Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska D. Gov. Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico E. Tommy Thompson F. Brownback G. Cox (Correct answer: 3 points) 3. Who has been least associated with presidential politics? A. Paul Tsongas B. Ron Paul C. Pat Paulsen D. RuPaul (Correct answer: 1 point) 4. Match the potential health risk with the politician: Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois; Fred Thompson former Republican senator of Tennessee; Giuliani; Huckabee. A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma B. Adult-onset diabetes C. Prostate cancer D. Past smoking (One point for each correct match -- potential 4 points) 5. Match the eyebrow-raising quote with the speaker: Tommy Thompson, Obama, Giuliani, Romney and Yosemite Sam. A. ''Freedom is about authority. Freedom is about the willingness of every single human being to cede to lawful authority a great deal of discretion about what you do.'' B. ''I'm in the private sector and for the first time in my life I'm earning money. You know, that's sort of part of the Jewish tradition.'' C. ''In case you missed it, this week, there was a tragedy in Kansas. Ten thousand people died, an entire town destroyed.'' D. ''I'm not a big-game hunter. I've made that very clear. I've always been a rodent and rabbit hunter. Small varmints, if you will.'' E. ''Ya better say yer prayers, ya flea-bitten varmint! I'm a-gonna blow ya to smithereenies!'' (One point for each correct match -- potential 5 points) 6. Match the politician -- Tommy Thompson, Tancredo, Paul, Gravel -- with the descriptive phrase found on his official Web site: A. ''No amnesty for illegal immigrants'' B. The ''one exception to the Gang of 535'' on Capitol Hill C. ''The reliable conservative'' D. ''More like Cicero than Quixote'' (One point for each correct match -- potential 4 points) 7. Pomp my Ride. Match the candidates with how they say they roll: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York Former Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona Rep. Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio Giuliani Obama Dodd Romney A. 2005 Ford Mustang convertible B. ''For security reasons, we drive in Secret Service vehicles but the Service lets us use a Ford hybrid when we're home...'' C. Ford Escape hybrid, a compact S.U.V. D. Chrysler 300C, a full-size sport-luxury sedan E. ''I don't drive, I navigate.'' F. Cadillac CTS, a midsize luxury sedan G. Ford Focus compact (One point for each correct match: potential 8 points) 8. Fred Thompson? Tommy Thompson? What's the diff? A. Fred hasn't declared candidacy. B. Fred, from Tennessee, has a better southern drawl than Hillary Clinton. C. Tommy advocates trimming welfare more than John Edwards. D. Fred spends a lot less money on a trim than John Edwards. E. All of the above, probably (Correct answer: one point) Answers: 1) Brownback, G; Cox, H; Gilmore, F; Hunter, A; Thompson, D; Huckabee, E; Paul, C; Tancredo, B; 2) C; 3) D; 4) Obama, D; Thompson, A; Giuliani, C; Huckabee, B; 5) Thompson, B; Obama, C; Giuliani, A; Romney, D; Yosemite Sam, E; 6) Thompson, C; Tancredo, A; Paul, B; Gravel, D; 7) Clinton, B; Edwards, C; McCain, F; Kucinich, G; Giuliani, E; Obama, D; Dodd, C; Romney, A; 8) E There are a total of 34 possible points. If your score -- or political-obscurity quotient (P.O.Q.) -- is: 0-9 You never miss an episode of ''Judge Judy.'' 10-18 You have heeded John McCain's admonition to ''Get a life,'' and may actually know who he is. 19-27 You are a C-Span caller with the TV volume up too loud. 28-34 You are a model citizen, political pro or someone with entirely too much time on your hands.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: THOMSON ACQUIRES REUTERS -- The Thomson Corporation's $17.2 billion acquisition of the Reuters Group was announced, a confirmation of Thomson's success turning an Ontario newspaper chain into a financial information powerhouse. [Page C1.] The trustees charged with overseeing the integrity and independence of the Reuters Group endorsed the sale, but some employees said they feared the quality of Reuters's journalism would be diminished. [C8.] PAY-RELATED PROPOSALS AT AMR -- There may be fireworks at today's annual meeting of shareholders of AMR, the parent of American Airlines. Four shareholder proposals, including two related to executive pay, will come up for a vote. [C1.] TYCO TO PAY INVESTORS $3 BILLION -- Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced. The settlement, described as the largest payment ever by a company in such litigation, comes after one of the nation's most notorious cases of fraud. [C1.] LIFE AFTER THE AIRLINE INDUSTRY -- Financial difficulties in airlines have taken a toll on many of the industry's longtime workers, who have begun to look elsewhere to revive their interest in going to work. [C1.] SIGNS OF A SLOWDOWN -- Businesses kept a lid on prices again last month, and wage gains were scant for most working Americans, signs consistent with an economy in the midst of a slowdown. [C3.] AMGEN SHARES TUMBLE -- Amgen shares were battered again after Medicare proposed to sharply curtail reimbursement for the company's biggest selling product, the anemia drug Aranesp. [C3.] MOTOROLA'S NEW MODELS -- Motorola is hoping to revive its business prospects with some slick new mobile phones, including a sequel to its hit Razr phone and a new keyboard-equipped messaging phone. [C3.] LOBBYIST TURNS ENFORCER -- A lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers nominated by President Bush to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission will receive a $150,000 departing payment from the association when he takes his new job, which involves enforcing consumer laws against members of the association. [A1.] MAKING TAX-FREE INCOME TAXABLE -- Congress is considering closing a loophole that allows nonprofit groups to avoid paying taxes on income earned through offshore hedge funds. Many universities, foundations and pension funds would be affected. [A15.] ABC'S FALL FORECAST: UPBEAT -- ABC this fall will replace darker, complicated series that viewers and advertisers disdained with more upbeat, accessible fare. Examples of the 12 new shows include ''Dirty Sexy Money,'' about an ''absurdly wealthy'' family in New York, and a sitcom (featuring Dash Mihok, above) based on the misunderstood cavemen characters from television commercials for Geico insurance. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C6.] CBS will follow its stated goal of taking its prime-time schedule in unexpected directions with fall series exploring unusual themes like vampires and singing casino workers. [E3.] 'OPIE AND ANTHONY' ARE SUSPENDED -- XM Radio, the satellite provider, imposed 30-day suspensions on the hosts known as Opie and Anthony after the pair participated in an on-air discussion that imagined sexual assaults on Condoleezza Rice and Laura Bush. [E2.] MARKETS GIVE BACK GAINS -- Wall Street gave up a huge advance and closed mixed after an unimpressive snapshot of the housing market unsettled investors. [C9.] TRIAL OVER 'SAHARA' ENDS -- A trial over the failed big-budget movie ''Sahara,'' pitting the novelist Clive Cussler against a production company, came to an end after three and a half months, but with an unsatisfying Hollywood ending: neither side truly won. [A14.] SEEKING A DEAL ON WOLFOWITZ -- The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door to him resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board dropped its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office. [A8.] BETTER FOOD INSPECTIONS -- More people and organizations are calling for an overhaul of the way the Food and Drug Administration inspects food, in the wake of a series of cases of food contamination over the past year. [F1.] BAD NEWS FROM 2 BIG RETAILERS -- Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot posted quarterly results that presented a troubled outlook for retailers. [C5.] SPECIAL SECTION: SMALL BUSINESS -- Articles include a look at how a revolution in online ads is being led by small companies, and a profile of Burt's Bees, the company founded by a beekeeper that has become a mass-market powerhouse in the beauty business. [Section H.] ONLINE BUSINESS OF GREEN -- Companies seek economies of scale in alternative energy. An audio slide show and special section can be found at nytimes.com/business. THE UPFRONTS -- The Times's Bill Carter reports from Radio City Music Hall, where NBC presented its 2007 fall lineup. A video report is at nytimes.com/video. BRAZIL'S WINE COUNTRY -- Wine is now being made in nontraditional areas like Brazil's desert, challenging centuries-old grape myths. A slide show is at nytimes.com/multimedia.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Bombs Kill 3 in Lebanon on Day Before Memorial A day before Lebanon was set to mark the second anniversary of the assassination of its former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, three people were killed and about 23 others wounded when two minibuses were bombed as they took passengers to Beirut. It was the first attack directed at ordinary civilians, not public figures, since the end of Lebanon's civil war in 1990. PAGE A3 Rampage in Salt Lake City The bottomless silence between shots was what witnesses were recalling in Salt Lake City the day after a shooting rampage at the Trolley Square mall left six dead, including the gunman. The police still know little about the man, who was identified as an 18-year-old whose family came to Utah as war refugees from Bosnia. PAGE A18 Ex-C.I.A. Official Indicted Federal prosecutors in San Diego announced an 11-count felony indictment charging a former high-ranking Central Intelligence Agency official with using his influence to steer contracts to a friend. PAGE A24 The DNA of Modern Art Unlike the oil painters of the past, artists today often use acrylics, enamels, or even house paint. A lab at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles, above, is learning how to preserve art made with modern synthetics. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 House Debates Iraq War The House opened a full-throated debate over the Iraq war as lawmakers began considering a resolution to denounce President Bush's troop buildup plan. Democratic leaders said it was the first step in using Congressional authority to intervene in the conflict. PAGE A25 U.S. Trade Gap Sets Record The United States ran a record trade deficit in 2006 for the fifth consecutive year, an announcement that quickly reignited a policy dispute between the Bush administration and Democrats. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Romney Declares Candidacy Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., positioning himself as an outsider running against the Washington establishment. PAGE A22 Battle of Network Anchors Katie Couric's ''CBS Evening News'' is still third in the ratings, but it does look and sound different from NBC's ''Nightly News,'' and ABC's ''World News'' with Charles Gibson, which was No. 1 in the ratings last week for the first time since August 2005. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 He's the Top Dog James, an English springer spaniel who was named Best in Show at the Westminster dog show, with his handler, Kellie Fitzgerald. PAGE D1 A Valentine From Donor 150 There is no established ritual for how an anonymous sperm donor should contact his genetic children. But for one such donor, Valentine's Day seemed as good an occasion as any. And so six weeks ago, he logged on to the Donor Sibling Registry, the Web site devoted to connecting donors with their offspring. PAGE A18 Let's Get Lyrical He's melodies. She's words. He's Hugh Grant. She's Drew Barrymore. Together they're the yin and yang of ''Music and Lyrics,'' a competent Hollywood comedy about a semi-washed-up pop star and the woman he meets cute. A film review by A. O. Scott. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 A Cake With Allure Red velvet cake, with its clouds of icing and improbable color, is suddenly all the rage. DINING, PAGE F1

headline: Setting a Festive Scene For the Big Countdown
