Hosts can get away with serving nothing but caviar and fancy sweets, washed down with Champagne. But proper accouterments are important -- paper and plastic will not do on Dec. 31. 1. Lido glassware for wine or Champagne comes rimmed in gold or platinum. The glasses, made in Italy, are $26 each from wshome.com or (888) 922-4108. 2. Porcelain bowls for little nibbles or special desserts are decorated with 14-karat gold glaze, but they can go in the dishwasher. They come in various designs, in matte and shiny gold; $28 each from anthropologie.com or (800) 309-2500. 3. Desserts can be served on a 12-inch ceramic platter decorated with Audubon prints ($198) and a set of four eight-inch-round plates, each with a different pattern ($328). The limited-edition set by Richard Ginori, an Italian manufacturer, is available at brooksbrothers.com or (800) 274-1815. 4. A stainless steel caviar server with a six-ounce glass bowl inside can be used for shrimp cocktail if you don't like caviar; $29.95 from surlatable.com or (866) 328-5412. 5. Forte Tritan crystal Champagne flutes are made with titanium and zirconium instead of lead, so they are less breakable than ordinary crystal glasses. A set of six is $59.50 from surlatable.com or (866) 328-5412. 6. A 13-inch-diameter white ceramic platter with an embossed design is $19, and a set of four matching plates is $36; westelm.com or (888) 922-4119. 7. Bowls that look as if they are made of shiny foil are 8 inches high and 12 inches wide; $29.95 each at cb2.com or (800) 606-6252. 8. A self-balancing serving tray that can be carried with one hand has a stainless steel frame and a 16-inch-diameter plastic tray that comes in green or blue; $65 at mxyplyzyk.com or (800) 243-9810. 9. An oversize neon-green plastic Champagne cooler, designed by Marc Newson for Dom Perignon, is from an edition of 1,000. The 27-inch-high cooler is $1,000 at Moss; mossonline.com or (866) 888-6677. 10. Christofle's silver-plated straws are just right for sipping Champagne straight out of a split. A pair is $115 from vivre.com or (800) 411-6515.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Numbers Tell the Story As the TV Season Ends
summary: The traditional television season ended on Wednesday, and not surprisingly, Fox's ''American Idol'' accounted for the two top-ranked shows. In Nielsen's estimates, the Tuesday edition of that mammoth talent show drew an average of 31.2 million viewers, and the Wednesday show drew 30.2 million. Both were up in double-digit percentages compared with the previous season in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 years old. After the two nights of ''Idol'' came CBS's ''CSI'' (25.2 million), followed by ''Desperate Housewives'' (22.2 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (19.9 million). The most-watched new show of the season was the Monday edition of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' (15.8 million), which ranked 13th. ''The Unit'' (15.5 million) on CBS followed that and was the top scripted new show. ''Veronica Mars,'' formerly of UPN and now of the CW, was the least-watched show to be renewed for next season. That girl-detective cult series brought in an average of 2.3 million viewers and ranked 145th out of 156 shows. KATE AURTHUR

headline: INSIDE
summary: Americans in Poll Doubt G.O.P. Motives in Foley Case Americans say Republican leaders put their political interests ahead of protecting pages, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll also shows the war continuing to hurt President Bush's popularity. PAGE A22 U.N. Candidate Advances The United Nations Security Council officially nominated South Korea's foreign minister, Ban Ki-moon, to become the next secretary general, but North Korea's actions cast a shadow on the event. PAGE A10 Military Recruiting Goals Met One year after the Army failed to meet its annual recruiting goal by a wide margin, the Pentagon is to announce that all of the services reached their targets for recruits in 2006. PAGE E1 Prize to Columbia Economist Edmund S. Phelps, below, of Columbia University was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his contribution to a study of how wages, unemployment and inflation interact. headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Strangers on a train? No more, as Michael (Wentworth Miller) and Sara (Sarah Wayne Callies, right, with Mr. Miller) share a kiss en route to confront the president. Meanwhile, Mahone finds a new ally in his bid to capture he fugitives. And the Hollanders keep up appearances now that T-Bag -- that's Daddy to you -- is home. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) NORA ROBERTS'S MONTANA SKY -- Next up in the Lifetime quartet of movies based on Ms. Roberts's best-selling novels, this story about the three daughters of Jack Mercy, a millionaire cattleman, who must live on his enormous ranch for one year to collect their inheritance. Ashley Williams plays Willa, the daughter who calls the country home; Charlotte Ross is Tess, the one who can't wait to hightail it back to Hollywood. And John Corbett (above, with Ms. Williams) is Ben, the neighbor who supervises the Mercy ranch. Diane Ladd does a turn as Bess, the meddling Irish cook who tries to convince Willa and Ben that they belong together. 9 P.M. (History) DIGGING FOR THE TRUTH -- Josh Bernstein travels to Egypt to the Valley of the Kings, where he climbs into King Tut's tomb, fires the weapons he took to his grave, and tries to figure out the mystery behind his death. 9:30 P.M. (CBS) RULES OF ENGAGEMENT -- Boys and girls, playing together -- sometimes nicely, sometimes not. That's the premise of this new sitcom, starring Oliver Hudson and Bianca Kaljichas a newly engaged couple; Patrick Warburton and Megyn Price as an old married twosome, and perennial bachelor David Spade as a single man on the prowl. 10 P.M. (13, 49) AT CLOSE RANGE WITH NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC -- Joel Sartore, a photographer with National Geographic, travels to some of the most exotic locations on Earth for his job, but his accommodations are hardly five-star, as he lives in wretched conditions for weeks on end just to get the shot -- during which he has been chased by bears, wolves, alligators and musk oxen. This special follows Mr. Sartore as he travels from the wilderness to the magazine's offices in Washington for perhaps the most difficult part of his job: winnowing down thousands of photographs into the 10 or 20 that typically accompany a story. 10 P.M. (ABC) IN STYLE CELEBRITY WEDDINGS -- Desperate housewives? Probably not any time soon. This special goes behind the scenes of celebrity nuptials to watch lovebirds like Marcia Cross and Tom Mahoney (right), Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, Tori Spelling and Dean McDermott, Avril Lavigne and Deryck Whibley, and Niki Taylor and Burney Lamar tie the knot for better or worse. Or at least for now. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: THE NATION: 6 Ways to Watch the Election; The Religious Vote
summary: In 2004, frequent church attendance or conservative Christian beliefs were strongly correlated with voting Republican. But this year a handful of Democrats are actively courting religious voters -- even theologically conservative Christians. The results may determine their party's chances of making incursions into this part of the Republican base. Representative HAROLD E. FORD JR. of Tennessee plans to wind up his Senate campaign with a prayer breakfast this weekend. BOB CASEY JR. of Pennsylvania, known for his opposition to abortion rights, has met with many Catholic and evangelical clergy members during his campaign for Senate. HEATH SHULER, a former National Football League quarterback running for Congress in North Carolina, boasts of his active role in the evangelical Fellowship of Christian Athletes.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 4 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLENDEGENERES SHOW -- Jude Law (left, with Kate Winslet at the Toronto premiere of their new film ''All the King's Men'' on Sept. 10), in what could be a pre-emptive strike, gets in the good graces of Ms. DeGeneres, the better to keep from being the butt of her Oscar jokes next year. Be nice to your host, now . . . 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: COOK ISLANDS -- Subtitle this one ''War of the Worlds.'' In this much-debated season premiere, 20 contestants are divided into four teams based on ethnicity before being forced to make peace at a later date. 8 P.M. (Fox) 'TIL DEATH -- The women learn how to trade favors for furniture. 8 P.M. (History) WHERE DID IT COME FROM? -- Luxury high-rises? The ancient Romans had them first. 8 P.M. (Sundance) SIGNÉ CHANEL -- Picky, picky. In the second episode of this fashion series set in the House of Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld sees what his seamstresses have wrought from his designs and immediately begins to iron out the details. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) DICK CAVETT -- In an interview from the olden days (Oct. 20, 1971), Woody Allen and Mr. Cavett purvey their funny-urbane shtick. 9 P.M. (Travel) THE KIDS ARE IN CHARGE: FAMILY VACATION -- Never again will little passengers ask the inevitable if they're the ones planning the E.T.A. (History) AMERICAN EATS -- The snap, the crackle, the pop behind breakfast cereal. 10:30 P.M. (Food Network) ACE OF CAKES -- Duff gives cake-decorating lessons to a Brownie troop and then sets off to Hollywood with saws and power drills to make a birthday cake for Jay Leno in a hotel room. 11:35 P.M. Rosie O'Donnell (far left, with Barbara Walters amid a shower of confetti on Sept. 6) tries to do for Mr. Letterman what she has done for ''The View.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: GOOGLE KEEPS ON GROWING -- Google, the world's largest search engine company, said that its profits nearly doubled from a year ago, maintaining a torrid growth rate at a time when rivals like Yahoo appeared to be faltering. Google said it earned $733 million in the third quarter, up 92 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $2.69 billion, with 44 percent of that coming from outside the United States. [Page C3.] DOW ABOVE 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychologically important 12,000 level for the first time, indicating that investors were increasingly confident that the economy was poised to perform the rare feat of slowing without stalling. The performance in the months ahead will depend, in part, how gracefully the economy handles the slowing housing market. [C1.] BIG BANK EARNINGS -- Citigroup seemed to stumble and Bank of America appeared to strut through a messy third quarter as the country's two biggest banks contended with pressures of a slowing economy and higher interest rates. [C3] CBS SETTLES ACCUSATIONS -- CBS became the first radio corporation to settle accusations of illicit pay-for-play practices made by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. CBS, which runs approximately 180 radio stations, agreed to adopt more stringent policies on its stations' dealings with record labels and to make a $2 million payment to New York charities. [C3.] MEDICINE VS. MARKETING -- For many doctors, it's an irresistible pitch: a $250 profit from a 15-minute test. With that lure, some 12,000 of the nation's physicians have purchased an automated device that checks patients for nerve disease. Specialists say the problem is that many general practitioners are not qualified to do such tests. [A1.] HIGHER PROFITS AT DRUG MAKERS -- Drug makers continued to post strong profit gains, led by Pfizer, the world's biggest pharmaceutical company, which reported that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled from a year earlier. Eli Lilly, Novartis, and Wyeth also reported higher quarterly profits. [C2] VIDEO GAME WARS -- Laying the groundwork for a battle against rival Microsoft, Sony said that 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 game console when it goes on sale next month. Sony also plans to highlight the console's ability to play high-definition DVD's in Sony's Blu-ray format. [C11.] BANNER YEAR IN HONG KONG -- In a reflection of China's growing prominence in international finance, Hong Kong is set for a banner year in global markets with more money raised by companies selling shares to the public here than on the biggest exchanges in New York and London. Pricing will be set today for the world's largest IPO ever, that of China's biggest bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. [C1.] BEYOND REGULATORS' REACH -- Every month, roughly 19,000 households across the country write check to Christian Care Ministry. The members pool their health expenses and contributions and the ministry writes checks to health care providers. Such payments totaled $57 million in the latest fiscal year. While ministry members say they are helping to carry each others burdens, some Florida state officials see what they would call unregulated health insurance. [C1.] RULING AGAINST GRASSO -- A New York judge ruled that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million of a fiercely contested $139.5 million retirement payout to the exchange The judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said that Mr. Grasso did not disclose to his fellow directors on the board of the exchange the extent to which his soaring compensation had caused his pension and savings to balloon. [A1.] MERGER REVERBERATIONS -- The $8 billion combination of Chicago's derivatives markets is being heralded as good for Chicago and good for the exchanges. But in Europe, it is raising concerns at banks and rival exchanges that it may increase costs or stifle competition. One of the biggest fears in London where the local derivatives exchange will be dwarfed, is that it creates a so-called vertical silo, or a market where one giant entity is both a trading platform and a clearing system. [C8.] NBC STAFF CUTBACKS -- NBC said it planned to reduce its 6,000-person newsgathering staff by an estimated 5 percent, or 300 people to adapt to the migration of news viewers to the Internet and eliminate overlaps in news coverage. Steve Capus, president of NBC News, said the bulk of the cuts would come from eliminating jobs already vacant, as well as from early retirements and voluntary buyouts, but that some layoffs were inevitable. [C4.] LOWER COST PROGRAMMING -- As part of the extensive cost-cutting program it announced yesterday, NBC intends to dramatically alter its prime-time programming, starting in the fall of 2007, filling the 8 p.m. hour each night of the week with lower-cost, unscripted programs and saving its more expensive scripted comedies and dramas for the 9-to-11 block. [C1.] WEAK NEWSPAPER PROFITS -- Newspaper companies continued to show weakness, with The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both reporting lackluster earnings, citing soft advertising sales as a major culprit. At the Times Company, the slowdown ''is expected to continue through the end of the year,'' said Janet L. Robinson, the company's president and chief executive. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. McDonald's reported a 15 percent rise in third-quarter profitmeeting a better-than-expected forecast it gave last week. (REUTERS) The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest provider of health insurance, said third-quarter net income rose 38 percent after acquisitions raised the number of policyholders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Travelers packed planes operated by Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines over the summer, but Continental's third-quarter profit grew while Southwest's earnings fell in another sign that traditional carriers were narrowing the gap with low-cost rivals. (AP)

headline: Drawing the Line At Dangerous Jobs
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Mom's Balancing Act'' (column, Aug. 1): Judith Warner writes that women less privileged than Katie Couric ought to be able to say ''no'' to dangerous assignments for work. I agree. But there is another model.

headline: TONIGHT'S TV LISTINGS: What's on Wednesday Night
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE MARINES They call it ''warrior culture'' -- the smallest but fiercest branch of the United States armed services. This special ventures into Marine Corps training facilities in Parris Island, S.C.; Quantico, Va.; and Twentynine Palms, Calif., to reveal what it takes to be a Marine -- from a recruit's arrival at boot camp and often grueling training, including the martial arts program, confidence course and rifle range instruction, to the demanding Officer Candidate Leadership reaction course and the infamous Quigley exercise, which requires navigating a four-foot-deep stretch of 50-degree swamp water. More than 30 Marines weigh in on the history, traditions and importance of being the proud and the few. 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO After a 12-week hiatus, the series returns with a prequel episode, set 36 hours before the bombs exploded, that seems to have an explanation for just about everything.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Congress Accepts War Bill, Ending Impasse With Bush Congress voted to meet President Bush's demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy. A1 The powerful Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr has quietly returned to southern Iraq after a four-month sojourn in Iran, according to American intelligence reports. A1 Rivals Clash in Spanish Voting Spaniards go to the polls Sunday to elect local and regional officials, but parochial concerns have been overshadowed by a debate between the Socialist prime minister and the leader of the conservative Popular Party. The vote is in many ways a dry run for next year's general election. A9 British Terror Trials Criticized Peter Clarke, the head of British counterterrorism at Scotland Yard, criticized what he called excessive secrecy in Britain's terrorism trials. He called for changes that would permit freer reporting and wider discussion of the issue, preventing broad public skepticism and suspicion about the scale of a threat. A11 Israel Seizes 33 Palestinians Israel stepped up its campaign against Hamas, arresting 33 prominent West Bank Palestinians in raids and accusing them of ''terrorist activity,'' army officials said in a statement, describing those arrested as ''senior members of the Hamas terror organization.'' A3 NATIONAL A12-17 Poll Shows Americans Support Immigration Bill As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans -- Democrats, Republicans and independents alike -- for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 Americans view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the poll. A16 House Approves Lobby Bill The House voted to drag into public view the role that lobbyists play in soliciting and collecting contributions for political campaigns, exposing how influence-seekers ingratiate themselves with lawmakers and presidents. A17 Cemeteries in Need of Money Historic cemeteries, desperate for money to pay for badly needed restorations, are reaching out to the public in ever more unusual ways, including dog parades and bird-watching lectures, as Americans choose cremations in record numbers. A1 Congress Backs Higher Wage Congress approved the first increase in the federal minimum wage rate in a decade, handing a major victory to low-income workers. A12 Senate Keeps Immigration Plan The Senate voted to keep a provision that offers legal status to most of the nation's 12 million illegal immigrants, turning aside the most significant challenge to the comprehensive immigration bill now under debate. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Low-Paying Health Jobs Fuel Employment Growth Poor-paying positions in health care and social work -- with little prospects for upward mobility -- have accounted for most of the growth in employment in New York City in the last 15 years, according to the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The jobs accounts for nearly one-third of all private-sector jobs and wages in Brooklyn and the Bronx. A1 H.I.V. Tests for Rape Suspects Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a majority of New York State lawmakers are backing a bill requiring H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges. But its chances of passage are unclear. B1 War Hangs Over Cadets The war in Iraq has hovered over the class of 2007 at the United States Military Academy in West Point. The 1,000-plus cadets who will graduate this weekend were the first to enter West Point after the invasion of Iraq in March 2003. B1 OBITUARIES B7 Philip M. Kaiser A diplomat or political appointee under every Democratic president from Harry S. Truman to Jimmy Carter, he was 93. B7 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Ignoring the warnings, again?; get moving on traffic relief; closer to reform; lighting the way. Columns: Paul Krugman and David Brooks. BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Pay Gap at the Very Top As executive pay surges in most American companies, attention has focused on the growing gap between the earnings of top executives and the average wage of workers. Less noticed is how wide the gap has become between top officers and their immediate subordinates. A1 Business Digest C2 Crossword E31 TV Listings E23 Weather B8

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Housewives' Hearten ABC
summary: ABC outflanked the heavy sports competition on Sunday night and landed on top, aided by this season's third installment of ''Desperate Housewives.'' That episode, in which Susan (Teri Hatcher) and Ian (Dougray Scott) escaped to the country while their lovers lay in the hospital, was the most watched program of the night with 20.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The results were more mixed for ABC at 10 p.m. Once again ''Brothers & Sisters,'' following ''Housewives'' and featuring Calista Flockhart, suffered a steep dropoff in viewers, including 12 percent of its audience in its last half hour. Still, ''Brothers & Sisters'' finished No. 1 for the hour among adults 18 to 49 and second to CBS's ''Without a Trace'' (15 million) in total viewers (13.1 million). Both NBC and Fox broadcast live sporting events. NBC's coverage of the San Diego Chargers' victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers averaged 15.1 million viewers for the night. As of deadline, time-zone adjusted estimates were unavailable for Fox's coverage of the San Diego Padres' elimination at the hands of the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 4 of the National League playoffs. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Those Dodger Blues Just Won't Go Away
summary: The epic villainy of Walter O'Malley for moving the Dodgers west is like a family legend told through baseball generations: Come on and listen to this story of unparalleled baseball greed, my son. In following the money to Los Angeles, O'Malley initiated a half-century's burst of nostalgia for the old team, for Jackie, Duke, Gil and Pee Wee, for Red Barber and Hilda Chester, for Ebbets Field and for what Brooklyn used to be and could have been.

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE RUBY IN THE SMOKE -- The mystery! The melodrama! Billie Piper (left) portrays Sally Lockhart, a scrappy teenage sleuth, in this ''Masterpiece Theater'' production adapted from the first of Phillip Pullman's quartet of Victorian-era novels. Tonight, armed with a pearl-handled pistol and plenty of pluck, Sally, an orphan, uncovers the secrets of her father's death, discovers cursed jewels and faces down England's most sinister villains without batting an eyelash. J J Feild and Matt Smith play Frederick Garland and Jim Taylor, Sally's partners in crime-solving; David Harewood does a stint as the Bedwell twins -- one, an opium-addicted sailor who was the last to see Sally's father alive, and the other, a clergyman who doesn't mind getting down and dirty for a just cause. Julie Waters is Mrs. Holland, the old woman who wouldn't mind seeing Sally dead. And then there is the title object: the fabled Ruby of Agrapur, which is depicted by a red bauble enhanced by computer-generated effects. 2:30 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES: OVERTIME -- Just in time for Posh's and Becks's move to Los Angeles, this primer, in the form of an all-day marathon following the off-field antics of Anika Beevor (Georgina Mellor) and her roster of salacious players. 4 P.M. (21) AN EVENING WITH DELLA REESE -- In this hourlong special, taped in Atlanta in June 2004 as part of ''The History Makers'' series, Lorraine Toussaint interviews Ms. Reese (right) about her life and career -- from her beginnings as a jazz and gospel singer in Detroit, performing with Mahalia Jackson, to her years as a talk-show host and actress on series like ''Touched by an Angel'' and as a minister at her church, Understanding Principles for Better Living. 9 P.M. (HBO) ROME -- Atia (Polly Walker) turns the tables on Servilia (Lindsay Duncan), Octavian (Simon Woods) wins a battle against Mark Antony (James Purefoy), and Vorenus (Kevin McKidd) learns of the fate of his children. 10:30 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS -- In this two-part episode, someone places a 911 call quoting Bible passages only moments before a wealthy couple is murdered after a Super Bowl party. And then he posts that killing, and others, on the Internet. 10:30 P.M. (13) DANCE PARTY: THE TEENARAMA STORY -- Martha Reeves of Martha and the Vandellas is host of this documentary, which uses archival film footage, reenactments and interviews with artists like James Brown (above) to examine the success of ''Teenarama Dance Party,'' a televised program created in Washington in 1963 for black teenagers who were excluded from white dance shows. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). ''What we got here is failure to communicate,'' says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman, front, with Wayne Rogers, far left, and J. D. Cannon), a war hero, has been sentenced for two years after cutting the heads off parking meters. Mr. Newman earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as a prisoner who refuses to break under a brutal system. George Kennedy won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Dragline, the gang's top dog. At 10:30, Steve McQueen and Dustin Hoffman play convicts trying to escape Devil's Island in ''Papillon'' (1973). 8 P.M. (CMT) COWBOY U -- With boot camp finished, the city slickers must put their newfound skills to the test on a two-day cattle drive, followed by a calf-branding session. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) goes after a corpse (Jamie Bamber of ''Battlestar Galactica,'' in a guest turn, right, with Ms. Hewitt) from a local morgue who was reanimated by a spirit that needs this particular body to get his work done. 9 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Forensics? Who needs it? Monk uses his detective skills to find a serial killer in San Francisco when he is teamed with a technologically astute federal agent. 9 P.M. (Sundance) LADETTE TO LADY -- The six remaining ladettes compete for three positions as chalet girls in Verbier, the Swiss ski resort. But it's not just about breezing down the bunny slope, as the winners are put to work creating gourmet meals for eight hungry but eligible bachelors. The losers have to learn elocution and flower arranging. 10 P.M. (TLC) THE GREATEST FASHION ICONS IN FILM -- Just in time for red-carpet analysis at the Oscars, a special that looks at the ones who clearly did know what to wear. And where would any list of the sartorially savvy be without a mention of Audrey Hepburn, her little black dress and her little slim pants, now interpreted for a new generation by the Gap? There's also a nod to contemporary stars and their fashion influences. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- The smoking glove? A publisher is found dead after backing out of a deal regarding a controversial book in which a baseball player speculates how he might have murdered his wife. 11 P.M. (BBC America) SPOONS -- This new sketch comedy series about the fragile relationships (bad sex, worse marriages) of young urbanites deals in types, including the paranoid boyfriend, the clueless husband and the wife who can't have a baby soon enough. The comic stable includes (above) Tom Goodman-Hill, Rosie Cavaliero, Simon Farnaby, Rob Rouse, Elizabeth Bower, Kerry Godliman, Josie D'Arby and Kevin Bishop. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY'S MATCHUPS
summary: New Orleans Saints (11-6) at Chicago Bears (14-3) 3 p.m., Fox The Saints have never reached the National Football Conference championship game. No team with a record as bad as the Saints' 3-13 last season had ever made the conference championship the next season. But here are the Saints, and, tailback Deuce McAllister said, ''This may be destiny.'' It may be many things, but two stand out: Can the Bears' celebrated defense rise from the doldrums and handle McAllister, quarterback Drew Brees, the all-around threat Reggie Bush and those dangerous receivers? Which Rex Grossman will show up at quarterback for the Bears? Last week, Grossman was mostly good in an overtime victory against the Seahawks, and the Saints' secondary has been vulnerable to the long pass. Grossman was erratic during the regular season, with 23 touchdown passes and 20 interceptions. ''What's important is those players have a belief in him,'' Saints Coach Sean Payton said. Although the Bears' defense has lost some of its dominance because of injuries, linebacker Lance Briggs said, ''We tweak a little, we're right back where we were.'' The Bears will have an advantage from a home crowd, and Chicago weather in January can be shocking to a dome team from a warm-weather city. Reporter's Pick: Saints New England (14-4) at Indianapolis (14-4) 6:30 p.m., CBS History favors the Patriots. They have won three of the last five Super Bowls, Coach Bill Belichick is 13-2 in playoff games and quarterback Tom Brady is 12-1. Colts quarterback Peyton Manning is 4-10 against the Patriots. In two playoff games this season, he has thrown one touchdown pass and five interceptions. Or maybe history will favor the Colts in the American Football Conference title game. They beat the Patriots 11 weeks ago, when Brady threw four interceptions, and he threw three last week against the Chargers. Still, the Patriots have won five straight games, and they always seem to come up with defensive innovations. They will need offensive fire because the Colts, who have suffered on defense all season, have turned into a defensive power. Reporter's Pick: Patriots

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 49TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS -- The Police (from far left, Stewart Copeland, Sting and Andy Summers, in 1980) will reunite to open these festivities, held at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, honoring excellence in the recording industry. Justin Timberlake will perform with the winner of ''My Grammy Moment,'' a nationwide campaign in which viewers can vote online for one of three contestants, with the winner announced during the ceremony. Mary J. Blige, Beyoncé, Christina Aguilera, Ludacris, Carrie Underwood, the Dixie Chicks, Shakira, Wyclef Jean, Gnarls Barkley and the Red Hot Chili Peppers are among the performers. Chris Brown, Lionel Richie and Smokey Robinson will pay tribute to great male R&B artists, and John Legend, John Mayer and Corinne Bailey Rae will team up for a special, smooth segment. 5 P.M. (E!) COUNTDOWN TO THE RED CARPET: THE 2007 GRAMMY AWARDS -- What the celebrities are wearing these days, and what they probably shouldn't be. 7 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- In two consecutive episodes, Ty Pennington and his team rebuild the home of Jason Thomas, an ex-Marine who helped rescue two police officers from the debris of the twin towers during the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York. Though he acted anonymously and received no credit at the time, his story became the basis for the Oliver Stone film ''World Trade Center,'' starring Nicolas Cage. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS -- Lisa is chosen to represent her school at city hall after she, ahem, embellishes her heritage as an American Indian for a class project. And watch out! Bart gets a driver's license. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SUPERSIZE CROCS -- Why is this crocodile smiling? In this ''Nature'' special, the herpetologist Romulus Whitaker looks at the reasons -- including some fairly delicious stomach content -- some crocodile species now exceed 20 feet. 9 P.M. (13, 49) DRACULA -- Honey, I'm home! In this ''Masterpiece Theater'' production, Stewart Harcourt takes Bram Stoker's dark blood-sucker to England, where he becomes a powerful figure in the lives of an unhappily married couple. Marc Warren bares his fangs in the title role, Sophia Myles plays Lucy, Stephanie Leonidas is Mina, and David Suchet portrays the vampire slayer Van Helsing. 11 P.M. (IFC) THE DREAMERS (2003). Three's not a crowd in this Bertolucci drama of cinema and passion about an American who establishes a friendship with a French brother and sister in Paris during the 1968 student riots. Louis Garrel (above left), Eva Green and Michael Pitt play the starry young lovers. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Makes the Most Of Sunday Night
summary: ABC retained the title of most-watched network Sunday night as ''Desperate Housewives'' continued to dominate the 9 p.m. hour, drawing 21.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Also on ABC, ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' remained the leader in its 8 p.m. time slot (15.8 million), while at 10 p.m. ''Brothers & Sisters'' (12.7 million), with Sally Field and Calista Flockhart, improved slightly over its ratings performance in recent weeks. Among adults 18 to 49, NBC finished a close second to ABC for the night. Its coverage of the Dallas Cowboys' victory over the Carolina Panthers averaged 17.3 million viewers, according to time-zone adjusted estimates. Also on NBC, the fourth-season premiere of ''Las Vegas'' on Friday at 9 p.m. earned 9.3 million viewers as the network ranked third for the night behind Fox's World Series coverage and CBS's lineup of ''Ghost Whisperer'' (10.8 million), ''Close to Home'' (10.8 million) and ''Numb3rs'' (11 million). NBC's new game show, ''1 vs 100,'' drew 9.5 million viewers at 8 p.m. Friday, down nearly 2.5 million viewers from its 9 p.m. performance a week earlier. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Jets (2-2) at Jacksonville (2-2) 4 p.m., CBS JETS' OFFENSE VS. THE FIRST QUARTER Chad Pennington, below, and Company have not scored a touchdown in the first quarter in the first four games. The Jets have not managed an offensive touchdown in the opening 15 minutes since Week 2 of last season, a streak of 18 games. In the first quarter against the Colts last week, the Jets had one turnover and one first down. In their last road game, at Buffalo, they had no first downs in the first quarter. CHAD PENNINGTON VS. PAUL SPICER On the Jets' first drive of the second half against the Jaguars in Week 3 last season, Spicer, a defensive end, yanked Pennington's arm as he was attempting a pass, causing a new tear in the rotator cuff of Pennington's surgically repaired throwing shoulder. Pennington returned to finish the game after his backup, Jay Fiedler, was injured, but then had season-ending surgery and missed the final 13 games. Pennington keeps a framed photograph on his desk of Spicer tugging on his arm. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)

headline: In Death Coverage, a Broadcast Rite of Passage Manages to Avoid Melodramatic
summary: Death is sad, at least in most cases. But the death of a former president has become an almost cheery television event. It's been more than 40 years since John F. Kennedy was assassinated. His successors died out of office, relatively quietly and well into old age. The passing of a retired commander in chief perks up the day with a wallop of stately special reports and bittersweet nostalgia, (plaid jackets, ''Saturday Night Live,'' détente) without undue anxiety or grieving.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- Chris Rock (right) will be James Lipton's guest tonight. Expect Mr. Lipton's usual attempts to get the nitty gritty details of his guest's childhood and influences. The two should have plenty to chat about: ''Saturday Night Live,'' Mr. Rock's experience as the host of the Academy Awards, his sitcom ''Everybody Hates Chris'' and his work in films including ''New Jack City'' and his latest project, ''I Think I Love My Wife.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Julia Louis-Dreyfus settles into her new 8:30 p.m. timeslot with back-to-back episodes. In ''Sleepless in Mar Vista'' at 8:00, she takes some sleeping pills, starts acting even more wacky than usual and later discovers that she made a few embarrassing phone calls while she was incoherent. That is followed at 8:30 by another new episode, ''Undercover Brother.'' Christine learns a big secret from Richard's brother Joe (Charles Esten), but is she likely to keep her mouth shut? 9 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- Another well-known actor joins the cast: Rick Schroder steps in as Mike Doyle, a new Counter Terrorism Unit agent who will head up Field Ops. He comes on board just in time to oversee a crucial mission. 9 P.M. (A&E) KINGS OF SOUTH BEACH -- (2007) A television movie based on the true story of Chris Troiano, a nightclub impresario who opens one of the most sizzling hotspots ever to hit the scene in Miami's South Beach and the troubles that follow. Jason Gedrick(above) is Troiano, and Donnie Wahlberg plays his best friend, Andy Burnett. With a screenplay by Nicholas Pileggi, who wrote ''Goodfellas'' and ''Casino,'' expect a whirlwind tale of models, mobsters, money and murder. 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- In this season finale, ''Walker Family,'' our new millennium Mary Poppins, Jo, helps a couple who have three children, a live-in nephew and an in- home daycare business that interferes with child rearing. 9 P.M. (Discovery) FUTUREWEAPONS -- Viewers get a glimpse into the secretive, technologically advanced and rather creepy world of military weapons development. On this new episode, ''Smart Destroyers,'' the host (and ex-Navy SEAL) Richard (Mack) Machowicz introduces super-intelligent weapons including the Protector Unmanned Surface Vehicle, a waterborne weapons system that thinks for itself, and the Squad Mission Support System robotic vehicle. Don't mess with this guy. 10 P.M. (FX) THE RICHES -- Eddie Izzard and Minnie Driver star in this new series about a larcenous family of Gypsies that strikes it rich by assuming the identities of a couple they accidentally killed and taking up residence in a posh suburban development. 10 P.M. (NBC) THE BLACK DONNELLYS -- Tommy (Jonathan Tucker, right) is plagued with guilt when Kate(Molly Schaffer), the widow of the Irish mob kingpin Huey, asks him to be host of her murdered husband's wake. When Jimmy (Thomas Guiry) appears to pay his respects, Huey's brother Dokey (Peter Greene) suspects that Jimmy may be the killer. STEVEN MCELROY

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) RHINOCEROS -- Virtually unchanged over 25 million years, the rhinoceros once roamed the earth in hordes. Today, it is one of the planet's rarest animals, with three of the remaining five species (including the white rhino, right) headed toward extinction. This ''Nature'' special follows rangers through the savannahs of South Africa, the grasslands of India and the jungles of Indonesia to examine efforts to protect rhinos from poachers and relocate them to new habitats, and peers into a fertility lab at an American zoo to find out about attempts to breed them in captivity. It also zooms in on some startling behavior in the rhinos' natural environments, including a nursery full of mothers and calves and a charge from an angry bull. 8 P.M. (BET) CELEBRATION OF GOSPEL -- '07 Steve Harvey gets spiritual as host of this evening of rafter-raising inspirational music from the Orpheum Theater in Los Angeles. Performers include Kirk Franklin, Yolanda Adams, Fantasia, Tye Tribbett, Kelly Price, Tonex, Coko, Smokie Norful, Lil' Mo, Pastor Shirley Caesar, Dr. Bobby Jones, Fred Hammond and the Caravans. Lou Gossett Jr., Quincy Jones, Blair Underwood, Gabrielle Union, Loretta Devine, Idris Elba, Derek Luke and Keke Palmer are among the presenters. The show also features a tribute to Tyler Perry for his work in gospel-themed urban theater. 8 P.M. (GSN) THE WOMEN WHO CHANGED GAME SHOWS -- Vicki Lawrence leads a survey of some of the women, including Betty White, Arlene Francis, Dr. Joyce Brothers, Anne Robinson, Meredith Vieira and Vanna White, who kept people guessing and spinning. 9 P.M. (CBS) THE VALLEY OF LIGHT -- Chris Klein stars in this Hallmark Hall of Fame movie, based on a novel by Terry Kaye, about a World War II veteran who returns to the family farm to find life in shreds. But all is not lost, as he discovers on a journey to the South, where he befriends a young widow (Gretchen Mol, above, with Mr. Klein) and a silent boy. 10 P.M. (BET) AN EVENING OF STARS: TRIBUTE TO ARETHA FRANKLIN -- In 1979, Lou Rawls, who died in January 2006, originated this annual special, which raises money for the United Negro College Fund. This year, Ms. Franklin (above) follows in the footsteps of Mr. Rawls, Quincy Jones and Stevie Wonder -- and stands on her own as the first woman -- as the recipient of the fund's Award of Excellence. Performers include Michael Bolton, Natalie Cole, Fantasia, James Ingram, Al Jarreau, Chaka Khan, Mary Mary, Smokey Robinson, Bebe Winans and Mr. Wonder Angela Bassett and Courtney B. Vance narrate vignettes that speak to the significance of historically black colleges and universities. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; The Battle for Thursday
summary: Despite the dwindling ratings for ''Game Show Marathon,'' the rest of CBS's tried-and-true Thursday lineup delivered the network a victory among total viewers. Reruns of ''CSI'' (11.1 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (10.4 million) compensated for ''Marathon,'' which brought in an audience of 6.8 million. But CBS placed third for the night among 18-to-49-year-olds, since younger adults preferred the N.B.A. finals on ABC and, second to that, Britney Spears's gum-chewing appearance on a special edition of NBC's ''Dateline.'' Basketball was broadcast live on ABC, and therefore its ratings were preliminary, but the overnight numbers showed that it drew a larger audience than Game 4 of last year's finals. NBC, which was third among viewers, showed repeats of ''My Name Is Earl'' (5.5 million) and ''The Office'' (5.1 million), ''Dateline'' (8.9 million) and the second episode of ''Windfall'' (7.8 million), the network's new scripted series. The lottery drama fell slightly from its premiere last Thursday, but beat ''Without a Trace'' at 10 p.m. in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: ADDED DUTY FOR BUCK
summary: Fox Sports is expected to announce Monday that Joe Buck, its lead N.F.L. play-by-play announcer, would also be the host of its Sunday N.F.L. pregame program. He would replace James Brown, who left earlier this year to rejoin CBS Sports. Fox is making the program a road show from the sites where Buck and Troy Aikman will call games. Buck is expected to work with Terry Bradshaw, Howie Long and Jimmy Johnson for about the first 45 minutes of each program. Buck may return for the postgame program. RICHARD SANDOMIR (NYT)

headline: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
summary: ''They talk about wanting a break with the past. Look at the Murrow film. I don't want to break with that past.'' DAN RATHER, on his longtime employer, CBS News. [B16]

headline: Debates in Senate Races
summary: Now they're talking. After sniping at one another from afar for the last few weeks, the Senate candidates in New Jersey and those in Connecticut will face one another in a series of debates in each state before the Nov. 7 election.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Couric Slips to Third Place
summary: On the fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, more evening news viewers chose to watch ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' than the broadcasts of his two main competitors, Charles Gibson on ABC and Katie Couric on CBS, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday by the networks. Mr. Williams's program drew an estimated 8.3 million viewers, more than the estimated 7.9 million who watched ''World News'' with Mr. Gibson, and the estimated 7.5 million who saw Ms. Couric, on her fifth night. All three programs were pre-empted in some parts of the West Coast on Monday by President Bush's address, and yet Mr. Williams's audience was still bigger than the average number he drew last week (about 7.1 million a night), as was Mr. Gibson's (6.9 million a night). Ms. Couric, who easily won the ratings race last week with an average of 10.2 million viewers a night, was down substantially on Monday. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Arts, Briefly; A True Survivor
summary: Terry Deitz, an airline pilot, has been unbeatable on this season's ''Survivor'' on CBS, having succeeded in all four individual immunity challenges (competitions that prevent the winner from being voted off during that episode). The streak was a necessity for Mr. Deitz; otherwise, he would surely have been voted off by now. Thursday's episode perked up in the ratings compared with its record in recent weeks, bringing in 17.1 million viewers in the Nielsen estimates. After ''Survivor'' won the 8 p.m. hour, CBS's ''CSI'' (26.9 million) had a ''Rashomon''-like structure, with each detective reconstructing a crime scene that had been robbed of evidence. ''CSI'' crushed its competition in the 9 p.m. hour, most notably ABC's ''American Inventor'' (7.3 million) and NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' (8.9 million) and ''The Office'' (7.7 million). The ratings of those two NBC comedies among viewers 18 to 49 have gradually declined since they moved to Thursdays in January. At 10 p.m., ''Without a Trace'' (17.9 million) gave CBS another hourly win, and handed the network a big victory on the first night of the May sweeps period. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) 29TH ANNUAL KENNEDY CENTER HONORS -- No wonder they're smiling. Caroline Kennedy is host of this ceremony, taped on Dec. 3, celebrating the lifetime achievements of (from above left) the conductor Zubin Mehta, the director Steven Spielberg, the singers Dolly Parton and Smokey Robinson, and the composer and producer Andrew Lloyd Webber. 8 P.M. (History) LAST DAYS ON EARTH -- Just in time for dire New Year's predictions, a scientific evaluation of the seven deadliest threats to humanity, including black holes, artificial intelligence, supervolcanoes, asteroid strikes, nuclear war, disease and climate change. 8 P.M. (Sundance) OFFICE TIGERS -- They call them B.P.O's, for business process outsourcing - the so-called ''back offices'' that American companies open in developing countries where costs are low and ambition is high. This four-part documentary series travels to southern India to capture the lives of the staff at Office Tigers, a multinational business-services company that provides high-end, low-cost support work to the world's top legal firms, investment banks and consultancies. 8 P.M. (NBC) IN THE SHADOW OF THE AMERICAN DREAM -- In this ''Tom Brokaw Reports'' special, Mr. Brokaw (above) travels to the Colorado Rockies between the resort towns of Aspen and Vail, an area that has seen an influx of Hispanics, mostly from Mexico, to explore the realities -- economic, social and political -- surrounding illegal immigration. 9 P.M. (ABC) BIG DAY -- An amply endowed bridesmaid threatens to upstage the bride. 9 P.M. (Biography) TOTAL EXCESS: THE ROBBER BARRONS -- A new series devoted to the ways the rich are not like you and me. 9 P.M. (VH1) INSANE CELEBRITY REAL ESTATE '06 -- Because celebrities apparently need large houses to house their large egos. 10 P.M. (HBO) REAL SPORTS WITH BRYANT GUMBEL -- A jockey without medical insurance is the equivalent of a Nascar driver without a seatbelt. Yet, for the men and women who race 1,200-pound thoroughbreds, a helmet is often their only coverage. Tonight, Mr. Gumbel returns to this story, which he first explored in April, before tackling the disturbing weight gains of high school linemen; a runner who used a stolen identity to get into Princeton University; and the hard-knock life of Bill Johnson (above), the first American to win an Olympic gold medal in downhill skiing. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Miami (1-4) at Jets (2-3) 4:15 p.m., CBS ERIC MANGINI vs. NICK SABAN After Saban, below, became coach of the Dolphins, he tried to lure Mangini from New England to be his defensive coordinator. Their relationship goes back to 1995, when they worked under Bill Belichick in Cleveland. ''Obviously we come from the same tree, the same root system, professionally and philosophically,'' Saban said. This will be no grudge match. Of Saban, Mangini said, ''I respect him as much as I can respect any head coach in the way he approaches things.'' D'BRICKASHAW FERGUSON vs. JASON TAYLOR The crash course that is Ferguson's rookie season continues, with Miami's Taylor, a defensive end who has 96 1/2 career sacks, serving as this week's roving instructor. Ferguson, the Jets' left tackle, has squared off against Dwight Freeney and Paul Spicer, with mixed results. As Pete Kendall, a Virginia graduate who is Ferguson's linemate, said, ''It's certainly different than the A.C.C.'' Ferguson's approach to facing what amounts to a murderers' row of defensive ends is to play as if he were wearing blinders. ''To get caught up in what I did last week or what I didn't do last week would not put me in the best position to play well this week,'' he said. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)

headline: Arts Briefly; 'Dancing With the Stars' Enjoys the Playoffs
summary: With baseball playoffs pre-empting ''House'' on Fox, ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' carried the first half of primetime Tuesday unscathed. The show averaged 18.3 million viewers over 90 minutes, lifting ABC to No. 1 for the night, according to Nielsen's estimates. But ABC lost steam again at 9:30 with its new Ted Danson comedy, ''Help Me Help You'' (10.4 million). NBC's ''Friday Night Lights,'' the critically acclaimed new series from Peter Berg, made a weak debut at 8 (7.2 million) -- the lowest-rated premiere of any new drama on the four major networks this fall. However, the combination of ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (12.0 million) and ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.2 million) helped NBC nearly best ABC for the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS had a similarly up-and-down night. While its dramas ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.5 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (13.2 million) both posted 10 percent growth over a week before, the audience for ''Smith'' eroded further to 8.4 million viewers. At deadline yesterday, Nielsen's time-zone-adjusted estimates of the Detroit Tigers and New York Yankees game on Fox were unavailable. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Viacom Asks YouTube to Remove Clips
summary: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded yesterday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming. Viacom, along with other major media companies, including the News Corporation and NBC Universal, has become increasingly frustrated with YouTube as it has amassed a vast library of copyrighted clips, placed on the site by its users.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: TELECOM DEAL IN ITALY -- Telefónica and a group of Italian investors have agreed to pay about $5.6 billion for an 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, which would let Telefónica, Europe's second-largest telecommunications provider, enter the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America. [Page C1.] ALL ME, ALL THE TIME -- The social networking phenomenon is leaving the confines of the personal computer. Powerful new mobile devices are allowing people to send round-the-clock updates about their vacations, their moods or their latest haircut. [C1.] A NEW FILM RISK -- If the horror at Virginia Tech has changed the chemistry of America's popular culture, those who count box-office receipts at Lionsgate will be among the first to know. The independent studio still plans to release on June 8 its ''Hostel: Part II,'' about the torture killing of college students. [C1.] SPEAKING VIAGRA -- In promoting Viagra, its impotence treatment, Pfizer has irritated regulators with its wink-and-a-nod ads. Now it has ads feature middle-aged men and women talking in a made-up language, save for one word. [C1.] YAHOO MAKES A DEAL -- Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace. [C2.] U.N.'S SOLE ACCREDITED BLOGGER -- Matthew Lee, left, is the only blogger at the United Nations with media credentials, entitling him to free office space and access to briefings and news conferences. The United Nations is one of the few institutions of size and importance that allow bloggers not affiliated with larger, more traditional media companies. [C6.] THE FIVE-MINUTE 'STARSKY' -- The Sony Corporation has shrunk episodes of '70s and '80s television series to three and a half to five minutes, hoping to create a new business in retooling old shows for a new era of entertainment. [C4.] COMPETITIVE VOCABULARY -- Now that spelling bees have been turned into a hit Broadway show and crossword puzzles into a movie, the publishers of the American Heritage dictionary are hoping to create a cultural moment with a competitive game about word definitions. [C4.] ALL YOUR STUFF, ONLINE -- At least three companies have emerged in recent months with the aim of helping people catalog and value their possessions and post them online. The plan is to attract millions of people, then find retailers who want to sell them more items to go along with their possessions. [C8.] MORE GARDEN THAN GUN -- The title of Garden & Gun, a new lifestyle magazine from Charleston, S.C., might not have raised eyebrows had it not been for the fact that the premiere issue hit newsstands just days before the shootings at Virginia Tech on April 16. [C6.] GOOGLING STATE DATA -- Four states have joined forces with Google to make information from their Web sites more directly accessible through Internet searches. [C8.] INVESTING IN CLEAN ENERGY -- Money flowing into alternative energy companies is raising the threat of a bubble, according to a research firm, but investors may be overlooking other clean technologies. [C7.] A PLUG FOR PHONE LEAKS -- Drumming up business would seem to be an easy task for those who sell encrypted cellphones in Italy. All they have to do is browse the major newspapers, looking for leaked telephone conversations. [C6.] EX-ABC NEWSMAN MOVING TO TIME -- Mark Halperin, the longtime political director of ABC News and a pioneer of online reporting, is moving to Time magazine. [C2.] ADS FOR INTERNET RADIO -- A start-up company, TargetSpot, is trying to turn the nascent field of Internet radio into a viable business, and CBS Radio is its first customer. [C10.] CHINA TIGHTENS MONEY AGAIN -- For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. [C2.] BEST PLACES TO BLOG ABOUT -- Clinton Hill in Brooklyn is the most blogged-about neighborhood in America, says a Web site that found a link between gentrification and the number of people who feel compelled to think out loud about the changes in their backyards. [C6.] WHAT GOES AROUND -- The pop culture magazine Radar has accused a Chilean magazine of ripping off its story on ''Toxic Bachelors,'' but freely admits that it borrowed the concept from other sources, like a book by Danielle Steele and the ''Sex and the City'' series. [C6.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; Dance Wins for Fox
summary: Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' was Wednesday's most-watched show, with 10.4 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. The mean-spirited dance competition led Fox to a victory in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49; it also drew the highest 18-to-34 ratings of any show so far this summer season. But NBC was No. 1 in households for the night. Its two-hour ''Dateline: To Catch a Predator'' delivered 7.8 million viewers, and a ''Law & Order'' rerun brought in 7.9 million. CBS's ''Game Show Marathon'' is proving to be no ''Deal or No Deal'' ratings-wise. It attracted 6.9 million viewers at 8 p.m. and dragged down the rest of CBS's schedule, reruns of ''Criminal Minds'' (8 million) and ''CSI: New York'' (9.3 million). Sunday's season finale of ''The Sopranos'' drew 8.9 million viewers. That was a drop from its last season-ender, in June 2004, which brought in an audience of just under 11 million. The show returned this year after a long hiatus. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Soaps Deliver Their Demographic
summary: For the May ratings sweeps, ABC's full daytime lineup, which includes ''The View,'' was No. 1 among women 18 to 49, the demographic advertisers try to reach during the day. And for the network's soap opera schedule -- ''All My Children,'' ''One Life to Live'' and ''General Hospital'' -- it was the sixth consecutive sweeps period that ABC won in the 18-to-49 age group. Among total viewers ABC's daytime dramas delivered an average audience of 3.38 million, which was second to CBS's 3.88 million. CBS's ''Young & the Restless'' was the top-rated soap opera among 18-to-49-year-old women, but over all, the network tied with NBC for second place in that demographic. The History Channel's Memorial Day broadcast of ''Washington the Warrior,'' an examination of George Washington as a military leader, brought in 2.47 million viewers. Yesterday Nielsen Media Research did not release its overnight ratings for Sunday because of what it said was an error in processing them. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Sharker Tops Stalker
summary: On NBC's ''Medium'' on Monday, the 1980's teenage idol Molly Ringwald, below, was a guest star, playing a blind woman who was being stalked. In Nielsen's estimates for this sweeps night, the psychic drama drew 10.03 million viewers, which was good enough for second place. But Ms. Ringwald's appearance competed with the No. 1 show of the night, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (18.68 million), in which viewers saw a human foot yanked from a dead shark. CBS was first for the night among total viewers, but second to Fox in the 18-to-49 demographic. In that age group CBS was dragged down, as it often is, by ''King of Queens'' (7.54 million) and ''How I Met Your Mother'' (7.34 million). Filling the 8 p.m. hour, those sitcoms placed fourth among adults 18 to 49, behind NBC's ''Deal or No Deal,'' Fox's ''Prison Break'' and ABC's ''Wife Swap.'' And ''Mother'' barely scraped by the second half of the WB's ''Seventh Heaven,'' beating the soon-to-conclude family drama by only two-tenths of a ratings point in the demographic advertisers pay a premium to reach. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Before the Fall: TV of Seasons (Just) Past
summary: THE extended game of Russian roulette known as the fall television season got under way this week with the early start of the Fox network's baseball-contorted schedule. But the real rush of the broadcast networks' season and series premieres won't come for another month yet. For the intervening dog days of cable, when the best bet on any given night is likely to be a ''House'' rerun or a special episode of ''Trick My Truck,'' DVD's may be the best way to get your television fix. So here, plucked from the flood of TV shows making their way onto their video shelves, are some current and soon-to-be released discs that caught the eyes of writers for The New York Times. The shows range from comedies to dramas to cartoons to classical music, with an emphasis on box sets of seasons that have only recently ended. That reflects the marketplace: a glance at the various (and often highly contradictory) charts of DVD sales demonstrates that while home entertainment companies keep releasing lovingly packaged collections of classic shows, people keep buying the new stuff. And there's also an emphasis on shows from HBO. That reflects the fact that people who write about TV like to write about HBO. Happy clicking. SURFACE: THE COMPLETE SERIES (Universal, $49.98) The often disparaging chatter about the fact that there were three new alien-invasion shows on last fall's schedule -- one each on ABC, CBS and NBC -- obscured the fact that two of them were pretty good (and that the third, ''Threshold'' on CBS, starred Carla Gugino, which made up for a lot). The first and, as of now, final seasons of all three are out on DVD this month: ''Threshold: The Complete Series'' (Paramount, $54.99), ''Invasion: The Complete Series'' (Warner, $59.98) and the gem of the bunch, the 15 episodes of the NBC series ''Surface.''

headline: Arts, Briefly; N.B.A. Scores Victory for ABC
summary: In the preliminary Nielsen estimates for Thursday's ratings, ABC scored a rare victory for the night in households and in the 18-to-49 demographic because of Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals, in which the Dallas Mavericks beat the Miami Heat. CBS, led by reruns of ''CSI'' (12.37 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (11.1 million), appeared to be No. 1 among total viewers but was dragged down by ''Game Show Marathon'' at 8 (6.84 million). CBS placed fourth for the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox was second behind ABC in that age group: a rerun of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (6.37 million) was followed by a new episode (10 million). And NBC broadcast four repeats of ''My Name Is Earl,'' along with the premiere of ''Windfall.'' That be-careful-what-you-wish-for lottery drama delivered 8.98 million viewers at 10 and beat ''Without a Trace'' in the 18-to-49 demographic. But it lost some of its audience from the first half-hour to the second, which can sometimes be a harbinger of failure. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO -- Just in time for the series's return on Feb. 21, this hourlong primer, which gives a recap of the first 11 episodes -- from the day the bomb went off in view of the Kansas prairie to the reappearance of Emily's fiancé, Roger (Christopher Wiehl, above, with Ashley Scott). 8 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS -- In tonight's episode, which carries a warning about graphic language, tensions escalate as the black players on the Panthers team refuse to play unless Mac (Blue Decker) is fired for his comments -- leaving Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) torn between losing one of his best coaches and giving in to his players' demands. 8 P.M. (ABC) GEORGE LOPEZ -- Just how many people can you offend at once? Benny needs George's testimony to get out of jail when her mother (Rita Moreno), defense attorney (Adam West) and judge (Marilyn Milian) all turn against her. 8 P.M. (11) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK -- The remaining two teams prepare for the big elimination in tonight's season finale by revealing aspects of themselves that they've never before shown. One even makes a personal sacrifice that turns the competition upside down. But what's up with those unexpected visitors? 8 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICA'S BALLROOM CHALLENGE -- Sweeping ballgowns. Men in tails. Formal, regal dancing. These are the characteristics of the International Standard, ballroom's oldest style, with steps that date back hundreds of years to the royal courts of Europe. Tonight, the couples dance the waltz, tango, Viennese waltz, foxtrot and quickstep, all of which must be performed in the closed position -- meaning that the man and woman must remain in contact at all times. 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE KNIGHTS OF PROSPERITY -- Make that knights in shining armor. The guys find their mission veering off track as they try to rescue Esperanza, who is being held captive at the diner by her exboyfriend. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- The competition officially begins as judges reveal the top 24 semifinalists. 9 P.M. (13) THE HIDDEN EPIDEMIC: HEART DISEASE IN AMERICA -- Larry King examines the myths, risks and warning signs of heart disease, and offers new ways to predict and treat it before it becomes lifethreatening. 9:30 P.M. (Sundance) IN SHORT: THE ART OF SEDUCTION -- Nine brief films, originally co-produced for video cell phones by the National Film Board of Canada, look at the more unbridled side of human desire. 10 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Hurley enlists Charlie to help him get the truth out of Desmond (Henry Ian Cusick, left), who has been acting strangely ever since the hatch imploded. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- The cover model of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, on newsstands today, reveals herself. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: KEY MATCHUPS
summary: Houston (2-5) at Giants (5-2) 1 p.m., CBS DAVID CARR VS. GIANTS' PASS RUSH No quarterback has been sacked as many times as David Carr, below, has in recent years, but the Texans have reduced those numbers considerably this season. Still, Carr was benched last week against Tennessee because he fumbled twice on sacks and threw an interception into tight coverage. The Texans have a turnover margin of minus-9 (14 giveaways, 5 takeaways), tied for worst in that category. Carr has contributed to that statistic, losing 5 of 10 fumbles.
