headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) CHINA FROM THE INSIDE -- For all of China's vaunted power, much of the country remains a mystery to the outside world. This four-part documentary travels from the Great Wall (above), temples in Tibet and the border areas of Muslim Xinjiang to courtrooms, newspaper offices and a women's labor camp to paint of a portrait of its 1.3 billion people in all their contradictions. Tonight's episodes look at the Communist Party, at 9; and the country's women, who have one of the highest suicide rates in the world, at 10. The series continues on Jan. 17. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SCIENCE INVESTIGATORS -- This special, one of three being considered for development as a new science series by PBS, aims to put a 21st-century spin on the age-old subject. Among tonight's topics: Neanderthal DNA, knuckleball pitches, iPods powered by bacteria, a better bionic arm for a veteran of the Iraq War and an electric racecar. 8 P.M. (CBS) ARMED AND FAMOUS -- Whom, exactly, would you really trust these celebrities to protect and defend? Erik Estrada, La Toya Jackson, Jack Osbourne, Jason (Wee-Man) Acuna and Trish Stratus undergo police training to become reserve officers in Muncie, Ind., and then go on patrol with the officers who traditionally ride with the new trainees. Mr. Estrada (above) brings the most experience to his new role from his old days as Officer Poncherello in 119 episodes of ''CHiPs.'' 9 P.M. (Major Networks) PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS -- President Bush unveils his new strategy for the war in Iraq. 9 P.M. (Oxygen) TEASE -- Lisa Rinna, she of the artfully tousled do, is host of this new competition series, in which two hairstylists face off in each episode in snip-and-blow challenges for the ultimate goal of competing against a master stylist. First up: a celebrity look-alike contest. 10 P.M. (TVLand) TV LAND MYTHS AND LEGENDS -- What former lover inspired Carly Simon to write ''You're So Vain''? Is the ghost of a 9-year-old boy lurking in the movie ''Three Men and a Baby''? And did the cast of ''Green Acres'' really barbecue and eat the pig that played Arnold Ziffel? This new series aims to separate fact from fiction on these and other burning questions of our time. 10 P.M. (Oxygen) THE JANICE DICKINSON MODELING AGENCY -- When the cat was away, the mice appear to have played. Or so Ms. Dickinson (right) discovers when she returns from her summer vacation in this season premiere to find the agency is disarray. And just who are all those new models knocking on her door? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) TSUNAMI, THE AFTERMATH -- A young couple searches for their child. A Thai survivor tries to prevent developers from seizing the land his village is built on. An overwhelmed British official finds his faith in the system has disintegrated. These are just a few of the stories in this fictional re-creation of events surrounding the tsunami that ravaged Thailand in December 2004. Local residents were interviewed for their input prior to production on this twopart movie, which was filmed in Phuket and Khao Lak, Thailand. The all-star cast includes Tim Roth, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Sophie Okonedo (above, with Mr. Ejiofor), Hugh Bonneville, Gina McKee, Samrit Machielsen, Grirggiat Punpiputt and Toni Collette. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE AMAZING RACE 10 -- The rain in Spain: the final three leave Barcelona and head toward the finish line. 8 P.M. (TLC) HOUSE OF TINY TERRORS -- Three families try to regain control of their terrible toddlers by moving for six days into a custom-designed house, where they will be supervised by a clinical psychologist. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) SANTA BABY -- Youknow-who doesn't always know best. In this madefor- television comedy, Jenny McCarthy (right) plays Mary Class, a Type A businesswoman whose success is recognized by everyone but Dad. But when her father, aka Santa Claus, falls ill and has trouble making good on his promises, Mary returns home, aka the North Pole, to help modernize operations. George Wendt is the man under the white beard. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) ONLINE AND IN DANGER? HOW TO PROTECT YOURSELF IN THE VIRTUAL WORLD -- According to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, 25 million children either have been or are currently online. Out of those, 71 percent of teenagers have been contacted by someone they don't know, yet fewer than one in five have informed a parent or guardian. In this ''Nick News'' special, Linda Ellerbee and experts like Parry Aftab, executive director of WiredSafety, look at ways to protect children from predators. The TeenAngels, a group of teenage volunteers, offer tips on safe surfing. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) CHRISTMAS ON CHESTNUT STREET A greedy storekeeper learns the true meaning of Christmas, and falls in love in the process, after her employee starts a holiday competition. 9 P.M. (HGTV) WHAT'S WITH THAT CHRISTMAS HOUSE? -- The good, the bad and the ugly. 'Nuff said. 9 P.M. (Showtime) SLEEPER CELL: AMERICAN TERROR -- A new cell is uncovered in this eight-hour series, shown each night through Dec. 17. Tonight, the F.B.I. agent Darwyn Al-Sayeed (Michael Ealy, left) tries to begin a new life. Then he feels the pull. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Springer Loses, ABC Wins
summary: Jerry Springer was finally voted off ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' on Wednesday, as the show earned a series-best 19.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. (Below, Mr. Springer with Kym Johnson.) ABC ranked No. 1 for the night, faring particularly well among adults 18 to 49. In that important demographic, ABC posted a 57 percent lead at 9 with ''Lost'' (16.8 million). CBS's ''Criminal Minds,'' the No. 2 show in that hour, still managed to draw 16.6 million total viewers, helping the network finish a close second in that category for the night. CBS also got a boost from ''CSI: New York,'' which dominated the 10 p.m. hour (17.1 million), while ABC's new drama in that hour, ''The Nine,'' drew its smallest audience to date (8 million). NBC placed third for the night, as its new comedies, ''30 Rock'' (6 million) and ''Twenty Good Years'' (5.4 million), once again finished behind CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.5 million) among adults 18 to 49. With the World Series in rain delay, Fox was fourth in viewers for the night, broadcasting repeats of ''The War at Home,'' with Michael Rapaport, which averaged 5.5 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Dance Outdraws Rock
summary: The conservative pundit Tucker Carlson got the ax on Wednesday night from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show, which included a surprise appearance from the singer Tom Jones. The show drew 16.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, putting ABC on top at 8, far above the conclusion of CBS's ''Rock Star: Supernova,'' in which the band crowned the goth rocker Lukas Rossi, right, its lead singer. The ''Rock Star'' finale drew 7.1 million viewers, second to ABC among adults 18 to 49, but behind in total viewers to Fox's ''Bones'' (8.4 million) and NBC's predator-catching ''Dateline'' (7.1 million). A second ''Dateline'' at 9 featured an interview with the teacher Debra Lafave, who discussed her relationship with a 14-year-old student. It led for the hour, with 10.7 million viewers, besting ''Justice'' on Fox (7.54 million), a repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' on CBS (9 million), and two half-hour ''Sneak Peek'' previews on ABC (9.1 million for comedy and reality shows, 6 million for dramas). At 10, a special ''Salute to Jimmy Kimmel Live!'' on ABC held up poorly (4.4 million) against repeats of CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (9.9 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order'' (8.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; President and First Lady Give Thanks on 'Idol'
summary: It may have been Bon Jovi night on ''American Idol'' Tuesday, but temporarily upstaging the rocker were President Bush and his wife, Laura. The first couple made a taped appearance on the show to thank viewers for helping raise $70 million during the ''Idol Gives Back'' charity drive last week. The latest installment of Fox's singing competition dominated the ratings as usual, drawing 25.8 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox easily won the night over all, as ''House'' led the 9 p.m. hour by a similarly wide margin, attracting 21.3 million viewers. In a competitive three-way race for second place Tuesday, CBS maintained a slim edge over both ABC and NBC. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show at 9 (15.8 million) tied NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' at 10 (11.3 million) as the night's third highest rated show among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fox and NBC Duke it Out
summary: With its combination of ''Prison Break'' and ''24,'' Fox edged ahead of NBC on Monday to win the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Prison Break'' matched a season's best 9.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., while the sixth hour of ''24'' earned 14 million viewers to lead the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers ahead of NBC's ''Heroes'' (13.6 million). ''Heroes'' did remain the night's highest-rated show in the 18 to 49 demographic, ahead of second-place ''24.'' For the night, NBC outdrew Fox by a half million total viewers. Its game show at 8, ''Deal or No Deal,'' claimed the title of most-watched show on Monday (16.9 million), but the 10 o'clock hour remained NBC's weakest, as ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' attracted 7 million viewers opposite a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (13.4 million). CBS broadcast reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 and finished third over all. ABC was fourth, despite new episodes of ''Supernanny'' at 9 (8.7 million) and ''What About Brian'' at 10 (5.7 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' and President Win for Fox
summary: On the night of President Bush's State of the Union address, the ''American Idol'' judges kicked off prime time in Memphis with imposing ratings as usual. According to Nielsen's estimates, which do not account for time zone discrepancies due to interruptions for the president's live speech, the series yielded 31.2 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour Tuesday, significantly ahead of second place ''NCIS'' on CBS (14.3 million). As a result, Fox retained a substantial lead going into State of the Union programming at 9. Ratings for the 49-minute address weren't immediately available, but preliminary approximations show Fox's coverage on top, followed by NBC and CBS in a close race for second, and ABC in fourth. On Sunday, ''Ocean's Deadliest,'' the documentary Steve Irwin was filming when he was killed, attracted 3.2 million viewers. It was carried on two cable channels, Discovery (1.7 million) and Animal Planet (1.5 million), from 8 p.m. to 9:30. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (HBO) RUN GRANNY RUN In January 1999, at the age of 89, Doris Haddock, left, laced up her sneakers and trekked across America for 14 months to support campaign-finance reform. Five years later, at 94, she jumped at the chance to become the Democratic nominee in the United States Senate race in New Hampshire, running against Judd Gregg, an incumbent Republican. This documentary by Marlo Poras follows Granny D, as Ms. Haddock likes to be known, campaigning in 2004, when she learned not only to talk the talk but to walk the walk. 8:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Jack (Alec Baldwin) heads General Electric off at the pass by hiring his own private investigator (Steve Buscemi). And Jenna (Jane Krakowski) discovers to her horror that she is starting to lose weight.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Twice-Told Tales Cost ABC
summary: With ABC's usually commanding Sunday-night lineup in repeats, CBS was the most-watched network for the evening. But afternoon football on Fox, which spilled into prime time, gave Fox the lead among adults 18 to 49, while NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' coverage of the Seattle Seahawks' nail-biting victory over the Denver Broncos finished the night in second place in that category. CBS outdrew ABC in both the 9 and 10 o'clock time slots, according to Nielsen's estimates, as CBS's ''Cold Case'' (14.2 million viewers) and ''Without a Trace'' (14.1 million) surpassed ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' (12 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' (6.9 million). But at 8, CBS's ''Amazing Race 10'' (10.7 million) could not defeat ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' repeat (12.7 million). On Friday night ABC ranked first over all with a broadcast of the Robert Zemeckis film ''The Polar Express'' from 8 to 10. Also on Friday, a special two-hour episode of NBC's ''Las Vegas'' earned a season high 10.3 million viewers from 9 to 11, leading the 10 o'clock hour and giving NBC a second-place finish for the night. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Stars Fall for ABC
summary: CBS won the title of most-watched network on Tuesday, as ABC fell to fourth in total viewers. The victory was limited, however, as CBS ranked behind ABC in fourth among adults ages 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. Even at 8 p.m., when CBS's ''NCIS'' garnered a season high of 17.9 million viewers, ABC's special, ''A Charlie Brown Christmas'' (13 million), outperformed it among adults 18 to 49. Fox won the night in that category, mainly thanks to ''House'' at 9 (17.2 million), which overshadowed the competition, including ABC's premiere of ''Big Day'' (7.6 million). At 10, NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.6 million) remained on top, ahead of ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (9.8 million) and CBS's ''3 Lbs'' (7.9 million). Meanwhile, the CW posted its best Tuesday of the year with season's-best ratings for ''Gilmore Girls'' at 8 (4.8 million) and ''Veronica Mars'' at 9 (3.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Grey' Leads for ABC
summary: ''Grey's Anatomy'' outdrew its 9 p.m. competition on Thursday on CBS, NBC and Fox combined, as ABC went on to dominate the night over all. According to Nielsen's estimates, this medical drama drew 22.9 million viewers, its second-largest audience since September. ABC also led in total viewers at 8 p.m. with ''Ugly Betty'' (13.4 million), while at 10, ''Men in Trees'' (10.3 million) edged out a repeat of CBS's ''Shark'' (10.2 million) to finish second behind NBC's ''ER'' (12.1 million). Among adults 18 to 49, NBC ranked No. 2 for the night, thanks to ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (10.9 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (10.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) PUSHING DAISIESLee Pace plays Ned, a young pie baker with a gift for bringing people (and fruit) back to life with the lift of a finger -- and sending them back to death in the same way. He's found out by Emerson Cod (Chi McBride, above center, with Mr. Pace and Ellen Greene), a private eye who enlists Ned's help in solving murder cases so that Emerson can collect the rewards. And then there's Chuck (Anna Friel), Ned's childhood sweetheart, whom he brought back to life after she was murdered. If only he could touch her. 8 P.M. (2) WIRED SCIENCE Spun off from Wired magazine, this new series looks at science and technology in segments from around the globe, starting with a report from Estonia on a cyberattack that shut down the country's banks and newspapers, a look at cardiac surgery performed by a robot and an interview with Paul Kedrosky, a venture capitalist with new ideas in technology.

headline: Hey, I Know That Guy!
summary: What does it mean to be the front-runner at a very early stage in a presidential campaign? Well, polling in the summer of 2003 showed that Joseph I. Lieberman and Gen. Wesley K. Clark were the preferred candidates among Democrats. John Kerry, who would eventually win the party's nomination, remained well back in the Democratic pack in the polls until he won in Iowa and New Hampshire in January 2004. Only about 10 percent of voters in a New York Times/CBS News poll in October 1991 could give an opinion of Bill Clinton, good or bad. What national polls are measuring, mostly, at this stage is name recognition, which may or may not mean anything when it comes to winning over the voters.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Classy Debut for Fox Quiz
summary: ''Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?'' -- the Fox quiz show from the ''Survivor'' creator Mark Burnett, which derives its questions from elementary school textbooks -- made its debut on Tuesday to the largest audience ever for a series premiere on Fox. Featuring the comedian Jeff Foxworthy as host, ''Are You Smarter'' attracted 26.6 million viewers at 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. It owed some of its ratings success to being scheduled directly after Fox's ''American Idol,'' which dominated from 8 to 9:30 with 30.4 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night, and NBC was third. ABC finished in fourth place, as the ABC News special ''To Iraq and Back: Bob Woodruff Reports'' drew 10.1 million viewers in the 10 p.m. hour, ranking behind CBS's repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' (10.5 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (11.7 million). In the cable news race for February, all three channels posted increases from a year ago: among adults ages 25 to 54 in prime time, Fox News saw a 19 percent increase in viewers (to 408,000 from 342,000), CNN was up 28 percent (to 244,000 from 190,000) and MSNBC improved 20 percent (to 183,000 from 153,000). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Thursday Is 'Anatomy' Day
summary: On the first Thursday of February sweeps, ''Grey's Anatomy'' drew 23.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, making ABC No. 1 for the night. ABC also led at 8 with ''Ugly Betty'' (14 million), and among adults 18 to 49 shared first place in that hour with NBC's comedies ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (10.7 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (10.1 million). ABC's 10 o'clock offering, ''Men in Trees,'' came in third with 10.7 million viewers, losing 3.5 million viewers over its last half-hour. CBS ranked No. 2 for the night, and had the No. 2 program, an episode of ''CSI'' at 9 (21.3 million). A ''CSI'' rerun at 8 earned 12.2 million viewers, and at 10 CBS's ''Shark'' (14.1 million) expanded its advantage over NBC's ''ER'' (11.8 million). NBC came in third over all. Among adults 18 to 49, ''ER'' remained on top in its time slot, but ''Scrubs'' at 9 (6.9 million) and ''30 Rock'' at 9:30 (5.7 million) performed poorly. Fox was a distant fourth, just ahead of the CW. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TRANSACTIONS
summary: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX--Placed INF Alex Cintron on the bereavement list. Recalled INF Andy Gonzalez from Charlotte (IL). DETROIT TIGERS--Optioned RHP Aquilino Lopez to Toledo (IL). Purchased the contract of RHP Virgil Vasquez from Toledo. OAKLAND ATHLETICS--Recalled LHP Dallas Braden from Sacramento (PCL). Designated INF Todd Walker for assignment. TORONTO BLUE JAYS--Recalled INF Ryan Roberts from Syracuse (IL). N.F.L. JETS--Signed FB Jesse Allen, RB Alvin Banks, DT Mike DeVito, DB Caleb Hendrix, DE Matt King, OL Dominic Moran, WR Dustin Osborn, S Leonard Peters, QB Brett Ratliff, OL Nick Smith, RB Kyle Steffes, DE Jason Trusnik, OL Andrew Wicker and LB Mark Zalewski. BUFFALO BILLS--Signed CB Riley Swanson. Released DL LaRon Harris. COLLEGE MICHIGAN STATE--Named Shane Clipfell women's assistant basketball coach.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Crushes The Competition
summary: Fox dominated the ratings once again on Tuesday as the San Antonio auditions on ''American Idol'' had 33.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Fox's ''House'' followed at 9 and attracted 25 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, the network outperformed CBS, NBC, ABC and the CW combined. CBS finished a distant second for the night. Its Navy-themed criminal procedural, ''NCIS,'' drew 16.2 million viewers at 8, while ''The Unit'' at 9 earned 12.3 million viewers. A second episode of ''The Unit'' at 10 (10.4 million) ranked second in its time slot behind NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (13.4 million). NBC was third for the night. On Saturday the two-episode debut of Nickelodeon's new ''mockumentary'' comedy series, ''The Naked Brothers Band,'' drew 3.5 million viewers at 8:30 and 3.8 million viewers at 9. Among 6- to 11-year-olds it was the highest-rated Nickelodeon premiere in seven years. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Today in Business
summary: FALLOUT ON WALL STREET Analysts and bankers say the underlying problems at Citigroup and Merrill Lynch have been in the making for months and will take many more months to fully play out. THE SMALLER SCREEN Cyriac Roeding's position as executive vice president of CBS Mobile, a unit of the television network's interactive division, puts him at the vortex of Hollywood's new media revolution. [C1.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; Growing 'Grey's'
summary: A two-hour ''Grey's Anatomy,'' half of which laid the groundwork for a possible spinoff, made ABC No. 1 in Thursday's ratings. The episode, in which Addison (Kate Walsh) encounters a new cast of flirtatious doctors in a Santa Monica clinic, attracted 21 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, doing especially well among adults 18 to 49. CBS ranked second over all, winning the 8 p.m. hour with ''Survivor: Fiji'' (10.7 million) and coming in second with ''CSI'' at 9 (18.9 million) and ''Shark'' at 10 (12.7 million). NBC was third, filling two hours with episodes of ''My Name is Earl'' (7.6 million), ''The Office'' (7.4 million) and ''Scrubs'' (4.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Jordin Wins for Fox Too
summary: Jordin Sparks was not the only winner on Wednesday, the final night of the television season. As this 17-year-old singer took home the sixth ''American Idol'' crown, the finale's predictably commanding ratings helped make Fox the highest-rated network for the season among adults 18 to 49. Fox has won that title for three consecutive years. Nielsen estimated approximately 29.5 million viewers tuned in to the show's final installment from 8 to 10, down slightly from its performance last year but far ahead of ABC's finale of ''Lost,'' which ranked second for the night. The ''Lost'' finale had 13.7 million viewers from 9 to 11, in line with its performance this season but down more sharply than ''Idol,'' compared with a year ago, falling 17 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS finished third with reruns on the night; NBC ranked fourth as its repeat broadcast of ''Saturday Night Live in the '90s: Pop Culture Nation'' drew just 4.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 2007 AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS Jimmy Kimmel is host of the 35th edition of this show, created by Dick Clark, that rewards musicians on the basis of record sales and, for the first time, online voting. Nominees include Justin Timberlake, Beyoncé, at left, Linkin Park and Daughtry, with three nods each. Alicia Keys, Avril Lavigne, Nicole Scherzinger, Celine Dion, Daughtry, Fergie, Duran Duran, Chris Brown, will.i.am, Maroon 5 and Rihanna are scheduled to perform live from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. 8 P.M. (26) THE BEAUTY OF UGLY Mother Nature wasn't necessarily being cruel when she planted that attention-getting nose on the proboscis monkey or devised the warthog's protective covering. From the ''Nature'' people, this documentary examines the functional beauty of some of the wild kingdom's most unattractive inhabitants, including star-nosed moles, lappet-faced vultures, tapeworms, dung beetles, Indian storks, elephant seal bulls and needle-toothed viperfish.

headline: Those Young People, They're So Unpredictable
summary: Young Americans defy easy political labels. Findings of a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll suggest that the presidential candidates will face challenges as they seek support from these voters, ages 18 to 29, who accounted for 17 percent of the ballots cast in the 2004 presidential race.

headline: G.O.P. Senator Says Gonzales Might Quit
summary: Senator Arlen Specter, the senior Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said Sunday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales might resign rather than face a potential no-confidence vote in the Senate. Senate Democrats have said they would bring a no-confidence resolution to the floor as soon as this week because of questions about Mr. Gonzales's role in the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors last year and doubts about his leadership.

headline: Arts, Briefly; '24' Is Fox's Lucky Number
summary: With a double episode of ''24,'' Fox posted the slightest of leads in the ratings race on Monday among adults 18 to 49, while CBS led the night in total viewers, aided by the season's best ratings for ''CSI: Miami.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, the two-hour installment of ''24'' averaged 13.4 million viewers from 8 to 10, leading during the 8 o'clock hour in the 18-to-49 set while tying CBS's comedies in the 9 o'clock hour, ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.6 million) and ''Rules of Engagement'' (13.5 million), for second place in that demographic. Meanwhile, NBC's ''Heroes'' (14.7 million) led the 9 o'clock hour over all with 14.7 million viewers, and ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 posted that night's highest ratings, garnering 19.9 million total viewers. ABC finished fourth for the night, even though ''Wife Swap'' at 8 (8.3 million) and ''Supernanny'' at 9 (9.7 million) each earned season-high ratings among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Jericho' Struggles
summary: After a long hiatus, ratings for the return of ''Jericho,'' CBS's post-nuclear disaster drama, struggled Wednesday opposite Fox's ''American Idol.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Jericho'' garnered just 8.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., down two million viewers from its average in the first half of the season and earning its lowest ratings yet among adults 18 to 49. The show did however finish second in its time slot, ahead of ABC's comedies, ''George Lopez'' at 8 (5.9 million) and ''Knights of Prosperity'' at 8:30 (4.2 million), which ranked third. Meanwhile ''American Idol'' remained unbeatable from 8 to 10 with 30.3 million viewers as the top 12 female contestants faced off. Fox easily won the night, and CBS was second, ranking No. 2 at 9 with ''Criminal Minds'' (14.5 million) and at 10 with ''CSI: New York'' (14.1 million). ABC was third for the night ahead of NBC. Although ABC's ''Lost'' finished second at 10 with 12.9 million total viewers, it maintained a sizeable lead among adults 18 to 49, posting the night's second highest ratings in that demographic behind only ''American Idol.'' BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'House' Piles Up Numbers
summary: A double-header of ''House'' made Fox the ratings victor on Tuesday. According to Nielsen's estimates, the 9 p.m. episode, in which Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) managed to save himself from jail time, was the highest-rated show of the night, drawing 17.8 million viewers. It followed an 8 p.m. repeat of ''House'' (9 million), which also ranked first in its time slot among adults 18 to 49, even as a rerun of CBS's ''NCIS'' at 8 outdrew it in total viewers (12.8 million). NBC led the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.5 million) and edged out CBS for second place for the night. NBC earned modest ratings successes earlier in the night with ''Dateline'' at 8 (9.6 million) and ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' at 9 (11.9 million). From 9 to 11, CBS's coverage of the 33rd Annual People's Choice Awards, with Queen Latifah as host, drew 11.3 million viewers, a slight increase from the show's ratings a year ago. ABC was fourth for the night as ''Big Day'' continued to garner small audiences at 9 (4.4 million) and 9:30 (4 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Gridiron Drama Makes Fox a Winner
summary: Fiesta Bowl coverage of Boise State's dramatic overtime victory over Oklahoma on Monday gave Fox a ratings victory for the night, but CBS's lineup of repeats trailed close behind. According to Nielsen's preliminary estimates, which do not account for discrepancies across time zones, approximately 14 million viewers tuned in during prime-time hours to watch the game, which kicked off at 8:53 p.m. and lasted until 12:51 a.m. CBS was second for the night in total viewers, getting a boost at 9 from ''Two and a Half Men'' (12.1 million) and at 10 from ''CSI: Miami'' (12.1 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC appeared to edge out CBS for second place, dominating the 8 p.m. hour because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage of the Rose Bowl. Later in the night, however, repeats of ABC's ''Supernanny'' at 9 (6.7 million) and 10 (6.9 million) ranked a distant third. NBC was fourth over all with a marathon of ''Heroes'' repeats, which drew 5.5 million viewers at 8, 5.2 million at 9 and 4.6 million at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Today
summary: NOON (Nickelodeon) WORLDWIDE DAY OF PLAY In its annual effort to get children off the couch and into motion, Nickelodeon (as well as its sister networks Nicktoons and Nick Games and Sports) will go dark from noon to 3 p.m. The theme continues at 6 p.m. on Nickelodeon with the season finale of ''Let's Just Play Go Healthy Challenge,'' which has followed two 13-year-olds in their efforts to become more fit. We'll see Kenderick, above, compete in a triathlon and April play in her first match with the volleyball team. 8 P.M. (Fox) COPS The granddaddy of reality shows celebrates its longevity with a one-hour 20th-anniversary special, featuring the best high-speed pursuits, domestic disturbances, D.U.I. arrests and, you hope, fat guys running while their pants fall down from the past two decades.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: IGNORING SUBPRIME RED FLAGS An examination of regulatory decisions shows that the Federal Reserve and other agencies waited until it was too late before trying to tame excesses in the mortgage industry. THE SHOWS WILL GO ON NBC said that Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien would return as late-night hosts on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by writers was not resolved. David Letterman is pursuing a deal to return to his show on CBS. [C1.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Earl' to the Rescue
summary: With Earl and Randy, the well-meaning losers on ''My Name Is Earl'' (played by Jason Lee, below, and Ethan Suplee), on a mission to Mexico to rescue a deported friend, NBC had a second consecutive Thursday of modest ratings success, finishing No. 2 for the night. The hourlong special episode of ''Earl'' delivered a season-high 10.1 million viewers at 8, surging past a repeat of ''Ugly Betty'' (8.7 million) on ABC for second place, according to Nielsen's estimates; CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (16.6 million) won the hour, as usual. CBS led the night over all, dominating at 9 with ''CSI'' (23.7 million) opposite a rerun of ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' (10.5 million). NBC's comedies in the hour, ''Scrubs'' at 9 (8.4 million) and ''30 Rock'' at 9:30 (6.8 million), showed considerable improvement. ''Scrubs'' posted its highest ratings in more than two years, edging ahead of the first half of ''Grey's Anatomy'' among adults 18 to 49. ''30 Rock'' also had its best result for that demographic group. A Christmas episode of ''ER'' (11.9 million) on NBC remained No. 1 at 10 o'clock among the 18 to 49 set, though CBS's ''Shark'' finished ahead in total viewers (14.7 million). ABC's ''Men in Trees'' ranked third, with 8.4 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Commercial-Free TV, With Sponsorship in Show
summary: An effort by a broadcast television network to present a series beginning in the fall with no commercial breaks has gained the support of a major media agency, whose clients will sponsor each episode of the show. MediaVest in New York agreed to buy all the sponsorships in ''CW Now,'' a 30-minute magazine-style show scheduled for 7 p.m. Sundays during the 2007-8 season.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLIAMS, ROBERT HAYDEN
summary: WILLIAMS--Robert Hayden Loving husband and father, died Tuesday, July 3rd , of natural causes at the age of 81 years. Robert lived the last ten years in Oregon, living between Cape Mears and the downtown Portland Area. While in Portland, he enjoyed the city in no small measure, attending the Symphony, the Opera, and a unique relationship with Portland State University as a member of the Friends of the Library, the PSU Foundation, and serving on the committee to select a new librarian. Prior to his residence in Portland, Robert lived in Coalville, Utah, for eighteen years and served as Summit County Treasurer, co-founder of KPCW public radio in Park City, from where he would broadcast a weekly classical music program. Robert also owned Ryan's Bar and Dolly's Bookstore on Main Street in Park City. His primary career was as an insurance broker to the entertainment industry from 1952 to 1979 in Los Angeles, California, where he worked for the Fireman's Fund, CBS, and as owner and president of the Albert G. Ruben Company. In this capacity, Robert worked with some of the great talent agencies and studios in Hollywood, and innovated preproduction insurance for the movie industry. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College, class of 1947, and served in the United States Navy during World War Two. He was born to Lida and Frank O. Williams, October 31, 1925, in Kingston, Pennsylvania moving soon thereafter to Maplewood, New Jersey, living there until he went to college. Robert is survived by his wife of 57 years, Joan Hackett Williams of Portland, Oregon, sons Kenneth Shales of Portland Oregon, Mayor Robert Dana of Park City, Utah, Evan David of Salt Lake City, Utah, Todd Jeffery of Los Angeles, California Grant Edward of San Diego, California, ten grand children and one greatgrandchild. The family wishes to express a warm thanksgiving to all who have contributed to the life and times of this wonderful man and to assure each one of them that they are remembered well through the memories, stories, and attributes each gave to him in his life. These gifts remain in us now and we are forever grateful to you all. Our lives will be his memorial. Respectfully, The Williams Family

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Retains Ratings Lead
summary: ''Desperate Housewives'' gave ABC another ratings victory on Sunday, drawing 21.4 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC also led in total viewers at 8 with ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (14.7 million) and at 10 with ''Boston Legal'' (13.8 million). Without football as a lead-in, CBS finished second for the night in total viewers, but a distant fourth among adults 18 to 49. Both CBS's ''60 Minutes'' at 7 (13 million) and ''Amazing Race 10'' at 8 (10.6 million) posted weaker than usual ratings. From 9 to 11, CBS's ''Candles on Bay Street'' (12.8 million) fared just better than ''60 Minutes'' among adults 18 to 49. Fox got a boost from its football game overrun, helping make ''The Simpsons'' (10.9 million) No. 1 in its half-hour among adults 18 to 49. The rest of Fox's lineup, ''American Dad'' (8.8 million), ''Family Guy'' (9.5 million) and ''The War at Home'' (7 million), posted their best ratings in months. NBC ranked third for the night. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Gun Laws and Handgun Violence
summary: Most Americans favor stricter handgun control, but few say it would have done a lot to prevent the shootings last week at Virginia Tech, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Two-thirds of the adults surveyed Friday through Sunday said the laws covering the sale of handguns should be stricter, and 27 percent said the laws should be kept as they are now.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS Network television's grimmest series begins life A.M. (after Mandy). Actually, not quite: Mandy Patinkin's Agent Jason Gideon makes a brief appearance in this third-season premiere (small college, young women, serial killer), but after that it will be up to Joe Mantegna to carry the show, beginning around the fifth episode. headline: POLL
summary: As President Bush and Congress square off over the Iraq war, most Americans agree with Democrats that a timetable should be set to withdraw troops, and they approve measures to link financing with such a timetable, a CBS News poll finds. Fifty-seven percent of the respondents said a withdrawal timetable should be set for some time next year, and 38 percent disagreed. One-third said all the troops should be removed now, and 37 percent favored lowering troop levels.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Assisted Suicide Shapes A Retrospective
summary: For ''Mike Wallace: Some of My Favorite Stories,'' a retrospective to be broadcast on Sunday at 7 p.m. on CBS, this (mostly) retired ''60 Minutes'' correspondent was not content merely to walk down memory lane. He wanted to make news. And so on Friday Mr. Wallace plans to be in Coldwater, Mich., to nab the first interview with Dr. Jack Kevorkian after he is paroled from a federal prison. Dr. Kevorkian, the advocate for assisted suicide who has served eight years for second-degree murder, was the subject of a piece by Mr. Wallace on ''60 Minutes'' in 1998. In that segment Dr. Kevorkian, above right, could be seen administering the lethal injection that resulted in the charges against him. That Mr. Wallace, 89, above left, has not lost his zest for a big ''get'' was obvious even over the phone yesterday, as he described securing the Kevorkian meeting through an intermediary and then plotting how to outwit others seeking the same interview. In the special Mr. Wallace will also be seen conducting a new interview with Vanessa Redgrave, whom he profiled on ''60 Minutes'' in 1979, and talking to Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the Iranian president, in a segment first broadcast last year. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' vs. 'Grey's Anatomy'

According to Nielsen's estimates, 21.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for ''CSI,'' ranking it just behind ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which had 21.9 million viewers in the same time slot. CBS led during the 10 p.m. hour opposite a repeat of NBC's ''ER'' (6.1 million), as ''Shark'' (15 million) matched its season's best ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic. ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' drew the most total viewers (14.1 million) at 8, while the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic went to NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (9.7 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (9.3 million). NBC, with ''Scrubs'' at 9 (6.6 million) and ''30 Rock'' at 9:30 (5.1 million), was third for the night. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Sets Fox Record
summary: The return of ''American Idol'' on Tuesday delivered record ratings for Fox, as 37.3 million viewers watched the series' sixth season premiere from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. No other Fox premiere has ever garnered more total viewers; among adults 18 to 49, it tied the 1997 ''X-Files'' season debut. For the night, Fox outdrew CBS, NBC, ABC, and the CW combined by 78 percent in the 18-to-49 demographic. CBS was second over all, buoyed by ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.9 million). NBC ranked third as ''Law and Order: Special Victims Unit'' led at 10 (14.1 million). On Friday, the Disney Channel posted its second-most-watched day on record as ''Jump In!'' with Corbin Bleu (''High School Musical'') and Keke Palmer (''Akeelah and the Bee''), drew 8.2 million viewers, the most for a Disney Channel original movie. Following it, 7.6 million viewers tuned in for the premiere of ''Cory in the House,'' the best start for a Disney series. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Holiday Parties, Holiday Ratings
summary: Competing workplace holiday parties on ''The Office'' propelled NBC to No. 2 in the ratings on Thursday night among adults 18 to 49, but CBS, with the second-to-last installment of ''Survivor: Cook Islands,'' led the night in total viewers. According to Nielsen's estimates, 8.5 million people tuned in for the hourlong ''Office'' episode at 8 p.m., starring Steve Carell, below. Meanwhile, ''Survivor,'' whose finale is on Sunday, remained dominant at 8 with 14.5 million viewers. NBC's comedies in the next hour, ''Scrubs'' at 9 (7.8 million) and ''30 Rock'' at 9:30 (6 million), trailed farther behind CBS, whose ''CSI'' repeat drew 15.1 million. Also at 9, Christmas arrived on ''The OC'' (Fox), and the show's ratings reached 4.3 million viewers, a season high, however meager. Of the three repeats at 10, NBC's ''ER'' (7.6 million) posted a slight advantage among adults 18 to 49, while CBS's ''Shark'' (10.1 million) drew the most viewers. ABC's all-rerun lineup finished the night in second place over all, ahead of NBC in total viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Gilmore Girls' Bows Out On a (Relatively) High Note
summary: The CW's seven-year old drama, ''Gilmore Girls,'' made its farewell on Tuesday, drawing its best ratings of the season in its target demographic of adults 18 to 34. Opposite Fox's ''American Idol'' at 8 p.m., ''Gilmore Girls,'' according to Nielsen's estimates, also ranked second in the hour in the 18-to-49 demographic, while finishing in last place in total viewers (4.8 million). By comparison, ''American Idol'' drew 23 million in the hour. Fox dominated the night over all, winning the 9 o'clock hour as well, with ''House'' (21.6 million), which actually posted the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC finished second for the night, as the ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show at 9, which eliminated Ian Ziering, earned its largest audience of the season (18.1 million). With Kenny Chesney collecting his third consecutive trophy for entertainer of the year, the broadcast of the ''42nd Annual Academy of Country Music Awards'' from 8 to 11 (9.2 million) put CBS in third, just ahead of NBC, which led the 10 o'clock hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (12.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Worship
summary: ''American Idol'' again helped all Fox's ratings Wednesday, as the 8 p.m. drama ''Bones'' drew a season high of 12.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Bones'' led its time slot over all, as did ''American Idol'' at 9 with 31.5 million viewers. CBS edged NBC for second place for the night with a 9 p.m. repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' (9.7 million) between two reruns of ''CSI: New York'' at 8 (8.6 million) and 10 (10.6 million). Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC slightly outperformed CBS. Its supernatural crime drama ''Medium'' finished No. 1 in that demographic at 10, drawing 9.8 million total viewers, while ''Deal or No Deal'' ranked second at 9 (11.4 million). At 8, NBC's ''Friday Night Lights'' also garnered an improved 6.9 million viewers. ABC was fourth for the night as its comedy line-up, including new offerings ''Knights of Prosperity'' at 8:30 (5.2 million) and ''In Case of Emergency'' at 9:30 (4.6 million). CW's ''Beauty and the Geek'' (4.1 million) ranked second in the 8 p.m. hour among younger viewers 18 to 34. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Stowaway Sleepers
summary: WITH summer guests on the way, it is time to prepare extra beds. Many of those shown open to accommodate two people, while others sleep one. And some can be stacked, in multiples, when not in use. 1. Duo is a 26-by-26-inch ottoman that can be used as a coffee table during the day with a tray on top. Unfolded, it becomes a 76-by-25-inch sleeping mattress for one. Made in Denmark, it is $298 (plus $48 for the tray) from Apt, 61 Greene Street (Spring Street), (800) 694-9164 or apt-ny.com. 2. One2 opens to a queen-size bed. Designed by two architects, Flemming Busk and Stephan Hertzog, and made in Denmark, it is available in various colors; $998 from Apt (see No. 1 for contact information). 3. The Lubi Daybed could be used as a psychiatrist's couch or a bed for one; unfolded, it accommodates two. The foam-rubber cushions have a removable khaki-color cover made of a polyester, cotton and linen blend fabric, and the daybed measures 79 by 32 1/2 inches; $749 from CB2, (800) 606-6252 or cb2.com. 4. City is a sofa that opens into a 59-by-82-inch double bed. It has two individually adjustable backrests, so one person can sit while another is lying down. Created by Stine Engelbrechtsen, a Danish designer, it is available in 13 colors; $1,498 from Apt (see No. 1 for contact information). 5. Duo, designed by Pascal Mourgue, can be purchased as a single lounge-daybed ($3,210) or, as shown, as a sofa bed ($6,290); from Ligne Roset, ligne-roset-usa.com (for stores nationally) or (800) 297-6738. 6. The simplest kind of extra bedding is a floor cushion that folds in half for storage (and can be stacked in anticipation of a crowd). This 74-by-33-inch version is covered in taupe velvet; $100 from Urban Outfitters, urbanoutfitters.com or (800) 282-2200. 7. Flip Flap, by Ana Mir, a designer in Barcelona, is a 72-by-28 1/2-inch daybed made of foam rubber on a wood frame with stainless steel legs. Covered in wool felt, as shown, it is $3,815 (although other fabrics are available or you can supply your own); at Dune, 88 Franklin Street (Church Street), (212) 925-6171 or dune-ny.com.

CBS was a distant second in total viewers, as ''CSI: New York'' (13.4 million) led the 10 o'clock hour. CBS's new reality show, ''Armed and Famous'' (4.7 million), sank to fourth place at 8. NBC edged out CBS in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the night, winning second place behind Fox with the help of ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (10.1 million). Nielsen also estimated that the State of the Union address, carried live on Tuesday by nine national broadcast and cable networks, drew almost four million viewers more than President Bush's 2006 address (45.5 million, compared with 41.7 million). Despite the overall increase, the Fox News channel drew its smallest audience for a State of the Union by Mr. Bush, off nearly two million viewers from a year ago (4.6 million, compared with 6.5 million). Fox News's coverage remained first among cable channels, but No. 2 CNN saw a slight increase (to 2.4 million from 2.2 million) and No. 3 MSNBC's audience more than doubled, to 1.6 million viewers from 707,000. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE MEN WHO MADE THE MOVIES: WILLIAM WELLMANTurner Classic Movies pays tribute to Wellman, one of Hollywood's most prolific filmmakers and toughest taskmasters, beginning with this documentary. The evening continues with the Wellman films ''Wild Boys of the Road'' (1933), in which an impoverished girl (Rochelle Hudson) masquerades as a boy to run with a gang of young hobos, at 9; ''The Ox-Bow Incident'' (1943), about a posse hunting suspected rustlers, starring Henry Fonda (above, with May Beth Hughes), Dana Andrews and Anthony Quinn, at 10:30; ''The Public Enemy'' (1931), with James Cagney as a punk trying to make it big in organized crime, at 1 a.m.; ''The Star Witness'' (1931), with Grant Mitchell as an old man threatened by gangsters, and Walter Huston as a district attorney, at 2:30; and Wellman's last film for Warner Brothers, ''Heroes for Sale'' (1933), with Richard Barthelmess as a veteran fighting drug addiction, at 3:45. 8 P.M. (CBS) KID NATION The Town Council travels to meet with local American Indians -- and leaves the sheriff in charge.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Milestone for ABC's 'World News'
summary: For the first time since 1996, ABC's evening newscast, now known as ''World News With Charles Gibson,'' can lay claim to being the most-watched of the so-called Big 3 in two consecutive ratings sweeps periods: this past February, and now May, according to figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday by ABC. For the four-week period beginning on April 26, ''World News'' drew an average of about 8 million viewers a night, while ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' attracted an estimated 7.3 million, Nielsen estimated. The ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' trailed well behind, with about 6.1 million viewers. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Arts, Briefly; Restless Audience Deserts 'Dream Vote'
summary: After two hours of some of the highest-rated reality shows on television, viewers by and large tuned out for ABC's ''Great American Dream Vote'' on Tuesday at 10 p.m. The new reality competition, with Donny Osmond as host, has audiences voting on which contestants' lifelong dreams are most deserving of coming true. According to Nielsen's estimates, the debut episode on Tuesday, which ABC called a preview, earned a paltry 6.1 million viewers and a third-place finish in the 10 p.m. hour. (The formal premiere was last night.) The show's ratings were striking, given ABC's strong performance at 9 for the ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show (17.6 million), in which the supermodel Paulina Porizkova became the first celebrity dancer to be eliminated this season. ABC finished the night solidly in second place behind Fox, which led at 8 with ''American Idol'' (26.8 million) and at 9 with ''House'' (22.2 million). (Estimates for ''House'' do not reflect a seven-minute overrun of ''American Idol'' into the 9 p.m. hour.) NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (12.8 million) led the 10 p.m. hour, and a repeat of CBS's ''Shark'' ranked second (7.7 million). NBC was third for the night, followed by CBS. BENJAMIN TOFF

summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) MOVIES ROCK! headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Gets Off On the Right Foot
summary: With its highest-rated debut yet, ''Dancing With the Stars'' kicked off its fourth edition on Monday, leading ABC to an easy victory in the ratings. This premiere dominated overall from 8 to 10 p.m., drawing 21.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, improving over its September 2006 premiere by 1.5 million viewers. At 10, ABC's ''What About Brian'' (7.4 million) received a slight boost from the added exposure, earning a second-place finish ahead of ''The Black Donnellys'' on NBC (5.8 million). CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' led the 10 p.m. hour as usual, with 17.4 million viewers. In a three-way race for second place on Monday, CBS had an advantage in total viewers, but Fox edged ahead among adults 18 to 49 with ''Prison Break'' at 8 (8.3 million) and ''24'' at 9 (11.9 million). NBC ranked third in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic as a two-hour episode of ''Deal or No Deal'' averaged 14.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Juggling Several Balls In Real Estate
summary: As Gilbert and Sullivan might sing, he is the very model of a modern chief executive. Brett White, who became chief executive of CB Richard Ellis in 2005 -- about a year after the company went public for the second time -- is tall and rangy, with a broad smile. But looks aside, he has brought the international commercial real estate firm to its present success by following a plan made in 1991. After Mr. White, 47, released a stellar first-quarter earnings report on Wednesday, Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs raised their projections for the company, and JPMorgan Chase put it on its list of hot stock picks. The shares fell 40 cents yesterday, to $37.43.

headline: THE POLLS
summary: Vice President Dick Cheney's popularity has hit an all-time low, with recent polling by The New York Times and CBS News suggesting that he has replaced Dan Quayle as the most unpopular vice president in recent history. Two polls taken in May and June reveal an erosion of Mr. Cheney's base of support -- seen in both his job approval rating and his favorability. Just 28 percent of those polled in June approve of the job Mr. Cheney is doing, while 59 percent disapprove, a reading similar to that of President Bush. The highest rating for Mr. Cheney was 56 percent in August 2002. Mr. Cheney's favorability among Americans has also suffered -- it fell to 13 percent in May, from a high of 43 percent in October 2000.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Makes Monday ABC's Night
summary: Heather Mills, the estranged wife of Paul McCartney who has a prosthetic leg, drew rave reviews from the judges Monday during an extended two-hour edition of ''Dancing With the Stars.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, the competition garnered an average of 20.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., giving ABC a decisive victory for the night. At 10, ABC's ratings fell sharply for the season finale of ''What About Brian'' (7.6 million), which finished second in the hour behind a repeat of ''CSI: Miami'' on CBS (13 million) but ahead of ''The Black Donnellys'' on NBC (5.7 million). Fox was second for the night with ''Prison Break'' at 8 (8 million) and ''24'' at 9 (11.8 million). NBC ranked third, getting a boost from two episodes of ''Deal or No Deal,'' a rerun at 8 (10.8 million) and an original at 9 (12.1 million). CBS, with a lineup of all repeats, posted a fourth-place finish over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Wins Again
summary: The first two of the five hours Fox has scheduled this week for ''American Idol'' averaged 29.4 million viewers on Tuesday from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, as Fox easily led the night in the ratings. CBS ranked a distant second, finishing as runner-up opposite ''Idol'' with ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.4 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (11.6 million). Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC tied CBS for the night, winning the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (11.9 million), ahead of ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (9.4 million) and a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (8 million). ABC finished fourth over all. On Sunday ''The 1/2 Hour News Hour'' made its debut on Fox News Channel at 10 p.m. The news satire show from the executive producer Joel Surnow (''24'') drew 1.5 million viewers and more than doubled that cable channel's first quarter average this year in the time slot among those 25 to 54 (to 499,000 from 228,000). By comparison, Comedy Central's ''Daily Show'' has averaged 1.6 million total viewers this quarter on weeknights at 11 and 1 million viewers 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: BROADCASTER VICTORY
summary: The Federal Communications Commission and the Bush administration suffered a sharp setback when a federal appeals court struck down the government policy of punishing networks and stations for broadcasting shows with fleeting obscenities. The commission, which recently has stepped up enforcement against broadcasters, is widely expected to appeal the decision either to the full federal appeals court in New York, or directly to the Supreme Court.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Corzine Is Seriously Hurt In Car Crash on Parkway Gov. Jon S. Corzine was in a major car accident on the Garden State Parkway and underwent surgery last night for injuries that included a broken leg, sternum and collarbone as well as six broken ribs on each side, officials said. State Senate President Richard J. Codey stepped in as acting governor. PAGE B1 Shift Urged on Gonorrhea The rates of drug-resistant gonorrhea in the United States have increased so greatly in the last five years that doctors should now treat the infection with a different class of antibiotics, the last line of defense for the sexually transmitted disease, officials said. PAGE A10 Remembering Robinson Mets Manager Willie Randolph, who grew up in Brooklyn idolizing Jackie Robinson, will be among the major league figures wearing Robinson's number on Sunday, the 60th anniversary of his breaking baseball's color barrier. SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1 Sallie Mae Is in Buyout Talks Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender to college students, is in talks to be taken private in what could be a $20 billion deal. The possible buyout poses unusual problems, because the bulk of its portfolio is federally subsidized loans. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 University Official's 2 Roles A vice president at Widener University, a nationally known financial aid administrator who made a business of it, is an example of how university officials have become cozy with lending companies. PAGE A13 Dinosaur Protein Recovered In a retrieval once thought unattainable, scientists have used advanced research techniques to recover and identify proteins in a bone of a well-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex that lived and died and was fossilized 68 million years ago. PAGE A11 CBS Ends Imus Radio Show Off the Air After 30 Years CBS canceled the ''Imus in the Morning'' program, effective immediately, bringing a weeklong controversy over racial and sexual insults by the radio host Don Imus to an end. MSNBC, which simulcast the show, had removed it from its morning cable lineup a day earlier. CBS's decision means that Mr. Imus, who has been broadcasting his program for more than 30 years, no longer has a home on either national radio or television. BY BILL CARTER AND JACQUES STEINBERG, PAGE C1 Caught in a Wildfire For a few days, it seemed that Don Imus might pull out of the death spiral. Once he came under fire, Mr. Imus said he was sorry for the racial insult, then began a week of penance, raising money for sick children and turning up at various other microphones to renew his apology. But even as he went through the ritual of public mortification, his backers began to see what he did not: the drumbeat was not going to stop. THE MEDIA EQUATION BY DAVID CARR, PAGE C1

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) IN GOD'S NAME The brothers Jules Naudet, near left, and Gedeon, flanking Imam Muhammad Sayed Tantawi, grand sheikh of Al-Azhar University, focus on spirituality through interviews with 12 of the world's most influential spiritual and religious leaders in this two-hour documentary. The Naudets, who filmed the Emmy Award-winning documentary ''9/11,'' solicited opinions on terrorism and war, as well as on faith, tolerance, unity and peace, from a variety of sources, including Pope Benedict XVI; the Dalai Lama; Alexy II, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church; Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a Shiite leader; Yona Metzger, Ashkenazi chief rabbi of Israel; Joginder Singh Vedanti, the Sikhs' highest authority; and Dr. Rowan Williams, Archbishop of Canterbury and head of the Church of England. 4 P.M. Ms. Judd's mother, Naomi, and the skaters Brian Boitano and Evan Lysacek provide backup.

headline: Race Is On, and Voters Are Watching
summary: It's the middle of summer and months before the first vote is cast, yet polls confirm what the political cognoscenti had suspected: most Americans are already tuning in to the presidential election. More than two-thirds of respondents in a New York Times/CBS News poll this month said they were paying at least some attention to the 2008 presidential campaign. This time four years ago, 4 in 10 Americans were paying attention.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Cops Vs. Docs
summary: ''CSI,'' on CBS, came within a half million viewers of ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' on Thursday night at 9. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''CSI'' drew just under 21 million viewers, to 21.4 million for ''Grey's Anatomy.'' CBS finished No. 1 for the night in total viewers, but ABC dominated among adults 18 to 49. At 8, a rebroadcast of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (12.4 million) finished first ahead of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (9.8 million), which posted its best ratings for a rerun. A rerun of CBS's ''Shark'' (14 million) led at 10 in total viewers, while ABC's ''Men in Trees'' (11 million) edged it out among adults 18 to 49, posting a series high in that demographic. NBC was third for the night with a lineup of comedy reruns from 8 to 11. ''My Name Is Earl'' at 8 (8.4 million) and ''The Office'' at 8:30 (7.8 million), led at 8 among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Ahead
summary: ''Grey's Anatomy'' led ABC to a relatively easy victory in the ratings on Thursday, drawing 21.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. The ''March Madness'' coverage on CBS averaged 10.5 million viewers from 8 to 11, putting CBS in second. During the 8 o'clock hour, ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (10.5 million) tied for first with Fox's ''Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?'' (10.4 million), although the quiz show did slightly better among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked third for the night, and NBC finished fourth as its new drama ''Raines'' (8.6 million) finished last at 10, behind ABC's new drama ''October Road'' (12.3 million), which led the hour. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK The staff holds its annual ''Ludachristmas'' party, but Tracy (Tracy Morgan) is slowed down by his alcohol-monitoring bracelet in this last new episode of 2007. Jack (Alec Baldwin) and Liz (Tina Fey, above right) invite their parents (on Liz's side, Buck Henry, above left, and Anita Gillette; on Jack's, Elaine Stritch). Liz's brother (Andy Richter, center) who thinks he's 17 rather than 40 because of skiing-accident-induced memory loss, also tags along. Meanwhile Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) decides to teach the writing staff a lesson about gratitude by inviting a priest. 7 P.M. (ABC Family) THE LITTLE DRUMMER BOY Greer Garson narrates this 1968 animated holiday special, featuring music by the Vienna Boys Choir, about an orphan who comes upon the Three Wise Men on their way to Bethlehem.

headline: People
summary: Peter Stringham joined Young & Rubicam Brands, New York, part of the WPP Group, as chief executive, succeeding Ann Fudge, who retired in December. Mr. Stringham had been in charge of worldwide marketing at HSBC, London. Before that, he was North American chief executive at the Y&R unit of Young & Rubicam Brands. Jeffrey Wolf joined the Kaplan Thaler Group, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, as managing director for strategic planning and research, a new post. He was most recently a partner and account planning director at Deutsch, New York, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) TIN MAN They're off to see the wizard -- make that the Mystic Man (Richard Dreyfuss) -- in this darkly reimagined version of ''The Wizard of Oz.'' This time around it's the O.Z., as in Outer Zone, where DG (Zooey Deschanel, second from left above, as a motorcycle-mama Dorothy) winds up after riding the tail of a tornado from Kansas to an alternate universe. Her sidekicks in this three-part series include the zipped-up Glitch (Alan Cumming, left above, as a sort of scarecrow); the half-human, half-wolverine psychic Raw (Raoul Trujillo, right above, channeling the cowardly lion); and, in the title role, Neal McDonough, second from right above, as an ex-cop who spent years imprisoned in a metal suit. Kathleen Robertson is Azkadellia, the evil sorceress who holds the O.Z. hostage. 8 P.M. (HBO) MR. WARMTH: THE DON RICKLES PROJECTJohn Landis directed this 90-minute documentary, which celebrates the life and times of one of America's most acerbic -- and enduring -- funny men. Among the highlights: Mr. Rickles's appearances on ''The Tonight Show,'' on Dean Martin's celebrity roasts and, more recently, at the Stardust Hotel in Las Vegas. Dave Attell, Roseanne Barr, Roger Corman, Billy Crystal, Robert De Niro, Clint Eastwood, Whoopi Goldberg, Jay Leno, Richard Lewis, Bob Newhart, Carl Reiner, Joan Rivers, the Smothers Brothers and Robin Williams testify to Mr. Rickles's inspiration.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Numbers Slide
summary: The ''American Idol'' finalists continue to draw enormous audiences week after week, but lately ratings for that singing competition have been falling short of their levels a year ago. Tuesday night was no different, as the 11 remaining contestants performed, and Sanjaya Malakar won atypical praise from the judges. The two-hour show garnered 29.4 million viewers from 8 to 10, according to Nielsen's estimates, a decline of about 6 percent from the same night in 2006. Some of the year-to-year decline, a trend that has persisted for several weeks, can be attributed to this year's early change to daylight saving time, which reduces television audiences over all. The decrease is so small that it has not kept Fox from dominating Tuesday nights, as it did again this week. CBS was No. 2 for the night, as both ''NCIS'' at 8 (15.5 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (12 million) ranked second in their time slots. A repeat of CBS's ''CSI'' (10.4 million) led the 10 o'clock hour ahead of ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (9.1 million) and a rerun of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (7.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Top Model' Struts
summary: Despite the competition from Fox's ''American Idol,'' the eighth edition of ''America's Next Top Model'' made its highest-rated debut Wednesday, as the CW network posted its best night yet in its target demographic, adults 18 to 34. According to Nielsen's estimates, the two-hour premiere earned 5.4 million total viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., ranking third, ahead of ABC and NBC in both hours, among adults 18 to 49. Fox again dominated over all, as 29.6 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 9:30 to watch the top 10 female singers perform on ''Idol.'' Fox's ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' at 9:30 (26.5 million) declined by 3 million viewers from its Tuesday debut, but it remained far ahead of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (14.9 million), which finished second in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS was No. 2 for the night, winning the 10 p.m. hour in total viewers with ''CSI: New York'' (14 million). ABC's ''Lost'' (12.8 million) maintained a significant lead at 10 among adults 18 to 49 but matched its lowest ratings ever in that demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Loser' Makes a Winner Of NBC on Wednesday
summary: Losing 214 pounds, or more than half his body weight, Erik Chopin, a 36-year-old from West Islip, N.Y., pictured below before and after, weighed in as the winner of ''The Biggest Loser 3'' on Wednesday, as NBC's live telecast of the finale earned a season's best 11.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC edged out CBS to win the night among adults 18 to 49, although CBS finished ahead in total viewers. CBS was second during the 8 p.m. hour with back-to-back episodes of ''King of Queens,'' which each earned 9.1 million viewers. Fox's ''Bones'' (8.6 million) was third in the hour, and ABC's ''Show Me the Money'' (6.4 million) finished fourth. At 9, CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' surged into first in total viewers (16.2 million), but the NBC finale maintained the lead among adults 18 to 49. Meanwhile ABC's ''Daybreak'' finished in last place at 9 with 3.9 million viewers. At 10, opposite CBS's dominant ''CSI: New York'' (15.6 million), NBC's ''Medium'' (9.9 million) posted its season's highest rating among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Few Care to Look At 'Miss Universe'
summary: On a Memorial Day evening of low-rated television all around, NBC's broadcast of the 56th annual ''Miss Universe'' pageant, won by Riyo Mori, below, of Japan, delivered the event's lowest ratings in 12 years in the sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated the show attracted 7.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., about 2.5 million fewer than last year's broadcast on a Sunday in July. CBS led the night over all with a lineup of repeats. ABC and NBC tied for second among adults 18 to 49. Wedged between ABC's ''Wife Swap'' at 8 (6.3 million) and ''Supernanny'' at 10 (5.3 million), the debut of ABC's new reality show, ''Ex-Wives Club,'' made an unexceptional showing at 9 (5.3 million). Fox finished a distant fourth for the night as the official time-period premiere of ''On the Lot'' earned just 2.9 million viewers from 8 to 10. BENJAMIN TOFF
