headline: Arts, Briefly; Slow Start for 'The Winner'
summary: It would be premature to write off ''The Winner'' as a loser for Fox, but this new sitcom featuring Rob Corddry (''The Daily Show'') made its debut on Sunday to unexceptional ratings, drawing 7.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The premiere did rank first in its 8:30 p.m. time slot among male viewers aged 18 to 49, a feat facilitated by its placement in Fox's schedule in between episodes of ''The Simpsons'' at 8 (9.1 million) and ''Family Guy'' at 9 (8.5 million). A second episode of ''The Winner'' at 9:30 attracted 6.1 million viewers. Fox ranked third for the night among adults 18 to 49, but fourth in total viewers behind NBC. ABC led every hour on Sunday in the 18-to-49 demographic, while No. 2 CBS finished close behind in total viewers. CBS led in that category at 7 with ''60 Minutes'' (13 million) and at 10 with ''Without a Trace'' (14.7 million). NBC's lineup, including ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' at 8 (6.2 million) and ''The Apprentice'' in its new 10 o'clock time slot (6.6 million), finished last in the 18-to-49 set. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Kelley's 'Wedding Bells' Rings Softly
summary: Despite heavy promotion and a plum time slot following ''American Idol,'' Fox's new scripted series from David E. Kelley (''Ally McBeal,'' ''Boston Legal'') made its debut Wednesday to lackluster results. According to Nielsen's estimates, the premiere of ''The Wedding Bells'' averaged 12.5 million viewers in the 9 p.m. hour, losing 3.5 million viewers from its first half to its second and falling considerably short of the 28.5 million viewers who tuned in at 8 for ''American Idol.'' By comparison, Fox's new quiz show, ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?,'' drew 23.4 million viewers in its half-hour broadcast Wednesday, Feb. 28. ''Wedding Bells'' finished No. 2 in total viewers in the hour, behind a repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' (13.8 million) on CBS. Still, Fox easily won the night over all. ABC ranked second among adults 18 to 49 largely because of ''Lost,'' which earned the night's second-highest ratings in that demographic while garnering 12.3 million total viewers at 10. Meanwhile, CBS placed second ahead of ABC in total viewers for the night, despite a lineup of reruns following ''Jericho'' at 8 (8.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BRENNAN, JOHN JOSEPH, SR.
summary: BRENNAN--John Joseph, Sr., a longtime resident of Manhasset, NY, died suddenly September 18. He was 83. Eileen, his loving wife of 59 years, his sister, 10 children, their spouses, 24 grandchildren, two great-grandsons, a brother-in-law and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins survive him. He was born October 11, 1923, in New York City, third of William R. and Margaret Healy Brennans six children. Raised in Neponsit, he went to St. Francis de Sales, Brooklyn Prep, Holy Cross College and Fordham Law School. He joined the family business Brennan and Sloan, Inc., a concrete contracting firm. In his long career he worked on many New York City landmarks, including the UN, the Citicorp and McGraw Hill buildings, CBS headquarters and the Jacob Javits Convention Center. He was past-president of the Building Trades Employers Association. He married Eileen Fitzgerald on July 10, 1948. They moved to Manhasset in 1957, where they raised their 10 children. A parishioner of the Church of St. Mary in Manhasset, he was a member of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of the City of New York. He is survived by his wife, Eileen, of Manhasset; sister, Sr. Beatrice Brennan RSCJ, of Albany; daughters Eileen Ann Brennan of Kent, NY; Beatrice Wall (Robert) of Lloyd Harbor, NY and Virginia Waechter (Jim) of Nashville; and sons John Jr. (Joan) of Ardmore, PA; Edward (Julia) of Sea Cliff, NY, Michael (Lisa) of Manhasset, Stephen (Patricia) of Irvington, NY, Peter (Bernadette) of Bronxville NY, Thomas of Philadelphia and William (Margaret) of Waterloo, Belgium and Yorktown Heights, NY; brother-in-law Michael F. Armstrong, of New York; grandchildren, Nell (Ted) Timmer, Mary and Kate Ogorzaly; Claire, John, Nora, Ned, Billy, Michael, Lauren, Carrie, Jack, Fiona, Anna Rose, Eliza, Molly, Elizabeth, Kevin, Catherine and James Brennan, and Robert, Kevin, Patrick and Jack Wall, and great-grandsons Henry and Jasper Timmer. Visiting at Fairchild Sons Inc. of Manhasset Thursday and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm Funeral Mass Saturday 10am at St. Marys Church in Manhasset. BRENNAN--John. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John J. Brennan, a Life member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Alfred E. Smith, IV President Brian G. Andersson, Historian

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: MORE MIDDLE-CLASS AUDITS -- Since 2000, authorities at the Internal Revenue Service have nearly tripled audits of tax returns filed by people making $25,000 to $100,000 as part of a broad change in audit strategy. [Page C1.] SALLIE MAE UNDER SIEGE -- Sallie Mae, the nation's largest provider of student loans, is under siege on several fronts, political and financial. Its stock is sagging and at least two private equity buyers are in talks to acquire the company. [C1.] TAKING A MAGAZINE RISK -- Skepticism abounded when Condé Nast announced in September 2005 that it was starting a business magazine, Portfolio, at a time when many others were foundering. S. I. Newhouse, Condé Nast's chairman, said that Portfolio could be the company's last big investment in a new print publication, but as for any doubts, he said: ''Damn the torpedoes and full speed ahead.'' [C1.] HEALTH ON THE WEB -- Stephen M. Case, the America Online founder who oversaw an ill-fated merger with Time Warner before he left in 2003, says the time is ripe for a dominant health care brand -- one that could be as powerful as Starbucks in latte or Nike in fitness. [C1.] EASY E-MAIL BY PHONE -- Nicholas Fodor, a French computer programmer, will soon introduce Freedom Mail, a simple free service that he says will make it possible to view and respond by cellphone to messages sent to almost any e-mail account. [C9.] GOOGLE MAKES A RADIO DEAL Google will begin selling advertisements across all of the stations of Clear Channel Communications, the No. 1 radio station owner in the United States, at the end of June, the companies will announce today. [C4.] CBS'S STRUGGLE AGAINST IPOD -- Even with Don Imus off the air, profound problems face Dan Mason, CBS Radio's new chief executive. In an industry suffering from sluggish advertising sales, CBS and other broadcasters have been laboring to cling to listeners who are spending more time with their mobile phones, Internet radio and portable music players. [C6.] TED FOR THE MASSES -- With $6,000 and some high-level connections, you could attend an invitation-only TED conference (TED stands for Technology, Entertainment and Design) in Monterey, Calif. Alternatively, you could pay nothing and visit a new Web site that offers about 100 of its TED Talks. [C8.] AL JAZEERA ON YOUTUBE -- Starting today, YouTube will carry content from Al Jazeera English, the English-language version of the Qatar-based television news station, with guests like Yusuf Islam, above, formerly known as Cat Stevens. [C5.] SHOPPING BY TEXT MESSAGE -- A company called ShopText has introduced a system that lets people buy products instantly, using text messages, thus eliminating the need to go to a store or even visit a Web site. [C6.] CASUALTY COUNTS ONLINE -- The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are the first with significant United States military casualties to take place in the Internet age. And while there have been debates over how much public attention to give members of the military who have been killed in combat, a string of Web sites has plunged ahead. [C4.] TECH ADVANCE AT INTEL -- At its Intel Developer Forum in Bejing this week -- the first to be held in China -- Intel is planning to announce several technology advances, including one that could lead to a new class of wireless hand-held computer. [C4.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THAT'S THE WAY IT IS: CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90 -- He led the country in mourning when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, pushed the story of the civil rights movement, publicly expressed his opinion of the Vietnam War and helped to send the United States' space program soaring. No wonder Walter Cronkite, above, with George Clooney, became the nightly news anchor to watch. In this hourlong special colleagues including Katie Couric, Barbara Walters, Brian Williams, Charles Gibson, Dan Rather, Ted Koppel and Diane Sawyer as well as friends like Bill Clinton and Mr. Clooney discuss Mr. Cronkite's legacy in honor of his 90th birthday. 7 P.M. (SNY, YES) NEW YORK METS VS. NEW YORK YANKEES -- The 2007 subway series begins, with Keith Hernandez, Ron Darling and Gary Cohen providing analysis for the Mets on SNY and Michael Kay, Al Leiter and Ken Singleton following the Yankees on YES. 8 P.M. (ABC) AMERICA'S FUNNIEST HOME VIDEOS -- Three $100,000 prize winners from this past season return to compete for a Disney vacation. 8 P.M. (CMT) THE ULTIMATE COYOTE UGLY SEARCH -- Shimmy up to the bar: in this competition's finale, three teams show off their drink mixing, dancing and flair skills in the hope of winning $50,000 and being named the ultimate coyotes. 8 P.M. (TLC) MAKING THE CUT -- A class of freshmen at a Vidal Sassoon beauty school go from all thumbs and paint-by-numbers to scissor wizards and dye divas in this new reality series. But first their instructor makes them wash and blow-dry one another's hair to learn the importance of communication. 9 P.M. (CBS) A DR. PHIL PRIMETIME SPECIAL: CAGED? Dr. Phil McGraw ventures into a Florida prison to confront Randall Piercy, who is serving time for locking his young son in a darkened room with no bathroom for three years. 9 P.M. (ABC) NATIONAL BINGO NIGHT -- In this new game show contestants compete against members of the studio audience in three games of bingo for a chance to win cash, trips and other prizes. Viewers can log on to ABC.com to print their own bingo cards and play along. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- Fans can exhale now that NBC has verified that it won't be killing off this New York institution just yet. Tonight in the season finale, Harry Hamlin guest stars as Randall Bailey, a former senator whose ex-wife is found viciously murdered. Bailey is willing to cooperate with detectives. But then he's found standing over another family member's dead body. Hmm. Jeremy Sisto plays his slick attorney; Jeffrey Tambor, above, plays a media-hungry judge. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STANTON, FRANK
summary: STANTON--Frank. For many years, President of CBS who risked contempt of Congress for the freedom of the television press. In 1971, a CBS News program Selling of the Pentagon exposed an unauthorized Pentagon public relations campaign for the Vietnam War. A Congressional Committee subpoenaed Stanton to produce program outtakes for their investigation of CBS News editorial judgment. President Nixon backed the Committee. As journalists know, such government hearings can deter reporting of news to inform the public, particularly about government misconduct. They also scare away news sources. Stanton appeared but would not produce material nor testify about news judgments, asserting the First Amendment. The Committee moved for contempt of Congress to jail Stanton, fine CBS and threaten its broadcast licenses. Journalists, stations, newspapers, NBC and other broadcasters rallied to Stanton. Minority Leader Gerald Ford led Republicans to join those Democratic members who no longer supported their Committee. The vote for contempt failed. Television news gained its freedom from such Congressional hearings. We all are beneficiaries of Stanton's courage and his fight for First Amendment protection for television news. Corydon B. Dunham Esq., Former Executive Vice President and General Counsel, NBC; Counsel, Cahill Gordon and Reindel.

headline: Going Like 60 (Tick Tick Tick)
summary: George J. Tenet accuses the White House of bungling the Iraq war and setting him up (''slam dunk'') to take the fall. John McCain says he shopped peacefully in a Baghdad market, then cameras pull back to show him in body armor surrounded by armed guards. John and Elizabeth Edwards explain why her cancer won't stop his run for the presidency. In a prison interview, L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco's former C.E.O., answers questions about his $6,000 shower curtain. Those ''60 Minutes'' reports were some of the more notable moments in television news this season, and all the more surprising for being on a stately news program that until recently seemed slated for extinction. Its creator, Don Hewitt, retired in 2004; some of the most famous television reporters, people like Ed Bradley and Mike Wallace, were dying, retiring or taking emeritus status. News cycles keep getting shorter and more Internet-driven, and younger viewers are fleeing network news in droves. Yet oddly enough, with many new faces and a lot less fanfare, ''60 Minutes'' is quietly flourishing.

headline: Calvert DeForest, 85, Larry (Bud) Melman on 'Letterman'
summary: Calvert G. DeForest, the dweebish man who gained cult status on David Letterman's late-night shows as the comic figure Larry (Bud) Melman precisely because he was not funny, died Monday in Babylon, Long Island. He was 85. He suffered from a long illness, according to a statement by Mr. Letterman, on whose shows Mr. DeForest appeared dozens of times.

headline: Arts, Briefly; The Ratings 'Deal'
summary: A two-hour ''Deal or No Deal'' gave NBC a ratings victory Monday night in total viewers, but NBC's continuing struggles at 10 p.m. cost it the outright lead among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Deal or No Deal'' averaged 16.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., the night's highest ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic. At 10, however, Episode 3 of ''The Black Donnellys'' ranked a distant second with 6.7 million viewers, far behind a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (14.2 million) although still better than ABC's ''What About Brian'' (4.8 million). With solid second-place finishes at 8 for a ''House'' rerun (9.7 million) and 9 for ''24'' (12.3 million), Fox tied NBC for first among adults 18 to 49. CBS finished third in the 18 to 49 set as the return of its comedy ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' stumbled at 8 (7.7 million) and 8:30 (8.3 million), underperforming the season average for previous occupants of that time slot, ''How I Met Your Mother'' and ''The Class.'' ABC, which broadcast the finale of ''Supernanny'' at 9 (7.5 million), ranked fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Majority Back Health Care for All
summary: Robin Toner reports on a New York Times/CBS News Poll showing support for guaranteeing health insurance for every American.

headline: What's on Tonight
summary: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) ORANGUTAN ISLAND Deep in the forest of Borneo, illegal logging is destroying the last stronghold of the country's orangutan population, leaving hundreds of babies orphaned and homeless. But a new project is offering hope for the survival of the species. This series follows the 35 red-haired classmates of Forest School 103 at the Nyaru Menteng rescue and rehabilitation center. There, Cha Cha, Saturnus, Daisy, Hamlet (above) and some other ''children of the forest,'' as they're known to their teachers, led by Lone Droscher-Nielsen, learn to form their own society and get some education in the real world. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Cesar Millan tries to tame Opie, a black lab mix who has been compared by his owner to both Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde; Flirt, a tiny dog with a hugely neurotic personality; and Bubba, who's just plain spoiled rotten. And then there's Garrett, a German shepherd who won't stop chasing his tail.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 11 P.M. (TBS) FRANK TV You could call it a multiple-personality disorder. The impersonator Frank Caliendo has made his name mimicking celebrities from John Madden and Dr. Phil to Jack Nicholson, Al Pacino and President Bush. In this new comedy series Mr. Caliendo, above left as Mr. Madden, riffs on modern society in stand-up routines and sketches, and introduces a few new characters to his roster, including Jay-vid Lenoman, a combination of Jay Leno and David Letterman. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS The team goes into the woods searching for the survivalist father of a 9-year-old boy.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Big 'Deal'
summary: On a positive night for NBC, ''Deal or No Deal'' edged past a June 2006 record to earn a series-best 18.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, dominating the 8 p.m. hour Monday. NBC easily finished first, leading the 9 p.m. hour as well with ''Heroes'' (14.9 million), the night's highest-rated show among adults 18 to 49. At 10, Episode 2 of ''The Black Donnellys,'' NBC's new drama, garnered 7 million viewers, a slight decline from its premiere but enough to finish No. 2 in its time slot. Fox ranked second for the night in the 18-to-49 set with its reliable thrillers ''Prison Break'' at 8 (9.7 million) and ''24'' at 9 (13 million). CBS, which was third in the 18-to-49 demographic, managed to post a second-place finish in total viewers ahead of Fox, despite a lineup of mostly reruns. CBS did broadcast two new episodes Monday, which earned about average ratings: the season finale of ''The Class'' at 8:30 (8.8 million) and ''Rules of Engagement'' at 9:30 (12.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Talkers in Trouble, on the Radio and at a Chemical Giant
summary: THE flameout of the radio host Don Imus dominated the discourse this week, but there was other intrigue, including what Dow Chemical said were unauthorized merger talks held by two of its officials and the continuing investigation into the practices of student loan companies. MONEY TALKS -- As politicians and political groups criticized the radio host Don Imus for his remark about the women's basketball team at Rutgers University, advertisers used their money to make a statement.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Lost' Loses in Its Return
summary: The return of ''Lost'' gave ABC's ratings a lift Wednesday, but on a night of intense competition, the network could not achieve better than a third-place finish over all. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Lost'' drew 14.7 million viewers at 10, trailing CBS's ''CSI: New York'' (15.8 million) for first in the hour. Among adults 18 to 49, ''Lost'' garnered the night's second-highest ratings, after Fox's ''American Idol.'' Fox won the night over all. Its crime drama ''Bones'' held steady from a week ago to draw 12.6 million total viewers, leading the 8 p.m. hour. ''American Idol,'' at 9, delivered 27.6 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night ahead of ABC by the slimmest of margins among adults 18 to 49 but with a considerable edge in total viewers. At 9 the conclusion to a two-part episode of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' attracted 17.3 million viewers, its best delivery ever opposite ''American Idol.'' The episode followed a repeat of Part 1, which originally was shown on Sunday following the Super Bowl, at 8 (10.3 million) The publicity surrounding the uproar in Boston over an ad campaign that raised concerns of a terror plot did not help the ratings of ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' on the Cartoon Network. It averaged 386,000 viewers last week among its target 18-to-24-year-old audience after averaging 380,000 in that group the week before. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Laugh Lines
summary: JAY LENO A new poll says that 40 percent of Americans still mistakenly believe that Iraq was responsible for 9/11. The sad part? Two of those people: Bush and Cheney.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Late Show Without David Letterman
summary: David Letterman went home sick yesterday afternoon, forcing his CBS program to quickly call in reinforcements from its guest list. Adam Sandler, who had been scheduled to be the lead guest on ''Late Show with David Letterman'' last night, was hurriedly enlisted to step in as host. Mr. Letterman has been forced to call in guest hosts on two previous occasions because of illness. This time, Mr. Letterman contracted the stomach virus that has been raging in the New York area and was too ill to perform, a spokesman for the show said. Mr. Sandler called in Don Cheadle to be the lead guest on last night's show. Mr. Cheadle is the co-star in the movie Mr. Sandler intended to promote last night, ''Reign Over Me.'' BILL CARTER

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Shark' Passes 'ER'
summary: CBS won the ratings race on Thursday night as a case of murdered twins on ''CSI'' had a season high of 23.8 million viewers, outdrawing ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' at 9 for a second week, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Grey's Anatomy'' (21 million) remained No. 1 in the hour among adults 18 to 49, but by its smallest margin this season, as ABC tied CBS in that category for the night. CBS also led at 8 with ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (15.5 million) and at 10 with ''Shark'' (15.3 million), which overtook NBC's ''ER'' (12.4 million) for the first time. ''ER'' finished last in total viewers behind the first part of a two-part ABC special with Barbara Walters, above, ''30 Mistakes in 30 Years'' (13.1 million), but still led the hour among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked third for the night, as a ''supersized'' 40-minute "30 Rock" made its Thursday debut with a weak but improved showing (5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC and ABC News Continue Battle for First
summary: Brian Williams broadcast from Iraq last week and Charles Gibson was on vacation, but the ratings competition between their network newscasts remained tight, according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. While Mr. Williams's ''NBC Nightly News'' was seen by more people over all (about 8.99 million each night last week, compared with 8.94 million for ABC), ''World News'' on ABC (with Elizabeth Vargas, above, filling in for Mr. Gibson) drew more viewers between the ages of 25 and 54, the demographic used to determined advertising rates. With an estimated 7 million viewers over all, the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' drew nearly 2 million fewer viewers than its counterparts on NBC and ABC. JACQUES STEINBERG

RANGERS--Assigned D Darius Kasparaitis to Hartford of the AHL.

headline: Arts, Briefly; On Day 3, Couric Has a Lead
summary: On Thursday, her third night as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' Katie Couric, right, drew an estimated 9.5 million viewers, a loss of about 600,000 from the night before, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday by CBS. On a night when ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' was pre-empted on the West Coast by the opening game of the National Football League season, Ms. Couric's chief competition, ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC, was seen by an estimated 6.6 million, down about a half-million from the previous evening. Because Ms. Couric's arrival at CBS has been supported by a marketing campaign on a scale more akin to that of a blockbuster movie than of a news program, and because the evening news audience tends to fluctuate from night to night, it will be some time before any conclusions can be drawn about whether her entry has raised CBS from its longtime No. 3 ratings position, behind NBC (the leader under Mr. Williams and Tom Brokaw before him) and ABC. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) NEW ORLEANS -- It began as a small French settlement surrounded by water and became a party zone for the nation -- a city at once the most integrated in the country and the site of some of the most vicious white supremacist violence. What, then, would America be without New Orleans? That's the question at the heart of this ''American Experience'' documentary, which looks at more than 200 years of defining events in the history of the city, from the Reconstruction Constitution and the Great Flood of 1927 to the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. Among those offering opinions: the restaurateur Leah Chase, known as the queen of creole cuisine; Teddy Pierre, a stonemason; the jazz musician Irvin Mayfield, who is also heard on the film's soundtrack, and members of the irreverent Krewe D'Vieux, which was the first Mardi Gras organization to parade after Katrina. 8 P.M. (11) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- Honor student: Chris's black substitute teacher (Orlando Jones) holds him to a higher standard than his classmates. 8 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- In ''Day 6: 1:00 P.M. -- 2:00 P.M./2:00 P.M. -- 3:00 P.M.,'' tonight's double bill, the nation continues to deal with the aftermath of the terrorist attacks; Reed Pollock and Vice President Noah Daniels find themselves in the middle of chaos, and Gredenko and Fayed maneuver the threat. 8 P.M. (E!) FASHION POLICE: THE 2007GRAMMY AWARDS -- The good, the bad and the perennially ugly on the red carpet. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- In ''Romance Is in the Air,'' Mr. Lagasse shows love the way to the stomach with a dinner of lobster parfait, ribeye for two, creamed spinach, potato gratin and cherries jubilee. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) NORA ROBERTS'S BLUE SMOKE -- Latest in the film quartet based on Ms. Roberts's best-selling novels, this story about a young girl, now grown(as played by Alicia Witt, left), whose life changed after watching her family business burn to the ground as a child. Turns out she's an arson investigator with a new, ahem, flame. Matthew Settle, Scott Bakula and Talia Shire star. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Liar, liar: Alan fudges his online dating profile, only to wind up with a fellow profile-embellisher (Allison Janney). And Charlie must face reality -- and those pesky emotions -- when Rose announces she is moving to London. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: MIAMI -- A member of the team dies after being shot in the head. 10 P.M. (Logo) FIRST COMES LOVE -- And then, if you're gay, lesbian or transgender, marriage in some unique ways. 10 P.M. (NBC) STUDIO 60 ON THE SUNSET STRIP -- Those were the days: Matt (Matthew Perry) remembers how he and Harriet (Sarah Paulson, right) met. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Models Trump 'Brian'
summary: A ''CSI: Miami'' episode about the seedy underbelly of the modeling world was Monday's most-watched show, putting CBS on top for the night. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''CSI: Miami'' averaged 17.9 million viewers in the 10 p.m. hour. It easily beat the season premiere of ''What About Brian'' on ABC (7 million) and the fourth installment of NBC's ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' (8.8 million), in which Matt Albie (Matthew Perry) clashed with his old girlfriend, Harriet (Sarah Paulson). ''Studio 60'' notably increased its audience among adults 18 to 49 by 12 percent, ending its marked ratings slide since its premiere four weeks ago. CBS's comedies in the 8 p.m. hour, which swapped time slots this week, also showed improvement: ''How I Met Your Mother'' drew 9.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., and ''The Class'' drew 10 million at 8:30. The other Monday night comedies on CBS, ''Two and a Half Men'' (17.1 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (13.7 million), shared the lead in the 9 p.m. hour with NBC's new serial drama, ''Heroes'' (13.3 million), which was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. NBC finished second for the night. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Recaptures Lead
summary: After dominating the ratings with its previous two ''Sunday Night Football'' games, NBC fell to third place on this Sunday, as its telecast of the San Diego Chargers' victory over the Denver Broncos drew 12.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, which did not account for time zone discrepancies. Meanwhile, ABC recaptured the lead in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, as ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (15.4 million) and ''Desperate Housewives'' (21.6 million) easily won the 8 and 9 o'clock hours. At 10 Rob Lowe joined the cast of ABC's ''Brothers & Sisters'' (13.2 million), playing a conservative senator and potential love interest for Kitty (Calista Flockhart). The show finished first in its hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS ranked No. 1 in total viewers for the night, leading the 7 o'clock hour partly because of an overrun of the Dallas Cowboys and Indianapolis Colts football game. Directly after it, approximately 17.8 million viewers tuned in to watch ''60 Minutes,'' which featured an interview with Joe Namath, the former quarterback. Among adults 18 to 49 for the night, CBS edged slightly ahead of NBC for second. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Madonna in London? No. Gigantic Balloons? Yes.
summary: Madonna may not have been a big ratings draw Wednesday night for NBC, but the network's coverage of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade attracted a reliably huge audience on Thursday morning. According to preliminary estimates from NBC, 42.8 million people tuned in for at least several minutes of the telecast of the 80th parade, whose giant balloons had to be flown lower than usual because of bad weather. In contrast, ''Madonna: The Confessions Tour, Live From London'' finished fourth on Wednesday with 4.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS won every hour of Wednesday prime time with its lineup of ''Jericho'' at 8 p.m. (9.8 million), ''Criminal Minds'' at 9 (16.6 million) and ''CSI: New York'' at 10 (15.2 million). CBS also won Thursday night in total viewers, with ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (12.7 million) leading the 8 p.m. hour. But ABC remained No. 1 on Thursday among adults 18 to 49, aided by a first-place finish for ''Grey's Anatomy'' (18.5 million). NBC was third for the night with a two-hour ''Deal or No Deal'' (11.6 million) at 8, followed by ''ER'' at 10 (13 million). Despite Fox's broadcast of ''Spider-Man 2'' (7.5 million), it was a distant fourth over all on Thursday. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Bears Make NBC a Winner
summary: The Chicago Bears' victory over the New York Giants on Sunday night gave NBC its third consecutive ratings triumph on Sunday nights in the 18-to-49 demographic. Approximately 16.1 million viewers tuned in for the ''Sunday Night Football'' game, according to Nielsen's estimates, which did not account for time zone discrepancies. Meanwhile, ''Desperate Housewives'' (22.2 million) gave ABC a slight edge in total viewers for the night as it dominated the 9 o'clock hour. Also faring well for ABC, ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (15 million) finished second to football at 8, although ''The Simpsons'' on Fox (11.4 million) ranked ahead of it from 8 to 8:30 among adults 18 to 49. CBS was third in total viewers for the night. Its ''60 Minutes'' tribute to Ed Bradley led the 7 o'clock hour with 16.2 million. At 10 CBS ranked second with ''Without a Trace'' (15 million), but ABC's ''Brothers & Sisters'' (13.1 million) finished 27 percent ahead of it in the hour among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TRANSACTIONS
summary: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL American League OAKLAND ATHLETICS--Acquired OF Chris Denorfia from Cincinnati for two players to be named and cash considerations. National League CINCINNATI REDS--Agreed to terms with RHP Todd Coffey on a one-year contract extension through the 2008 season. Sent RHP Jared Burton from Louisville (IL) to Chattanooga (SL) on a rehabilitation assignment. SAN DIEGO PADRES--Activated C Josh Bard from the 15-day DL. Placed INF Russell Branyan on the bereavement list. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS--Optioned LHP Randy Keisler to Memphis (PCL). Purchased the contract of RHP Kelvin Jimenez from Memphis. N.B.A. LEAGUE--Fined Golden State G-F Stephen Jackson $50,000 for his conduct following an ejection from a game on April 25. SEATTLE SUPERSONICS--Named Lenny Wilkens president of basketball operations. N.F.L. CLEVELAND BROWNS--Re-signed OT Nat Dorsey to a one-year contract. NEW ORLEANS SAINTS--Signed CB Jason David to a four-year contract. PITTSBURGH STEELERS--Signed OT Max Starks to a one-year contract. N.H.L. LOS ANGELES KINGS--Signed F Teddy Purcell to a multiyear contract. COLLEGE KANSAS--Announced the resignation of Earle Mosley, running backs coach, for health reasons. Named Louie Matsakis running backs coach and special teams coordinator. Announced sophomore G Brandon Rush will make himself available for the NBA draft. LSU--Announced Christie Sides, women's assistant basketball coach, will not return for the 2007-08 season. OKLAHOMA STATE--Announced junior G Jameson Curry will make himself available for the NBA draft. SAINT LOUIS--Named Rick Majerus men's basketball coach. USC--Announced junior G Gabe Pruitt will make himself available for the NBA draft.

headline: Investors Get a Break, but Some Lenders Absorb Blows
summary: Four of the nation's biggest radio station owners moved to resolve accusations that programmers accepted bribes and other incentives to play specific songs on the air. As part of a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission, the four broadcasters -- Clear Channel Communications, CBS, Entercom Communications and Citadel Broadcasting -- agreed to pay a combined $12.5 million and to monitor more closely their programmers' relationships with record labels.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT?
summary: 7:50 P.M. (IFC) INTACTO (2001). In Juan Carlos Fresnadillo's metaphysical thriller, four people gamble with their good fortune on a Spanish island. Among the lucky: Sam (played by Max von Sydow, above left, with Leonardo Sbaralia, center, as Tomas), a casino operator and Holocaust survivor, who has spent the last 30 years in a basement playing Russian roulette. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER The lyin', the witch and the wardrobe: a mud-spattered ghost transports Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) from her closet to a jungle, where she uncovers a mystery involving one of Professor Payne's colleagues. 8 P.M. (Biography) MARY KAY The cosmetics empire of Mary Kay Ash, from foundation to eyelashes. 9 P.M. (CBS) CLOSE TO HOME Annabeth (Jennifer Finnigan) prosecutes a recovering alcoholic for the murder of his niece. But it may not be his first stab at killing. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS Ho ho ho humbug: the Montecito staff reluctantly participates in Ed's Secret Santa gift exchange. Meanwhile, Danny's car is stolen on Christmas Eve as Delinda plans their first Christmas together. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MY FAMILY Ben Harper (Robert Lindsay) and his wife, Susan (Zoë Wanamaker), discover that their daughter Janey's love interest is married. 9 P.M. (Fox) TRADING SPOUSES: MEET YOUR NEW MOMMY Changing weather conditions: Henrietta DeConciliis, an interior designer married to a male model, of Miami Beach, and Marla Hawkins (right, with Marco DeConciliis, her new ''husband''), a hospital worker married to a youth mentor, of Buffalo, switch families. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Jenny C., a college registrar in Atlanta, stocks her wardrobe with clothes from a thrift shop. Stacy and Clinton show her that not everyone else's trash is her treasure. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS Don and Charlie try to catch a serial killer who is making targets of sexual predators on the Internet. 10 P.M. (Discovery) I SHOULDN'T BE ALIVE After bad weather sets in, a couple of scuba divers find themselves adrift at sea with no rescue -- but several sharks -- in sight. 10 P.M. (Discovery Times) WHO KILLED JULIUS CAESAR? No one has ever been quite sure. This special uses technology and modern profiling techniques to try to find out. 10 P.M. (TVLand) 100 GREATEST TV QUOTES AND CATCHPHRASES This final installment counts down from No. 20 to No. 1. To whet your appetite: ''Come on down!'' ''Good grief.'' And this immortal line: ''Yada, yada, yada'' (from ''The Yada Yada'' episode of ''Seinfeld,'' with Jerry Seinfeld, above right, and Henry Woronicz as a priest). 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO Sarah McLachlan performs songs from her new holiday album, ''Wintersong.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Finishes on Top
summary: Racking up 3.6 million more viewers at 8 p.m. than CBS, NBC and Fox combined, ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show garnered 27.2 million viewers on Wednesday, according to Nielsen's estimates, the largest audience ever for the series. The finale, with the former National Football League star Emmitt Smith, right, as the winner, gave ABC the night's ratings crown, although it failed to sustain its sizable audience from 9 to 11 for the debut of ''Day Break,'' its new serial drama with Taye Diggs. The two-hour premiere lost 5.4 million viewers from its first half hour to its last, averaging 10.5 million viewers. In contrast to ''Day Break,'' the third-season premiere of ''Medium,'' which NBC broadcast in the same two-hour time period, added viewers every half-hour, averaging 9.4 million. CBS ranked second for the night as ''Criminal Minds'' (16.6 million) led the 9 o'clock hour and ''CSI: NY'' (16 million) led at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Tyroler, Herman
summary: TYROLER--Dr. Herman Alfred, died February 18, age 82, in Chapel Hill, NC. A loving and generous husband, father, grandfather, and brother, he is survived by wife Marilyn (Chapel Hill); children William (Milwaukee), Barbara (Greenbelt, MD) and Steven (Chapel Hill); grandchildren Samm Tyroler-Cooper (New York), Elisabeth (Chapel Hill) and Isaac (Minneapolis); and sister, Leona (New York). Born in Brooklyn, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Ohio University, received his MD from New York University, and served in the USAF Medical Corps. He taught for more than 40 years at the Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, UNCCH, achieving national prominence for work in the areas of cardiovascular disease and minority health. The Department grants its highest honor to its alumni in his name. He earned election to the Institute of Medicine, National Academy of Sciences. His numerous awards include the Distinguished Achievement Award and Ancel Keys Lecture (American Heart Association) and the John Snow Award (American Public Health Association). Memorial gifts may be made in his memory to: UNC-CH School of Public Health Foundation, Inc., CB No. 7407, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-7407.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Leads ABC
summary: ABC won the ratings race on Tuesday night, as the Mario Lopez and Karina Smirnoff team tied three other pairs for top marks on ''Dancing With the Stars.'' The samba- and rumba-themed episode averaged 20 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 9:30, according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS finished second for the night, with ''NCIS'' drawing 15.6 million viewers at 8 p.m. In the 10 p.m. hour, in lieu of its canceled ''Smith,'' CBS's repeat of ''CSI'' (10 million) finished just behind ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (10.1 million) but outdrew it among adults 18 t0 49. NBC's dependable ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' ranked first in that hour, although it posted a below-average 13.8 million viewers. Over all, NBC finished third: ''Friday Night Lights'' (6.3 million) declined by 12 percent in the 8 p.m. hour from its sluggish debut a week ago, and at 9, ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (11.3 million) finished about even with ''The Unit'' on CBS (13 million) in the 18-to-49 demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: FIJI -- It only sounds like paradise. In this series's latest installment, 19 Americans (above) start out as one tribe on an island rich with supplies and resources with which they set up what is being promoted as an exceptionally comfortable camp. But on Day 3, trouble starts to brew as the castaways are split into two teams and the losing tribe must relocate to a new island with only a pot, a machete and a water source. Castaways who don't play well with others will be further banished -- one per episode -- to Exile Island, miles away from civilization. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Take it to the mat, girls! Joy learns that she has a half sister who could be used to invoke sympathy from the jury -- if only she weren't Joy's lifelong mortal enemy, Liberty Washington (Tamala Jones), a wrestler. Turns out she's also No. 101 on Earl's list: ''Stole a girl's identity.'' 8 P.M. (Fox) 'TIL DEATH -- The guys throw Jeff a long-overdue bachelor party. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- He's back. No, wait. She's back. And she wants revenge. Tonight, Mode and the Meades descend into chaos after the masked woman (Rebecca Romijn, above right, with Eric Mabius as Daniel Meade and America Ferrera as Betty Suarez) makes her shocking announcement. 8:30 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE -- Phyllis (Phyllis Smith) regrets giving Michael (Steve Carell) an important job at her wedding after he makes some embarrassing missteps that threaten to spoil her big day. Meanwhile, Dwight is determined to catch wedding crashers. 9 P.M. (MTV) JUVIES -- What does it take to scare someone straight? That's the question behind this new documentary series in which good youngsters who have done bad things travel to Lake Country Juvenile Center in Indiana to discover their fates as first-time offenders. And that can mean being locked up with criminals of a more violent variety. 9 P.M. (Speed) SPEED PERFORMANCE AWARDS -- Fans vote on a variety of motorsports honors in this inaugural ceremony, in which the performer of the year receives the Mario Andretti Trophy in honor of the racecar driver. At 10, in ''Mario Andretti: Conversation With a Legend,'' Mr. Andretti (above, watching his grandson Marco Andretti drive this week in Spain) waxes poetic about his favorite motorsports memories. 10 P.M. (CBS) SHARK -- A young starlet who is a favorite target of paparazzi dies when her car is run off Mulholland Drive and into a canyon. But whodunit? Maybe the Hollywood socialite she squabbled with at a club just before the crash. Maybe the mystery man she dumped that night. Or maybe someone else. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Takes Election Night
summary: Tuesday may have been a sweep for the Democrats, but the prime-time ratings race was much tighter. ABC led the night, aided by the ''Dancing With the Stars'' competition among the final three pairs, but Fox's ''House'' outdrew it among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, the dancing competition earned 22.4 million viewers from 8:30 to 9:30 p.m., while a half-hour recap special at 8 drew 18.7 million viewers. At 9, Fox's ''House'' (15.9 million) edged ahead among adults 18 to 49, dominating CBS's ''Unit'' (11.7 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (7.7 million). CBS ranked second at 8 with ''NCIS'' (15.7 million viewers), ahead of NBC's ''Friday Night Lights'' (6.2 million) and Fox's ''Standoff'' (5.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Proud Peacock Monday
summary: NBC continued to command Monday night in the ratings with its pairing of ''Deal or No Deal'' with ''Heroes,'' winning the night for the third time this season in total viewers, along with its usual victory among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Deal or No Deal'' drew 17.6 million viewers, easily beating the No. 2 rated show in the hour, the fall season finale of Fox's ''Prison Break'' (9.6 million). NBC's ''Heroes'' averaged 15.5 million viewers, leading throughout the 9 o'clock hour opposite CBS's comedies ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.6 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (12.2 million). CBS ranked second for the night, as its 10 o'clock powerhouse, ''CSI: Miami'' (16.9 million) posted season low ratings among adults 18 to 49. The episode faced added competition from a two-hour edition of ''The Bachelor: Rome'' (10.3 million) from 9 to 11. Also on Tuesday, The Hollywood Reporter noted that ABC had taken its new drama ''The Nine'' off its schedule indefinitely after the series, which follows the lives of nine former bank robbery hostages, drew just 4.1 million viewers on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Weaves Its Spell
summary: Due to the departure of Sara Evans, no one was eliminated Wednesday from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' but the results show delivered its largest audience to date, 19.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ranked first for the night. Also at 8 p.m., ''Jericho'' (10.8 million) held up on CBS, the No. 2 network for the night, while NBC's new comedies, ''30 Rock'' (5.9 million) and ''20 Good Years'' (5.1 million), declined markedly from their soft debuts a week ago. The show ''20 Good Years'' placed fifth behind both CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.1 million for the hour) and Fox's coverage of the New York Mets Game 6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. For the night, Fox beat NBC to finish third. At 9 p.m., CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' tied ABC's ''Lost'' in total viewers (16.1 million), while ''Lost'' retained a healthy, if diminished, 44 percent lead in the 18-to-49 demographic. And at 10, ''The Nine,'' ABC's new drama with Tim Daly, steadily shed viewers over the hour, averaging 8.6 million, while CBS's ''CSI: New York'' dominated (15.7 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Making Light Of Katie Couric
summary: CBS has not been shy about promoting its new ''Evening News'' anchorwoman, Katie Couric, a process that began in May when, though still working for NBC's ''Today'' show, she made a surprise appearance at CBS's annual presentation to advertisers, in which it promotes its fall lineup, this year at Carnegie Hall. This month, however, CBS is showing off a new Katie Couric. As part of a cover story in its promotional magazine Watch, a picture of Ms. Couric taken at that event has been altered to give her a noticeably slimmer physique and fewer facial lines. (At right, before and after.)

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Earl' Bests 'Betty'
summary: NBC's latest incarnation of ''Must See TV'' showed signs of life Thursday, as two of its comedies garnered season-high ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''My Name Is Earl'' drew 10 million viewers at 8 p.m., with its best showing in seven months among adults 18 to 49. It beat the first half-hour of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (14.3 million) in that demographic; NBC's 8:30 offering, ''The Office'' (9.7 million), tied the second half of ''Betty'' with its highest ratings since February among the 18-to-49 set. At 9, opposite ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' (24.3 million) and a repeat of CBS's ''CSI'' (15.9 million), the sixth-season premiere of NBC's ''Scrubs'' posted a two-year best of 8.4 million viewers. Still, ABC led the night over all, as ''Men in Trees'' (11.9 million), which has been relocated to Thursdays, fared better than recent episodes of the 10 p.m. time slot's last occupant, ''Six Degrees.'' CBS, whose schedule following ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' at 8 (15.5 million) consisted of repeats, came in third for the night in the 18-to-49 demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Anatomy' and Its Destiny
summary: As Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) juggled dating both Finn (Chris O'Donnell) and Derek (Patrick Dempsey) on ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' on Thursday night, the show soared over CBS's ''CSI'' for the third consecutive week. According to Nielsen Media Research, ''Grey's Anatomy'' attracted 22.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., beating ''CSI'' (21.5 million) among adults 18 to 49 by nearly 29 percent. At 8 p.m., Week 2 of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (14.3 million) remained solid, but second to CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (15.8 million). NBC's comedies ''My Name Is Earl'' (8.9 million) and ''The Office'' (8.9 million) showed growth at 8 and 8:30. At 10, ABC's ''Six Degrees'' (9.1 million) fell behind CBS's ''Shark'' (13.8 million) among adults 18 to 49, while NBC's ''ER'' (14.7 million) increased its advantage in that demographic to 61 percent. On Fox, the New York Mets second-game playoff victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers averaged 6.5 million viewers. In Nielsen's estimates for Friday, CBS's lineup of ''Ghost Whisperer'' (9.8 million), ''Close to Home'' (11.9 million) and ''Numb3rs'' (11 million) finished first for the night, topping second-place NBC in every hour among adults 18 to 49. ABC's ''Men in Trees,'' with Anne Heche, finished third at 9 with 7.1 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC Starts Off Strong
summary: In the official start of the fall television season, NBC knocked CBS off its perch as No. 1 in total viewers on Monday nights. While the premiere of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 p.m. drew 17.2 million viewers, making it the most watched show of the night, the total was 2 million below that of last year's premiere. Meanwhile, the debut of the new Aaron Sorkin drama, ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' gave NBC a lift in the hour with 13.4 million total viewers. From 8 to 10, the two-hour premiere of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' drew 15.6 million viewers, eclipsing CBS's comedy lineup. At 8 p.m. CBS's new show ''The Class'' drew 10.6 million, while ''How I Met Your Mother'' posted 10.5 million at 8:30. Among adults 18 to 49, both series were third in their time slots, behind the fifth installment of Fox's hourlong drama ''Prison Break'' (9.4 million). CBS fared better at 9 with ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.1 million) and also at 9:30 with ''New Adventures of Old Christine'' (12.1 million). On ABC back-to-back episodes of ''Wife Swap'' delivered 7.1 million viewers at 8 and 8.7 million at 9. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Hollywood Officials Seek End to System Of Paying Residuals
summary: In an unusually blunt session here on Wednesday, several of Hollywood's highest-ranking executives called for the end of the entertainment industry's decades-old system of paying so-called residuals for the reuse of movie and television programs after their initial showings. The executives stopped short of saying they would demand an immediate end to residuals in the coming, and most likely difficult, negotiations with writers, actors and directors. But they were emphatic in calling for the dismantling of a system under which specific payments are made when movies and programs are put on DVD, shown abroad or otherwise resold.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SHULMAN, ALBERT
summary: SHULMAN, Albert. better know as (A.E. Shulman) passed away on December 23rd, 2006 due to complications of Parkinson's Disease. Devoted and loving husband of Miriam, caring father of Ed and Doreen Shulman, Wendy and Mark Teppel and Dean and Leslie Shulman. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Brian, Eric, Allie, Amanda, Max, and Sam. Formerly Senior Vice President, General Manager, of CBS Records (Sony Records) Special Products, residing in Del Ray Beach, Florida formerly of Syosset, New York. Al spent 50 years at CBS Records as an innovative leader in the record industry, working for such recording giants as Clive Davis, Walter Yetnikoff, and Tommy Matola. Al created the beginning of an entire industry, using older catalogue music to create ''Greatest Hits Compilation Records'', Demo 8 track tapes to sell high fidelity in automobile and hundreds of uses of music catalogue for the premium business. A.E. Shulman was loved by everyone who met him, a tough business man yet incredibly a gentle human being, who always was willing to help others asking nothing in return. Al's intensity and zest for life will be greatly missed by all those lives he touched. Grave Side Services will be held on Tuesday December 26th, 2006 at New Montefiore Cemetery in West Babylon, New York. Shivah observances will be at the home of Wendy and Mark Teppel of Great Neck, New York. Donations can be made to the the South Palm Beach County Chapter of the National Parkinson's Foundation, PO BOX 880145 Boca Raton, Florida 33488-0145.

headline: TRANSACTIONS
summary: BASEBALL Major League Baseball MLB--Suspended Chicago Cubs manager Lou Piniella four games for his actions in a June 2 game against Atlanta. American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX--Optioned RHP David Aardsma and RHP Mike MacDougal to Charlotte (IL). Purchased the contracts of RHP Ryan Bukvich and RHP Bret Prinz from Charlotte. Transferred INF-OF Pablo Ozuna from the 15- to the 60-day DL. YANKEES--Placed 1B Doug Doug Mientkiewicz on the 15-day DL. Recalled RHP Matt DeSalvo from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre (IL). SEATTLE MARINERS--Activated RHP Chris Reitsma from the 15-day DL. Optioned LHP Ryan Feierabend to Tacoma (PCL). TAMPA BAY DEVIL RAYS--Placed C Shawn Riggans on the 15-day DL. headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: RECRUITING BATTLES As much of the high-tech industry is enjoying a renewed boom, the competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields is as intense as ever. Companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo find themselves going after the same candidates or recruiting in one another's backyards. At the same time, they are running up against a myriad of start-up companies across Silicon Valley. To lure talent, these companies have expanded their recruiting arsenal far beyond the traditional job fair to include events like technology lectures, cocktail parties, pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests, called ''code jams'' or ''hack days.'' [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR STARS Despite being the first and certainly the largest African-American cable channel, Black Entertainment Television has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs. It relies on reruns, movies and music videos for the bulk of its lineup. The chief executive of BET, Debra L. Lee, has tried to reverse that trend, this year increasing the channel's production budget 50 percent and plunging into original programming with 16 new shows for the fall. [C1.] POLICEMAN, NOT A REPORTER David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter named Peter MacKay from the free daily tabloid 24 Hours Vancouver. But when Mr. Cunningham arrived outside a shopping mall for what he thought would be an interview, Peter MacKay turned out to be a plainclothes police officer who arrested him. Someone in the Vancouver Police Department thought the deception was a clever way to lure Mr. Cunningham, but the ruse provoked widespread criticism from civil rights and journalism groups. [C4.] HIGH ASPIRATIONS Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo, the Russian telecommunications investment company, has aspirations of becoming a global power. But the problem it faces, some analysts say, is that at this point, Altimo has made few allies. If it is known beyond Russia at all, it is for its propensity to fight tenaciously in court and on corporate boards for its ambitions, some say. [C5.] THE MALE DIETER The face of dieting may be changing. Of the 72 million people dieting in the United States, 38 percent -- about 28 million -- are men, according to Marketdata Enterprises, a market research company. It estimates that the diet industry will be $58.7 billion this year. And NutriSystem has hired its first male spokesman, the former quarterback Dan Marino, and has started advertising in Sports Illustrated, Men's Health and ESPN magazine. [C3.] MAINSTREAM PROMOTION Mel Gibson's 2004 film ''The Passion of the Christ'' demonstrated to Hollywood just how many evangelical moviegoers there are and how much money can be made from them. Mindful of that market, Universal Pictures has teamed up with Grace Hill Media, a public relations firm that reaches out to religious groups, to publicize the mainstream film ''Evan Almighty.'' Scheduled for wide release on June 22, it stars Steve Carell as a politician who abandons Congress in order to build an ark, taking off on the story of Noah. [C3.] TALLYING GLIMPSES When the sleek yacht of the Luna Rossa team sailed away with a victory in the America's Cup semifinals, there were two vital results. The Italian crew eliminated the American team of BMW Oracle Racing with a 33-second lead. And fleeting glimpses of the flapping mainsails -- branded with logos of Telecom Italia Mobile and the broadband service Alice -- reached millions of television viewers. Those glimpses are now being counted down to the second, categorized by clear and partial visibility, tallied by major countries and then compared with the cost of traditional spot advertisements. [C2.] WEB PROPERTY DEVELOPER NameMedia, a privately held owner and developer of Web sites based in Waltham, Mass., is best seen as an online property developer, its chief executive, Kelly P. Conlin, said. Analysts suggest that NameMedia and its competitors could represent the next wave of Internet initial public offerings, while also providing a peek at a significant change in what people see when they stumble onto obscure Web properties. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report. [C5.] THE TOUCH-UP In a situation not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O.J. Simpson's mug shot on its cover a decade ago, no fewer than three magazines were reacting to claims last week that they had doctored their covers -- and one retouched celebrity even cried foul. [C4.] A PULITZER AWARD Often the writing and photography that win Pulitzer Prizes require heroic efforts. For one recipient, Jahangir Razmi , the process of receiving the award also took 27 years. In 1979, Mr. Razmi stood near executioners as they shot Kurdish prisoners in Sanandaj, Iran. One picture was picked up by the wire service United Press International. To protect Mr. Razmi, his name was never printed. But after decades of keeping silent, Mr. Razmi allowed his name to appear in a December 2006 article in The Wall Street Journal, which prompted the Pulitzer Prize Board to seek out Mr. Razmi to award him the prize in person. [C4.] VIEWER REVOLT The cancellation of the CBS series ''Jericho'' has led to a viewer revolt that has included not only the usual petition drives, but also the delivery of tons of nuts (mostly walnuts, but also peanuts and pecans) to the two responsible CBS executives. [C4.] THE PRETEEN MARKET With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive, bolstered by last year's enthusiasm for new stars from the Disney Channel's hit ''High School Musical,'' which made household names not only of Zac Efron and Corbin Bleu, but also of Ashley Tisdale and Vanessa Anne Hudgens. [C1.]

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths TYROLER, DR. HERMAN ALFRED
summary: TYROLER--Dr. Herman Alfred, died February 18, age 82, in Chapel Hill, NC. A loving and generous husband, father, grandfather, and brother, he is survived by wife Marilyn (Chapel Hill); children William (Milwaukee), Barbara (Greenbelt, MD) and Steven (Chapel Hill); grandchildren Samm Tyroler-Cooper (New York), Elisabeth (Chapel Hill) and Isaac (Minneapolis); and sister, Leona (New York). Born in Brooklyn, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Ohio University, received his MD from New York University, and served in the USAF Medical Corps. He taught for more than 40 years at the Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, UNCCH, achieving national prominence for work in the areas of cardiovascular disease and minority health. The Department grants its highest honor to its alumni in his name. He earned election to the Institute of Medicine, National Academy of Sciences. His numerous awards include the Distinguished Achievement Award and Ancel Keys Lecture (American Heart Association) and the John Snow Award (American Public Health Association). Memorial gifts may be made in his memory to: UNC-CH School of Public Health Foundation, Inc., CB No. 7407, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-7407.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Lifts ABC
summary: ''Dancing With the Stars'' did not stumble on Tuesday as it dealt with the unexpected departure of the country singer Sara Evans for personal reasons. The 90-minute dancing competition averaged 21.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, lifting ABC to No. 1 for the night. Despite the ratings onslaught in the 8 p.m. hour, CBS's ''NCIS'' fared well (15.8 million), while NBC's ''Friday Night Lights'' remained distant with 6.6 million viewers. NBC recovered at 9 when its ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (10.9 million) tied CBS's ''The Unit'' among adults 18 to 49, although ''The Unit'' retained an edge in total viewers (12.8 million). Winning the 10 p.m. hour, NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (12.8 million) revealed the tragic past haunting the new detective Dani Beck (Connie Nielsen). Rounding out the night for ABC, the Ted Danson comedy ''Help Me Help You'' at 9:30 and ''Boston Legal'' at 10 each averaged 10.9 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; McDreamy Is Irresistible, With a Ratings Victory
summary: The flirty surgeons prevailed over the forensic investigators in Thursday night's much-anticipated television matchup. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy,'' starring Patrick Dempsey, below, whose character is often referred to as ''Dr. McDreamy,'' captured 25.1 million viewers. It topped the premiere of CBS's Thursday goliath, ''CSI,'' by 45 percent in the vaunted demographic of adults 18 to 49. ''CSI'' drew a formidable 22 million total viewers, although that figure was down 24 percent from last year's debut. NBC's premiere of ''ER'' led at 10 p.m. with 15.6 million viewers. Although the ''Grey's Anatomy'' momentum slowed at 10 p.m., ABC's ''Six Degrees,'' the latest from J. J. Abrams (''Lost''), still fared 38 percent better among adults 18 to 49 than CBS's older-skewing ''Shark,'' with James Woods, which drew 15 million total viewers. Notably, however, ''Six Degrees'' lost 4 million viewers in its second half, averaging 13.3 million viewers for the hour. In the 8 p.m. slot, CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' held relatively steady from last week with 17.3 million viewers, while premieres of NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' (8.9 million) and ''The Office'' (9.1 million) were third behind ''Survivor'' and a special ''Grey's Anatomy'' retrospective (13.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Football Playoff Piles Up Record Ratings
summary: With the best ratings for an American Football Conference championship game in 10 years, CBS's coverage of the Indianapolis Colts' victory over the New England Patriots on Sunday outdrew even last week's ''American Idol'' premiere telecasts to usurp the title of highest-rated program of the 2006-7 television season. According to Nielsen's estimates, which do not account for discrepancies across time zones, the game averaged approximately 43 million viewers for the night. ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' was the second-most-watched show on Sunday, delivering a much-reduced 17.1 million viewers at 9. ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (12.6 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (11.9 million) helped ABC secure a distant but respectable second-place finish for the night. NBC was third over all, as ratings for Week 3 of its reality shows ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' at 8 (8.1 million) and ''The Apprentice'' at 9 (6.9 million) remained steady after falling in the shows' second week. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: CAUGHT IN THE SQUEEZE Even if banks make it through the current credit squeeze, it is bound to hit them in one way or another. The financial damage, analysts say, will probably start next quarter, and continue through at least next year. The eastern German state of Saxony was forced to sell a troubled state-run bank, Landesbank Sachsen Girozentrale, as the global liquidity crisis set off by the United States subprime mortgage crisis claimed its first major European victim. [C2.]

headline: Warren J. Mitofsky, 71, Innovator of Polling
summary: Warren J. Mitofsky, an innovator and standard-setter in the polling industry for four decades, died on Friday. He was 71. The cause was an aneurysm of the aorta, said his widow, Mia Mather.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 3 - 9; TELEVISION
summary: The time has come for the annual broadcast of the beloved, old-as-the-hills holiday animated specials. ''A Charlie Brown Christmas'' has come and gone, but on Friday night CBS is hauling out a block of oldies narrated by long-dead celebrities. It begins at 8 with ''RUDOLPH, THE RED-NOSED REINDEER,'' first shown in 1964 and narrated by Burl Ives. Four decades later it seems as if an elf who really wants to be a dentist has always been part of Rudolph's story. But the song's original plot is around, too: glowing-nosed outcast, ridiculed and banned from reindeer games, leads Santa's sleigh through a foggy Christmas Eve and saves the holiday. ''FROSTY THE SNOWMAN'' (1969), narrated by the great Jimmy Durante, follows at 9, with its tale of a magic hat that brings a snowman to life and the little children who set out to save Frosty when he begins to melt. Unfortunately the original ''Frosty'' is only a half-hour long, so CBS has scheduled its highly inferior 1992 sequel, ''FROSTY RETURNS,'' at 9:30. Could be a good time to walk the dog. And now for something completely unholidaylike: PATRICK STEWART, lauded interpreter of Shakespeare, Dickens and ''Star Trek,'' stars in a new offering from BBC America. In ''THE ELEVENTH HOUR,'' a four-hour, four-part series beginning Monday at 9 p.m., he plays Ian Hood, a government science adviser (and former physics professor) whose raison d'être is preventing mad, evil or simply misguided scientists from misusing technology. Hood's hobby appears to be making his bodyguard (Ashley Jensen) crazy. In the first episode he goes after a mastermind nicknamed Geppetto, who is heading an ambitious human cloning project. The first clue is 27 graves of malformed fetuses, each buried with a cross (not by Geppetto) and each with the same DNA.

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 3 P.M. (NBC) THE MEGAN MULLALLY SHOW -- She's no Karen, but that's O.K. Ms. Mullally (left), the other woman on ''Will & Grace,'' finds a new voice in the premiere of her talk show. Will Ferrell and Jenny McCarthy are the guests; Bret Simmons leads the band. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY -- Not quiteMartha material?
