headline: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Lovers and Grammys
summary: This year the week after the Grammy Awards included Valentine's Day, and one result was a Top 10 filled with lovers' music and prizewinners. Norah Jones, right, who was not nominated (but was featured in a ''60 Minutes'' segment on CBS before the show), returned to No. 1, with her album ''Not Too Late'' (Blue Note) selling 210,000 copies in its third week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. No. 2 is ''In My Songs'' (Atlantic) by Gerald Levert, the amorous R&B singer who died in November; it moved 165,000 copies. The compilation ''Grammy Nominees 2007'' (Grammy/Sony BMG) is at No. 3, with 131,000 sales, and Corinne Bailey Rae, who performed at the show but did not win, rose five spots to No. 4 with her self-titled debut on Capitol; in the week that ended on Sunday, it sold 120,000, more than double what it had the week before. Big gains were also posted by Justin Timberlake (No. 7, with 108,000 sales, a 123 percent increase) and John Mayer (No. 10, with 80,000, up 182 percent). But the top winner at the awards is also the highest climber on the chart: the Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia) had a nearly sevenfold increase, to 103,000 copies, leaping 64 spots on the chart to No. 8. BEN SISARIO

headline: The Week Ahead: Sept. 16-- 22
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Heroes' Holds Off '24'
summary: After a six-week hiatus, the return of NBC's ''Heroes'' Monday relegated Fox's ''24'' to second place in the 9 p.m. ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Heroes'' led ''24'' by 20 percent among adults 18 to 49, and had 14.8 million viewers, compared to 14.4 million for ''24.'' NBC ranked first for the night in the 18-to-49 set as its game show ''Deal or No Deal'' (17.6 million) easily won the 8 p.m. hour over Fox's ''Prison Break,'' which drew a season-high of 9.9 million viewers. Despite ranking third for the night among adults 18 to 49, CBS managed to finish first in total viewers. Its sitcom ''Two and a Half Men'' outdrew ''Heroes'' and ''24'' in its half-hour at 9 (16.1 million), while ''CSI: Miami'' (18.7 million) dominated the 10 p.m. hour. ABC was fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Fends Off 'House'
summary: In its new 9 p.m. time slot, ''House'' gave Fox a lift in the ratings on Tuesday, but ABC, with its hit ''Dancing With the Stars,'' led the night over all. The dancing contest, down to the final four teams, delivered 20.5 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS ranked second for the night, aided by ''NCIS,'' which finished solidly No. 2 at 8, with 15.9 million viewers. Fox ended the night in third, dragged down by ''Standoff'' at 8 (4.9 million). ''House,'' on the other hand, drew 14 million viewers at 9 as it introduced a new police detective antagonist played by David Morse, who will appear for a six-episode stint. Opposite ''House,'' both CBS's ''The Unit'' (11.4 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (8.5 million) were weaker than usual, and at 9:30 on ABC, the Ted Danson comedy ''Help Me Help You'' drew a series low of 9.5 million viewers. NBC finished fourth for the night, although it remained on top in the 10 p.m. hour as Mariska Hargitay returned to ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (13.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Sunday Night Football' Makes NBC a Winner
summary: With one of the largest audiences to date for ''Sunday Night Football,'' coverage of the Indianapolis Colts victory over the New England Patriots put NBC firmly on top of the ratings race on Sunday. According to Nielsen's time-zone-adjusted estimate, the game garnered approximately 22 million viewers. ABC was second for the night, aided at 9 p.m. by the much-hyped episode of ''Desperate Housewives'' (22.5 million), in which Caroline Bigsby (Laurie Metcalf) was shot and killed after taking hostages in a local supermarket. The ratings dropped off at 10 for ABC's ''Brothers & Sisters'' (13.7 million), but the show still finished ahead of CBS's programming in the hour, which was delayed because of an afternoon football game overrun. CBS's ''Cold Case'' averaged 13.6 million viewers over its hour, and ''Without a Trace'' averaged 12.8 million. At 8, the 17th ''Treehouse of Horror'' edition of ''The Simpsons'' on Fox drew 10.4 million viewers. While down from a year ago, this year's Halloween special, which included an allegory of the American occupation of Iraq, performed well among adults 18 to 49, ranking second in its half hour ahead of ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (15.3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Kicking and scheming, 8 of the N.F.L.'s 12 playoff teams will be in action this weekend in back-to-back doubleheaders. KANSAS CITY AT INDIANAPOLIS 4:30 p.m., NBC DALLAS AT SEATTLE 8 p.m., NBC TODAY -- The games include a team that was in last year's Super Bowl (the Seahawks), a team that can't seem to get to the Super Bowl (the Colts) and a coach (the Cowboys' Bill Parcells) who would like to get there one more time. JETS AT NEW ENGLAND 1 p.m., CBS GIANTS AT PHILADELPHIA 4:30 p.m., Fox TOMORROW -- The pairings feature division rivals, with the Jets trying to upset the Patriots for the second time this season and the slumping, but fortunate, Giants trying to justify their presence by surprising the Eagles.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Sunday-Night High
summary: Sunday may be ''Football Night in America'' on NBC, but ABC and CBS made it a three-way race for viewers this week. In the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, however, ABC handily finished first, buoyed by ''Desperate Housewives,'' which drew 21.2 million viewers for the 9 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC also got a boost from ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (14.7 million) and its new drama with Calista Flockhart, below left, ''Brothers & Sisters,'' at 10 (13.9 million). CBS held steady all night, starting at 7 with a much-publicized Mike Wallace ''60 Minutes'' interview with Bob Woodward (17.5 million). CBS's ''Amazing Race 10'' (13.3 million) improved on its week-ago performance at 8, while ''Cold Case'' (13 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (14.9 million) were off from their premieres but solid. NBC's live broadcast of the Seattle Seahawks and Chicago Bears game averaged 16.9 million viewers for the night, in time-zone adjusted estimates. On the CW, the premiere of ''Everybody Hates Chris'' (2.4 million) slipped 72 percent in viewers 18 to 49 from its hyped Thursday debut last season -- its worst showing to date except for reruns. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) SCRUBS -- All the hospital's a Broadway stage when a woman checks into Sacred Heart complaining of hearing incessant music. Stephanie D'Abruzzo (right,on a stretcher), an original cast member of the Tony Award-winning ''Avenue Q,'' plays the patient with singing in her ears; Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx, who wrote the show's music, composed the songs for this episode. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Wouldn't you know it? Before Earl (Jason Lee) can make amends, the man he once locked in a truck dies -- leaving Earl to plan a funeral for someone he didn't even know. Meanwhile, Randy (Ethan Suplee) and Catalina (Nadine Velazquez) try to make their marriage seem more real by looking for an apartment together. 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Calling all superheroes: the Flash, Aquaman and Cyborg show up in Smallville to help the Green Arrow take down Luthor Corp's secret lab. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- America Ferrera, who plays the title frump in this sitcom set in the fashion world, just proved that you don't have to look like, say, Sarah Jessica Parker to win a Golden Globe for best-actress in a television comedy. Tonight, Betty determines to get Daniel back to work and over his sadness about Sofia (the beauteous Salma Hayek, one of the show's executive producers) by setting him up on a date with a supermodel. Back at the office, Wilhelmina starts dreaming in pink -- as in slips -- about who will stay and who will go once she is made editor in chief of Mode. And the woman behind the mask is finally revealed. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- Liev Schreiber (left) joins the cast in a recurring role as Michael Keppler, a seasoned crime scene investigator sent in to replace Gil Grissom (William Petersen ) during his teaching sabbatical. He's as tough to read as a closed book. 9 P.M. (Discovery Health) THE DAN HO SHOW -- Attention, freshmen: Mr. Ho dishes out healthy living habits to keep college students from gaining the proverbial 15 pounds. At 9:30, he helps a couple of pack rats clean up their garage. 9:30 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK -- Liz (Tina Fey) and Jenna (Jane Krakowski) decide to get serious about their dating lives. But can they step into the other's shoes? 10 P.M. (CBS) SHARK -- After admitting that he has long followed the career of Sebastian Stark (James Woods, right), a serial killer (Billy Campbell) decides to test his wits by acting as his own lawyer during his trial. Turns out it's not such a bad move. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Warm Reception Expected For Bush Visit to Albania President Bush will be the first sitting American president to visit Albania. The country's support for the war in Iraq is nearly unanimous and it was one of the first allies to send troops to Afghanistan and one of the first to join the forces in Iraq. A1 Putin Elaborates on Missiles President Vladimir V. Putin offered suggestions for alternatives to a missile defense system in Europe, saying Russia would not object to American interceptor missiles in Iraq, Turkey or at sea, and proposed that Russia and the West study emerging missile threats together. A6 Report on Secret C.I.A. Prisons In a report, the lead investigator for the Council of Europe gave a bleak description of secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency in Eastern Europe, with information he said was gleaned from anonymous intelligence agents, many of whom wanted to unburden themselves. A7 Separatist Arrested in Spain The Spanish police arrested Arnaldo Otegi, the leader of the political wing of the violent Basque separatist group ETA, according to an official from the National Court. The move signaled a new government crackdown after the group renounced a 15-month cease-fire. A4 A Syrian arms dealer was arrested in Madrid and charged in a plot to ship weapons--including C-4 explosives and surface-to-air missiles--to guerrillas in Colombia seeking to attack American forces serving there on antidrug missions, American prosecutors said. A4 Pakistan Lifts Media Strictures After a barrage of criticism and angry but peaceful nationwide protests by journalists and rights groups, the Pakistani government has suspended its restrictions on independent television stations. The restrictions were originally imposed by Gen. Pervez Musharraf last March. A7 Italy Prosecutes C.I.A. Agents A trial that charges American and Italian intelligence operatives with kidnapping a radical imam in 2003 opened in Milan, the first prosecution involving the contentious American policy of abducting terrorism suspects for interrogation elsewhere. A7 NATIONAL A9-13 Chairman of Joint Chiefs Will Not Be Reappointed The Bush administration said it had decided not to reappoint Gen. Peter Pace to a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, making him the highest-ranking officer to be a political casualty of the fight over Iraq. A1 Court Ruling is Criticized A decision by the Supreme Court earlier this week that made it easier for prosecutors to exclude from capital juries people who express reservations about the death penalty will produce whiter and more conviction-prone juries, experts in law and psychology said. A1 Paris Hilton Returned to Jail The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released with an ankle monitor for an unspecified medical problem. A1 New Passport Rules Suspended The State Department and the Department of Homeland Security formally announced they were temporarily suspending new passport requirements for travel to neighboring countries. A9 Wave of Youth Suicide American Indian and Native Alaskan ages 15 to 24 are committing suicide at a rate more than three times the national average for their age group, according to the surgeon general. A9 Nominee Draws Criticism President Bush's nomination of Dr. James W. Holsinger Jr., a Kentucky cardiologist, to be surgeon general is drawing criticism from gay rights groups, physicians and lawmakers who are troubled by his opinions critical of homosexuality that he voiced as a high-ranking layman in the United Methodist Church. A11 A Smooth Shuttle Launching The shuttle Atlantis thundered off the launching pad into a stunningly clear evening sky on a mission to continue building the International Space Station. Already delayed for three months by a hailstormthat damaged the foam covering the shuttle's external tank, the launching was unusually smooth. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Commuters Like Goal, Not Price, of Traffic Plan Commuters who would be affected the most by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's fast-advancing plan to charge $8 to drive in the most congested parts of Manhattan seem to agree on two points: that something desperately needs to be done about traffic and that they do not want to have to pay for it. B1 Citywide Tests May Pay A Harvard economist known for his work on racial inequality in schools is in New York with a big idea: pay students cash for high scores on standardized tests and their performance might improve. And he has captured the attention of Mayor Bloomberg and the chancellor of city schools. B1 Contractors in Name Only Gov. Eliot Spitzer is planning to step up enforcement against thousands of companies in New York that illegally misclassify workers as independent contractors to cheat on taxes and skimp on employee benefits, the state labor commissioner said. B1 Beliefs B5 OBITUARIES C10 Edwin Traisman A food scientist who helped standardize McDonald's French fries and develop Cheez Whiz for Kraft Foods, as well as researching the risks of E. Coli bacteria, he was 91. C10 ARTS B7-17 Trimming Classical Critics Classical music criticism, an endeavor that has been around at least as long as newspapers, has taken a series of hits in recent months. Critics' jobs have been eliminated, downgraded or redefined at newspapers around the country. B7 CBS Revives 'Jericho' The resurrection of ''Jericho'' after its cancellation by CBS reflected the efforts of thousands of fans who, because they regularly viewed the show on the Internet or through other nontraditional formats, might not have been counted in the familiar Nielsen television ratings. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Investors With School Ties Mutual-fund managers invest more money in companies that are run by people with whom they went to college or graduate school, a new study shows. C1 Popularity of Pickups Drops The popularity of pickup trucks is in decline, and as sales drop, rebates and other incentives climb. Among the culprits for the decline: a growing sense of environmental responsibility that has flared along with gas prices. C1 Summer Jobs Go Wanting The job market for summer work -- such as life guarding or selling hot dogs -- is strong. But many of the jobs are not filled as students seek out internships or positions that will provide training for a career. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: A failure of leadership; nasty, unfinished cold war business; the road to somewhere; trans-Pacific chicken. Columns: Bob Herbert and Timothy Egan. Bridge B16 Crossword B15 TV Listings B17 Weather B18

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: PUBLIC DATA SHOWED DRUG RISK -- A cardiologist found that GlaxoSmithKline's popular diabetes drug Avandia posed a heightened cardiac risk by analyzing the studies that the company voluntarily posted online. The finding is liking to spur efforts to require drug makers to disclose study results. [Page C1.] REHABBING HOME DEPOT -- Home Depot's annual meeting today is a chance for the chief executive, Frank Blake, to use his humble and low-key approach to distance himself from his predecessor, Robert L. Nardelli. Attendees are looking for change in another area, too: Home Depot's flagging performance. [C1.] ALCAN REJECTS ALCOA'S BID -- The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan not only rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, but it said it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa. [C1.] RELEVANCE IN QUESTION -- The crisis over Paul D. Wolfowitz is over, but the World Bank and the other structures of the international economic architecture -- including the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization -- are now is buckling under the weight of globalization, trade disputes and the ambitions of rising economic powers. [C1.] TRADE TALKS WITH CHINA -- Teams of Cabinet members from China and the United States held a day of talks to reduce economic tensions but ran into familiar disagreements over trade, currency issues and at least one new concern, the safety of Chinese food exports. [C3.] FREMONT SELLS PROPERTY UNIT -- The Fremont General Corporation, a financial services company caught up in the subprime mortgage lending mess, has agreed to sell its commercial real estate unit for $1.9 billion and bring in new managers. The new management team will be led by Gerald J. Ford, above, who once ran Golden State Bancorp. Fremont will also receive $80 million for selling a minority stake in the remaining business to a group of investors led by Mr. Ford. [C3.] ACTIVISM WITHOUT LIMOUSINES -- Shareholder activism is beginning to take root in Europe. But the efforts at forcing change are not led by the likes of Carl C. Icahn or Kirk Kerkorian, but often by ordinary investors. [C5.] POLISHING AN INSURER'S IMAGE -- Marsh & McLennan, the giant insurance broker that was staggered in recent years by accusations of rigging bids and taking kickbacks from insurance companies, is trying to restore its image with an advertising campaign that urges readers to ''find the upside.'' Advertising. [C3.] INTEL IN DEAL ON MEMORY CHIPS -- The Intel Corporation announced that it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips. [C3.] CBS BUYS A FINANCIAL WEB SITE -- CBS has bought Wallstrip, an online company whose Web site mixes finance with humor, to add to its daily financial news Web broadcast. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. [C8.] RESTAURANT OWNER IS SOLD -- OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners. The buyout group raised its bid 2.9 percent, to $41.15 a share, OSI said. OSI, based in Tampa, Fla., owns Outback, the largest steakhouse chain in the nation, as well as the Carrabba's, Bonefish and Lee Roy Selmon's restaurants. [C10.] MARKETS STALL -- Several new deals were announced, but Wall Street failed to gain much momentum as it waited for new economic data, leaving the markets little changed. [C8.] SAVANNAH'S GROWING DOWNTOWN -- A developer is proposing the largest expansion of the historic downtown in Savannah, Ga., since the grid of compact streets and squares was first designed in 1733. [C6.] NATION'S STRICTEST EMISSION LAWS -- Officials from California demanded that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation. [A19.] IMMIGRATION BILL SURVIVES -- A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year. [A20.] DIG DEEPER FOR A SIRLOIN -- The cost of producing beef and the demand for it have risen so much that prices are soaring and the supply of top-quality beef has dropped. Contributing to the rising cost is the demand for ethanol and a harsh winter, which have caused the price of corn to rise about 60 percent in recent months. [F1.] ONE CHOICE FOR ACTION MOVIE FANS -- ''Live Free or Die Hard,'' which opens in June, will be the only straight-ahead, major studio action film set for the year's prime moviegoing weeks. Its studio, 20th Century Fox, is betting that the summer movie audience still has a taste for cinematic red meat. [E1.] SALLIE MAE'S CHIEF STEPS DOWN -- SLM, the student lender commonly known as Sallie Mae, said that its vice chairman and chief executive, Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, was resigning to pursue other interests and would be succeeded by the company's chief financial officer. [C2.] anheuser-Busch raises forecast The Anheuser-Busch Companies said that profit would rise more than forecast this year on higher sales of imported beers and fewer discounts of Bud Light and Michelob. [C8.] HOUSE PASSES MORTGAGE BILL -- Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cleared the House. But the bill could lose the support of the Bush administration because of a provision trimming the authority of federal regulators. [C2.] ONLINE THE ENERGY CHALLENGE -- A series of articles examines how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more energy-efficient, environmentally benign future. The series is online at nytimes.com/energychallenge. WEEKEND BUSINESS -- In a podcast, reporters and editors from The Times's Sunday Business section offer perspective on the week in business and beyond. Subscription information is at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Will Obama Mobilize Young Voters?
summary: Fred D. Thompson, a Republican candidate for president, spoke to a few hundred people the other night in one of the ballrooms in the Marriott convention center in Coralville, Iowa. The crowd, not unusually for a political event in Iowa, was decidedly older, for the most part north of 50. A few hours later, Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat, addressed an audience of more than 1,000 just up the hallway. His crowd contained a striking number of people under 30. Mr. Obama has clearly struck a chord among younger voters. And his campaign has made what seems to be the most sophisticated effort of any of the Democrats to reach out to them, sending recruiting teams to Iowa high schools and trying to ensure that New Hampshire college students who might be out of state on Primary Day get absentee ballots.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: NORWAY'S RULES -- Norway invests its $300 billion nest egg, built from profits from oil exports, to advance an ambitious ethics code. And that has meant pulling investments out of Wal-Mart and companies like Boeing and Lockheed Martin for what it says are ethical failings. [Page C1.] SPENDING FOR A CAUSE -- In a welcome display of gilded age excess, the titans of hedge funds and private equity came together at the 2007 Robin Hood charity dinner this week and raised $71 million, up 32 percent from last year, by bidding on items like the chance to sing with Aerosmith. [C1.] MURDOCH'S THOUGHTS -- Rupert Murdoch, who has bid at least $5 billion to purchase Dow Jones, reflected in an interview that about his plans to invest in the company's journalism and about his family's commitment to preserving The Wall Street Journal's heritage. [C1.] EAT LIKE MARTHA STEWART -- Beginning in 2008, Martha Stewart's name -- and reputation -- will adorn a line of fresh, refrigerated and frozen foods sold at Costco, the nation's largest warehouse retailer. [C1.] DUTCH COURT BARS BANK DEAL -- The sale of LaSalle Bank, a longtime Chicago institution that has suddenly become a pivotal prize in the world's largest banking takeover battle, was blocked by a Dutch court. [C3.] SHELL'S EARNINGS ARE UP 5.7% -- Royal Dutch Shell, Europe's biggest oil company, said that its first-quarter earnings rose 5.7 percent, despite falling oil prices and declining profit at its production and refining arms. The improvement was mainly a result of the good performance of the stock market. The company's corporate financing arm reported earnings of $801 million, up from $227 million last year. [C3.] BANKER ACCUSED OF INSIDER TRADES -- Federal authorities arrested a Wall Street investment banker and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of Texas energy giant TXU. [C1.] NEW CHIEF AND NEW PROBLEMS -- Tony Hayward, the new chief executive of BP who took over the top job on Tuesday after John Browne abruptly quit, now faces the task of fixing a company with a broken image and damaged morale. [C3.] MAN DETAINED IN PET FOOD INQUIRY -- The manager of a Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to pet food suppliers in the United States has been detained by the Chinese authorities. [C2.] Investigators from the Food and Drug Administration have begun visiting pet food makers that use vegetable protein concentrates from China to make sure that the additives are not contaminated. [C2.] UBS TO CLOSE HEDGE FUND -- UBS, the big Swiss bank, said that it would close its hedge fund arm, Dillon Read Capital Management, after less than two years because of losses in the United States mortgage market. The decision to close Dillon Read is a blow to John P. Costas, above, who ran the hedge fund and helped propel UBS into the upper echelons of Wall Street. [C4.] MONEY TO REFINANCE LOANS -- Three Democratic senators proposed using $300 million in federal funds to help refinance troubled subprime mortgages and introduced a bill that would require brokers and lenders to act in the interest of borrowers. [C9.] VERIZON VOTE ON PAY IS CLOSE -- The shareholder vote on an executive pay proposal at Verizon Communications is too close to call. The proposal, which would allow investors to vote on executive pay, will now go to a recount. [C2.] DISAPPOINTING QUARTER AT G.M. -- General Motors lost $85 million on its North American automotive operations in the first quarter, a period in which most analysts thought it should have earned a profit. G.M.'s stock fell more than 5 percent. [C3.] NEW PUBLIC EDITOR AT THE TIMES -- The New York Times named its next public editor, Clark Hoyt, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who oversaw the Knight Ridder newspaper chain's coverage that questioned the Bush administration's case for the Iraq war.[C6.] IMUS TO SUE CBS FOR $40 MILLION -- The lawyer for the ousted radio host Don Imus said that he would file a $40 million lawsuit against CBS for breach of contract next week. [C5.] S.& P. 500 CLOSES ABOVE 1,500 -- The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed above 1,500 points for the first time since September 2000 as Wall Street extended its advance. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Starbucks said that its fiscal second-quarter profits jumped 18 percent as the company opened 560 new stores in an aggressive global expansion. (AP) No new cases of a serious brain infection have been reported among patients taking Biogen Idec's multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri since the government allowed it back onto the market, the company announced. (AP) IAC/InterActiveCorp, owner of Citysearch and Ticketmaster, posted higher first-quarter earnings, but predicted that its second-quarter results would feel pressure from lower sales at its HSN home shopping network and LendingTree units. (AP) Electronic Data Systems, the technology services company, reported a sharply higher quarterly profit as revenue from contracts increased. (REUTERS)

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fiction Meets Harsh Reality On NBC's 'Studio 60'
summary: In week 2 of the show-within-a-show on NBC's ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' Matt Albie (Matthew Perry) and Danny Tripp (Bradley Whitford) managed to muster astonishing audience growth on Monday night. But the ratings for the real show told a grimmer story. The third installment of ''Studio 60'' slipped another 16 percent, dropping to third place at 10, with 9.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC finished second for the night, and No. 1 in the 8 p.m. hour with ''Deal or No Deal'' (13 million), which tied Fox's ''Prison Break'' (8.9 million) among adults 18 to 49. Also at 8, the audience for the new CBS comedy ''The Class'' eroded another half million from a week ago, to 8 million viewers. By contrast, CBS's ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9 (15.9 million) and ''New Adventures of Old Christine'' at 9:30 (13.7 million) improved opposite NBC's ''Heroes'' (12.6 million). ABC finished third in the 9 p.m. hour with the premiere of ''The Bachelor: Rome,'' the show's ninth iteration. The bachelor, Prince Lorenzo Borghese, attracted an average of 8.9 million over two hours, faring better at 10, when ''The Bachelor'' finished second to the most-watched show of the night, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (17.3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Look, Mom! No Arms
summary: THE slipper chair, typically armless, upholstered and low to the ground, is a versatile piece of furniture, as comfortable in the bedroom as it is tucked into a corner of a library or next to a fireplace. Unobtrusive and usually small in scale, it can be pulled out for extra seating. The chairs come in a wide range of prices. Although slipper chairs have a reputation for being traditional, the new ones are just as likely to have a modern shape or contemporary upholstery. 1. The Gaucho Chair is covered in a floral cotton fabric and sits on legs stained to resemble wenge wood. Its seat is wider than those of some other slipper chairs; $499 at (800) 606-6252 or cb2.com. 2. West Elm's slipper chair is covered in a summery white leather; $499 from (888) 922-4119 or westelm.com. 3. Milo, right, and Cooper, left -- small, lightweight chairs with loose seat and back cushions and very short legs -- can be pushed around easily; $2,775 from Donghia to the trade (not including the cost of seven yards of upholstery fabric), (800) 366-4442 or donghia.com. 4. The Microsuede Slipper Chair comes with a matching bolster pillow, in red and other colors, and is available online only; $249.99 at (800) 591-3869 or target.com. 5. Inspired by the spare lines of Danish modern design, McGuire's Danish Cord Slipper Chair has a rattan pole frame and a woven cord base; price starts at $2,995. For information and locations: (800) 662-4847 or kohlerinteriors.com. 6. The Lydell Tufted Slipper Chair from Martha Stewart Furniture with Bernhardt has cherry wood finish legs and costs $825. For locations: (888) 562-7842 or marthastewart.com. 7. The Thompson Slipper Chair, shown in dark brown mohair with steel legs, has an unusually voluptuous profile; $1,425 from Desiron, 151 Wooster Street (Greene Street), (212) 353-2600 or desiron.com. 8. The Gabrielle Chair has a tufted back; $2,955 from Ralph Lauren Home. For information and locations: (888) 475-7674 or rlhome.polo.com.

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER 8 The reality series that tapes 14 housemates seven days a week and puts them on television three nights a week (Thursdays, Sundays and Tuesdays) has some new twists, which were introduced in the premiere episode on Thursday: the matching of residents with rivals or sworn enemies from their past, and the introduction of a game element called ''America's Player.'' After tonight's episode viewers can for the first time vote on an assignment that the player must attempt to carry out. 5 P.M. (HGTV) SIZZLING SUMMER Where else should you enjoy summer but in your backyard, which is also a pirate ship? Or how about relaxing in your pool, which has a volcano in the middle? Peek into 10 backyards that are more amusement park than private home in this summer special.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Top Model' Buoys CW
summary: A 21-year-old photographer, CariDee English, below, won the title of ''America's Next Top Model'' on Wednesday, as the finale of that series's seventh cycle lifted the new CW network to its best ratings ever and made it No. 1 on the night in its target demographic. According to Nielsen's estimates, the finale drew 6.3 million viewers and led the 8 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 34. It finished second to the season premiere of ''The King of Queens'' (9.5 million) on CBS in the 18-to-49 set. CBS ranked first in total viewers for the night, as its repeats of ''Criminal Minds'' (14.1 million) and ''CSI: New York'' (12.5 million) dominated at 9 and 10 p.m., respectively. NBC finished solidly in second, leading the 9 p.m. hour in the important 18-to-49 demographic as the remaining four ''Biggest Loser'' contestants spent their final week on the ranch. That show posted its best ratings in more than a year (9.4 million). Fox, with its doubleheader of ''Bones'' repeats, finished about even with ABC in last place. ABC's ''Show Me the Money'' (7.1 million) and ''Day Break'' (4.5 million) both declined to their lowest levels. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLASS OF 3000 -- André (3000) Benjamin of the hip-hop group Outkast lends his voice to Sunny Bridges (above right), the lead character of this somewhat autobiographical new animated series about a music star who gives up everything to teach a group of musical prodigies in Atlanta. Good news for Outkast fans: Mr. Benjamin, who is also a creator and executive producer of the show, will write a new song for ''Class of 3000'' each week. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Together at last, but not for long. Melinda and Jim's first camping trip is interrupted when the ghost of a woman who left her husband and young daughter asks Melinda to help her tell her child about her parents' past. 9 P.M. (CBS) CLOSE TO HOME -- When a father is murdered during a school function, Annabeth suspects a P.T.A. mother of having had an affair with the victim. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS -- Ed returns from a secret trip to Morocco and makes a shocking revelation about his past. 9 P.M. (VH1) ICE-T'S RAP SCHOOL -- The York Prep Crew starts to feel the pressure when their rap master, Ice-T (left), books them for their first performance in this reality series about a group of young musicians at a private school on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. 9 P.M. (History) THE LOST EVIDENCE -- Aerial photographs, computer graphics and interviews with veterans help recreate Gen. Douglas MacArthur's invasion of Luzon in the Philippines on Jan. 9, 1945, in this season premiere. 9 P.M. (Fox) TRADING SPOUSES: MEET YOUR NEW MOMMY -- Fair trade agreement? Tonight, one mother spends her mornings on a lobster boat while the other has to deal with a childish husband. 10 P.M. (History) DOGFIGHTS -- War buffs, don your flight suits. This new series uses computer simulation, archival footage and firsthand accounts to take viewers into the cockpit for recreations of famous battles, starting with the Air Force fighter pilots who flew F-86 Sabres during the Korean War 10:30 P.M. (TLC) COVER SHOT -- Amy, a 28-year-old cancer survivor who recently lost 125 pounds, gets a glamour treatment for a photo shoot and winds up with her image on a billboard over Times Square. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Martin Short (right) hams it up in the guest's seat. The comedian Marc Maron has the difficult job of conjuring up some laughs for himself. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Ugly Betty' Looking Good
summary: ABC's ''Ugly Betty,'' starring America Ferrara, below, became the most-watched new show of the fall season in its Thursday night debut, besting the Sunday premiere of ''Brothers & Sisters'' on ABC by 400,000 viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Ugly Betty'' drew 16.1 million viewers, lifting ABC over CBS for the night in the crucial demographic of adults 18 to 49. CBS attracted the most total viewers every hour, starting with ''Survivor: Cook Islands,'' which topped ''Ugly Betty'' with 16.6 million viewers. At 9, CBS's ''CSI'' (23.5 million) returned to form, edging out ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC (23.2 million) for the top spot, but ''CSI'' finished second by 19 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS's new drama ''Shark,'' with James Woods, led at 10 with 14.7 million viewers, but it, too, lagged among adults 18 to 49. ABC's ''Six Degrees'' (10.8 million) took second in that demographic by a 5 percent margin, while the leader, NBC's ''ER'' (14.2 million), outperformed ''Shark'' by 45 percent. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fox Rides the Tigers' Back
summary: Game 2 of the World Series on Sunday night gave Fox its first ratings victory in recent weeks. The Detroit Tigers' victory over the St. Louis Cardinals averaged 18.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen's time-zone adjusted estimates. ABC finished No. 2 for the night as, among the many plot lines on ''Desperate Housewives,'' Carlos (Ricardo Antonio Chavira) discovered Gabrielle (Eva Longoria) in bed with another man. The episode garnered 19.5 million viewers, leading the 9 p.m. hour over both baseball on Fox and ''Cold Case'' on CBS (14.6 million). At 8, ABC's repeat of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (12.7 million) outdrew CBS's ''Amazing Race 10'' (11 million), in which Sarah, an amputee and her boyfriend-teammate, Peter, a clinical prosthetist, were eliminated. At 10, ABC's ''Brothers and Sisters'' (12.1 million) held a slight edge in the 18-to-49 demographic over CBS's ''Without a Trace,'' which averaged more total viewers in the hour (14.8 million). NBC finished fourth for the night with a marathon of repeats of its new show ''Heroes.'' BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'House' Makes Fox's Night
summary: The brilliant drug-addicted Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) contemplated rehab Tuesday, as Fox's ''House'' drew 16.1 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, giving the network a victory for the night among adults 18 to 49. This compensated for Fox's ''Standoff'' (5 million), which ranked last in the 8 p.m. hour behind NBC's third-place ''Friday Night Lights'' (5.7 million). In total viewers CBS finished the night No. 1 ahead of Fox, aided by ''NCIS'' at 8 (17.4 million) and ''The Unit'' at 9 (13.5 million). ABC finished third over all, getting a boost from its 8 p.m. special, ''Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas'' (11 million). At 10, ABC's Barbara Walters special, ''The 10 Most Fascinating People of 2006'' (8.8 million), led among adults 18 to 49, despite finishing third in the hour in total viewers to repeats on CBS and NBC. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TRANSACTIONS
summary: BASEBALL American League BOSTON RED SOX--Named Jon Deeble manager and Ace Adams pitching coach for Lowell of the New York Penn League; Bruce Crabbe minor league infield coordinator; Mike Cather pitching coach for Portland of the EL; Bob Kipper pitching coach for Wilmington-Lancaster of the Carolina League, and Walter Miranda pitching coach for Greenville of the South Atlantic League. TAMPA BAY DEVIL RAYS--Acquired INF Brendan Harris from the Cincinnati Reds for a player to be named or cash. BASKETBALL National Basketball Association GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS--Signed G Kelenna Azubuike. PORTLAND TRAIL BLAZERS--Waive G Stephen Graham. NBA Development League ALBUQUERQUE THUNDERBIRDS--Signed F-C Eddy Fobbs. Waived C Manual Narvaez. FOOTBALL National Football League CINCINNATI BENGALS--Added LB Jason Berryman, TE Tim Day, TE Ronnie Ghent, DE Eric Henderson, OL Nate Livings, FB Chris Manderino, TD Sean Mulcahy, OL Alan Reuber, CB Brandon Williams and DL Jimmy Verdon to their offseason roster. GREEN BAY PACKERS--Signed WR Carlton Brewster, LB Spencer Havner, OL Travis Leffew, S Alvin Nnabuife, WR Calvin Russell, G Adam Stenavich, T Orrin Thompson and CB Tramon Williams to reserve/future contracts. OAKLAND RAIDERS--Announced the resignation of Chuck Pagano, defensive backs coach, to become defensive coordinator at North Carolina. PHILADELPHIA EAGLES--Signed QB Koy Detmer. Signed QB Omar Jacobs to the practice squad. Released CB Bruce Perry. PITTSBURGH STEELERS--Announced the retirement of Dick Hoak, running backs coach. SAN FRANCISCO 49ERS--Allocated WR C.J. Brewer, WR Marcus Maxwell, S Vickiel Vaughn and G Tavares Washington to NFL Europe. SEATTLE SEAHAWKS--Placed DB Kelly Herndon and DB Jimmy Williams on injured reserve. Signed DB John Howell and DB Pete Hunter. HOCKEY National Hockey League ANAHEIM DUCKS--Assigned G Michael Wall to Portland of the AHL. ATLANTA THRASHERS--Assigned RW Darren Haydar to Chicago of the AHL. BOSTON BRUINS--Recalled G Phillipe Sauve from Providence of the AHL. Assigned G Hannu Toivonen to Providence. DALLAS STARS--Recalled C Joel Lundqvist from Iowa of the AHL. MINNESOTA WILD--Assigned RW Joel Ward to Houston of the AHL. OTTAWA SENATORS--Assigned RW Jeff Heerema and C Serge Payer to Binghamton of the AHL. SAN JOSE SHARKS--Assigned RW Steve Bernier and D Matt Carle to Worcester of the AHL. American Hockey League IOWA STARS--Added D Mario Scalzo to the roster. NORFOLK ADMIRALS--Released D Mitch Maunu. WILKES-BARRE/SCRANTON PENGUINS--Announced C Patrick Thoresen has been assigned to the team by the Edmonton Oilers. Central Hockey League AMARILLO GORILLAS--Waived G Garth Carrell. headline: Arts, Briefly; Charles Gibson of ABC Leads Nightly News Race
summary: For the second time in less than a month, the most-watched network evening newscast last week was ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC, according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. With an average of 9.4 million viewers each night last week, ''World News'' outdrew ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' by about 310,000 viewers a night. (The ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' trailed Mr. Gibson's program by about 2.5 million viewers a night.)Before winning the overall weekly ratings crown during the week ending Feb. 9, the ABC program had not done so since August 2005, immediately after the death of Peter Jennings. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Corrections
summary: An obituary on Dec. 26 about Frank Stanton, the former president of CBS, overstated his role in efforts to persuade Congress to suspend an ''equal time'' law so that the 1960 presidential debates between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon could be broadcast. Spokesmen for NBC and ABC testified in support of Mr. Stanton's effort; Mr. Stanton alone did not persuade Congress to suspend the provision.

headline: THE BLOGS
summary: There are blogs out there for every political persuasion. But who is reading them? College graduates who are paying attention to the 2008 campaign are the prime audience, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Registered voters, particularly those who plan to vote in a primary, are more likely to visit blogs.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WHITE, LAWRENCE (LARRY)
summary: WHITE--Lawrence (Larry), died on March 25, 2007. Born in Cohoes, NY, he was one of the pioneers of the early days of television broadcasting. He began his career at the Dumont Television Network. At CBS he was instrumental in developing the long running daytime programs, 'As the World Turns', and 'Hollywood Squares'. He then joined NBC daytime, and eventually became Vice President of Nighttime TV in Los Angeles. He was President of Columbia Pictures TV. He produced the award winning miniseries 'The Blue and the Gray'. A graduate of Syracuse University, he received their George Arents Alumni Award. He is survived by his devoted wife and partner, Catherine DeCarlo White, daughters Carol Bishop and Lauren White, son-in-law Alex Gansa, and grandchildren Michael and Steven Bishop, and William Gansa. Services will be held on Friday, March 30, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to the Visiting Neighbors Association. 611 Broadway, NY 10012, Suite 510.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: ALL TOO REAL Perhaps more than any other program on television now, ''Intervention,'' A&E's documentary series about addiction, highlights the sticky situations reality show producers can find themselves in as they document unpredictable and unstable subjects or situations. [C1.] ''Kid Nation,'' the CBS reality program that had trouble attracting advertisers because of early criticism of its premise, has nearly tripled its number of advertisers since the premiere, though the audience has continued to shrink. [C3.]

headline: Weighing History and Taste, Network Executives Consider Images of a Hanging
summary: In the hours before the hanging of Saddam Hussein television news executives were thrown into hurried consultations yesterday over how to handle any images of his execution that might be released. Though there was some question as to whether any video images would be issued any time soon, the network news divisions at ABC and CBS said that should the video become available, some visual documentation of Mr. Hussein's death might be broadcast, but no overly graphic images, and certainly not the complete execution.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Bad Night for Television's New Prime-Time Shows
summary: This season's new Wednesday shows posted disappointing results all around, according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC's comedies ''30 Rock'' (8 p.m., 4.8 million) and ''Twenty Good Years'' (8:30, 4.2 million) fell to their lowest levels to date. Among adults 18 to 49, the NBC sitcoms finished sixth in the hour behind Univision's ''Fea Más Bella'' (4.3 million). Also at 8, CBS's ''Jericho,'' one of the few successful newcomers this fall, drew its smallest audience yet (10 million). At 9, a new Fox quiz show, ''The Rich List,'' made a weak fourth-place debut (4.1 million), and at 10, ''The Nine'' earned a series-low 6.7 million viewers on ABC, ranking third in its time slot behind NBC's ''Dateline'' (7.1 million), which featured an interview with Madonna. ABC and CBS led the night over all. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show (19.2 million) dominated at 8, as Monique Coleman and her partner, Louis Van Amstel, were the latest to go. At 9, CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (16.8 million) finished ahead of ABC's ''Lost'' (16.1 million) in total viewers for the first time. (''Lost'' retained a 35 percent edge in adults 18 to 49.) At 10, CBS's ''CSI: New York'' remained unbeatable (16.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Rudolph Reigns
summary: CBS racked up another Thursday-night ratings victory as ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer'' outstripped the fourth night of NBC's ''Identity.'' According to Nielsen's estimates, the 1964 Christmas classic, narrated by Burl Ives, earned 10.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. It was the second-highest-rated show Thursday, behind CBS's ''CSI'' repeat at 9 (13.2 million). Meanwhile, despite its second-place finish at 8, NBC's ''Identity'' showed slight growth from its Wednesday edition, drawing 9.5 million viewers. Aided by a decent showing at 9 for an encore of last week's Christmas episode of ''The Office'' (5.8 million), NBC ranked second for the night among adults 18 to 49, but third in total viewers behind ABC's all-rerun lineup. Fox was fourth, with original episodes of '' 'Til Death'' at 8 (5.2 million) and ''The War at Home'' at 8:30 (4.7 million). At 9, ''The OC'' improved on its season high a week ago to garner 4.5 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Fall on 'Dancing,' But No Slip in Ratings
summary: While balancing on her prosthetic leg at the end of her samba routine, Heather Mills, below, fell during Monday's edition of ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' which remained the night's leader in the ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, this 90-minute variety show averaged 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., putting ABC on top over all, even as ''The Bachelor,'' which followed, drew 9.3 million viewers from 9:30 to 11. CBS, which ranked second for the night, led during that portion of prime time with ''The King of Queens'' at 9:30 (12.3 million) and ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (15.2 million). Fox's new drama ''Drive'' garnered a last-place 5.7 million viewers in its official time-period debut at 8, but the serial drama ''24'' at 9 (11.1 million) helped Fox finish third for the night. NBC was fourth; neither its improv comedy ''Thank God You're Here'' at 9 (6.9 million) nor its ''Dateline'' special on the Virginia Tech shootings at 10 (6.4 million), fared better than last place. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KYRIAZES, GEORGE
summary: KYRIAZES--George, on November 24, 2006, after a long, valiant battle, of complications from a brain tumor. Born in Samos, Greece 1948, son of Kalliope Kyriazes and the late Dr. Dimitrios Kyriazes. He graduated from high school in Samos, then attended Mount Herman Preparatory School of Massachusetts in 1967. He attended Columbia School of Engineering, he was an honors student and a star soccer player, and member of the Art Students League, excelling at fine arts drawing and industrial drafting. During his third year of undergraduate studies, George became fascinated with econometrics and the role of computing in business. He changed his major and graduated with a BA in Economics from Columbia College in 1972, and a MBA in Finance from Columbia Business School in 1975. He devoted his entire professional career to CBS, starting as a Financial Analyst in 1975, and held increasingly responsible positions in CBS records, Corporate Finance and the CBS Television Network. In 2001 he was appointed Vice President, Finance, Sales Analysis and Development. In that position through his departure in 2005, George played an integral role in developing CBS Network Television Sales strategy. George was highly regarded for his superb analytical and managerial skills, his vision, planning and execution, and above all his human touch in collaborating with and helping his colleagues as a team member, leader, mentor and friend. An ardent fan of all sports, his New York friends forgave him his preference for the Boston Red Sox. He served for 15 years as a Board MemBer for the Epilepsy Institute. He is survived by his wife Sheila and by his Mother, Kalliope Kyriazes, and he is survived by a large group of family and friends. Funeral Services 9:30 AM from Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, 486 Pompton Avenue, (Route 23), Cedar Grove, NJ 07009. 10:30AM Sts. Helen and Constantine G.O. Church, Orange, NJ. Interment at Prospect Hill Cemetery, Caldwell. Visiting Hours Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Heroic NBC
summary: ''Heroes,'' NBC's new hit, earned a series high on Monday, with 16 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. NBC led the night among adults 18 to 49 years old, and won the 8 o'clock time slot with ''Deal or No Deal'' (16.7 million). Fox's ''Prison Break'' (9.6 million) finished second, ahead of ABC's ''Charlie Brown'' double-header (9.5 million) and CBS's half-hour comedies, ''How I Met Your Mother'' (8.9 million) and ''The Class'' (8.3 million). CBS finished about even with NBC in total viewers for the night, with solid showings by ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.2 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (11.7 million), from 9 to 10. CBS also won the 10 o'clock slot with ''CSI: Miami'' (18.2 million), which easily beat NBC's ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' (7.3 million) and ABC's ''What About Brian'' (5.3 million). Fox was third for the night, ahead of ABC. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Charles Gibson in the News
summary: For the third time in four weeks, and the second week in a row, ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC was watched by more viewers last week than ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams,'' according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. Each night, ''World News'' was seen by an average of 9.57 million viewers, about 180,000 more than ''Nightly News,'' with 9.39 million. (The ''CBS Evening News'' with Katie Couric was a distant third, with 7.51 million.) In a sign that the competition between ABC and NBC remains exceptionally tight, Mr. Williams's broadcast outpaced Mr. Gibson's last week among the viewers of most interest to advertisers: those between the ages of 25 and 54. JACQUES STEINBERG

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Anatomy' and 'CSI'
summary: As the men of ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' camped out in the woods on Thursday night, the show's ratings fell to their lowest levels this season. According to Nielsen's estimates, at 9 the flirty surgeons drew 20.6 million viewers, a diminished if still large audience virtually equal to that of CBS's ''CSI'' in the same hour (20.5 million). ''Grey's Anatomy'' maintained a 25 percent edge among adults 18 to 49, and ABC led the night in that demographic, while CBS won in total viewers. ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (14.6 million) gave CBS the lead overall at 8, opposite ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC, which hit its own ratings low (12.9 million) and tied NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' (9.1 million) for second place in its first half-hour among adults 18 to 49. NBC was third for the night, carrying the 10 o'clock hour, as usual, with ''ER'' (14.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: A TUMULTUOUS YEAR Stocks fell, ending a year that left some financial firms wounded but other parts of the market and the world with huge gains. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended the year up 3.5 percent, slightly less than inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 6.4 percent for the year. [C1.] THE MEDICINE HUNTER Chris Kilham, an ethno-botanist from Massachusetts who calls himself the Medicine Hunter, has searched faraway lands for three decades for plants, oils and extracts that can heal -- to the benefit of Western pharmaceutical companies, a few unknown indigenous communities and Mr. Kilham himself. [C1.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; World Series and Reruns
summary: Game 4 of the World Series led Fox to a ratings victory on Thursday night, with about 16 million viewers tuning in during prime time for the St. Louis Cardinals' win over the Detroit Tigers, according to Nielsen's estimates. But Fox's competition was mostly reruns, with ABC and CBS in a close race for second. At 8, a new episode of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (13.1 million), in which Betty's father (Tony Plana) revealed that he was an illegal immigrant, outdrew a recap edition of CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (12.6 million). In the same hour, NBC broadcast repeats of ''My Name Is Earl'' (7.6 million) and ''The Office'' (6.4 million). The major networks were solidly in reruns the rest of the night. CBS's ''CSI'' (16.6 million) overshadowed ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' (12.2 million) at 9, while NBC's ''ER,'' this season's 10 p.m. leader, finished at 7.2 million, behind CBS's ''Shark'' (10.4 million) and a second ''Grey's Anatomy'' repeat on ABC (9.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Sugar Bowl Victory for Fox
summary: Football once again reigned in the ratings on Wednesday, as Fox's coverage of the Sugar Bowl led the night in every half-hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. In the race for No. 2, CBS outdrew NBC, and both networks overshadowed the premieres on ABC. CBS's only new show of the night, ''The King of Queens,'' ranked second at 8 p.m. with 8.6 million viewers. It was followed by repeats of ''Two and a Half Men'' at 8:30 (8.5 million), ''Criminals Minds'' at 9 (11.9 Million) and ''CSI: New York'' at 10 (10.4 million). NBC was not far behind, getting a boost from ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (11.3 million) and ''Medium'' at 10 (9.3 million). Faring less well for NBC, ''Friday Night Lights'' earned 6.3 million viewers at 8. ABC was last over all, despite the season premiere of ''According to Jim'' at 8 (7.4 million). Neither of ABC's new comedies, ''Knights of Prosperity'' at 9 (7.2 million) or ''In Case of Emergency'' at 9:30 (6.3 million), fared better than fourth place. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Horse Racing Is Safe, Fans Say in Poll
summary: A year ago, some fateful missteps by Barbaro in the Preakness Stakes resulted in him shattering his right hind leg, eventually leading to him being euthanized in January. But the sad ending appears not to have swayed most horse racing fans about the safety of the sport.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Country Music Cheers ABC
summary: The 40th annual Country Music Awards, with Brooks & Dunn and Brad Paisley as hosts, averaged 15.9 million viewers on Monday, according to Nielsen's estimates, giving ABC the lead for the night. Despite the added competition, NBC held up, ranking a strong second at 8 with ''Deal or No Deal'' (14.5 million) and at 9 with ''Heroes'' (14.3 million). ''Heroes'' actually posted the best ratings of the night among adults 18 to 49, ahead of CBS's comedies ''Two and a Half Men'' (14.5 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (11.6 million), by significant margins in that demographic. At 10, NBC's weakest hour, Part 1 of a two-part ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' earned 7.8 million viewers, about even with recent weeks. As usual, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (16.5 million) was No. 1 at 10, the only hour when ABC did not lead in total viewers. CBS edged out NBC in that category for second place for the night, while finishing third among adults 18 to 49. Fox was fourth over all, as ''Justice'' underperformed at 9 (5.8 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Game Shows Battle to a Tie
summary: ''Identity,'' NBC's latest game show, in which contestants compete by matching strangers to a list of identities, made its debut on Monday, tying NBC's 8 p.m. game show, ''Deal or No Deal,'' for the night's best ratings among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Identity,'' which features Penn Jillette as host, drew 12.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., while ''Deal or No Deal'' garnered more total viewers (15.3 million). NBC won the night over all, even as a Christmas-themed repeat of ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' (4.6 million) ranked last in the 10 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. A repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (12.3 million) led that hour, and CBS finished second for the night, broadcasting repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10. Fox was third with repeats of ''House'' at 8 (7.6 million) and ''Bones'' at 9 (6.2 million). ABC trailed, in fourth, despite original episodes of ''Supernanny'' at 9 (6.5 million) and ''What About Brian'' at 10 (4.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Subjects and Colleagues Recall Ed Bradley
summary: Jimmy Buffett, accompanied by Allen Toussaint on piano, had just finished singing ''Do You Know What It Means to Miss New Orleans?'' at the memorial service for his friend Ed Bradley yesterday when a tall, white-haired figure ascended the pulpit for a eulogy unbilled in the program. It was Bill Clinton. ''I knew I had arrived in national politics when Ed Bradley wanted to interview me,'' Mr. Clinton told the more than 2,000 people who had assembled at Riverside Church in Manhattan to pay tribute to Mr. Bradley, who died on Nov. 9. ''I always preferred watching him interview others.''

headline: Doping Scandal Puts Dark Cloud Over Coverage of Tour de France
summary: Correction Appended The end of the Lance Armstrong era was not fated to be easy for Versus.

headline: Feelings Are Mixed About Bonds's Chase
summary: More than a third of Americans want Barry Bonds to break the career record for home runs and almost as many hope he fails, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. Asked, ''Are you rooting for Barry Bonds to break Hank Aaron's record, or do you hope he will fall short?'' 35 percent said they hoped he surpassed Aaron's mark, while 30 percent said they wanted him to fall short. Nineteen percent said they did not care, and 16 percent said they did not know or had no answer.

headline: GAMESMANSHIP
summary: Analysts blame weak sales of the PlayStation 3 game console for Sony's recent profit drop, but Sir Howard Stringer, the chairman and chief executive, has no complaints. ''We've sold everything we can make and we will continue to do so,'' he said in New York last week. ''We're launching in Europe in March. We're in pretty good spirits about it.''

headline: Make Medicare for All
summary: To the Editor: With luck, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll that found that access to affordable health care is at the top of the public's domestic agenda will motivate political leaders to address the dysfunctional health care system (front page, March 2).

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Victory for NBC
summary: NBC finished on top in the ratings race on Monday, winning the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots by impressive margins, while its main competitor for the night, CBS, broadcast reruns. At 8, ''Deal or No Deal,'' NBC's successful game show with Howie Mandel as host, garnered 16.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, dominating the No. 2 show in the hour, Fox's ''Prison Break'' (9 million). NBC's new hit, ''Heroes'' (14.7 million), led the 9 p.m. hour by a 73 percent margin among adults 18 to 49. Its advantage in total viewers over repeats of CBS's ''Two and a Half Men'' (13.8) and ''New Adventures of Old Christine'' (10.8 million) was less pronounced. In third and fourth at 9 p.m. were ''The Bachelor: Rome'' on ABC (8.2 million) and ''Justice'' (6.5 million) on Fox. At 10 p.m. NBC's special edition of ''Friday Night Lights,'' normally seen on Tuesdays, drew a series-best 8.3 million viewers. But the show lost 1.5 million viewers from its first half to its second, ranking far behind a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (14.2 million) for second in the hour, but ahead of ABC's ''What About Brian'' (6.4 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: A SHAKE-UP AT CITICitigroup's embattled chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, announced a major reorganization and management shake-up as questions linger about his ability to run the giant bank. NEWSCAST FOR THE WEB Unlike its competitors at NBC and CBS, ABC News produces a daily Webcast that looks very different from its nightly newscast: the segments look raw and personal, as if they were made for MTV. ABC executives say they are deliberately aiming to please the 25- to 54-year-olds whom every news organization covets. [C1.]

headline: A Brave New World for TV? Virtually
summary: IF you can find him, Vincent Tibbett is precisely the sort of well-connected cultural liaison any emerging filmmaker should want to know. An employee of the Sundance Channel, he is as easily recognizable for his shaggy haircut and assertively casual attire as he is for the crowds of aspiring artists who follow him around, hoping to chat him up about cinematic trends, get him to evaluate their movies or simply score his e-mail address. But if Mr. Tibbett seems a bit harder to pin down for a lunch date than the average in-demand tastemaker, that's because he doesn't exist on our plane of reality. He is an electronic avatar found only in Second Life, the popular online virtual community.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Deidre's Tour Detour
summary: Just two weeks after Simon & Schuster indefinitely postponed a book tour for Deidre Imus, the wife of the talk show host Don Imus, the publisher has quietly reinstated two appearances -- with Mr. Imus possibly along for the ride. The couple will be at R. J. Julia, a bookstore in Madison, Conn., on May 9 and at the public library in Westport, Conn., on May 22 to promote ''Green This! Volume 1: Greening Your Cleaning,'' a paperback guide to environmentally friendly house cleaning. ''There are many booksellers who wanted her to appear and still do,'' David Rosenthal, publisher of Simon & Schuster, said. Mr. Imus, he added, had offered to join his wife, but the details have not yet been worked out. The book was published April 10, just days before CBS Radio canceled ''Imus in the Morning'' after he made racially and sexually derogatory remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. A day after the cancellation, Simon & Schuster postponed Ms. Imus's tour, citing the ''enormous pressure that Deirdre and her family are under.'' That tour was also to have included numerous television appearances, with Mr. Imus included on two of them: ''Larry King Live'' on CNN and ''The Tim Russert Show'' on CNBC. Victoria Meyer, a spokeswoman for Simon & Schuster, said that television appearances were again under discussion but that nothing had been scheduled. Ms. Imus is donating all the profits from the book -- including her seven-figure advance for the current book and four others -- to the couple's ranch for children with cancer in New Mexico. MOTOKO RICH

headline: Arts, Briefly; Underdog Leads 'Idol' to Victory
summary: Sanjaya Malakar, below, the 17-year-old ''American Idol'' underdog who stunned judges with a faux-hawk hairstyle for his performance on Tuesday, made the cut on Wednesday's results show along with eight other contestants. Chris Sligh, 28, however, did not, receiving the lowest total of the more than 30 million votes cast. Preliminary overnight numbers from local television markets indicate that the half-hour results show at 9 p.m. gave Fox an easy victory for the night. In second place, CBS's lineup of repeats following ''Jericho'' at 8 bested ABC and NBC, which tied for third. The Discovery Channel's three-hour premiere of its 11-part series, ''Planet Earth'' reached 12 million viewers Sunday, earning the network its highest household rating in 18 months. And NBC's ''Saturday Night Live,'' with the Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning as host, posted its best results among adults 18 to 49 in more than a year, averaging 7.9 million total viewers. That was well above the 6.5 million viewers who watched in April 2005, when Tom Brady, quarterback of the New England Patriots, was host. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: INSIDE
summary: In Poll, Americans Express Concern Over Warming Americans in large numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment and think it is necessary to take steps to reduce its effects, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds. PAGE A20 Letter by Washington Found A letter written by George Washington in 1787 was discovered among the private papers of a prominent New Jersey family. PAGE B1 U.S. Charges Officer in Iraq The American military has charged a commander at its main detention center in Baghdad with nine violations of military law, including ''aiding the enemy,'' a rare and serious accusation that could carry a death sentence. PAGE A16 Jack Valenti Is Dead Jack Valenti, a confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson who then led the Motion Picture Association of America for 38 years, devising its ratings system, was 85. PAGE C10 Corzine Says He's 'Blessed' Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, left, in his first public statement since he was critically injured in a car crash, said he felt blessed to have survived. He allowed a five-minute photo session at the Camden hospital where he is recuperating. PAGE B5 Identifying Diabetes Genes Researchers said they had identified seven new genes connected to Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease. PAGE A22 Inquiry Into Atlanta Police After a fatal shooting in a botched drug raid, prosecutors say they are investigating a ''culture of misconduct'' in the Atlanta police. PAGE A18

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Propels Fox to Victory
summary: Melinda Doolittle drew another round of praise on Fox's ''American Idol'' as the network dominated Tuesday with more than twice the viewers of its closest competitor. According to Nielsen's estimates, 25.7 million viewers tuned in to ''American Idol'' at 8 p.m. Following it, ''House'' at 9 attracted 21 million viewers of its own. CBS ranked second for the night ahead of ABC, whose ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show garnered 14.6 million viewers at 9. Among adults 18 to 49, ABC shared third with NBC, which led the 10 p.m. hour with ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (11.2 million). In the cable news race, the three leading channels all posted improvements in the first quarter of 2007 compared with the same period a year ago. MSNBC, in third place, showed the largest percentage increases, particularly in prime time, where it saw a 37 percent jump in total viewers (from 353,000 to 485,000). Fox News remained far ahead in first, averaging 1.5 million viewers in prime time, and CNN finished a solid second (759,000). Comedy Central also earned its best first quarter in the network's history, averaging of 1.1 million total viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: WARNING FOR TWO DIABETES DRUGS -- The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs, Avandia and Actos. The decision comes a year after the agency's safety reviewers strongly recommended just such a step. It also occurs during a Congressional inquiry into why the agency delayed its warnings about Avandia. [Page A1.] A medical researcher told a House hearing about name-calling and a veiled threat of a lawsuit by a drug company executive after the researcher had criticized Avandia. [A30.] CHINA TO OVERHAUL FOOD LAWS -- China said that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections. The announcement was a response to growing international concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs. [A1.] A BOOMING BUSINESS IN AUTO PARTS -- China's auto parts exports have increased more than sixfold in the last five years, nearly topping $1 billion in April, and are part of a broader shift as China moves up from basic goods like textiles and shoes toward higher-value industrial goods that compete directly with countries like the United States. [C1.] AUTOMAKERS OPPOSE ENERGY BILL -- The chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler met with Senate lawmakers, less than a week before Democrats plan a vote on a sprawling energy bill, and asserted that the bill's proposed increase in mileage requirements would be impossible to meet and would gravely damage the industry. [C1.] BUILDING A BETTER PATENT SYSTEM -- The Bush administration wants to revamp the nation's patent system, requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the patent office's chief. The goal, said Jon W. Dudas, above, the director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, is to improve the quality of patents and curb the rising wave of patent disputes and lawsuits. [C3.] LESSONS FROM LONDON -- The Bancroft family, owners of a controlling interest in Dow Jones, is trying to learn from the lessons of The Times of London as they attempt to come up with a system for keeping The Wall Street Journal's newsroom independent of Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation who has bid to buy the company. [C1.] INTEREST RATE JITTERS -- For the second consecutive day, Wall Street recoiled at the prospect that inflation would not settle down enough to suit the Federal Reserve. And investors appeared to worry not only that interest rates will stay where they are, but that the Fed could raise them even higher. [C1.] RABBIT EARS WILL NEED SOME HELP -- A broadcasters group unveiled two versions of devices that television viewers will need beginning Feb. 17, 2009, if they use rabbit ears or rooftop antennas to receive their television signal. On that date, stations must switch from traditional analog signals to digital broadcasting. [C3.] ASTRAZENECA EXECUTIVE LEAVING -- AstraZeneca, Britain's second-largest drug maker after GlaxoSmithKline, said that its chief financial officer was leaving to join to Goldman Sachs, one of AstraZeneca's corporate brokers, as a managing director. Jon Symonds, who joined Zeneca from KPMG in 1997 and was instrumental in the $30 billion merger with Astra of Sweden a year later, will step down at the end of July. [C5.] BUSH OPPOSES EMISSION TARGETS -- The White House said it would hold firm against concrete long-term targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, a major priority for Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, the host of this week's Group of 8 meeting. [A14.] EUROPEAN RATE GOES UP -- The European Central Bank raised borrowing costs to their highest level in nearly six years, pointing to a humming economy that, while welcome, raised the risk of higher inflation. European stock markets fell. [C5.] ORIENTING ELECTRONICS TO WOMEN -- Making a consumer electronic product more appealing to women no longer means offering a pink or pastel version. More manufacturers are discovering that feminizing technology is more about a product's fundamentals, often expressed in its ease of use. [C7.] PRUDENTIAL CLOSES RESEARCH UNIT -- Prudential Financial decided to close its small, struggling equity research and sales business. About 420 people will be laid off. [C3.] CITIGROUP TO PAY $15 MILLION FINE -- NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of the BellSouth Corporation into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns. [C4.] FENDI SETTLES WAL-MART SUIT -- Fendi, the Italian fashion designer and maker of luxury products, settled a lawsuit against Wal-Mart Stores that contended the retailer had sold counterfeit handbags and wallets in its Sam's Club stores. [C9.] CBS RELENTS AFTER SERIES PROTEST -- CBS reversed course three weeks after canceling the apocalyptic drama ''Jericho,'' and ordered seven new episodes after a sustained and creative protest by fans of the series. The new episodes are for broadcast late this year or early in 2008. [C4.] PHONE BOOKS ON A DIET -- The fat phone book is losing some of its girth as more people give up their land lines for cellphones. In Manhattan, despite population gains in recent years, the 2007 Verizon White Pages was 142 pages smaller than the 2006 edition. [B1.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC News Beats Katie Couric
summary: The Katie Couric bounce further eroded last week as the ''CBS Evening News'' fell firmly behind ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams,'' which finished at No. 1 all five nights last week. According to Nielsen's estimates for the week of Sept. 18-22, Ms. Couric's third week on CBS drew 7.7 million total viewers, down 2 percent from her second week. On Thursday and Friday, CBS finished last behind ABC. NBC posted nearly a half-million more viewers than CBS for the week (8.2 million), and ''ABC's World News With Charles Gibson'' finished a close third with 7.6 million. In the crucial demographic of adults 25 to 54, the three networks tied with a 2.1 rating. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; No Comedy Joy for NBC
summary: In the competitive 8 p.m. hour on Wednesday, NBC's ''30 Rock'' and ''Twenty Good Years'' made quiet debuts. ABC's ''Dancing with the Stars'' led the hour with 18.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The NBC comedies also finished behind CBS's ''Jericho'' (10.9 million). ''30 Rock,'' with Tina Fey, drew 8.3 million viewers, and ''Twenty Good Years,'' with Jeffrey Tambor and John Lithgow, 7 million. Also at 8, the CW's ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.5 million) tied NBC for the hour among adults 18 to 49, winning over all in the 18-to-34 demographic. For the night, NBC finished well behind CBS, which was on top in total viewers, and ABC, which ranked first among adults 18 to 49. In the 9 p.m. hour, ABC's ''Lost'' (16.7 million) led with a 52 percent edge in that demographic, but CBS's ''Criminal Minds,'' in which the F.B.I. team profiled a bank robber who forced his hostages to undress, posted a strong 16.5 million viewers. At 10, CBS's ''CSI: New York'' (17.7 million) outstripped Week 2 of ABC's show ''The Nine'' (8.4 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Leads, of Course
summary: With the early arrival of daylight time, relatively warm weather across much of the nation and television lineups of mostly repeats, overall prime-time viewership declined considerably Tuesday from the same night a year ago. The decrease was most marked in the 8 p.m. hour where audiences in the 18-to-49 demographic were down 12 percent, according to Nielsen's estimates. The drop-off impacted the start of the finals on Fox's ''American Idol,'' which attracted 29.4 million viewers from 8 to 10, some 3 million viewers less than a year ago (32.7 million). CBS ranked a distant second for the night with reruns of ''NCIS'' at 8 (11.5 million), ''The Unit'' at 9 (7.7 million) and ''CSI'' at 10 (9.2 million). On FX, Monday's 10 p.m. debut of ''The Riches,'' with Eddie Izzard and Minnie Driver, drew 2.5 million viewers aged 18 to 49, the second-best tally ever for an FX series premiere. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Falling Into Sweeps
summary: With the start of November sweeps, Fox faltered into a sixth-place finish on Thursday behind both CW and Univision, whose broadcast of the Latin Grammy Awards delivered 5.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. After a hiatus for baseball, Fox's comedies '' 'Til Death'' (4.3 million viewers) and ''Happy Hour'' (3.1 million) returned at 8 p.m. in last place; at 9, ''The O.C.'' made a weak fourth-season debut (3.4 million). NBC fared well for the night, as ''My Name Is Earl'' (9.6 million), featuring a guest appearance by Roseanne Barr, above, surged into second from 8 to 8:30 among adults 18 to 49, and at 9, ''Deal or No Deal'' posted 13.1 million. For the night, CBS and ABC shared the lead, with CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (15.6 million) ahead of ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (13.7 million) at 8, and ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' (21 million) edging out CBS's ''CSI'' (20.5 million) at 9. NBC's ''ER'' (13.8 million) remained the show to beat at 10, while ABC's ''Six Degrees'' sank to its lowest level to date (7.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF
