headline: Help for Small Business In Creating TV Spots
summary: An online service that helps small businesses advertise on television is getting its first investments from big advertising and media companies. The CBS Corporation, the Interpublic Group of Companies and the WPP Group are among several investors that are giving the service, called Spot Runner, a total of $40 million in additional capital. Spot Runner (online at spotrunner.com) began operations in January with $10 million in venture capital from investors like Allen & Company.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Newcomers Lose Viewers
summary: Two high-profile shows resumed their ratings slides on Monday night, one week after showing turnaround promise. ''The Class,'' CBS's new comedy from David Crane and Jeffrey Klarik, dipped to 8.7 million viewers in its second try at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. And on NBC, after holding steady a week ago, ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' the new drama from Aaron Sorkin, garnered a season-low 7.8 million viewers, shedding 13 percent of its audience in its second half-hour. NBC's woes at 10 might have been compounded by ABC's ''What About Brian'' (8.3 million), which improved to second in the hour. CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (17.6 million), which featured a case of eminent domain and a murdered politician, ranked first. But NBC did fare well for the night over all, finishing behind only CBS in total viewers and No. 1 in the important 18-to-49 demographic. At 8, NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' dominated with 17.3 million viewers. And at 9, NBC's new drama ''Heroes'' (13.1 million) won among adults 18 to 49 over both CBS comedies in the hour, ''Two and a Half Men'' (16.4 million) and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (13.3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Anatomy' and Baseball
summary: ABC led the Thursday prime-time television ratings among adults 18 to 49, as ''Grey's Anatomy'' expanded its lead over CBS's ''CSI'' in that important demographic to 40 percent. ''Grey's Anatomy,'' at 9 p.m., had 21.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''CSI'' posted strong results in total viewers (20.2 million), helping CBS win the night in that category. CBS also topped the 8 p.m. hour with a double-elimination episode of ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' (15 million); ABC's ''Ugly Betty'' (13.1 million) remained in second. Game Seven of the National League Championship Series gave the lead for the 10 p.m. hour to Fox, which ranked third for the night. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC Wins With Ease
summary: With CBS broadcasting repeats Monday, solid showings for ''Deal or No Deal'' and ''Heroes'' lifted NBC to an easy ratings victory for the night. According to Nielsen's estimates, NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 17.2 million viewers, while ABC's ''Wife Swap,'' the closest competitor in the hour, garnered 9.1 million viewers. At 9, NBC's ''Heroes'' (15 million) also overshadowed the third season premiere of ABC's ''Supernanny'' (10.5 million), which finished second in the hour. A repeat of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (11.5 million) still managed to lead the 10 p.m. hour, as ratings for ABC's ''What About Brian'' (6.2 million) and a Christmas-themed ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' on NBC (7.4 million) showed little change from their most recent installments. Fox ranked a distant fourth for the night with its coverage of the 17th Annual ''Billboard Music Awards'' (6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Stones' Mild Horses Plan Troubles Animal Lovers A plan to sedate more than 300 horses at a Belgrade race track where a Rolling Stones concert on July 14 is expected to draw more than 100,000 people has ignited rage among Serbian animal lovers, Reuters reported yesterday. O.R.C.A., the country's largest animal protection society, said that the noise and vibrations of the concert would be extremely harmful to the animals and added that sedating them is not the answer. The society said that if it failed to persuade the organizers to move the concert from the Hippodrome, Belgrade's largest fenced space, it would appeal directly to the Stones -- including Mick Jagger, above -- who have never performed in Serbia. ''I believe we'll succeed, since such a reputable band will not allow such a stain on its record,'' said Elvir Burazerovic, the president of O.R.C.A. A Book Club of One The Canadian author Yann Martel, below, who wrote the best-selling novel ''Life of Pi,'' wants the country's prime minister, Stephen Harper, to pay more attention to the arts. So Mr. Martel is sending him some reading. Mr. Martel said he was upset that Mr. Harper had appeared to pay no attention during a recent ceremony honoring Canadian artists, Reuters reported. ''But he must have moments of stillness,'' Mr. Martel said. ''For as long as Stephen Harper is prime minister of Canada, I vow to send him every two weeks, mailed on a Monday, a book that has been known to expand stillness.'' First up: ''The Death of Ivan Ilyich'' by Leo Tolstoy. There was no immediate comment from Mr. Harper's office. Mr. Martel said he would post all selections and other developments on the Internet at whatisstephenharperreading.ca. 'Survivor' Heads for China China will be the location of the 14th edition of the CBS reality show ''Survivor,'' Variety.com reported. American productions on the mainland have been rare, but China has become more open. The CBS series will be the first American network show to be filmed there, Variety said. Kirov Ballet Plans A City Center Visit The Kirov Ballet and Orchestra will perform at New York City Center for the first time when it appears there next year, from April 1 to 20. Under the artistic direction of Valery Gergiev and the director of the ballet Makhar Vaziev, the company from St. Petersburg, Russia, will dance repertory classics including Petipa's ''Kingdom of Shadows'' from ''La Bayadère''; Fokine's ''Scheherazade'' and ''Chopiniana''; Gorsky's ''Grand Pas de Deux'' from ''Don Quixote''; Balanchine's ''Jewels'' and ''Ballet Imperial'' and Forsythe's ''Septet.'' Tickets go on sale on Friday. Tickets for the 75th Radio City Christmas Spectacular go on sale at 9 a.m. Sunday. The show, featuring new scenes and Rockette performance numbers and new Rockette costumes, will run from Nov. 9 through Dec. 30 at Radio City Music Hall. Gere's Kisses Reach Court India's overburdened judicial system has two new cases after three lawyers filed complaints against Richard Gere, 57, for kissing the actress Shilpa Shetty, below, 31, at an AIDS awareness rally in New Delhi, The Associated Press reported. Public displays of affection are largely taboo in India. In one complaint a lawyer accused the actors of committing ''an obscene act,'' the Press Trust of India reported. Two other lawyers filed another complaint in Ghaziabad, a town on the outskirts of New Delhi, naming Ms. Shetty and private television channels for showing videos of the incident. Ms. Shetty said the hug and kisses were not obscene and that the public was overreacting. Yesterday, her representative, Dale Bhagwagar, declined comment on the court complaints but said, ''The media should concentrate on the cause of AIDS awareness rather than making an issue out of kisses.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CMT) THE ULTIMATE COYOTE UGLY SEARCH -- What, exactly, is a coyote, you ask? For those who never saw the movie, it's a woman who can sing, dance, bartend and ''flare'' (translation: juggle bottles, shakers and glasses à la Tom Cruise in ''Cocktail'') better than any other. And yep, she has to be pretty. In the finale of this reality series, Liliana Lovell, the founder of Coyote Ugly -- originally a rowdy watering hole in Manhattan's East Village, and now a chain -- takes five finalists (above, from left, Gina, Kassie, Tess, Amber and Michaela) down to New Orleans, where they'll put on their best barkeep behavior to win $25,000, and center stage, on the night of that city's Coyote re-opening. 8 P.M. (CBS) A DR. PHIL PRIME-TIME SPECIAL: ESCAPING DANGER -- According to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, 691,710 nonfatal acts of domestic violence were committed in the United States in 2001; 85 percent of these were against women. And in 2000, 1,247 women and 440 men were killed by an intimate partner. In this hourlong special, Dr. Phil McGraw gets inside the mind of a young mother whose husband has held her captive through terror and counsels her on life-saving decisions. And then he confronts her abuser with a not-to-beignored request that he take responsibility for his actions. 9 P.M. (CBS) CLOSE TO HOME -- Season finale. Annabeth (Jennifer Finnigan, right) prosecutes two teenagers for the murder of a man they claim was an online sexual predator. But then death hits even closer to home. 9 P.M. (NBC) CONVICTION -- In yet another episode ripped from the headlines, a bouncer becomes the prime suspect when a woman is murdered after leaving a bar. At 10, a courthouse shootout leaves the staff of the assistant district attorney's office otherwise occupied. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS -- It's easy to blame Mom. In this season finale, Olympia Dukakis plays the mother of a rapist-turned-serial killer -- and you know where that story line is headed -- and JoBeth Williams portrays Margaret Eppes, the dead mother whose memory Charlie (David Krumholtz) has never laid to rest. 10 P.M. (CMT) UNSUNG STORIES -- Many a country song has sprung from a kernel of truth. That's the premise behind this new series in which professional songwriters take a real event and transform it into lyrics and music. First up, ''Jake's Goin' All the Way,'' an anthem by Jeffrey Steele and Keith Anderson (above right, with Mr. Steele) about a developmentally disabled teenager whose touchdown on a football field touched an entire community. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Democratic Leader Put to Work as G.O.P. Campaign Star
summary: Representative Melissa Bean of Illinois, a Democrat, has a Republican opponent in next week's election, but he does not appear in the advertisement that skewers her. Instead, that role is being played by a fellow Democrat, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the minority leader. Judging by some of the political name-calling in the final days before the elections, Ms. Pelosi seems to be in the thick of campaigns for Congress from Illinois to Georgia and several places in between. She is the unwitting star of at least a half-dozen television spots -- and countless radio spots, direct-mail campaigns and candidate debates --warning voters that if they choose their local Democrat for Congress, they are also casting a vote for Ms. Pelosi.

headline: Arrivals and a Departure | May 28-June 3
summary: THE MONEY MAN The News -- President Bush nominated Henry M. Paulson Jr., chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, to become his next Treasury secretary. Behind the News -- In some ways, an odd choice. Mr. Paulson is a deficit hawk while the administration has built up historic budget deficits. But many allies of the White House had lobbied for him, convinced he could help convey the strengths in the economy and reassure voters of the president's economic competence. Mr. Paulson had to be carefully courted, a sign of the prestige the job has lost under Mr. Bush. THE NONCIVILIAN The News -- Gen. Michael V. Hayden was sworn in as director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Behind the News -- At the ceremony Wednesday, President Bush felt compelled to give agency employees a pep talk, assuring them that they remained ''vital'' to the White House. The event was for public consumption. (The general officially became director Tuesday.) The administration wanted to lift agency morale and portray a sense of calm after several turbulent years at the C.I.A. Sensitivity lingers over a military officer leading the civilian agency. THE GOLDEN ARM The News -- Roger Clemens, the future Hall of Fame pitcher, agreed to come out of retirement and rejoin the Houston Astros. Behind the News -- A break for the struggling Astros, the defending National League champions. Clemens turns 44 in August but is hardly teetering. He led the major leagues with a 1.87 earned run average last year. His time off could keep him fresh in September. Three other 43-year-old pitchers are still kicking: Terry Mulholland of Arizona, Jaimie Moyer of Seattle and David Wells of Boston. One subplot: Clemens's son Koby, an infielder in Houston's minor league system, could join his father soon. THE NEW CHILD The News -- Well, not so new a child. Prince Albert II of Monaco acknowledged that he is the father of a 14-year-old American girl, a lawyer for the prince's family, Thierry Lacoste, told Le Figaro, a French newspaper. Officials in Monaco said they would not comment on the matter. Behind the News -- Last year, Prince Albert, who is not married, acknowledged that he was the father of a 3-year-old boy. He later told The New York Times that he did not know of any other paternity claims that could be true. Mr. Lacoste told Le Figaro that legal paternity was established several weeks ago. THE LONG FAREWELL The News -- Katie Couric spent her final day as anchor of ''Today.'' Now it's on to the ''CBS Evening News'' in September. Behind the News -- For weeks, NBC built a relentless drumbeat of publicity. Then came Wednesday's lovefest packed with memories and tributes. Was it too much? It could have ''turned unbearably cloying but didn't, mainly because Ms. Couric reined in her emotions and did not exit in a puddle of tears,'' wrote Alessandra Stanley of The New York Times. But David Hinckley of The Daily News said the show was ''more like a long in-house graduation party.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 33RD ANNUAL DAYTIME EMMY AWARDS -- The hosts, at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood, are Tom Bergeron and Kelly Monaco (above), who worked together on ''Dancing With the Stars'' (as host and first winner). Rick Springfield, the erstwhile Dr. Noah Drake on ''General Hospital,'' performs. And the perpetually nominated hosts of the talk show ''The View'' are predicting that they'll lose again. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- All season, Melinda Gordon (Jennifer Love Hewitt) has been receiving and conveying messages from the unhappy dead. Tonight she hears from people who aren't quite there yet -- a pilot and a flight attendant on a plane that is losing cabin pressure and about to crash. Part 1 of a two-part season finale. 8 P.M. (A&E) BIOGRAPHY: DOLLY PARTON -- Ms. Parton (right), 60, was born in Tennessee, began singing at the Grand Ole Opry in her teens, won her first Grammy in 1977 (for ''Here You Come Again'') and has her own theme park. 8 P.M. (Ovation) RAY DAVIES: THE WORLD FROM MY WINDOW -- In the 1960's Mr. Davies was recording rock hits like ''You Really Got Me'' and ''All of the Night'' as lead singer and songwriter of the Kinks. Today he's 61 and a Commander of the British Empire. 10 P.M. (NBC) CONVICTION -- Alexandra Cabot (Stephanie March), who was promoted to bureau chief when she moved from ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' to this newer Dick Wolf series, isn't completely happy with the ''stage presence'' that two of her young, eager assistant district attorneys (Julianne Nicholson and Jordan Bridges) display in court. So she sends them to acting class. Another A.D.A. (Eric Balfour) runs into a ''wall of blue'' prosecuting his latest case. 11 P.M. (HBO) REAL TIME WITH BILL MAHER -- George Clooney is Mr. Maher's guest. 12:15 A.M. (TCM) DINER (1982). Steve Guttenberg, Tim Daly and (above, from left) Kevin Bacon, Mickey Rourke, Daniel Stern and Paul Reiser play old high school pals who are having trouble adjusting to adult life, especially marriage, in late-1950's Baltimore. Why, they wonder, should a wife take precedence over passions for, say, the Baltimore Colts or a cherished record collection? This was Barry Levinson's first film. ANITA GATES

headline: FIRST AND LONG -- VERY LONG
summary: Bill Hambrecht is a rich old Wall Street guy who has made his money tilting at windmills and disrupting the establishment. ''That's what I do,'' he says. ''It's fun.'' Almost a decade ago, at 62, he founded WR Hambrecht + Company, whose fundamental premise is that companies don't need to use Wall Street investment bankers -- and pay their outrageous fees -- to go public. Hambrecht + Company has since become so threatening to traditional underwriters that they often refuse to be involved in any I.P.O. in which his firm takes part. And now, at an age when most people are well into retirement, he has decided to tackle the establishment again. This time, though, the establishment isn't Wall Street. It's the National Football League. Bill Hambrecht, you see, is starting up a professional football league. So far, he and his partner, Tim Armstrong, a senior executive at Google, have pledged $2 million each. They've hired a C.E.O. and a C.O.O., both of whom cut their teeth at the National Basketball Association. They've got a name: the United Football League. And they've lined up a wealthy, well-known businessman as their first owner: Mark Cuban, the billionaire who owns the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks. Like Hambrecht, Cuban loves nothing more than confronting the status quo.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Dancing Into the Ratings
summary: After excelling in the first week of ''Dancing With the Stars,'' a nervous Tatum O'Neal, below, fell victim to a pro-Master P voting campaign in Week 2, even though that lead-footed hip-hop star still seemed reluctant to be there. Master P, despite receiving a lower judges' score than Ms. O'Neal at the end of the Thursday performance show, then netted more viewer votes, beating Ms. O'Neal in Friday night's results show. ABC's hourlong ''Dancing'' was the most-watched program of the night, with 13.67 million viewers, but CBS's lineup -- ''Ghost Whisperer'' (10.98 million), ''Close to Home'' (11.14 million) and ''Numbers'' (12.77 million) -- won the night both in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. ABC was a competitive second place in both of those areas, as its new legal drama, ''In Justice,'' held up fairly well in its second week (8.73 million on Friday versus 9.17 million on Jan. 6). But NBC's ''Book of Daniel'' bombed: it delivered only 6.96 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Senate Leaders Reach Deal to Offer Citizenship to Most Illegal Immigrants Senate leaders reached agreement on a broad compromise that would put the vast majority of the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship. The plan would also create a temporary worker program that would allow 325,000 foreigners to fill jobs in the United States each year. If passed, it would be the most sweeping immigration accord in two decades. But the plan quickly ran into resistance from conservative Republicans. [Page A1.] U.S. to Name Outside Experts to Monitor Heart Units The Food and Drug Administration is planning to strengthen how it monitors heart devices like defibrillators by appointing outside medical experts to help it review the safety of units on the market, an agency official said. [C1.] Next Task for Massachusetts: Workable Health Plan The Massachusetts plan to achieve nearly universal health coverage now faces the challenge of creating a viable market in affordable insurance policies, so that businesses and individuals will buy the coverage mandated by the state's legislature. [C1.] Reality Series to Focus on Aspiring Filmmakers Television's most successful reality-show producer, Mark Burnett, left, will work with the film director Steven Spielberg on a Fox series devoted to finding the ''American Idol'' of unknown movie directors. The series, called ''On the Lot,'' will combine elements of several previous reality series to form an elimination contest for aspiring filmmakers. Mr. Burnett said the show would try to take advantage of the enormous number of self-made video and film shorts that have become ubiquitous on the Internet. [C6.] CBS Looks to Couric to Turn Viewing Tide in Key Cities CBS is betting millions of dollars that Katie Couric's move to its evening news program from the ''Today'' show will have a major impact on the television-watching habits in ''battleground'' television markets like Grand Rapids, Mich. In the cities and suburbs of western Michigan, more than half of the televisions that are turned on at 6:30 p.m. are tuned in to one of the three network newscasts, as compared with about a third nationally, according to Nielsen Media Research. [C1.] NBC named Meredith Vieira to the co-host position of the ''Today'' show, to succeed Katie Couric. [C4.] Morgan Stanley Hires Prominent Deal Maker Morgan Stanley, which has suffered a series of executive defections, announced one of its biggest coups, hiring Robert A. Kindler, who was the global head of mergers and acquisitions at J.P. Morgan Chase. Mr. Kindler will become vice chairman of investment banking at Morgan Stanley. [C6.] Ford President to Retire; Chief Executive to Take Post Ford Motor said that its president, James Padilla, would retire July 1. His duties will be assumed by Ford's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., who is forming a new executive operating committee to help run the company. [C6.] European Bank Catches Markets Off Guard on Rates In a surprise to financial markets, the European Central Bank doused widespread expectations that it would raise interest rates next month as part of its gradual tightening of monetary policy. [C6.] Gold and Silver Hit Highs Not Seen Since 1980's Gold touched $600 an ounce for the first time in 25 years and silver hit a 22-year high as investors continued to pour money into precious metals. [C7.] The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.05 points, to 11,216.50. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.52 points, to 1,309.04, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.42 points, to 2,361.17, its best close since Feb. 16, 2001. [C7.] News Corporation Settles Suit on Antitakeover Plan The News Corporation settled a shareholder lawsuit two weeks before the opening of a trial in a lawsuit that accused the company of defrauding investors by denying them a vote on whether to extend an antitakeover resolution adopted in 2004. [C6.] Former Merck Chief Takes Stand in Vioxx Case The punitive damages phase of the fourth Vioxx case to reach a jury began with testimony from Raymond V. Gilmartin, the former chief executive of Merck, who faced the plaintiff lawyer, W. Mark Lanier. Mr. Gilmartin took the stand the day after a New Jersey jury awarded $4.5 million to John McDarby, a 77-year-old who had a heart attack in 2004 after taking Vioxx for four years. Mr. Gilmartin seemed relatively unfazed after a day of difficult questions from Mr. Lanier, who in August won an even larger verdict against Merck in the first Vioxx personal injury case. [C3.] Pfizer to Acquire a Biotechnology Company Pfizer will acquire Rinat Neuroscience, a privately held company developing drugs for pain, Alzheimer's disease and other neurological disorders. [C6.] Armenia Settles Gas Conflict With Russia In a settlement of the latest natural gas dispute in the former Soviet Union, Armenia will receive natural gas supplies from Russia at prices well below European averages until 2009. In exchange, it will surrender a small but crucial section of gas pipeline to Russia. [C6.] In Russia, Warning of a Bubble That Might Burst Russia's top market regulator is warning that the surging Russian stock market is showing some ''alarming signs'' of become too expensive. [C5.]

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 U.S. Urges U.N. Sanctions On North Korea After Test The United States proposed tough new United Nations sanctions on North Korea after what seemed to be its test of a nuclear device, and President Bush warned the North he considered its activity a potential threat to American national security. A1 The North Korean test appears to have been a nuclear detonation, but was fairly small by traditional standards, and possibly a failure or a partial success, government and private analysts said. A8 Korean Closer to U.N. Post The United Nations Security Council officially nominated Ban Ki-moon, the foreign minister of South Korea, to become the next secretary general of the United Nations. A10 Northern Ireland's Rivals Meet The Rev. Ian Paisley, the leader of Northern Ireland's largest Protestant political party, held formal talks for the first time with the leader of the province's Roman Catholic Church. A12 South Africa to Seize Farms South Africa's land claims commissioner said the government would expropriate two white-owned farms claimed by black citizens, signaling a quickening in the pace of the nation's land reform. A13 Sibling of Sunni Leader Slain Men wearing military police uniforms broke into the house of the brother of Iraq's Sunni vice president, chased him onto a neighbor's roof and shot him in the head, killing him, Iraqi authorities and witnesses said. A14 NATIONAL A16-23 Scandal Weakens G.O.P., New Poll Data Shows Americans say that Republican Congressional leaders put their political interests ahead of protecting the safety of teenage pages, and that House leaders knew of Mark Foley's sexually charged messages to pages before he was forced to quit Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. A22 Post-9/11 Strategy Tests F.B.I. Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks spurred a new mission, F.B.I. culture still respects door-kicking investigators more than deskbound analysts sifting through data. The agency's uneasy transition into a spy organization has provoked criticism. A1 More Worries for Farmers The timing of the latest recall of California produce, that of 8,500 cartons of lettuce, could not have come at a worse time for farmers still reeling from an E. coli outbreak in spinach. A16 Military Makes Recruiting Goal The Pentagon is poised to announce that the military reached its targets for signing up new recruits in 2006, a year after the Army failed to meet its recruiting goal by the widest margin in two decades. A19 King Items Displayed in Atlanta A collection of personal items that once belonged to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been returned to Atlanta and will go on public display in January, officials at Morehouse College announced. A16 Missouri School Shooting No one was hurt when a seventh-grade student in Joplin, Mo., fired an assault rifle in his school, the authorities said. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 School Ignored Signs of Teacher's Misconduct Diane Cherchio West was allowed to continue working in the public schools in Bayonne, N.J., for two decades even though she repeatedly became sexually involved with her students. Now, as the school district faces a lawsuit, Bayonne has been forced to examine how little was done to stop her earlier. A1 New Stage in School Lawsuit A 13-year-old lawsuit accusing New York State of shortchanging New York City's schools by billions of dollars is expected to enter its last round today. B1 Man Hit by Car After Chase Detectives were trying to determine why two men forced a third man into the busy eastbound lanes of the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn on Sunday night, leaving him seriously injured after he was struck by a car, the police said. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Google to Buy YouTube Google, the online search behemoth, agreed to pay $1.65 billion in stock for YouTube, the video-sharing phenomenon that is the darling of an Internet resurgence known as Web 2.0. A1 Only one venture capital firm got in on what has been one of the hottest Internet deals since Google went public in 2004: Sequoia Capital. C1 F.D.A. and Nanotechnology The first generation of nanotechnology-based food products has entered the market, raising new issues for the Food and Drug Administration. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES C15 Timo Sarpaneva A Finnish glassmaker whose creations found their way into art museums, he was 79. headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Marines in Iraq Juggle War and Reconstruction Marines in Iraq are planning to rebuild a bridge they destroyed near the Syrian border because residents say they are unable to shop or get to the doctor. The shifting priorities illustrate the tradeoff between combat and reconstruction that the American military is grappling with in remote regions where the Iraqi government is almost nonexistent. A1 Saddam Hussein faced cross-examination for the first time in his trial and admitted that he had signed an order of execution for 148 men and boys with only a glance at the case against them. A15 An adviser to Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari of Iraq, who is under pressure to resign, said the visit this week by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Foreign Secretary Jack Straw of Britain only strengthened his resolve to keep his post. A15 Rice Defends India Nuclear Deal Facing questions about the Bush administration's proposed deal to aid India's civilian nuclear program, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice told Congress she would press New Delhi to take more steps to stop the spread of nuclear arms. A10 SCIENCE/HEALTH Fossil May Be a Missing Link Scientists have discovered fossils of a 375-million-year-old fish, a large scaly creature not seen before, that they say is a long-sought missing link in the evolution of some fishes from water to a life walking on four limbs on land. The skeletons have the attributes of a giant fish, but on closer examination, the scientists found telling anatomical traits of a transitional creature. A1 NATIONAL A16-22 Georgia Drug Sting Raises Claims of Bias The American Civil Liberties Union is accusing federal prosecutors of ethnic bias in a sting in which South Asian owners of convenience stores in Georgia were charged with selling household ingredients that could be used to make methamphetamine, a highly addictive drug. A16 Security Official in Court The Department of Homeland Security's deputy press secretary appeared in a Maryland state court and refused extradition to Florida, where he faces charges of using the Internet to seduce someone he thought was a 14-year-old girl. A22 Bush Pitches Health Care Plan President Bush visited Connecticut to highlight his prescription for soaring health care costs. A21 Video Reports are Faulted Many television news stations are continuing to broadcast reports as news without disclosing that the segments were produced by corporations pitching new products, according to a new report by a watchdog group. A19 EDUCATION Bill Seeks to Alter School Lunch A bipartisan group in Congress plans to introduce legislation that would prohibit the sale all fatty and sugary foods, including soft drinks. A16 Few Students Took Needed Aid Only fractions of public school students who were eligible last year for free tutoring or for transfers out of failing schools under federal law received those options, the Department of Education reported. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Council Approves Plans For New Yankee Stadium The New York Yankees' effort to build a new 53,000-seat stadium cleared its biggest hurdle with a City Council vote supporting the team's ambitious plan to knock down the Bronx institution known as the House That Ruth Built. B1 Welfare Rolls Hit a Low The number of New York City residents receiving public assistance fell to 402,281 last month, officials said, the lowest in 41 years and a drop of nearly two-thirds from a peak of 1.2 million over a decade ago. B1 A Rival for Cablevision Town officials in Hempstead, on Long Island, granted Verizon a franchise to provide cable television through its fiber optic telephone lines, setting the stage for head-to-head competition with the longtime local monopoly, Cablevision. B5 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-6 Duke Opens Five New Inquiries Duke University announced five new inquiries into actions by the university and men's lacrosse team, canceled the lacrosse season, accepted the coach's resignation and suspended a player from school. D1 OBITUARIES A23 Gene Pitney A clean-cut crooner who became a teen idol in the early 1960's with hits like ''Town Without Pity,'' ''(The Man Who Shot) Liberty Valance'' and ''Only Love Can Break a Heart,'' he was 65. A23 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 New CBS News Anchor In the end, Katie Couric's desire to anchor a network newscast outweighed all the other factors as she accepted the job of anchoring the ''CBS Evening News.'' A1 Macs Set to Run Windows Apple introduced a program that will give its Mac computers the ability to run Windows, the operating system of its rival, Microsoft. A1 Merck Loses Vioxx Suit A jury in New Jersey jury awarded $4.5 million in damages in a product liability suit over Vioxx, the arthritis drug made by Merck. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Resolving the wiretap debate; the semantics of Mideast peace; it's not about the trustees; stop -- don't test those cows. Column: David Brooks. Bridge E8 Crossword E4 TV Listings E10 Weather D8

headline: Change in Terms | May 14-20
summary: LIBYA The News -- The United States renewed diplomatic relations with Libya, ending more than a quarter-century of estrangement. Behind the News -- The two countries' relationship has come a long way since 1979, when the United States severed relations, and particularly since 1988, when Libyan agents blew up Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland, killing 270. Libya did its part by abandoning unconventional weapons and renouncing terrorism. But in some ways the world has also passed Libya by, and with Iraq, Afghanistan, Al Qaeda and now Iran, the United States has bigger fish to fry. IRAQ The News -- A panel of judges in the trial of Saddam Hussein approved formal charges of crimes against humanity in the case. Behind the News -- The ruling means that Mr. Hussein and seven co-defendants would almost certainly face the death penalty if convicted. Mr. Hussein and the others are on trial in connection with the execution of 148 Shiites in 1982. Convictions would not come anytime soon, however. The trial has already gone on for more than seven months -- the judges' ruling came after the prosecution presented its evidence -- and is expected to continue into the fall. WASHINGTON The News -- Less than a day after the deadline for enrollment in the Medicare prescription drug program, a bipartisan group of senators pushed to eliminate the penalty for people who missed it. Behind the News -- The administration had defended the penalty -- an increase on future premiums -- as a stick to encourage people to sign up for the program, which subsidizes drug coverage. But the senators, uneasy about upsetting the electorate in an election year, said the program was difficult to understand. Waiving the fee would cost an estimated $1.7 billion over five years. RHODE ISLAND The News -- A judge in Rhode Island sentenced the onetime reality TV star Richard Hatch to 51 months in prison for tax evasion. Behind the News -- The sentence was at least 10 months longer than expected, and the judge said he opted for the longer term because it was clear to him that Mr. Hatch had lied during the trial. Mr. Hatch denied that he had been less than truthful, but fans of reality television could believe the judge's comments, given that Mr. Hatch connived his way to winning the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' in 2000. TEXAS The News -- The Texas Department of Transportation said it would consider raising the speed limit to 80 miles per hour on parts of two Interstate highways. Behind the News -- By making the proposal, the department seemed to thumb its nose at those who argue that Americans need to conserve gasoline. And traffic safety experts said that raising the limit would make the highways, in rural parts of West Texas, less safe. But officials said that if they raised the limit, they would just be acknowledging the obvious: that motorists drive that fast already.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Rose-Colored Victory
summary: As the University of Texas became the national college football champion( the quarterback Vince Young, above), beating the University of Southern California in the Rose Bowl on Wednesday night, ABC scored a huge victory in Nielsen's estimates. During its broadcast of the prime-time portion of the exciting game, the network drew an average of 33.95 million viewers. That total was more than all five of the other networks combined. And, of course, ABC was first among 18-to-49-year-olds for the night, delivering a demographic rating that also equaled more than the sum of every other network's ratings for that age group. CBS's all-rerun lineup placed second in total viewers (third in adults 18 to 49), while NBC's schedule was No. 3 in total viewers (and second among the 18-to-49 demographic). NBC broadcast a two-hour ''Biggest Loser'' special, which had a hard row to hoe against football. It attracted 8.54 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: CBS Plans Subscription Service That Sends News and Entertainment to Cellphones The CBS Corporation is expected to announce the first subscription services that send news and entertainment alerts, including video clips, to mobile phones. The services are part of a broad new strategy to sell wireless media products directly to consumers. [C1.] In what is the boldest venture yet by an established media company to insinuate itself into millions of cellphones, the News Corporation has created a mobile entertainment store called Mobizzo and a production studio to focus exclusively on developing cellphone entertainment in much the same way that 20th Century Fox creates movies and television. [Page C1.] Before Harvard President's Ouster, an Influential Article Two years ago, when David McClintick, left, agreed to write an exposé on Harvard's effort on behalf of the United States government to help Russia privatize its economy in the 1990's, he had little inkling the article would play a part in forcing the ouster of Harvard's president, Lawrence Summers. ''How Harvard Lost Russia'' was published in the January issue of Institutional Investor magazine, a subscription-only publication, about a month and a half before Dr. Summers's resignation, which he announced last Tuesday. The move came just two weeks after a heated Feb. 7 meeting at which Dr. Summers was challenged on several issues, including his reaction to the events described in Mr. McClintick's provocative article. [C3.] Working to Make Computer Power More Portable When Samsung decided to mount a serious challenge to Apple Computer's iPod music player early last year, it turned to a Silicon Valley start-up and a small team of programmers led by Paul Mercer, 38, a veteran Apple Macintosh software designer. For Mr. Mercer, the Samsung project is the culmination of more than two decades of focus on extending personal computer technologies into the realm of portable devices. [C1.] Tense Ties Between White House and Press By its nature, the relationship between the White House and the press has historically held an inherent tension. And many say the relationship has been eroding since the Vietnam War and Watergate, when reporters had reason to distrust most everything the White House said and made a scandalous ''gate'' out of every murky act. But today, those on both sides say, the relationship has deteriorated further, exacerbated by live White House briefings. [C1.] Gauging the Marketing Magnetism of the Oscars Since the nominations for the 78th annual Academy Awards were announced, sponsors have shrugged off skeptics who questioned whether the ceremony, to be broadcast on Sunday by ABC, would draw a sizable audience. None of the five nominees for best picture are box-office blockbusters, the skeptics point out, and few of the nominees for acting awards are household names. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.] If you drill down into this year's best picture nominees, you will find that they are guerrilla insurgencies backed by superpowers. David Carr. [C1.] Web Companies Turn to 'Pay-Per-Call' Services Businesses like Ingenio, based in San Francisco, are helping Internet companies move into ''pay-per-call'' services, where consumers on the Web click on an icon to have someone call them or simply dial a number in an ad. Judson Brady, left, the owner of Broad Street Flowers, an Atlanta-based floral service, pays Ingenio around $4.15 for each call from a prospect -- most of whom see his ads on AOL, which introduced its pay-per-call service last year. More than a third of the callers place an order, Mr. Brady said, making it more effective than his ''pay-per-click'' advertising. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C7.] Test Scores Not Lowered by TV, Study Finds A new study by two economists from the University of Chicago taps into a trove of data from the 1960's to argue that when it comes to academic test scores, parents can let children watch TV without fear of future harm. [C6.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 41ST ANNUAL ACADEMY OF COUNTRY MUSIC AWARDS -- ''Country Music's Biggest Party'' just got bigger with a move to MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, which holds 17,157 and was patterned after Madison Square Garden. The bright-eyed Reba McEntire, in her eighth turn as host, will introduce performers including Rascal Flatts, Kenney Chesney, Big & Rich, Martina McBride and two ''American Idol'' winners: Kelly Clarkson, who earned two Grammys in February but neglected to thank the show that gave her a jumpstart, and Carrie Underwood (above), a contender tonight with four nominations. Wonder what she'll say. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Blood may be spilled on this Night of Nights, when Taylor Hicks pits his gravelly funk against Katharine McPhee's saccharine crooning in what ultimately boils down to a gladiator-like battle of the overheated voters. 8 P.M. (ABC) STEPHEN KING'S DESPERATION -- Something wicked -- and very, very determined to keep a secret -- this way comes in this three-hour made-for-television movie, set in a remote Nevada mining town named Desperation. Tom Skerritt, Steven Weber, Annabeth Gish, Henry Thomas, Matt Frewer and Charles Durning portray some of the town's reluctant heroes. Ron Perlman (above) plays Sheriff Collie Entragian, who isn't feeling much like his old self these days. 9 P.M. (NBC) 10.5: APOCALYPSE -- Part 2 of 2. The big one has hit, and all of North America continues to shake, rattle and roll. 9 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE -- Season finale. We know his bedside manner has all the subtlety of a sledgehammer. But when a disgruntled former patient (Elias Koteas) walks into the office of Gregory House M.D., and shoots him, well, that's going a bit far, isn't it? Imagine, then, when House has to share his hospital room with this wacko. And now imagine when he can walk without his cane. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) JAMIE KENNEDY'S BLOWIN' UP -- Mr. Kennedy, in his somewhat misguided quest to become a hip-hop superstar, accepts a cameo on ''Law & Order: SVU.'' Anything to meet Ice T. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Def Leppard (including its lead singer, Joe Elliott, right), who will be saluted alongside Kiss, Queen and Judas Priest on Thursday in Las Vegas at the ''VH1 Rock Honors,'' makes a racket in works from its new album, ''Yeah,'' which drops into stores today. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL 3-10 Israelis Raid Lebanese Site Helicopter-borne Israeli commandos landed near the Hezbollah stronghold of Baalbek and engaged in a lengthy firefight in what the Lebanese prime minister called a ''flagrant violation'' of the cease-fire brokered by the United Nations. The office of the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, issued a statement saying that the raid violated the truce. 1 Despite the cease-fire agreement, Israel intends to do its best to keep Iran and Syria from rearming Hezbollah and to kill the militia's leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, a senior Israeli commander said. 6 As leaders in world capitals review United Nations plans for a peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, they are weighing whether the stated goals are clear and achievable and whether the rules of engagement will allow them to protect their forces. 6 Plot Inquiry Focuses on Family While little is known about the strength of the British government's evidence against the suspects in the plot to down airplanes across the Atlantic, three members of one family, and the charity it established, are at the heart of the investigation. 1 A Dictatorship on Trial The trials of military and police officials in Argentina accused of human rights violations during the country's brutal military dictatorship 30 years ago have raised new evidence of torture, rape and murder and brought victims face to face with some of the men they accused of abuse. 3 Iran Shells Iraqi Kurdistan Artillery shells fired from Iran have landed in remote northern villages of Iraqi Kurdistan in recent days and have killed at least two civilians and wounded four others, a senior Kurdish official said. Dozens of families have fled the region. 8 NATIONAL 12-23 Avoiding Child Porn Laws The latest trend in online child exploitation appears to be Web sites for pedophiles offering explicit, sexualized images of children who are covered by bits of clothing -- all in the questionable hope of allowing producers, distributors and customers to avoid child pornography charges. 1 Image Campaign for Couric To reintroduce Katie Couric to the country as a serious yet still accessible evening news anchor, CBS has embarked on an image campaign worthy of a presidential candidate, one that would cost well in excess of $10 million if the national television commercials featuring her were being bought by an outsider. 1 Poverty in Rural Oregon In Oakridge, Ore., residents now live with lowered expectations, and a share of them have felt the sharp pinch of rural poverty. The town is an acute example of a national trend, the widening gap in pay between workers in urban areas and those in rural locales. 12 California Immigration Vote Illegal immigration has long been a political minefield in California. Now, with Congress considering the most sweeping changes to immigration laws in two decades, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is learning just how troublesome that terrain can be in an election year. 23 Penalties for Candidates The Democratic National Committee voted to penalize 2008 presidential candidates who defied a new nominating calendar devised to lessen the longtime influence of New Hampshire and Iowa, the two states that have traditionally kicked off the nominating process. 18 NEW YORK/REGION 25-29 City Pensions May Fall Short A close inspection of city pension records shows that the funds committed to the retirement plans of city workers may fall well short of the city's promises to its workers. The city plans appear to be fully funded chiefly because the city has been using an unusual pension calculation that does not comply with accepted government accounting rules. 1 Medicare Billing Investigated The rapid rise in the prominence of St. Barnabas Health Care System was fueled by what prosecutors said was one of the most lucrative Medicare fraud schemes in the nation's history, bilking the federal government of hundreds of millions of dollars. 1 City May Sue Over 9/11 Book The Bloomberg administration is threatening to sue the publisher of a new book about the Sept. 11 terror attack over photographs of ground zero taken by a former New York City police detective. 28 Chess 29 Obituaries 30 TV Update 29 Weather 20

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: INTEL EARNINGS FALL Intel, the world's largest chip maker, reported a 35 percent decline in third-quarter profit, but still managed to beat Wall Street estimates. Andy Bryant, the chief financial officer, said Intel's fierce price war with Advanced Micro Devices, was likely to ease during the fourth quarter. Fourth-quarter profit would be roughly in line with analysts' forecasts, the company said. [Page C2] CHINESE CAR EXPORTS Despite anxiety that China might soon begin to flood foreign markets with its car exports, it appears that it will be several years before Chinese automakers start exporting large numbers of cars they both design and make. Plans to sell cars in the United States as soon as 2007 have been pushed back. [C1] EXCHANGE MERGER The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, longtime fierce competitors, said they would merge in an $8 billion deal that would create the largest market for financial derivatives contracts in the world. [C1] MANHATTAN REAL ESTATE DEAL Jerry I. Speyer, a property magnate who controls some of the New York's most prominent landmarks, from Rockefeller Center to the Chrysler Building agreed to pay $5.4 billion for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, a vast corridor of 110 apartments along the East River. [A1] HOLLYWOOD INVESTIGATION Prosecutors have called at least 10 lawyers from the firm of Bertram H. Fields before a grand jury in what defense lawyers say is a last-ditch effort to connect Mr. Fields, the Hollywood lawyer, to a wiretapping and conspiracy case against the private investigator Anthony Pellicano. [C6] RATINGS FOR COMMERCIALS An effort by Nielsen Media Research to measure the number of people watching commercials has set off a battle worthy of a ''Survivor'' episode, with just about everyone in the TV and advertising businesses disagreeing over how Nielsen should measure ad viewership. Unable to resolving the disputes, Nielson plans to delay releasing the new ratings until December. Adverstising [C1] SNIPES TAX INDICTMENT A grand jury in Tampa, Fla., has indicted the actor Wesley Snipes, star of the ''Blade'' trilogy and other films, on tax fraud and conspiracy charges after a four-year investigation by the Internal Revenue Service. [E3] BRITISH STEEL BID The Corus Group of Britain said it had received a takeover bid of £4.1 billion ($7.6 billion), from Tata Steel of India. If successful, the deal would create the world's sixth-largest steel company. [C3] NEW DIABETES DRUG Federal drug regulators approved a new diabetes medicine from Merck that is expected to become a blockbuster treatment used by millions of people. Januvia is a once-daily pill that has fewer severe side effects than existing diabetes medications and does not cause weight gain. [C3] WALL STREET EARNINGS Merrill Lynch followed its Wall Street rivals by reporting third-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected, fueled by its debt and equity markets business. Merrill also joined its peers in taking more risk in allocating its capital. [C12] WHOLESALE PRICES FALL A sharp drop in the price of gasoline helped push the Producer Price Index down a sharp 1.3 percent in September. Excluding food and energy, however, the core index rose a greater-than-expected 0.6 percent. [C3] VIDEO GAME WARS With the arrival of its PlayStation 3 less than a month away, Sony is about to embark on a marketing campaign that will collide with an equally ambitious effort by Microsoft. Having spotted Microsoft's Xbox 360 a one-year head start, Sony must show that its new console can hold its own in Internet-based gaming, its rival's sweet spot. And both will face a challenge from the lower-priced Nintendo Wii. [C1] LABOR LEADER ARRESTED Brian M. McLaughlin, a Queens assemblyman who as head of the nation's biggest municipal labor council personified New York City's powerful labor movement, was arrested on federal charges of embezzlement, receiving bribes, fraud and money laundering, charges. [A1] CITIGROUP DEAL IN TURKEY Citigroup said it would pay $3.1 billion for a 20 percent stake in Akbank, a premier Turkish bank It was Citigroup's first deal since the Federal Reserve lifted its ban on acquisitions this spring, and Charles O. Prince III's biggest purchase since taking over three years ago as chief executive. [C4] COURIC IN THIRD Katie Couric has passed the six-week mark on the ''CBS Evening News'' having fallen behind NBC and ABC in the ratings in recent weeks and having lost much of the momentum her program had early on. [E1] SHORTAGE OF ELDERLY SPECIALISTS As the United States population ages, geriatricians -- doctors who specialize in illnesses of the elderly -- are increasingly in short supply. It is a specialty of little interest to medical students, suggesting the shortage will get worse. [A1] MORGAN STANLEY SETTLEMENT The New York Attorney General, Eliot Spitzer, said that Morgan Stanley had agreed to pay more than $1 million to settle a case in which it reportedly failed to supervise a broker who defrauded 15 clients. [C12]

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Shot in the Arm From a Shot in the Eye
summary: Half of CBS's schedule on Monday was repeats, but the network won the night anyway. A new episode of ''CSI: Miami'' (19.82 million), starring David Caruso, below, which featured what being shot in the eye might look like and was the most-watched show in prime time, was preceded by Week 2 of Jenna Elfman's sitcom ''Courting Alex.'' Since it followed a rerun of ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.29 million), which delivered a smaller audience than an original episode, ''Alex'' was down from its premiere (13.46 million, versus 14.9 million last week) but retained a good percentage of ''Men'' viewers. Fox was a strong second place for the night in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, with the strangely juxtaposed ''Skating With Celebrities'' (9.93 million) and ''24'' (13.76 million). On WB's soon-to-be-canceled ''7th Heaven,'' Sandy (Haylie Duff) gave birth to a son, and Martin (Tyler Hoechlin) decided to take responsibility for him after being mean throughout the pregnancy. The episode brought in 6.06 million viewers but failed to help the ratings of ''Related,'' which had an audience of a mere 2.42 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; A New 'Idol' Dwarfs Competition
summary: With the February ratings sweeps period looming, the networks have largely been hoarding original episodes, and on Wednesday, viewers were offered few new programs. But ''American Idol'' was new, and slaughtered everything in its path, giving Fox another victory for the night. The talent competition, which apparently found few good singers in its auditions in Austin, Tex., delivered an estimated audience of 30.15 million. At 9 p.m. on Fox, an episode of ''Bones'' again lost a significant portion of ''Idol'' viewers, bringing in 12.61 million. Though the bantering procedural placed first among adults 18 to 49 for the hour, a rerun of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' attracted a larger audience (13.28 million). The cable-news broadcast of the State of the Union address on Tuesday resulted in the usual pecking order: Fox News (6.46 million), CNN (2.22 million), MSNBC (707,000). Fox News and CNN brought in more viewers for the speech than they did for last year's low-rated address: CNN nearly doubled its 2005 audience, while Fox News had an 8 percent increase. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) VH1 ROCK HONORS -- Pump up the volume. VH1 worships the gods of heavy metal in this tribute to Kiss (with Gene Simmons, above left, and Tommy Thayer), Queen, Def Leppard and Judas Priest. Godsmack, Foo Fighters and the All-American perform hymns of praise. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Ricki Lake leads celebrity contestants through classic games in this new revolving weekly tournament. Taking the first spin: Lance Bass, Paige Davis, Tim Meadows, Kathy Najimy, Leslie Nielsen and Brande Roderick in ''The Price Is Right.'' 9 P.M. (A&E) INKED -- Having the world's first casino tattoo parlor apparently wasn't extreme enough for Corey Hart, the motocross champion. Now he's starting an outré clothing line. This season, Mr. Hart maneuvers around fashion-industry obstacles while keeping his skin artists in line. 9 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES -- Gordon Ramsay (left), the celebrity chef with a temper perpetually set to boil, sure knows how to dish it out. In this season premiere of this British series, he sharpens his knives at down-and-out Momma Cherri's Soul Food Shack near the beach in Brighton and helps keep its burners lit. 9 P.M. (Bravo) CELEBRITY POKER SHOWDOWN -- Christopher Meloni, Jason Alexander, Macy Gray, Jorge Garcia, Fred Savage, Jennifer Tilly and Michael Ian Black bet and bluff their way to a $1 million prize pool for Hurricane Katrina charities. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- In the season premiere of this weekly trip down Illusion Lane, Mr. Angel merges mind, body and spirit to float from one building to another. 10 P.M. (BBC America) BAD LAD'S ARMY -- Thirty young petty criminals turn to military life to mend their ways in this new British documentary series, and transform themselves from boys into men in the process. 10 P.M. (MTV) THE HILLS -- On ''Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County,'' Lauren Conrad (right) was the emotional blonde who wore every smidgen of excitement or frustration on her face, sometimes both at once. This offshoot trails her to Los Angeles, where she attends the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising and flits through the offices of Teen Vogue. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) CHEYENNE -- When she was 8, she booked her own nightclub gigs. At 10, she was named America's Most Talented Kid. Now, at 15, Cheyenne Kimball is about to become a rock star. Come on, she's got her own show. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: FORD TO OFFER BUYOUTS -- In the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive, the Ford Motor Company agreed to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to all its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs. [Page A1.] HEDGE FUND MAY GO PUBLIC -- A hedge fund named Fortress Investment Group is considering an initial public offering for later this fall in a deal that could value the company in the range of $5 billion to $7 billion, according to people who have been briefed on the plans. [C1.] RUSSIAN REGULATOR IS KILLED -- Andre Kozlov, below, a top Russian bank regulator who had been engaged in an effort to reform Russia's corrupt and risk-laden banking system, died yesterday after being shot on the street the night before. Mr. Kozlov, 41, the first deputy chairman of Russia's central bank, had been leading a drive to combat money laundering and to bring stability to Russia's rapidly expanding banking sector. Among many programs in his portfolio, he had been closing disreputable banks by withdrawing their licenses, a practice his colleagues said had made him enemies in criminal circles. [A3.] SETBACK FOR U.S. ON SHELTERS -- A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals. [C1.] TALKS TO SELL DIRECTV -- Rupert Murdoch, who spent more than two decades coveting the satellite broadcaster DirecTV before acquiring control of it three years ago, is now in talks to sell it to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night. [C1.] UTILITY MERGER ABANDONED -- The Public Service Enterprise Group of Newark, the parent company of New Jersey's largest utility, and Exelon of Chicago called off their merger, saying that their differences with New Jersey regulators were ''insurmountable.'' [B5.] CHINA AND NEWS SERVICES -- Chinese officials promised that new rules restricting the sale of reports by foreign news agencies would not have an effect on press freedoms. But the officials also strongly defended efforts to control the distribution of financial and economic news inside the country. [A10.] CALIFORNIA'S EMISSIONS FIGHT -- California is betting that it can succeed in reducing greenhouse gas emissions without wrecking its economy, and therefore inspire other states -- and countries -- to follow its example on slowing climate change. [A1.] AOL EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE POST -- Ted Leonsis, who has been a top leader of AOL for 13 years, will give up his jobs as president of what AOL calls its audience business, which creates Web sites and sells advertising on them. He will remain vice chairman of the company. [C4.] MICROSOFT'S MUSIC PLAYER -- Hoping to upstage the Apple iPod, Microsoft said that its Zune player, which it plans to release in time for the holiday season, will include wireless technology to allow Zune owners to easily share their favorite songs and playlists with one another. [C3.] MEXICO SECURITIES SETTLEMENT -- The billionaire investor Ricardo Salinas Pliego and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission reached a settlement in the first case against a foreign company under the corporate governance rules of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. [C3.] BATTLE OVER JOB CUTS AT PAPER -- The editor of The Los Angeles Times appears to be in a showdown with the paper's owners at the Tribune Company over newsroom job cuts. [C3.] RESHAPING RADIO -- Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making. Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest radio operator, is considering selling some of its 1,200 stations in smaller markets, according to industry analysts. The CBS Corporation did the same thing recently and now says it is looking at further station sales. Walt Disney recently struck a deal to get out of the radio business altogether, and Susquehanna Broadcasting has been sold to another broadcaster. [C1.] INDIA'S CELLPHONE GROWTH -- India has become the fastest-growing cellular market in the world, adding a net 5.9 million cellular subscribers in August, the Cellular Operators Association of India said. The gain outstripped China's increase of 5.19 million subscribers. [C4.] SMALL RISE IN RETAIL SALES -- Retail sales rose 0.2 percent in August after a surge of 1.4 percent in July. Another report showed that weekly first-time claims for jobless benefits fell. [C4.] STOCKS END THE DAY MIXED -- Wall Street closed mixed, with blue chips falling and technology stocks managing a slight gain. [C8.]

headline: TRANSACTIONS

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (BBCA) THE THICK OF IT -- This British political satire about the encounters between a hapless parliamentary minister and the terrifying policy enforcer for No. 10 -- that's code for the prime minister -- arrives in the United States with promises of manipulation, backstabbing and spin. The Daily Telegraph of London called this show ''inspired, seemingly effortless and far too close for comfort,'' while The Independent declared it ''simultaneously depressing and elating.'' Chris Langham (above) and Peter Capaldi, who star, are supposedly improvising parts of their dialogue. But maybe they're just gleaning it from newspapers. 7 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SNY SPOTLIGHT -- In this new monthly series, Steve Berthiaume interviews movers and shakers in the sports world at the television home of the New York Mets and Jets. First up: Woody Johnson, the Jets chairman and chief executive, who talks about purchasing the team, the 2006 draft, the similarities between politics and football, and growing up an heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune. 8 P.M. (CBS) KEITH BARRY: EXTRAORDINARY -- Mr. Barry, a magician and psychological illusionist (translation:mind control) wields his mental power over celebrities including Matthew McConaughey, Wilmer Valderrama, Elijah Wood, Vivica A. Fox, Rachel Hunter and Jessica Simpson, which, frankly, doesn't sound all that taxing. 8 P.M. (The N) DEGRASSI: THE NEXT GENERATION -- Emma's eating disorder has peaked, and now only she can save herself in this new episode, which should be required viewing for the Nicole Richie generation. 8 P.M. (Showtime) LITTLE MAN -- Nicole Conn focuses the lens on her son, Nicholas (left, with Ms. Conn), who was delivered 100 days early and at less than one pound, and shows that even extremely premature babies can make a big impact. That's why she calls him Mr. Enchantment. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS -- One of the Montecito ladies prepares to walk down the aisle in this season finale, giving rise to a flurry of bachelorette parties. Only this time, what happens in Vegas doesn't stay in Vegas. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR -- Millions of viewers routinely blow off date night to watch Stacy London and Clinton Kelly work their makeover magic. And, yep, we're among them. Tonight, the subject of their discernment is the brazenly beautiful Camilla B., a Salt Lake City professional with tattered tops and safety-pinned pants. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- How many more interviews does Tom Hanks have in him before ''The Da Vinci Code'' opens on May 19? Apparently at least one. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
