headline: People and Accounts of Note
summary: Maria Antonelli, a partner at the Star Group, Cherry Hill, N.J., was promoted to managing partner. She continues as senior vice president and general manager at StarShipley, the Wilmington, Del., office of the Star Group. Chad Boettcher joined Nike, Beaverton, Ore., as director for corporate responsibility and community affairs for the United States. He had been director for strategic partnership and public affairs at MTV, New York, part of Viacom.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (11) THE BEDFORD DIARIES -- ''I'm Going to Love College.'' In this new drama series for very young adults, a handsome young man (Penn Badgley, left) enters Bedford College, a fictional institution in New York City. He is immediately accepted into a prestigious sex seminar (taught by Matthew Modine), as is his older sister (Tiffany Dupont), whose affair with a professor may soon be exposed in the campus newspaper. The show borrows a device from ''Sex, Lies & Videotape,'' having the students use video cameras as confessionals, but that oldie ''The Harrad Experiment'' also comes to mind. Audra McDonald, as a faculty member, lends some intelligence to the proceedings. 6 P.M. (TCM) DOUBLE INDEMNITY (1944). Hey, baby, you're cute: let's kill my husband and collect a big insurance settlement. Barbara Stanwyck and Fred MacMurray star in what may be the ultimate film noir. Raymond Chandler and Billy Wilder wrote the screenplay. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE NEW MEDICINE -- Adelaide, the sneezy, sniffly character in ''Guys and Dolls,'' knew it half a century ago when she sang, ''A person can develop a cold.'' Stress can make you sick. But maybe meditation or just happy thoughts can heal. In this two-hour documentary, doctors look into the mind-body connection. The show's host is Dana Reeve (above), who died of lung cancer earlier this month after nine years of caring for her paralyzed husband, Christopher Reeve. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- The hatch takes on a life of its own. That's the hatch where the plane-crash survivors discovered that the island on which they've been marooned for a couple of months (almost two seasons in television-series time) may be part of some bizarre scientific experiment. 9 P.M. (5) AMERICAN IDOL -- One of the 10 finalists bites the dust. 10 P. M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- Life in New York is all about deadlines. Tonight a helicopter is hijacked on a hospital roof, and the hijackers make off with the human liver it was transporting. The liver has to be found fast, before the transplant patient dies. 10 P.M. (Sci Fi) PSYCHIC AT LARGE -- Char Margolis (left) is the star of this new six-episode reality series. Ms. Margolis will accost strangers on the street to give them psychic readings. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 11 P.M. (History) THE PLOT TO KILL: RONALD REAGAN -- On the afternoon of March 30, 1981, John Hinckley Jr. shot President Ronald Reagan (left) in the chest in front of the Washington Hilton, where the president had been making a speech. The plot, in this case, seems to have been a one-man operation. This new documentary uses a little of everything -- interviews, eyewitness accounts, archival tape and re-enactments -- to examine the events of that day and Mr. Hinckley's stated purpose: to impress the actress Jodie Foster, then a student at Yale University. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: PANAMA -- EXILE ISLAND -- The two tribes merge. Sally, the 27-year-old social worker from Chicago, returns from Exile Island. Bruce, the 58-year-old karate and art teacher from Simi Valley, Calif., chips a tooth. 8 P.M. (TCM) FAHRENHEIT -- 451 (1967). Julie Christie and Oskar Werner star in Ray Bradbury's story of a world, not so far in the future, in which all books are banned, the home television set fills a whole wall (uh-oh) and the fire department's purpose is to start fires. 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE -- Apparently, the country's growing conservative mood is affecting even gay entertainment media. Britney Spears (right) guest-stars as Jack's right-wing new co-host on his OutTV talk show. Grace continues to be pregnant. 9 P.M. (5) THE O. C. -- An engagement announcement and an A.A. meeting figure in the plot. 9:30 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE -- To celebrate his birthday, Michael (Steve Carell) takes his employees ice skating. 11 P.M. (Oxygen) THE ELLEN DEGENERES SHOW -- Liza Minnelli (left), whose Emmy-winning 1972 special, ''Liza With a Z,'' is returning to television on Saturday night, drops by to chat. (In case you forgot to record NBC's original daytime showing of this on March 24.) 3:30 A.M. (Fox Movie Channel) THE ROSE -- (1979) Bette Midler, in her first major movie, plays a Janis Joplin-like character, a rock star who seems doomed to self-destruct with the help of drugs, alcohol, exhaustion and self-loathing. The tour date in her hometown, where people used to be cruel to her (and her parents can't be bothered even to attend the concert), could be the fatal emotional blow. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 7:30 P.M. (Disney) MICKEY MOUSE CLUBHOUSE -- At last, a club for those who don't yet know the theme song. This new 3-D computer-animated series introduces preschoolers to the Sensational Six -- Mickey, Minnie, Pluto, Goofy, Daisy Duck and Donald Duck -- and to the concept of problem solving, whether counting to 10, recognizing shapes or learning to spell M-O-U-S-E. And because the show is interactive, that leader of the band encourages talking back. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- In Part 2 of the season finale, Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) tries to help the hundreds of passengers killed in a plane crash cross over to the other side. But how will she explain to investigators why she knew there was trouble before the thing went down? 8 P.M. (11) SURVIVAL OF THE RICHEST -- Season finale. Talk about stacking the odds. This reality series pits seven young adults with a combined family worth of more than $3 billion against seven of ''society's most disadvantaged,'' as a press release put it, in tasks ranging from living richly at a racetrack to cleaning up the spectator stands after the event. In this last episode, the two remaining teams help remodel an after-school center in South Central Los Angeles and try to win a large cash prize by, um, proving that they are capable of living without their parents' money. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SCHOOL OF ROCK (2003). Parents, admit it. Dewey Finn, played with dark delirium by Jack Black, is your idea of a substitute teacher too. The three R's? Those kids learned them, in the form of rock, roll and rebellion. For this network premiere, Mr. Black (above right, with Joey Gaydos Jr. as Zack), as host, reminisces about playing a flat-broke guitarist who fakes his way into a job at an uppity private school. A high point: when Joan Cusack, as the tightly wound principal, loosens the vise-grip on her inner Stevie Nicks. 8:35 P.M. (Sundance) NEWS FOR THE CHURCH -- Andrew McCarthy, who in 1985 played a Roman Catholic schoolboy discovering the opposite sex in ''Heaven Help Us,'' makes his directorial debut with this short about a woman who confesses her onenight stand to a priest. 9 P.M. (11) REBA -- Season finale. After arguing, Van and Cheyenne call off their second wedding, and Reba collapses at their feet. Will her hospitalization put an end to all the bickering? 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS -- Sam and Woody share a romantic weekend together, Delinda answers Dr. Derek's marriage proposal, and the Olympic skater Sasha Cohen (right, with Josh Duhamel as Danny), in her television acting debut, takes a whirl through the Montecito. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) MISS USA 2006 -- Funny how the Miss America pageant was kicked off network television, but this Johnny-comelately (founded in the early 1950's) preliminary to the Miss Universe pageant is still around. Drew Lachey and Nancy O'Dell are the hosts, and Carson Kressley of ''Queer Eye'' provides witty commentary as 51 young women compete in Baltimore. Last year's winner, Chelsea Cooley (above), was Miss North Carolina, an art-school student, aspiring fashion buyer, opponent of domestic violence and shag-dance champion whose career dream, she said, was to work for Ralph Lauren. 8 P.M. (NBC) CELEBRITY COOKING SHOWDOWN -- Earlier this week, the three semifamous finalists -- Cindy Margolis, Ashley Parker Angel and Chelsea Cooley (see ''Miss USA'' item above) -- cooked up a storm with their superstar-chef partners. Tonight, in the finale, the winner will be announced, and the chefs themselves (Wolfgang Puck, Cat Cora and Govind Armstrong) will show off their superior skills. 9 P.M. (Comedy Central) STAND-UP NATION WITH GREG GIRALDO -- Mr. Giraldo (above) performs and is host to comic guests, including Brian Kiley and Reno Collier. 9:30 (11) MODERN MEN -- The laws of psychological transference being what they are, when three male friends are seeing the same therapist aka life coach (Jane Seymour), at least one is bound to fall in love with her. One does. Another of the guys jumps into bed with an old girlfriend who may not have married as well as it first appears. (There's a reason the children are cold to her.) 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS -- Don Eppes (Rob Morrow), F.B.I. agent, begins pondering his work's effect on his personal life after an A.T.F. (Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) agent is found dead and she turns out to be his former girlfriend. 10 P.M. (TCM) CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS (1989). Woody Allen took on the getting-away-with-murder theme long before he wrote and directed ''Match Point,'' in which Jonathan Rhys-Meyers's character gets tough with his mistress (Scarlett Johansson). In the darkly comic ''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' a respectable, successful man (Martin Landau, above left) turns to his not-so-respectable brother (Jerry Orbach) to make sure that his family never finds out about his flightattendant girlfriend (Anjelica Huston). 2 A.M. (Sundance) BELLE DE JOUR (1967). The improbably beautiful Catherine Deneuve stars as a bored French newlywed who takes an afternoon job at a brothel. ANITA GATES

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SHAKE-UP AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard shook up its board in an agreement that seemed to leave all the parties in its boardroom tussle satisfied, if not happy. Its chairwoman will step aside in January, its chief executive will succeed her, and its longest-serving director resigned. [Page A1.] BRISTOL CHIEF IS OUSTED -- Peter R. Dolan's troubled five-year term as chief executive of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb ended as the board dismissed him over the botched handling of a patent dispute involving the company's blockbuster drug, Plavix. Mr. Dolan, 50, will be succeeded by an interim chief, James M. Cornelius, a Bristol-Myers director. [C1.] MEDICARE PREMIUMS TO INCREASE -- The basic Medicare premium will rise next year to $93.50 a month, an increase of $5, the Bush administration announced. It said that more affluent beneficiaries would have to pay a new surcharge, ranging from $12.50 to $68.60 a month. [A20.] VIOXX RISKS -- Vioxx, which is no longer on the market, may have posed heart risks that a similar drug, Celebrex, and other painkillers do not, according to two papers published by The Journal of the American Medical Association. [A18.] LONELYGIRL UNMASKED -- A nearly four-month-old Internet mystery involving the cryptic video musings of a fresh-faced teenager known as Lonelygirl15 appears to be solved, with the girl identified as an actress who is part of a project to make a movie. [C1.] TAX PROVISION AND ARTWORK -- Directors and trustees of the nation's top art museums are preparing a lobbying effort to reverse a federal tax provision that they say will significantly harm their ability to acquire new artworks. [E1.] TAX RULING IN EUROPE -- Europe's highest court ruled that countries could not go after profits earned by company subsidiaries in other European countries as long as the businesses were not ''artificial'' arrangements to avoid paying taxes. [C4.] TAKING AIM AT SALT -- The American Medical Association is going after the government and the food industry to reduce what it sees as a persistently high level of salt in many processed foods. [C1.] STRONG EARNINGS AT GOLDMAN -- Despite a summer slump in trading up and down Wall Street, and expectations of a significant decline in investment banking, Goldman Sachs reported strong third-quarter earnings. Market Place. [C3.] SHARES RISE -- Stocks rose the most in about a month, led by retail shares as investors bet that falling crude oil prices would propel consumer spending and lift corporate profits while easing inflation. [C10.] TRADE DEFICIT HITS RECORD -- The United States trade deficit rose sharply in July to a record $68 billion, as oil import prices and demand for foreign goods and services rose to new highs. [C4.] BIG LAW FIRMS LOOK AT MERGING -- Two prominent law firms on opposite coasts -- Dewey Ballantine of New York and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe of San Francisco -- confirmed that they were discussing a possible merger that could create one of the nation's largest corporate legal advisers. [C4.] REACHING OUT TO RUST BELT -- Labor-starved Wyoming, with its energy boom in coal, oil and natural gas, is vigorously courting the workers of the Rust Belt -- in particular, those in Michigan's auto industry. And the workers are responding. [A1.] APPLE'S NEW PLANS -- Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple Computer, announced plans for a device that will plug into a television and wirelessly pull in video and music from a Macintosh computer in the den or from the Internet. Mr. Jobs also introduced new products including an ultrasmall version of the iPod Shuffle, above, that disappears in the palm of a hand and clips onto clothing. [C1.] SOROS DONATES $50 MILLION -- The financier and philanthropist George Soros said that he was contributing $50 million to support a sprawling social experiment, organized and led by the economist Jeffrey D. Sachs, that aims to help villages in Africa escape grinding poverty. [A18.] GATES FOUNDATION AND AFRICA -- The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced that it was working with the Rockefeller Foundation to increase agricultural productivity in Africa. [A18.] PANEL TO EXAMINE SECURITIES LAWS -- A committee filled with business leaders and academics was created to consider changes in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and other laws and regulations governing securities markets and companies, with the intention of improving competitiveness for American markets. [C3.] ONLINE SMALL BUSINESS -- The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies. A special report can be found at nytimes.com/business. KATIE COURIC -- Bill Carter of The Times offers his take on Katie Couric's debut on the ''CBS Evening News'' at nytimes.com/television. DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing An article on this development are at nytimes.com/business. COMVERSE TECHNOLOGY, A MAKER of voice-mail software, said second-quarter sales rose 38 percent, butthe company did not report full results because of an investigation into its stock option grants. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Travel) JEREMY PIVEN'S JOURNEY OF A LIFETIME -- Not that weever get actors confused with their roles, but who would have thought that Ari, the heart-of-stone agent on HBO's ''Entourage,'' had a spiritual side? Jeremy Piven (left), who plays Ari, goes to India and attends a traditional Kathakali theater performance. Next week he visits the holy town of Rishikesh, mecca for yoga devotees. 6 P.M. (MTV) YO MOMMA. -- Series premiere. Wilmer Valderrama, the sexy-nerdy exchange student Fez on ''That 70's Show,'' is host of this reality competition series. ''Real kids from the streets,'' he says, will try to outdo one another talking smack, talking trash, snapping or whatever it's called. As in ''Yo momma is so fat that . . . '' 8 P.M. (13) THE JUILLIARD SCHOOL: CELEBRATING 100 YEARS -- Renée Fleming, Emanuel Ax, Leontyne Price, Itzhak Perlman and Wynton Marsalis are among the performers in this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' concert. Juilliard opened in 1905 as the Institute of Musical Art. 8 P.M. (5) PRISON BREAK -- It's flashback time. Viewers learn how several characters ended up behind bars. 8 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Martin Sheen guest-stars in this 2005 episode of his son Charlie Sheen's hit sitcom. The elder Mr. Sheen (right, with his son) plays the father of Charlie's sweet-natured stalker, Rose (Melanie Lynskey). 9 P.M. (IFC) AMÉLIE -- (2001). Audrey Tautou stars as the most cheerful waitress in Paris. She loves to arrange her friends' lives but may finally find a love of her own. 9 P.M. (5) 24 -- ''Day 5: 10 P.M.-11 P.M.'' headline: Exit Polls Show Independents, Citing War, Favored Democrats
summary: A majority of independent voters aligned with Democratic candidates yesterday, driven by their distress over the Iraq war, disapproval of Congressional leadership and concern about the direction President Bush was leading America, according to interviews with voters as they left their polling places. In a contentious midterm election in which both parties forcefully mobilized their bases, voters in the center of the electorate aided Democrats in their quest to overtake Republican majorities in the House and Senate.

headline: 'Tune In Tomorrow '
summary: HELEN WAGNER, the actress who plays the elderly matriarch of the daytime soap opera ''As the World Turns,'' has witnessed many changes since she awoke in a twin bed next to the one occupied by her on-screen husband 50 years ago and spoke the program's opening line, ''Good morning, dear.'' The world has turned some 18,000 times since that April 2, 1956. Ms. Wagner is now a white-haired great-grandmother, but she still appears on the CBS daytime soap that she inaugurated. And although her character, Nancy Hughes, is still a straitlaced materfamilias who continues to represent traditional family values, almost everything about the character's surroundings has changed.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Book Challenges Decline Efforts to ban books from library shelves dropped last year to the lowest total recorded by the American Library Association since it began to survey the phenomenon in the early 1980's, when it established Banned Books Week as a celebration of free expression, The Associated Press reported. The association said 405 challenges were reported last year and added that although they have fluctuated over the years, they have dropped by half since Banned Books Week was begun. Judith F. Krug, the director of the association's Office for Intellectual Freedom, said the decline might be attributable to better preparation by librarians to organize community support for books and to a shift in focus by would-be censors to online content. The organization said that the number of books actually removed from shelves had decreased to about 44 in 2005 from more than 200 in 1982. The most challenged book last year was Robie H. Harris's ''It's Perfectly Normal: Changing Bodies, Growing Up, Sex and Sexual Health,'' a guide for middle school students. Others high on the list were J. D. Salinger's ''Catcher in the Rye,'' Judy Blume's ''Forever'' and Robert Cormier's ''Chocolate War.'' The 25th annual Banned Books Week is scheduled for Sept. 23 to Sept. 30. ''The purpose of Banned Books Week is to bring to everyone's attention that our First Amendment rights are fragile and that somebody out there will take them away from you if you're not careful,'' Ms. Krug said. Taylor Hicks Settles Lawsuit Taylor Hicks, the incumbent American Idol, has settled his lawsuit against a Nashville producer over rights to three songs Mr. Hicks wrote before becoming famous, The Associated Press reported. According to documents filed in District Court in Birmingham, Ala., the settlement gives Mr. Hicks possession of the master recordings in exchange for agreeing not to pursue further legal action against the producer, William Smith, who recorded the songs several years ago and recently put two of them up for sale on Apple's iTunes Music Store. Country Award Nominees Brooks & Dunn and Brad Paisley, below, with six nominations each, led the way yesterday when nominations for the 40th annual Country Music Association Awards were announced. Kenny Chesney, Keith Urban and Carrie Underwood got four nominations each, and Rascal Flatts and Dolly Parton came away with three each. Brooks & Dunn, Mr. Chesney, Mr. Paisley, Rascal Flatts and Mr. Urban will all compete for entertainer of the year. ABC will broadcast the awards ceremony live from the Gaylord Entertainment Center in Nashville on Nov. 6. Princeton Acquires Irish Theater Collection Princeton University has received a major Irish theater collection spanning 160 years, including an unpublished play by Sean O'Casey, the university announced yesterday. To be called the Milberg Irish Theater Collection, the trove includes more than 1,000 plays, photographs, playbills, above, and other materials dating to the mid-19th century, and includes works by Dion Boucicault and John Millington Synge as well as Samuel Beckett, Brian Friel, Martin McDonagh and Conor McPherson. In celebration of the opening of the collection, Princeton will hold a symposium from Oct. 13 to Oct. 15; the actors Gabriel Byrne, Stephen Rea and Fiona Shaw and the Tony Award-winning director Garry Hynes are scheduled to appear. The O'Casey play is ''The Cooing of the Doves,'' which was once thought to be lost. O'Casey said he incorporated the one-act work into the second act of his ''Plough and the Stars.'' The collection is a gift from Leonard L. Milberg, a 1953 alumnus, who earlier donated collections of modern American poetry Irish poetry in 1994 and American Jewish writing to the university in 2001. ''For Irish theater, I don't think there is anything else like this, especially outside of Ireland,'' he said of his latest gift. ''I know people may be interested in a lot of other things, but if it's Irish theater, they'll call Princeton.'' Footnotes The Metropolitan Opera's free performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' is to take place at 8 tonight in Cunningham Park, Queens. The performance, originally scheduled for last night, was postponed to its rain date. Information: (212) 362-2000. The 15,000th television episode of Procter & Gamble Productions' CBS soap opera ''Guiding Light'' will be broadcast on Sept. 7. The series originated in 1937 as a 15-minute radio serial, ''The Guiding Light,'' and moved to television on June 30, 1952. The Cincinnati Art Museum has announced the appointment of Aaron Betsky as its director. Mr. Betsky, for the past five years the director of the Netherlands Architecture Institute and previously a curator at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, is expected to assume his new post in mid-November. He succeeds Timothy Rub, who left in April to become director and chief executive of the Cleveland Museum of Art.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SILICON VALLEY POWER ALLIANCE When Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, left, was named to Apple Computer's board this week, the announcement touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the move: Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs. [Page A1.] CALIFORNIA EMISSIONS BILL California's political leaders announced an agreement that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon-dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington. [A1.] FILLING UP ON CORN A 2,100-mile drive through the region where ethanol fuel is most popular revealed that despite all the good will toward E-85, as the corn-based fuel blend is known, its success is far from assured. [C1.] LOOPHOLE FOR FLEXIBLE FUEL As car companies promote E-85 as an alternative to gasoline, they are benefiting from a loophole that allows them to receive credits toward environmental standards when they sell flexible-fuel vehicles that run on the ethanol-based fuel. [C4.] ECONOMY EXPANDED IN QUARTER The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported. [C1.] STOCKS EDGE UP The Dow average and the Nasdaq rose slightly in thin trading, helped by a government report showing economic growth remains reasonably strong. [C13.] JITTERS OVER HURRICANES All along the coasts, from Texas to New England, insurers suffering from hurricane jitters are raising rates and cutting back on coverage. But nowhere is the crisis more severe than in Florida, where storms in recent years have added billions to the insurers' losses. [C1.] PESSIMISM AMONG WORKERS Three new opinion polls found deep pessimism among American workers, with most saying that wages were not keeping pace with inflation and that workers were worse off in many ways than a generation ago. [A21.] ALCATEL DEFENDS LUCENT DEAL With a week to go before a crucial vote on a deal that would reshape the telecommunications equipment industry, Alcatel disputed criticism about its planned takeover of Lucent and insisted that the deal would benefit shareholders. [C3.] COKE EXECUTIVE LEAVES The president of Coca-Cola's North American unit, Donald R. Knauss, resigned abruptly to become chairman and chief executive of Clorox. [C3.] G.M. DROPS 'SURVIVOR' ADS General Motors has decided not to advertise on the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' for the upcoming season, one that has attracted criticism because teams of contestants are being pitted against each other based on race. Advertising. [C3.] NEW ALUMINUM GIANT Alcoa may face a rival for global dominance if a tentative merger of two Russian aluminum companies and a major Swiss commodity trader comes to fruition. Should Alcoa drop from its No. 1 spot it would be partly a reflection of wider industrial shifts that now favor Russia's commodity-driven economy. [C5.] TiVo'S LOSS CLIMBS TiVo reported a quarterly loss that was seven times the size of its loss a year ago, largely because of hefty legal costs associated with a high-stakes intellectual property patent dispute. [C4.] NOT GUILTY PLEA IN OPTIONS CASE The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, pleaded not guilty to 12 counts of securities fraud and other charges that he improperly backdated employee stock option grants. [C11.] NO ACTION ON SHELL'S EX-CHIEF The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to take no action against Sir Philip Watts, the former chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell, over the 2004 scandal involving the overbooking of oil reserves. [C11.] REVERSAL OF VIOXX AWARD Merck won the first reversal of a damage award over its Vioxx painkiller when a judge said that a $51 million verdict was ''grossly excessive.'' [C11.] ONLINE DEALBOOK Daily news on mergers and acquisitions, I.P.O.'s, venture capital and more is at nytimes.com/dealbook. HUGE APARTMENT SALE With a target price of nearly $5 billion, the sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village would be the biggest deal for a single U.S. property in modern times. A report is at nytimes.com/realestate. UNLIKELY DORM MATES Barnard College has built a dormitory where faculty members occupy the same floors and share laundry facilities and common space with students. A report is at nytimes.com/business. ONCE AND FUTURE MILEAGE KING Can an automobile be ahead of its time and yet be obsolete? As it heads into retirement, the Honda Insight certainly looks that way. A report is at nytimes.com/business. BUSINESS AFTER KATRINA A year after Hurricane Katrina, many small businesses are open across New Orleans, but times are tough and their survival is in doubt. A multimedia report is at nytimes.com/business.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10:30 P.M. (MTV) TIARA GIRLS -- You know those beauty pageant contestants who manage to answer any interview question with a pledge to work for world peace? Some of them actually have help with those answers. This new reality series focuses on young women (like Megan, above, hellbent on becoming Miss Iowa) who devote much of their lives to the stressful, expensive quest for beauty-contest crowns. Some of them just like the attention. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- Dr. Temperance Brennan (Emily Deschanel) heads for New Orleans to help identify victims of Hurricane Katrina. But she wakes up there one morning, beaten, with no memory of the day before, and suspected of murdering the local medical examiner. Voodoo may have been involved. 8 P.M. (9) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- A restaurant hostess, an interpreter, a saleswoman, a baby sitter and three students are still in the running for the latest round of this reality-competition series. Tonight someone has surgery, and Janice Dickinson makes a special appearance. 8 P.M. (TCM) THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST -- (1952) Michael Redgrave, Joan Greenwood (right, with Redgrave), Edith Evans and Margaret Rutherford take on Oscar Wilde's witty-for-the-sake-of-wit 1895 play about a deceptive bachelor, his best friend, two lovely young ladies and an absent-minded governess. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SHOW CATS -- Christopher Guest could have made this one-hour special as a companion to his film ''Best in Show'' (which was about dogs). Eccentric owners show off their animals and take them to a major cat show in Houston. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Rod Stewart performs. Then one of the seven remaining finalists is sent home. 9 P.M. (13, 49) HOLY WARRIORS -- Saladin, a polo-playing cavalry officer, decides, after a near-death experience, to wage jihad and win back the holy city of Jerusalem for Islam. Richard of England, soon to be known as Richard the Lionheart, fights to keep it for the Christians. In this two-hour re-enactmentstyle documentary, both men emerge from the Crusades with glowing reputations. 10 P.M. headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICAN MASTERS -- ''John Ford/John Wayne: The Filmmaker and the Legend.'' ''John Wayne was to Ford what David was to Michelangelo,'' the Ford biographer Joseph McBride once said. ''He was the ideal man, the masculine ideal.'' They'd met when Wayne (above left, with Ford, on the set of ''The Alamo'' in 1960) was a college student working as a prop man, and their friendship, forged over poker games in Ford's yacht, spanned 50 years and 14 films, three of them nominated for Oscars. This 90-minute documentary uses home movies, back-lot film footage and interviews to navigate one of Hollywood's most enduringly resonant relationships. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- And then there were three. The results of the Elvis tribute are in, and one of the final four checks into the Heartbreak Hotel. 9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS -- Season finale. They've got mail. A psychopathic killer turns Gideon, Hotchner Morgan (Shemar Moore, left, with an unidentified woman) and their team into his playthings when he sends them each mysterious items on their vacations -- which they must piece together before his next victim dies. 9 P.M. (11) THE BEDFORD DIARIES -- Season finale. Professor Macklin (Matthew Modine) talks abstinence in his human behavior and sexuality seminar. After which Natalie won't let Owen stay with her, Lee just says no to both gambling and women, and Richard hires the virginal Zoe to be the school newspaper's new sex columnist. The episode is directed by the Oscar-winning documentarian Barbara Kopple, whose history with Tom Fontana, the show's creator, goes back to ''Oz'' and ''Homicide.'' 9 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC -- ''To Catch a Predator.'' Chris Hansen continues his series of hidden-camera investigations intended to snare men who appear to be trying to meet children online for sex. The culprits include an elementary school teacher, a fireman and a church youth-group counselor. 9:30 P.M. (Fox) UNAN1MOUS -- Season finale. Only four of the original nine contestants are still eligible to win. And the $1.5 million prize has dwindled down to about $380,000. Will the bunker-mates finally vote unanimously and award the remaining cash to one of their own? Or will the money, and the goodwill, run out along with the clock? 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- It's a whack right out of ''The Sopranos'' when Michael Imperioli (right), reprising his guest role as Detective Nick Falco, discovers the woman he took home the night before slashed to death in his bathroom. And he swears he didn't do it. Now it's up to Fontana, Green and McCoy to help him make his case. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Crushes The Competition
summary: ''American Idol'' had some highlights on Tuesday, as when 17-year-old Paris Bennett, the granddaughter of Ann Nesby from Sounds of Blackness, sang beautifully and was praised by the judges. It also had lows. Simon Cowell, below, said to a male contestant, Kenneth (Chase) Bush, ''It's going to sound odd, but I almost imagine you in a dress when you sing.'' After Mr. Bush assured the judges he wasn't interested in doing drag, Randy Jackson and Paula Abdul outvoted Mr. Cowell and sent Mr. Bush to the next round. The two-hour episode drew 34.75 million viewers for Fox in Nielsen's estimates. The broadcast was the talent show's third-highest-rated ever, and delivered an overwhelming victory for the network. In its second week of the season, ''Idol'' is taking a toll on its network competition between 8 and 10 p.m. ABC's ''According to Jim'' (6.01 million), ''Rodney'' (5.6 million) and ''Commander in Chief'' (10.33 million) all suffered blows to their ratings, as did NBC's ''Fear Factor'' (4.69 million) and two episodes of ''Scrubs'' (5.47 million), then (5.73 million). CBS placed a far-off second for the night. Its new midseason series ''Love Monkey'' fared poorly in Week 2, attracting only 7.65 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 12 - March 18; TELEVISION
summary: The last new episodes of ''THE SOPRANOS'' were so long ago (June 2004) that Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston were still together. But the long, frustrating wait is over. A new 12-episode season begins Sunday night (HBO at 9), with Tony Soprano (JAMES GANDOLFINI) dealing with mob-boss problems like tensions between the New York and New Jersey crime families and realizing that his children aren't children anymore. FRANKIE VALLI is tonight's returning guest star. BEN KINGSLEY will turn up later in the season. And this is not the end: eight more episodes are planned for 2007. There is absolutely no such thing as a ''Seinfeld'' curse. The majority of all new series flop, so the failure of sitcoms with Michael Richards, Jason Alexander and JULIA LOUIS-DREYFUS doesn't mean much. Still, the premiere of ''THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE'' (Monday at 9:30 p.m. on CBS), starring Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, makes some of us nervous. She plays a divorced mom (as if her old character, Elaine, had a maternal bone in her body) and gym owner. The first episode is all about enrolling her 8-year-old son (TREVOR GAGNON) in a private school (''Where are the black people?'' he asks) and establishing her relationship with her ex-husband (CLARK GREGG), who has a new girlfriend (EMILY RUTHERFORD), also named Christine. Thus the title. SEBASTIAN TELFAIR, a young basketball player from Coney Island, is such a star that on the first day of his senior year in high school he holds a press conference. And no one thinks that's unusual. The documentary ''THROUGH THE FIRE'' (Sunday night at 8 on ESPN), which has a lot in common with Steve James's ''Hoop Dreams'' (1994), sees him through graduation, his choice between going to college and a pro career, and the point of it all: getting himself and his family out of the projects.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Triumph
summary: The second night of the early tryouts of ''American Idol'' meant another victory Wednesday for Fox in Nielsen's estimates. ''Idol'' ended on a cruel note: after a young man named Zachary Travis, who had a high voice and high heels, sang Whitney Houston's ''Queen of the Night,'' Simon Cowell called the performance ''atrocious'' and ''confused.'' As Mr. Travis cried to his family afterward, the show itself piled on, playing the theme song from ''The Crying Game,'' the 1992 movie that featured a transgendered character. Regardless, the show delivered its largest audience, 31.44 million, for a Wednesday edition since the finale of the second season, when Clay Aiken lost to Ruben Studdard. ''Idol'' helped lift the premiere of ''Skating With Celebrities,'' which drew 18.73 million viewers. On ABC, ''Lost'' filled in the marital discord part of the past of Jack (Matthew Fox) in flashbacks and ended back on the island with him asking Ana (Michelle Rodriguez, left) for advice on how to train an army to fight the evil Others. ''Lost'' was ABC's sole winner of the night, with 19.3 million viewers; the network placed second to Fox in adults 18 to 49, and third among total viewers, behind CBS. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Sundance) KARL LAGERFELD IS NEVER HAPPY ANYWAY -- Whether conjuring up visions in tulle and silk for Chloé, Fendi and Chanel or getting low with Madonna, Kylie Minogue and H&M, Mr. Lagerfeld (above left) is always aiming for, he says, ''intellectual sexiness.'' This 2000 documentary by Gero von Boehm shows this thinking woman's fashion designer (pre-significant weight loss) at work. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Lance Bass, Paige Davis, Tim Meadows and Leslie Nielsen come on down to play ''Let's Make a Deal.'' 9 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Some clearly ought to think again, as these Chicago auditions demonstrate. 9 P.M. (Food Network) THROWDOWN WITH BOBBY FLAY -- Mr. Flay, whose food confidence knows few bounds, works up an uncustomary sweat in competitions against Butch Lupinetti, a barbecue-pit master, and Giorgio Giove, whose pizza has been honored as the second-best-tasting in the world 9 P.M. (13) THE METROPOLITAN OPERA PRESENTS: THE MET SALUTES JOSEPH VOLPE -- His reign was celebrated for its innovations -- and the occasional insurrection. This special honors Mr. Volpe (left), the Met's retiring general manager, with performances by stars, some of whose careers he helped to make. Among those singing praise: Natalie Dessay, Plácido Domingo, Renée Fleming, Thomas Hampson, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, Kiri Te Kanawa, Karita Mattila, Frederica von Stade and Deborah Voigt. 9:30 P.M. (BET) SEASON OF THE TIGER -- The Grambling State University football field reverberates with the roar of competition in this season finale as the marching band tries to out-maneuver its archrival, Southern University, and Bruce vows to lead his team to victory in the Bayou Classic. 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE HUMAN BEHAVIOR EXPERIMENTS -- In this new documentary, Alex Gibney revisits three famous studies to explore age-old questions about why people do the things they do. The telling trio: Stanley Milgram's obedience-to-authority experiments in which subjects willingly inflict pain on another person; Philip Zimbardo's prisoner-and-guard role-play study, and the 1969 experiment at Columbia University that showed how being in a group can cause humans to behave like animals. 10:30 P.M. (DIY) THE DIRT ON GARDENING -- How does your garden grow? Possibly without sneezes, sniffles or red, itchy eyes, thanks to this new episode on weeding allergies out of the flower patch. MIDNIGHT (Sundance) A FOND KISS -- (2004). Atta Yaqub plays the secondgeneration Pakistani son of strict Muslims and Eva Birthistle (right, with Mr. Yaqub) is a Catholic school teacher in Ken Loach's Romeo-and-Juliet story set in Glasgow. Yes, they're in love against their families' wishes, but their relationship doesn't quite end in death. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: BRYANT GUMBEL HIRED
summary: The NFL Network hired Bryant Gumbel and Cris Collinsworth as the announcers for its eight games in the fall, although Gumbel has never called a pro football broadcast in his more than 30-year career. ''I did some local football, but that was 30 years ago,'' Gumbel said in a conference call. ''But when you do breaking news, you're doing play-by-play of a sort.'' He added: ''When I left sports for news, there were a lot of questions about making the transition. It's a challenge.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) SHARK: MIND OF A DEMON WITH FABIEN COUSTEAU -- With the Cousteau blood running through his veins, it was perhaps inevitable that Fabien Cousteau, son of Jean-Michel and grandson of Jacques Yves, would heed the call of the ocean. But it was ''The Adventures of Tintin: Red Rackham's Treasure,'' whose cover has a submersible in the shape of a shark on it, that inspired his latest adventure. Mr. Cousteau went on to build the craft (above) and then to spend the next two years in it, swimming with the Great White off Isla Guadalupe, Mexico. The result is this hourlong special that Mr. Cousteau hopes will give one of nature's most maligned creatures a much-needed break. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Last week Aleksandra Wojda and Dmitry Chaplin lost their partners to clumsy maneuvers. In this two-hour episode, they're stuck with each other as the top 16 contestants try not to step on each other's toes. 8 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM -- In 1955, Arthur Mitchell joined New York City Ballet and became the first African-American man to be made a permanent member of a major company. Inspired by the death of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Mitchell decided it was his turn to give others, especially children in Harlem, a chance to dance. Teaching in a remodeled garage, he helped to found Dance Theater of Harlem in 1969. This special honors the organization's legacy with performances by Harolyn Blackwell, the Rev. Al Green, Audra McDonald and LeAnn Rimes as well as some of the students (above) Dance Theater has taught to soar. 10 P.M. (AMC) HUSTLE -- Like a certain national hero, these London scammers steal from the city's hardened upper crust - but they don't give back. In this season premiere, the gang tries to con an obnoxious pub owner whose lug of a son aspires to be the next Eminem. If only he had a way with words. 10 P.M. (TV Land) MY FIRST TIME -- Whether good, bad or merely a yawn, it's almost always unforgettable if it's you there. This new series looks at how celebrities got their big breaks, starting with Henry Winkler and Katey Sagal, whose initial close encounters were with Mary Tyler Moore. 10 P.M. (Spike) BLADE: THE SERIES -- Half man, half vampire, all living nightmare. In this new series adapted from the movie trilogy starring the monosyllabic - at least in this role -Wesley Snipes, Kirk ''Sticky Fingaz'' Jones (above) plays it passive-aggressive as the Marvel Comics madman while opening up the lines of communication. Translation: he uses bigger words. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 7 P.M. (ESPN) WORLD SERIES OF DARTS Last year Sport England, which governs financing and strategy for the country's athletics, recognized darts as an official sport, something that any pubgoer could have told them generations ago. This 32-man knockout (the top 16 players as ranked by the Professional Darts Corporation, a British organization, and 16 additional American competitors), taped in May at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut (a qualifying round is shown above), has a decidedly nonamateurish purse: $1 million if the winner is a United States citizen, or $100,000 if he's not. 8 P.M. (CNBC) CONVERSATIONS WITH MICHAEL EISNER In some weird permutation on ''The First Wives Club,'' Mr. Eisner, the former chief executive of Disney, talks with Goldie Hawn, Bette Midler and Candice Bergen but still manages to make the show mostly about himself. 9 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA Was that pleasure or pain on Tommy Lee's face before he cut Chris Pierson, who'd just offered up a dollop of admiration to Mr. Lee, in last week's elimination round? It's these fleeting moments of near-kindness that separate this competition series from the summer chaff, as Mr. Lee and his fellow-panelists Jason Newsted and Gilby Clarke genuinely seem to want to help would-be rockers achieve their dreams. In varying degrees, of course. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING Viewers decide which of the remaining five comedians will float to the top or sink with the ship they've been living on. 9 P.M. (ABC) THE ONE: MAKING A MUSIC STAR By now, you know the drill: contestants live and breathe music as they compete for a recording contract, helped or hindered by a few so-called experts. The twist in this latest series is that these 11 fledgling performers (including Jadyn Maria and Austin Carroll, above) are attending a Los Angeles music academy while sharing a house, and on camera 24/7. Which doesn't leave enough to the imagination. 9 P.M. (Bravo) KATHY GRIFFIN: MY LIFE OF THE D-LIST Enough already. Ms. Griffin and her woes go bye-bye, at least for this season. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) EUREKA His wife has left him, his daughter, Zoe, is a delinquent and he's starting to feel that he's living a nightmare. And to top it off, U.S. Marshal Jack Carter (Colin Ferguson, above, with Jordan Hinson as Zoe) crashes his car near an idyllic-seeming town in the Pacific Northwest in this high-minded dramatic series. Only this place isn't on any map. 10 P.M. (GSN) THE 50 GREATEST GAME SHOWS OF ALL TIME Bill Dwyer of ''I've Got a Secret'' spins the wheel, slowly, in this seven-week countdown, starting here with Nos. 50 and 49. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Olympic Games Light A Night for NBC
summary: Though ratings continue to be down in comparison with those for previous games, Monday's Olympics broadcast resulted in one of its better performances so far. In Nielsen's estimates for prime time, NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49 and drew an average of 22.48 million viewers. Its highest-rated time period was at 10 p.m., which featured men's aerial skiing and, more notably, ice dancing and the soap opera antics of the feuding Italian pair Barbara Fusar Poli and Maurizio Margaglio, above, who appeared to broker their reconciliation during their time on the ice. That hour delivered 23.83 million viewers. Elsewhere on the networks, a Monday episode of ''House'' (14.06 million) and a regularly scheduled ''24'' (13.7 million) put Fox in second place for the night. CBS, which normally wins Monday nights, continued to get out of the Olympics' way and ran repeats, finishing third among total viewers and fourth (behind ABC) in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Democrats Are Unified in Opposition to Troop Increase, but Split Over What to Do About It
summary: The White House sought Sunday to head off building pressure in Congress to cut off or limit financing for sending more troops to Iraq. But even as President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney made it clear that they would proceed with their plan to increase the United States military presence in Iraq in the face of opposition from the House and Senate, Democrats exhibited splits within their ranks over how aggressively to oppose the plan.

headline: Poll Shows Foley Case Is Alienating Public From Congress
summary: Americans say that Republican Congressional leaders put their political interests ahead of protecting the safety of teenage pages, and that House leaders knew of Mark Foley's sexually charged messages to pages well before he was forced to quit Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll, completed before North Korea announced that it had detonated its first nuclear test, also found that the war in Iraq was continuing to take a toll on President Bush and the Republican Party, and that the White House was having difficulty retaining its edge in handling terrorism.

headline: Capitalizing on a Town's High Values
summary: TWO major corporations have decided to cash out of Greenwich's high-flying office market and relocate to less expensive settings, abandoning their headquarters in the town this year. Though the moves will open up nearly 300,000 square feet of office space, commercial brokers say the surge in availability will amount to not much, in a community increasingly dominated by companies willing to pay to be in a business district that has become nearly as exclusive as the lanes winding past back-country estates.

headline: Pulpy TV and Soapy Comics Find a Lot to Agree On
summary: Comic books and soap operas have a lot in common: never-ending stories, characters with complex histories and a preponderance of long-lost relatives (evil twins or otherwise). Now they will share a superhero. ''Guiding Light'' and Marvel Comics have teamed up for an episode of this long-running series, to be shown at 10 a.m. tomorrow on CBS. In the episode, ''She's a Marvel,'' Beth Ehlers, as Harley Davidson Cooper, one of the show's main characters, has an accident that gives her superpowers. To commemorate the occasion, Marvel has produced an eight-page comic.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (BBC America) IF I HAD YOU -- A policewoman, played by the tart Sarah Parish (left), investigates the murder of a teacher after a class reunion in which the chief suspect is her childhood best friend's husband, and her own formerly undercover lover. 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- The competition gets heated as teams compete for $50,000 by dangling from a helicopter while getting squirted by fire-boat water cannons, downing the hottest peppers in the world and sliding through fire. 9 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Last week, Jenny Galt was booted north to Vancouver, leaving her fellow Canadian Luke Rossi to defend their flag in this search for a lead singer for Tommy Lee, Jason Newsted and Gilby Clarke's fledgling band. Tonight, the remaining 12 contestants perform, while the women in the audience will have someone new to ogle: Dave Navarro, the show's newly single co-host. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- One comic goes home before the final four let 'er rip. 9 P.M. (13) CLASS OF 2006 -- ''Wide Angle'' travels to Morocco, where 50 female graduates of an imam academy in Rabat become some of the first contemporary women to be officially trained as religious leaders in the Arab world. 9 P.M. (Sundance) CITY OF MEN -- Surf's up, and so are the girls. Laranjinha (Darlan Cunha) and Acerola (Douglas Silva, far right, with Mr. Cunha) continue to be boys in the second season of this series about best friends living in an impoverished favela in Rio de Janeiro. But trouble is brewing. 10 P.M. (13) THE TAILENDERS -- Since 1939, Global Recordings Network has produced audio Bible stories in more than 5,500 languages -- and says it isn't stopping until it records every language on earth. This ''P.O.V.'' documentary follows the Los Angeles-based company as it distributes the recordings, along with hand-wind players, to isolated migrant workers in the Solomon Islands, Mexico, India and the United States, who are the last to be reached by global evangelism. 10 P.M. (Discovery Health) STRICTLY DR. DREW -- In this new series, Dr. Drew Pinsky combines celebrity interviews (Danny Bonaduce on addiction; Katie Couric, Sharon Osbourne and Lance Armstrong on survival), expert advice and audience chit-chat to dissect a range of health topics, starting tonight with the truth about germs. 10 P.M. (TLC) MIAMI INK -- Yoji Harada (right), the shop's downtrodden apprentice, finally gets to hold a pen in the second season of this series about a South Beach tattoo parlor. Tonight, he reveals his creative side as he and top-dog Ami James ink best friends. Meanwhile, five contestants show no pain in their pursuit to become the new shop manager. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) JAMIE FOXX: UNPREDICTABLE Two years ago, Mr. Foxx (above) was just another actor-singer with a canceled WB sitcom. Now he's an Oscar winner (last year, for playing Ray Charles in ''Ray'') and important enough that when he has a new album (''Unpredictable'') it's occasion for a one-hour special. Between musical numbers with the likes of Snoop Dogg and Mary J. Blige, there are life-story vignettes. 8 P.M. (Flix) SEX, LIES AND VIDEOTAPE (1989). James Spader stars as a young man who has chosen an unusual route to physical satisfaction. This, the director and writer Steven Soderbergh's first feature film, won the audience award at the Sundance Film Festival and the Palme d'Or at Cannes. Mr. Soderbergh was 26. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST Charlie, the former rock musician, is having surreal dreams. This leads him to believe that Claire's baby is in danger. It leads Locke to believe that Charlie may be using drugs again. Meanwhile, Sawyer thinks it's a good idea for Hurley to speak up about his attraction to another plane-crash survivor. 9 P.M. (9) VERONICA MARS Lucy Lawless (left), Xena the Warrior Princess herself, guest-stars as an F.B.I. agent. One is needed because Duncan (Teddy Dunn) has kidnapped a baby. He has also broken up with Veronica (Kristen Bell), but that's not a crime. 9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS A husband and wife are about to be executed as serial killers, but there is reason to believe the wife may be innocent. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE WAR THAT MADE AMERICA As the French and Indian War (1754-63) drags on, the French are outnumbered, the Iroquois help the British and George Washington is almost killed by friendly fire. Parts 3 and 4 of 4. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY A college student is found dead on the subway tracks, but it may not be a subway-surfing accident. A commodities trader is found hanged, but it may not be suicide. Both victims had made enemies. 11 P.M. (Lifetime) WILL & GRACE Dylan McDermott (far right), erstwhile dreamboat of ''The Practice,'' guest-stars in this 2003 episode as a handsome bachelor Will (Eric McCormack) meets while taking a walk with his mother. ANITA GATES

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Iraqi Shiites Pressure U.S. And Assert Independence In a continued effort to demonstrate their independence from Washington, Iraqi Shiites are pressing a fresh set of conditions on their American supporters, asking for changes in the Iraqi government's relationship with the United States military. A12 Moscow May Lose Its Casinos Pressed by President Vladimir V. Putin, lawmakers are drafting a law that would banish casinos and other gambling halls from Moscow, which would do more to alter the cityscape than anything since the collapse of the Soviet Union. A3 Rivals Back Panama for U.N. Venezuela and Guatemala agreed to withdraw from their race for a seat on the United Nations Security Council and to support Panama as a candidate. Their agreement ended a drawn-out contest that had shown the limits of the efforts by the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, to find a prominent platform for his views. A5 Kosovo's Independent Future Though Kosovo is likely to win independence soon from Serbia, it is increasingly evident that international authorities will need to retain far greater responsibility in the province than Western governments had hoped for after seven years of supervising it. A16 Congo Runoff Vote Is Called Fair The Carter Center gave the presidential runoff in Congo its stamp of approval, saying that despite sporadic violence and isolated reports of voter fraud, the election had been disciplined, peaceful, free and fair. A16 NATIONAL A18-25 Public Expects Democrats To End War, Poll Shows Americans expect Democrats to end American military involvement in Iraq if they win control of Congress next week, and say Republicans would increase troop levels to try to win the war if they hold on to power on Capitol Hill, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. A1 President Bush sought to rally Republican voters with a vigorous defense of the war in Iraq and a vow to keep Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in office until the end of Mr. Bush's term. A24 Benefits Found in Red Wine Researchers report that a natural substance found in red wine offsets the bad effects of a high-calorie diet in mice and significantly extends their lives. A1 Design Flaw Cited in Big Dig Engineers changed the design of the ceiling in Boston's Big Dig highway tunnel after they had already finished building the roof from which it would hang, the National Transportation Safety Board said. A18 Possible Link in Fire Cases The police are investigating whether a man charged this week in two brush fires may be connected to last week's wildfire near Palm Springs that killed five United States Forest Service firefighters. A18 6 Killed in Reno Hotel Fire Six people were killed and more than 30 injured in a fire that partly destroyed a historic residential hotel in the downtown casino district in Reno. A casino worker was arrested and charged with arson and multiple counts of murder. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Spitzer Stands Alone On Vision for School Aid Attorney General Eliot Spitzer has promised that if elected governor of New York, he would provide up to $8.5 billion more a year for needy school districts statewide, setting him apart not only from his Republican opponent, John Faso, but also from Governor Pataki, who fought a lawsuit seeking more money for New York City schools. B1 Immigrant Workers' Rights The American Civil Liberties Union and other groups charged in a petition that the United States has failed to protect basic workplace rights to millions of unauthorized immigrant workers. The petition was filed on behalf of six illegal immigrant workers, including the widow of a Mexican killed on a Brooklyn demolition site. B3 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 New Royalties Investigation The Government Accountability Office is beginning a broad investigation into potential deficiencies in how the government collects billions of dollars in royalties from companies that produce oil and gas on federal territory. C1 Bankers Offer Farmers Deal With big profits gushing forth from ethanol plants, dozens of Wall Street bankers, in loafers and suits, have been descending on the cornfields of the Midwest promising to make thousands of farmers rich overnight. Most of the farmers, however, are proving reluctant to cash in. A1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES B8-9 William Styron A novelist from the American South, he was 81. B9 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: The great divider; voting for judicial independence; wiring development; Horton sees an image. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E2 -TV Listings E11 Crossword E6 Weather D8

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 14 - May 20; TELEVISION
summary: This season the very idea of repeats seemed more infuriating than ever, perhaps because viewers have grown used to uninterrupted runs of reality series like ''AMERICAN IDOL'' and the unbroken sprints of ''NIP/TUCK,'' ''THE SOPRANOS'' and other scripted offerings. Now the networks' May finales have arrived in one large heap: the density is almost insulting after such long patches of tiresome reruns. But we must persevere. So among the season finales this week are two of the ''CSI'' franchises (''NEW YORK,'' CBS, Wednesday at 10 p.m., and the Las Vegas flagship, Thursday at 9 p.m.). All three ''LAW & ORDER'' shows also conclude: On ''SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT'' (NBC, Tuesday at 10 p.m.) a famous man's condemnation of prescription drugs will lead a young fan (BRITTANY SNOW) to jettison her meds and go loony. And on the ''Law & Order'' mother ship (Wednesday at 10 p.m.) the audience will see why one of the main characters will not be returning next season. This year ''GREY'S ANATOMY'' inherited the space in the popular consciousness formerly occupied by ''FRIENDS.'' On Sunday (ABC, 10 p.m.) and Monday (9 p.m. to 11) that hospital soap opera will conclude its second season: the search for a new heart for Denny (JEFFREY DEAN MORGAN) will become critical, and surgeons with awkward relationships -- which is everyone -- will be forced to work closely together. Meanwhile a slew of veteran series will adjourn forever this week. ''THAT 70'S SHOW'' (Fox, Thursday at 8 p.m.) will finally ring in 1980, after eight seasons, and in a cloud of pot smoke. ASHTON KUTCHER -- and a second fan favorite -- will rejoin the festivities. ''THE WEST WING'' will also end its acclaimed run (Sunday at 8 p.m.) with the inauguration of Matt Santos (JIMMY SMITS) and the retirement of Jed Bartlet (MARTIN SHEEN).

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Is Sweet Music For Fox Once Again
summary: ''American Idol'' massacred everything in its path, and as a result so did Fox, according to Tuesday's Nielsen estimates. On ''Idol,'' the theme was songs from the 21st century. Most of the performers were roundly criticized by the judges -- yes, even by Paula Abdul, the nice judge. An audience of 31.48 million tuned in, and of the 18-to-49-year-olds who watched television between 8 and 9 p.m., 32 percent chose ''Idol.'' Those ratings continued the talent competition's streak of double-digit growth in comparison with last year's telecasts. Fox's ''House'' also won its hour in dominant fashion, with 21.51 million viewers at 9 p.m. In that slot, the CBS action series ''The Unit'' brought in 15.9 million viewers, placing second to ''House''; it is this season's most-watched new show so far. Also of note, the good news for NBC was that its new sitcom, ''Teachers,'' drew 6.7 million viewers and retained most of the ''Scrubs'' audience (6.8 million). The bad news was that the combination of the two shows was good enough only for a weak third place for the hour. KATE AURTHUR

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Iraqi Government Removes Senior Police Commanders The Iraqi government removed the country's two most senior police commanders from their posts, in the first broad move against the top leadership of Iraq's unruly special police forces. The two generals had commanded Iraq's special police commandos and its public order brigade, both widely criticized as being heavily infiltrated by Shiite militias. A1 Rice to Urge Asian Monitoring Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will urge the countries of northeast Asia to create a strict system of radiation monitoring and inspections to prevent North Korea from smuggling nuclear materials into or out of the country, a senior State Department official said. A10 U.N. Deadlock Over Open Seat Venezuela's campaign to gain Latin America's open seat on the Security Council next year lagged for a second straight day, but Guatemala, the persistent leader after 22 ballots, was unable to win enough votes to secure the position. A12 Abbas Warns Hamas Leaders The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, warned that the current Palestinian political crisis was intolerable, and suggested he would dismiss the Hamas-led government if the rival factions cannot agree soon on a national unity government. A9 NATIONAL A15-21 Supply of Geriatricians Fails to Meet Demand Even as the population ages, geriatricians are in short supply. It is a specialty of little interest to medical students because geriatricians are paid relatively poorly and are not considered superstars in an era of high-tech medicine. A1 Ohio Voters Favor Democrats Ohio appears to have become hostile terrain for Republicans this year, with voters overwhelmingly saying Democrats are more likely to help create jobs, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. A16 Inquiry Faults Ex-Congressman Former Representative Randy Cunningham pressured staff members of the House Intelligence Committee to help steer more than $70 million worth of classified federal business to favored military contractors, according to a Congressional investigation. A15 Bush Signs Terror Suspect Law President Bush signed legislation that creates new rules for prosecuting and interrogating terrorism suspects, a move said to enable the C.I.A. to resume a once-secret program to question dangerous enemy operatives. A20 300 Millionth American Is Born The 300 millionth American was born, and hospital publicists and proud parents staked their claims to the title. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Real Estate Firm Buys Complexes for $5.4 Billion Jerry I. Speyer, a real estate tycoon who controls some of New York City's most prominent landmarks, signed the largest American real estate deal ever, agreeing to pay $5.4 billion for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, a vast corridor of 110 apartment buildings along the East River in Manhattan. A1 Labor Leader Arrested Brian M. McLaughlin, a seven-term assemblyman from Queens who is president of the nation's biggest municipal labor council, was arrested on federal racketeering charges. A1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-6 Mets Fall Behind in Game 5 The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Mets, 4-2, in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series. The Cardinals now lead the series, 3-2. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Chicago Exchange Merger The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade announced that they would merge in an $8 billion deal that would create the largest market for financial derivatives contracts in the world. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The odor from Capitol Hill; if the price is right; a treat worthy of Cinderella; monitoring a little-noticed war. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E8 Obituaries C15 TV Listings E11 Weather B9

headline: Once Again, the Tragedy You Can't Avoid
summary: IT is too soon. That explains why the scores of fifth-anniversary specials, documentaries, mini-series and feature films that seem so bold are really quite timid. Sept. 11 is still an emotional solar eclipse; those who look at it do so through a pinhole projector that at least partly shields the mind and the heart.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Joey': New Night, Same Old Story
summary: ''Joey,'' the ''Friends'' spinoff on NBC that stars Matt LeBlanc, left, has failed, and its time-slot switch to Tuesdays was another monument to that failure: the first new episode of ''Joey'' in months drew an estimated 4.12 million viewers, and among 18-to-49-year-olds it was nearly beaten by a ''Gilmore Girls'' rerun on WB. Fox was far and away the winner on Tuesday, when ''American Idol'' (28.26 million) and ''House'' (20.64 million) both outdrew all competitors. But CBS, which placed second for the night, did very well with the debut of ''The Unit.'' That new David Mamet series delivered 18.19 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Opposite ''The Unit'' and ''House,'' ABC's premiere of ''Sons & Daughters,'' its semi-improvised family comedy, wilted, with 8.35 million tuning in for the first episode and 7.48 million watching the second. Notably, ''Sons & Daughters'' did beat NBC's ''Scrubs,'' its comedy competition in the hour. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 11 P.M.(Bravo) WORK OUT -- Jackie Warner lives hard and plays hard with one goal in mind: perfection. Of the body, that is. This new reality series follows Ms. Warner, the owner of a luxe Beverly Hills gym and spa, as she whips her fitness trainers (including, from above left, Rebecca Cardon, Jennifer Gray and, far right, Erika Jacobson, with Ms. Warner) into shape so they can do the same for clients. 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- One of the remaining 13 singers falls to earth. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE ONE: MAKING A MUSIC STAR -- And then there was one fewer. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Pity the woman who gets paired with Dmitry, whose partners have, so far, been consistently axed while he just keeps on kicking. Tonight, the remaining 10 dancers perform. Only the rules have changed: viewers now get to vote for their favorite individual rather than pair. And the judges don't have the final say. 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT -- The jury's still out on exactly how much talent America's got, but viewers seem to think it's enough to make this one of the summer's bigger hits. In this second semi-final episode, David Hasselhoff, Piers Morgan and Brandy green light one contestant for a move to the finals, while viewers will vote in another, whose identity will be revealed tomorrow night. 9 P.M. (TNT) NIGHTMARES AND DREAMSCAPES: FROM THE STORIES OF STEPHEN KING -- In ''Umney's Last Case,'' the latest installment in this bedtime horror-story series, William H. Macy plays a crime writer trying to escape his life by becoming his fictional detective. At 10, no good deed goes unpunished in ''The End of the Whole Mess,'' in which a filmmaker (Ron Livingston, above) documents his final hour -- and spills some interesting beans. 9 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES -- Chef Ramsay tries to plug a leak in La Gondola, an Italian joint stuck in the 70's, whose décor and cuisine (canned tuna, anyone?) he has deemed hideous. 10 P.M. (13, 49) MARILYN MONROE: STILL LIFE -- She had a face that just begged for the camera's lens. This ''American Masters'' documentary chronicles the life of Marilyn Monroe through the works of photographers like Richard Avedon, Henri Cartier-Bresson and Inge Morath and explores why, though Monroe (above, in 1953) would have turned 80 in June, her appeal is timeless. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'ER': Aging but Attractive
summary: In Nielsen's estimates, Thursday was a mixed bag. NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, as its aging ''ER'' (13.63 million) was the highest-rated hour in that demographic for the night. NBC also benefited from pulling the flailing sitcom ''Four Kings'' at 8:30 p.m. and substituting a repeat of ''My Name Is Earl'' (8.71 million). CBS's N.C.A.A. basketball tournament coverage, featuring the upset by Louisiana State over Duke, drew the most viewers over all, and ABC managed to place second among total viewers. A Thursday edition of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' the first part of the emotional home show's series on Hurricane Katrina (10.72 million), led into the second week of ''American Inventor'' (12.99 million). The new Simon Cowell invention competition helped ''Primetime'' bring in 10.87 million viewers, and ABC was No. 2 for the night among adults 18 to 49. The criticism of its departed cast member Isaac Hayes and the Church of Scientology drew 3.5 million viewers to ''South Park'' for its Season 10 premiere on Wednesday. It was the highest-rated season premiere for the show since 2002. KATE AURTHUR

headline: In the End, Why It Makes Sense to Go for 2
summary: One of these days, an N.F.L. coach in a playoff game is going to face a choice similar to the one Boise State Coach Chris Petersen had at this year's Fiesta Bowl. There will be no time left on the clock, and, having just scored a touchdown to pull within a point, the coach will have a chance to go for a 2-point conversion that could win the game then and there. Petersen, after electing to kick an extra point to send the game to overtime, went for 2 at the end of the first overtime to allow his team to upset Oklahoma, 43-42.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Hyman, Helen Kandel
summary: HYMAN-Helen Kandel, 85. Died at home in Westport, Ct. on March 6, surrounded by her children, grandchildren and adoring dog. She was born in Manhattan, the daughter of Jessie and Isaac Leon Kandel, and graduated from the Horace Mann School and Barnard College. Her professional career began at CBS during the Golden Age of radio, where she wrote dramatic scripts. After starting a family, she continued writing as a freelancer, while living abroad for extended periods with her husband, sociologist Herbert Hyman, and their children. She co-authored ``You and Your Aging Parent'' (1976), and ``Growing Older Together'' (1992), which have been translated into many languages. A third edition was planned at the time of her death. Widowed for twenty years, she is survived by her daughter, Lisa Horowitz and her husband Ted, of Westport; her son David and his wife Eugenie, also of Westport; her son Alex and his partner Deborah Levitzky, of Washington, D.C. and New York City; four grandchildren, Daniel and Anna Horowitz, Nicholas and Graham Hyman; her brother Alan Kandel and his wife Carol, of Detroit; as well as many good friends and admirers from a long, rich life. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Save the Children or Mid-Fairfield Hospice. Burial was private. A memorial will be held at the Westport Playhouse on March 26 at 2 PM.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Another 'Idol' Victory
summary: It is rare that a single half-hour television show can lift a network to a first-place finish in the ratings for the entire night. But most shows are not ''American Idol.'' On Wednesday at 9 p.m., the first results show of its final round drew an audience of 27.84 million in Nielsen's estimates, giving Fox an easy victory. The series premiere of ''The Loop'' followed, and, as often happens with shows after ''Idol,'' half the audience was lost: 13.75 million tuned in. Earlier in the night, Fox's ''Bones'' delivered 12.13 million viewers. In recent weeks, the network has given that crime series a post-''Idol'' berth to boost its audience, and has now moved the show to 8 p.m. The strategy appears to have worked: ''Bones'' tied for first for the hour among adults 18 to 49, and placed second in the time slot to CBS's ''Survivor'' recap (12.69 million) in total viewers. ABC's combination of piggybacking ''Lost'' and ''Invasion'' has been less successful. Wednesday's episode of ''Lost'' (7.14 million) at 9 p.m. was a low-rated repeat, causing the creeping aliens of ''Invasion'' to tank at 10 p.m., with 7.23 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Local Radio Is Cutting the Static and Going Digital, Finally
summary: AS drivers pick their way down the West Side Highway of Manhattan, the noise is often more annoying than the traffic -- and it's not just the honking. What's so irksome is the static from the car's sound system, a result of congestion in the radio frequency spectrum in an area packed with AM and FM stations. But that analog annoyance may fade away as radio broadcasters, carmakers and consumer electronics companies make the transition to digital radio.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'American Idol' And American President
summary: Between ''American Idol'' on Fox at 8 p.m. and the State of the Union coverage for the remainder of the night on most networks, Fox had another easy victory on Tuesday. ''Idol,'' in which the normally cheery Paula Abdul said ''no'' more readily and crankily than she usually does, delivered 28.73 million viewers and a dominant 18-to-49 rating. According to the early ratings approximations for President Bush's live address, Fox also placed first in its broadcast of the speech, followed by CBS, ABC and NBC. (But the latter two networks were so close in their ratings that the order could change when the final numbers come in.) Opposite the first hour of the speech, WB's ''Supernatural'' scored better-than-usual ratings, with an audience of 5.87 million and a second-place finish among adults 18 to 34 and 18 to 49. On Monday, A&E's ''Flight 93,'' a television movie about one of the planes hijacked on Sept. 11, 2001, brought in 5.9 million viewers, making it the most-watched program in that cable channel's 22-year history. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 3 P.M. (BBC America) QUEEN AND COUNTRY -- On June 15, Britain will celebrate the 80th birthday of Queen Elizabeth II (along with the 85th birthday of her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh). This four-hour special examines the key aspects of the reign of one of the world's most photographed personalities, who, even now, remains an enigma to her people. At 7, ''H.M. the Queen: A Remarkable Life'' looks at how the queen (above, shown arriving at Westminster Abbey on May 17) has weathered change during more than 50 years on the throne. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 60TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS -- She may not have earned a Tony nomination, but her star turn in ''Three Days of Rain'' was a major factor in the 4.1 percent boost in ticket sales this year, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers. We're sure she'll rake in more than a few viewers in her role as a presenter at this, the least glitzy (and most scantily watched) of all major award ceremonies, broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan. 9 P.M. (Food Network) FOOD NETWORK CATERS YOUR VEGAS WEDDING -- It's a bride's dream-come-true when Giada de Laurentiis, Bobby Flay and other network chefs whip up a feast fit for the celebration of a lifetime. 9 P.M. (USA) THE 4400 -- Only seconds ago, Isabelle (Megalyn Echikunwoke, left) was a year-old baby. Now, in this season premiere about 4,400 humans who were abducted by aliens and then returned to Earth, she's a beautiful 20-year-old. And there are repercussions. 9 P.M. (Discovery) KRAKATOA: VOLCANO OF DESTRUCTION -- Multiply the magnitude of the 2004 tsunami by four and add the devastation of a volcanic eruption. That was the impact of the 1883 eruption of Krakatoa in Indonesia, whose explosion could be heard 3,000 miles away in Australia. This computergenerated special is almost, but thankfully not quite, like being there. 9 P.M. (HBO) DEADWOOD -- Lawlessness comes to an end with the beginning of a new season, as the town's first real election approaches. Call it strategic planning. 10 P.M. (HBO) ENTOURAGE -- Vince takes a brand-name date to his ''Aquaman'' premiere. And it's spelled M-O-M. 10:30 P.M. (HBO) LUCKY LOUIE -- Louis C.K. and Pamela Adlon (left) play Louie and Kim, typical blue-collar parents raising a child, in this new sitcom. Which is why her offer of sex for a week sounds awfully suspicious. 11 P.M. (HBO) DANE COOK'S TOURGASM -- Mr. Cook and three fellow comics tour 28 states in 30 days in a cramped bus in this new docu-comedy series. And they're still laughing. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
