headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Linkin Park on iTunes Linkin Park, one of the few major acts that had not made its music available on Apple's iTunes Music Store, has changed course and made a deal with the service, Reuters reported. Three of the group's albums were available beginning yesterday, each with two bonus tracks and a third iTunes exclusive cut. In addition, iTunes is selling the video content featured on the group's ''Live in Texas'' and ''Collision Course'' DVD's. ''We were really excited when iTunes told us that we were one of their most requested acts,'' Mike Shinoda, a member of the group, said. ''We will never ignore our fans, and the timing seemed right to make our music available, with some special additions.'' Warning on Streisand Concert Tickets More than 1,000 tickets for the first United States concert tour of Barbra Streisand, below, in more than a decade have been invalidated because they were bought with stolen credit card information, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Organizers announced that the tickets, bought through Ticketmaster, turned up on various Internet resale sites. With tickets priced at $100 to $750, the 19-performance tour is to begin in Philadelphia on Oct. 4. (Performances in Madison Square Garden are scheduled for Oct. 9 and 11.) The national promoter, Michael Cohl, and Ms. Streisand's manager, Martin Erlichman, warned that no one holding the invalidated tickets would be admitted. Jessica Simpson's Lost Cord If timing is everything, then Jessica Simpson got nothing much yesterday. Nothing much, that is, besides a case of laryngitis. Just as she was about to begin promoting her new album, ''A Public Affair'' (Epic), she lost her voice, The Associated Press reported. ''She has been ordered to rest,'' said Rob Shuter, her press representative. ''She can talk; she can croak out a few sentences. She sounds a little off, but, you know, she can't sing.'' He said Miss Simpson, 26, became ill on Friday and has ''a strain, a bruise on her vocal cord.'' On Second Thought The rapper Foxy Brown, below, pleaded guilty and then pleaded for reconsideration when she appeared in Criminal Court in Manhattan on Monday to answer to misdemeanor assault charges, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Brown, 26, whose real name is Inga Marchand, was accused of kicking an employee of a salon and smacking a second in an argument over a payment for a manicure. When she appeared in court on Monday, she was spared jail time but, under a plea deal with the Manhattan district attorney's office, accepted three years' probation and agreed to attend anger management classes. Minutes later, she tried to return to the courtroom and withdraw her plea, contending that she had been rushed into her decision, said Edison Alban, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office. He said the judge told her that ''the plea stands.'' Emmys Nip 'Pirates' The Emmy Awards might have provided joy aplenty for winners including Kiefer Sutherland and ''The Office,'' as well as the host, Conan O'Brien, but Sunday night's ceremonies were only so-so for NBC, The Associated Press reported. According to estimates from Nielsen Media Research, the show attracted its fourth-smallest audience ever, averaging 16.1 million viewers, down from 18.8 million last year, when CBS broadcast the awards in September. Nevertheless, NBC won the night's ratings race. The Emmys, seen from 8 to 11 p.m., beat strong competition in the form of ABC's broadcast of ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' from 7 to 10 p.m. It averaged 10.2 million viewers. The Disney Channel has a new hit on its hands: ''The Cheetah Girls 2,'' seen on Friday from 8 to 9:55 p.m., drew an average of 7.8 million views, the most for an original movie debut in the channel's history.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (USA) AFI LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO SEAN CONNERY -- ''Bond. James Bond.'' Uttered in that silken voice, those words left more than a few viewers shaken and stirred. In this special, taped on June 8 at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles, some of Sir Sean's (above) envious peers pay homage to the actor who has gotten his way with more brazen beauties than any other, at least onscreen. Harrison Ford, no slouch in the seduction department, bestows the honors. 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER 7: ALL-STARS -- Historically, democracy has been riddled with subterfuge, deception and treason. Which may be why the producers of ''Big Brother'' opted to let viewers vote for the series's next 12 houseguests from hell in this hour-long casting special for the new season, which begins July 6 at 8 p.m. 8 P.M. (13) DANCE IN AMERICA: BEYOND THE STEPS: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER -- Past, present, future: that concept is at the heart of the Ailey's mission statement, which means performing in the here while looking ahead to what the ensemble hopes to achieve and keeping a legacy alive. This ''Great Performances'' documentary follows the company as it travels to Russia for the first time in 20 years, moves into its new headquarters in Manhattan, and creates ''Love Stories'' (above, with, from left, Clifton Brown, Matthew Rushing and Dwana Adiaha Smallwood), a three-part ballet choreographed by the Ailey's artistic director, Judith Jamison (whose segment, she said, references the past), the hip-hop innovator Rennie Harris (the present) and the modern dance trailblazer Robert Battle (the future). 9 P.M. (13) A LION IN THE HOUSE -- Every year in the United States, some 12,500 children hear the diagnosis that leaves most adults quaking: ''You have cancer.'' This ''Independent Lens'' documentary follows five young patients and their families at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center and asks the tough questions: How do you decide to stop medical intervention when treatment fails? And how do you put your lives back together when it succeeds? 9 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT -- In varying degrees, of course, as will be made brutally apparent in the latest in Simon Cowell's anything-for-fame series. An array of singers, dancers, comedians and promising ''unique acts'' will pour their hearts out for a chance at $1 million, with the final two contestants chosen, one each, by viewers and a panel of celebrity judges. If ''American Idol'' had Paula Abdul, Randy Jackson and Mr. Cowell, this time around it's the singer Brandy, the actor David Hasselhoff and Piers Morgan, a somewhat scurrilous British media personality. Standing in for the dentally enhanced Ryan Secrest: the toothsome Regis Philbin (above). KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Last year, Tommy Lee, the libidinous drummer of Mötley Crue, went back to college, sort of. This season, he's furthering his education by forming a band with some of his fellow metal masters, including Jason Newsted of Metallica and Gilby Clarke (above left, with Mr. Lee, center, and Mr. Newsted) of Guns N' Roses. This new series chronicles their quest to find a lead singer from among 15 rock 'n' roll neophytes, after which the group will strike out to set the world on fire. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Last week, Nigel Lithgoe, whose teeth-baring attacks can at times make Simon Cowell look like a lap dog, did the unthinkable and apologized to Aleksandra Wojda for his criticism of her the night before. And then he axed her anyway, along with the ethereally monosyllabic Ben Susek, leaving 14 contestants, who continue to twirl for the title here. 8 P.M. (13, 49) NIAGARA FALLS -- It's not just for honeymooners anymore. Mariette Hartley narrates this documentary, which looks at the grandeur of one of North America's most aweinspiring natural wonders, the environmental groups who maintain it, and the daredevils who can't take a hint and keep trying to harness its violent force. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) EDGE OF OUTSIDE -- To be an independent filmmaker no longer means being ostracized from the commercial realm, as Oscar-winning films like ''Crash'' and ''Brokeback Mountain'' proved this year. In this documentary, Martin Scorsese, Peter Falk, Edward Burns, Spike Lee, Henry Jaglom, Arthur Penn (above, with Faye Dunaway on the set of ''Bonnie and Clyde''), Gena Rowlands and John Sayles talk about the struggles -- creative, financial and emotional -- of being a maverick in Hollywood and the extraordinary vision that can result from it. 9 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES -- It's hard to decide what's more delicious: watching Gordon Ramsay pummel wannabe chefs into submission on his Fox series, ''Hell's Kitchen, or whip, beat and froth foundering restaurant into working order, which he does here. Tonight Dave, the self-appointed head chef of Clubway 41 who hasn't been in a kitchen for 30 years, incurs the brunt of Mr. Ramsay's wrath. 9 P.M. (Travel Channel) PROFESSIONAL POKER TOUR -- Thrill seekers play at five of the country's glitziest casinos for a cut of $2.5 million, starting at Foxwoods in Connecticut. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- Mr. Angel reads the minds of celebrities like Ice Cube, Vince Neil, Mark McGrath (right) and Robin Leach. But does he find anything there? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Kean Name vs. Doubt on Bush Makes for Tossup in New Jersey
summary: Thomas H. Kean Jr., the Republican challenger for United States Senate in New Jersey, has capitalized on his father's reputation to offset voters' qualms about his inexperience. Senator Robert Menendez has been buoyed by discontent with President Bush. The result in this heavily Democratic state is an extremely tight race, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The poll suggests that Mr. Kean, a state senator, has done surprisingly well in a year when other Republicans are struggling even on friendlier turf not because of Mr. Kean himself, but because of his father, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, one of the state's most popular politicians.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Feb. 5 - Feb. 11; TELEVISION
summary: It's a colossal television week. There's the SUPER BOWL, in which the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Seattle Seahawks will face each other in Detroit (ABC, Sunday at 6 p.m., with pre-game coverage beginning at 2:30 p.m.). On Wednesday, CBS will broadcast the ''48th ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS'' at 8 p.m.: MARIAH CAREY, KANYE WEST and JOHN LEGEND lead the nominees. And then there's the OLYMPICS, which start on Friday (NBC, 8 p.m.): unfortunately, BJORK will not be adding an element of arty weirdness to the opening ceremonies, as she did in Athens 2004. But there are sadder things to discuss than a Bjork-less Olympics. ''ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT'' will conclude -- for now -- on FOX after two and a half years of excellent critical notices and Emmy Awards (and virtually no viewers). But do not go gentle into that good Friday night at 8 p.m., Mitchell Hurwitz; rage, rage, for the chance to continue the show you created. All hope is not lost: SHOWTIME has publicly been courting the show in the hope that it can bring the Bluth family's selfish, alcoholic charms to the pay-cable channel. Guest stars abound in the final four episodes. In one, WILLIAM HUNG, the dreadful ''American Idol'' contestant, appears as himself, and JUDGE REINHOLD, solely on the strength of his first name, has been given a courtroom show -- on which Michael (JASON BATEMAN) defends the Bluths in a mock trial. In an episode called ''FAMILY TIES,'' JUSTINE BATEMAN -- Jason's sister, who made her name in that bygone sitcom -- plays Michael's long-lost sister. ''I've always been mildly attracted to you,'' she tells him. This two-hour block of the Fox series will be broadcast opposite the Olympics kickoff. In other words, it will go out as it came in: as roadkill.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) THE ACCIDENTAL WITNESS -- Natasha Gregson Wagner (right), Natalie Wood's 35-year-old daughter, stars in this television movie as a lawyer pursued by a killer. He believes she witnessed one of his crimes. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Michael (Wentworth Miller, now an official covermodel hunk) is in the psychiatric ward freaking out because part of his tattoo is missing. As most people who have even heard of this drama series know, the tattoo is a map of the entire prison facility. Two other inmates, C-Note (Rockmond Dunbar) and Tbag (Robert Knepper), play poker. 8 P.M. (NBC) CELEBRITY COOKING SHOWDOWN -- Wolfgang Puck is one of the famous chefs in this five-night series. Tom Arnold (near left, with Mr. Puck) is one of the celebrities who will be partnered with chefs. Gael Greene is one of the judges. 8 P.M. (11) 7TH HEAVEN -- Everybody in the family seems to have a secret about a wedding ring. 9 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- ''Day 5: 12 P.M.-1 A.M.'' As this show's fifth season and fifth terrorist crisis near their close, martial law is still in effect. And there's a significant reunion: Jack (Kiefer Sutherland), Audrey (Kim Raver) and the Secretary of Defense (William Devane). 9 P.M. (11) EVERWOOD -- Rose (Merrilyn Gann) smokes medical marijuana. Andy and Jake (Treat Williams and Scott Wolf) save a drunk driver. 10 P.M. (ABC) WHAT ABOUT BRIAN -- Brian (Barry Watson) sets out to hook up (as we say now) with two different women in one day. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: MIAMI -- A tsunami is heading toward Florida. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Viewers must ask just how many dreams Allison DuBois (Patricia Arquette), psychic heroine, is going to have about murder victims and how many serial killers she is going to foresee before this generally smart series runs its course. But Allison's daughter Bridgette (Maria Lark) does have an unusual problem. Asked to make a school presentation about her parents' careers, how is she going to explain her mother? 1:20 A.M. (Cinemax) THE ACCUSED -- (1988). Jodie Foster (below) won her first best actress Oscar for her role as a fun-loving bluecollar woman who is gang-raped and then finds her character, rather than her attackers, on trial. Kelly McGillis plays the prosecutor, who believes the men who cheered them on are guilty, too. ANITA GATES

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: A FORD STEPS DOWN -- William Clay Ford Jr., great-grandson of the founder of the Ford Motor Company, brought in an outsider to help run the company, in a tacit acknowledgment that he needed a new approach in his efforts to turn the company around. Mr. Ford, above, gave up the titles of president and chief executive to Alan Mulally, an executive with no experience in the auto industry. [Page A1.] VIACOM CHIEF FORCED OUT -- Viacom's chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, forced out his top executive, Thomas E. Freston, dramatically reasserting his control over the media giant he built over decades. [C1.] REDSTONE ASSERTS HIMSELF -- In abruptly replacing the chief executive of Viacom, Sumner M. Redstone sent another blaring signal that he does not intend to fade out of the picture. [C5.] UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR BRAD GREY -- Viacom's executive shuffle fueled open speculation about the fate of Brad Grey, who was hired by the departing chief executive last year to engineer a turnaround of Paramount Pictures. [C5.] COURIC'S FIRST DAY -- Katie Couric handled her first broadcast as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' calmly and competently. [A15.] MORTGAGES ATTRACT INVESTORS -- Even as experts have been ringing warning bells about exotic mortgages for months and fresh housing data has indicated that the risks are rising, investors have increased their exposure to the securities. Market Place. [C1.] INTEL OUTLINES CUTS -- Intel said it would reduce its work force by 10 percent and cut $5 billion in costs over two years. [C1.] JUDGE REJECTS PAY PLAN -- A plan to pay millions of dollars to the top officials of the Dana Corporation, the auto parts company, violates the new bankruptcy law and cannot go forward, a judge ruled. [C1.] AFRICA MAKES STRIDES -- Africa moved up from last place to the middle of the pack among the world's regions in carrying out changes that make it easier to start and run a business, according to a World Bank report. [A12.] NOMINEE FOR TRANSPORTATION -- President Bush said he would nominate Mary Peters, a strong advocate of bringing private companies into the construction and operation of highways, to be the next transportation secretary. [A14.] BACKDATING PROVES COSTLY -- A new study estimates that the stock options backdating scandal may cost shareholders hundreds of millions of dollars. [C4.] SUPPORT FOR FASHION DESIGNER -- Simon Fuller, the British producer behind lucrative pop culture phenomena like ''American Idol'' and the Spice Girls, said he would begin a new division of his company to promote a struggling fashion designer, Roland Mouret. [C4.] RULES FOR GENETIC SCREENING -- The Food and Drug Administration took a step toward regulating a new category of genetic screening and other complex diagnostic tests that are expected to play a growing role in tailoring medical treatments to specific patients. [C4.] BEER AS TV STAR -- Anheuser-Busch is preparing to introduce an online entertainment network called Bud TV, accelerating its push into the business of providing program content. Advertising. Stuart Elliott. [C4.] DROP IN HOME PRICES -- Prices of single-family homes fell in 87 of the nation's 379 major metropolitan areas from the first quarter to the second, the government reported. [C6.] BIG OIL FIND IN GULF -- Chevron, Devon Energy and Statoil said they had found 3 billion to 15 billion barrels of oil in the Gulf of Mexico, 30,000 feet below the water surface, a discovery that may usher in a new era in ultra-deepwater offshore drilling. The discovery could also increase the country's oil reserves by as much as 50 percent. [C7.] LIGHT DAY FOR STOCKS -- Stocks rose in thin trading as a gain in Chevron, on news that it tapped an oil reserve deep in the Gulf of Mexico, outweighed a drop in Viacom after its chief executive quit. [C11.] MINING MERGER IS QUASHED -- Phelps Dodge and Inco, the mine operators, walked away from their troubled merger agreement after the proposed combination, which would have been worth about 20 billion Canadian dollars, met with shareholder resistance. [C7.] SPYING AT H.P -- Hewlett-Packard's chairwoman ordered phone surveillance of its directors to determine the source of news leaks, prompting a furor in which one director quit and another rebuffed efforts to oust him, the company said. [C1] NEW CAPITOL HILL PAPER -- A third Capitol Hill newspaper, The Capitol Leader, is set to make its debut in November, to compete with Roll Call and The Hill. [C11.] ONLINE Dealbook -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. A federal bankruptcy judge approved Delta Air Lines' request to terminate its pilots' pension plan. (AP) The oil and gas field surveyor Géophysique will buy its American rival, Veritas, for $3.1 billion in cash and stock, establishing a major global player in the oil exploration industry. (AP) The video game company Atari said it had appointed David Pierce as its president and chief executive, succeeding Bruno Bonnell, who will continue as chairman and chief creative officer. (REUTERS) MacDermid, a maker of specialty chemicals, said it received a proposal from its chief executive, Daniel H. Leever, and Court Square Capital Partners to buy the company's outstanding shares for $1 billion. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Laugh Lines
summary: Jay Leno That Arab company that was going to guard our seaports -- they have agreed to allow a formal investigation into the deal. They agreed to it! That's big of them. I knew they were running our ports -- I didn't know they were running our government, too. On the port deal, a lot of Republican congressmen are saying let's not rush to judgment, let's investigate it and be sure of our facts. Gee, too bad they didn't try that before we invaded Iraq.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: At Last, an Oscar Five times a nominee for the Academy Award for best director in a career that spans 55 years, Robert Altman, 80, is to receive an honorary Oscar at the annual ceremony, on March 5, in Los Angeles, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Altman, left, who has made 86 films, has been nominated for best director for ''M*A*S*H'' (1970), ''Nashville'' (1975), ''The Player'' (1992), ''Short Cuts'' (1993) and ''Gosford Park'' (2001) but shares the record for Oscar futility with Martin Scorsese, Alfred Hitchcock, Clarence Brown and King Vidor. Sidney Ganis, the president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, said its board ''was taken with Altman's innovation, his redefinition of genres, his invention of new ways of using the film medium and his reinvigoration of old ones.'' Penélope Cruz, praised by the French culture minister as a ''great European actress,'' has been proclaimed a knight in the Order of Arts and Letters, The Associated Press reported. At ceremonies in Paris attended by Salma Hayek, her co-star in ''Bandidas,'' a new movie Ms. Cruz is promoting, Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres said, ''It's France's role to be the ardent defender of cultural diversity and to recognize those who extend, with their talent, the culture of their country.'' Ms. Cruz's career includes roles in French, English, Italian and her native Spanish. Local Girl Makes Good Queen Latifah invited hundreds of guests to the red-carpet premiere of her new movie, ''Last Holiday,'' in Newark on Wednesday night, The Associated Press reported. Mayor Sharpe James was happy. ''She's our queen,'' he said. ''This young lady is so multitalented. She's still the girl next door. She still comes home to Newark.'' This month, Latifah became the first hip-hop artist to receive a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. In her new film, co-starring Timothy Hutton and Gérard Depardieu, as well as LL Cool J, who accompanied her, Latifah plays a department store cookware saleswoman who embarks on a dream vacation in Europe after receiving a mistaken diagnosis of fatal illness. Latifah, who has homes in New Jersey and Los Angeles, was happy with the Newark opening night on Wednesday. ''It just means I don't have to go far to get home from the premiere,'' she said. ''My whole family is here, so it's wonderful. I can celebrate with Jersey for a change.'' (A review of ''Last Holiday'' is on Page E12.) Darwin House Nominated Britain has nominated the house where Charles Darwin, below, developed his theory of evolution for listing as a United Nations World Heritage Site, Agence France-Presse reported. The home, Down House in Downe, Kent, in southeast England, is also the site of an experimental garden where Darwin demonstrated his theory through the study of plants and animals. His work resulted in the publication in 1859 of ''On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection.'' Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell said the World Heritage Committee had called for nominations to recognize outstanding achievements in science. If the nomination is successful, the site could be recognized by 2009, the bicentenary of Darwin's birth. Footnotes Richard Hatch, who won $1 million in 2000 on the first CBS ''Survivor'' show, was depicted by his lawyer yesterday as the ''world's worst bookkeeper,'' not a tax evader, as his trial opened in a federal court in Providence, R.I., The Associated Press reported. But Andrew Reich, the prosecutor, told jurors the government would prove that Mr. Hatch willfully failed to report his winning to avoid more than $200,000 in taxes. The run of ''The Little Dog Laughed'' has been extended. Scheduled to close on Jan. 29, the Douglas Carter Beane comedy, directed by Scott Ellis, will continue through Feb. 26 at the Second Stage Theater. Chita Rivera will be reunited with Dick Van Dyke, her co-star in ''Bye Bye Birdie'' (1960), when he makes a guest appearance in ''Chita Rivera: The Dancer's Life'' for four performances from Jan. 24 through Jan. 26 at the Schoenfeld Theater. Mr. Van Dyke's last Broadway appearance was more than 25 years ago, in a revival of ''The Music Man.'' The Guggenheim Museum designed by Frank Gehry in Bilbao, Spain, has been a hit, Agence France-Press reported. Since its opening in 1997, it has attracted 8.1 million visitors, 60 percent of them tourists. By comparison, 57 percent of the visitors to temporary exhibitions in the Prado in Madrid are Spanish. Last year, attendance in Bilbao increased 13.54 percent, to 965,082.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Arab Democracy Falters, Frustrating U.S. Goals Steps toward democracy in the Arab world, a crucial American goal that just months ago was cause for optimism -- with elections held in Iraq, Egypt and the Palestinian areas -- are slowing, blocked by legal maneuvers and official changes of heart throughout the Middle East. A1 Iraqi leaders held a news conference to denounce Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian president, for publicly asserting that Iraq was already engulfed in civil war and that Iraqi Shiites were loyal to Iran. A6 Brazil Expands Ethanol Use Brazil is meeting its growing demand for fuel by increasing production not only of petroleum, but also ethanol. The use of ethanol, derived in Brazil from sugar cane, is already so widespread that gas stations have a set of pumps for each. A1 U.S. General Writes on Iraq War The three-star Marine Corps general who was the military's top operations officer before the invasion of Iraq expressed regret in a published essay that he did not more energetically question those who had ordered the nation to war. He urged active-duty officers to speak out if they had doubts about the war. A6 European Probe Nears Venus Venus Express, the first mission by the European Space Agency to Earth's nearest neighbor, is set to go into orbit around the second planet from the sun. The $260 million Venus Express is intended to study the planet for at least two Venus days, one for every 243 of Earth's. A12 Stampede Kills 30 in Pakistan At least 26 women and 4 children were killed in a stampede at the end of a religious gathering of about 10,000 women marking the birthday of the Prophet Muhammed in the southern port city of Karachi at the Islamic center Faizan-e-Madina, the police and hospital officials said. A4 NATIONAL A14-21 Army Struggles to Keep Its Newer Officers Young Army officers, including growing numbers of captains who leave as soon as their initial commitment is fulfilled, are bailing out of active-duty service at rates that have alarmed senior officers. A1 Statement on Iraq Findings A senior Bush administration official confirmed that President Bush ordered the declassification of parts of a prewar intelligence report on Iraq to rebut critics who said the administration had exaggerated the nuclear threat posed by Saddam Hussein, but said the president did not authorize leaking information to reporters. A14 Rallies for Immigrant Rights Thousands of people protested in cities around the country in favor of changes in federal immigration measures that would legalize undocumented workers. A14 Towns Welcome Nuclear Plants As the memories of the accidents at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl fade, local governments eager for jobs and tax revenues to replace vanished industries are embracing nuclear plant construction. A20 Air Traffic System Problems A vast program to replace the voice and data lines that link the Federal Aviation Administration's air traffic control system has caused at least three major failures in the system recently, resulting in the grounding of scores of airliners. A20 Students Take On College Costs Experts say more middle- and upper-middle-class parents are limiting what they will pay for higher education, and are willing to pass more of the burden on to their children. A1 Treatment May Cause Diabetes A newly published study found that a popular therapy for dealing with kidney stones by sending shock waves that pulverize them into sandlike material greatly increases the risk for diabetes and high blood pressure later in life. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Another Cheese Museum Gets Help From Albany A sliver of state money has recently been directed to the Cuba Cheese Museum in Western New York from a pool of cash controlled by Gov. George E. Pataki. The museum is the second cheese museum in two decades that has been partially financed by state spending. A1 Buyouts in Brooklyn Although many neighborhood residents have protested Bruce Ratner's plans to redevelop 22 acres for his Atlantic Yards project, some former apartment and business owners say that negotiations with his company provided an opportunity to leave spaces that had grown too small and to make a profit in the process. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Mickelson Wins Masters, Again Phil Mickelson won the Masters tournament for the second time in three years, shooting a 3-under 69 in the final round for a two-shot victory over Tim Clark. D1 ARTS E1-10 Brazilian Wins Pritzker Prize Paulo Mendes da Rocha of Brazil, known for his provocative ways with concrete and steel, has won the 2006 Pritzker Architecture Prize, considered the profession's highest honor. Mr. Mendes da Rocha, 77, is best known for his Brazilian Sculpture Museum in São Paulo. E1 OBITUARIES B7 Allan Kaprow An artist who coined the term ''happenings'' and whose anti-art, audience-participation works contributed to radical changes in the course of late-20th-century art, he was 78. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Reviving Evening News Katie Couric's new position at the CBS anchor desk is occurring as the networks aim to re-invent the evening news and appeal to a younger audience. C1 Tabloid Rivalry Heats Up The New York Daily News has taken its lumps from its cross-town tabloid rival, The New York Post, while also losing readers to it. Now The Daily News is having a field day with accusations that a reporter for The New York Post's Page Six tried to extort $220,000 from a billionaire to protect him from negative publicity. C1 Newspapers After Katrina After Hurricane Katrina, The Sun Herald of Biloxi, Miss., and The Times-Picayune of New Orleans have rebuilt and reinvigorated their readership. For their role in covering and enduring the storm, both papers have been mentioned as possible recipients of the Pulitzer Prize. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The Saddam Hussein trials; deaths after RU-486; a victory for California; Francis X. Clines on the anatomy lesson. Column: Paul Krugman. Bridge E4 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather B8

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 14 Die in Afghan Riot After Crash of U.S. Truck A traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy that killed five people escalated into an anti-American riot that raged across Kabul, the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured. Witnesses said American soldiers fired on Afghans throwing stones at them after the crash, though the United States military said only that warning shots had been fired in the air. A1 More Reserve Troops to Iraq The top American commander in Iraq has decided to move reserve troops now deployed in Kuwait into the volatile Anbar Province in western Iraq to help quell a surge in insurgent attacks there, two American officials said. A1 Two Britons working as members of a CBS News television crew were killed and an American correspondent for the network was critically wounded when a military patrol they were accompanying was hit by a roadside bomb. The police said at least 31 other people were killed in one of the worst days of bloodshed in the capital for weeks. A10 Support for Haditha Accused Denial and utter disbelief are the overwhelming reaction in Camp Pendleton, California, to reports of the killings in Haditha, Iraq, involving marines based at the camp. If there is any truth to the accusations, some say, then the troops must have been acting on direct orders, responding as they were trained to do. A11 Volcano Destabilized by Quake Significant amounts of aid began arriving in Bantul, the town hit the hardest by an earthquake on Saturday, but Mount Merapi, a nearby volcano, has increased its threatening activity. Volcanologists said the quake destabilized a dome at the mountain's peak, which if it collapses, would set off a large eruption of lava, rocks and hot gas. A8 Israeli Policy Debate in Britain Britain's biggest association of higher education instructors decided to urge its 67,000 members to consider boycotting Israeli academics who failed to renounce what it called Israel's ''apartheid policies'' in the West Bank and Gaza. A11 Call for Tiananmen Reparations A group of 126 people whose relatives died in the suppression of the June 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square issued a joint appeal to reassess the incident and compensate victims, even as Chinese authorities worked to stop any commemorations of it as the anniversary approaches. A8 Corruption Behind Brazil Unrest Fighting in São Paolo, Brazil between the police and criminal gangs that left at least 168 people dead has ceased, at least for now. The cause of the outbreak is what political leaders, lawyers and human rights groups describe as endemic corruption in law enforcement agencies and prisons. A3 NATIONAL A12-17 Identity Thieves Carve A Niche in Phoenix The Phoenix area has the highest rate of identity theft complaints in the nation, according to the Federal Trade Commission. In an economy that runs increasingly on the instantaneous flow of information and credit, the area provides a window into one of the system's unintended consequences. A1 FedEx Drivers Look to Unionize FedEx drivers in Massachusetts are looking to join the Teamsters, pitting one of the most powerful unions against a hugely successful company, where none of its 60,000 drivers is unionized. A12 Bush Invokes the Fallen President Bush paid homage to fallen members of the nation's military, using his annual Memorial Day speech at Arlington National Cemetery to draw a link among those who fought in an earlier era and those killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. A12 Pelosi Becomes a Target Some optimistic Democratic lawmakers, hoping to win a Congressional majority in November, have taken to referring to Representative Nancy Pelosi as ''speaker,'' as in speaker of the House. So have some optimistic Republicans. A1 New Scrutiny of Lawmaker Testimony in the trial of David H. Safavian, left, a former White House budget aide accused of lying about his contacts with the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, is expected to result in new scrutiny of Representative Bob Ney, an Ohio Republican caught up in the scandal. A15 Church Leaders Offer Amends Cardinal Sean P. O'Malley is leading a nine-day series of Masses and services to acknowledge sexual abuse by clergy members in the Archdiocese of Boston and to pray for forgiveness and healing. A14 Possible Return to the C.I.A. With Porter J. Gross being forced out as the C.I.A.'s director, Stephen R. Kappes is poised to become deputy director under Gen. Michael V. Hayden, making him the first person since 1973 to ascend to one of the agency's top two positions from a career spent in the clandestine service. A17 EDUCATION No Diploma, No Problem Many colleges are accepting students who have not graduated from high school or earned equivalency degrees. And it's fueling a debate over whether the students should be in college at all and whether state financial aid should pay their way. A1 OBITUARIES C11 George Field The guiding spirit of Freedom House, an organization dedicated to democracy and human rights, he was 101. C11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 9/11 Collectors Search For Permanent Archives Steven Rosenbaum, left, is one of the many collectors of 9/11 materials struggling with financing and the need to find a permanent home for their collections and electronic archives. B1 Sailors Take Shore Leave The Navy men and women who visited New York for Memorial Day experienced a very different, lower decibel shore leave than the one experienced by the thousands of sailors who have come before them over the decades. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Mice Ignore Mendel's Laws A perplexing strain of brown laboratory mice have white feet and white-spotted tails because of a genetic defect engineered into a gene that controls pigmentation, a gene that ignores Mendelian laws of inheritance, a group of researchers report. F3 Twin Births Tied to Dairy American women who eat dairy products appear to be five times as likely to give birth to fraternal twins than those who do not, according to a new study, and one explanation may be dairy products from cows injected with synthetic growth hormone. F7 Health & Fitness F5 ARTS E1-8 Treasure Stolen in Turkey Objects from the treasure of King Croesus, a collection that the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York returned to Turkey in 1993 after a legal battle, have been stolen from the Archeological Museum in Usak, Turkish authorities say. E3 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Deal to Buy Kinder Morgan A group of managers led by Richard D. Kinder announced a $22 billion private offer to buy Kinder Morgan Inc., the pipeline giant that he founded in 1997. The deal would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. bought RJR Nabisco in 1989 for $25 billion. C1 Travelers Cut Back on Spending As the summer travel season began, Americans were jamming highways and filling airports. But in some small ways, with possibly large consequences, many travelers said they were cutting their spending. A1 Hispanics New Phone Target Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Block the vote; energy shortage; industry's role in hypertension; a violent detour in Turkey. Columns: John Tierney; Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E2 TV Listings E8 Weather D8

headline: Sharp Reaction To G.O.P. Plan On Gas Rebate
summary: The Senate Republican plan to mail $100 checks to voters to ease the burden of high gasoline prices is eliciting more scorn than gratitude from the very people it was intended to help. Aides for several Republican senators reported a surge of calls and e-mail messages from constituents ridiculing the rebate as a paltry and transparent effort to pander to voters before the midterm elections in November.

headline: Balancing Act By Democrats At Hearing
summary: Early in the Judiciary Committee's domestic spying hearings, Senator Edward M. Kennedy warned Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Monday that the ''toughest, meanest and cruelest members of Al Qaeda'' could escape prosecution, at great risk to national security, if eavesdropping evidence were to be found inadmissible in court. ''If we don't get it right,'' Mr. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, declared, ''we're going to find that we have paid a very harsh price.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: In Sweeping Deal With Union, G.M. Offers Buyout Packages to Workers General Motors reached a landmark agreement with the United Automobile Workers intended to sharply reduce the ranks of an entire generation of autoworkers long envied by other blue-collar workers for their rich wages and benefits. G.M. said it would offer buyouts and early retirement packages -- ranging from $35,000 to $140,000 -- to every one of its 113,000 unionized workers in the United States who agrees to leave the company. [Page A1.] For G.M. workers who once thought they were set for life, the buyouts may well represent the first real gamble of their careers: Do they stay with G.M. and hope for a turnaround or take the money and run? [C4.] China Seeks to Win Over Visiting Senators China is responding with respectful attention to the visit of two United States senators who have attacked the country for its economic policies. The reason seems clear: At a time of rising economic nationalism in the United States, China fears that a bill drafted by the senators to impose a 27.5 percent tariff on Chinese exports to the United States has a chance to upend economic relations between the world's richest nation and its fastest-growing rival. [C1.] China announced plans to increase existing taxes and impose new ones for everything from gas-guzzling vehicles to chopsticks. [C6.] Ex-Enron Treasurer Contradicts Founder's Claims Ben F. Glisan Jr., Enron's former treasurer, delivered stinging testimony that refuted claims made by Kenneth L. Lay, the company's founder, that he was unaware of Enron's crumbling financial picture and did not know about some of the illicit side deals involving top managers. [C1.] Bertelsmann Results Strong Amid Talk of Public Offer Bertelsmann, the global media empire, reported upbeat financial results, propelled by pop-culture sensations like the singer Kelly Clarkson and Dan Brown's thriller, ''The Da Vinci Code.'' At the same time, senior executives turned away a barrage of questions about how the company would respond to a plan by a minority shareholder, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, to push for an initial public offering, possibly later this year. [C1.] Morgan Stanley Reports 17% Quarterly Profit Gain Morgan Stanley reported a 17 percent increase in first-quarter profit as the firm's increased focus on riskier trading strategies began to pay off. But the results, while surpassing expectations, showed continued weakness in the firm's retail and asset management businesses. [C3.] Microsoft Offers Technical Support to Rivals Microsoft offered to give rival software companies unlimited technical support to help them develop programs that work smoothly with the Windows operating system, the company's latest effort to comply with a European Commission order and avoid daily fines of up to 2 million euros. [C6.] Samsung Executives to Plead Guilty in Price-Fixing Case Three executives of Samsung, the Korean electronics company, have agreed to plead guilty and serve prison sentences in the United States for their roles in a price-fixing conspiracy, federal prosecutors said. [C11.] Study Finds Value in Multiple Depression Treatments Some people with depression who do not recover with an initial course of antidepressant therapy can increase their chances of finding relief by trying other drug treatments, researchers are reporting. The study is the most extensive ever of people undergoing multiple treatments for depression. [A20.] Dow Reaches Highest Level in Nearly 5 Years The Dow Jones industrial average rose 81.96 points, to 11,317.43, its highest level in almost five years, as the outlook for corporate earnings improved. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 7.81 points, to 1,305.04. The Nasdaq composite index gained 9.12 points, or 0.4 percent, to 2303.35. [C11.] Interpublic Group Posts Fourth-Quarter Loss The Interpublic group of advertising companies, struggling since 2002 with financial and operational problems, posted a loss for the fourth quarter and restated results for the first three quarters of 2005, which reduced revenue by $14.1 million. It also disclosed that its controller and chief accounting officer, Nicholas S. Cyprus, would leave after less than two years. But an optimistic note from the chief executive, along with the news that an Interpublic media agency, Initiative, had won an assignment from CBS, seemed to resonate with investors more than a recitation of the company's latest woes. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.] KPMG Revises Settlement With Shelter Investors KPMG said that it had reached a revised settlement with tax shelter investors, but warned that the reduced agreement could still fall apart. [C3.] British Broadcaster Says It Opposes a Buyout Plan ITV, the biggest commercial broadcaster in Britain, said that it had rejected an approach from a group of buyout firms, under which a former head of the BBC would take over as ITV's chief executive. [C12.] Fearing F.C.C. Reaction, WB Censors New Drama Concerned about the recent decision by the Federal Communications Commission to fine television networks for material deemed indecent, the WB network will broadcast a new drama next week, ''The Bedford Diaries,'' that it has censored over the objections of the program's creator. [E1.]

headline: Third-and-Ready?
summary: Giants quarterback Eli Manning operates in a haze of optimism. He is not yet everything he was hoped to be when he was selected with the first choice in the 2004 N.F.L. draft, but it is generally believed that he still can be. He remains protected by promise. Maybe there would be more doubt if his name were Eli Leaf. Or if he had not shown marked improvement after his rookie season, when he looked an awful lot like the next Heath Shuler. Or if the Giants had not won a division title in 2005, even as Manning completed barely half of his passes and saw his performance dip late in the season.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Court Charges Hussein With Genocide of Kurds The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced that it had charged him with genocide, saying he had sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages. A1 Syria Silences Opposition Syrian officials, despite indications that they would consider limiting the ruling Baath Party's power, are aggressively silencing domestic political opposition while accommodating religious conservatives to shore up support across the country. A1 Thai Leader Will Resign Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said he would step down, ending five years of tumultuous rule and breaking a political stalemate over demands for his resignation. A3 French Premier Defies Protests Waves of demonstrations struck France again as Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin refused to bend to the demand that the government scrap a disputed youth labor law. A8 Ex-Spy in I.R.A Found Dead Denis Donaldson, a former member of the Irish Republican Army who was exposed as a British spy last year, was found shot dead at his home. A3 SCIENCE/HEALTH U.S. AIDS Policy Is Criticized An insistence by Republican Congressional leaders that American money to fight the spread of AIDS globally be used to emphasize abstinence and fidelity is undercutting more comprehensive aid models, the General Accountability Office said. A9 NATIONAL A12-20 Massachusetts Approves Universal Health Care Bill Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the State Legislature that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign. A1 Treasury Chief May Step Down Treasury Secretary John W. Snow is reported to be considering resigning from his position amid speculation in Washington that the White House is seeking a replacement. A12 DeLay's Ex-Aides Investigated Lawmakers and others said Representative Tom DeLay's decision to resign his House seat came as federal prosecutors continued to investigate the aides who once made up his inner circle. A15 Mr. DeLay's surprise resignation threw Texas state politics into turmoil, with the prospect of an electoral free-for-all in coming months. A15 Justices Opposed to Cameras At a Congressional hearing to discuss the Supreme Court's budget, Justices Clarence Thomas and Anthony M. Kennedy came out strongly in opposition to a request by lawmakers that the court televise its proceedings. A16 Officials Criticize Red Cross International Red Cross officials who were dispatched to help in the United States said the American Red Cross's response to Hurricane Katrina was poorly planned, relied too heavily on inexperienced managers and often failed to meet the needs of victims. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 A Nightly Family Ritual Makes a Comeback A nationwide study by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University found a recent rise in the number of teenagers who said they ate dinner with their families at least five times a week. The increase follows decades of decline in the ritual. A1 New Details in Homicide Police officials investigating the stabbing death of Andrew M. Kissel, a Connecticut real estate developer who had been charged with fraud, have found no signs of robbery or forced entry in the house where his body was discovered, leading the authorities to conclude that Mr. Kissel was the ''intentional target.'' B1 Backing for Stadium Station Governor Pataki and Mayor Bloomberg have called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to devise a plan for a new Metro-North Railroad station adjacent to the proposed site of a new Yankee Stadium. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-8 Terrapins Win Championship Maryland beat Duke, 78-75, in overtime to win their first N.C.A.A. women's basketball championship. D1 ARTS E1-10 NBC Courts Next Co-Host As CBS nears a deal to make Katie Couric the next anchor of its evening news program, NBC has nearly concluded an agreement with Meredith Vieira of ABC to replace Ms. Couric as co-host of the ''Today'' show, said a person who has been briefed on the negotiations. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Tax Cuts Help the Rich An analysis of Internal Revenue Service data found that President Bush's tax cuts for investment income reduced the bills of taxpayers with incomes greater than $10 million by an average of $500,000 in 2003. A1 Wal-Mart Helps Competitors Wal-Mart Stores, whose all-in-one retailing model has forced scores of competitors to close their doors over the last 40 years, is turning to an unusual business plan: helping them. C1 Old Testimony at Enron Trial As Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, moves to the witness stand as soon as today, he will have to be prepared to confront his own past testimony. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials:The amnesty trap; the fall of the Hammer; no hands on deck; dark days for Philippine democracy. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E8 Obituaries A21 TV Listings E10 Weather D7

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: OFFER FOR KINDER MORGAN -- A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997. The deal, which includes the assumption of about $8 billion in debt, would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company bought RJR Nabisco in 1989 for $25 billion. [Page C1.] TWO IN NEWS CREW KILLED -- Two Britons working as members of a CBS News television crew were killed on Monday and an American correspondent for the network, Kimberly Dozier, was critically wounded when a military patrol they were accompanying was hit by a roadside bomb. [A1.] THE BATTLE FOR AIR -- Americans are increasingly recognizing that the effects of carbon emissions on global warming are a serious problem, but there are no rules in the United States regulating heat-trapping gases comparable to those that most other developed countries have adopted under the Kyoto Protocol. Some United States businesses, though, are responding for a variety of reasons anyway: to satisfy customers or shareholders who worry about the environment, to improve their public image or to drive down their energy costs. In addition, some states and local authorities have stepped in to try to curb their contributions to global warming. [C1.] A STEEL WAR -- When it came to repelling a hostile takeover bid from Mittal Steel, Arcelor left no stone unturned as it searched for a poison-pill partner. But some critics say that the solution -- a deal that gives more than a third of Arcelor to a Russian billionaire, Aleksei Mordashov, left, may leave a bitter aftertaste. If it is approved by the shareholders, the agreement will put Russian executives in crucial management positions at Arcelor, raising questions about integration between the two corporate cultures, and concerns among some shareholders about what role the Russian government may want to play. [C3.] HISPANIC CALLERS -- Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics. And there is ample reason for the carriers' attention. One of the country's fastest growing demographic groups, Hispanics often have large families that span international borders, making for larger phone bills. [C1.] THAT 60'S SHOW -- AMC cable television network is considering a series that would explore how Madison Avenue remakes itself to meet the changing needs of clients as consumers and the media undergo transformation. So the show would be a reality series, right? Not exactly. It is fictional, a drama about the advertising industry circa 1960. In another example of how the more things change the more they remain the same, if AMC decides to pick up the series, each episode may be sponsored by a single advertiser -- just as was done in 1960. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C7.] A SUMMER OF HIGH GAS PRICES -- As the summer travel season began in earnest this past weekend, Americans were indulging their wanderlust, jamming highways, and filling airports, motels and eateries. But in some small ways, with possibly large consequences for the health of the economy, travelers interviewed across the country over the weekend said they were cutting their spending and downsizing their plans for summer trips. [A1.] A MOVE IN EUROPE -- When BAE Systems, the British military contractor, announced that it was bowing out of its nearly 30-year relationship with Airbus, the split was greeted in Britain with shock at first, followed by recognition that the companies had grown apart. BAE's departure now could be transformational not only for it, but also for Airbus, whose ownership -- and decision-making -- structure is evolving. [C4.] BRIGHT SPOT FOR G.M. -- Four years ago, Daewoo Motor was the biggest and ugliest addition to South Korea's junkyard of bankrupt companies. Its parent conglomerate had collapsed, and most potential investors were intimidated by its militant labor union. Its founder, Kim Woo Choong, left, is on trial on corruption charges linked to the disintegration of his conglomerate in 1998. But Mr. Kim is gone, and Daewoo has become a bright spot for G.M. [C4.] AIRLINE APOLOGIZES -- WestJet Airlines agreed on Monday to pay 15.5 million Canadian dollars ($14 million) to settle accusations of spying on an internal Web site of its rival, Air Canada. The settlement, which came with an apology, brought to an end two years of litigation. [C9.] THE OPEC MEETING -- Most delegates at this week's meeting of OPEC are expected to nod politely to Venezuela's calls for output cuts that could drive prices even higher, while doing the opposite by reaping all they can from the current bonanza of high prices. The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates rejected talk of a possible cut in the cartel's output quotas of 28 million barrels a day. [C1.] A SOFTWARE BATTLE IN CHINA -- Responding to years of intensive international lobbying, the Chinese government has introduced measures offering the potential to curb widespread piracy and increase revenue for software companies. The Business Software Alliance estimates that more than 90 percent of the software in China is unlicensed. [C3.] A NEW TAX COMPLAINT -- In an effort to raise revenues, tax writers in Congress added a last-minute provision that increased taxes for Americans living abroad. But the sudden imposition of taxes has surprised overseas taxpayers, and it has employers concerned about the added cost. [C3.] PAYING WITH ATTENTION -- With the cost of mobile phone calls already dropping sharply, Virgin Mobile USA plans to announce a way that people can talk for no money at all. They will, however, have to pay with a chunk of their attention. [C4.] FROG POWER -- A tribal cure in Brazil, derived from the secretions of a poisonous tree frog, raises hope of a wonder drug that might benefit the country's indigenous people as well as its drug industry [C1.] GLOBAL SECURITY -- In an increasingly global economy, more business travelers find themselves visiting places that, if not as obviously dangerous as Baghdad or Kabul, are unfamiliar and possibly treacherous. And a number of risk management and security firms are providing services to help them, and say their business is growing. [C8.]

headline: New Twist to Draft: A Second Network
summary: For 26 years, ESPN had the N.F.L. draft to itself, carrying what was once deemed a nonevent, a silly, talking-heads endeavor and the sports equivalent of a political convention. But a devoted, growing viewership long ago overcame the criticism. And still, somehow, the state of the draft expert Mel Kiper Jr.'s pompadour remains relevant. ''If any event typifies how far we've come as a company, it's the N.F.L. draft,'' John Wildhack, an ESPN senior vice president, said earlier this week.

headline: A Long Island City Awakening
summary: Midtown Manhattan is closer to Long Island City than it is to downtown Manhattan, and the transportation links are excellent. All this has made the area particularly attractive to deep-pocketed developers of residential projects, like Rockrose and AvalonBay, and they and other builders have a number of projects under way to house people who cannot afford Manhattan prices or decline to pay them. As a result, the prospective influx of people to what had been an industrial area seems likely to attract retailers and other service companies. But will office developers and business tenants be attracted to what has long been designated as New York City's fourth central business district, after Midtown, downtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn?

headline: One Draft Guru Outshines ESPN
summary: Remember this name: Mike Mayock. On Saturday, faced with better-known and certainly higher-paid analysts at ESPN during the National Football League draft, Mayock, the NFL Network's draft guru, lapped them all. A former Giants defensive back and college football analyst for ABC, CBS, ESPN and Fox Sports Net, Mayock used superior insight to catapult himself beyond any voice at ESPN, which has carried the draft for 26 years.

headline: On the Cover
summary: ''LOVE MONKEY,'' a CBS comedy-drama starring Tom Cavanagh, could make a classic case study in how a television show evolves from initial concept to ready-for-prime-time. For one thing, between the first pitch and the pilot episode, the show's main character, Tom Farrell, underwent a career change, and that gave the series a whole different defining element: music. Michael Rauch, the show's creator, said that the series was inspired by Kyle Smith's novel about the dating foibles of a New York thirtysomething and that its protagonist initially was, as in the book, a tabloid journalist. Somewhere along the line, though, somebody suggested that a different career would make for livelier television, and Farrell became a record industry A&R scout -- for ''artist and repertory,'' the guy who looks in clubs and concert halls for music's next big thing. Mr. Rauch said that, having spent a lot of time with a friend who was in the music business, he had no trouble seeing the possibilities.

headline: Big Climbs, Slippery Slopes
summary: Try as he might to block them out, tight end Doug Jolley was bowled over a few times during his stint last year with the Jets by memories of another season that began with high hopes for a championship and ended in disappointment. Jolley was a rookie with Oakland in the 2002 season when the Raiders won the American Football Conference title and then were soundly beaten by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl XXXVII. The Raiders returned virtually intact for another title run in 2003, only to limp to a 4-12 record.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: 'Survivor' Winner in Protective Custody Richard Hatch, below, who won $1 million in the inaugural ''Survivor'' competition on CBS only to be found guilty in January of failing to pay taxes on his prize and other income, is being held in protective custody pending sentencing on April 25, The Associated Press reported. His lawyer, Michael Mimms, said Mr. Hatch, 45, asked to be placed in protective custody at a jail in Plymouth, Mass., and Charles Wyant, a deputy United States marshal, said the request had been granted because Mr. Hatch is a celebrity. ''The situation he's in is the best possible position for him to be in at this point in time, the safest and most secure,'' Mr. Wyant said. Mr. Hatch was put in custody immediately after he was found guilty of tax evasion because Federal District Court Judge Ernest Torres said he posed a flight risk. Indonesian Muslims Protest Playboy Hurling stones, shattering windows and tearing up magazines, hundreds of Muslims attacked the offices of Playboy in Jakarta, Indonesia, yesterday after the magazine was published in the country for the first time, Agence France-Presse reported. About 300 members of the Islamic Defenders' Front massed outside the building to demand that the local version of Playboy, which does not publish nude photographs, cease publication. One of approximately 90 police officers guarding the building was injured, but most of the magazine's employees had left when the demonstration took place. Salim Al Hamid, a leader of the group, told Radio Elshinta, ''We will carry out more attacks if Playboy refuses to stop publishing.'' The Indonesian edition of the magazine was quickly sold out when it appeared on Friday, and copies later changed hands at more than three times the cover price, $4.33. It features pictures of women in underwear but is regarded as no racier than Indonesian editions of the men's magazines FHM and Maxim. Muslims make up about 88 percent of Indonesia's population of 220 million. Crime Takes a Holiday It's Easter in Norway, and crime is booming. As Norwegians rush off to their mountain cabins for a final feast of skiing before the snow melts, they take with them a supply of mysteries, Reuters reported, and in keeping with a tradition known as Easter Crime, television and radio stations schedule thrillers back to back. ''People sit inside their cabins, watch crime on television and then read crime books at night,'' said Ane Farsethaas, a book reviewer. ''It's a very Norwegian thing to do.'' The bookshop chain Tanum estimates that sales of crime books soar about 500 percent in the week leading to Easter, and this week, its top 10 best-sellers are all crime novels, led by the Swedish writer Stieg Larsson's ''Men Who Hate Women.'' No one seems to know how the Easter Crime tradition began, although the ancient Norsemen who returned from raids on the British Isles were fond of settling down with flasks of mead and recounting tales of murder and pillage to their women and children. Footnotes The bad-boy rocker Pete Doherty didn't keep his date to appear in a London court yesterday for a review of his progress in drug rehabilitation, The Associated Press reported. Told that he had been unable to return from Paris after a performance by his group, Babyshambles, Thames Magistrates' Court adjourned the case until May 12. He is to appear in the same court in a separate drug case next Thursday. The Australian pop star Kylie Minogue, below, has been invited to headline the 2007 Glastonbury Festival, a highlight of the British summer music calendar, The Associated Press reported. In London for the premiere of ''Glastonbury,'' a documentary about the festival's 35 years, Michael Eavis, a working farmer who stages the event in his fields, said: ''Kylie is coming back, hopefully. Her people are quite confident; she wants to do it.'' Last year, she canceled her performance after learning she had breast cancer. No festival will be held this year, to allow Mr. Eavis's cows to graze without interruption. A film school named for the great Japanese director Akira Kurosawa (''Rashomon,'' ''The Seven Samurai,'' ''Yojimbo'') has been established in Tokyo by his son, Hisao Kurosawa, and an associate, Tatsuya Nakadai, an actor long linked with the filmmaker, The Associated Press reported. Beginning in September, the two-year school will hold classes for 30 aspiring actors and 80 students of production. The perennial question of the authorship William Shakespeare's plays will be explored once more in an exhibition beginning in November at Shakespeare's Globe Theater in London. The roundup of suspects like Francis Bacon, Edward de Vere and Henry Neville will include an examination of their lives, schooling, careers and opportunities and a look at what some see as clues hidden within the plays.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 North Korea Announces Test of Nuclear Weapon North Korea said that it had set off its first nuclear test -- just two days after the country was warned by the United Nations Security Council that the action could lead to severe consequences. American officials cautioned that they had not yet received any confirmation that the test had occurred. A1 The North Korea nuclear test amounted to a major failure for China, which mounted one of its most extensive diplomatic efforts in years to find a negotiated solution to the North Korean nuclear crisis. The Chinese expressed their anger in unusually strong terms, saying the test was ''flagrant and brazen.'' A6 Tsunami Project Stalled Construction of a road in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, meant as a good-will gesture from the American people to the survivors of the 2004 tsunami, has met with difficulty. Because of long negotiations to acquire right of way through residential and farm land, and through several hundred graves of religious significance, the project has not even started. A8 Hints at Need for Iraq Change James A. Baker III, the Republican co-chairman of a panel reassessing Iraq strategy for President Bush, said he expected that the panel would depart from Mr. Bush's repeated calls to ''stay the course,'' and he strongly suggested that the White House enter direct talks with countries it has so far kept at arms length, including Iran and Syria. A1 American and Iraqi troops fought a fierce battle with militants in the city of Diwaniya, a stronghold of militia members loyal to radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, the American military said. The skirmish was the third serious clash between American or Iraqi soldiers against members of the Mahdi Army in Diwaniya in less than two months. A8 Japan and China Mend Fences China and Japan said they had made progress addressing their historical animosities and territorial differences as Shinzo Abe, the new Japanese prime minister, made his first trip to mend ties with Asian neighbors. President Hu Jintao of China, left, called Mr. Abe's visit a turning point for two Asian powers whose relations had sharply declined. A3 Iran Opposition Cleric Seized Ayatollah Mohammad Kazemeni Boroujerdi, a senior cleric who opposes clerical rule of Iran, was arrested after clashes with Iranian police officers, news agencies reported. The reports quoted officials as saying that some of the cleric's supporters were armed with knives and daggers and that the police used tear gas to disperse them. A3 Transponder Not Recalled The electronic device for broadcasting a plane's identity and altitude carried by the business jet that apparently collided with a Boeing 737 over the Amazon was not one of the potentially faulty ones ordered repaired by American safety officials, the manufacturer said. A9 NATIONAL A10-15 Religious Employers Enjoy Legal Shield From Lawsuits Legislators, judges and regulators have carved out or preserved safe havens that shield religious employers of all faiths from most employee lawsuits, from laws protecting pensions and providing unemployment benefits, and from laws that give employees the right to form unions to negotiate with their employers. A1 Virginia Republicans Resolute In dozens of interviews in southeastern Virginia, a swing state in tight races for the House and Senate, many conservative Christians said that rather than discourage them from going to the polls, the scandal surrounding Representative Mark Foley only reinforced their reasons to vote for their Republican incumbents. A1 For all the contradictions and inconsistencies in the tale of Mark Foley, the investigation into how Republicans handled concerns about his conduct may hinge on what transpired in a private meeting that was convened in his office last year. A12 Races Hinge on Local Economy Michigan's political races for governor and the Senate are hinging nearly entirely on the struggling economy and the question of who is to blame for it. And in other Rust Belt states, including Ohio, Indiana and Pennsylvania, economic worries are playing a similar role, if a far more subtle one. A10 Lawyer's Book Causes Trouble Joyce Dudley, a deputy district attorney in Santa Barbara, published a crime novel. The novel concerns a rape case with echoes of a real one. An appeals court in Ventura, Calif., ruled that Ms. Dudley's novel had crossed an ethical line, and removed her from the case. A10 Fight Over National Park Hunt Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California, is fighting to preserve an agreement by the National Park Service to close 45,000 acres of parkland on Santa Rosa Island, Calif., to the public for hunting, August through December. A15 Lettuce Recalled for E. Coli Less than a week after the Food and Drug Administration lifted its warning on fresh spinach grown in the Salinas Valley, a popular brand of lettuce grown there was recalled over concerns about E. coli contamination. The lettuce does not appear to have caused any illnesses, the president of the grower said. A10 Senator's Finances Questioned For the past five years, Senator George Allen, Republican of Virginia, has failed to tell Congress about stock options he received for his work as a director of a high-tech company. Congressional rules require senators to disclose all deferred compensation, like stock options. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Despite Criticism at Home, Giuliani Retains Support Rudolph W. Giuliani, former mayor of New York, is scheduled to make his first public appearance in two years in New Hampshire. Yet as Mr. Giuliani traverses the country, polls show he has emerged as a leading candidate for the Republican presidential primaries -- largely because of how he guided a wounded city in the weeks after 9/11. headline: A Race That Could Tip the Balance
summary: GLORIA DOOGAN walked out of the dentist's office one recent afternoon with a wince on her face, and it had nothing to do with the tooth she had just had extracted. Mrs. Doogan, 74, a fairly reliable Republican in a town where registered Republicans outnumber Democrats, had just been asked about the United States Senate race in which New Jersey voters have been bombarded with vitriolic television commercials. Her painful expression spoke volumes about how she and many voters feel about the matchup between Senator Robert Menendez and State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., one of the nation's most fiercely contested races and one whose outcome could tip the balance of power in Washington.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: EXECUTIVE PAY Defenders of executive pay packages have contended that because most are tied to company performance, they are both earned and deserved. But as some examples show, investors often find that compensation exceeds the amounts allowed under directors' performance targets. [Page A1.] JOB CUTS AT SUN Sun Microsystems, the struggling network computer maker, announced that it planned to cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the next six months as it tries to return to profitability. The cuts will reduce Sun's work force by 11 percent to 13 percent. [C1.] STREET CREDIBILITY Henry M. Paulson Jr. is almost certain to win easy Senate approval as Treasury secretary and become a central player on President Bush's team. But analysts say he and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, need to establish their credibility in financial markets. [C1.] VENEZUELA'S PROSPECTS President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela will be the host for an OPEC meeting at which he can be expected to point up his country's vast oil potential. [C1.] ABOUT-FACE AT SAKS Of all the changes at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label. Now, Saks's chief executive is introducing a replacement. [C1.] BRITISH INVASION British news media are entering the American market or seeking to raise their profile here. In the latest example, a campaign will introduce Americans to BBC World News, a 24-hour cable news network. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MINORITIES AND MORTGAGES Black and Hispanic home buyers entering the fast-growing market for subprime mortgages tend to pay higher interest rates than whites with similar credit ratings, a statistical study by an advocacy group says. [A22.] STOCKS RALLY Stocks closed higher, buoyed by the first drop in oil prices in a week and by signs that the tension with Iran over its nuclear program might ease. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 73.88 points, to close at 11,168.31. [C11.] HEALTH CARE SHORTFALLS Employers and consumers are paying a billion dollars more a year for medical care to compensate for shortfalls in the nation's health care system resulting from tight Medicare and Medicaid budgets, according to Blue Cross officials and actuaries. [C3.] ENRON VERDICTS A federal jury in Houston convicted one of two former executives of Enron's broadband unit in connection with an $111 million accounting fraud. The second executive was acquitted. [C3.] DELTA CONCESSIONS APPROVED A bankruptcy judge approved the $280 million-a-year concessions agreement between Delta Air Lines and its pilots, hours after the pilots gave their approval. [C4.] MIDWESTERN GROWTH A survey showed Midwestern business expanded in May at its fastest rate in seven months, surging at a time when many economists had been expecting slower growth. [C5.] PAY UP Vonage, the Internet telephone provider, said it might seek reimbursement from customers who fail to pay for shares they committed to buy during the company's disappointing initial public offering. [C11.] COURIC'S SEND-OFF NBC pulled out all the stops on Katie Couric's last morning as a co-anchor of ''Today.'' She is moving to CBS to become the first female solo anchor of a network evening news program. [E1.] VILLAGE VOICE EDITOR The Village Voice announced the appointment of Erik Wemple, editor of Washington City Paper, as editor in chief. [E1.] MICROSOFT DEFENDS SPENDING Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, left, defended his decision to increase spending next year and signaled that he was unlikely to increase the company's share buyback plan. [C11.] DEMAND FOR ARCELOR VOTE Some Arcelor shareholders, upset at the steel giant's deal to sell a stake to the chief executive of Severstal of Russia, demanded that the company hold an emergency shareholders meeting to vote on the deal. [C6.] FRENCH REACTION When United Breweries, the world's third-largest spirits company, said it had withdrawn from the bidding for the French Champagne maker Taittinger, it cited a local reaction to its Indian roots. [C6.] ONLINE TABLEWARE OR LEADING INDICATOR? A boom in gold and silver may be a sign that the U.S. is finally going to pay for years of easy money, mounting debt and trillion-dollar budget deficits. A column by David Leonhardt is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. TIFFANY & COMPANY, the jewelry retailer, said first-quarter earnings rose 7.7 percent -- to $43.1 million from $40.1 million -- on the strength of international sales.
