headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (NBC) CONVICTION -- Dick Wolf, creator of the ''Law & Order'' empire, introduces a drama series about glamorous young lawyers in the district attorney's office. In the premiere episode, a drug dealer cuts open a woman's abdomen to retrieve the drugs she smuggled for him; one inexperienced lawyer on her first trial cleverly leaves the evidence unguarded; and another blithely tells a stranger where his boss is having dinner, information that leads to a fatal shooting. That's Stephanie March (above) as Alexandra Cabot, a character who has transferred here from ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.'' 8 P.M. (Encore) ANNIE HALL (1977). Woody Allen's best-picture Oscar winner stars Mr. Allen as Alvy Singer, the quintessential New York neurotic, and Diane Keaton as the eccentrically dressed, adorably ditsy Midwestern young woman that he loves. The film took home three more Oscars -- for best director, actress and screenplay (Mr. Allen and Marshall Brickman). 8 P.M. (5) N.A.A.C.P. IMAGE AWARDS -- ''Crash,'' the drama about race relations in Los Angeles, is the movie with the most nominations. ''Grey's Anatomy,'' ''Everybody Hates Chris'' and ''The Bernie Mac Show'' are among the nominated television series. The show also honors achievement in music (Carlos Santana, above, will be inducted into the hall of fame) and literature. Cuba Gooding Jr. is host. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAS VEGAS -- A woman finds a finger in the casino's new buffet. But there's a chance, as in a similar real-life case, that it was planted. And rather than suing the casino, the woman makes another, more personal demand. It involves Danny (Josh Duhamel). 10 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Adrian Monk, the obsessive-compulsive detective, suspects an astronaut of murder. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS -- An antiwar-protest bombing looks like the work of a 1970's activist who went underground (or at least dropped out of sight) roughly 30 years ago. 10 P.M. (Sundance) IN SHORT: ACADEMY AWARD-WINNING SHORTS -- Five of them. ''The Wrong Trousers'' and ''A Close Shave'' are Wallace and Gromit animated films from Nick Park (shown at Cannes with a statue of Gromit). ''Ryan'' is Chris Landreth's portrait of an artist turned panhandler. ''Wasp'' is about a working-class British single mother of four. And ''Harvie Krumpet'' is about a home-schooled Polish boy with Tourette's syndrome. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- Jo Frost (left), the amazing British nanny who has turned devil children into angels, is back -- and none too soon for her client of the week. Cheryl Carsley is a divorced mother of five (ages 4 to 7), including two sets of twins. While she recovers from a difficult divorce and trains for a teaching career, her children repeatedly hit her and scream at her. 9 P.M. (ABC Family) BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE -- Season premiere. In the first season, Lynn Kerr (Daphne Zuniga) moved to New York with her two daughters. Sophie (Sarah Foret) had a scholarship to a prestigious private school. And Karen (Torrey DeVitto) was an aspiring model. Now the girls' father (Grant Show, Ms. Zuniga's old ''Melrose Place'' costar) enters the picture. He wants custody of Sophie. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Young Jake (Angus T. Jones) is having a birthday party. His father, Alan (Jon Cryer), doesn't want his sexy 22-year-old girlfriend to attend. Of course, the fact that Alan has a sexy 22-year-old girlfriend negates the whole premise of the series. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) DOUBLE CROSS -- Two desperate housewives (Yancy Butler, right, and Barbara Niven) jokingly agree to murder each other's husbands. But maybe one of them isn't kidding. Farley Granger could have predicted that. (See ''Strangers on a Train,'' Alfred Hitchcock, 1951.) 9 P.M. (NBC) THE APPRENTICE -- Task No. 2 for Donald Trump's would-be protégés: Get New Yorkers to do a lot of textmessaging on their cellphones. 10 P.M. (ABC) MIRACLE WORKERS -- Series premiere. A 34-year-old man who has been blind since childhood may see again, thanks to stem-cell treatment. And a 47-year-old woman with degenerative bone and joint disease may be able to kiss her wheelchair and walker goodbye, after cutting-edge spinal surgery. Maybe medicine shouldn't descend to the makeover genre, but these are life-changing opportunities for the lucky few. 2 A.M. (FX) HURLYBURLY -- (1998). It's far too late to see the original Broadway production of David Rabe's play about misanthropes in Hollywood. Or the New Group's highly praised 2005 revival with Ethan Hawke. But the film version, with (above, from left) Kevin Spacey, Anna Paquin and Sean Penn, lives on. Just try to ignore Meg Ryan, trying her best to look damaged. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) DARK KINGDOM: THE DRAGON KING -- It's Wagner's ''Ring Cycle'' without the singing. It's ''The Lord of the Rings'' without the hobbits. This two-part television movie tells the epic story of a young blacksmith, Siegfried (Benno Fürmann, above right, with Max von Sydow as Eyvind), who slays a dragon (in this case an impressive computer-generated one) and falls in love with the Queen of Iceland (Kristanna Loken), an early supermodel type. Part 1 of 2. 8 P.M. (5) PRISON BREAK -- Michael Scofield (Wentworth Miller) spent the first season getting into Fox River State Penitentiary so he could help his brother, Lincoln Burrows (Dominic Purcell), an innocent man on death row, escape. But the breakout failed. This is Lincoln's execution day. The vice president (Patricia Wettig, formerly of ''Thirtysomething''), who may have gotten Lincoln where he is today, continues to be evil. 9 P.M. (13, 49) EUGENE O'NEILL -- This ''American Experience'' documentary from Ric Burns looks at the life and work of O'Neill (1888-1953), the Nobel Prize-winning playwright who was the author of ''The Iceman Cometh,'' ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' and ''A Moon for the Misbegotten.'' (The photograph above was taken in 1936.) Al Pacino, Jason Robards, Liam Neeson, Christopher Plummer, Tony Kushner, John Guare and Zoe Caldwell comment or perform. 9 P.M. (5) 24 -- ''Day 5: 9 P.M.-10 P.M.'' The terrorists decide to add a few hundred thousand civilians to their hit list. Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland), counterterrorist hero, does the unthinkable. 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- Jo Frost's challenge tonight is the Young family. The 13-year-old boy is fine, but his 5-year-old brother and 3-year-old sister are literally climbing the walls. 9 P.M. (History) DIGGING FOR THE TRUTH -- While the world waits for the British judge's decision in Dan Brown and Random House U.K.'s ''Da Vinci Code'' trial (the authors of ''Holy Blood, Holy Grail'' are suing because, they say, Mr. Brown stole their concept: that Jesus married Mary Magdalene, had children and now has descendants living in France), Josh Bernstein (above) does some DNA testing to try to determine if there is any truth to the books' premise. 9:30 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- ''One Toe Over the Line, Sweet Jesus.'' Matthew (Christine's brother) tells Richard (Christine's exhusband) that Christine (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) has a new boyfriend. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (11) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK -- Season finale. It's down to the last two deliberately mismatched couples. Brittany (right), who works at a tanning salon, is teamed with Joe, a speedchess champion who majored in philosophy. Cher, a beer spokesmodel and former Hooters waitress, is with Josh, a museum critic who suffers from panic attacks. They'll be tested to see how much they've learned. 7:30 P.M . (21) BARRY MANILOW: MUSIC AND PASSION -- Mr. Manilow's concert special seems to be all about oldies. He'll do ''I Write the Songs,'' ''Copacabana'' and ''Mandy,'' plus numbers from his new album, ''Manilow: Greatest Songs of the 50's.'' 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- ''I Like to Watch.'' Grissom (William Petersen) and the team are chosen to be part of a reality series. This means a camera crew follows them around while they try to solve the murder of an affluent real-estate agent found dead in her high-rise apartment. 9 P.M. (5) THE O.C. -- Life is hard for gorgeous young people in Orange County. Even though Johnny went off a cliff a few episodes ago, he's still pulling Ryan (Benjamin McKenzie) and Marissa (Mischa Barton) apart. First, Marissa had a thing for Johnny, as did her devious sister. Now Ryan is off on a road trip with Johnny's good-looking cousin Sadie (Nikki Reed, above, with Mr. McKenzie) to find Johnny's father. 9 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Years ago, Earl lost his father's beloved Mustang in a bet. Now he'll try to get it back. Beau Bridges guest stars as Earl's dad. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) THE DAY AFTER -- (1983). Jason Robards and JoBeth Williams star in this grim television film, endlessly analyzed at the time, about the aftermath of thermonuclear war in Kansas. 10 P.M. (NBC) ER -- After 11 seasons of walking around with that cane, Dr. Kerry Weaver (Laura Innes, right) finally thinks about hip-replacement surgery. 12:30 A.M. (IFC) MRS. PARKER AND THE VICIOUS CIRCLE -- (1994). Jennifer Jason Leigh plays Dorothy Parker. Campbell Scott is Robert Benchley, her dearest friend (his wife never seemed to mind), journalistic colleague and fellow Algonquin Round Table habitué. Witty people, miserable love lives, glamorous era: might as well watch. ANITA GATES

headline: TRANSACTIONS
summary: BASEBALL Major League Baseball MLB--Suspended Marcos Chavez and Jonathan Gonzalez of the St. Louis Cardinals' organization 50 games for violations of Major League Baseball's Venezuelan Summer League drug prevention and treatment program. American League KANSAS CITY ROYALS--Activated C Paul Bako from the DL. Optioned C Paul Phillips to Omaha of the PCL. MINNESOTA TWINS--Recalled RHP Boof Bonser from Rochester of the IL. Activated RHP Matt Guerrier from the 15-day DL. Optioned INF Terry Tiffee to Rochester. TEXAS RANGERS--Optioned RHP Scott Feldman to Oklahoma of the PCL. National League HOUSTON ASTROS--Activated OF Orlando Palmeiro from the bereavment list. Optioned INF Eric Bruntlett to Round Rock of the PCL. METS--Recalled LHP Royce Ring from Norfolk of the IL. Optioned RHP Mike Pelfrey to Norfolk. BASKETBALL National Basketball Association MINNESOTA TIMBERWOLVES--Re-signed F Justin Reed. SAN ANTONIO SPURS--Signed C Francisco Elson. FOOTBALL National Football League ARIZONA CARDINALS--Released TE Ben Hall. DALLAS COWBOYS--Signed S Roy Williams to a four-year contract extension through the 2010 season. Waived DE Vontrell Jamison. NEW ORLEANS SAINTS--Traded RB Michael Bennett to Kansas City for an undisclosed 2007 draft pick. ST. LOUIS RAMS--Signed RB Moe Williams to a one-year contract. SEATTLE SEAHAWKS--Signed TE Matt Murphy. Waived TE Matt Henshaw. TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS--Signed CB Ronde Barber to a five-year contract extension. HOCKEY National Hockey League ANAHEIM DUCKS--Signed D Brian Salcido to a three-year contract. CAROLINA HURRICANES--Signed RW Jesse Boulerice to a one-year contract. CHICAGO BLACKHAWKS--Acquired F Vaclav Pletka from the Philadelphia Flyers for F Eric Meloche. RANGERS--Agreed to terms with D Fedor Tyutin on a two-year contract. OTTAWA SENATORS--Signed F Dean McAmmond to a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH PENGUINS--Re-signed D Alain Nasreddine to a one-year contract. Signed D Alain Nasreddine and F Libor Pivko to one-year contracts. ST. LOUIS BLUES--Signed LW Martin Rucinsky. ECHL FLORIDA EVERBLADES--Signed D Chris Lee to a one-year contract. IDAHO STEELHEADS--Signed F Mark O'Leary and F Nathan Ward to one-year contracts. LONG BEACH ICE DOGS--Agreed to terms with C Alex Kim. READING ROYALS--Named Jeff Flanagan assistant coach. Central Hockey League YOUNGSTOWN STEELHEADS--Signed G Jeremy Symington. United Hockey League KALAMAZOO WINGS--Signed F Tyler Willis. MUSKEGON FURY--Signed LW Ryan Barnes. MOTORSPORTS CHAMP CAR WORLD SERIES--Placed driver Paul Tracy on probation for three races, forfeited seven championship points and fined him an undisclosed amount for an unjustifiable risk and unsportsmanlike behavior during last week's race. Fined driver Alex Tagliani an undisclosed amount for unsportmanslike behavior. Placed driver Katherine Legge on probation for three races for on-track misconduct. COLLEGE NCAA--Placed Northern Illinois on probation for one year for limited violations in women's basketball, mostly related to extra benefits given to a student-athlete by a faculty member. SKYLINE CONFERENCE--Announced Bard College and Polytechnic University have accepted invitations as full members for the 2007-08 academic year. AIR FORCE--Suspended PK Ryan Harrison indefinitely for an unspecified violation of school standards. BUTLER--Named Joel Cornette coordinator of men's basketball operations. CALIFORNIA, PA.--Named David Cole secondary and minority liaison coach and Shawn Rohrer, Lloyd Price and Nicolas LaFear assistant football coaches. COLGATE--Named Scott Lucas assistant strength & conditioning coach. DARTMOUTH--Named Glen Wilson assistant squash coach. FORDHAM--Named Dionne Dodson women's assistant basketball coach. INDIANA, PA.--Named Chris Fite and John Janovsky men's assistant basketball coaches and Cathy Hanek women's graduate assistant basketball coach. NORTH DAKOTA STATE--Named Leslie Kuhn women's graduate assistant volleyball coach. NORTH FLORIDA--Promoted Scott Schroeder to men's golf coach and Tom Strother to assistant athletics director for media relations. NOTRE DAME--Named Ryan Sachire men's assistant tennis coach. NYU--Named Jennifer Gardikas women's assistant volleyball coach, Warren Rand men's assistant tennis coach, and Ralph DeNisco and Corey Luce men's assistant wrestling coaches. RHODE ISLAND COLLEGE--Named Jack Holloran assistant sports information director. ROCHESTER--Named Dan Provenzano equipment manager. SALEM STATE--Announced the resignation of Bobby Mattin, swimming coach. SALVE REGINA--Named John Egan men's soccer coach and intramural director. SAM HOUSTON STATE--Announced the resignation of James ''Wooly'' Hatchell, women's basketball coach. SOUTHERN MAINE--Named Lori Towle women's tennis coach, Barry Tripp women's volleyball coach and John Lauziere women's ice hockey coach. WELLESLEY--Named Bridget Belgiovine athletic director, effective Sept. 1. WORCESTER STATE--Named Renee LaValley field hockey coach.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS -- Kirstie Alley (right), down 60 pounds from her ''Fat Actress'' days, guest-stars as Carrie's new real estate client. While Carrie (Leah Remini) is working hard, her husband (Kevin James) is secretly renting an apartment with his pals. But it's above a Chinese restaurant and just for innocent hanging out. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP -- Melissa Kraut, a happy Pennsylvania shopaholic who gives lingerie parties for a living, trades houses, families and everyday lives with Kathy Hardin, a deeply religious Tennessean who spends about $500 a year on clothes. And that's for herself, her husband and their eight children. Guess who gets to clean a chicken coop. 9 P.M. (13, 49) JESSE JAMES -- An ''American Experience'' documentary confirms that he was not a nice guy. For one thing, he had a habit of shooting unarmed men. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) FOR ONE NIGHT -- Raven Symone (left), the former ''Cosby Show'' cutie, stars in this television film about a small-town Louisiana high school that has always had two separate proms: one for white students and one for black. In 2002, somebody finally recognizes that as oldfashioned segregation. Aisha Tyler plays the hometown girl turned New Orleans journalist who makes a fuss. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- What happens when a psychic falls in the bathtub and suffers a concussion? Her visions change. Allison (Patricia Arquette) has just such an accident tonight. 4:40 A.M. (Cinemax) REDS -- (1981). Warren Beatty and Diane Keaton (below) star in this epic about the radical American journalist John Reed; his wife, Louise Bryant; and 10 days that shook the world: the Russian Revolution. The film won three Oscars (for Mr. Beatty's direction, Vittorio Storaro's cinematography and Maureen Stapleton's supporting performance as Emma Goldman) and was nominated for nine more. The Internationale never sounded so good. And so sad. ANITA GATES

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Reconstruction Audit Cites Further Fraud in Iraq A new audit of American financial practices in Iraq expands on previous findings of fraud, incompetence and confusion as the American occupation poured money into training and rebuilding programs in 2003 and 2004. A3 The court trying Saddam Hussein postponed the resumption of the trial, in an announcement that appeared to be related to behind-the-scenes conflict among the judges. A3 Israel Leader Backs Sharon Plan Ehud Olmert, in his first major policy address since becoming Israel's acting prime minister, said that he backed the creation of a Palestinian state, and that Israel would have to relinquish parts of the West Bank to maintain its Jewish majority. A12 Bombs Kill 8 in Southern Iran Two separate bombs exploded in Ahwaz, Iran, at a bank and a government building, leaving 8 people dead and 46 wounded, state-run news agencies reported. A6 6 Powers to Meet on Iran The foreign ministers of Britain, France, Germany, Russia and China and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will meet in London in an effort to resolve their differences on how best to punish Iran for its nuclear activities, three diplomats said. A6 No Proof of Secret Prisons Seen The Council of Europe's inquiry into allegations that the C.I.A. has operated secret detention centers in Eastern Europe has turned up no evidence that such centers ever existed, though the leader of the inquiry said the investigation would continue. A6 NATIONAL A14-19 Senate Panel Approves Supreme Court Nominee The Senate Judiciary Committee voted along party lines to approve the nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court, as senators turned the occasion into a debate over the rancorous and partisan nature of the confirmation process. A1 Katrina Papers Will Be Withheld The Bush administration, citing the traditional confidentiality of executive branch communications, does not plan to turn over certain important White House documents about Hurricane Katrina or make senior White House officials available for sworn testimony before Congressional committees investigating the federal response. A1 Gonzales Backs Eavesdropping Ramping up the administration's defense of its domestic eavesdropping program, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales invoked historic precedents in justifying President Bush's broad power to wage the fight against terrorism. A19 States to Get Drug Cost Refund The Bush administration said states would be fully reimbursed for any costs they incurred in paying claims for prescription drugs that should have been covered by the new federal Medicare program. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Doctors Seek Ban on Gifts The gifts that makers of pharmaceuticals and medical devices routinely give doctors undermine medical care and should be banned, a group of doctors assert in The Journal of the American Medical Association. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Incomes Trail Inflation Outside of Manhattan Incomes in all four of the boroughs outside Manhattan have trailed inflation over the last few years as the pay and purchasing power of Manhattan residents have grown. The pattern is an example of the increasing income disparity in New York City. A1 New Office to Monitor Abuse Mayor Bloomberg, in response to the death of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown, announced that retired law enforcement workers would be dispatched to work in child welfare offices and that he would create a new mayoral office to ensure that city agencies work together to prevent abuse. B1 Neediest Cases B5 EDUCATION B7 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-6 DINING OUT D1-10 OBITUARIES B8 ARTS E1-10 Witnesses Back Author Two men who say they attended a Minnesota drug and alcohol rehabilitation center with the author James Frey said they believed his overall description of his experience was accurate but said they could not corroborate many of the specifics in Mr. Frey's disputed book ''A Million Little Pieces.'' E6 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Tax Shelter Inquiry Widens Federal prosecutors are investigating three lawyers at a prominent Dallas law firm, Jenkens & Gilchrist, in a widening investigation into questionable shelters that shielded billions of dollars from taxes, according to people briefed on the inquiry. C1 CBS-Warner Bros. Venture Two small television networks became a large one when CBS and Warner Brothers Entertainment joined forces to form a youth-oriented network out of the programs on UPN and WB. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: A threat to the campaign law; secrecy as a spoil of victory; the ''whites only'' retirement fund; Canada tilts, cautiously, rightward. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E8 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE BARBARA WALTERS SPECIAL -- It's the 25th annual Oscar edition, but only one of Ms. Walters's four guests is even nominated. That would be George Clooney (above, with Ms. Walters), up for best director for ''Good Night, and Good Luck'' (which is also nominated for best picture) and for best supporting actor in ''Syriana.'' Patrick Dempsey (enjoying a burst of fame on ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy''), Matthew McConaughey and Mariah Carey are the other interview subjects. 8 P.M. (NBC) DEAL OR NO DEAL -- At the midpoint of this weeklong game show, the contestants hoping to choose the right briefcase (one has $1 million inside) are Mark Adrian from Burlington, N.J., and Cindy Pridgeon of El Cajon, Calif. 8 P.M. (5) AMERICAN IDOL -- The top 10 male semifinalists give it their all in a 90-minute show. 8 P.M. (11) ONE TREE HILL -- An unhappy student brings a gun to school. Nathan and Lucas (James Lafferty, near right, and Chad Michael Murray) do everything possible to prevent a Columbine-like disaster. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Claire worries about her baby. Jack and Locke worry about their prisoner. Viewers worry about how all of these bizarre clues and mysteries can ever add up to a coherent explanation about the nature of this island. 9:30 P.M. (5) FREE RIDE -- Series premiere. How would a guy feel if, right after graduating from college, he headed for his parents' house and found they had turned his room into a gym? In this new sitcom, Nate Stahlings (Josh Dean, below) faces that bitter reality but decides to move back home anyway. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY -- The three fashion designers still in the competition prepare for New York Fashion Week. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- Water Gun Wars, an assassination-fantasy game, becomes all the rage, but someone isn't using water guns. Meanwhile, a woman is found dead in her apartment after attending a grotesque event for foodies. Live octopus and Brazilian cockroaches were on the menu. ANITA GATES

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: HOME SALES AT TWO-YEAR LOW -- In the latest indication that the home buying and selling frenzy is over, sales of previously owned homes in July fell to the lowest level in over two years, prices flattened and sellers waited longer to find buyers for their homes. The stock of unsold houses hit a record high. [Page C1.] SHARES SLIDE -- Stocks dropped the most in three weeks as a plunge in sales of previously owned homes heightened concern that the economy was headed for a slump. [C14.] INDIA SEES SECURITY RISKS -- Amid concerns that some foreign investments might overstep into areas of national security, the Indian government is drafting legislation to block overseas companies from doing business in India if they are perceived as security risks. ''As investors flood vital sectors such as telecommunications, media, airlines and ports, our priority is to bring in comprehensive safeguards,'' said Kamal Nath, above, the minister of commerce and industry. [C4.] CHEAPER AUTO RATES -- For the first time in decades, prices for automobile coverage are falling in New Jersey, and insurers are fighting for the business of drivers. It is a mammoth change that puts New Jersey in line with auto insurance practices in most of the country. [C1.] FORD CONSIDERING DEALS -- Ford is evaluating the prospects for ties with other automakers even as it moves ahead with its own restructuring efforts, people who have been briefed on Ford's activities said. [C1.] REDSTONE VS. CRUISE CONTINUES -- A day after Viacom's chairman, Sumner Redstone, abruptly evicted Tom Cruise from his home on the Paramount movie lot, the war of words was on the verge of escalating from recrimination to retribution. [C1.] CRUISE'S SLIDE -- Tom Cruise's likability began to plummet even before his couch-jumping days. In the annual Harris poll charting America's favorite movie stars, done every January, Mr. Cruise has not even been in the Top 10 since the poll in 2004, when he ranked No. 5. [E1.] A PUSH FOR VIOXX SUCCESSOR -- Setting the stage for a scientific and regulatory battle, Merck said that a potential successor to its painkiller Vioxx had shown in a large study to be no more dangerous to the heart than an older painkiller still widely in use. [C1.] HANDS OFF RUSSIAN GAS -- Ukraine's new prime minister, Viktor F. Yanukovich, has promised that his government will refrain from siphoning natural gas from Russia's export pipelines to meet Ukraine's shortfall this winter, a practice that has incensed Russian officials who characterize it as stealing. [A7.] MEDICARE MIX-UP -- About 230,000 Medicare recipients were mistakenly sent refunds last week averaging about $215 for monthly premiums they paid this year for drug coverage, the head of the Medicare program said. [A25.] PAPER DEAL -- Weyerhaeuser will merge its fine-paper operation with a Canadian company, Domtar, in a cash-and-stock deal worth $3.3 billion. [C4.] RECORD NET FOR MINING COMPANY -- BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, reported its third consecutive record full-year profit, as China's booming economy and surging prices for copper offset rising costs and pressure from workers for higher wages. [C4.] I.B.M. TO BUY SOFTWARE FIRM -- I.B.M. took another step in its strategy of blending software and services, announcing plans to buy Internet Security Systems of Atlanta for $1.3 billion. It would be the largest acquisition added to I.B.M.'s services business since it bought PriceWaterhouseCoopers Consulting for $3.5 billion in 2004. [C5.] RITE AID TO BUY A RIVAL -- The Rite Aid drug store chain agreed to buy Brooks/Eckerd for $2.55 billion in cash and stock, putting it within striking distance of its two largest rivals, Walgreen and CVS, according to people involved in the deal. [C3.] GRABBING MORE ADS -- Some distinctly uncool factions of the magazine industry are stealing attention from the high-end fashion magazines like Vogue, Elle and Harper's Bazaar. Martha Stewart's namesake magazine saw a 69.5 percent increase in ad pages over last September, and Oprah Winfrey's title had a 56.4 percent jump. Advertising. [C6.] RACE ON 'SURVIVOR' -- For the first time since it went on the air in 2000, the hit CBS reality show ''Survivor'' will divide its teams along racial lines. [C6.] ONLINE CAREER COUCH -- Find out how to recover from botched presentations and workplace blunders at nytimes.com/jobs. MANAGING GLOBALIZATION -- Daniel Altman, the International Herald Tribune's global economics correspondent, offers a look at the day's news in a blog at nytimes.com/business. YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with Your Money, a free weekly newsletter from The New York Times. nytimes.com/yourmoney VICTIMS OF A COAL BOOM -- As coal powers China's sizzling economy, thousands of acres of land are literally sinking because of the ravages of underground coal mining. A report is at nytimes.com/worldbusiness. FROM RECORDS TO CD'S -- David Pogue tests Teac's GF-350 recording machine, which can turn vinyl records and cassette tapes into CD's. A video report is at nytimes.com/technology. TECH TALK -- A podcast of a weekly technology program from the tech experts at The New York Times is available at nytimes.com/technology.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: WIDER CONTRACEPTIVE SALES -- The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive called Plan B to those 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's history. Over-the-counter sales will begin by the end of the year. [Page A1.] FINANCIAL SIDE EFFECTS -- The long political debate over the Plan B emergency contraceptive pill may have helped raise the profile of its maker, Barr Pharmaceuticals, but over-the-counter sales of Plan B will barely register on the company's balance sheet. That is why Barr does not plan to advertise the drug on television or radio. [C1.] APPLE RECALLS BATTERIES -- Apple Computer said it was recalling 1.8 million battery packs from some laptop computer models because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire. The batteries were made by a unit of Sony, which also made the 4.1 million laptop batteries that Dell recalled last week. [C1.] HOME SALE DISCOUNTS -- As home sales fall rapidly and the number of houses on the market continues to surge, many sellers are offering thousands of dollars in perks so they do not have to slice deeply into asking prices. As a result, home prices may now be falling, despite what the official numbers show, many economists say. [C1.] HONG KONG AND THE LAW -- An assault on one of Hong Kong's best-known lawmakers and litigators could raise concerns about the potential for damage to Hong Kong's reputation for the fair settlement of disputes in court. [C1.] AOL TO OFFER 4 STUDIOS' MOVIES -- AOL said it would offer movies from four major Hollywood studios for downloading on its Internet video service. [C7.] SIGNS OF SLOWING GROWTH -- Sales of new homes and orders for durable goods both fell more than expected in July, providing further evidence of slowing economic growth. [C3.] STOCKS EDGE HIGHER -- Wall Street managed a razor-thin gain as investors sifted through data that pointed to stable interest rates, but also suggested that the economy had moderated more than expected. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.56 points, to 11,304.46. [C7.] FANNIE MAE CASE DROPPED -- Almost two years after it started investigating accounting improprieties at Fannie Mae, the mortgage giant, the Justice Department is no longer pursuing criminal charges, the company and federal officials said. [C3.] RUSSIANS RETURN PHONES -- The Russian authorities returned 117,519 Motorola mobile phones worth $15 million that had been seized at a Moscow airport five months ago. [A7.] LABOR DISPUTE GOES TO COURT -- The makings of an old-fashioned airline labor standoff involving Northwest Airlines, flight attendants and the federal government will come together today in federal court in New York. [C3.] DRUGSTORE SALE ANNOUNCED -- The Jean Coutu Group of Canada confirmed it would sell its Eckerd and Brooks drugstore chains in the United States to Rite Aid for $2.55 billion in cash and stock. When the deal is completed, Coutu, founded by Jean Coutu, above, a pharmacist who wears a lab coat at work and occasionally dispenses pills at his stores, will own about 30 percent of Rite Aid. [C5.] CHINESE BANK DEAL -- The China Construction Bank, one of China's four main state-controlled banks, agreed to buy the retail banking operations in Hong Kong and Macao of the Bank of America for $1.25 billion. [C5.] LAWYER LEAVING EMBATTLED FIRM -- The embattled securities class-action law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, was dealt another blow after a prominent trial lawyer, Patricia M. Hynes, said she was leaving. [C3.] MAKING A NAME FOR CW -- To help their new CW broadcast network gain traction in the proverbial 500-channel universe, CBS and Time Warner are sponsoring an ambitious campaign to create an identity for it. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C7.] WAL-MART DROPS NEW YORK SITE -- Wal-Mart's plans to open its first New York City store in Staten Island have fallen through, company officials confirmed. [B6.] ONLINE SWEET, WEIRD OR FRAUD? Virginia Heffernan evaluates the competing claims for an online video star, lonelygirl15, in her blog at screens.blogs.nytimes.com. headline: Assistants Adhere To Code Of Silence
summary: Before yesterday's news conference introducing him as the Jets' new head coach, Eric Mangini was a mystery to the news media. As a branch on the Parcells-Belichick coaching tree, he was ordered not to speak to the press. ''They all come off as the Great Sphinx because they have marching orders about not talking to the media,'' Randy Cross of CBS Sports said.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Jan. 29-Feb. 4; TELEVISION
summary: If Eliza Doolittle were around today, she wouldn't be a Cockney flower girl. She'd probably be what the British call a ladette, a young woman trying to be one of the lads by drinking to excess, shouting four-letter words and, if necessary, belching. In ''LADETTE TO LADY,'' imported by the SUNDANCE CHANNEL (Thursday, 9 p.m.), some tasteful teachers play Henry Higgins at tasteful Eggleston Hall. They take on 10 proud ladettes, who compete to be transformed into the sorts of girls PRINCE WILLIAM could bring home. The first step is putting them into sweater sets and pearls. Even viewers who think most reality series are drivel may find this one entertaining. The British do that sort of thing so well. Then, sometimes, American television takes a British series and wrings the social anthropology out of it. Yes, the big one is back. ''SURVIVOR: PANAMA -- EXILE ISLAND'' has its season premiere Thursday night at 8 on CBS. A new batch of attractive people (including a retired astronaut, a performance artist and a social worker) compete for big money by being devious and manipulative. There is plenty of worthy, culturally significant programming ahead for Black History Month, but one of the most intriguing specials comes from an unlikely source: TV LAND. WAYNE BRADY is a much better stand-up comedian than he is a talk-show host, but he doesn't need to be scintillating on ''THAT'S WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT,'' which begins on Wednesday (10 p.m.). His guests (HARRY BELAFONTE, DIAHANN CARROLL, PAUL MOONEY and TOURÉ on the first of the three one-hour segments) take the ball and run with it, with some promising straight talk about perceptions of race in popular culture. The old clips and photos speak volumes. And the list of most influential black television shows puts ''THE JEFFERSONS'' ahead of ''ROOTS.''

headline: In Search of the Way Out of Iraq
summary: To the Editor: The headline ''U.S. General Says Iraq Could Slide Into a Civil War'' (front page, Aug. 4) sent chills down my spine. The dire picture of Iraq's endless internecine struggles and the tragic loss of lives is a cruel indictment of our missteps and lack of adequate postwar planning.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: New York Daily News Is Making The Most of a Scandal at Its Rival Over the last few years, The New York Daily News has taken its lumps from its cross-town tabloid rival, The New York Post, while also losing readers to it. Now The Daily News has pulled out all the stops in its coverage of accusations of attempted bribery involving a popular contributor to The Post's vaunted Page Six gossip column. [Page C1.] Little Known in U.S., Orkut Finds Fans in Brazil Orkut, the social networking service created by a Google software engineer named Orkut Buyukkokten, never really caught on in the United States, where MySpace rules teenage cyberspace. But it is nothing short of a cultural phenomenon in Brazil. [C1.] After the Hurricane, Two Newspapers Thrive The Biloxi Sun Herald of Mississippi and The Times-Picayune in New Orleans have rebuilt and reinvigorated their advertising bases and readership after Hurricane Katrina. [C1.] As Couric Moves, Networks Aim to Revive Evening News As Katie Couric moves to CBS, the networks know that they must find a way to bring down the median age of their news shows' audience -- which now hovers at around 60 -- and reinvent their anchors as more than newsreaders behind a desk. [C1.] New Web Site Offers Outlet for Obscure Knowledge A new Web site, Squidoo.com, is offering Internet authors the chance to earn money on their obscure expertise. Squidoo features more than 21,000 so-called lenses, or sites devoted to various subjects, with many more being added daily. Each lens author is responsible for his postings, and according to Squidoo's chief executive, Seth Godin, above, the site offers technology that is intended to make the pages easier for authors to maintain -- and more useful to readers -- than conventional blogs. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C7.] An Abridged Version of the Web, on a Laptop A company called Webaroo plans to announce that Acer will begin selling laptops furnished with an abridged version of the Web. [C8.] Cable Companies Move to Close Wireless Gap In the race with the Bell companies to become one-stop shops for communications services, the country's biggest cable companies are developing wireless products, the missing piece of their so-called quadruple-play bundle. The centerpiece of that effort is a venture involving Sprint Nextel and Comcast, Time Warner Cable, Cox Communications and Bright House Networks. [C4.] Debate Surrounds Wireless Network in San Francisco Since San Francisco selected Google and Earthlink to build a wireless network, the city has been at the center of a debate about the implications of the network on issues like privacy and advertising. [C5.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) STARGATE SG-1 -- Season finale. The SG-1 team happens upon an alien version of King Arthur's Camelot. Merlin (who, it turns out, was one of the ancients from Atlantis) has quite a security system, but Cameron and Daniel (Ben Browder, above left, and Michael Shanks, center, with John Noble as a local official) need to get into his library. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- The carnival comes to town, and Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) encounters a dead magician (Jonathan Firth) who believes his demise -- during an underwater stunt -- was no accident. He wants revenge on his brother (Orlando Seale), who always envied him. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER -- Cesar Millan (below left) goes Hollywood. He visits the actress Denise Richards, who is having trouble with three out-of-control pets: Lucy the Boston terrier, Hank the French bulldog and Betty the pug. Ms. Richards catches on to Mr. Millan's instructions fast, and Hank looks very cute on a treadmill (working off some of that nervous energy). There is no sign of Ms. Richards's on-again, off-again husband, Charlie Sheen. 8 P.M. (History) WARRIOR QUEEN BOUDICA -- She's for real. Boudica (Charlotte Comer) lived in Roman-occupied Britain in the first century A.D. When Rome didn't treat her people, the Iceni, very nicely after their king's death, she led a revolt and massacred some 70,000 Romans and British sympathizers. She paid a price. 10 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Jon Favreau gueststars as a sadistic dentist. Adrian Monk (Tony Shalhoub) will have to fight his obsessive-compulsive tendencies with all his might to investigate by posing as a patient. But it has to be done. The doctor is suspected of murder. 3:30 A.M. (TCM) DUCK SOUP (1933). This was the Marx brothers' last movie for Paramount. Groucho (right) plays Rufus T. Firefly, the new dictator of Freedonia, who declares war against neighboring Sylvania over the love of Mrs. Teasdale (Margaret Dumont) -- well, the love of her money. Groucho and Harpo do the amazing mirror routine later adapted on ''I Love Lucy.'' The film is also a commentary on politicians and war. ''Go and break through the lines,'' says Rufus. ''And remember while you're out there risking your life and limb through shot and shell, we'll be in here thinking what a sucker you are.'' ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (MTV) THE REAL WORLD: KEY WEST -- Season premiere. The seven strangers moving in together (left) include a Ferris Bueller type with a Penn State degree, a gay swimming champion from Minneapolis and a 19-yearold pre-med student at Temple described as a ''voluptuous fireball.'' But the great waterfront house isn't enough for them. They all take off for a vacation in Spain. 8 P.M. (5) AMERICAN IDOL -- Television's apparently addictive talent show rolls on. 8 P.M. (11) GILMORE GIRLS -- ''Bridesmaid Revisited.'' Lorelai, whose only child, Rory, is grown up and living in sin at Yale, volunteers to baby-sit. The baby is the 4-year-old daughter of Rory's previously absent father, Christopher (David Sutcliffe). Meanwhile, Rory goes to her rich boyfriend's sister's wedding. 8 P.M. (13) ARCTIC PASSAGE -- When Sir John Franklin and 134 men sailed from England in 1845 to navigate the Northwest Passage, sought as a shortcut from London to Asia, the trip ended in disaster (and possibly cannibalism). Roald Amundsen, who set off in 1903, had better luck. This ''Nova'' documentary looks at the reasons in great detail. 9 P.M. (CBS) THE AMAZING RACE -- Two-hour season premiere. There's a Pizza Hut manager from Kansas, a retired doctor from Colorado and a valet from Fort Lauderdale. There are three New Yorkers: a young writer (traveling with her Georgia- based mother) and two childhood friends from Staten Island (Danielle Turner, above left, and Dani Torchio). Eleven two-member teams start off the $1 million competition by flying to Brazil. This series has won the reality-series Emmy three years in a row, 10 P.M.(NBC) LAW& ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT -- With so many real-life and fictional television stories of class-trip tragedies, it's surprising that the trips still go on. In this episode, a Montreal high school student vanishes from her New York trip. Three arrogant prep-school boys who all had sex with her are the suspects. 10 P.M. (History) MODERN MARVELS: ENGINEERING DISASTERS -- ''New Orleans.'' Why did the levees break? 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- Denny Crane (William Shatner) is caught with a woman other than his wife. This is not out of character, but his bride (Joanna Cassidy, above) -- they said ''I do'' less than three hours earlier -- wants an annulment. And lots of Denny's money. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 48TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS John Legend (left), Kanye West and Mariah Carey are the superstars this year, with eight nominations each. They'll be performing live from Los Angeles tonight, as will a bevy of other nominees, including Bruce Springsteen, Coldplay, U2, Sugarland and Faith Hill. Viewers can also expect to see Madonna, Christina Aguilera, Herbie Hancock, Jay-Z, Linkin Park, a tribute to Sly and the Family Stone, and Paul McCartney's first Grammys performance ever. It's still the most prestigious pop-music award around. 8 P.M. (ABC) GEORGE LOPEZ ''The Kidney Stays in the Picture.'' Who says you can't make a sitcom episode about bedwetting? 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL Simon Cowell's pain is over, at least for this season. The auditions have ended, and the aspiring singers who were good enough to have been asked back are now in Hollywood to begin the real competition. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST Sun (Yunjin Kim, left) becomes the victim of a kidnap attempt. It fails, but she is injured, leading the plane-crash survivors to wonder if the Others are back. 9 P.M. (13) AFRICAN AMERICAN LIVES Last week Henry Louis Gates Jr., the Harvard scholar, told some noted black Americans about their American ancestors. Tonight he heads to Africa, where DNA testing can trace bloodlines to very specific places and people. Part 2 of 2. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER Kathleen Turner guest-stars as a powerful lawyer defending a privileged high school senior accused of murder. The victim was a Hispanic classmate at a magnet school who, it turns out, was selling test answers and writing term papers for his less intellectually gifted friends. 10 P.M. (TV Land) THAT'S WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT Spike Lee, the Rev. Al Sharpton and the comedian Wanda Sykes (below right) are among the guests taking on tonight's topics: politics, comedy and sports. They debate about which athletes are more influential -- early stars like Jesse Owens and Jackie Robinson or today's champions like the Williams sisters and Tiger Woods. On an unrelated topic, a particular 1994 murder case, some guests give guarded, carefully phrased answers. But Ms. Sykes says it straight out: ''O. J. is guilty.'' Part 2 of 3. ANITA GATES

headline: A Jeopardy Question For the Nov. 7 Crowd
summary: POLITICAL reporters love asking hypothetical questions, almost as much as politicians hate answering them. But it has become a settled expectation of political life that any candidate who supported the Iraq war resolution in 2002 must now answer the dreaded, ''If you knew then what you know now'' question.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, 9, 13, 47, C-Span, C-Span 2, FNC, MSNBC) STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESS -- President Bush (right, with Vice President Dick Cheney), entering the second year of his second term, delivers his State of the Union address, telecast from the United States Capitol. The two hours of coverage will include news analysis and the Democratic response. 8 P.M. (11) GILMORE GIRLS -- Lorelai and Rory, mother-and-daughter best friends, have always dreaded those staid Friday night dinners with Lorelai's rich parents. But at this one, all the Gilmores finally put their cards on the table. Meanwhile, there's a thoroughly justified student-staff revolt at The Yale Daily News. 9 P.M. (BBC America) BAD GIRLS -- Season 2 of this prison drama began last week, with the heroin addict Zandra (Lara Cazalet) giving birth, facing custody problems and trying to throw herself from a roof. Tonight's story focuses on inmate-staff romances, as Helen (Simone Lahbib), the wing warden, tries to find a way to put her romance with Nikki (Mananda Jones) behind her. And a mobile phone helps the sexy but psychotic Shell (Debra Stephenson) prove her affair with Jim (Jack Ellis) to his disbelieving wife. 10 P.M. (BET) TOP 25 MOST OUTRAGEOUS MOMENTS IN BLACK HISTORY -- Well, there's Michael Jackson (left) dangling his baby son from a hotel balcony in Berlin in 2002. There's O. J. Simpson leading the Los Angeles police on a slow-speed car chase five days after his wife was murdered. And there's more where those came from. 10 P.M. (Court TV) LAS VEGAS LAW -- Series premiere. In the 1980's and 90's, ''L.A. Law'' was a stylish, occasionally absurdist drama series with an ensemble cast. Today ''Boston Legal'' is a stylish, frequently absurdist drama series with an ensemble cast. But ''Las Vegas Law'' is a reality show focusing on just one man -- James Buchanan (known as Bucky), a flashy, cocky, bald criminal defense lawyer -- and the absurdity of his cases is all too real. ''A good lawyer knows the law,'' Mr. Buchanan says. ''A great lawyer knows the judge.'' 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE -- Jesan Hyde, a 25-year-old bike messenger and pizza delivery guy, wants to become a model. The male supermodel Tyson Beckford offers makeover guidance. (Above from left: Mr. Hyde, Jai Rodriguez, Mr. Beckford and Ted Allen.) ANITA GATES

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Two Senate Leaders Want Another Look At Recent Incentives for the Oil Industry As anxiety spread in Congress over soaring oil prices, lawmakers in both parties said they are ready to take a new look at oil and gas incentives they passed eight months ago. Citing record industry profits and huge executive pay packages, the top Republican and the top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee asked the Internal Revenue Service to turn over tax returns for the nation's 15 biggest oil and gas companies. [Page A1.] Kenneth Lay Loses His Cool on the Witness Stand After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand in the Enron fraud trial. [C1.] Denver Post Publisher to Buy Four Knight Ridder Papers The MediaNews newspaper chain, publisher of the Denver Post, said it would buy 4 Knight Ridder newspapers that are among the 12 that the McClatchy Company plans to sell after it acquires Knight Ridder. [C1.] Several big media companies, including Walt Disney and CBS, have met with Univision's management over the last week about making bids for the company, people involved in the talks said. [C7.] Change Sought in Oversight of Heart Device Implants A major medical group called for sweeping changes in how the medical device industry and the government oversee implanted heart devices and urged companies to use outside experts to help them decide when to issue alerts about suspect products. [C1.] Discontented Shareholders Becoming More Vocal Annual shareholder meetings are typically dull, scripted affairs, but as executives and directors of public companies step into the spotlight at this year's gatherings, some for the first time are hearing organized and articulate shareholder discontent. [C1.] Detroit Auto Chiefs Plan Meeting with Bush President Bush, who touched a nerve with Detroit carmakers by telling them to build relevant vehicles, will meet with the companies' chief executives, from left, Thomas W. Lasorda of Chrysler, William Clay Ford Jr. of Ford, and Rick Wagoner of General Motors. The meeting is expected to focus on energy and the environment; costs like pensions and health care premiums; and how currency issues affect Japanese automakers. [C3.] Data Show Economic Pickup; Economists Are Cautious Two measures of housing and manufacturing activity rose sharply in March, the Commerce Department said, indicating that the economy has picked up steam. But economists cautioned that higher energy costs and interest rates may sap some of that vitality. [C3.] Microsoft Swaps Charges in European Trade Case Microsoft said the European Commission had forced it to hand over trade secrets to rivals, giving them a ''free ride'' on its work, but the commission's lawyer said Microsoft had managed to strangle its rivals' innovation. [C7.] Microsoft is close to reaching a deal to buy Massive Incorporated, which makes technology to insert advertisements into video games for somewhere between $200 million and $400 million, a member of Massive's board of directors, Douglas P. Miscoll, said. [C9.] Warner Brothers Television Plans Unit for Cable Shows Warner Brothers Television, the biggest producer of prime-time series for broadcast networks over the last two decades, is creating a unit to generate series specifically for cable TV networks. [C8.] Russian President Favors Asia as an Oil Market President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia should direct oil and natural gas exports to Asia because ''unprincipled competition'' blocked its energy companies from expanding elsewhere. His remarks suggest his government believes it has a strong negotiating hand with Europe on energy issues. [C14.] Economic Optimism in Germany Contradicts Statistics A survey of German consumers showed more optimism in the country's economy than at any time since 2001. That report came one day after a survey of business executives showed the most optimism since 1991. Some of the data is so rosy that critics say it does not reflect reality in a nation that still has tepid growth and nearly double-digit unemployment. [C14.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (USA) MONK -- ''Mr. Monk Goes to a Fashion Show.'' Tony Shalhoub (above) is back with new episodes as Adrian Monk, the lovable obsessive-compulsive detective, and he has Malcolm McDowell as a guest star. Monk helps out when the son of his favorite shirt inspector is wrongly accused of murdering a model. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Melinda Gordon (Jennifer Love Hewitt) can't go anywhere without running into a spirit who needs her help. At an art exhibition, she's approached by the ghost of an executed prisoner who was also an artist. His problem is making sure that the money for his valuable paintings goes to his daughter. Father and daughter were estranged, but Melinda can probably fix that. 8:30 P.M. (Fox) MALCOLM IN THE MIDDLE -- This is what happens when the children on a series start growing up. (Remember, on ''My Three Sons,'' Chip was, like, 12 when they married him off.) Now Reese -- yes, little Reese (Justin Berfield, who will be 20 next month)-- runs away to Las Vegas to elope. Her name is Raduca. And Grandma Ida (Cloris Leachman, above, with Mr. Berfield) is to blame. Part 1 of 2. 9 P.M. (ABC) IN JUSTICE -- This new series, starring Kyle MacLachlan, is about a legal team that works to right judicial wrongs. Tonight their project is an innocent high school athlete who was convicted eight years ago of murdering a college student. 10 P.M. (NBC) THE BOOK OF DANIEL -- The distinguished stage star Marian Seldes (most recently seen in Terrence McNally's ''Dedication or The Stuff of Dreams'') gueststars as the Rev. Daniel Webster's formidable mother-in-law. But Daniel, a suburban Episcopal priest, has other concerns. The mob is insisting that he use their chosen construction company for the next big church project. As usual, Daniel will ask what Jesus would do. In fact, he'll ask Jesus (Garret Dillahunt). 10 P.M. (CMT) IN THE MOMENT -- Bo Bice (right) started out in Helena, Ala., sang his heart out on ''American Idol'' and came in second (to Carrie Underwood). But that was good enough. In this special, Mr. Bice works on his first album and adjusts to fame and his growing family. ANITA GATES

headline: Today's Matchups
summary: Pittsburgh Steelers (12-5) at Indianapolis Colts (14-2) 1 p.m., CBS The Steelers are on a roll. They have won five consecutive games, the latest against the Cincinnati Bengals last Sunday when they knocked quarterback Carson Palmer out of the game and onto the operating table with a knee injury. The Steelers have a strong defense, an insistent running game and secure quarterbacking from Ben Roethlisberger. A year ago, as a rookie, he threw five interceptions in two playoff games. But, he said, ''I'm more mature this year.'' Wide receiver Hines Ward said of Roethlisberger: ''He's prepared now. He's not out there winging it.''

headline: Oops. A Few End Up Afloat in the Pool.
summary: Know anyone who has the Final Four intact in the office pool? No way. After all, not one top-seeded team made it. The last time that happened was 1980. Who could have picked the Patriots -- not Tom Brady & Company, but the ones from George Mason?

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (CBS) LOVE MONKEY -- Series premiere. In ''Ed'' (NBC, 2000-4), Tom Cavanagh played a man who left New York and returned to his hometown after losing his job and catching his wife in bed with another man. In this new show,Mr. Cavanagh (right) plays a man who decides to stay in New York after he loses his job and his girlfriend on the same day. So this is not the same show. He plays a music industry executive, for instance, not a lawyer. And he's determined to sign up a talented teenager and start his own record label. So really it's more like ''Jerry Maguire.'' Jason Priestley plays his bosom-buddy brother-in-law. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- This all auditions episode is the fifth-season premiere. Ryan Seacrest is back as host. Paula Abdul, Randy Jackson and the ferocious Simon Cowell are back as judges. They will be looking for outstanding singing talent. Viewers will be looking for the next William Hung. 8 P.M. (TV Guide) GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS FASHION WRAP -- Joan Rivers and her daughter, Melissa (left), reveal what they were really thinking while talking to the celebrities on the red carpet last night. About their clothes, anyway. 10 P.M. (13) GIRL TROUBLE -- Their names are Shangra, Stephanie and Sheila, and they come from backgrounds of poverty and substance abuse. One is 16 and pregnant, one is a drug addict and one sells crack. This ''Independent Lens'' documentary follows the lives of these three teenagers, their dealings with the juvenile justice system, and the glimmers of hope offered at a center founded by a 22-year-old woman from a background much like theirs. 10 P.M. (Spike) KING OF VEGAS -- Series premiere. The title may sound as if it belongs to a sitcom, but this is a reality show. Bigtime casino gamblers compete for a $1 million grand prize. The games they'll play include blackjack, roulette, baccarat and Caribbean stud (poker). 10 P.M. (TCM) BRIEF ENCOUNTER -- (1945). Celia Johnson and Trevor Howard (right) star in what must be the greatest adultery story in British movie history. They meet at a train station. They're married, but not to each other. They suffer, lust, pine and are overwhelmed with guilt, all to Rachmaninoff. ANITA GATES

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Heaviest Day of Fighting In Israel's 2-Front Conflict Israel's two-front conflict had its heaviest day of fighting, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza. Hezbollah kept up its sustained fire on northern Israel, with 130 rockets hitting the region, wounding more than 10 Israelis. A1 When Israel sent in its elite Golani Infantry Brigade to secure the Hezbollah stronghold of Bint Jbail -- a town Israeli officers claimed to control -- hundreds of soldiers were pinned down in an ambush and eight soldiers were killed, showing how far Israel has to go in driving Hezbollah from southern Lebanon. A1 The United Nations said its top officials in New York and its officers in Lebanon made numerous calls to the Israeli mission and the Israeli military to protest repeated firing on its outpost in Lebanon where four unarmed observers were eventually killed. A14 Civilians in the Path of Battle Dozens of Hezbollah missiles have struck the Israeli city of Haifa in recent days, completely paralyzing it. They have driven residents into shelters or out of the city, and many who have stayed have sent their children farther south, where the missiles have not reached. A15 Countries Fail on Mideast Plan World powers failed to agree on a plan to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah, underscoring the power of the United States when it comes to dealing with Israel. A15 Iraq Head Addresses Congress Addressing a joint meeting of Congress, the Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, described Iraq as the ''front line'' in the war on terrorism and vowed to make Iraq an ''active player'' in the security and stability of the Middle East. A12 Saddam Hussein appeared publicly defiant at his trial by praising insurgent attacks on Americans, denouncing the court as illegitimate and rejecting the charge that he ordered the 1982 execution of 148 men and boys in Dujail. A12 Envoy Optimistic on Kabul The European Union's chief representative in Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, has expressed confidence in NATO's ability to stem the rising violence in the south, as the alliance prepares to take command of security operations there. A8 Georgian Forces Hunt Rebel Georgian special forces pressed their attacks through the mountainous Kodori Gorge, trying to put down a rebellious militia whose leader had said he would no longer recognize the central government. A6 SCIENCE/HEALTH Improving Bird Flu Vaccine A new vaccine against bird flu developed by GlaxoSmithKline is more effective than any previous version and works at a far smaller dose, the company reported. A1 NATIONAL A18-23 Chicago Council Votes To Raise Pay in Retail After months of fevered lobbying and debate, the Chicago City Council passed a groundbreaking ordinance requiring ''big box'' stores, like Wal-Mart and Home Depot, to pay a minimum wage of $10 an hour by 2010, along with $3 in benefits. A1 Poll Shows U.S. Pessimism The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that Americans are pessimistic about the state of affairs in the Middle East, with majorities doubtful that American troops will be able to leave Iraq any time soon. A22 Ban on Gay Marriage Is Upheld The Washington Supreme Court upheld a state law banning same-sex marriages, with some in the majority stressing that the Legislature remains free to extend the right to marry to gay couples. A18 Passing of Energy Bill Is Likely The Senate moved closer to passing a bill that would expand energy production in the Gulf of Mexico. A procedural vote of 86 to 12 signaled wide support for opening up large new tracts for drilling. A20 Butterflies Invade South Texas South Texas is under siege from millions of snout butterflies that have taken advantage of an unusual drought-and-deluge cycle to breed in spectacular profusion. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Claims of Neglect Surround Famed New York Socialite Brooke Astor, once the doyenne of New York society, is at the center of a bitter intergenerational dispute that has become public. In a lawsuit, one of her grandsons accuses her son, who is her legal guardian, of mistreating her and turning her final years into a grim shadow of the glittery decades that had gone before. A1 Another Power Outage Consolidated Edison, still reeling from the end of a lengthy blackout in western Queens, found itself grappling with a new power failure when 16,000 customers in Staten Island lost electricity for several hours. B1 M.T.A. Delays Fare Increases The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it was postponing a planned increase in fares and tolls from January to September 2007, a decision that tossed the prospect of future increases into an unpredictable political realm because a new governor will be able to influence the authority's actions next year. B1 OBITUARIES B7 C. Frederick Mosteller The founding chairman of Harvard's statistics department and a pioneer in using statistics to analyze an array of topics, he was 89. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 New S.E.C. Rules on Pay The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted new rules that should make it easier to see how much top executives are paid. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Shrugging off trade promises; the wrong lesson; more hope for the truly rich; an appetizer of a debate. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E10 TV Listings E13 Crossword E6 Weather D8

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) PHANTOM LIMB -- When Jay Rosenblatt was 9, his little brother, Eliot, died. Mr. Rosenblatt's artistic half-hour reflection on reactions to death is dedicated to Eliot (above left with Jay), who was 7. It begins with Eisenhower-into-Kennedy-era home movies of the brothers and moves on to film (much of it black-and-white) of collapsing buildings, tearful crowds, a little boy whose pet bird has died, an experiment with rats and electric shock, a man shearing a sheep (while a voice-over advises grieving parents), a surgical amputation and childbirth. 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE -- For seven and a half seasons now, Karen Walker has been an exemplary substance abuser, cynic, liar, slacker and tramp. But tonight the existence of a so-called forbidden room in her home will suggest that she has a gentler side. Meanwhile, Will forbids Grace to work for his ex-boss (Lily Tomlin) and Grace ignores him. 8 P.M. (13) KING GEORGE & QUEEN MARY: THE FIRST WINDSORS -- Talk about a marriage of convenience. When the future George V's older brother died, George dutifully married his fiancée. But things worked out well for George and Mary of Teck, who were Elizabeth II's paternal grandparents. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI -- When a young man is found dead in his girlfriend's garage after a big night of partying and drugs, Gil Grissom (William L. Petersen, left) and the C.S.I. team think the girlfriend did it. Then they find out who else was having an affair with him. 9 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Earl (Jason Lee) knocks over a bus-stop sign. More bad karma. 9:30 P.M. (ABC) CRUMBS -- Suzanne Crumb (Jane Curtin) decides it would be a good idea to adopt a Ukrainian baby. Suzanne, you may know, has two grown sons, a runaway husband and has just gotten out of a mental institution. 1:15 A.M. (Encore) LEAVING LAS VEGAS -- (1995). Nicolas Cage won the best-actor Oscar (and a long list of other best actor awards) for his role as a lonely, washed-up Hollywood screenwriter who decides to drive to Nevada and drink himself to death. Elisabeth Shue (above with Mr. Cage) plays the sweet, vulnerable prostitute who falls in love with him. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) FESTIVAL DAILIES -- For those who would kill to be at this year's Sundance Film Festival but can't, this show, straight from Park City, Utah, may have to do. A nightly half-hour report (through Jan. 29), it's about the films (with sneak peeks), the parties, maybe even the skiing. The show will be followed by movies from past festivals, starting tonight at 9:30 with ''Three Seasons'' (above), a portrait of cultural transition, filmed in Saigon and directed by Tony Bui. ''Victoria Para Chino,'' about undocumented Mexican workers being smuggled into Texas, starts at 11:15 p.m. 8 P.M. (Disney) HIGH SCHOOL MUSICAL -- School productions can make strange bedfellows, like Troy (Zac Efron) and Gabriella (Vanessa Anne Hudgens). When they try out together, clique confusion ensues. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER -- Buddy likes to eat skateboard wheels. Matilda prefers to chew on her fellow animals. Teddy just twirls compulsively. Cesar Millan (right) -- an affable man who, during the opening segment of his series, boasts, ''No dog is too much for me to handle'' -- thrills the pets' owners by curing them. The trick, he shows, is in knowing the difference between dog psychology and human psychology. 8:15 P.M. (IFC) SHALLOW GRAVE (1995). Ewan McGregor (who was pretty much unknown at the time) stars with Kerry Fox and Christopher in this dark, dark drama about Scottish yuppies who take in a new roommate. Then they find him dead. Then they find all this money. Then their morality goes downhill fast. 9 P.M. (CBS) CLOSE TO HOME -- A very religious woman explains that God told her to kill her husband. 9 P.M. (11) REBA -- ''Parenting With Puppets.'' Reba (Reba McEntire, left) disapproves of the child-discipline methods of her exhusband's wife. Around the same time, the ex-husband (Christopher Rich) and his son-in-law (Steve Howey), two guys who will never go to see ''Brokeback Mountain,'' visit a day spa together and are taken for a couple. 2:30 A.M. (TCM) THE CONFORMIST (1970). Bernardo Bertolucci's masterpiece about politics and sex stars Jean-Louis Trintignant as a good Italian Fascist who always does what he's told. Then his superiors instruct him to run an errand while he's in Paris on his honeymoon: shoot and kill an old professor of his. ANITA GATES

headline: PRO FOOTBALL
summary: Pittsburgh Steelers (13-5) at Denver Broncos (14-3) 3 p.m., CBS The surprise here is that the Colts and the Patriots are sitting home while the Broncos and the Steelers, both with strong playoff histories, are playing for the A.F.C. title and a trip to Super Bowl XL. A little more than a month ago, the Steelers were 7-5 and struggling. But with quarterback Ben Roethlisberger healthy again, they are winning. ''We're the same team that went 15-1 last year and made it to the championship game,'' receiver Hines Ward said.
