headline: Today's Matchups
summary: Washington Redskins at Seattle Seahawks 4:30 p.m., Fox Like all the other playoff games this weekend, this is a rematch of a regular-season game. In Week 4, the Redskins beat the Seahawks on a field goal in overtime.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) C.S.I. CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- The fabulous Faye Dunaway guest stars. Ms. Dunaway plays a former Las Vegas showgirl with mob connections who gives a party at which one of the guests ends up dead. Gil Grissom (William Petersen, above, with Ms. Dunaway) is on the case, but the case is a particular problem for his associate Catherine Willows (Marg Helgenberger) because her father (Scott Wilson) is a suspect. 8 P.M. (13) THE NEW ROYALS -- It's easy to forget that in some parts of the world, princes like William and Harry of Britain are more than just movie-star equivalents to fantasize and gossip about. This one-hour National Geographic special takes a look at monarchies (at least 28 still exist) and asks how kings and queens have managed to endure into the 21st century. 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE -- During a dinner date they had really dreaded, Will and Grace get a major surprise. Their waiter is Will's former boyfriend Vince the policeman (Bobby Cannavale). Well, make that the former policeman. 9 P.M. (13) RICKY NELSON SINGS! -- In the late 1950's, as Nelson (1940-85) grew from the irrepressible Ricky into a brooding rock idol, he began doing musical numbers on his parents' squeaky-clean sitcom, ''The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet.'' This one-hour profile includes some of those songs plus interviews with Nelson's children and friends. 9:30 P.M. (Sundance) FACE -- (2002). Bai Ling (left) stars in this drama as a rape victim going home to Queens after many years to reconnect with the daughter (Kristy Wu) born of that crime. The girl, brought up by her grandmother and now graduating from high school, is in love with a D.J. (the rapper Treach). 9:30 P.M. (ABC) CRUMBS -- Suzanne (Jane Curtin) finds the support group for recently divorced people unbelievably boring, so she joins a recovering drug addicts' group instead. 9:30 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE -- Michael (Steve Carell) realizes, for the first time, that his employees may not all adore him. To bond with them, he moves out into the bullpen. 10 P.M. (History) DECLASSIFIED: LINDBERGH -- For decades, there have been reports that Charles Lindbergh (right), America's golden-boy aviator hero, was a Nazi sympathizer and, in fact, thought Hitler was doing a great job. This documentary looks at certain declassified documents to clarify the matter. ANITA GATES

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 China and South Korea Say Trade With North Will Go On Questions over the effectiveness of the Security Council's punitive sanctions on North Korea for its claimed nuclear test grew, as both South Korea and China -- the North's two most important trading partners -- indicated that business and economic relations would largely be unaffected. A1 U.S. Deaths in Iraq Accelerate Two marines were killed by insurgents in Anbar Province, the American military command said, and three American soldiers died a day earlier in a bombing in southern Baghdad, bringing the total of American troop deaths in Iraq this month to at least 53, a rate of almost four a day. A9 7 Killed, 1 Taken in Afghanistan Two Canadian soldiers in the NATO force were killed and three were wounded in an ambush in southern Afghanistan, an Afghan provincial council member was assassinated on his way to work, two police officers were killed near the border with Pakistan, two civilians were killed by a bomb, and an Italian photojournalist was reported to have been kidnapped by gunmen in southern Afghanistan. A6 Israeli Official May Be Charged After a nearly two-month inquiry, the Israeli police released a statement recommending that President Moshe Katsav face charges of rape and sexual assault allegedly committed against several women in his office. Israel's attorney general, Menachem Mazuz, must now decide whether to file such charges. A8 Video Disputes China's Claim A videotape that appears to show Chinese security forces shooting two Tibetan refugees in the Himalayas contradicts Beijing's claim that the refugees were shot when soldiers acted in self-defense. The New China News Agency said soldiers acted after refugees seeking to cross illegally into Nepal from China attacked border troops. A6 The Chinese police have charged a prominent human rights lawyer with inciting subversion, part of a crackdown on people who have sought to use China's nascent legal system to limit the power of the state. He was taken into custody in mid-August, but the police only recently made clear the nature of the charge, his lawyer said. A6 Thai AIDS Patients Shunned Thailand's primary AIDS hospice, once a place of certain death, is now becoming overcrowded by people whose lives have been saved by medication but are rejected by their families or neighbors. Thailand has become a pioneer in distributing low-cost drugs, which are available for all those who need them for less than a dollar per treatment. A8 Pope Names 4 Saints Pope Benedict XVI named four saints, among them two nuns who pioneered schools for women, including schools in the wilds of 19th-century frontier Indiana. The canonization ceremony was the second round of saints named by Benedict since he became pope in April 2005. A4 NATIONAL A12-17 Party Leaders Shift Focus To Winnable Campaigns The choices being made by top Republican and Democratic leaders are setting the strategic framework of the final weeks of Congressional campaigning. They signal, by where they are spending television money and other resources, the Senate and House races where they believe they have the best chance of success. A1 Tony Snow, the White House press secretary and former television commentator and radio host, is using his star power and conservative bona fides in a controversial and unprecedented way: by raising money for Republican candidates. A16 Coast Guard to Arm Lake Boats United States Coast Guard officials want to mount machine guns on their cutters and small boats around the Great Lakes as a counterterrorism measure, and plan to hold live fire exercises on the lakes. Some residents of the lakeside towns consider the idea to be potentially dangerous to ordinary boaters and a surprising place to be bracing for terrorists. A1 Earthquake Rocks Hawaii An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.6 rippled through the Hawaii islands, knocking out electrical power and triggering a landslide that rained boulders and debris on a major highway on the largest island. A12 Power Supply Trails Demand Companies are not building power plants and power lines fast enough to meet growing demand, according to a group recently assigned by the federal government to assure proper operation of the power grid. A14 Players Maintain Innocence Three former Duke University students told the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' that they were falsely accused of raping a woman hired to dance at a lacrosse team party. A14 SCIENCE/HEALTH Scientists Aid Paralyzed Man A team of neuroscientists reported that it had restored some movement and speech to a severely brain-damaged man by stimulating his brain with pulses of electric current. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Pirro and Cuomo Clash In First Televised Debate The New York attorney general's race, one of the most combative and colorful political contests in recent memory, turned ever nastier as the two candidates, Jeanine F. Pirro and Andrew M. Cuomo, spent an hour attacking and undercutting each other in their first televised debate. A1 Final Concert for CBGB Last night was the last concert at CBGB, the famously crumbling rock club that has been in continuous, loud operation since December 1973. It served as the casual headquarters and dank incubator for some of New York's most revered groups, as well as thousands more whose blares left less of a mark on history but whose graffiti and concert fliers might still remain on its walls. B1 Lawyer Faces Sentencing Lynne F. Stewart, the lawyer who was convicted of aiding terrorists almost two years ago, will be sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The prosecution is seeking to condemn Ms. Stewart to 30 years in prison. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-10 Mets Win Evens Series The Mets rolled to a 12-5 victory against the Cardinals in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series at Busch Stadium, evening their best-of-seven series at two games apiece. D1 A New Power on L.P.G.A. Tour In a final-round duel at the Samsung World Championship, one of the L.P.G.A. Tour's biggest tournaments, Lorena Ochoa shot a final-round, seven-under-par 65 to defeat Annika Sorenstam by two shots, signaling a potential power shift on a tour Sorenstam has ruled. D4 ARTS E1-10 Renaissance Panels Tour U.S. Three newly restored panels from the bronze doors known as ''The Gates of Paradise,'' which were designed for the Piazza del Duomo in Florence during the Renaissance, are scheduled to tour North America for the first time. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Advertising on Social Sites Big-name marketers and Internet companies are turning to social networking sites like MySpace, Facebook and YouTube to gain the attention of young people who increasingly avoid television commercials. C1 Lauder Profits from TV Sale Ronald S. Lauder, the art collector and cosmetics heir, has sold half his stake in Central European Media Enterprises for $190 million, making a sizable gain on his investment. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Faith-based profits; an Alzheimer's treatment debunked; great candidates? that's debatable; Orhan Pamuk's Nobel Prize. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 Obituaries B8 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- ''Melinda's First Ghost.'' Melinda Gordon (Jennifer Love Hewitt), friend and enabler to spirits trying to cross over into the next world, flashes back to the first time a dead person asked her for help. It was a little girl (Abigail Breslin, right, a star of ''Little Miss Sunshine,'' the Sundance Film Festival's latest hit) who wanted to communicate with her parents. Anne Archer guest-stars as Melinda's mother, who doesn't want to hear about her daughter's newly discovered powers. 8 P.M. (AMC) THE RIVER WILD (1994). Meryl Streep has never exactly done an action movie, but this one comes close. She plays a former whitewater rafting guide on vacation with her son. A good-looking young man (Kevin Bacon) flirts with her, but it turns out that he and his pal (John C. Reilly) are actually criminals who just want her help in their escape plans. 8 P.M. (FX) THAT 70'S SHOW -- Jessica Simpson (left) stars in this 2002 episode as a California girl who steals the heart of Kelso (Ashton Kutcher). This was a year before MTV's ''Newlyweds'' made Ms. Simpson and Nick Lachey, her husband at the time, famous. 9 P.M. (Logo) ARMISTEAD MAUPIN'S MORE TALES OF THE CITY -- As this 1997 sequel to ''Tales of the City'' begins, several young, single 1970's San Franciscans are out of town. Mary Ann (Laura Linney, before she was a big star) and her best gay friend, Mouse (Paul Hopkins), are on a Mexican cruise, and Mona (Nina Siemaszko) has driven to Nevada and taken a job at a brothel. She's the receptionist. Parts 1 and 2 of 6. 10 P.M. (SHOWTIME) MASTERS OF HORROR: HAECKEL'S TALE -- When Ernest Haeckel (Derek Cecil) takes shelter in a secluded New England cabin, he is clearly told: Whatever happens, do not go outside. Something about the undead. 10 P.M. (USA) MONK -- It's just an average day for Adrian Monk (Tony Shalhoub) and Capt. Leland Stottlemeyer (Ted Levine), investigating a drug dealer's murder. Then a police sergeant claims to be having an affair with the captain's wife (Glenne Headly, right, guest star). Stottlemeyer punches him, then puts Monk on the case. ANITA GATES

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: 'Survivor' Winner's Prison Life Richard Hatch, right, winner of $1 million in the first ''Survivor'' competition on CBS, says he will be tutoring his fellow prison inmates to earn their general equivalency diplomas and polish their job skills while his lawyer works on an appeal of his conviction for failure to pay taxes on his prize and other income, The Associated Press reported. In addition, Mr. Hatch, 45, of Newport, R.I., plans to write a book about his experiences on ''Survivor'' and his legal problems. But in a telephone interview he also told The Dominion Post of Morgantown, W. Va., that when it comes to life in the minimum-security prison where he arrived on July 25 under a 51-month sentence, ''I don't think I will adjust to any of this until I can prove I was unethically prosecuted.'' Mr. Hatch was convicted by a federal jury in January and sentenced in May by a judge who said he had repeatedly lied on the witness stand. Pellicano Named In Wiretapping Suit A lawyer who represented the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian's former wife has sued Mr. Kerkorian's lawyers, contending that they illegally wiretapped his telephone conversations with her during her divorce proceedings, Bloomberg News reported. In a lawsuit filed on Wednesday in Superior Court in Los Angeles, the lawyer, Stephen A. Kolodny, said Mr. Kerkorian's lawyers, Terry N. Christensen and Dennis Wasser, hired Anthony Pellicano, below, a Hollywood private investigator who was indicted in February, to wiretap the calls to gain a tactical advantage in the litigation between their client and his former wife, Lisa Kerkorian. Mr. Kolodny is seeking unspecified damages for invasion of privacy and intentional infliction of emotional distress. In February Mr. Christensen pleaded not guilty to criminal charges that he had paid Mr. Pellicano at least $100,000 to wiretap the telephone of Ms. Kerkorian. In 2002 Mr. Kerkorian and his former wife were involved in a legal dispute over child support. Mr. Christensen's lawyer, Terree A. Bowers, and Mr. Wasser did not immediately respond to calls for comment. Singing Lessons Give Jagger Satisfaction After 35 years without a singing lesson, Mick Jagger, below, has changed his tune. ''Better late than never,'' Mr. Jagger, 63, told Virgin Radio as he readied himself for the Rolling Stones concerts in London on Aug. 20 and 22 as part of the band's ''Bigger Bang'' world tour, Agence France-Presse reported. ''I did a bit of voice coaching a couple of years ago, after 35 years with no voice coaching,'' he said. ''A bit of voice coaching and warm-ups really helps. I always tell these younger singers, 'I never used to do it either, but you should.' '' He added: ''I mean, you sing a lot. Every night you are singing for hours and hours, and your voice gets tired, like anything -- like running every night. That's why you have to warm up properly. I just learned that, so that's probably helped me.'' Royalty and 'High Society' at Newport Jazz Festival Prince Albert II of Monaco will be on hand tonight when the Newport Jazz Festival begins with a concert that is part of an anniversary celebration of the 1956 film ''High Society,'' starring his mother, Grace Kelly, The Associated Press reported. Co-starring Frank Sinatra and Bing Crosby, the film, with Newport, R.I., and its mansions as its backdrop, was the last Kelly made before her marriage to Prince Rainier III. The weekend festivities at the event, established in 1954 and now formally known as the JVC Jazz Festival Newport, include a private dinner-dance gala for Albert, 48, at Marble House, built as a Vanderbilt ''cottage,'' where ''High Society'' will be screened in various rooms. The opening-night concert, a tribute to Sinatra, will feature the guitarist and vocalist John Pizzarelli, who opened concerts for him in the early 1990's. ''There's an extra, added excitement to the whole thing,'' Mr. Pizzarelli said. ''It's more than just a music story, it seems, at this point.'' Philharmonic Opener Is Announced The New York Philharmonic, led by Lorin Maazel, will open its 165th season with a concert and gala on Sept. 13 at Avery Fisher Hall. The event will feature the pianists Emanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman in Mozart's Concerto for Two Pianos in E flat, and also Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture and Symphony No. 3, the ''Eroica.'' The concert will be broadcast on ''Live From Lincoln Center'' on PBS stations. Time Warp for 'Star Wars' The ''Star Wars'' epic runs for more than 13 hours, but George Lucas, below, has given permission to the Reduced Shakespeare Company to condense the proceedings into a 20-minute show, The Guardian of London reported. The Reduced Shakespeare Company has the right stuff. It raced through the ''Complete Works of Shakespeare'' in 97 minutes. Adam Long, who will write, direct and star in ''Star Wars -- Shortened'' with two other actors, said, ''In the space of 20 minutes, I'm going to be Jabba the Hutt, Jar Jar Binks, Darth Vader and Anakin Skywalker.'' The show will be filmed for Sky Movies on Aug. 17 in a performance at the Criterion Theater in London.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Discovery) GRIZZLY MAN (2005). At first, Timothy Treadwell (above) has the air of a noble environmentalist, living among grizzly bears in Alaska and fighting for the preservation of their habitat. But as Werner Herzog's documentary continues, Treadwell seems more and more like a deeply disturbed man, looking for fame while rejecting the civilized world. In 2003, after 13 summers in the wilds, a bear did attack and kill Treadwell and his girlfriend. His friends and family comment. 6 P.M. (TCM) IN WHICH WE SERVE (1942). TCM has started its monthlong salute to the Oscars, with a round-the-clock schedule of Academy Award-winning and nominated films and performances. This war drama, nominated for best picture, is a piece of British propaganda about a battleship, starring, directed (with David Lean) and written by Noël Coward, whose screenplay was also nominated. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE BERNIE MAC SHOW In this awardwinning sitcom's 100th episode (it had its premiere in November 2001), Bernie (Bernie Mac) encourages his nephew Jordan (Jeremy Suarez) to get to know his new neighbor, David (Kyle Kaplan, above right, with Mr. Suarez), because he's Jewish and it will expand Jordan's cultural horizons. David bores Jordan to death at first, until he learns about bar mitzvahs. What could be more culturallyenriching than a huge party -- with gift bags? 8 P.M. (IFC) MAX (2002). John Cusack stars in this historical fantasy as Max Rothman, a Jewish art dealer in post-World War I Germany. He strikes up a friendship with an ambitious young painter named Adolf Hitler (Noah Taylor), who seems to have some personality problems. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS It's bad enough that an expensive piece of equipment has been stolen from a Cal Sci DNA lab. But even worse, the prime suspect is an honors student, a track star and someone who has worked with Don (Rob Morrow) and his math-genius brother Charlie (David Krumholtz). And he may be hiding something. 10 P.M. (USA) MONK Money is on Adrian Monk's mind. But just as Monk (Tony Shalhoub), the lovable obsessivecompulsive detective, is about to ask for a raise, he and his faithful sidekick, Natalie (Traylor Howard, above, with Mr. Shalhoub), learn that the fabulous Alexander Diamond has been stolen from a local museum and there's a $1 million reward. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (CBS) LOVE MONKEY James Blunt (left), the hot new young British rocker, gueststars, playing himself. In this episode, Tom (Tom Cavanagh), a record producer, helps his ex-girlfriend's husband make his first music video. 9 P.M. (9) GET THIS PARTY STARTED Series premiere. Arin and Alexis Jones, sisters and fellow Louisiana State University students, have put their lives on hold since Hurricane Katrina so they can help their family. But Arin and this show's producers have decided that Alexis' 21st birthday should still be celebrated in style. The show, which promises ''life-changing surprises and gifts,'' seems to be yet another 21st-century variation on ''Queen for a Day.'' Instead of a new washing machine, the deserving person gets a splashy party in Las Vegas. 9 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE The baffling diagnosis of the week is what causes a woman taking fertility treatments to develop uncontrollable flailing. Between consultations, Dr. Gregory House (Hugh Laurie) decides, with his onetime love (Sela Ward, above, with Mr. Laurie), whether or not their recent kiss meant anything. A little girl asking about Dr. House's painful leg makes an apt diagnosis of her own: ''Is that why you're so sad?'' House sets her straight: ''I'm not sad. I'm complicated.'' 9 P.M. (Golf) THE BIG BREAK V: HAWAII Season premiere. Eleven undiscovered golfers, all women, go to the island of Oahu and compete for a batch of prizes, including the opportunity to play with the big kids on the L.P.G.A. tour. 9 P.M. (13) SEX SLAVES This ''Frontline'' documentary examines the growth of human trafficking in Eastern Europe. 10 P.M. (13) NEGROES WITH GUNS: ROB WILLIAMS AND BLACK POWER ''Independent Lens'' looks at a forgotten civil rights activist who advocated armed resistance. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL Michael J. Fox continues his guest-starring stint as his terminally ill character decides to hold his funeral while he's still around to be the host. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT A lawyer who moonlighted as a stripper is found murdered in her apartment. The question is which job led to her death. Rebecca De Mornay (right) gueststars as the victim's boss. Betty Buckley guest-stars as the boss's lawyer. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (CBS) WITHOUT A TRACE -- Leah Robinson (Meeghan Holaway) is justa sweet,church going suburban stay at-home mom, her husband and her minister say. So what was she doing at a Manhattan gallery opening with another man? Investigating her disappearance, Jack and Anne (Anthony LaPaglia and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, above) learn about a disgruntled client and Leah's husband's socalled hunting trip, which involved a waitress. 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE -- ''The Definition of Marriage.'' Grace is busy preparing for her green-card wedding to Will's new boyfriend (Taye Diggs). This is Grace's third, you know, if you count the runawaybride incident in the pilot in 1998. Karen hires Hall and Oates to sing ''Maneater.'' 8 P.M. (Discovery Times) ONLY IN AMERICA: THE REAL 8 MILE -- Charlie LeDuff, a reporter for The New York Times, visits Detroit to investigate its hip-hop scene. 8 P.M. (9) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- On Valentine's Day, the only cards that young Chris receives are nasty ones from the school bully. But all is not lost: he's falling in love with Tangee (Raven Goodwin), a girl he sees on the bus. (Above: Tyler James Williams as Chris with Tichina Arnold as his mother.) 8:30 P.M. (NBC) FOUR KINGS -- Ben (Josh Cooke) gets an assignment for New York magazine. Unfortunately it's an article about his roommate Jason (Todd Grinnell) and the building full of low-income tenants that he's evicting. Their other two roommates (Shane McRae and Seth Green) befriend a couple of older ladies but forget to define ''befriend.'' Clearly, the young men never saw ''Midnight Cowboy.'' 9 P.M. (Sundance) LADETTE TO LADY -- In the second week of their course in becoming more ladylike, the ladettes (who have been seen getting drunk at their local pubs and grabbing men's crotches) have to prepare a five-course dinner for some refined eligible bachelors. Flower arranging goes fairly well, but there is belching at the wine tasting and one queasy young woman can't deal with gutting the scallops. Naturally, dessert is a soufflé. 9:30 P.M. -- (NBC) THE OFFICE -- America's most appalling boss (Steve Carell) pays a visit to New York. He's spending Valentine's Day at corporate headquarters. (Above: Mr. Carell with, from left, Angela Kinsey, Kate Flannery, Phyllis Smith and Jenna Fischer as his colleagues.) ANITA GATES

headline: G.O.P. Sets Aside Work on Immigration
summary: As they prepare for a critical pre-election legislative stretch, Congressional Republican leaders have all but abandoned a broad overhaul of immigration laws and instead will concentrate on national security issues they believe play to their political strength. With Congress reconvening Tuesday after an August break, Republicans in the House and Senate say they will focus on Pentagon and domestic security spending bills, port security legislation and measures that would authorize the administration's terror surveillance program and create military tribunals to try terror suspects.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BROWN, HELEN MARIE
summary: BROWN--Helen Marie, lifetime resident of New York City, graduate of Hunter College, President and Executive Director of the CBS Company Foundation and esteemed mentor and colleague to generations of philanthropy professionals, died December 29th, 2005 at home in Manhattan. The daughter of John Brown and Margaret Wade, Helen was predeceased by her sister Jean. Arrangements were private. For further information contact John Krtil Funeral Home.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Leaves 'Lost' a Wreck
summary: The 90-minute ''American Idol'' on Wednesday, when the top 10 male contestants performed, continued to steamroll the competition. The talent show's 29.18 million viewers put Fox far ahead in first place in Nielsen's estimates. The network's premiere of ''Free Ride'' followed ''Idol'' and lost more than half of its audience; the slacker comedy drew 14.24 million viewers. On ABC, ''Lost'' suffered from ''Idol'' encroachment into the 9 p.m. time period. The plane crash mystery delivered its lowest ratings for an original episode this season, with 16.34 million viewers. Following ''Lost,'' ABC's ''Barbara Walters Special'' (10.26 million), decoupled from its usual platform before the Academy Awards, took third place behind both CBS's ''CSI: New York'' (13.73 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order'' (12.41 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Venezuelan Leader Spends To Counter U.S. Aims President Hugo Chávez is spending billions of dollars of his country's oil windfall abroad, subsidizing samba parades in Brazil, eye surgery for poor Mexicans, and even heating fuel for poor families in parts of the United States. Mr. Chávez has been building a bulwark against what he has called American imperialistic aims in Latin America. A1 Highest U.S. Toll in Iraq for '06 In the deadliest day for American forces since the beginning of the year, three Marines and one sailor were killed in a rebel assault in Anbar Province. In another part of Anbar, a flash flood toppled a seven-ton truck, killing five Marines riding inside it and wounding one, the military said. A10 Trail Links Sydney to Iraq Graft A hearing into accusations that the Australian companyAWB Ltd., paid kickbacks to Saddam Hussein under the United Nations oil-for-food program was delayed while lawyers in Sydney examined documents over the weekend. A10 Liberian Denies War Crimes In his first appearance before the international tribunal trying him on 11 counts of war crimes, Charles Taylor, the former Liberian president, pleaded not guilty. A3 Canada Ends Marijuana Plan Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced a scrapping of legislation to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana, a measure that had been strongly criticized by the Bush administration. A12 U.N. Aide Blocked from Sudan Sudan has blocked Jan Egeland, the United Nations' top emergency aid official, from visiting western Darfur this week, prompting Mr. Egeland to accuse Khartoum of trying to hide conditions there. A3 NATIONAL A14-20 Ensnared in Scandal, DeLay to Quit Congress Representative Tom DeLay, the relentless Texan who helped lead House Republicans to power but became ensnared in a corruption scandal, has decided to leave Congress, House officials said. A1 Supreme Court Declines Case Jose Padilla, the American citizen held for more than three years as an enemy combatant, fell a vote short of persuading the Supreme Court to take his case. The result left standing a lower court ruling that affirmed the government's power to seize and hold a citizen indefinitely. A1 A federal jury found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths that occurred during the Sept. 11 attacks and is thus eligible to be executed. A1 Standoff on Benefits Programs President Bush and the Senate are at an impasse over the appointment of trustees for Social Security and Medicare, crippling the panel that supervises the two programs. A14 E.P.A. Proposal Is Criticized A draft regulation on emissions from oil refineries, chemical plants and other industrial operations has angered regional directors of the Environmental Protection Agency. A20 Handling Terrorism at Sea A report released by the Department of Justice inspector general warned that potentially disastrous confusion could arise during a terrorist attack on a cruise ship or ferry because of a power struggle between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Coast Guard. A17 Tornadoes Ravage Midwest Thunderstorms that spawned produced up to a half-mile wide roared across the Midwest and South, killing at least 27 people, injuring hundreds, destroying thousands of homes and businesses and leaving tens of thousands without electricity.A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Synagogues Attempt A More Hip Approach Jewish religious leaders, driven by fears about shrinking numbers, are becoming increasingly sophisticated and aggressive about marketing Judaism, turning to the same kinds of outreach techniques and strategies that evangelical Christians rode to mega-church success. A1 Medicine and Connections A report released by a federal monitor has found that patronage hiring was so pervasive at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, that job applications were marked with a numeral indicating the potency of the applicants' political connections. B1 Politicians' Pet Projects Two reports examining the state budget show that lawmakers in Albany have charged allocations, which state officials call member items or economic development funds and critics call pork, totaling nearly a million dollars, to the expense of New York taxpayers. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Working Organs Built in the Lab Bladders created in the laboratory from a patient's own cells and then implanted in seven young people have achieved good long-term results in all of them, a team of researchers reported. F6 Health & Fitness F5 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-8 Florida Wins Championship The Florida basketball team began this season unranked with a roster full of talented but unproven players. The Gators ended it by winning the N.C.A.A. championship with a score of 73-57 over U.C.L.A. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 G.M. Board Backs Its Chief The board of General Motors expressed support for its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, and announced a long-anticipated deal to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, GMAC, for $7.4 billion. C1 CBS Anchor Deal Said Near CBS may reach a deal this week to recruit Katie Couric away from NBC's ''Today'' show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News, people close to the negotiations said. C1 Enron's Defense Testimony The Enron trial has moved to the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executives who are accused of fraud and conspiracy. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The high court punts; flunking the oil addiction test; Mr. Schröder's gag test; Verlyn Klinkenborg on John McGahern. headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC Shows Trump the Art of 'Deal'
summary: After the final two women left on ''The Apprentice'' turned on each other in last week's episode, Donald Trump decided to fire them both for disloyal behavior. That left Sean and Lee as the finalists, and the two men competed in Monday's penultimate episode. NBC's ''Apprentice'' did not benefit from being one of the few original offerings on the prime-time schedule; in Nielsen's estimates, it brought in 9.63 million viewers, in line with its average for this edition. But NBC performed steadily, and its ''Deal or No Deal'' rerun at 8 p.m. was the night's most-watched show, with 13.66 million viewers, making the network No. 1 among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. On ABC the fourth game of the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference finals was broadcast live, so its ratings were preliminary. But it appeared to put the network in a tie with CBS for second place in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; After the Olympics
summary: NBC won all three Fridays during the Olympics with relative ease. Last Friday, the network unveiled a rejiggered lineup featuring the move of ''Las Vegas'' from Tuesday and ''Conviction,'' the new legal drama from Dick Wolf, the creator of ''Law & Order.'' The schedule gained ground on CBS, which has dominated Friday nights all season, but didn't manage to win outright. NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, with an average of 11.04 million viewers in primetime. (''Las Vegas'' drew 10.87 million and ''Conviction'' 10.15 million.) But CBS managed to bring in 11.88 million; its biggest draw was ''Ghost Whisperer'' with Jennifer Love Hewitt (12.28 million) at 8 p.m., which faced down NBC's game show ''Deal or No Deal'' (12.09 million). Without the Friday results show of ''Dancing With the Stars,'' ABC fell to third place for the night. Its ''In Justice'' particularly suffered from the absence of ''Dancing,'' bringing in only 6.6 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE -- (1962). What lies beneath? That's the question on nearly everyone's mind in John Frankenheimer's Cold War noir about a Korean war hero (Laurence Harvey) who returns home with an agenda, one that's hidden even from him. Frank Sinatra plays a comrade whose dreams have infiltrated his reality. Angela Lansbury (above, with Harvey) is mommy dearest. 8 P.M. (History) VICTORIAN REBORN -- In this ''Save Our History'' special, Steve Thomas documents the efforts to revive the George Barber-designed McCubbins-McCanless House in Salisbury, N.C., from the cracks in its foundation to the tip of its crumbling chimney. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) KRAKEN: TENTACLES OF THE DEEP -- Movie buffs named this one by voting on the channel's Web site in July. The premise: a marine biologist and a couple of sailors go in search of vast riches watched over by a beast of terrifying proportions (above) -- the same creature that killed one's parents years before, but not before their son gouged out an eye. You get the picture. Victoria Pratt, Jack Scalia and Charlie O'Connell, perhaps best known as ''The Bachelor'' of Season 7, play the daring trio. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICA'S MOST WANTED: AMERICA FIGHTS BACK -- This show just keeps adding notches to its belt. Tonight, police use DNA evidence to link a man who attacked a homeless woman in New York to three attempted rapes in Miami. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MALE, 33, SEEKS PUBERTY -- Danger: raging hormones. In this documentary, Lawrence Koomson, a London doctor, undergoes treatment to increase his testosterone from the level found in a 12-year-old boy to that of a grown man, in only a year. 10 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS MYSTERY -- Was it the butler in the galley or the captain in the private dining room? In this first whodunit of the 10th season, an aspiring actress is found dead in her cruise-ship cabin. 11 P.M. (Fox) MAD TV -- What's that you say? Tonight's guest, Howie Mandel (left) of ''Deal or No Deal,'' leaves behind his hotline and suitcases to join Bobby Lee in a ''24'' spoof; the rapper Chingy performs. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (WE) SKATING'S NEXT STAR -- Reality-competition figure skating brought in the ratings for Fox's ''Skating With celebrities.'' In this variation, 12 skaters who have tried for stardom before but failed receive a second chance. Tonight each will have only 60 seconds on the ice to impress the judges. In the next two episodes they'll compete to be the fastest spinner and do the best reverse axel. Kristi Yamaguchi (above), the Olympic gold medalist, is host. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Season premiere. The escape plan failed, and now the men have to get back to their cells unseen. Lincoln's execution is hours away, but his brother has a plan. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS -- Kevin hates Carrie's new short haircut. Robert Goulet guest-stars as himself and stirs up trouble about it. Mr. Goulet is the entertainment on a cruise that Kevin and Carrie financed with the money the wigmaker paid for her long, luxurious hair. One shudders to think that this episode might have been inspired by O. Henry's ''Gift of the Magi.'' 9 P.M. (Lifetime) SAFE HARBOR -- Tracey Gold (right), who came of age as the brainy Carol Seaver on ABC's ''Growing Pains,'' stars in this television movie as a detective investigating a series of satanic murders. Strangely, all the victims once spent time in the same foster home where she grew up. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Alan (Jon Cryer) still -- inexplicably -- has that young girlfriend, but he's getting tired of paying her bills. 9 P.M. (NBC) THE APPRENTICE -- Well, every project can't be sexy. Tonight the would-be Donald Trump employees design billboards for a cereal. 9 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- ''Day 5: 8 P.M. - 9 P.M.'' Interpol gets into the act. Homeland Security tries to change Counter Terrorist Unit protocol. Everyone is after Bierko the billionaire terrorist (Julian Sands). The wacky but smart first lady (Jean Smart) questions the administration's decisions. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: MIAMI -- A group of women have their relaxing visit to a luxurious day spa interrupted by a robbery. Marisol Delko (Alana De La Garza, right), the beautiful sister of Detective Eric Delko (Adam Rodriguez), was at the spa and is now in danger because she was a witness. ANITA GATES

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: WARNING FOR SLEEPING PILLS -- The most widely prescribed sleeping pills, including Ambien and Lunesta, can cause strange behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration said, announcing that strong new warnings would be placed on the labels of 13 drugs. [Page A1.] G.M.'S MIXED PICTURE -- General Motors reported its largest quarterly profit in two and a half years. But it still lost $2 billion last year, the second consecutive year of multibillion-dollar losses. Market Place. [C1.] CHARGES DROPPED IN H.P. CASE -- A judge dismissed charges against Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, in a corporate spying case that gained national attention. H.P.'s shareholders, at their annual meeting, appeared to give Mark V. Hurd, the new chairman, a vote of confidence and indicated they felt that last year's problems were now behind the company. [C1.] H&R BLOCK'S SUBPRIME PROBLEM -- The tax-preparation giant H&R Block became another victim of problems plaguing the subprime mortgage industry, reporting quarterly losses of $60 million. [C1.] HARVARD'S INVESTOR -- Mohamed El-Erian, who manages Harvard University's $30 billion endowment, has brought an international flair and bond expertise to the job since arriving one year ago. [C1.] A BID TO CURB A REFRIGERANT -- A coalition of industrial and developing countries has begun pushing for stringent limits on the world's most popular refrigerant for air-conditioners, as evidence mounts that it harms the earth's ozone layer and contributes to global warming. [C3.] A CLEANER COAL-FIRED PLANT -- American Electric Power, a major electric utility, is planning the largest demonstration yet of capturing carbon dioxide from a coal-fired power plant and pumping it deep underground. [C3.] IMPORTS DOWN; EXPORTS UP -- The current-account deficit shrank in the fourth quarter of 2006 to its smallest in more than a year as lower oil prices took a bite out of imports and exports continued to rise. [C4.] CANCELING A CONTRACT -- The Coast Guard said it was canceling a contract with Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman to develop a vessel for a range of missions. [A25.] MISSING MEDICAL DATA FOUND -- A missing compact disc containing sensitive medical and personal information on 75,000 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield members was recovered. [C2.] AVON'S AT THE DOOR -- Avon, the cosmetics retailer known for the perky commercials that began with the ringing of a doorbell followed by the words ''Avon calling,'' is now starting the largest campaign in its 121-year history. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] NATIONAL MAGAZINE AWARDS -- The finalists for the National Magazine Award for general excellence were announced, and among the publications in the running is The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the journal with the so-called Doomsday Clock on the cover. [C4.] BLAME THE HEDGE FUNDS -- The recent volatility and pullback in Asian markets have prompted some investors to sound a familiar refrain: It's all the fault of the hedge funds. [C9.] DOW ENDS UP -- Wall Street closed with a respectable advance, though the Dow Jones industrial average initially fell as much as 136 points, and briefly dropped below 12,000. [C11.] LEHMAN PROFIT UP 5.6 PERCENT -- Lehman Brothers Holdings, the global investment bank, said that robust trading and overseas expansion drove its first-quarter profit up 5.6 percent, matching Wall Street's expectations. [C4.] A STEP TOWARD PRIVACY -- Google said it would take steps to make anonymous the logs its keeps of all searches that people conduct. [C4.] SEARCHING VIA SPOKEN WORD -- Microsoft said that it had agreed to buy Tellme Networks and its voice-recognition software. The purchase gives Microsoft voice-recognition programs it can combine with mobile phone applications. Steven A. Ballmer, above, the Microsoft chief executive, said that search on cellphones would be a battlegrounds between Microsoft and Google. [C5.] GOOGLE COMES TO TOWN -- Residents of Lenoir, N.C., an Appalachian furniture-making area that has lost thousands of jobs, may have gotten some good news: Google is building a ''server farm,'' a building full of computers, in their town. [A18.] HELP WANTED UNDER THE HOOD -- There are not enough qualified auto mechanics in New York, in part because the rapid computerization of car engines that has prompted many senior mechanics to retire. So the city's Department of Education and union leaders are holding free classes for anyone who wants to learn the trade. [B1.] ONLINE ALL ABOUT EXECUTIVE PAY -- Sumner M. Redstone's compensation for his role as chairman of CBS will be reduced after a shareholder lawsuit. At Citigroup, Charles O. Prince was paid $25.98 million for his work in 2006, an increase of about 13 percent over 2005. More news about executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business. WEEKEND BUSINESS -- In a podcast, reporters and editors from The Times's Sunday Business section offer perspective on the week in business and beyond. Information on subscribing is at nytimes.com/business.

headline: A Rocky Start For British REITs
summary: AFTER much fanfare, legislation creating real estate investment trusts in Britain, one of Europe's biggest property markets, took effect on Jan. 1. Almost immediately, nine of the country's largest real estate companies converted to REITs, while five others made the switch soon after and a handful more plan to follow suit by year-end. In the months leading up to the big debut, expectations ran high, with the hope that Britain's already-strong commercial real estate industry would further flourish. A REIT market, after all, could attract more investors globally and make it easier for the local companies to raise capital. (The corporate structure gives real estate investment trusts favorable tax treatment in exchange for disbursing most of their income to shareholders as dividends.)

headline: An Admirer of America Sets a New Course for France
summary: Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in France's deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls in the nearby pasture stayed away. ''A vague resemblance to the look of George W. Bush on his Texan ranch,'' is how the left-leaning newspaper Libération described Mr. Sarkozy, who was elected president on Sunday, beating the Socialist candidate Ségolène Royal in a runoff. The newspaper dismissed the event as a media stunt, saying, ''Everything for the image, right up until the last minute.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE: SAY GOODNIGHT GRACIE -- Pull out the tissues for this sentimental journey as the cast muses over its eight effervescent seasons as New York's resident odd couple and best friends. At 9, the series and its stars (above, from left, Eric McCormack, Megan Mullally, Debra Messing and Sean Hayes) bid adieu in an hourlong finale. After which life as we know it will be a lot more, uh, sober. 8 P.M. (Fox) THAT '70'S SHOW -- Tonight, Kelso (Ashton Kutcher) and his old gang are gonna party like it's 1979 in this series finale. But what happens when they wake up in the morning and it's 1980? 8 P.M. (11) DRUMLINE (2002). Nick Cannon plays a self-righteous drummer from Harlem at odds with the fierce regimentation of the marching band at the historically black college where he's a student -- and where the whole point of a Saturday afternoon football game is the halftime show. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- The team ponders the fashion choices of a wasp-waisted stiff with a fondness for corsets. Meanwhile, the life of another member is in the hands of a colleague. 9 P.M. (Fox) THE O.C. -- Season finale. With graduation comes change. And the lives of Seth, Ryan, Marissa (Mischa Barton, near left, with Rachel Bilson as Summer) and even Sandy are about to. 9 P.M. (ABC) AMERICAN INVENTOR -- In this ''finale results show,'' the inventor with the most votes receives $1 million. (And just maybe they could use part of the money to dream up a new wardrobe for Doug Hall, that ever-eccentric judge, next season.) 9:30 P.M. (BET) SEASON OF THE TIGER -- Eva, a freshman drummer, challenges Shunnie, the master drill sergeant, to a battle of the beat in this real-life version of ''Drumline,'' set amid the athletes and musicians on the football field of Grambling State University in Louisiana. 10 P.M. (NBC) ER -- Season finale. A very pregnant Abby (Maura Tierney) finds herself in the line of fire when County General turns into a war zone after a couple of injured inmates arrive, hoping for get-out-of-jail-free cards. Sounds like they've been watching ''Prison Break.'' 10 P.M. (CBS) WITHOUT A TRACE -- Talk about making an exit. In this season finale, Jason Priestley (right), playing a murder victim's former boyfriend, does, and it's not pretty. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- Loose lips sink ships, or at least fashion magazines. Amanda, Marc and Betty (above,from left, Becki Newton, Michael Urie and America Ferrera) fear for their jobs when a rival magazine copies Mode's big Christmas photo spread -- you know, the one they were blabbing about at happy hour. 5 P.M. (9) THE TYRA BANKS SHOW -- Ms. Banks looks at body-image disorders including trance eating and bigorexia, an obsession, typically affecting men, with being muscular. 8 P.M. (Military) CELEBRITIES IN UNIFORM -- Atten-hut! A look at the famous types who suited up for their country in times of conflict. 8 P.M. (Travel) PASSPORT TO EUROPE WITH SAMANTHA BROWN -- Ms. Brown rocks on in Reykjavik, Iceland. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Earl encounters No. 50 on his list -- an elderly man whom he and Randy made the lead singer in their rock band, but then booted before the first concert because he scared the women -- while Joy does community service at a senior citizens center to polish her image for an upcoming trial. And then he runs into No. 51, Randy's mother. Hmmm. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- Religious differences? Sara (Jorja Fox, right) and the team uncover a bizarre love triangle at the bottom of the murder of a woman in a church. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- Tonight, Bailey treats a young mother battling breast cancer, Derek gets the dish on Mark and Addison's relationship, and the interns go to bat for a resident whose competency is questioned at a staff meeting. 9 P.M. (Travel) JOAN CUSACK'S LOCAL FLAVOR -- Ms. Cusack crinkles up her pretty nose to go truffle hunting in Italy and visits the Tasty Tuscany cooking school. 10 P.M. (Discovery Health) STRICTLY DR. DREW -- Dr. Drew Pinsky discusses some of the weighty issues connected to obesity in America. 10 P.M. (NBC) ER -- Dr. Kovac tries to remember how he treated a stroke patient (Forest Whitaker, in a guest role) in preparation for court. 10 P.M. (Travel) MOMS ON THE ROAD: AFRICA -- The eight American mothers go on safari in the Etosha National Park in Namibia, where they encounter an endangered black rhino. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Twice as nice. Sally Field talks about her roles in both ''Brothers & Sisters'' and ''ER''; Ruud Kleinpaste, a k a the Bug Man, shows off some of his favorite exotic creatures; and Kevin Federline (above) performs. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Nascar Smooths Fox's Ride
summary: Nascar spilled into prime time on Sunday, which meant that Fox won the night among adults 18 to 49. After the race, repeats of Fox's animated comedies either won or tied their half-hour slots in that demographic. In Nielsen's estimates, a 9 p.m. ''Family Guy'' (6.61 million) was second only to the Nascar broadcast among 18-to-49-year-olds. In the total viewer category, CBS won easily. Its ''60 Minutes'' (9.25 million) was the most-watched show of the night, and a rerun of ''Cold Case'' (8.22 million) also brought in a large audience for a summer Sunday. ABC, which dominated Sundays during the regular season, placed third in the 18-to-49 demographic and fourth, behind NBC, among total viewers. Its repeats of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 p.m. (6.07 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' at 10 p.m. (6.61 million) fared well, but the ''Desperate Housewives'' rerun (4.51 million) sandwiched between them wiped out. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC) DAY BREAK -- Giving added meaning to rise and shine, this new series, in which Taye Diggs plays Detective Brett Hopper, who has been framed for murder on what proves to be a very bad day. Only now Hopper has to relive that same day over and over again until he can figure out why his life is broken -- and how he can fix it. Moon Bloodgood (above, with Mr. Diggs) plays Hopper's girlfriend Rita Shelton. Turns out she's the ex-wife of his former partner, Chad Shelton (Adam Baldwin), who knows a lot more about this state of affairs than he's willing to admit. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- It's dark down here: Brennan (Emily Deschanel) becomes the next victim of a serial killer who buries his victims alive and leaves them to die if his ransom demands are not met. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS -- And the Fancy Feet award goes to . . . 8 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF THE DEAD -- A look at the creation, testing and deployment of ''bouncing bombs'' designed to destroy dams and impede German steel production during World War II. 8 P.M. (Travel) JAMIE'S GREAT ITALIAN ESCAPE -- In the latest episode in this foodie adventure series, Jamie Oliver boards his camper and heads to a Benedictine monastery in Farfa, north of Rome, where he tries to put a little spice into the monks' gardens, kitchens and dining rooms. 9 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Well, that's one way to get your girl back. In this season premiere, Allison's former lover (Thomas Jane) moves into the Dubois house after his death. Meanwhile, Allison (Patricia Arquette, above) discovers that she and her daughter are having the same strange dreams. 9 P.M. (Food Network) ULTIMATE THANKSGIVING FEAST -- Get out your recipe cards and start taking notes. In this special, four chefs have five hours to turn out a holiday meal for a shot at $10,000. On the menu: a signature turkey plus five side dishes. 9 P.M. (BET) BET HIPHOP AWARDS -- Katt Williams is host of this inaugural ceremony honoring excellence in hip-hop, taped earlier this month at the Fox Theater in Atlanta. Among the nominees: T.I., Yung Joc, Missy Elliott, Busta Rhymes, Kanye West, Jay-Z, Nelly, Diddy and (from above left), Young Jeezy, Ludacris and Jermaine Dupri. Grandmaster Flash goes home with the I Am Hip-Hop Icon award. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- Mercy killing: A young woman is murdered in her hospital bed following a car accident she caused while driving drunk. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Laughter Is Good Medicine for NBC
summary: ''Last Comic Standing'' returned to NBC Tuesday night after being absent from the summer schedule last year. The comedy reality competition was a hit for the network in summer 2004, but when NBC rushed another edition into production at the end of that season, it bombed. But the two-hour premiere delivered a respectable audience of 8.51 million in Nielsen's estimates, and along with a rerun of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.49 million) helped NBC easily win the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was No. 1 in total viewers, with episodes of ''NCIS'' (11.12 million) and ''The Unit'' (9.15 million) repeating well. At 10 p.m., a new ''48 Hours Mystery,'' which has moved to that time slot for the summer, brought in 9.59 million viewers and tied ''SVU'' in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; The Heat Builds In 'Hell's Kitchen'
summary: The second season of Fox's ''Hell's Kitchen'' made its debut on Monday, and Gordon Ramsay, the screaming chef, divided the teams by sex, made them crawl around in garbage and got rid of three competitors. (Two were eliminated; one left because of too much stress.) The cooking contest won the night for Fox among adults 18 to 49 and delivered 6.7 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. It built steadily from its first half-hour at 8 p.m. (5.5 million viewers) to its last at 9:30 p.m. (7.9 million). CBS's night of repeats placed first among viewers, and second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Its ''CSI: Miami'' rerun at 10 p.m. was the night's most-watched show, with 13.4 million viewers. That trampled the series premiere of ABC's ''How to Get the Guy,'' a dating reality show, which drew a mere 4.3 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating system and its own. That means a single Apple computer will run the universe of programs written for either the Mac or Windows. Apple's stock jumped almost 10 percent on the news. [Page A1.] Apple's announcement helped lead the overall market higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 35.70 points, to 11,239.55. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.63 points, to finish at 1,311.56. The Nasdaq Composite index climbed 14.39 points, or 0.61 percent, to close at 2,359.75. [C11.] Jury Orders Merck to Pay $4.5 Million in Damages In a serious blow to Merck, a jury in New Jersey awarded $3 million to a man who had a heart attack after taking Vioxx for four years, and an additional $1.5 million to his wife. [C1.] Coca-Cola Announces Unusual Pay Plan for Directors The Coca-Cola Company announced an unusual plan for paying outside directors: If earnings per share do not rise fast enough over a three-year period, directors will get nothing. But they will get a raise from what they used to get if earnings do perform as expected. While many companies pay directors all or part of their pay in stock or stock options, Coca-Cola appears to be the first to have adopted a plan that will pay directors nothing if the company does not perform well. Market Place. [C1.] Couric Confirms That She Will Move to CBS Katie Couric announced that she would leave her job as co-host of NBC's ''Today'' show, a job she has held for 15 years, to take the riskier but historically significant step of becoming the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News.'' [A1.] As Katie Couric prepares to ascend to anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' she will be moving into a world that for several years has emphasized softer features. Still, some people in the business agree that it will be her ability to direct and deliver so-called hard news that will determine whether she is able to move CBS from its longtime spot in last place among the three network newscasts and to attract younger viewers. [C1.] Media buyers are asking: When Katie Couric jumps to the ''CBS Evening News,'' will advertising dollars follow? [C5.] In Massachusetts, a Rare Consensus on Health Care Massachusetts has more than its share of political egos per capita, so one of the most surprising things about this week's legislation creating near-universal health care coverage is that it involved the cooperation of virtually every political stakeholder in the state. News Analysis. [A16.] Online Answer to High Drug Costs Runs Into Problems Canadian online pharmacies -- hailed as an alternative to multinational drug giants -- have been swamped by problems that have cut into sales and forced some of them out of business. [C1.] Criminal Charges in Britain Over Drug Prices Five pharmaceutical companies and nine executives are facing criminal charges of conspiracy to defraud the British National Health Service, after an investigation into prices of antibiotics and blood-clotting drugs. [C13.] Chinese Officials Plan to Show Buying Prowess in U.S. Chinese leaders, eager to improve relations with the United States ahead of a visit by President Hu Jintao this month, have dispatched a large delegation of business and economic officials to display China's buying power and to cool protectionist sentiment in Congress. [A8.] Thales of France to Acquire Alcatel Units Thales, the French military contractor and electronics company, said that it had agreed to buy satellite and security businesses from Alcatel for cash and stock worth about 1.7 billion euros ($2.1 billion) to keep the operations in French hands. The deal comes days after Alcatel agreed to buy Lucent Technologies of New Jersey. [C6.] Poland Reaches Deal With Italian Bank Breaking an impasse that had stained its image and put it on a collision course with the European Union, the Polish government reached an agreement with the giant Italian bank UniCredito that allows two Polish banks to be combined under their Italian ownership. Under the deal, UniCredito agreed to sell 200 of the 480 branches of Bank BPH, the big Polish financial institution it acquired last year through its purchase of the HVB Group of Germany. UniCredito's chief executive, Alessandro Profumo, above, said selling the branches ''won't be easy, but the sale will be a clear and transparent process, held internationally.'' [C6.] Lawmakers Seek Compromise on Immigration With the prospect of a legislative failure looming, Senate Republicans and Democrats struggled to hammer out a compromise on an immigration bill that would affect the fate of the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants. [A21.] Russian 'Wine Blockade' Ignites Trade Conflict Popular wines from Georgia and Moldova have been banned from Russian shelves, spurring a trade dispute. [A12.] Ford Chief Says Company Has Plenty of Cash William Clay Ford Jr., the chief executive of Ford Motor, said that he was confident that the automaker could solve its financial problems and said that a bankruptcy filing was not an option. [C3.]

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Madonna: Did She or Didn't She? Madonna and her husband, the British filmmaker Guy Ritchie, visited an orphanage yesterday in southern Malawi, Reuters reported, after her spokeswoman denied reports by local government officials that the singer was planning to adopt a 1-year-old boy in the impoverished and AIDS-stricken African country and was seeking their help in the adoption. Madonna, right, did not talk to reporters yesterday, but some officials continued to insist she was going to adopt a local child. Amid the assertions and denials, Henry Chimunthu Banda, Malawi's minister of energy, mines and natural resources, said the government would say nothing more until he met Madonna today on behalf of the president, Bingu wa Mutharika. Streisand Tour Begins Singing hits like ''Funny Girl'' and ''Come Rain or Come Shine'' and ridiculing President Bush before a capacity crowd of 16,000, Barbra Streisand began her first United States tour in 12 years on Wednesday in the Wachovia Center in South Philadelphia, Reuters reported. Ms. Streisand, left, said she was emerging from retirement at 64 to raise money for her foundation, which supports causes related to the environment, education, health care and the like. The show featured a skit in which an actor portraying Mr. Bush delivered lines including ''If I cared about the polls, I would have run for president of Poland'' and ''I'm concerned about the national debt, so I'm selling Canada.'' For Couric, the News Is Good and Not So Good How is Katie Couric doing after a month of anchoring the ''CBS Evening News''? There are two answers. Judged in terms of the audience of adults from 25 to 54 --a demographic favored by advertisers -- she is doing fine. After four weeks, Ms. Couric, left, has given her network its first monthly victory over NBC and ABC in nearly 20 years, Reuters reported. But in terms of total viewers, the CBS newscast finished the last week of September just where it has languished for more than a decade, in third place. The weekly average, 7.5 million viewers, was closer than in the past to ABC, the second-place network. With Ms. Couric and her estimated $15 million annually salary in the limelight, the three network newscasts are battling for $450 million in advertising revenue and a nightly audience of some 25 million viewers. Berlin to Examine 'Idomeneo' Security The city government of Berlin said yesterday that it would soon reassess the security risks surrounding the Deutsche Oper production of Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' canceled last month for fear of outraging Muslims, The Associated Press reported. ''The risk assessment will happen soon,'' said Tatjana Pohl, a spokeswoman for the Berlin state interior ministry. She declined to specify the timing, but said a security plan would be drawn up if the opera company decided to reschedule the production, featuring a scene involving the severed heads of Jesus, Muhammad and Buddha. Alexander Busche, a spokesman for the Deutsche Oper, said it was waiting for the risk assessment and said that even with new assurances of safety, the opera could not go on again before December. Sentencing in Theft Of Gardner Heirlooms A 43-year-old woman has been sentenced to 30 months' probation for stealing family heirlooms and original Frank Sinatra recordings among more than $1 million in property from the estate of the actress Ava Gardner, right, The Associated Press reported. In Winston-Salem, N.C., the woman, Angela Renee Sykes, entered a so-called Alford plea to the charge, not admitting guilt but acknowledging that the evidence was likely to lead to her conviction, The Winston-Salem Journal reported. The prosecutors said that Ms. Sykes took the property between 2001 and 2005, when she was working as a nurse for Myra Pearce, Gardner's older sister and closest living relative, who inherited the estate after Gardner's death in 1990. Forsyth County Superior Court Judge Henry Frye Jr. suspended Ms. Sykes's sentence of six to eight months but demanded that she help recover the items she took. Ms. Sykes has maintained that she is entitled to the property. Honors for Herzog And de Meuron The Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron, below from left, whose projects have included the Tate Modern museum in London, have won the Royal Gold Medal, given in recognition of a lifetime's work and approved personally by Queen Elizabeth II. The announcement of the award, recognizing the impact of Herzog & de Meuron on cities and architects, was made yesterday by Jack Pringle, president of the Royal Institute of British Architects. Their projects in the United States include the Walker Art Center expansion in Minneapolis, the new de Young Museum in San Francisco, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y., and the Miami Art Museum. Footnotes The Rolling Stones will perform at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan on Oct. 29 and 31. Guns N' Roses will perform on Nov. 5 at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., and on Nov. 10 at Madison Square Garden. Nellie McKay, who was dropped by Columbia Records earlier this year, will release her new album, ''Pretty Little Head'' on her own label, Hungry Mouse. ''Pretty Little Head'' will be available digitally on Oct. 24 and in stores on Oct. 31. The two-CD set features duets with K. D. Lang and Cyndi Lauper. The four-time Tony Award winner Audra McDonald will usher in 2007 when she sings standards by Ellington, Gershwin and others with the New York Philharmonic at its New Year's Eve gala on Dec. 31. The ''Live From Lincoln Center'' performance, with Beverly Sills as its host, will be broadcast on PBS.

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Top Spot for 'Dance'
summary: A two-hour ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' which featured the first performances by the competition's finalists, put Fox in the No. 1 slot on Wednesday night. In Nielsen's estimates, ''Dance'' drew 9.7 million viewers, and its viewership and demographic ratings built as the evening went on. So far, the show's ratings have increased significantly over its first season last summer. The CBS primetime special ''AFI: 100 Years, 100 Cheers'' (8.3 million) put the network in second place. NBC continued its broadcasts of hockey's Stanley Cup finals; though the ratings for the games were preliminary, they indicated an audience of fewer than 5 million. Speaking of small audiences, the once formidable ''Commander in Chief'' had its candle snuffed out on Wednesday. In its finale the president, played by Geena Davis, inspired a groundswell movement to pass the Equal Rights Amendment. An audience estimated at 5.4 million said goodbye. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Love, '24' Style
summary: Spring is here, and love is in the air on ''24.'' Or the action series's version of love, anyway. In Monday's episode, Jack (Kiefer Sutherland) had to interrogate his beloved ex-girlfriend, Audrey (Kim Raver, below), to find out if she had sold secrets to terrorists. An audience of 14.53 million watched Jack throw Audrey against a wall before determining that she was innocent. (She later forgave him.) Monday's ''24'' drew its best ratings since its time slot premiere in January. With CBS broadcasting repeats but for a single episode of ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (12.1 million), Fox easily won the night among adults 18 to 49 and placed a close second to CBS among total viewers (12.43 million versus 12.32 million). On WB, ''Everwood'' returned to the schedule for the first time in more than three months. The acclaimed family drama, which may be a casualty of the merger between UPN and WB, delivered an average of 3.52 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. That was more than UPN's lineup attracted (3.16 million), but the two networks tied in the 18-to-34 demographic the merged network, CW, will aim at next season. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Wins With Miami
summary: ABC's broadcast of Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals delivered a ratings victory for the network on Sunday. Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the live event indicated that the ratings for the Miami Heat's overtime defeat of the Dallas Mavericks were up slightly from last year's equivalent game. CBS placed second among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49, with a steadily performing night of repeats: ''60 Minutes'' (9.05 million), ''Cold Case'' (8.24 million) and the Mel Gibson movie ''What Women Want'' (9.45 million). NBC's prime time led off with a spillover of the United States Open golf tournament, which took first place between 7 and 7:30 p.m. Later, the two-hour debut of ''Treasure Hunters'' brought in an average of 6.91 million viewers. At 10 p.m. NBC broadcast a rerun of its new series ''Windfall,'' which drew a mere 3.89 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Play Ball! | April 2-8
summary: THE BRONX The News -- The baseball season opened with the Yankees winning a big one: the New York City Council approved plans for a new $800 million stadium. Behind the News -- The vote was the last real hurdle in a decades-long quest for a new stadium. The Yankees at one point threatened to move the team to New Jersey, and more recently Manhattan had been in the running. But in the end the team opted for a site next to the existing stadium in the South Bronx. The Council went along, over objections from neighborhood residents that the project would usurp parkland. SILICON VALLEY The News -- Apple Computer said it would introduce software to enable its Macintosh computers to run the Microsoft Windows operating system as well as its own. Behind the News -- For Apple, which had long ignored and even mocked Microsoft's product, the decision was nothing short of revolutionary. But it was based on a simple business calculus: limiting its computers to a single operating system had limited the company's growth. If Macintoshes can run the vast array of Windows-only software, Apple may grab more than its current 5 percent share of the PC market. WASHINGTON The News -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice lobbied Congress to support the administration's effort to aid India's nuclear power program. Behind the News -- Legislators had criticized the deal, citing concerns over India's nuclear weapons program. Ms. Rice sought to reassure the critics, saying she would push India to safeguard its civilian plants and block exports of weapons-making material. The calming words had an effect: several lawmakers offered qualified support for the agreement, leaving the White House optimistic that it would be approved. ISRAEL The News -- The Kadima Party, the winner in Israeli elections last month, said it would form a coalition with the Labor Party. Behind the News -- The announcement does not quite settle the issue of what the new government will look like, as two or three smaller parties will be needed to form a parliamentary majority. But it goes a long way toward ensuring the continuation of the policies of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who is incapacitated by a coma. The parties agree on critical policy, including the removal of more Israeli settlements from the West Bank. TV LAND The News -- Katie Couric, a fixture on NBC's ''Today'' for 15 years, will join CBS, where she will anchor the evening newscast. Behind the News -- For CBS, which courted Ms. Couric for a year, the move is an effort to attract new viewers to its newscast, a ratings also-ran in recent years. The hope is that some of her legions of fans who have made ''Today'' a ratings hit will start watching her at night. CBS may also be thinking that ''Today'' may stumble without her, creating an opening for the network's morning show, which is even more of a ratings laggard.

headline: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
summary: Three Republican senators voiced fresh concerns on Sunday about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's handling of the dismissals of eight United States attorneys amid questions about whether the firings were politically motivated. The comments, made in separate televised interviews by Republicans with histories of breaking with the White House, provided further indication of waning support for Mr. Gonzales where he needs it most, among fellow Republicans.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 40TH ANNUAL C.M.A. AWARDS -- Brooks & Dunn (from near right, Ronnie Dunn and Kix Brooks) are hosts of this 40th anniversary event honoring excellence in country music, broadcast live from the Gaylord Entertainment Center in Nashville. They also lead the list of nominees along with Brad Paisley, each of whom received six tips of the hat in categories including entertainer of the year. Dierks Bentley, Kenny Chesney, Gretchen Wilson, George Strait, Sara Evans, Alan Jackson, Rascal Flatts, Carrie Underwood and Mr. Paisley are expected to perform. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Mahone and Kellerman track Michael and Sara to New Mexico; Lincoln gets help from his father, whom L. J. has never met; Sucre plans a getaway with Maricruz; and T-Bag runs into an old, familiar face. 8 P.M. (11) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- Chris's new principal, played by Jason Alexander in a guest role, pairs him with Caruso on the school field trip. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE GOLD RUSH -- The California gold rush began on Jan. 28, 1848, when James Marshall found gold near the fork of the American and Sacramento Rivers,and unleashed a massive migrationfrom around the world. This ''American Experience'' documentary uses the stories of a small group of diverse characters (like this unidentified miner, above) -- Chinese and Chilean, northerner and southerner, black and white -- to chronicle the evolution of California from a backwater filled with easy riches into a place where fierce competition and not a little luck determined who won thefew remaining claims and who went home poorer but wiser, if they were lucky. 9 P.M. (Sundance) CROSSING ARIZONA -- In this documentary, Joseph Mathew looks at the stand-off in Arizona along the border between the United States and Mexico, where thousands of migrants heading north have died since the mid-1990's. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) TO HAVE AND TO HOLD -- A married man pays the consequences when he messes around with the wrong woman in this made-for-television. Justine Bateman plays the wife who could have told him so. 9 P.M. (BBC America)VINCENT -- Ray Winstone (right) portrays Vincent Gallagher, a headstrong private eye who fights crime his own way, even if that means working outside the law. Tonight, in the first of four new episodes, he helps a devoted husband who suspects his wife is cheating on him, while trying to rebuild his own shattered life. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: MIAMI -- When a 19-year-old man is decapitated while performing a stunt in his tricked-out car, Horatio starts to think it wasn't just an accident. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Fanfare, please. Like a court awaiting a coronation, the Top 12 contenders reunite on the ''Idol'' stage in the season finale of the show it seems the whole world is watching. Carrie Underwood, the reigning Idol, performs her single ''Don't Forget to Remember Me'' before new royalty is crowned. Daniel Powter sings the show's theme song, ''Bad Day.'' Which it will be for either Taylor Hicks or Katharine McPhee (above, with Mr. Hicks). 7:30 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL RED CARPET PRESHOW -- Just a little eye candy to divert from pre-ceremony jitters. 8 P.M. (CBS) DR. PHIL PRIME-TIME SPECIAL: ESCAPING ADDICTION NO. 2 -- Last week Dr. Phil McGraw helped a mother of two extract herself from a physically abusive situation. Tonight he counsels a couple whose drinking has put their own family in grave danger on how to get out from under the influence. 8 P.M. (Style) MY CELEBRITY HOME -- Millions of girls crave her looks, her style, her hair, her flair. But what this young fan wants is Hilary Duff's sewing room. And she gets it, or at least a version of it, in her own home. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Season finale. To push or not to push: that is the question facing Locke (Terry O'Quinn, left). And his decision may prove cataclysmic. 9 P.M. (BBC America) WHAT NOT TO WEAR ON HOLIDAY -- Trinny and Susannah save women from their gut instincts in this mandatory viewing for the beach-bound. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) GHOST HUNTERS -- Jason and Grant count down their Top 20 freakiest moments. 9 P.M. (Sundance) KATH AND KIM -- Kath Day and her ''hunk of spunk,'' Kel Knight, recount their fairy-tale nuptials. It seems Kath didn't exactly feel like a princess. 9 P.M. (VH1) HEAVY: THE STORY OF METAL -- Part 3 of this four-episode series features a historical examination of California metal and its primary outgrowth, the hair band. 10 P.M. (Bravo ) TOP CHEF -- Season finale. The remaining contestants, Tiffani Faison and Harold Dieterle, go burner to burner for the pièce de résistance: $100,000 in seed money for a culinary career, a feature in Food & Wine magazine and an appearance at the Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., next month. Oh, and the freedom from packing up their knives. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- In a scene -- finally -- not out of reality, Jennifer Aniston (right) talks about ''The Break-Up,'' her new movie, co-starring her boyfriend, Vince Vaughn, with whom she is apparently still going strong. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Ratings After 'Seinfeld'
summary: The two episodes of the series debut of ''The New Adventures of Old Christine,'' the latest post-''Seinfeld'' comedy of Julia Louis-Dreyfus, left, helped CBS win Monday night's race in Nielsen's estimates. The half-hour episodes delivered 12.48 million viewers at 8:30 p.m., then 15.27 million at 9:30 p.m., both above average for those time slots. (''Two and a Half Men'' was shown in between, and had 17.56 million viewers.) But NBC and Fox also had reason to be happy. NBC's game show ''Deal or No Deal'' easily won the 8 p.m. hour in total viewers (15.38 million) and among 18-to-49-year-olds, and lifted the network to a second-place finish over all in that age group despite its weakened ''Apprentice'' (9.91 million). And Fox's ''24,'' which featured the deaths of Tony Almeida (Carlos Bernard) and Lynn McGill (Sean Astin), drew 13.57 million viewers, winning the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. When ''Prison Break'' returns with new episodes at 8 p.m. next Monday, Fox will present a formidable challenge to CBS in the sought-after 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR
