headline: Arts, Briefly; Battle of the Reality Titans
summary: The February ratings sweep period is upon us. And though entertainment programs will soon be challenged by NBC's Olympic coverage, Thursday featured another kind of intense competition: the premiere of the new ''Survivor'' went up against its reality-show opposite, ''Dancing With the Stars.'' Both drew large audiences, as the 90-minute ''Dancing'' on ABC brought in an estimated 18.74 million viewers, and CBS's ''Survivor'' -- which, in this installment, has four tribes instead of the usual two -- delivered 19.34 million. CBS, which won the night in Nielsen's estimates, picked up steam at 9 p.m. with ''CSI'' (27.99 million), by far the most-watched show of the night. And the network's ''Without a Trace'' (20.8 million) easily beat NBC's ''ER'' (13.78 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Google's Stock Falls 7% After Disclosure That Technical Limits Restrict Its Growth Google's shares tumbled 7 percent yesterday after the chief financial officer told investors that the company saw few additional advances in a technology that had brought it a substantial increase in advertising revenue. The financial executive, George Reyes, left, told an investor conference held by Merrill Lynch, that its revenue growth would slow as a result. [Page C1.] Supreme Court to Consider Business Tax Incentives The Supreme Court takes up a major case today about the legality of tens of billions of dollars in tax breaks that states and local governments award businesses each year to build factories, or just to stay put. [C1.] JetBlue Tries to Revive Its Profit With Higher Fares JetBlue Airways, the low-cost carrier, is trying to raise fares in a bid to restore profit after surging fuel prices caused it to lose $42.4 million in the fourth quarter. [C1.] The first 100 or so of thousands of small passenger jets will soon begin flying, the Federal Aviation Administration said, in what some proponents say, could alter the air-travel industry. [C5.] Restoration of Gulf Oil Production Remains Unfinished The huge task of fixing the country's most important energy hub is far from over. Six months after Hurricane Katrina battered the gulf with 175-mile-an-hour winds and waves higher than eight-story buildings, more than a quarter of the region's oil output is still shut. [C1.] The Bush administration is scaling back on audits of energy companies that generate billions of dollars in sales from leases to produce oil and gas on federal property, state officials said. The changes have sparked protests from several oil-producing states and Indian tribes. [C1.] J. P. Morgan Fills a Gap With a Fidelity Partnership J. P Morgan announced a partnership with Fidelity Investment's brokerage arm that gives millions of individual investors access to the same new equity and fixed-income offerings its institutional clients have long received, filling a gap in the company's services. [C3.] Existing Home Sales at Two-Year Low in January Sales of existing homes dropped to their lowest level in nearly two years in January and the number of unsold homes on the market rose, a trade group reported. [C3.] Apple Pushes Further Into Home Entertainment Apple Computer furthered its push into home entertainment on the introduction of a high-fidelity stereo system for the iPod music player, as well as a new version of the Mac Mini computer with features for managing digital music and video. [C2.] CBS Radio Sues Howard Stern Over His Departure CBS Radio filed a lawsuit yesterday against Howard Stern charging that its former radio star used his last months on the air at CBS to build up his future employer, Sirius Satellite Radio, and gained significant financial advantages that damaged CBS Radio. Mr. Stern countered that the lawsuit was an attempt by CBS to distract attention from its poor quarterly results. [C3.] Stocks Tumble on Mixed Economic Statistics Mixed economic statistics caused stocks to tumble. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 104.14 points, to 10,993.41. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 13.46 points, to 1,280.66, and the Nasdaq fell 25.79 points, to 2,281.39. [C10.] Ports Takeover Opponents Raise New Objections Lawmakers raised new objections to the proposed takeover of some terminal operations at six United States ports by a Dubai company. [A13.] A Former Enron Executive Testifies on Contracts A former Enron executive gave the strongest testimony yet in a five-week-old trial that Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, signed off on a controversial accounting shift involving troubled trading contracts. [C3.] Technology Opens Opportunities for the Disabled Thousands of people with disabilities are finding jobs and becoming independent as a result of technological advances like faster computers and broadband Internet connections that let them work at home. [C7.] Some Medicare Patients Find Themselves in Two Plans Tens of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries have found themselves enrolled in two prescription drug plans at the same time as a result of confusion over the new program. [A1.] House to Vote on Pre-Empting States' Food Safety Rules The House is expected to vote Thursday on a bill that would pre-empt state food safety regulations that are more stringent than federal standards and set a uniform set of rules across the nation. [A14.]

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) MOYERS ON AMERICA Bill Moyers tackles some tough issues confronting Americans these days in three new documentaries, this first of which traces the rise and fall of the lobbyist Jack Abramoff (left), who in January pleaded guilty to three felony counts. Afterward, Norman Ornstein, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, and Thomas Frank, author of ''What's the Matter With Kansas? How Conservatives Won the Heart of America,'' will discuss the scandal's impact on Washington. 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO Who's buying the next round? And the one after that? Tonight, a satellite television in a local bar picks up a signal from an Asian news program that shows the extent of the nuclear attacks. 9 P.M. (BET) BEEF: THE SERIES In his new series, Quincy Jones III looks at the pitfalls of competition within the ranks of pop culture, starting with some public complainers and their supporters. First up: Lil' Romeo vs. Bow Wow, Naomi Campbell vs. Tyra Banks, Houston north side vs. Houston south side, and Das vs. Kurupt. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST This third season picks up 65 days after the crash of Oceanic Airlines Flight 815 on a not-so-deserted tropical island, and focuses on that band of outcasts called The Others. In this season premiere, Jack, Kate and Sawyer discover what's in store as their prisoners. 9:30 P.M. (BET) NEXT LEVEL: VINCE YOUNG Fast on the heels of his debut last Sunday as the starting quarterback with the Tennessee Titans (against the Dallas Cowboys, no less), Mr. Young (right) is the inaugural subject of this new series focusing on transitions in the careers of stellar athletes. This episode steps back to his final year at the University of Texas as he prepares for the N.F.L. draft. 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) SOUTH PARK In this first of seven new episodes, Cartman, Kyle, Stan and Kenny try to save the online gaming world. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY Lock up the scissors! In this reunion special, the original 15 designers get snippy. 10 P.M. (ABC) THE NINE That's the number of hostages inside Fidelity National Bank when a robbery goes far, far south. This new drama series follows the victims (including Camille Guaty, above left, as Franny, a party girl, and Lourdes Benedicto as Eva, a bank teller and Franny's older sister) as they try to recover from the trauma -- and figure out what really happened during those 52 hours. 10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) FREAK SHOW They're superfreaky, this band of carnival freaks-cum-superheroes out to save the world in this new animated series. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Travel) JOAN CUSACK'S LOCAL FLAVOR -- Ms. Cusack (above) puts acting on the back burner to sample some of the food, culture and family traditions in Europe, starting in this premiere episode in France. Tonight, she visits the landmark Dalloyau patisserie and the Poilâne bakery in Paris, and stirs up laughter along the way. 5 P.M. (9) THE TYRA BANKS SHOW -- Ms. Banks looks at addictions, vices and obsessions and then challenges viewers to give up their own in seven days. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- After Earl watches Catalina give a facial wax, he decides to make amends for No. 91 on his list: ''Made fun of Maggie Lester for having a moustache.'' 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Blow, winds, blow: Clark cleans up the mess left in Zod's wake and catches a cold. 8 P.M. (Sundance) SIGNÉ CHANEL -- In this final episode of the reality series set at the House of Chanel in Paris, all the fashion world's atwitter as Karl Lagerfeld prepares to reveal his latest collection. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- Born beautiful? Not neccessarily. Tonight, Betty (America Ferrera, right) loses The Book, a proof of the entire magazine that includes un-retouched photos of a popular actress (Sarah Jones) that could put a blemish on everyone's life. 8:30 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE -- All play and no work makes Michael (Steve Carell) a busted boy. Tonight, Angela tries to get Dwight to make a run for Michael's job after his Movie Mondays initiative is discovered. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- The dead are alive again in Dr. Robbins's morgue, where they shed a little light on their own murder investigations. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- Cristina helps Preston deal with his hand tremors, and Izzie returns to Seattle Grace Hospital for the first time since she quit the program. 10 P.M. (JAZ) COMMITTED: THE CHRISTIES -- BET's companion channel watches how the ball bounces in the unique marriage of the N.B.A. player Doug Christie and his wife, Jackie. 10 P.M. (NBC) ER -- Pratt (Mekhi Phifer) takes on the role of attending, and Neela (Parminder Nagra) learns that her new surgical chief (J. P. Manoux) intends to make her life unbearable. Meanwhile, Gates (John Stamos) assesses the condition of an older man with congestive heart failure, whose partner (the wonderful John Mahoney, above left, in a guest spot) must fight to keep him alive. 11 P.M. (Showtime) WHITE BOYZ IN THE HOOD -- Thirty stand-up comics try to transcend race in this new comedy series. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: BIG DROP IN MARKETS -- Stock markets around the world plummeted in a wave of selling. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 546 points before closing down 416 points, or 3.29 percent. The falling prices continued in early Asian trading today. [Page A1.] A FINANCIAL TSUNAMI -- The Shanghai stock market's worst one-day tumble in a decade set off a tumult that rolled through markets around the globe, from Tokyo to Frankfurt to Brazil to Wall Street. [C1.] WEAKNESS IN DURABLE GOODS -- American manufacturers reported a sharp drop in demand last month for expensive heavy-duty items, renewing concerns about softness in the economy. [C7.] FEWER SUBPRIME LOANS -- Freddie Mac, one of the largest buyers of mortgages, said it would tighten lending standards and stop buying certain kinds of risky home loans made to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit records. [C1.] A WIDENING SCANDAL -- Siemens, the German engineering giant, has reported buoyant financial results, but it is immersed in a fast-expanding corruption scandal that threatens to torpedo its reputation. [C1.] SETTLEMENT IN HOLOCAUST CASE -- A federal judge approved a settlement of a class-action suit against an Italian insurance company, ending a long-running dispute over payments on life insurance policies taken out by Holocaust victims. [C3.] FEDERATED'S PROFIT IS UP -- Federated Department Stores posted a 5 percent increase in quarterly profit and said it would change its corporate name to the Macy's Group. Federated, which also operates Bloomingdale's, said the name change would be effective on June 1. The company also approved a $4 billion increase in its stock buyback program. [C5.] ANOTHER BID, PERHAPS? -- The question being whispered in Frankfurt at a gathering of the world's private equity chiefs: Will anyone dare to mount a rival bid for TXU? [C3.] TOYOTA, VIA TUPELO -- Toyota said that it would invest $1.3 billion to build its eighth North American assembly plant in Blue Springs, Miss., just outside Tupelo. The plant will build the Toyota Highlander and employ 2,000. [C3.] BUYING A STAKE IN CHINA -- Wal-Mart's purchase of a 35 percent stake in the Bounteous Company, a Taiwan-owned group that operates more than 100 retail outlets in China, is part of a strategy to gain greater access to the world's most rapidly growing major economy. [C10.] DECLINE IN BLOCKBUSTER EARNINGS -- Blockbuster said that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 28 percent, largely because of the cost of starting and promoting its online movie-rental business. The company also said it was trying to resolve a dispute with its chairman and chief executive, John F. Antioco, above, over his 2006 bonus. [C5.] LOBBYING FOR A MERGER -- The chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, Mel Karmazin, is taking the campaign to sell his company's proposed merger with XM Satellite Radio to Washington, where he will speak at a House panel hearing. [C7.] INTERACTIVE MADNESS -- A division of CBS is hoping to intensify the March Madness college basketball mania by offering students and other fans a chance to create exuberant video clips and share them with friends, family and strangers. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] 2 PROMISING AIDS DRUGS -- Two new AIDS drugs, one developed by Pfizer and the other by Merck, have proven safe and highly successful in large studies, a development that doctors said would significantly expand treatment options for patients. [A1.] THE COST OF 'FLUSHED AWAY' -- DreamWorks Animation SKG, the studio behind animated movies like ''Shrek'' and ''Madagascar,'' said that it swung to a fourth-quarter loss on costs to write off ''Flushed Away,'' which performed poorly at the box office. [C2.] GUEST WORKER ABUSES -- Many low-skilled foreign workers who enter the United States under the guest worker program become the victims of abusive employers. New complaints have come to light as President Bush and many in Congress are pushing to expand the program. [A1.] SPACE NOT AVAILABLE -- The demand of office space in Lower Manhattan, an area whose prospects seemed dire after the World Trade Center was destroyed, has bounced back. [C8.] A BIGGER WHOLE FOODS -- Whole Foods, the supermarket chain with roots as a natural food store, continued its growth last week with a deal to acquire a competitor. But as it grows, many of its fans say Whole Foods has strayed from its original vision. [F5.] ONLINE NEW LIFE FOR HEART BYPASS -- After a decline of more than a decade, heart bypass surgery may be poised for a comeback. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/multimedia. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. SHARES OF RADIOSHACK surged after the company said that fourth-quarter profit jumped 64 percent as lower costs more than offset a decline in revenue and same-store sales. (AP) EL PASO CORPORATION, the natural gas producer and pipeline operator, said that its fourth-quarter loss widened, hurt by a tax charge related to the sale of its stake in a pipeline. (REUTERS)

headline: Diane Farr, Seung Chung
summary: Diane Farr, an actor in television and film, was married yesterday to Seung Yong Chung, an entertainment marketing executive. Barry G. Littman, a film executive who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Rainbow Tarns, a lodge in Mammoth Lakes, Calif. Five Buddhist monks also participated in the ceremony. Ms. Farr, 36, is keeping her name. She is a star of ''Numb3rs'' on CBS. She is also the author of ''The Girl Code: The Secret Language of Single Women'' (Little, Brown, 2001), and owns OtherAnnouncements.com, an online greeting card company. She graduated magna cum laude from the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Season finale. And they're out! Michael (Wentworth Miller), Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) and their Fox River cronies (above) run for their lives, with the dogged Bellick (Wade Williams) close on their heels. Meanwhile, Veronica (Robin Tunney) races to Montana and sees a ghost. Hmm. Next season, ''Manhunt''? 8 P.M. (Fox Sports New York) RED SOX VS. YANKEES -- THE ULTIMATE RIVALRY -- ''I think we've upgraded from a battle to a war,'' Grady Little, former manager of the Boston Red Sox, said during the 2003 American League Championship Series, after Pedro Martinez, then a Sox pitcher, threw Don Zimmer, the 72-year-old Yankees bench coach, to the ground. This hour long documentary focuses on the heated period between 2003 and2005, and especially 2004, when the 86-year-old Curse of the Bambino was reversed. Terry Francona, the Sox's current manager, narrates. (In a bit of fair play, the DVD version offers alternate narration by the Yankees' manager, Joe Torre.) 8 P.M. (ABC) OPRAH WINFREY'S LEGENDS BALL -- This two-hour special rehashes the glam moments of the May 2005 weekend-long festivities with which Ms. Winfrey (left) honored 25 of her personal heroes, in case your invitation never arrived. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) CRADLE OF LIES -- A woman pregnant with a baby girl learns that her husband must have a son to inherit his family's fortune. Shannon Sturges and Dylan Neal play the unhappy couple. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- In Part 1 of a two-episode season finale, Mia (Emmanuelle Vaugier), the former girlfriend of Charlie (Charlie Sheen), returns with an unexpected request. And just maybe he's not so over her after all. 9 P.M. (A&E) TATTOO FIXATION -- A drone has echoed across America for more than a century, as the buzz of the tattoo needle has grown louder. This one-hour special looks at the visceral desire of everyone from hardened criminals to modern aristocracy to decorate themselves, and explores why the appeal of ink is more than skin deep. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- Season finale. The residents at Seattle Grace Hospital display their newfound maturity in this two-hour season finale. But has Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) grown up enough to make a rational choice between McDreamy (Patrick Dempsey) and McVet (Chris O'Donnell, above right, with Ms. Pompeo)? 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: MIAMI -- Will the dangerous Mal Noche gang put an end to Horatio's dreams of happily ever after? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: NBC's 'Today' Is Expected To Add a Fourth Hour
summary: Meredith Vieira won't appear on it at all, and Matt Lauer will make only an occasional cameo, if that, but NBC is expected to announce formally today that it will expand ''Today,'' its morning-program empire and the most profitable program on television, to a fourth hour, beginning at 10 a.m. on weekdays next fall. The network, which supersized the program from two to three hours in 2000, knows that it risks diluting the ''Today'' brand through yet another expansion. But it is banking, instead, on the ''Today'' name serving as a lure to women, in particular, who watch television midmorning, said an NBC Universal television executive who was briefed directly on the ''Today'' plan but who would only discuss it anonymously before today's announcement.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Top Taliban Member Is Said To Be Captured in Pakistan The former Taliban defense minister was arrested in Pakistan on Monday, the day of Vice President Dick Cheney's visit, two Pakistani officials said. The man, Mullah Obaidullah, was a senior leader of the Afghan insurgency, which has battled American and NATO forces with increasing intensity over the last year, and is the most important Taliban member to be captured since the American-led invasion of Afghanistan. A1 Ahmadinejad to Visit Saudi King President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will visit Saudi Arabia for a landmark meeting with King Abdullah intended to tackle the growing sectarian and political crises wracking the Middle East, Iranian officials said. A9 Bomb Kills 7 at Iraq Wedding A car bomb that was apparently aimed at a policeman's wedding party in Falluja killed seven guests and wounded six, the local police said. Locals said the attack appeared to be part of a battle between insurgents and other groups. A8 A New, and Feared, Top Chechen President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appointed Ramzan A. Kadyrov, a widely feared young official whose security forces have been accused of kidnappings, torture and other abuses, to be president of Chechnya, the battered southern republic. A6 South Korea Resists Chinatown While the growing wealth of both Chinese and overseas Chinese has given birth to new Chinatowns in places as varied as Las Vegas, Dubai and Belgrade, plans for a chinatown in South Korea have been fraught with historical subtexts and have not progressed very far. A3 NATIONAL A11-15 Army Dismisses General Over Hospital Conditions The two-star general in charge of Walter Reed Army Medical Center was relieved of command after disclosures that wounded soldiers being treated as outpatients were living in dilapidated quarters and enduring long waits for treatment. A1 Views on Health Care A majority of Americans say the federal government should guarantee health insurance to every American, especially children, and are willing to pay higher taxes to do it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 California Gains Attention While the 2008 presidential campaign is well under way in traditional bellwether states, candidates are also making an early run at voters in California, a delegate-rich but typically sidestepped state. A15 Deadly Tornado Hits Southeast A storm system that stretched nearly 1,000 miles from the Midwest to the Southeast killed at least eight people in two states, including five who died when an apparent tornado caused the roof to collapse at a high school in Enterprise, Ala., state emergency management officials said. A13 SCIENCE/HEALTH Children's Medicine Examined Federal drug regulators have started a broad review of the safety of cough and cold remedies meant for children, a top official said. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Citing Rent Concerns, U.S. Rejects Starrett Deal The federal housing secretary has rejected the proposed $1.3 billion sale of Starrett City, a working-class enclave of 46 buildings in Brooklyn, because the prospective buyer has failed to supply adequate financial information or a plan for how the complex would remain ''a viable community for New Yorkers of modest means.'' A1 Counseling for Sex Offenders New York's new guidelines for detaining sex offenders who have completed their prison sentences go beyond confining the most violent predators: they also provide mental health counseling and treatment to inmates while they are jailed or confined and provide supervision and treatment after their release. B1 More Restaurants Closed New York City shut 13 fast food restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owns the Greenwich Village KFC/Taco Bell where swarms of rats were found. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Paper Mills in a Trade Case American paper mills have become a test case for a possible confrontation between the United States and China that many industry officials and members of Congress hope will lead to new tariffs on steel, furniture, textiles and plastics. A1 Google Finds Another Way Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: A suddenly convenient truth; ground zero victims; the path to citizenship; Robert B. Semple Jr. on a historian's valedictory. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. SPORTSFRIDAY C10-13 Chinese athletes Gao Wei, Ding Long and Shen Yalei knew nothing about football last summer, when they were selected by the N.F.L. at a tryout in China. Now they are immersed in a crash course on kicking footballs -- and the league is hoping one of them can provide international appeal in Asia. C10 Crossword E35 TV Listings E25 Weather C10

headline: Fox to Try Fixing Fall Woes and '24'; CW Adding 6 Shows
summary: The Fox network, emphasizing its position as the network leader in reaching audiences that most advertisers want to reach, announced a prime-time schedule yesterday aimed at solving its chronic problems in the fall, while maintaining its strength in the winter and spring. That meant adjustments on five nights in the fall and a promise of some serious changes in the format of its hit drama ''24'' when it starts again in January.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Battle of the Older Viewers
summary: CBS's criminal procedurals tend to draw an older audience, particularly after the season has wound down. On Thursday, its reruns of ''Numbers,'' featuring Rob Morrow, below (8.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates); ''CSI'' (13 million); and ''Without a Trace'' (11.8 million) won the night in total viewers. But the shows were the strongest among viewers 55 and older, allowing Fox to take the night among adults 18 to 49, the chunk of the population advertisers prefer. Fox's lineup was made up solely of the premiere of the second season of ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' a competition from the producers of ''American Idol.'' It built its audience steadily over the course of two hours, during which a bunch of freaks and a few talented people auditioned for the show. Over all, ''Dance'' delivered 10.6 million viewers, and high ratings in both the 18-to-49 and 18-to-34 age groups. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- Behind many a TV forensics scientist lies the gruesome death of a loved one. Dr. Temperance Brennan (Emily Deschanel, above) is no different. In this season finale, she comes to terms with a case close to her heart: the murder of her mother. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE AMAZING RACE 9 -- Five continents, 10 countries and more than 59,000 miles later, the teams head toward the finish line in this two-hour season finale, with a prize of $1 million as incentive. 8 P.M. (9) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- They've endured shorn locks, tooth bonding, six-inch heels and accessorizing with Madagascar hissing cockroaches, all in an attempt to enter the pantheon of Tyra Banks's girls. But nothing can rival the challenge of both walking and talking in a Cover Girl commercial, as the remaining three contestants discover in this season finale. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- One for the money and two for the show are all that are left, as a member of the final three is voted off. 9 P.M. (13) THE WORLD OF NAT KING COLE -- ''He was cool before it was cool to be cool,'' Isaac Hayes says of this barrier-breaking crooner (right), who had a voice anyone could love. This American Masters documentary uses archival performances, home movies and interviews to illustrate 30 years of Cole's achievements, which include becoming the first African-American to have his own television series. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- Don't pick up! In this season ending, the team races against the clock to stop a bomber who is using random cell-phone pages to trigger explosions around the city. 10 P.M. (ABC) INVASION -- Season finale. Chaos reigns as the hybrids continue to round up the humans during the hurricane. 10 P.M. (MTV) MY SUPER SWEET 16 -- How do you spell class? We're guessing the teenagers whose disturbing acts of ostentation and one-upmanship are at the heart of this reality series -- and the parents who support them -- haven't a clue. In this season finale, a New Jersey boy orders up a party fit for a hiphop king. Maidens, prepare your rose petals. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- Season finale. McCoy (Sam Waterston, above) risks his career when he uses a corrupt federal drug agent (Ritchie Coster) to lure psychopathic killers out of hiding. 10:30 (MTV) TIARA GIRLS -- Season finale. Proving that beauty is not always as beauty does. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: The Entertainment Center Moves Outdoors
summary: SUMMER entertaining has begun, and hosts are scrambling for the right paraphernalia to set up outdoors. On the other side of the table, guests are searching for gifts. Picnicware is always welcome, and melamine is a good choice to replace paper. Clear acrylic goblets come in enough sizes to suit all summer offerings, from ''ades'' to ''itas.'' 1. Plastic containers for transporting food, inspired by traditional metal Chinese lunchboxes, come in two sizes; the smaller is $30, the larger is $38. At Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street) or (800) 243-9810. 2. Lawn bowling is a good diversion from too much relaxation. The wood set comes with nine pins and two balls; $49 from L. L.Bean, llbean.com or (800) 441-5713. 3. A plastic serving bowl looks as good empty as it does filled with fruit salad; $18 at Mxyplyzyk. 4.Mini Bloomin' garden stakes are $38 for a set of six; target.com/redhotshop or (800) 800-8800. 5. A plastic knife, fork and spoon snap together for ease of packing and setting up at picnics. They come in clear or transparent green, red or yellow. A box of four sets is $10 at the Shop at Cooper-Hewitt, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8355. 6. The Lush Life wine cooler is made of double-walled acrylic for insulation, and comes in a variety of hot colors like magenta; $18, lushlifehome.com or (858) 454-1431 for stores. 7. Sommar tea light holders are $3.99 each. Made of steel, they come in a variety of colors; in Ikea stores only, ikea.com or (877) 345-4532 for locations. 8. Claro acrylic glasses come shaped for martinis, margaritas, wine or water. Each is $2.95 from CB2, cb2.com or (800) 606-6252. 9. A set of eight 11-inch-round melamine dinner plates with a colorful parrot is $19.99. Eight 9-inch salad plates, in the same pattern, are $14.99. Sets of eight dinner and salad plates in solid colors for the same prices are also available. All from Target, target.com or (800) 800-8800. 10. Dyning, a polyester hammock, comes in a variety of colors, like white, orange, green and blue. The 89-inch-long sling is strong enough to hold about 660 pounds. It is $34.99 and available only in Ikea stores; ikea.com or (877) 345-4532 for locations. On the front page of this section: The weather-resistant Vintage Modern rocking chair by Thomas O'Brien; sold in pairs, $179.98 at target.com or (800) 800-8800.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Wins With the N.B.A.
summary: During the regular season ABC wins the ratings race on Sunday nights because of the interpersonal games that take place on ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Grey's Anatomy.'' But the network won this Sunday because of games of a different sort: the N.B.A. Finals. Nielsen's estimates for the live broadcast were preliminary, but its overnight ratings showed that ABC was ahead among total viewers and adults 18 to 49, and that this year's game No. 2 delivered a larger audience than last year's. CBS and its Tony Awards placed second among viewers, but fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox, in turn, was No. 2 among 18-to-49 year-olds, and fourth among viewers. Its most-watched show of the night was a rerun of ''Family Guy'' at 9 p.m., with 5.93 million viewers. It led into the comedy ''It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia'' by FX, Fox's cable sibling; it drew a series-high 3.75 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; A Big 'Deal' for NBC
summary: The ratings for the season finale of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' showed the remarkable strength of that game show. Its 90-minute denouement, which featured Celine Dion, delivered 18 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. By its final half-hour, an audience of 21.2 million had tuned in, 10 million of whom departed once ''The Apprentice'' finale began at 9:30 p.m. The fifth season of the Donald Trump show, which concluded with the hiring of Sean Yazbeck, brought in 11.2 million viewers. That made it the highest-rated episode of this edition, but it was the lowest-rated ''Apprentice'' finale, and in total viewers, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' rerun (11.6 million) outdrew it. Despite the ''Apprentice'' lag, NBC easily won the night among adults 18 to 49 and total viewers. Elsewhere, the WB's critically beloved, canceled ''Everwood'' ended its four-year run with an audience of 4.1 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: A Crate & Barrel Web Baby Gets Its Own Catalog
summary: Once upon a time, a bricks and mortar store was followed by a glossy catalog, then a Web site for ordering online. (As the retail industry has learned, leafing through shiny pages at one's leisure gives shoppers confidence to go to the Web and buy.) But one home furnishings company, CB2, has done all this in reverse, issuing a catalog only after starting a Web site and then opening two stores. A spin-off of Crate & Barrel aimed at young nesters, CB2 has just mailed its first 67-page catalog with selections that include, left: a Flip Flop sofa that converts to a double bed and offers three ways to adjust the back ($999); a metal bookcase with five shelves ($199); and a 5-by-8-foot wool shag rug ($279). To order a catalog, simply go online (cb2.com) or pick up a phone: (800) 606-6252.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Flavor Flav Draws for VH1
summary: ''Flavor of Love,'' the VH1 reality show following the rapper Flavor Flav's search for a mate, concluded on Sunday night with the channel's highest ratings ever. Nielsen's numbers for the show grew significantly over its run, and for the finale, 5.88 million viewers watched Flav, above, pick Hoopz over a woman named New York; the winner was given a set of gold teeth. Tuesday's two-hour ''American Idol'' delivered an enormous audience estimated at 32.53 million, allowing Fox to run away with the night in every major demographic. But in adding ''The Unit'' (17.78 million) to its Tuesday schedule, CBS has found a good pairing with ''NCIS'' (17.61 million): military dramas stand up well against ''Idol.'' But CBS's ''Amazing Race'' has not benefited from its move to 10 p.m. That long-running reality series, such a ratings success a year ago, is sinking. Tuesday's episode drew 9.59 million, and was beaten by a repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' in both total viewers (11.22 million) and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) BILLYWILDER SPEAKS -- And boy, does he have a lot to say. In 1988, Wilder (right) -- director, writer and producer sublime -- agreed to be interviewed by a German film crew on the condition that his revelations not be disclosed until after his death. This 90-minute special, edited down from a longer television series, celebrates WilderÕs 100th birthday (he died in 2002) with snippets from films including ''Double Indemnity,'' ''Sabrina'' and ''Sunset Boulevard'' and nuggets about leading ladies like Audrey Hepburn, Gloria Swanson and Marilyn Monroe. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Lance Bass and Kathy Najimy try to fill in the blanks of questions posed by six celebrity panelists in ''Match Game,'' the latest installment in this competition series. Gene Rayburn was the host and Richard Dawson, Brett Somers and Charles Nelson Reilly the panelists in the 1970's, when the show, rife with double entendres and more than a hint of suggestiveness, became the most popular daytime program ever. This time around Adam Corolla, Adrianne Curry, George Foreman, Kathy Griffin, Bruce Vilanch and Betty White will provide the touch of raunch, with Ricki Lake overseeing the mayhem. 9 P.M. (13) A LION IN THE HOUSE -- Part 2 of this ''Independent Lens'' documentary, filmed over six years at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, looks at some of the obstacles facing five children with cancer and their families: the emotional and economic impact of experimental treatments, disparities among diagnoses and the difference between giving up and letting go. 9 P.M. (Sundance) HOUSE OF BOATENG -- Move over, Bravo. The Sundance Channel is posed to push ''Queer Eye'' and ''Project Runway'' off the catwalk with this new reality series following the British designer Ozwald Boateng (above), creative director of Givenchy, to America as he prepares to sink or swim. 9 P.M. (BBC America) WATERLOO ROAD -- What happens when the faculty at a troubled English high school is more out-of-control than the students? This series, that's what. In this new episode, a teacher announces she is pregnant, while another sets up a date with the principal. 11:35 (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Look, up in the sky! It's a bird! No, it's the plane flying in Kevin Spacey to promote his star turn in ''Superman Returns'' as Lex Luthor, a performance he says was inspired by Enron's deposed prince of darkness, Kenneth Lay. Taylor Hicks, who rose from Southern shlub to People magazine's hottest bachelor in the blink of an ''Idol,'' is the musical guest. 11:35 (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Shhh. Is that another Oscar nomination we hear in Meryl Streep's (right) future? Tonight she talks with Mr. Letterman about Vogue-ing for the camera in ''The Devil Wears Prada.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Partisan Divide on Iraq Exceeds Split on Vietnam
summary: No military conflict in modern times has divided Americans on partisan lines more than the war in Iraq, scholars and pollsters say -- not even Vietnam. And those divisions are likely to intensify in what is expected to be a contentious fall election campaign. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows what one expert describes as a continuing ''chasm'' between the way Republicans and Democrats see the war. Three-fourths of the Republicans, for example, said the United States did the right thing in taking military action against Iraq, while just 24 percent of the Democrats did. Independents split down the middle.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Talent Show Wins for NBC
summary: ''America's Got Talent'' got off to a strong start on Wednesday, giving NBC a victory for the night. The Simon Cowell-produced show, with Regis Philbin, above, as its host, drew 12.1 million viewers between 9 p.m. and 11. In the earlier prime-time hour, NBC broadcast a rerun of ''Dateline'' (6.4 million), which nearly dragged its overall ratings out of the No. 1 slot, as Fox finished a close second. Its competing talent show, ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' also from the ''American Idol'' family tree, brought in 8.9 million viewers and a strong sampling from the 18-to-49 demographic. On CBS, the ''Big Brother: All Stars'' casting special led off the night. Twenty former housemates from the ''No Exit''-like reality show's six previous seasons are competing for 12 slots in the new house; an audience of 6.1 million cared. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Another President With Sinking Ratings
summary: ''Commander in Chief,'' the ABC drama starring Geena Davis, below, as the first female president, was once this season's most successful new series, and Ms. Davis's performance earned her a Golden Globe for best actress. But that was six months and two executive producers ago. (First, Steven Bochco replaced Rod Lurie, the creator of the series, as the executive in charge of the show, and now Dee Johnson has taken over from Mr. Bochco.) On Thursday, a retooled ''Commander in Chief'' appeared for the first time since January, and the results were not pretty. It drew an estimated 8.2 million viewers, and in the 10 p.m. hour, was last among adults 18 to 49, behind CBS's ''Without a Trace'' (18.65 million) and a rerun of NBC's ''ER'' (6.03 million). It even lost viewers from its first half-hour (8.25 million) to its second (8.13 million), never a good sign. For the night over all, CBS's new episodes of ''Survivor'' (15.07 million) and ''CSI'' (23.91 million), combined with ''Without a Trace,'' to give the network an effortless victory in Nielsen's estimates. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; The Frog Is No Housewife
summary: Kermit the Frog, below, apparently cannot make up for the absence of new episodes of ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Grey's Anatomy.'' In a two-hour ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (13.04 million) that ran on ABC from 8 to 10 p.m. on Sunday, Kermit took over for Ty Pennington as the team leader. But Kermit, singing ''The Rainbow Connection'' to raise money for a family beset by problems, did not draw as large an audience as the women of Wisteria Lane do; and though ABC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, it lost to CBS among total viewers for the night. By running into prime time, the Masters golf tournament helped CBS, but because it was live, its Nielsen estimates were preliminary. NBC placed third for the night among total viewers and fourth, behind Fox, in the 18-to-49 demographic. With only a few episodes left in its run, ''The West Wing'' (8.35 million) perked up in the ratings, compared with its recent numbers. Leo died, and Matt Santos (Jimmy Smits) won the presidency. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Blaine Breathes And Audience Inflates
summary: The never-subtle ''7th Heaven'' television show ended its 10-season run Monday night as an actual fat lady (credited as ''the fat lady'') sang ''Embraceable You.'' Three out of the seven Camden kids, who grew up on the show, announced toward the end of the episode that they would be having twins; 7.17 million viewers were thankful for finales. That audience was the largest of WB's season, and pushed ''Everwood,'' a critically praised drama that might not make the new CW lineup, to 4.23 million viewers. As has been the recent pattern on Mondays, Fox was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, and CBS drew the most total viewers in Nielsen's estimates. On Fox, members of the ''Prison Break'' gang, or almost all of them, finally broke out, before an audience of 8.95 million. CBS had the night's most-watched show, as ''CSI: Miami'' drew 19.49 million viewers to the wedding of Horatio(David Caruso). ABC's special, ''David Blaine: Drowned Alive,'' delivered 9.94 million viewers. During the two-hour broadcast, during which Mr. Blaine tried and failed to set the world's breath-holding record, the audience grew from 7.06 million in the first half-hour to 13.66 million in the death-defying last half-hour. Mr. Blaine, who was suffering convulsions and was unconscious when he was rescued, according to his doctor and trainer, checked himself out of the hospital yesterday, The Associated Press reported. KATE AURTHUR

headline: With Iraq Driving Election, Voters Want New Approach
summary: A substantial majority of Americans expect Democrats to reduce or end American military involvement in Iraq if they win control of Congress next Tuesday and say Republicans will maintain or increase troop levels to try to win the war if they hold on to power on Capitol Hill, according to the final New York Times/CBS News poll before the midterm election. The poll showed that 29 percent of Americans approve of the way President Bush is managing the war, matching the lowest mark of his presidency. Nearly 70 percent said Mr. Bush did not have a plan to end the war, and 80 percent said Mr. Bush's latest effort to rally public support for the conflict amounted to a change in language but not policy.

headline: Oh What a Malleable War
summary: MAYBE the Bush White House can't conduct a war, but no one has ever impugned its ability to lie about its conduct of a war. Now even that well-earned reputation for flawless fictionalizing is coming undone. Watching the administration try to get its story straight about Iran's role in Iraq last week was like watching third graders try to sidestep blame for misbehaving while the substitute teacher was on a bathroom break. The team that once sold the country smoking guns in the shape of mushroom clouds has completely lost its mojo. Surely these guys can do better than this. No sooner did unnamed military officials unveil their melodramatically secretive briefing in Baghdad last Sunday than Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, blew the whole charade. General Pace said he didn't know about the briefing and couldn't endorse its contention that the Iranian government's highest echelons were complicit in anti-American hostilities in Iraq. Public-relations pandemonium ensued as Tony Snow, the State Department and finally the president tried to revise the story line on the fly. Back when Karl Rove ruled, everyone read verbatim from the same script. Last week's frantic improvisations were vintage Scooter Libby, at best the ur-text for a future perjury trial.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Americans Showing Isolationist Streak, Poll Finds Americans are overwhelmingly pessimistic about the state of affairs in the Middle East, with majorities doubtful there will ever be peace between Israel and its neighbors, or that American troops will be able to leave Iraq anytime soon, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. A majority said the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah would lead to a wider war. Over all, the poll found a strong isolationist streak after more than four years of war, underscoring the challenge for President Bush in trying to maintain support for his effort to stabilize Iraq and spread democracy through the region. PAGE A22 Energy Bill Is Poised to Pass An early test vote in the Senate signaled wide support for broadly expanding oil and natural gas drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. PAGE A20 A No to Same-Sex Marriage In a ruling with sharp divisions, the Washington Supreme Court upheld a state law banning same-sex marriages. PAGE A18 Tribute to Baseball Pioneers Induction into the Hall of Fame will illuminate the obscure history of blacks in the 19th-century major leagues. SPORTSTHURSDAY, PAGE D1

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (History) THE PASSION: RELIGION AND THE MOVIES From Monty Python's ''Life of Brian'' (above, with Graham Chapman, left, as Brian) to Mel Gibson's ''Passion of the Christ,'' the film industry has often tested the limits of acceptability when it comes to interpreting stories central to Christianity. This special uses film clips and interviews with Martin Scorsese, Willem Dafoe, Terry Gilliam and Mr. Gibson to examine the controversy over who controls imagery in the Bible. 4 P.M. (NBC) KURT BROWNING'S GOTTA SKATE 6.0 Brian Orser, Kyoko Ina, John Zimmerman, Joannie Rochette, Marie-France Dubreuil, Patrice Lauzon, Steven Cousins, Yuka Sato, Jamie Salé and David Pelletier skate to music by the Barenaked Ladies in this two-hour special, taped on Oct. 13 in Toronto. 8 P.M. The cast includes Tim Roth, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Sophie Okonedo, Hugh Bonneville, Gina McKee, Samrit Machielsen, Grirggiat Punpiputt and Toni Collette. 8 P.M. At 10, things heat up in Billy Wilder's ''Double Indemnity'' (1944), about a couple of adulterous insurance murderers. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS After Homer gets into a brawl at an ice-skating show (featuring guest voice Elvis Stojko, right), Marge takes the family shopping. But when Gil, dressed as Santa, gives Lisa his boss's daughter's gift and moves in with the Simpsons after losing his job, Marge finds her holiday spirit wearing thin. 8 P.M. headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day on Monday about MTV's plan to offer simultaneous versions of some programs -- one on television and one on a computer-- misidentified the network that broadcasts ''Lost,'' with the actress Michelle Rodriguez, who was involved in an early test of the MTV system. ''Lost'' is on ABC, not CBS.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Deal' Delivers for NBC
summary: NBC must be tempted to plug ''Deal or No Deal'' into every hole in its leaky schedule, as the ratings for the game show, whose host is Howie Mandel, below, continue to surge. On Monday, a two-hour ''Deal'' drew an estimated 17.5 million viewers, the largest audience for a series in that time period since May 1998. It led NBC to a win for the night in adults 18 to 49 and in total viewers, despite the fact that a 10 p.m. edition of ''The Apprentice'' (10.5 million) lost a large portion of ''Deal'' viewers. CBS's broadcast of the N.C.A.A. championship basketball game put the network in second place over all. Fox ranked third for the night. Its ''24'' drew 12.2 million viewers, and ''Prison Break,'' which flashed back to how most of the main characters ended up in jail, brought in 8 million. For the week that ended on Sunday, however, Fox was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49 for the sixth week in a row. CBS placed first among total viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Agassi's Farewell Will Not Be Easy
summary: Andre Agassi's final dash across the bright blue courts of the United States Open will either be a long embrace or a quick goodbye. Though he avoided Roger Federer's bracket in yesterday's draw ceremony at the United Nations, the unseeded Agassi will open his 21st and last United States Open against Andrei Pavel of Romania, and he could face Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus in the second round.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (TLC) ASHLEY JUDD AND YOUTHAIDS: CONFRONTING THE PANDEMIC -- In 2002 Ms. Judd (above right) became the goodwill ambassador for YouthAIDS, an organization that promotes AIDS prevention and treatment. In this special she travels through Central America with her friend Salma Hayek, where they try to get out the message that young people can change their future by changing the behavior that puts them at risk of infection. Juanes, the Latin rock star and a YouthAIDS ambassador to his region, follows along. 7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) BAH-HUMDUCK! A LOONEY TUNES CHRISTMAS -- Daffy Duck, as a modern-day Scrooge, tries to find the spirit of giving. Gordon Goodwin and his Big Phat Band provide the jazzy backup. 7 P.M. (Cinemax) POSITIVELY NAKED -- For nearly a decade, Spencer Tunick has challenged beliefs about nudity, privacy, sexuality and body image in his photographs of naked men and women. In this documentary he assembles 85 H.I.V.-positive people in downtown Manhattan and puts a human face on an illness that is still misunderstood. 8 P.M. (CBS) ICE WARS 2006: U.S.A. VS. THE WORLD -- On our side, the skaters Brian Boitano, Michael Weiss, Rory Flack Burghart and Angela Nikodinov; on theirs, Alexei Yagudin, Kurt Browning, Oksana Baiul and Shizuka Arakawa. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE POLAR EXPRESS (2004). A train conductor guides a boy who doubts the existence of Santa Claus by locomotive to the North Pole in this noirish animated film, based on the children's book by Chris Van Allsburg. Tom Hanks (above) lends his voice to five characters; he also wore a hat during recording that transmitted his movements to create templates for the characters' actions. 9 P.M. (Fox) TRADING SPOUSES: MEET YOUR NEW MOMMY -- Tonight one mother must attend Bible class with her host family while the other tries to instill Christianity in a household of nonbelievers. 10 P.M. (Showtime) MASTERS OF HORROR -- Dario Argento directs ''Pelts,'' in which a fur trader, played by Meat Loaf, who wants to make the perfect raccoon coat uses some supernatural hides that get violent with those who want to wear animal skins. 11 P.M. (BBC America) HARDWARE -- Boys and bolts. Need we say more? Martin Freeman stars in this new comedy about four young men working in an English hardware store. 11 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SNY SPOTLIGHT -- Joe Namath, the Jets legend, talks with Gary Apple (near right, with Mr. Namath) about his famous Super Bowl guarantee, playing football at Alabama, his struggle with alcoholism and his life today. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Behind (and Before) The Lincoln Center Music In a new partnership announced yesterday, the PBS show ''Live From Lincoln Center'' will team with National Public Radio to produce original content for NPR Music, to appear on the Internet. Fred Child, the host of NPR's ''Performance Today,'' was named the new announcer of ''Live From Lincoln Center,'' replacing Martin Bookspan, who left in May. Beverly Sills is the host. The Web content will include interviews with musicians appearing on ''Live From Lincoln Center,'' as well as other features related to the music scheduled on coming episodes of the series. The first segments -- interviews with the conductor Louis Langrée, above, and the pianist Garrick Ohlsson -- are available, in anticipation of Wednesday night's broadcast of the opening program of the Mostly Mozart Festival. These and future segments will be available on npr.org and lincolncenter.org before the broadcasts. Bangladesh Concert at 35 On Aug. 1, 1971, some 40,000 people attended two benefit concerts at Madison Square Garden under the title ''Concert for Bangladesh,'' organized by George Harrison, above left, to support relief efforts by the United Nations Children's Fund in East Pakistan, which was then struggling to become the separate state of Bangladesh. Bob Dylan, above right, along with Eric Clapton, Ravi Shankar and Harrison's fellow Beatle Ringo Starr. On Tuesday at 2 p.m., Madison Square Garden will celebrate the 35th anniversary of this event when Jay Marciano, the president of MSG Entertainment, installs a plaque on the MSG Walk of Fame. ''We are proud to commemorate the 35th anniversary of the Concert for Bangladesh on our Walk of Fame,'' Mr. Marciano said. ''George Harrison's wife, Olivia Harrison, will help us remember how music can help create change.'' The plaque, to be set alongside those honoring Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones and the Grateful Dead, will be the first of its kind given to an event rather than a person or group. A Newsy New Podcast CBS Radio's ''iCast with Chris Mavridis,'' which began yesterday, is the first network newscast developed specifically as a podcast, the network has announced. Mr. Mavridis creates a five-minute report on the news of the day on an MP3 file, available to listeners Mondays through Thursdays at 2 p.m. Listeners will be able to hear the report on CBSNews.com or download it for later listening. ''This podcast is aimed at a younger audience,'' said Harvey Nagler, vice president of CBS Radio News, in announcing the new project. ''It will most definitely change the way you think of CBS Radio News.'' Writing and Democracy Leonard Riggio, the chairman of Barnes & Noble, and his wife, Louise, will finance a program at the New School in New York focused on writing and democracy. The program, to begin in the fall, will include undergraduate writing workshops and seminars. ''Louise and I believe that skillful writing provides the voice for all political movements,'' Mr. Riggio said in a statement. ''With respect to democratic institutions, their ability to function and remain relevant in a rapidly changing world can be seen as a function of the many nuances of the language which is their lifeblood.'' New York Casting Report Jeff Daniels, below, and Mark Linn-Baker were among the names mentioned by Manhattan Theater Club's artistic director, Lynne Meadow, and executive producer, Barry Grove, in announcing principal casting for the 2006-7 season. Mr. Baker will star in ''Losing Louie,'' by Simon Mendes da Costa. The four-time Tony Award winner Jerry Zaks will direct the production, scheduled to begin previews at the Biltmore Theater on Sept. 21. Christine Baranski, George Grizzard, Sian Phillips and Jackie Hoffman will star in the premiere of Paul Rudnick's ''Regrets Only,'' to begin performances Oct. 19 at New York City Center. Mr. Daniels will star in ''Blackbird,'' by David Harrower, to be directed by Joe Mantello. Kieran Culkin (''After Ashley,'' ''The Cider House Rules'') is among the newly announced cast of Eric Bogosian's ''subUrbia,'' the Second Stage Theater's 2006-7 season opener. It will also feature Jessica Capshaw (''Fat Pig''), Michael Esper (''Manic Flight Reaction'') and Manu Narayan (''Bombay Dreams''). Jo Bonney will direct the production, slated to begin previews on Sept. 6. Jenn Colella (''Urban Cowboy'') and Christian Anderson (''Avenue Q'') have joined the cast of the Broadway-bound musical ''High Fidelity,'' based on Nick Hornby's novel. On the Auction Block The black dress worn by Audrey Hepburn as Holly Golightly in the 1961 film ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' will go on sale Dec. 5 at Christie's in London, in an auction to benefit the City of Joy Aid, a charity that helps underprivileged children in India, The Associated Press reported. The dress, designed by Hubert de Givenchy and modeled by Romilly Collins of Christie's, left, is expected to sell for $130,000. Also up for sale: Marlon Brando's annotated script of ''The Godfather,'' his harmonica and his British Academy of Film and Television Arts award, which he won for the 1952 movie ''Viva Zapata!'' These, along with letters from Tennessee Williams and clothes worn by James Dean in ''East of Eden'' and ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' will be sold at auction Oct. 6 and 7 at Heritage Auction Galleries of Dallas.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (VH1) HEAVY: THE STORY OF METAL -- It's loud. It's ugly. And for millions of hearing-impaired fans, it still thrills. This four-part series traces the four-decade evolution of heavy metal -- skintight jeans, luxuriant tresses, eyeliner, smashed guitars and all (as seen on Mötley Crüe, above). 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS -- Season finale. Carrie predicts a retirement home in Arthur's future after he sets the basement on fire. 8 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- ''Day 5: 5:00AM-6:00AM/6:00AM-7:00AM.'' As the day wanes in this two-hour season finale, Jack faces his biggest opponent yet. But in the end, who will rule? 8 P.M. (ABC) OPRAH WINFREY'S LEGENDS BALL -- After being bumped by the president's speech on May 15, this two-hour special rehashes the glam moments of the May 2005 weekend-long festivities with which Ms. Winfrey honored 25 of her personal heroes, in case your invitation never arrived. 8:30 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Those soccer moms can be so harsh. Christine gets relief from her outcast status when she finds another working mother at her son's snobby school. That is, until she discovers where she works. In the season finale, at 9:30, after ''Two and a Half Men,'' Christine is secretly pleased when she realizes that the attractive man those nasties are cooing over is an ex-boyfriend. That is, until she discovers she still has feelings. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE MAN BEHIND HITLER -- He was perhaps the original spin doctor, a brilliant but disturbed propagandist without whom Hitler -- and the Nazi Party -- might have been almost nothing. This ''American Experience'' documentary traverses the life of Joseph Goebbels (above right), the second most powerful member of the Third Reich, by letting him speak for himself through his own diary entries, read by the actor Kenneth Branagh. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Season finale. Charlie and Mia plan their wedding, with their families weighing in. 9 P.M. (ABC) ALIAS -- When will it all be over? Just as soon as Sydney can stop the cartel of evildoers from fulfilling Rambaldi's deadly plan in this two-hour series finale. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Season finale. Allison (Patricia Arquette, left) has visions of what her life would have been if she'd become a high-powered lawyer and married another man, and they aren't all that scary. 10 P.M. (MTV) PUNK'D -- Series finale. Ashton Kutcher puts an end to his tomfoolery, and Hollywood can sleep more soundly now. Unless, of course, we're being punk'd. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fox Piles Up the Numbers
summary: The ''American Idol'' contestants sang old standards, and ''House'' featured an insomniac lesbian; together they thrashed all of the network competition from 8 to 10 p.m. on Tuesday. In Nielsen's estimates, Fox's ''Idol'' brought in 27.48 million viewers, who watched the judges lavish praise on Katharine McPhee, below, who sang ''Someone to Watch Over Me.'' After that, ''House'' delivered 23.3 million viewers, which was that medical series's largest audience ever. ''House'' also retained more ''Idol'' viewership than any show following it ever has. Against Fox's unbeatable two hours, CBS's ''NCIS'' (15.56 million) and ''The Unit'' (15.39 million) were once again the only shows not humiliated by the ''Idol''/''House'' combination, and CBS placed a distant second to Fox for the night. The second night of NBC's ''Celebrity Cooking Showdown'' was not so lucky: it brought in a paltry 3.4 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WALTER CRONKITE: WITNESS TO HISTORY -- For more than three decades, he was the voice of America. This ''American Masters'' documentary chronicles the 70-year legacy of Mr. Cronkite (above, in 1954), from his childhood in St. Joseph, Mo., and his early career as a United Press reporter to his 31-year association with CBS, from which he stepped down as anchorman and managing editor on March 6, 1981. Katie Couric, who becomes anchor of CBS Evening News this fall, narrates. 9 P.M. (BBC America) SHIPWRECKED: BATTLE OF THE ISLANDS -- In this new competition series, two groups of young castaways are left stranded on two islands in the Aitutaki Atoll in the South Pacific, with an unaligned castaway dropped in each week. The game goes like this: the island with the most inhabitants at the end wins a huge cash prize to be divided among the group. But you don't want to divide it too many ways. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) STAN LEE'S LIGHTSPEED -- He conjured up X-Men, Spider Man, the Hulk and the Fantastic Four. Now, in this made-for-television action flick, comes Mr. Lee's latest creation: Daniel Leight, a government agent in pursuit of his college roommate-turned-nemesis whose lab mistake has just given Leight the ammunition to stop him. 9 P.M. (TNT) NIGHTMARES AND DREAMSCAPES: FROM THE STORIES OF STEPHEN KING -- Two more to keep you up at night. In ''The Road Virus Heads North,'' Tom Berenger plays a prize-winning author on a road trip who buys a mysterious painting. At 10, in ''The Fifth Quarter,'' a recently released criminal (Jeremy Sisto, above, with Samantha Mathis) searches for the pieces of a map that will lead to $1 million. 9 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- And he's off -- the show, that is. After weeks of watching his female partners get eliminated, the hypermasculine Dmitry Chaplin got the boot last week, while his partner, Donyelle Jones, emerged victorious. That leaves eight, who dance tonight. 10 P.M. (BBC America) BUMP 'N' GRIND -- Seems Americans aren't the only ones who think they can dance. In this new British competition series, 12 performers, helped along by three professionals, learn to shake their booty, with the best boy and best girl going foot-to-foot at the end for a yearlong contract with a dance agency. 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS -- Morgan Spurlock, the filmmaker who watched his health and his waist size go to pot by feasting on McDonald's in ''Super Size Me,'' returns with the second season of his reality series in which people live another's lifestyle for a month. Tonight, Frank George, who holds staunch anti-immigration opinions, lives with an undocumented Mexican family (above, with Mr. George, center) in a one-bedroom apartment in Los Angeles. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: What's on Wednesday Night
summary: 8 P.M. (MyNetworkTV) WICKED WICKED GAMES Last night, My Network extinguished the passion in its first two telenovelas, only to start heating things up again. In this new series, Tatum O'Neal plays a scorned woman who plots revenge on her ex-husband by scheming to have their two now-grown sons get close to his daughters from his other marriage -- all while framing him for murder. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS The Heffernans are back for a new season, with a whole new set of problems. Tonight, Doug spends their tax return on an ice cream truck. At 8:30, he tries to keep a woman who claims to have spent a romantic weekend with him to stop calling the house.

headline: Arts, Briefly; New Shows, New Lineups
summary: The television schedule featured several new shows and some shuffled lineups on Wednesday, but the results were status quo. In Nielsen's estimates, ''American Idol'' was the night's most watched program, and Fox won the night. On the half-hour ''Idol,'' 27.27 million viewers said goodbye to Kevin Covais, a 16-year-old from Long Island. The premiere of ''Unan1mous'' drew 15.84 million viewers in the post-''Idol'' slot. Behind Fox, ABC, CBS and NBC fought it out for second place among total viewers in a very close race, finishing in that order. (ABC was a clear No. 2 among adults 18 to 49.) ABC's ''Lost'' delivered an audience of 15.98 million, and led into the debut of ''The Evidence'' (9.23 million), which ranked second at 10 p.m. behind CBS's ''CSI: New York'' (13.9 million). NBC's crime entry during the 10 p.m. slot was its new series ''Heist.'' Though the show brought in 8.74 million and finished third, it retained a good percentage of the ''Law & Order'' audience (8.95 million). After years of dominating the 10 p.m. hour, ''Law & Order'' moved this week to 9 p.m. to face ''Idol,'' ''Lost'' and CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (11.85 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: On Abortion, Giuliani Faces a Potential Fall From Catholic Grace
summary: At first glance, Rudolph W. Giuliani should be an appealing presidential candidate for observant Roman Catholics. The grandchild of Italian immigrants, Mr. Giuliani went to Catholic schools, considered joining the priesthood, and as mayor of New York battled a museum that exhibited a painting of the Virgin Mary adorned in elephant dung. But church leaders say they are frustrated by prominent Catholic politicians like Mr. Giuliani who argue that while they are personally opposed to abortion, they do not want to impose their beliefs on others.

headline: Downsizing | June 18-24
summary: A MEMORIAL The News -- Officials in Lower Manhattan unveiled a more modest, and less expensive, design for a memorial at the site of the World Trade Center. Behind the News -- The redesign eliminates underground galleries where the names of the 9/11 victims would be inscribed. Instead, the names will be found on a plaza above the voids where the towers stood. This and other changes will lower the price tag by $162 million. Still, the project is estimated to cost $510 million. A COMMITMENT The News -- Japan announced that it would begin pulling troops out of Iraq. Behind the News -- About 600 soldiers have been in southern Iraq since 2004, providing reconstruction assistance. The contingent is Japan's most significant military mission since World War II. Despite the withdrawal plans, Japan remains a supporter of the American effort in Iraq. Even as he announced that the troops' mission was fulfilled, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said the air force would increase its support flights for American soldiers. A TEAM The News -- It was a bad World Cup for Serbia and Montenegro. Behind the News -- The team, which had performed well in qualifying for the tournament, lost all three of its matches, including a 6-0 shellacking at the hands of Argentina. Worse, though, the team also lost its country: with Montenegro's secession in an independence referendum, Serbia and Montenegro no longer exists. The coach said the political division had a demoralizing effect on the squad. Serbia will begin fielding its own national team next month; the future of Montenegrin soccer is less clear. A CAREER The News -- Dan Rather and CBS News parted ways after 44 years, and Mr. Rather was weighing an offer to work for a fledgling high-definition channel. Behind the News -- CBS announced Mr. Rather's departure -- five months before his contract was to expire -- praising him as one of the giants of television journalism. But Mr. Rather did not hide his displeasure at what he perceived as the network's refusal to give him significant work since he stepped down as anchor of the evening news last year after a reporting scandal. A FAMILY TREE The News -- The pool of Genghis Khan's descendants is not quite as big as thought. Behind the News Although a genetic test had shown that Thomas R. Robinson, an accounting professor in Florida, was descended from the Mongol conqueror, a more complete test showed that the initial result was faulty. The reversal may be a bit of a blow to Mr. Robinson, but it hardly takes the sheen off Genghis's image. He and his relatives amassed so many concubines that, by one estimate, 16 million men in Central Asia carry his Y chromosome.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARRY, ROBERT
summary: BARRY--Robert. Age 85, February 28, 2006, in New York City, passed peacefully away. Yale Drama School graduate. Long time CBS top Lighting Director. Well remembered for his work with Walter Cronkite and on CBS Sixty Minutes with Dan Rather. Survived by three nieces and two nephews of California and Seattle. His many close friends will also miss him. At his request, there will be no services in New York.

headline: Lawyer Attacked for Book His Panel Deems Offensive
summary: Raoul Felder, a celebrity divorce lawyer who is chairman of a state commission that oversees judges, has been given a unanimous vote of no confidence by the other nine members of the commission for helping to write a book they said is racially and ethnically inflammatory. In a statement issued Friday, the commission members said the book, which Mr. Felder and the comedian Jackie Mason wrote, ''repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.''

headline: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Olympics Outruns The Competition
summary: The reach of network television erodes nearly every year, so Thursday's full menu of popular choices spread among the big four broadcasters was a rarity. NBC's Olympics telecast, which featured the women's figure skating finals, carried the night, with an average of 24.49 million viewers in prime time, according to Nielsen's estimates. It was in the 8 p.m. hour when the four networks really collided. The results show of Fox's ''American Idol,'' during which 4 contestants of the top 24 got the boot, was the clear winner, with an audience of 23.07 million. Competing against it were CBS's ''Survivor'' (14.85 million) and the first hour of ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' (14.78 million), as well as the Olympics (17.74 million). The three non-Olympic programs cannibalized one another, as ''Idol'' didn't perform at its usual heights, and ''Survivor'' had its lowest-rated original episode ever. (''Dancing'' did rebound in its second hour, lifting its total audience to 17.68 million.) Between 10 p.m. and 11:30 p.m., skating took over, with an audience of more than 30 million tuning in to NBC. Over all on Thursday, Fox ranked second in the 18-to-49 demographic, followed by CBS and ABC. Among total viewers for this interesting night, ABC was No. 2, followed by Fox and CBS. KATE AURTHUR

headline: The Accorsi Scorecard
summary: The Ernie Accorsi Era for the Giants started after the 1997 season, when he took over as the general manager when George Young retired. Nine years later, it is Accorsi who is retiring at season's end. In many ways, he will be judged by the future performance of quarterback Eli Manning, right, acquired in a draft-day trade with the San Diego Chargers in 2004. Here are some of the other players who will help define Accorsi's legacy with the Giants. JOHN BRANCH HITS QB Kerry Collins (acquired: 1999) A controversial acquisition because of personal problems and declining statistics, Collins was resurrected with the Giants, playing five seasons and leading the 2000 team to the Super Bowl. LT Luke Petigout (1999) The Giants' first choice in the draft (19th over all), who is currently injured, is the respected protector of Manning's back side. TE Jeremy Shockey (2002) Accorsi moved up a spot in the first round of the draft to choose Shockey, who has made three Pro Bowls in four years. DE Osi Umenyiora (2003) Chosen in the second round, he was coveted by the Chargers as part of the Manning trade. Accorsi held firm, and Umenyiora became a premier rusher. G David Diehl (2003) Chosen in the fifth round, the starting left guard is one of several key players chosen on the second day of the draft. Others include linebacker Brandon Short, receiver David Tyree, safety Gibril Wilson, running back Brandon Jacobs and defensive tackle Barry Cofield. MLB Antonio Pierce (2005) Signed as a free agent, Pierce has been the defense's most consistent player and its main font of attitude. WR Plaxico Burress (2005) Signed as a free agent, the tall and lanky Burress has become the team's best big-play receiver -- and a constant source of mild off-field controversy. P Jeff Feagles (2003) He had already played 15 seasons when he signed as a free agent, but he seems to have become better. MISSES RB Ron Dayne (2000) The Giants' top pick (11th over all) in the draft, Dayne is Accorsi's biggest miscalculation. The silver lining: Dayne's shortcomings fueled the dependence on Tiki Barber, and Brandon Jacobs may become the bruising back Dayne was not. LB LaVar Arrington (2006) Signed last spring, Arrington brought a positive resolve and a few games of decent play before his season ended with an Achilles' injury. He hopes to return in 2007. CB's Will Allen and Will Peterson (2001) Accorsi never found a Pro Bowl-caliber defensive back, and fell short by using the first two choices of the draft on Allen and Peterson. DT William Joseph (2003) A first-round choice, Joseph has struggled to slip into the lineup past lesser-known players, and finds playing time mostly thanks to injuries. WR Joe Jurevicius (1998) He was getting better each season when the Giants let him slip away in free agency in 2002. He played in Super Bowls with Tampa Bay and Seattle, and the Giants went through a forgettable cast of replacements until Burress arrived. LB Carlos Emmons (2004) The Giants snagged him from the rival Eagles in free agency. He has struggled with injuries and struggled to make a big impact when healthy.

headline: 9/11 POLLS FIND LINGERING FEARS IN NEW YORK CITY
summary: Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say they are still ''very concerned'' about another attack on their city, a level of apprehension only slightly reduced from the fall of 2001, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News polls of the nation and New York City. Nearly a third of New Yorkers said they thought about Sept. 11 every day. Nearly a third said that they had not gone back to pre-Sept. 11 routines and that they were still dealing with changes caused by the attacks.

summary: TALKS ON A CHRYSLER DEAL DaimlerChrysler confirmed for the first time that it was in talks with a number of bidders about a deal for its troubled Chrysler Group. [C3.] LONE STAR'S EXIT STRATEGY? Lone Star Funds, the private equity firm embroiled in a dispute with South Korean prosecutors, said that it would divest itself of two of its Korean holdings, fueling speculation that it would exit the country. [C12.] UNIVERSITIES AND LOAN COMPANIES The directors of financial aid offices at Columbia University, the University of Texas at Austin and the University of Southern California profited from the sale of shares they held in a student loan company, which each of the universities recommends to student borrowers, according to an investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, New York attorney general. [A1.] YOUTUBE BLOCKED IN THAILAND Thailand's government blocked access to YouTube because of a video clip that denigrated the country's monarch. [C3.] SEEKING OPPORTUNITY IN ALASKA For women entrepreneurs, starting and sustaining a business in Alaska can pose special challenges. Small Business. [C14.] HINTS OF A WEAKENING ECONOMY Growth in the service sector fell to a four-year low last month while the job market showed only modest improvement, according to reports that reinforced views of a weakening economy. Its rival, Circuit City Stores, swung to a loss of $12.2 million, as it continued to struggle with charges related in part to store closings. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WISE, SIDNEY
summary: WISE--Sidney, journalist, died peacefully at home on August 24, one day before his 90th birthday. Sent to Madrid in 1943, first as an Assistant Press Attache of the American Embassy and later correspondent for the Overseas News Organization and CBS, he was the first journalist to expose the fascist Franco regime. His frank and honest reporting led to the Spanish government forcing him to surrender his credentials under the threat of explusion from the country. After returning from Spain, he worked as a public relations officer in Nelson Rockefeller's Office of Inter-American Affairs then went on to be a public information officer at the United Nations. He moved to Mexico in 1961 and subsequently won the Francisco Zarco award for the best international reporting on Mexico in 1968. An authority on the economy and investments in Mexico, Mr. Wise has written articles on theses subjects as correspondent to the New York Times and London Times as well as the Wall Street Journal. Over the span of his journalistic career, he knew and interviewed many of Latin America's most notable dignitaries, including Fidel Castro. He was owner and publisher of The Mexican Investor newsletter which in 1976, along with its money management business, was merged to Accival, a private stock brokerage. He later founded the investment firm Mexican Financial Advisory Service. In 1973 Doubleday published a worldwide edition of his book ''Invest and Retire in Mexico.'' He was a consultant to a number of organizations including Union Carbide Mexicana, Syntex, Alexander Proudfoot PLC and IBM de Mexico. He was predeceased by his second wife, author and playwright Margarita Urueta, after 40 years of marriage, and his son Jeffrey Wise. He is survived by his three daughters, Wendy, Carol, and Anne, his sister Edna and six grandchildren.
