headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Buy a Theater Ticket, Get a Commercial For those who hate the onslaught of commercials that precede movies, here is news to sour the blood and tighten the jaw: live commercials, performed by actors, are on the way to legitimate theaters. Yes, perhaps soon, it will possible to pay $100 or more for a ticket and be subjected to a product pitch before the curtain rises. The Guardian of London reported that a live commercial was to be enacted on Tuesday at the Gaiety Theater in Dublin before a performance of ''Saturday Night Fever.'' In a three-minute presentation to promote the West End in London to international theatergoers, six actors planned to use dialogue to reproduce the sights and sounds of London. The report said that the commercial would also be staged in Hamburg, Germany; New York; and Pittsburgh. Death Fast Urged As a 'Da Vinci' Protest A Roman Catholic organization in India has urged Christians to starve themselves to death to protest the release of ''The Da Vinci Code'' in movie theaters there, Agence France-Presse reported. Joseph Dias, the secretary general of the Catholic Secular Forum, who spoke of the ''fast unto death'' as a demonstration of ''the extent that our feelings have been hurt,'' said that it is ''a more Christian way of doing things rather than pulling down things and tearing them up.'' The forum said that it hoped that thousands of people would turn out for a protest today in Mumbai to burn effigies of Dan Brown, the author of the best-selling novel that is the basis for the film, scheduled for international release on May 19. Yesterday about 100 people gathered in Mumbai to burn pages of the book, but the police stopped them from torching an effigy of Mr. Brown, whose novel posits that Jesus and Mary Magdalene married and had children and that their line survives. About 2 percent of the 1.1 billion people in India are Christian. Old Vic Eyes New Season Kevin Spacey, left, will star in a London production of O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten,'' according to the Old Vic company's announcement of the schedule for Mr. Spacey's third season as its artistic director. The O'Neill play, to run from Sept. 15 to Dec. 23, will be staged by Howard Davies, who directed Mr. Spacey in the well-received 1999 Broadway production of O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh.'' The Old Vic season also includes Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew'' and ''Twelfth Night,'' to be presented in repertory in January, when Edward Hall will direct his all-male company, Propeller. Beginning in late February, the Old Vic will celebrate the 50th anniversary of ''The Entertainer,'' by John Osborne, with a new production starring Robert Lindsay as the aging and desperate comedian Archie Rice. Joyce Kilmer Would Approve The Mayor of Madrid, faced with protests and a threat from Carmen Cervera, the Baroness Thyssen-Bornemisza, below, has suspended plans to uproot centuries-old trees from the Paseo del Prado to make way for a pedestrian-friendly ''art walk,'' Agence France-Presse reported. Mayor Alberto Ruiz-Gallardón said that the public would now have six months to express its concerns to urban planners. The city said that the plan would affect only 29 trees; ecologists have put the number as high as 700. The baroness, a self-described nature lover whose family's renowned art collected is exhibited in a mansion on the street, had said she would tie herself to a tree to protest the plan. Footnotes The run of the Lincoln Center Theater revival of Clifford Odets's ''Awake and Sing!'' at the Belasco Theater has been extended for two weeks, through June 25. Christine Lahti, below, was withdrawn from the world premiere of ''The Busy World Is Hushed,'' the Keith Bunin drama that is to be the final production of Playwrights Horizons' 35th-anniversary season. She will be replaced by Jill Clayburgh. An announcement yesterday from the press representatives for the play attributed Ms. Lahti's withdrawal ''to family matters that necessitate her returning to the West Coast.'' The announcement said that a new date for the first preview, originally scheduled for May 27, would be announced soon, along with new opening and closing dates for the limited run. No more than a week's postponement of the first preview is expected. Nick Young has been named anchor of CBS Radio News's 68-year-old ''World News Roundup,'' described as the longest-running news program in American broadcast journalism. Mr. Young, who joined CBS Radio News in 1990, succeeds Christopher Glenn, who retired this year after 35 years with CBS. Mr. Young's appointment is effective immediately, CBS announced.

headline: NBC Winds Up Sales Of Commercial Time
summary: NBC has become the third broadcast television network to complete selling commercial time to advertisers before the start of the 2006-7 season. NBC, part of General Electric, sold about $1.9 billion in commercial time in what is called the upfront market, which takes place ahead of the fall season. Last year, in the upfront market before the 2005-6 season, NBC also sold about $1.9 billion.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: HEALTH CLAIM CHECKUP The claims-processing company Athenahealth plans to present a rare warts-and-all look at how well -- or not -- the nation's seven biggest health insurers pay their bills. [Page C1.] VONAGE'S TOUGH RECEPTION In their first day of trading, shares in Vonage, the country's leading Internet phone provider, fell nearly 13 percent below the initial offering price. The sour reception suggested that investors had doubts whether the company could survive in a market where big cable providers are rushing to offer competing services. Market Place. [C1.] MARTHA STEWART CASE TO RESUME A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations. The three-year-old civil case against her is resuming. [C1.] TASERS UNDER SCRUTINY The safety of Tasers, the electric pistols widely used by police, is under new scrutiny after a study by a Wisconsin scientist showed that shocks from the guns cause the hearts of healthy pigs to stop beating. Previous studies showed that Taser shocks did not cause heart disturbances in pigs, whose hearts are similar to those of humans. [C3.] WYETH ADDS TO FEN-PHEN FUND Wyeth won final judicial approval to add $1.3 billion to a $3.75 billion settlement of lawsuits over the fen-phen diet drug combination. The extra money will help settle about 42,000 pending claims, the company said. Wyeth withdrew Pondimin and Redux, part of the fen-phen combination, in 1997 after researchers linked them to heart and lung problems in some users. [C3.] OFFICIAL'S PLANS Robert B. Zoellick, the former United States trade representative, intends to resign as deputy secretary of state after barely 15 months in the job, aides and associates said. He has told associates he would like to be Treasury secretary if John W. Snow resigns. [A14.] CBS-STERN SETTLEMENT CBS Radio has settled its breach-of-contract lawsuit with the talk-show host Howard Stern, the judge presiding over the case said, but lawyers on both sides said the agreement had not yet been signed. CBS sued Mr. Stern in February for promoting his move to Sirius Satellite Radio on his CBS morning show. [C4.] G.M. REPLACES WORKERS General Motors shares rose after the company began replacing union employees lost to buyouts and retirements with temporary workers. The company is using the temporary employees to avoid hiring at factories that are closing and to cover shortages caused by the departures. [C3.] A.C.L.U. PHONE INQUIRY The American Civil Liberties Union said it was asking utility commissions in 21 states to investigate whether the country's largest phone companies handed over their customer records to the National Security Agency without warrants. [A18.] OUR SPONSOR For the next 40 days a radio station in Boston will be, when it comes to advertising, all Snapple, all the time. Beginning tomorrow, the Snapple line of drinks sold by Cadbury Schweppes will be the sole sponsor of all programming and promotions on WFNX, a Boston FM station. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C4.] SUPPORT FOR NUCLEAR POWER Speaking in Pennsylvania, President Bush called for the construction of more nuclear power plants to help reduce the greenhouse gases believed to contribute to global warming. [A18.] A MATTER OF TASTE After more than 40 years, the fashion label St. John -- the choice of powerful women in business and politics -- decided it needed a face-lift. To the label's devotees, it was scandalous. [G1.] ECONOMIC SIGNS New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a softening economy. [C1.] STOCK MARKET RALLIES Stocks rallied for the first time this week after oil dropped below $70 a barrel and the government said new-home sales unexpectedly jumped in April. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 18.97 points, to 11,117.32. [C12.] MASTERCARD OFFERING MasterCard priced its long-awaited initial offering at $39 a share, slightly below expectation. Some 61.52 million shares will begin trading today. [C6.] MOBILE PHONE DEAL China Mobile Communications is poised to make one of the country's largest foreign purchases. The deal, worth about $5 billion, is for Millicom International Cellular, a Luxembourg-based mobile phone company. [C7.] ONLINE The Business of Green Businesses are going green for many reasons, not just to enhance their image. Some are seeking a competitive advantage. A special report is at nytimes.com/business. headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: THE AMERICAN DREAM, REVISED -- For years, homeownership made more sense than renting. But now it is clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move. Economix: David Leonhardt. [Page A1.] IMUS AND THE RUTGERS TEAM -- For a third day, Don Imus apologized for a racially insensitive remark he made about the Rutgers women's basketball team, but it remained uncertain whether he could salvage his program, which generates about $20 million in annual revenue for CBS Radio, or his career. [A1.] A VIDEO GAME CHALLENGE -- Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings in the past, but he says none have been as complex as a turnaround of Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago. [C1.] BETTING ON TRUMP -- Two years after Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos emerged from bankruptcy proceedings, it is unclear whether they have the cash necessary to compete with their rivals. [C1.] CANADIAN GROCERY STRUGGLES -- The Loblaw Companies, Canada's largest grocery chain and once one of North America's most innovative retailers, is struggling with inventory problems and its first annual loss in 19 years. [C1.] 5 YEARS IN JAIL FOR EX-ADVISER -- Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail on a contempt of court charge, was sentenced to five years in prison and ordered to pay $80 million for running what prosecutors said was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. [C3.] ALCOA RIDES A GROWING DEMAND -- Alcoa reported its most profitable first quarter ever as rising metal demand from China and the aerospace industry bolstered prices. Net income rose 8.9 percent, and sales 11 percent. Aluminum prices have more than doubled in the last five years. [C3.] CHINA UNHAPPY WITH U.S. MOVE -- The Chinese government expressed ''deep regret and strong dissatisfaction'' with the Bush administration's decision to file two complaints against China with the World Trade Organization. [C1.] ROMANIAN WORKERS MAKE AN EXIT -- Romania's low wages and recent membership in the European Union is fueling a wave of emigration that threatens to slow an economic boom in recent years. [C7.] A BID FOR PUMA -- The French luxury goods retailer PPR bid about $7 billion for Puma, the German sporting goods company, promising to keep its chief executive, Jochen Zeitz, at the helm of the company he turned around. [C3.] SPANNING THE GLOBE, AND THE WEB -- As NBC's ''Today'' prepares for this year's version of ''Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?'' Hyundai will sponsor a Web site following Mr. Lauer, left, as he travels the world. It is an example of efforts by networks to interweave traditional programming -- and advertising -- with the online media. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] A BOOM IN RETAIL CONDOMINIUMS -- The market for retail condominiums in Manhattan has skyrocketed in recent years. More than 560,000 square feet of retail condo space sold last year, a sharp increase from 28,000 square feet in 2003. [C9.] EIGHT IN A ROW -- Stocks edged higher, giving the Dow Jones industrial average an eighth consecutive increase, though a modest one, for its longest streak since 2003. [C13.] QUESTIONS OVER FINANCIAL AID GIFT -- A federal Education Department official and financial aid directors at three universities received stock in a student loan company from the current president of the company in what could be a violation of securities law. [A13.] CELLPHONE CHARITY PROGRAM -- A new program that lets cellphone users send text messages to make donations to the American Red Cross has come under fire by a consumer group that points out the cellphone company can bill for the text message. [A15.] BIG DONATION TO COLUMBIA -- Columbia University plans to announce a gift of at least $400 million from John Werner Kluge, a 92-year-old billionaire whose multimedia company, Metromedia, was sold to Rupert Murdoch in 1986. [B1.] AN UPSIDE TO THE PET FOOD RECALL -- Stores and Web sites that sell pet food made from free-range meat, organic vegetables and brown rice say business has increased markedly since last month's recall of tainted pet food. [A14.] ONLINE HIGHLY PAID AT COACH -- The richest paydays are supposed to be reserved for Wall Street titans, oil barons and banking moguls. So what is a handbag maker doing atop the list? A special section on executive pay is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. NEW CENTURY FINANCIAL, the subprime lender, has asked a federal bankruptcy judge to speed up the auction and sale of its main lending business while it still has value, according to court papers. (REUTERS) UNITED RENTALS, the equipment rental company, said that it was exploring a possible sale of the company and that its chief executive, Wayland R. Hicks, would retire in June. headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: STUDENT LOAN XPRESS SUSPENSIONS -- The CIT Group has suspended three officers in its Student Loan Xpress subsidiary after new disclosures involving ties to some university financial aid officials. [Page A1.] BATTLE FOR CONTROL OF OIL -- An ambitious plan by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela to take control of several important oil projects from American and European companies is nearing a showdown. But in the end, all sides could wind up losing. [A1.] PATIENCE WITH CHINA WANING? -- For years, President Bush has avoided confronting China with sanctions or legal challenges to its trade practices, preferring to use diplomacy to press China to bring down its trade deficit with the United States. That stance may be hardening. [A1.] PFIZER DRUG ISN'T SELLING -- Exubera, the only commercially available inhaled insulin treatment for diabetes, is turning into an expensive flop for Pfizer. The drug maker had regarded Exubera as a potential blockbuster but after six months of marketing to doctors, only about one of every 500 prescriptions for insulin is for the drug. [C1.] AS CELEBREX AD IS CRITICIZED -- Public Citizen, a consumer group, has asked the Food and Drug Administration to ban a television advertisement for Pfizer's painkiller Celebrex on the ground that it gives consumers a false impression that the prescription drug has no more safety risks than some other painkillers. [C8.] MORE HOME LOAN PROBLEMS -- Mortgage difficulties appear to be cropping up in some loans made to borrowers with decent credit, as the lenders American Home Mortgage and M&T Bank Shares, both based in New York, have learned. [C1.] SHORING UP AN ARCHIVE -- Corbis, a corporation founded and owned by Bill Gates that holds rights to 100 million photographs, has appointed a new chief executive who is an expert in rights law. He is expected to plot the company's response to the rise of low-cost online photo services that threaten to undermine its lucrative photo sales. [C1.] DON IMUS IS SUSPENDED -- NBC News and CBS Radio have both suspended the radio host Don Imus for two weeks over his racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. [C1.] NEW BUYOUT RECORD POSSIBLE -- One of Canada's largest pension funds is in talks with other investors to form a consortium to make a $45 billion takeover bid for the parent company of Bell Canada in what would be the biggest buyout in history. [C1.] UNHAPPY WITH THE TIMES COMPANY -- A second corporate advisory firm, Glass, Lewis & Company, is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company's annual meeting later this month. [C7.] MIRANT PONDERS A SALE -- The Mirant Corporation, the electricity producer that abandoned a bid for rival NRG Energy last June, says it may put itself up for sale to capitalize on growing interest in power companies from buyout firms and other investors. [C5.] PAPER'S SALE VIOLATES CONTRACT -- An arbitrator ruled the Tribune Company's sale of The Advocate of Stamford to the Gannett Company violated a union contract by failing to require Gannett to honor the newsroom employees' collective bargaining agreement. [C2.] NEW CAMPAIGN FOR SONY -- Sony's new ad agency has produced a series of humorous ads tied into the ''Spider-Man 3'' movie to emphasize features on its camcorders and digital cameras that can solve age-old photography problems like blurriness and shakiness. [C3.] MCDONALD'S AGREES TO UNIONS -- A year after Wal-Mart Stores unionized all its stores in China under pressure from the government, McDonald's is cooperating with China to allow more unions in its 750 outlets. [C3.] REVAMPING CITIGROUP -- Citigroup chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, below, will announce plans tomorrow for the bank's first major overhaul since a merger forged Citigroup a decade ago. It is part of broad effort to streamline the bank's global operations and get costs under control. [C9.] FIRST N.Y.S.E. CHAIRMAN DIES -- James J. Needham, the first full-time paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Friday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. [B6.] A KING OF MEXICAN FOOD HAS DIED -- Louis Flores Ruiz, who built a modest enchilada factory in California into the nation's largest producer of frozen Mexican foods, has died. [B6.] ONLINE MORE PIECES, STILL A PUZZLE -- New rules were supposed to paint a fuller picture of executive pay, but more information has not brought more clarity. A special report on executive pay is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER of the beleaguered video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software announced his resignation, less than two weeks after a shareholder revolt that ousted the chief executive and several board members. (AP) JACKSON HEWITT TAX SERVICE said that a franchisee named in civil lawsuits filed last week by the Justice Department had agreed to temporarily suspend operations. (REUTERS) THE DEFENSE DEPARTMENT has drafted rules to curb lending practices it considers predatory -- including payday loans, car title lending and tax refund anticipation loans -- to military service members and their families. (REUTERS)

headline: G.O.P. Voters Voice Anxieties On Party's Fate
summary: After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. In a survey that brought to life the party's anxieties about keeping the White House, Republicans said they were concerned that their party had drifted from the principles of Ronald Reagan, its most popular figure of the past 50 years.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths HETKIN, BERENICE BERKE
summary: HETKIN--Berenice Berke, a woman of artistic proclivities and many interests died at the age of 86 on June 3, 2006 in her hometown, New York City. A professional interior designer for over 50 years, Berenice was equally proud of her achievements as a painter, illustrator, portraitist, performing artist and political activist. She studied at Columbia University, entering at age 14, and later at the Parsons School of Design and at the Ecole des Beaux Arts, Fontainebleau, France. When World War II broke out, she postponed further, studies and went to work for British War Relief and later the USO, performing as a vocalist and sketching the world at war on the homefront, in New York and in Montreal. Berenice became recognized as a skilled portraitist, meeting and drawing, to name a few, Hector Villa-Lobos, Andres Segovia, Charles De Gaulle, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Edward R. Murrow and a great number of United Nations ambassadors and delegates of the post-war infant organization at Lake Success, New York, where she was artistcorrespondent for ONA and several magazines. Her portrait of Edward R. Murrow is on display at CBS Broadcasting. Politically, Berenice headed the New York Speakers Bureau for Americans for Democratic Action and was active in the Democratic Party. In 1953 Berenice married Alfred H. Hetkin, a prominent New York real estate law attorney. Their marriage lasted more than 20 years. After the death of Mr. Hetkin, she remained close to her stepdaughter Maria Illo. Survivors are step granddaughter Shanti Reinhardt Kanter and step-great grandson, Kainoa Emmanuel Kanter, of Los Angeles, California, and distant cousins: Ilaria Lezzi De Breto of Virginia, Minnesota, Melody Brod Johnson of Boulder, Colorado, Daniel Ira Broad of Rockville, Maryland and Harriet Rubin of New York City.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 27-June 2; TELEVISION
summary: The network ''season,'' to the extent that the term still has any meaning, would seem to be ending with the ''House'' finale on Tuesday (9 p.m., Fox). So on to summer: This week brings us the premieres of Mark Burnett's new reality treasure hunt, ''PIRATE MASTER'' (8 p.m. Thursday, CBS), and Kevin Williamson's ''O.C.''-in-the-desert melodrama, ''HIDDEN PALMS'' (8 p.m. Wednesday, CW). Taylor Handley, who played the evil Oliver Trask in the first season of the real ''O.C.,'' now gets to play the Ryan character, a troubled teenager who moves to Palm Springs and discovers that he's the normal one. My own mindless-fun pick: the second season of ''HEX'' (8 p.m. Saturday, BBC America), the cheap-and-dirty, and highly entertaining, British ''Buffy'' clone. A full night of ''The Real World'' on MTV culminates in the first episode of a new six-episode spinoff, ''REUNITED: THE REAL WORLD VEGAS'' (10 p.m. Wednesday), in which cast members from the 2002 Las Vegas season reconvene in the same suite at the Palms. How long will it be before Steven, Brynn and Trishelle get back in the hot tub? Start your office pool now. Three months after Bob Woodruff's ''To Iraq and Back,'' CBS presents a special about the other high-profile American television journalist to be seriously wounded (so far) in Iraq: ''FLASHPOINT: KIMBERLY DOZIER AND THE ARMY'S FOURTH ID'' (10 p.m. Tuesday). Katie Couric anchors the program. Ian Somerhalder, whose Boone was one of the first casualties of ''Lost,'' turns up as the prettiest explorer you've ever seen on the Hallmark Channel's ''MARCO POLO'' (8 p.m. Saturday). The three-hour movie is a Robert Halmi production and as corny and campy as that suggests (Brian Dennehy as Kublai Khan!); watch for the moment when B. D. Wong, as Marco's assigned servant, Pedro, looks deep into Mr. Somerhalder's eyes and murmurs: ''I am to be your slave. My master's every desire is my only happiness.''

headline: Even Wookiees Need a Good Belly Laugh
summary: SOMETIMES, after a long day of working with Wookiees, Ewoks, Jedi knights and Mandalorian bounty hunters, even the employees of Lucasfilm need a break. And when they get distracted, like anyone else stuck in an office, they surf the Web. Their own particular fetish is videos, and among their favorites -- no surprise -- has a ''Star Wars'' theme. It is an animated short from ''Robot Chicken,'' the series created by Seth Green and Matthew Senreich for the Cartoon Network's Adult Swim programming block. In it the evil emperor Palpatine receives a weepy phone call from Darth Vader after the Death Star is destroyed. Only the emperor's (heavily bleeped) portion of the conversation is audible as he learns that his battle station has been blown up by a band of meddlesome teenagers. (''That thing wasn't even fully paid off yet,'' he grouses. ''Do you have any idea what this is going to do to my credit?'')

headline: On Reality Menu: Bathos (Lightly Basted With Malice)
summary: The problem with reality television is not that it traffics in humiliation. The problem is that it's not humiliating enough. There is no excuse for a series about spoiled suburban housewives that focuses on their inner lives. Yet ''The Tuesday Night Book Club,'' which begins tomorrow on CBS, showcases soul-searching and empowerment. Despite leering promos that promise bosomy, botoxed heroines drinking, dancing and plotting adultery (a Sisterhood of the Traveling Hot Pants), the series is a teary feel-bad/grow-stronger pageant along the lines of the daytime life-coaching series ''Starting Over.''

headline: Corrections
summary: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the merger of the WB and UPN networks to form the CW network misidentified the owner of some television stations. The stations -- WUPA in Atlanta, KXTA in Dallas, WBFS in Miami, KBHK in San Francisco and KSTW in Seattle -- are owned by the CBS Corporation, which split off from Viacom recently, not by Viacom.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fall Into Spring TV
summary: When daylight saving time goes into effect, as it did Sunday morning, the television audience usually drops, as viewers have more evening sunlight to enjoy. But even taking that trend into account, the ratings on Thursday night were particularly low. On CBS, which won every half-hour in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic, the latest edition of ''Survivor'' (16.4 million) continued to be down compared with last spring. And ''CSI'' (22.91 million) drew its lowest 18-to-49 rating for an original episode since October 2001 (not counting its broadcast opposite the ''Friends'' series finale two years ago). Fox, which has a solid schedule from Sunday through Wednesday, finished fourth for the night. Its once-dominant ''O.C.'' delivered a mere 5.03 million viewers, who watched Summer and Seth break up for the umpteenth time; the series's audience was the lowest it has ever had for an original episode among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9:30 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Julia Louis-Dreyfus (left), forever beloved (in a sinister way) as Elaine on ''Seinfeld,'' gives the prime-time sitcom world another try. This time she's the title character, a divorced mother who is running a gym, putting her son into a snobby private school and trying to maintain a friendly relationship with her ex. He, inconsiderately, has a new girlfriend, also named Christine. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP -- Where do they find these people? The Stamper family of Ohio like to pretend they're living in the Middle Ages -- all the time. So they homeschool their children in medieval arts and crafts, build Viking-style furniture, have meat and turnips for dinner, and play the harp. Stephanie Stamper will stay with the Haggertys, who live in Florida (in the 21st century), and Lisa Haggerty will try to drag the Stampers into the present. 9 P.M. (Lifetime) AUGUSTA, GONE -- Sharon Lawrence (right) stars as a businesswoman and divorced mother of two whose sweet, well-behaved 15-year-old daughter, Augusta (Mika Boorem), suddenly undergoes a complete transformation. She becomes hostile and self-destructive, begins drinking and taking drugs, and eventually ends up living on the street. Tim Matheson plays the ex-husband. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Yes, even Charlie (Charlie Sheen), playboy bachelor jingle writer, has insecurities. For years now, his advertising archrival (Jon Lovitz, guest star) has been beating him out at the awards banquet. So this time, Charlie decides to boycott. 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- Tonight's villain is misguided Aunt Donna. Cathy and Steve Schwartz, who both work full time, try to control their four children (ages 1 to 6), but Cathy's sister, Donna, who cares for them during the day, doesn't believe in discipline (''They're just kids''). Jo Frost, the visiting British supernannny, intervenes. 9 P.M. (5) 24 -- ''Day 5: 7 P.M.-8 P.M.'' The Homeland Security people arrive. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Allison (Patricia Arquette, below), psychic, wife and mom, is not as happy as you might expect when her brother suddenly shows up in town. That's because she has just dreamed that he robbed a local bank. And Allison's dreams always mean something. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13) TURKEY'S TIGERS -- At the crossroads of Europe and Asia, Turkey has long been run by secular politicians and businessmen aligned with the West, while pious Muslims have been jostled to the sidelines. This ''Wide Angle'' documentary looks at the Anatolian Tigers, a group of Muslim businessmen like Mustafa Karaduman (above), the chief executive of the country's largest Islamic-style clothing chain, who are embracing Western capitalism while ascending the ranks of Turkish society. 8 P.M. (History) THE EGYPTIAN BOOK OF THE DEAD -- It tells why the Egyptians built the pyramids and may have been the source of the 10 Commandments. (Some archaeologists argue that Moses co-opted a copy when he fled Egypt.) This special uses re-enactments and computer animation to follow the ancient scroll across nearly 4,000 years. 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- A Hurricane Katrina anniversary ''Fear Factor''? In this ''disaster'' episode, contestants must endure hurricane-force rain and wind while teetering on a ledge 100 feet in the air, eat cockroaches and battle a flash flood. 8 P.M. (CBS) J. C. PENNEY JAM: THE CONCERT FOR AMERICA'S KIDS -- It takes a village, or at least a chorus. Mary J. Blige (left), Andrea Bocelli, Jon Bon Jovi, Chris Botti, Kenny Chesney, Peter Cincotti, 3 Doors Down, Sara Evans, John Legend, Martina McBride and Sting lend their voices to the cause of children's education in this concert special supporting the J. C. Penney Afterschool Fund. Dr. Phil McGraw and his wife, Robin, are hosts. 9 P.M. (HBO) WHEN THE LEVEES BROKE: A REQUIEM IN FOUR ACTS -- Tonight, Acts III and IV in Spike Lee's visual epic about the effects of Hurricane Katrina on residents of New Orleans. 10 P.M. (Discovery Health) STRICTLY DR. DREW -- Smoking, drinking, gambling and too many cups of coffee. Dr. Drew Pinsky discusses addictions that destroy lives. 10 P.M. (13) LOMAX THE SONGHUNTER -- Alan Lomax was a man on a mission: to record the world's folk tunes before they would permanently disappear. Using film clips of Woody Guthrie and Leadbelly, and interviews with friends like Pete Seeger, this ''P.O.V.'' documentary follows his trail, from the cotton fields, rock quarries and prisons of this country to remote mountain villages in Spain and Italy, to recreate some of what Lomax heard before his death in 2001. 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE -- A year of marriage, a year's worth of fat. Tonight, the Fab Five help Erik and Khadijah Williams (right) celebrate their anniversary with a new apartment, new bodies and new moves. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Everything on TV Is a Competition
summary: On Wednesday's ''Lost'' on ABC, the formerly nice Michael (Harold Perrineau) turned not so nice after spending some time with the island's nasty Others. He shot, and perhaps killed, Ana Lucia (Michelle Rodriguez) and Libby (Cynthia Watros). But the first half of that episode faced the formidable competition of an ''American Idol'' results show on Fox (28.5 million); despite a strong performance in the ratings (15.03 million), ''Lost'' was still trounced. Fox won the night in Nielsen's estimates in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. On ''Idol,'' Paris Bennett, right, who sang Prince and Mary J. Blige songs on Tuesday, received the voting boot, leaving Katharine McPhee as the only female contestant. Ms. McPhee will vie for the ''Idol'' prize against Taylor Hicks, Chris Daughtry and Elliott Yamin. Elsewhere on the networks CBS placed second among total viewers, with its lineup of ''The Amazing Race'' (7.75 million), ''Criminal Minds'' (12.15 million) and ''CSI: New York'' (14.3 million). And on WB ''One Tree Hill,'' which is not a sure bet to be scheduled on the new CW network next season, wrapped up this season, and possibly the series, with an audience of 3.24 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Couples, On Screen an Off | Jan. 22-28
summary: YOUNG LOVE The News -- CBS and Time Warner said they would team up to turn two small young television networks, UPN and WB, into a new one called CW. Behind the News -- With the creation of CW, Leslie Moonves, chief executive of CBS, has his eye on youth. CBS is the best performer among all networks, but its least success is with the under-35 crowd. Neither UPN nor WB has raked in the money, but shows like UPN's ''Everybody Hates Chris'' and ''Friday Night Smackdown'' and WB's ''Gilmore Girls'' and ''Smallville'' play to that critical demographic. MICKEY 'N' WOODY The News -- Walt Disney said Tuesday that it would acquire Pixar Animation Studios in a $7.4 billion stock deal. Behind the News -- This deal has a lot to do with the companies' creative cultures. One animation blockbuster after another in recent years has come from Pixar, creator of ''Toy Story'' and ''The Incredibles,'' aided by the innovative use of computer technology. Disney, by contrast, is the old-fashioned grandfather of animation, with fewer hits of recent vintage. The deal promises to give Pixar's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, a powerful role in Hollywood. NO LONGER BETWEEN THE COVERS The News -- Oprah Winfrey withdrew her support for James Frey and ''A Million Little Pieces,'' his ''memoir'' about his trip into and out of the depths of drug addiction. Behind the News -- It's still a best seller. Still the fastest-moving book ever to be featured in Ms. Winfrey's television book club. Still the second-highest-selling book of 2005. It's not still a work of nonfiction, apparently, after Ms. Winfrey decided that dismissing the fictions of the book as nitpickery had been a mistake on her part. What is not yet clear is whether all the controversy will add to the huge sales of the book -- as well as Mr. Frey's follow-up book, ''My Friend Leonard'' -- or put a halt to them. That may depend on whether readers feel as Nan A. Talese, Mr. Frey's publisher, does about the genre. ''Memoir,'' Ms. Talese said, ''is personal recollection. It is not absolute fact. It's how one remembers what happened. That is different from history and criticism and biography, and they cannot be measured by the same yardstick.'' Time and sales will tell. GOODBYE, GRACE The News -- NBC said it would cancel ''Will & Grace'' and ''The West Wing'' at the end of the season. Behind the News -- The two series have been among NBC's most popular recent shows, but their ratings have fallen in the last two seasons and, more to the point, the network over all now trails its rivals. So there will be a shuffling of the new reliables in prime time, as well as the addition of some new shows. When viewers tune in to Turin next month for the Olympic Games, they'll get a look at the new lineup.

headline: Corrections
summary: A television review on Jan. 17 about ''Love Monkey,'' a new CBS series, misstated the title of a collection of Bob Dylan recordings that a woman gives to the hero. It is ''The Essential Bob Dylan,'' not ''The Ultimate Bob Dylan.''

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE UNIT -- This new action drama series is from David Mamet, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of ''Glengarry Glen Ross.'' Jonas Blane (Dennis Haysbert, near right, best known as the first president on Fox's ''24'') leads covert special-forces operatives on undercover missions around the world. In the series premiere, the team faces a hijacked plane full of European businessmen, and Jonas faces a brand-new recruit (Scott Foley, above right, who was Noel on WB's ''Felicity''). 8 P.M. (13) CHRIS BOTTI LIVE -- Mr. Botti, the heartthrob trumpeter who has dated Katie Couric and toured with Sting, does a 90-minute music special. His guests include Burt Bacharach, Sting and Gladys Knight. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS -- The case begins with Marine dog tags found by some teenagers in a national forest. Naval Criminal Investigative Service agents, including Leroy Jethro Gibbs (Mark Harmon, left), Tony DiNozzo (Michael Weatherly) and Ducky Mallard (David McCallum), are soon looking for a serial killer who may be using the forest as a conveniently secluded place to torture and kill women. 9 P.M. (ABC) SONS & DAUGHTERS -- Series premiere. One couple have three children of their own and an unhappy teenage son from the husband's first marriage. Another couple have two teenagers, but no sex (and haven't for years). The two couples give a party for Granny and her husband, who may be splitting up. In a second episode, at 9:30, one husband and wife go bowling and the other two reconsider abstinence. 9 P.M. (5) HOUSE -- ''Sex Kills.'' Howard Hesseman guest-stars as a man who, after a seizure and a heart attack, is in serious need of a transplant. Dr. Gregory House (Hugh Laurie) finds a donor heart but has to figure out what mysterious illness killed its owner before he can use it. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) 8TH & OCEAN -- This new reality series is about 10 aspiring bookkeepers who move in together in Des Moines. No, just kidding. It's about 10 aspiring models (above) who move in together in Miami and try to make it big. There's an arrogant guy from Puerto Rico; female twins from Florida; and a devout Midwestern minister's daughter, who may or may not be susceptible to the temptations of South Beach. ANITA GATES

headline: Arts, Briefly; Without Game, a Fumble
summary: In the absence of football on Monday night, ABC aimed at female viewers, subbing Heather Graham, John Stamos and ''The Bachelor'' for John Madden and the game of the week. But the premiere of this new schedule didn't work out well. Over all, ABC placed third in adults 18 to 49 and fourth among total viewers. ''Wife Swap,'' which led the night, was not the problem, as it drew an audience of 11.05 million and won the hour among 18-to-49-year-olds. Following that, the debut of Ms. Graham's ''Emily's Reasons Why Not'' (6.23 million) did poorly, and the return of Mr. Stamos's ''Jake in Progress'' fared even worse, with 5.58 million viewers. At 10 p.m., ''The Bachelor'' (6.2 million) didn't stand a chance against CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (19.6 million) and NBC's ''Medium'' (11.31 million). The ratings for the reality dating show were down in double-digit percentages from its premiere episodes last season. In Nielsen's estimates for the night, CBS easily won both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: J. P. Morgan Chase to Pay $425 Million To Settle Suit Over Offerings During Boom J. P. Morgan Chase said that it would pay $425 million to settle its part of a class-action lawsuit that contends that dozens of banks cheated investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars from initial public offerings during the market boom of the 1990's. [Page C1.] Questions on Proxy Adviser's Pfizer Recommendation Proxy Governance Inc. recently urged its investor customers to vote for all 13 of Pfizer's directors. A memo written in 2004 by Pfizer's chief executive, Hank McKinnell, urging corporations to buy and promote Proxy Governance's services just as the firm was opening for business, raises questions about whether the advisory firm's recommendation reflects an unbiased point of view or a relationship with the company and its top executive. [C1.] Alltel Announces Service Plan With Some Free Calls Alltel, the cellphone company, announced a new service plan that lets customers make free calls to any 10 numbers regardless of the cellphone or land-line carrier of the person being called. The ''My Circle'' plan, a first among major carriers, is premised on statistics that show that many consumers make most of their calls to about half a dozen numbers. Alltel expects that if customers can call these numbers free, they will have more minutes left over to call other people. [C9.] Google Reports Profit Gain of 60% in First Quarter Google returned to favor among investors, as its profit for the quarter increased by 60 percent, well above expectations. Its shares, which rose in regular trading, climbed higher after hours, when the results were released. [C1.] General Motors said it sharply reduced its loss during the first quarter -- a breakthrough for a company battered by accounting missteps and doubts about the future of its chief executive and of the automaker itself. [C3.] Merck, Eli Lilly and Schering-Plough reported higher first-quarter earnings as sales rose for drugs to treat cholesterol, depression and cancer. [C5.] Nokia, the cellphone maker, said that its first-quarter profit rose 21 percent from a year earlier as sales surged in North America and Asia. [C5.] Earnings Reports Help Dow as Nasdaq Drops Stocks closed mixed. Helped by earnings reports from Merck and G.M., the Dow rose 64.12 points, to 11,342.89, its best showing since it closed at 11,351.30 on Jan. 20, 2000. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.53 points, to 1,311.46, and the Nasdaq fell 8.33 points, to 2,362.55. [C7.] Democrats Putting Spotlight on High Gas Prices Democrats running for Congress are moving quickly to use the most recent surge in oil and gasoline prices to bash Republicans over energy policy, and more broadly, the direction of the country. [A1.] Signs of Tougher Stance on Illegal Immigrants The apprehension of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a pallet supply company based in Houston, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represented the start of a more aggressive crackdown on employers, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said. [A1.] A Complex View of Former Enron Executive The portrait of Jeffrey K. Skilling, former chief of Enron, that emerged in his criminal fraud trial was more complex than the caricature frequently drawn of him as a greedy, arrogant executive. Instead, Mr. Skilling showed himself to be a vulnerable, emotional, even affable character. But jurors also saw a man who did not like to be questioned or told he was wrong. [C1.] Volkswagen Chairman Says Chief Is Likely to Stay The chairman of Volkswagen's supervisory board, Ferdinand K. Piëch, said that he expected the embattled chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, to win a contract extension. That was a remarkable change in tone from February, when Mr. Piëch threw Mr. Pischetsrieder's future into doubt by suggesting that he had lost the support of Volkswagen's employees. [C7.] Roth May Be Replaced as Morning Radio Host CBS Radio and XM Satellite Radio are in talks to replace David Lee Roth, left, the morning host on seven CBS stations, with Opie and Anthony, the foulmouthed talk team that has been the marquee talent on XM for the last 18 months, according to executives at both companies. Under the deal, Opie and Anthony would do a cleaner version of their usual show -- one acceptable under broadcast standards -- for the CBS audience for three hours each weekday. That portion of the show would also be heard on XM. After that show, the two hosts would do two additional hours of the show, unrestrained. [C7.] Housekeepers Protest as Hotels Bulk Up on Amenities Housekeepers at the nation's hotels say that bigger beds and more pillows in rooms are creating more work and increasing the risk of injuries. The hotel workers' union says the issue will be a major factor in negotiations this spring with Hilton, Starwood and other hotel chains. [A20.] F.C.C. Steps Up Inquiry Into Radio Stations The Federal Communications Commission intensified its investigation into accusations of pay-for-play practices at four of the nation's biggest radio station owners after settlement talks collapsed, agency officials said. [C5.] Shell Says Repairs in Gulf Were Completed Early Royal Dutch Shell said that it had completed repairs on its Mars platform in the Gulf of Mexico and would resume production ahead of schedule. [C5.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; Déjà Vu All Over Again
summary: As strange as it might seem, viewers actually watch clip shows, those recycled montage episodes that purport to bring the audience up to date on a series. On Sunday, the ''Desperate Housewives'' (15.78 million viewers) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (14.44 million) clip shows were the night's two most-watched programs, and led ABC in its win in Nielsen's estimates. CBS ranked second among total viewers for the night. But its ''60 Minutes'' (11.28 million), ''Cold Case'' (12.46 million) and the television movie ''In From the Night'' (10.54 million) placed fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox placed second in that age group, led by ''The Simpsons'' (7.04 million) and ''Family Guy'' (8.04 million). NBC was No. 3 in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. At 10 p.m. ''Crossing Jordan'' (11.28 million) was the network's most-watched show. Earlier in the night, Rob Lowe returned to ''The West Wing'' (8.42 million) as the likely deputy chief of staff in the Santos administration, and forced the unhinged Josh (Bradley Whitford) to take a vacation. KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: PENSION BILL AND MINIMUM WAGE Senate Democrats blocked legislation tying the first minimum wage increase in almost a decade to a decrease in the estate tax, denying Republicans a legislative victory. But the Senate did pass an overhaul of the pension bill. [Page A1.] PREVIEW OF GRASSO TRIAL Court filings this week provide a glimpse of what the jury will hear in the trial over the pay of Richard A. Grasso, former head of the New York Stock Exchange. The filings also indicate that information about the exchange's financial results was inflated through the use of an improper accounting technique. [C1.] MORE STOCK OPTION QUESTIONS Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn are preparing charges over stock options grants against former executives of Comverse, a Long Island communications software company, a person close to the investigation says. [C1.] MERCK'S RECENT WINS Merck has turned the tables in the Vioxx litigation -- at least for the moment. On Wednesday, a California jury ruled that Merck's painkiller Vioxx did not cause the heart attack suffered by Stewart Grossberg in 2001. The case was Merck's second consecutive victory, after a win for the company in New Jersey last month. Meanwhile, more than 300 federal lawsuits have been dismissed. [C1.] ACCORD ON MILITARY INSURANCE American Amicable Life Insurance has agreed to pay up to $70 million to settle complaints that it used deceptive sales practices to sell unsuitable insurance products to thousands of military personnel across the country and on bases overseas. [C3.] AOL TO CUT 5,000 JOBS AOL will eliminate at least 5,000 jobs -- more than a quarter of its work force -- as part of its plan to scale back its Internet access business. [C3.] I.B.M. TO BUY SOFTWARE FIRM I.B.M. announced that it planned to buy MRO Software for $740 million, a move that underlines the increasing importance of software to the company's big services business. [C5.] RATE INCREASE IN EUROPE The board of the European Central Bank increased interest rates a quarter-point and warned of further increases in the future. [C3.] SL GREEN TO BUY RECKSON The SL Green Realty Corporation said that it would buy a rival, the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, for $4 billion in cash and stock. [C3.] FORD EXPANDS RECALL Ford significantly widened a recall that already involved millions of vehicles with cruise control systems that are prone to catching fire. Vehicles included in the expanded recall are 1994 to 2002 models of the Ford F-250, F-350, F-450 and F-550 Super Duty pickup trucks; 2000 to 2002 models of the Excursion, above; 1994 to 1996 Econoline vans; 1996 to 2002 E-450 vans; and 1998 Explorers and Mercury Mountaineers. [C4.] GIFT AND BURDEN A $1.5 billion bequest -- the largest single gift to a charity in history -- has posed a challenge for the Salvation Army, and caused soul-searching about its core purpose. [A14.] A WAY TO GIVE MORE Wealthy campaign donors in New York are legally using limited liability corporations as a vehicle to give money well above the maximum that is allowed. [A1.] SPRINT STOCK FALLS ON RESULTS Sprint Nextel reported disappointing second-quarter earnings, sending its stock down almost 12 percent. [C5.] HOT JULY HELPS RETAILERS Scorching heat gave retailers an unexpected sales bounce in July. [C4.] STOCKS RISE Economic data led to gains in the market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 42.66 points, to 11,242.59. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 1.72 points, to 1,280.27, and the Nasdaq gained 13.53 points, to 2,092.34. [C9.] REVERSE FINANCIAL COMMUTERS Thousands of financial workers stream into Grand Central Terminal every weekday morning. But many are not on their way to Wall Street. Instead, they are crowded into trains for Greenwich, Conn., which has emerged as the home of the ballooning hedge fund industry. [C6.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. NORTEL NETWORKS, the telecommunications equipment company, said an accounting gain allowed it to report a second-quarter profit, but profit margins continued to be squeezed. Nortel said it earned $366 million for the quarter. That was in contrast to a loss of $33 million, or 1 cent a share, for the year-earlier quarter. The profit included a gain of $510 million related to a shareholder litigation recovery, and a loss of $10 million on the sale of assets. (REUTERS) SHARES OF MEDTRONIC, a maker of electronic heart devices, tumbled 13 percent to their lowest level since late 2003, a day after it warned that its quarterly sales would fall short of expectations. Shares fell $6.61, to $44.32. (REUTERS) WARNER MUSIC GROUP said its third-quarter loss narrowed in part because of higher revenue and shrinking costs. For the quarter, the loss was $14 million, compared with $179 million, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $822 million from $742 million, while costs and expenses were $794 million, in contrast to $834 million in the year-earlier period. (AP) THE CBS CORPORATION posted higher earnings for its second-quarter on unusual items including a tax benefit and a gain on the sale of its parks division, but revenues declined on weakness in its radio operations. CBS earned $781.7 million, or $1.02 a share, in contrat to $753.8 million, or 94 cents a share, a year ago. (AP) THE COSMETICS MAKER REVLON Inc. said that its second-quarter loss widened. The company controlled by the investor Ronald O. Perelman lost $87.1 million in contrast to a loss of $35.8 million in the period a year ago. Revenue edged up 1 percent. (AP)

headline: A Winning Experience Starts With a Strategy
summary: When Is the United States Open? Today through Sunday, Sept. 10. Most of the day sessions start at 11 a.m., and night sessions begin at 7 p.m. The women's final is at 8 p.m. on Saturday, Sept. 9. The men's final is at 4 p.m. the next day. Where Is It? At the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. Arthur Ashe Stadium, the main court, holds 22,911 spectators. Louis Armstrong Stadium holds 9,689 and the Grandstand holds 5,000. Seating varies at the 15 other courts. Are There Any Tickets Left? Check at the box office (on the side of the Grandstand), call (866) 673-6849, or visit www.ticketmaster.com or Ticketmaster locations. Grounds passes, good for all courts but Arthur Ashe Stadium, are on sale throughout the tournament. How Do I Get There? By subway: take the No. 7 train to Willets Point-Shea Stadium (19 local stops from Times Square, 9 by express). By the Long Island Rail Road from Penn Station: take the Port Washington branch to Shea Stadium, a 16-minute ride. For more subway and L.I.R.R. information: visit www.mta.nyc.ny.us or call (718) 217-5477 in New York City; (516) 822-5477 in Nassau County; (631) 231-5477 in Suffolk County. A cab ride from Midtown Manhattan is about $30, including tolls. What If the Mets Are Playing? The Mets have a homestand at Shea Stadium Sept. 4-Sept 10. To alleviate traffic, a shuttle service will run every 15 minutes from a free parking lot at Orchard Beach in the Bronx to the tennis center, starting Sept. 4 at 10 a.m. Return shuttles will run every 15 minutes until 30 minutes after the conclusion of the night's final match. More information on the shuttle service is available at www.usopen.org. What Will Security Be Like? Spectators will be screened before boarding United States Open shuttles and while passing through the gates at the tennis center. There is a limit of one bag per person, and all bags are subject to search. There is no baggage check on the grounds. Sealed packages, briefcases, backpacks, coolers, glass bottles, cans, professional video cameras, recording devices, banners or signs, computers and any item deemed to be dangerous or inappropriate are prohibited. See the Open for Free U.S. Open Live in the streets of Manhattan, Sept. 2-10. Interactive games, tennis instruction and giant viewing screens carrying live tournament feeds from USA Network and CBS Sports, at Rockefeller Center and Madison Square Park. Live radio broadcasts of matches and video highlights are also available at usopen.org.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Buys Rights To Super Bowl Beer Ads
summary: Anheuser-Busch has agreed to be the exclusive sponsor in the beer category for four of the next five Super Bowls. Financial terms were not disclosed. Anheuser-Busch, which has been the exclusive beer sponsor for the Super Bowl since 1989, will do so again for the Super Bowls in 2007 and 2010 on CBS and in 2008 and 2011 on Fox Broadcasting, said Anthony T. Ponturo, vice president for global media and sports marketing at Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis. The company also plans to seek exclusive sponsorship for the 2008 Super Bowl on NBC, he said.

headline: POLL GIVES BUSH WORST MARKS YET ON MAJOR ISSUES
summary: Americans have a bleaker view of the country's direction than at any time in more than two decades, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sharp disapproval of President Bush's handling of gasoline prices has combined with intensified unhappiness about Iraq to create a grim political environment for the White House and Congressional Republicans. Mr. Bush's approval ratings for his management of foreign policy, Iraq and the economy have fallen to the lowest levels of his presidency. He drew poor marks on the issues that have been at the top of the national agenda in recent months, in particular immigration and gasoline prices.

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- In this two-part, pre-season special, Ty Pennington and his team build a high-tech home in Bergenfield, N.J., for the Llanes family, which has several members who are legally blind and another who is deaf. Famous guests include the actress Marlee Matlin (above right, with Paige Hemmis, a designer) as team leader; Don Lafontaine, the movie-trailer voiceover artist, as narrator; and the gospel group the Blind Boys of Alabama, which will perform. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THREE MOONS OVER MILFORD -- There are some things you just don't want to have to hear. Tonight, the residents start confessing to each other after the town priest gives up his profession. 8 P.M. (History) THE SAHARA -- Once as lush as the Garden of Eden, the Sahara is now the most unforgiving place on Earth. This special explores the environmental and sociological changes in the world's largest desert across more than 2,500 years, and examines the myth that, in 525 B.C., a Persian army of 40,000 warriors was buried beneath it by a sandstorm. 8 P.M. (Lifetime) CRIES IN THE DARK -- A detective (Eva LaRue) investigates the murder of her nine-months-pregnant sister, and the kidnapping of her baby. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS -- The White Stripes (left) perform in a benefit concert to raise money for Bart after his drumming arm is mangled by a tiger. 8:30 P.M. (CBS) THE AMAZING RACE 10 -- In this season premiere, 12 teams of two contestants each, including a coal miner and his wife and a couple of reigning beauty queens, prepare to travel more than 40,000 miles across 13 countries on four continents in under a month for a cool $1 million. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE INSPECTOR LYNLEY MYSTERIES, SERIES V: IN THE GUISE OF DEATH -- Did a horse trainer's money troubles really lead him to hang himself? In this new ''Mystery!'' episode, Inspector Thomas Lynley (Nathaniel Parker) contemplates murder, and tightens the noose around his future. 9 P.M. (Discovery) ASSAULT ON WACO -- On April 19, 1993, after a 51-day standoff with federal agents, the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., went up in flames, killing 76 members of the religious group, including 27 children and its leader, David Koresh. This documentary goes inside the compound (where the Mount Carmel Chapel, above, now stands as a memorial) using archival film footage, and recreates the F.B.I.'s efforts to bring Koresh in. 10 P.M. (E!) THE GIRLS NEXT DOOR -- ''I See London, I See France.'' Bet that's not all Hugh Hefner sees when he tours Europe with his three girlfriends. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SKILLING TO BE SENTENCED -- Jeffrey Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, is scheduled to be sentenced today in federal court. Most legal experts are betting that Judge Simeon T. Lake will give Mr. Skilling a sentence of at least 25 years for his role in heading a conspiracy to defraud Enron investors. If it exceeds that, it would be the longest sentence ever handed down for a white-collar crime. [C1.] FLAWS SEEN IN NO-SWIPE CARDS -- Researchers say they have discovered several potential security and privacy holes in a new generation of credit cards whose data is relayed by radio waves without need of a signature or a physical swipe through a machine. [C1.] GAP STARTS SHOE SITE -- The success of Zappos, the online shoe store, has enticed Gap Inc., which is in a sales slump, to introduce its own shoe site. Last week the company unveiled a new brand, Piperlime, on a Web site that features thousands of footwear styles from 150 brands. Toby C. Lenk, above, president of Gap Direct, the company's Internet division, said that his unit's recent technology upgrade had been paying off. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C9.] GOOGLE ATTRACTS LAWSUITS -- As Google has grown into the world's most popular search engine, it has become entangled in scores of lawsuits touching on a wide range of legal questions, including copyright violation, trademark infringement and its method of ranking Web sites. [C1.] A TV SHOW'S QUICK RETREAT -- CBS has canceled its new television show ''Smith,'' even though the first three episodes attracted an average audience of more than 9 million. The move points out how television, like the movie industry, has become a business where there is little room for a modest success. [C1.] NEW ROLE FOR TONY HAWK -- Rolling Stone is joining forces with two of its advertisers, Activision and Jeep, in a promotional program centered on Mr. Hawk, the skateboarding star. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C10.] AOL SEEKS EUROPEAN EXPANSION -- AOL attracted 31 million unique visitors to its European Web sites last month while Google sites drew more than 160 million. Jonathan F. Miller, chief executive of AOL, wants to start closing that gap as the company tries to transform itself from a business supported largely by subscriber fees to one financed primarily by advertising. [C4.] ROSE AND WAL-MART CHIEF -- Just two months after Charlie Rose, left, scored an interview with H. Lee Scott Jr., the camera-shy chief executive of Wal-Mart, Mr. Rose is honoring Mr. Scott at a private dinner party for his work on behalf of the environment. The close timing of interview and the dinner has raised the eyebrows of Mike Getler, the ombudsman at PBS, which distributes Mr. Rose's talk show. ''Don't do this,'' was Mr. Getler's unsolicited advice to Mr. Rose. [C4.] NORTH KOREA SAYS NO TO WEB -- While some restrictive governments have sought ways to limit the Internet -- through filters, blocks and threats -- North Korea has chosen to stay wholly off the grid. Tom Zeller Jr.: Link by Link. [C3.] NEW HIRE AT MILBERG WEISS -- Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, the embattled securities law firm, announced that Matthew Gluck, 63, a partner with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, was joining the firm as a senior partner. [C6.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; Nibbling at 'CSI'
summary: New episodes of CBS's ''CSI'' and ''Without a Trace'' meant that the Thursday Nielsen competition went back to status quo; the network was No. 1 in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. The numbers do suggest, though, that NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' and the 90-minute ''Dancing With the Stars'' on ABC have had some impact on the previously impenetrable ''CSI.'' At 9:30, when both shows ended, CBS's forensics ace in the hole went from an audience of 25.11 million for its first half-hour to 28.61 million for its second. ''Dancing'' (18.83 million) again helped the new Fred Savage sitcom, ''Crumbs,'' which delivered 11.45 million viewers. And on NBC, though ''Earl'' (10.75 million) and ''The Office'' (8.7 million) continue to do well in their new slots, ''Four Kings'' deteriorated, with 7.46 million viewers. At 10 p.m., ''Without a Trace'' faced ''Primetime Live'' on ABC (6.73 million) and a repeat of ''ER'' (7.41 million) on NBC. The morose missing-persons mystery brought in its largest audience (22.85 million) and best 18-to-49 ratings of the season. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Easter Offers No Feast For the Eyes
summary: Easter Sunday was a slow night for television. A number of series hit season-low ratings, including ABC's ''Desperate Housewives.'' But that comedic soap opera was still by far the night's most watched show in Nielsen's estimates, with 19.74 million viewers. That helped the series premiere of ''What About Brian,'' which took the place of ''Grey's Anatomy'' at 10 p.m. The wistful ''Brian'' delivered 12.84 million viewers, meaning it lost a significant number of the ''Housewives'' audience. But in the 18-to-49 demographic, it fared better, and easily beat NBC's ''Crossing Jordan'' (12.46 million) and the conclusion of the CBS movie ''Covert One: The Hades Factor'' (6.76 million from 9 to 11 p.m.). On the Sunday schedule, NBC's ''West Wing'' (8.28 million) was not the only veteran show about to end its run forever. WB's ''Charmed'' (3.05 million) and Fox's ''Malcolm in the Middle'' (2.92 million) will also go gently into that good night in the coming weeks. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STUART, DONALD KIRKLEY
summary: STUART -- Donald Kirkley. The retired president of Stuart Broadcasting Co. and founder of the National Baseball Network (NBN) died Thursday, March 23 at his home in Darien, CT at age 69. Born September 25, 1936 in Grundy VA to Russell Thorson and Caroline Clark Stuart, he graduated from Brown University in 1960 with a B.A. in English Literature. Prior to the formation of SBC and the NBN, Don was the national sales manager for WPIX-TV, a corporate Vice President of CBS and Broadcast Affairs Vice President for the New York Yankees. Don moved to Darien from New York City in 1977 and was active in the community. He is survived by his sister Lynn Stuart Merrell; a daughter, Michele Stuart; his sister's children and their families. A service was held in memory of Don on Tuesday, March 28 in the Chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Darien Library Annual Campaign, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820. www. lawrencefuneralhome.com

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) FOR LOVE OF IVY -- (1968). When a Long Island family's maid (Abbey Lincoln) wants to go back to school, their hippie son (Beau Bridges) decides a fix-up is in order, and his father (Carroll O'Connor) is there to guarantee that it happens. Sidney Poitier (above, with Ms. Lincoln) stars in this, Hollywood's first real attempt at portraying grown-up love between a black man and woman, and the follow-up to another first, ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' shown on TCM at 6. The Mamas and the Papas swing on the soundtrack. 7:30 P.M. (BET) ACCESS GRANTED -- Watch 'em here first. Tonight's show takes its cameras behind the scenes of the new video for T. I.'s ''Live in the Sky,'' featuring Jamie Foxx, and, at 8, Snoop Dogg's ''Vato,'' with Pharrell Williams and B Real of Cypress Hill. 8 P.M. (13) JEWELS FROM THE PARIS OPERA BALLET -- The muse behind George Balanchine's ''Jewels,'' the story goes, was not some ethereal ballerina but rather the gems in the cases at the New York jewelers Van Cleef & Arpels. In this ''Great Performances'' presentation, the Paris Opera Ballet lushly interprets this plotless three-act work created for New York City Ballet in 1967, and gives it a French couture twist, with costumes and backdrops designed by Christian Lacroix. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- Dr. Temperance Brennan (Emily Deschanel), television's prettiest crypt keeper, begins a new season of rummaging through fishy-smelling remains, starting with a train wreck that includes the bodies of a senator and a high-profile businessman. Meanwhile, there's tension back in the lab, where her new boss, Dr. Camille Saroyan (Tamara Taylor, above right), seems to have eyes for the object of Brennan's affections, Agent Seeley Booth (David Boreanaz). Ouch. 9 P.M. (Fox) JUSTICE -- Jerry Bruckheimer, the executive producer of CBS's ''C.S.I.'' and ''Without a Trace,'' tries out his Midas touch on this new legal drama about a Los Angeles dream team with an aptitude for forensics. Victor Garber plays the firm's slick-as-an-oil spill public persona; Rebecca Mader is the brilliant clinician whose radar is set to search and destroy. 9 P.M. (ABC) LAST DAYS OF EARTH -- Scare tactics? In this new ''20/20,'' scientists like Stephen Hawking explain seven of the deadliest threats to our existence: black holes, artificial intelligence, supervolcanoes, asteroid strikes, nuclear war, disease and climate change. 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS -- Er, make that 23 days. In this season finale of his reality show, Morgan Spurlock (left), who bulked up on -- and nearly blacked out from -- McDonald's food in his 2004 film ''Super Size Me,'' tries to stomach a month of serving time in a Richmond, Va., county jail. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: A British Perspective On the Couric Hoopla
summary: On a visit last week to New York, where much of the buzz focused on job changes at the major television networks, Richard Sambrook, the chief executive of BBC World and director of the BBC's global news division, offered a trans-Atlantic perspective on the game of musical chairs being played by Katie Couric and Meredith Vieira. BBC World has teamed up with Discovery Communications -- which already distributes BBC America, the BBC's entertainment channel -- to sell the BBC's 24-hour news channel, and this week expects to announce its first distribution deal with an American cable provider for the channel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Securities Inquiry on Japanese Internet Concern Leads to Turmoil on Tokyo Stock Exchange An investigation into a Japanese Internet services start-up for securities fraud had triggered a near-national panic as concerned investors have collectively withdrawn billions of dollars of their money from the Tokyo stock market over the last two days. [Page A1.] Is the Japanese establishment out to destroy an upstart who had the gall to try hostile takeovers and expand aggressively through acquisitions? Or is Takafumi Horie simply a 33-year-old crook who fooled investors with fake numbers? Market Place. [C1.] Apple Posts Strong Quarter, but a Disappointing Outlook Benefiting from brisk holiday sales of iPod music players, Apple Computer said its profit nearly doubled in the first quarter. But its outlook for the second quarter fell well below Wall Street's expectations, causing its stock to fall as much as 7 percent in after-hours trading. [C1.] Celebrity Revelations Possible in Executive Pay Proposal A provision in a federal proposal to disclose more information about executive compensation might also disclose the salaries of highly paid athletes, celebrities and business people. [C1.] J.P. Morgan Chase Says Quarterly Profit Rose 62% J.P. Morgan Chase said fourth-quarter profit increased 62 percent, but the strong performance was marred by concerns about the volatility of its businesses, especially trading. The company earned $2.7 billion, or 76 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $1.67 billion, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. But most of the profit came out of the $752 million pretax gains on the sale of BrownCo, its online brokerage unit. [C3.] Enron's Former Chief Eager to Tell His Side of the Story Just two weeks before his fraud trial is set to begin in federal court in Houston, Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of the Enron Corporation, is readying for battle. And he is eager to tell his side of the story. [C1.] Advanced Micro's Profit Tops Estimates by Wide Margin Advanced Micro Devices, the computer chip maker, reported fourth-quarter earnings that far exceeded Wall Street estimates and showed that it poses a serious threat to Intel, the world's biggest chip maker. [C11.] Two Airlines Post Higher Quarterly Revenue American Airlines and Southwest Airlines posted stronger-than-expected revenue growth for the fourth quarter, on higher air fares and fuller planes, but only Southwest was able to report a profit as high fuel and labor costs and a big debt load dragged down the results of American. [C2.] Economic Data Ease Concern About Inflation The consumer price index fell unexpectedly in December as energy prices dropped for a third consecutive month, the Labor Department reported, easing worries about sharply higher inflation last fall. [C3.] Federal Inspection Deal With Wal-Mart Expires Labor Department officials said that a much-criticized agreement that they had signed with Wal-Mart regarding workplace inspections was allowed to expire last week. The agreement gave Wal-Mart advance notice of federal inspections. [A15.] Labor Leader Calls for Universal Health Insurance The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, called on Congress to enact universal health insurance and to bar American companies from selling goods produced overseas under sweatshop conditions. Mr. Sweeney said the nation's unions would push in 30 states for legislation, like that enacted last week in Maryland, requiring large corporations to pay a specific percentage of their payroll toward health insurance. [A15.] Lawsuit to Challenge Some Food Ads Aimed at Children Two groups that promote controls over nutrition and advertising said they plan to sue Viacom and the Kellogg Company to challenge the use of popular cartoon characters to promote foods that have been deemed unhealthy. [C3.] President of CBS News Drops Hints on a New Anchor Sean McManus, the president of CBS News, said that he expected to name an anchor for ''CBS Evening News'' within a year; that it would be a solo anchor; and that the selection would come from outside CBS News. [B3.] Couple in Wendy's Finger Fraud Sentenced to Prison A couple who put a severed finger into a bowl of Wendy's chili in a scheme to extort money were sentenced to prison terms of at least nine years. [A10.] Stocks Fall on Disappointing Earnings Reports Stocks fell yesterday, pressured by disappointing earnings from Intel and Yahoo. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 41.46 points, to 10,854.86; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5 points, to 1,277.93; and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.05 points, to 2,279.64. [C10.]

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Enlivens ABC
summary: Suddenly, television's Thursday schedule is a lot livelier. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' returned this week and drew 17.33 million viewers to its two-hour premiere, according to Nielsen estimates. (Below, Giselle Fernandez, a journalist, and the dancer Jonathan Roberts.) ABC's Thursdays have had poor ratings this season, so ''Dancing'' was a big improvement over the sinking ''Alias'' and the canceled ''Night Stalker.'' The network finished in second place in total viewers. NBC also made a mark with its lineup changes. ''Will & Grace'' (7.98 million) moved to 8 p.m., in place of ''Joey,'' now on hiatus, and performed better than the woeful ''Friends'' spinoff did among 18-to-49-year-olds. ''Four Kings,'' from the creators of ''Will & Grace,'' made its debut at 8:30, and improved on its predecessor's demographic ratings, as well as its total audience (8.84 million). ''My Name Is Earl'' (11.2 million) and ''The Office'' (8.83 million), in their Thursday debuts this season, also did well among adults 18 to 49, with ''Earl'' getting the best ratings in that age group at 9 p.m. since the ''Apprentice'' finale in May. NBC placed second for the night in the same group. But with all these changes, one thing remained the same: ''CSI'' was on CBS's schedule. Twice, in fact, as the network broadcast a repeat (15.1 million) at 8 p.m., followed by a new episode (27.36 million) at 9 p.m. And that meant that CBS won the night in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) MISS TEEN USA 2006 -- At this age, the abs are naturally toned. But it's never too early to start polishing those pleas for world peace.
