Jackie, Jesse and Mimi take it to the mats. 9 P.M. (CMT) TIM MCGRAW: HERE AND NOW -- This concert special from 2004 finds Mr. McGraw (right) in Green Bay, Wis., where he performs and relaxes with his wife, Faith Hill; the hip-hop artist Nelly, and the Packers quarterback Brett Favre. 9 P.M. (Sundance) CITY OF MEN -- S-A-T-U-R-D-A-Y night in Rio, and the favela boys want to party. 9 P.M. (ABC) ACCORDING TO JIM -- In this re-broadcast of episodes from May 2005, Dana's wedding plans are knocked askew when the dress and a preacher both bite the dust. 10 P.M. (FX) RESCUE ME -- Fighting words tonight, with Tommy's dad and even the priest. 10 P.M. (13) A CLOSER WALK -- ''This is the way the world is,'' says Glenn Close, a conarrator with Will Smith, at the beginning of Robert Bilheimer's exploration of the global AIDS epidemic. Filmed on four continents over three years, this documentary, in its television premiere, uses interviews with victims, health-care workers and celebrity advocates like the Dalai Lama, Bono and Kofi Annan to examine the relationship between health, dignity and human rights. Annie Lennox, the Neville Brothers, Eric Clapton and Sade provide the soundtrack. 10 P.M. (Oxygen) THE JANICE DICKINSON MODELING AGENCY -- After weeks of enduring Ms. Dickinson (left) and her screeds, for the models it all comes down to the click of a shutter in tonight's season finale. Those who need to a refresher course in bullying can catch the entire season in repeats, starting at 5 p.m. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Bye-Bye, Bucky
summary: Even though his version of Queen's ''Fat Bottomed Girls'' earned praise from the judges, Bucky Covington, below, was voted off ''American Idol'' on Wednesday night. The hourlong results broadcast, in the unusual period of 8:30 to 9:30 p.m., drew an estimated 21.83 million viewers. Relative to the show's own smashing success, that audience was smaller than usual. But it was good enough to put Fox far ahead in first place for the night and do more damage to ABC's ''Lost.'' Wednesday's episode of the plane-crash mystery revealed that the island had cured not only the paralysis of Locke (Terry O'Quinn) but also the previously terminal illness of Rose (L. Scott Caldwell). ''Lost'' delivered its lowest 18-to-49 rating of the season (15.15 million), but it was still strong enough to put ABC in second place in that measurement over all. On Wednesday, April 5, the day Katie Couric announced that she would be leaving the ''Today'' show, the program brought in 6.2 million viewers and held that audience for the rest of the week. That was an improvement over the Monday (5.7 million) and Tuesday (5.5 million) viewer totals. For the week as a whole, ''Today'' was in first place, as it always is, outpacing ABC's ''Good Morning America'' (4.8 million) and CBS's ''Early Show'' (2.8 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Newspaper Investigates 'Opal Mehta' Author Kaavya Viswanathan, right, the 19-year-old Harvard University sophomore whose debut novel has been withdrawn amid allegations of plagiarism, will be the subject of an investigation by The Record, in Hackensack, N.J., where she wrote articles as an intern in 2003 and 2004, The Associated Press reported. Frank Scandale, the editor of the newspaper, said a service would be hired to examine the dozen or so feature articles written by Ms. Viswanathan. He said: ''To us she was a bright young kid that seemed to have the makings of a good writer. There were no alarms; nobody ever questioned any of her stories. We have no reason to believe there's anything wrong with her copy. But in light of what's going on, we thought we should check her stuff out.'' Ms. Viswanathan's debut novel, ''How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild, and Got a Life,'' was withdrawn from bookstores by Little, Brown after she admitted copying passages from two novels by Megan McCafferty. Ms Viswanathan has said the copying was ''unconscious and unintentional.'' Another Victory for Fox Another Tuesday, another dominant performance by Fox. More than 28 million viewers watched the final five contestants sing two songs each on ''American Idol,'' and ''House'' drew more than 22.7 million, according to Nielsen's estimates. For the night, Fox averaged more than 25 million viewers; CBS, which finished second, averaged 11.4 million. ''NCIS'' (14.9 million viewers) and ''The Unit'' (14 million) performed well for the network, but CBS's ''Dynasty Reunion'' was poorly attended: only 5.35 million viewers caught up with Krystle and Alexis. Fox also was a decisive winner among 18-to-49-year-old viewers. All three of ABC's comedies -- ''According to Jim,'' ''Hope and Faith,'' and ''Less Than Perfect'' -- had notably small audiences, and the network finished fourth for the night even with a solid performance by ''Boston Legal'' (more than 10 million viewers). The David E. Kelley drama has been renewed for next season. New Raid on Greek Home Of Former Curator The Greek police have again raided an island villa owned by Marion True, below, the former antiquities curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles who is on trial in Rome on charges of conspiring to deal in looted archaeological artifacts, Reuters reported. In the raid on her home on the island of Paros in the Cyclades in connection with a continuing investigation of antiquities smuggling, the police said they had found a dozen ancient works, including two small marble sarcophagi believed to date from around the time of Alexander the Great (356-323 B.C.). A police statement said that ''several objects were confiscated as illegally possessed.'' The police said the objects were not found during their raid in March because they had been incorporated into the architecture of the home and were not apparent. Ms. True has not been charged. Michael Brand, director of the Getty, will visit Athens on May 16 for talks with the culture minister, George Voulgarakis, the ministry said. How Do You Spell Hot? After a dozen years on ESPN, the National Spelling Bee, which began in 1925 with nine contestants, is going prime time. Interest buoyed by recent movies, books and a Broadway musical has prompted ABC to broadcast the final rounds of the two-day event live on June 1. ESPN will continue to broadcast the early final rounds in the afternoon, and ABC will show the championship rounds at night. The first day of the bee, on May 31, will not be televised. Footnote Chris Young, the 20-year-old singer from Murfreesboro, Tenn., who won the fourth ''Nashville Star'' talent search on the USA network on Tuesday, plans a concert tour this summer, The Associated Press reported. His prizes included a recording contract with the RCA Label Group, an appearance on the Grand Ole Opry and a Chevy truck.

headline: WHAT'S ON
summary: 1:30 (ESPN Classic) BASEBALL HALL OF FAME INDUCTION CEREMONIES -- Eighteen players and executives -- the largest class yet, including the relief pitcher Bruce Sutter and 17 inductees from the Negro Leagues and pre-Negro League eras -- are ushered in live in Cooperstown, N.Y. Effa Manley, the co-owner with her husband, Abe (above), and manager of the Newark Eagles from 1936 to 1948, becomes the hall's first female member. 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER: ALL-STARS -- The new Head of Household, whose perks include a luxe bedroom suite and a plasmascreen spy-cam, nominates two fellow contestants for the chopping block. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) LET'S JUST PLAY: GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE -- Four youngsters on the road to healthier lifestyles for their families, friends and themselves check in. 9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS -- Five years after his partner's death, Robbie Lewis (Kevin Whately) returns to Oxford with a new sidekick (Laurence Fox, far right, with Mr. Whately) and steps into the shoes of Chief Inspector Endeavour Morse. But he's only just gotten off the plane when his first victim, an American college student, rears her pretty head. 9 P.M. (E!) THE GIRLS NEXT DOOR -- In this second-season premiere, set at the Playboy mansion in Los Angeles, Hugh Hefner's live-in vixens -- Holly Madison, Bridget Marquardt and Kendra Wilkinson -- plan his 80th birthday party. 9 P.M. (HGTV) DESIGN STAR -- You mean once isn't enough? Last week Ramona Jan, the subject of derision last year when she forced her bag-lady aesthetic on a neatnik in ABC's ''Wife Swap,'' was sent packing -- cart, boxes and all -- in this design competition. Tonight, the remaining nine contestants redecorate three rooms in a house that has been on the market for a year and try to generate curb appeal. 9 P.M. (Discovery Channel) DIRTY JOBS: JOBS THAT BITE -- Since 1988, ''Shark Week'' on Discovery Channel has been attracting viewers like, well, carnivores to chum. In this season's inaugural program, Mike Rowe (left) climbs into a shark cage to swim with great whites in South Africa and tests a shark repellent on himself in the Bahamas. At 7, ''10 Deadliest Sharks'' offers a two-hour primer on what toothsome beasts to expect in the coming week. 10 P.M. (TLC) THE MESSENGERS -- The nine remaining zealots in this search for an inspirational speaker get a taste of what it's like to toil their lives away on a family-owned farm. 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Love-love. Hazel shows off her new tennis-pro girlfriend at the Milligans' party. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Under the Radar but Well Worth Their Grammy Invitations
summary: ON the Grammy Awards telecast Sunday night on CBS, many musicians' names will flash by just before commercials: the winners in dozens of categories that don't fit in prime time. The Grammys try to notice every niche of popular music and, with 108 categories this year, they can't keep up. But they do delve well beyond the Top 10 and the familiar names on the television show. I'm not picking winners here. The Grammys are inscrutable, especially in categories with only a coterie of voters, but these nominated albums and songs deserve their instant of Grammy attention. Dafnis Prieto The best Latin jazz album category holds more musical brainpower attached to more twisted melodies and more kinetic rhythms than any other Grammy niche. Lately Latin musicians have revitalized some of the knottiest structures of 1960s jazz, then gone on to make them dance, and all five entries in this category -- including those by Edsel Gomez, Ignacio Berroa, the Brian Lynch/Eddie Palmieri Project and Diego Urcola -- are worth hearing. The most brilliantly convoluted of the nominees is ''Absolute Quintet'' (Zoho) by the Cuban drummer Dafnis Prieto. His playing flaunts every shift built into his compositions and infuses every unexpected turn with a sense of joyful discovery. Casey Driessen Acoustic pickers and fiddlers have taken over the best country instrumental performance category, which includes Casey Driessen's ''Jerusalem Ridge,'' a thoroughly unorthodox remake of a fiddle tune from Bill Monroe. It's on Mr. Driessen's album ''3D'' (Sugar Hill). Over a choppy strummed beat that's almost funky, multiple fiddles come and go -- grappling with one another, sharing the tune as a chorale, switching its beat, even briefly carrying it eastward. It's a tour de force that still holds on to the tune's Celtic roots. Sex Mob The best contemporary jazz album category is usually good for tepid pop-jazz, but not this year. Sex Mob's ''Sexotica'' (Thirsty Ear) is the avant-gutbucket New York City brass-and-saxophone band's tribute to Martin Denny, a purveyor of lounge-music exotica in the 1950s and 1960s. The concept gives Sex Mob, led by Steven Bernstein on slide trumpet, excuses to toy with an international assortment of percussion and Mr. Denny's slinky modal tunes. It's sly and boisterous music, poised between parody and skeptical appreciation. The remixers Good and Evil sometimes toss in samples or chop up the music just to add an extra level of disorientation. Tye Tribbett In a year of increasingly grim wartime news, gospel insists on hope. Perhaps it's no accident that two nominees for best gospel performance are songs called ''Victory'': one by Tye Tribbett and one by Yolanda Adams. Ms. Adams sings with a soul belter's intensity about overcoming material hardships in her ''Victory'' (Verity). But Mr. Tribbett promises even greater empowerment to believers. Backed by an choir, razzle-dazzle horns and a funk rhythm section worthy of Prince on ''Victory Live!'' (Columbia), he bounces exhortations and percussive screams off his choir's enthusiastic responses, promising, ''Every situation I face I win/And everything works for my good in the end.'' The Flaming Lips Best rock instrumental is where straight-faced old-school lead guitarists -- Peter Frampton, Joe Satriani, David Gilmour -- run into alt-rockers like Arctic Monkeys and the Flaming Lips, whose ''The Wizard Turns On '' (from the Warner Brothers album ''At War With the Mystics'') is the goofiest nominated track. After a full 45 seconds of feedback and distortion, the song coalesces, more or less, into a woozy psychedelic march, smudging its own pomp with stray electronic noises and outlandishly wah-wahed guitar before melting down again. Alongside it the guitar heroes sound corny. Oscar D'León The Venezuelan singer, bandleader and bass player Oscar D'León has been a champion of classic salsa, but ''Fuzionando'' (Norte/Sony BMG), nominated for best tropical Latin album, announces its intentions in its title: it fuses salsa with reggaetón, flamenco and rock. The ambitions are pan-Latin, with some social commentary on black pride amid songs about love and dancing, echoing the 1970s legacy of pan-American thinkers like Rubén Blades. The music is buoyant and affable, perhaps because Mr. D'León knows he can outsing any of his guests. Northern Cree and Friends Drums pound steadily and voices whoop and shriek on ''Long Winter Nights: Round Dance Live'' (Canyon) by Northern Cree and Friends, a nominee for best Native American music album. It's stark traditionalist music with a primal, frenzied edge from singers who shout, wail, ululate and hoot bird cries. And when English lyrics arrive, some of them turn out to be deeply infuriated breakup songs. Buick Project Dance-music remixers are simultaneously restrictive and extravagant. They quantize vocals to fit a metronomic dance beat, but also freely reimagine songs after they've been reduced to their barest remnants. Nominated for best remixed recording, nonclassical, Buick Project's remix of ''Damage'' (Fine/Four Music Productions) by the German production team Tiefschwarz, featuring Tracey Thorn, makes a lonely song even lonelier. The remix keeps the synthetic bassline but turns the original's crisp chords into murky clouds; it puts space between electro blips, so they sound more like heart-monitor alerts or pacemaker jolts; and it leaves Ms. Thorn sounding more stranded than ever as she sings, ''I was always there, but you never chose to care.'' Hossein Alizadeh and Djivan Gasparyan The tone is mournful, the pace is measured and the atmosphere is profound on ''Endless Vision'' (World Village). It is nominated for best traditional world music album, but it crosses some traditional boundaries. Hossein Alizadeh, from Iran, is a virtuoso on Persian lutes who plays, on this album, the six-stringed shurangiz. Djivan Gasparyan is Armenian and plays the duduk, a liquid-toned reed flute. They recorded this live in Tehran, Iran, with a group that included male and female vocalists -- a rare mixed-gender ensemble -- singing recent and ancient poetry with a somber concentration that almost suspends time.

headline: Military Team Undertakes a Broad Review of the Iraq War and the Campaign Against Terror
summary: Senior military leaders have begun a broad review of strategy in Iraq and other crisis areas in the Bush administration's campaign against terrorism, according to Pentagon officials. In a closely held effort, Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has assembled a team of some of the military's brightest and most innovative officers and told them to take a fresh look at Iraq and Afghanistan, among other flashpoints.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Bush Says Democrats 'Undercut' Troops in Iraq The political brinksmanship over Iraq war spending intensified, as President Bush said Democrats had ''undercut the troops'' by passing legislation that ties continued war financing to timelines for the withdrawal of American units. A6 Members of a Republican Congressional delegation to Iraq who were criticized by Iraqis for portraying the security situation in Baghdad as much improved said they were realistic about the dangers that remain there. A6 Pelosi Arrives in Syria Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, arrived in Syria for a visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway Bush administration policy on Iraq and the Middle East. A6 Blair Hopeful in Iran Dispute Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he was still hoping to secure through diplomatic means the release of the 15 British sailors and marines captured by Iran and that the next 48 hours would be ''fairly critical'' in resolving the dispute. A5 Behind the crisis of Iran's detention of the Britons lies an internal Iranian struggle pitting radicals, aligned with the president, against more pragmatic officials concerned about the country's growing isolation. A5 An Iranian diplomat kidnapped by men wearing uniforms of the Iraqi Security Forces was freed in Baghdad, Iraq's foreign minister said, adding he continued to work to free five other Iranians held by American military forces. A7 Civil Conflict Linked to Youth A study conducted by Population Action International suggests that young populations can contribute to strife. While it is not clear why, the study shows that 80 percent of the civil conflicts that broke out in the 1970s, '80s and '90s occurred in countries where at least 60 percent of the population was under 30. A8 A Political Stand-Off in Ukraine Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, above, and his cabinet resisted an order by Ukraine's president, Viktor A. Yushchenko, below, to disband Parliament, while thousands gathered near the Parliament building in support of the prime minister. The cabinet, which is loyal to Mr. Yanukovich, responded to the decree by ordering government agencies to disregard it. A8 France Wary of a Paperless Vote While France will be using paperless computer voting for the first time in the coming presidential election, opposition to electronic voting has grown, in part because some are made by the American company whose machines were involved in a disputed Congressional election in Florida last November. A3 NATIONAL A9-12 West Seeks Water As Drought Resumes A Western drought that began in 1999 has resumed after a couple of wetter years. And some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in decades. A1 McCain Delays Announcement Lagging in fund-raising and under fire for supporting the Iraq war, Senator John McCain is overhauling his presidential campaign finance operation and delaying the official announcement of his candidacy, his aides said. A1 Debate on Greenhouse Gases A day after the Supreme Court ruled that the federal government had the authority to regulate greenhouse gases, President Bush said he thought the measures he had taken so far were sufficient. But the court's ruling was being welcomed by Congress and the states. A1 Efforts to Reduce Child Obesity The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation plans to spend more than $500 million over the next five years to reverse the increase in childhood obesity, one of the largest public health initiatives ever attempted by a private philanthropy. A9 Romney on the Trail The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney dashed across southern New Hampshire, enjoying the attention that has come with his fund-raising haul while trying to raise his profile among voters. A11 New King Documents for Sale A new cache of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers has surfaced for sale to the highest bidder. A9 Plans to House Veterans The Department of Veterans Affairs and two nonprofit groups in Los Angeles have plans to sign a long-term lease this month that will allow damaged V.A. buildings used as sets for movies and television programs to be transformed into housing with social services and counseling for disabled homeless veterans. A9 Democrats Seek Interview House Democrats requested a private interview with an aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who has asserted her constitutional right not to testify at a public hearing about the dismissals of United States attorneys. A11 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Risks in Hormone Therapy A new analysis of a large federal study of hormone therapy has found that women in their 50s do not appear to have an increased heart attack risk if they take the drugs. But women in their 60s and 70s who still had hot flashes and night sweats were at increased risk for heart attacks, even if they were not taking hormones. And if these women took hormone therapy, their risk was higher still. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 New Jersey Is Diverting Billions From Pension Fund New Jersey has been diverting billions of dollars from its pension fund for state and local workers into other government purposes over the last 15 years, using a variety of unorthodox transactions authorized by the Legislature and governors from both major political parties, according to an analysis by The Times. A1 New Tower Near Ground Zero? JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations with state and New York City officials to build a 1.3 million-square-foot skyscraper near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown, according to officials. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-8 Tennessee Wins Championship Tennessee defeated Rutgers, 59-46, to become N.C.A.A. women's champions, and Coach Pat Summitt won her seventh national title and first since 1998. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 Vermont, a Tax Haven At conferences of the offshore insurance industry, there is often someone promoting Vermont. The state offers companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements. C1 Pursuing the Tribune Company The news that Sam Zell is becoming the new chairman of the Tribune Company and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers hasn't discouraged potential buyers -- and even his rival bidders -- from planning their next move. C1 Russia on Global Positioning Russia and the United States are in the midst of a technological fight over America's monopoly on satellite navigation. The Russian space agency plans to launch eight satellites that would nearly complete the country's own system. C1 Business Digest C2 ARTS E1-12 Biography on Iowa Library Cat In a hotly contested deal, the life story of Dewey, a rescued cat who lived for 19 years in a library in a small town in Iowa, has sold for about $1.25 million to Grand Central Publishing. E3 OBITUARIES A13 Tom Moore A president of ABC Television Network in the 1960s who helped it narrow the ratings gap with NBC and CBS, and who later won five Emmys as head of his own production company, he was 88. A13 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: More than a feeling; it didn't end well last time; shackles on the AIDS program; stay on track. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E10 TV Listings E11 Weather C12

headline: Corrections
summary: A front-page article yesterday describing the results of the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll referred imprecisely to Americans' favorable opinions of President Bush. The 42 percent of respondents who said they viewed him favorably were referring specifically to how he handles his job. On another question -- about how he is liked over all -- the result was 37 percent favorable.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Surgery for Keith Richards The Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards underwent surgery yesterday in New Zealand to relieve headaches suffered after he fell while vacationing last month in Fiji, Reuters reported. The New Zealand Herald reported that the surgery was intended to relieve a blood clot on the brain, an operation that normally involves drilling a hole through the skull to drain the clot. Mr. Richards's publicists would not comment on the report. In a statement issued in London, they said, ''The operation was a complete success, and Keith is already up and talking with his family today.'' It added, ''He will need a few weeks' recuperation.'' As a result, early dates on the European leg of the Stones' Bigger Bang tour were canceled. Rescheduling is to be announced. Mr. Richards, 62, left, was flown to Auckland, New Zealand, after the accident, which followed the portion of the tour that included Japan, China, Australia and New Zealand. Last week a spokeswoman for the band said he had suffered only a mild concussion and would not require surgery. '60 Minutes' Recruits Anderson Cooper Anderson Cooper will contribute as many as five reports a year to CBS News's ''60 Minutes'' beginning with the start of the 2006-7 television season. An announcement yesterday from Sean McManus, the president of CBS News and Sports, and Jonathan Klein, the president of CNN's domestic operations, said that Mr. Cooper, left, the anchor of ''Anderson Cooper 360,'' would remain a full-time employee of CNN, and that the new arrangement allows a one-time rebroadcast of his ''60 Minutes'' reports on his CNN program. Yesterday's announcement came less than two months after Mike Wallace, a correspondent on ''60 Minutes'' since its inception in September 1968, said he would retire this spring, at the end of the current season. Mr. Wallace turns 88 today. David Bowie Ushers In The High Line Festival David Bowie, below, will headline his first New York City concert in four years when he takes to the stage next May as the curator and a co-founder of the High Line Festival, a new 10-day outpouring of music, nightlife, visual art, performance and film. The festival, envisioned as an annual event, will take place at street level and in the vicinity of the High Line, an abandoned 1.5-mile West Side railroad viaduct that is being transformed into an 22-block elevated park above 10th and 11th Avenues between 34th Street and Gansevoort Street; its first phase is scheduled for completion in 2008. The inaugural festival will culminate in an outdoor concert by Mr. Bowie, a founder of the event with the producers David Binder and Josh Wood. Each year a different person, from music, film or other arts, will be chosen as the curator, who will shape its content. In an statement Mr. Bowie said, ''I've been particularly excited about seeking out emerging artists and giving them a place in a festival that will also feature some very well-known names.'' Fats Domino Bows Out Hours before he was to take the stage as the headliner on Sunday, the final day of the 37th annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, Fats Domino, 78, below, canceled his performance, The Associated Press reported. ''He wasn't feeling well, so we took him to the doctor,'' said Haydee Ellis, a longtime friend. ''He's O.K., but he doesn't feel up to performing.'' Later Mr. Domino, a native of New Orleans and a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, briefly appeared onstage, apologized to the crowd that had come to hear him and thanked fans for their support, the first since Hurricane Katrina devastated the city last year. He lost his home, his pianos and his gold and platinum records in the hurricane. Last week he canceled an autograph session for his latest album, ''Alive and Kickin','' saying he was tired and wanted to rest for his show on Sunday. Footnotes Lisa Kron's ''Well,'' starring Ms. Kron and Jayne Houdyshell, will close on Sunday after 23 previews and 53 performances at the Longacre Theater. David Hallberg has been promoted to principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, effective on May 22.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: UNIVISION AUCTION The auction for Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language media company, was sent into chaos as a consortium led by Grupo Televisa, which was tipped to win the bidding, missed a deadline to submit its offer. [Page C1.] ESTATE TAX STRATEGY In a new gambit to permanently reduce the estate tax on inherited wealth, House Republican leaders moved to win over crucial Democrats with a tax sweetener for timber companies. [C1.] DRUG PRICE STUDIES According to separate studies issued by two large consumer advocacy groups, prices of the most widely used prescription drugs rose sharply in this year's first quarter, just as the new Medicare drug coverage program was going into effect. [C1.] DRUG LEGISLATION After more than a year of quiet negotiations, two influential senators -- Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts -- are expected to introduce within weeks a legislative proposal that could drastically change how drugs are tested and approved. [A13.] NURSES SUE HOSPITALS Nurses filed class-action lawsuits against hospitals in Chicago, Memphis, San Antonio and Albany, asserting that the hospitals had violated federal antitrust laws by conspiring to hold down wages. [A12.] A GREATER SAY FOR FRANCE Amid growing management turmoil at the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the French government called for revisiting its ownership structure to give Paris more say. Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France, above, said the government would seek to ''return to square one'' of the 2000 agreement that created EADS, the parent of Airbus. [C8.] THE DEBATE Even by the unruly standards of the French National Assembly, the session was exceptional. When François Hollande, the Socialist Party leader, berated the government for its handling of the crisis at EADS, Europe's leading aerospace company, Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin lost control. [A5.] HOUSING REPORT The federal government reported that construction of new homes rose in May, bouncing back from a disappointing April. But other numbers in the report pointed to a slowdown in the coming months and a market that is less robust than it was a year ago. [C6.] STOCKS CLOSE MIXED Wall Street pared an earlier advance to end mixed. At the close of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.72 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,974.84. [C9.] DAN RATHER LEAVING CBS Dan Rather and CBS News announced that they had agreed to end his career at the network, 44 years after he first went to work there as its Dallas bureau chief and five months before his contract as a ''60 Minutes'' correspondent was to expire. [C4.] G.M. DEBT RATINGS CUT Two major rating agencies cut General Motors' debt rating further into junk status after the automaker announced a plan to improve its liquidity by refinancing $5.6 billion in loans. G.M., which plans to eliminate 30,000 jobs and close 12 factories as part of a restructuring, said it would offer banks collateral and more favorable terms to extend its credit facility through 2011. [C4.] STEEL DEAL TERMS The Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov changed the terms under which he would buy a big stake in the European steel giant Arcelor, in an effort to salvage a deal that is facing increasing shareholder opposition. [C8.] TIMES ADS The New York Times plans to begin selling advertisements on the front of its Business news section. The ads would run along the bottom of the page and are expected to sell at a premium rate. [C7.] RETAILER LOOKS AT NEW YORK The owner of Topshop, the cavernous London fashion emporium, has been scouting a site for a New York flagship. The store could open as early as next spring. [C1.] SOUTHWEST TO TEST ASSIGNED SEATS Southwest Airlines said it would test assigning seats, in a comparison with its longtime first-come-first-served seating system. The airline wants to know if assigning seats will slow the unloading of arriving planes and the boarding of passengers for the next flight. [C7.] ACCENTING THE CONDITIONAL In the latest effort in a barrage from marketers of all types of insurance, Met Life is changing its theme for the first time in six years, to ''Guarantees for the If in Life.'' Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C4.] A SECOND NEW YORK TIFFANY'S Tiffany & Company plans to open its second shop in New York City, around the corner from the New York Stock Exchange. The store is to open in the fall. [B2.] RUSSIAN OIL DEAL A joint venture of BP in Russia announced it would sell several oil fields to Sinopec of China, the first direct sale of Russian oil assets to a Chinese company. Within hours of the announcement, Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled energy company, said it would exercise an option to buy 51 percent of Sinopec's newly acquired assets. [C8.] ONLINE ONLINE: DEALBOOK A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. WIRELESS LIVING Communities around the country are getting into the telecommunications business, wireless gambling, simple fixes for Wi-Fi woes, Internet calling without a laptop and more. A report is at nytimes.com/business. VIDEO: TIPS ON AIRPORT PARKING Joe Sharkey of The Times recommends making a parking reservation before you head to the airport this summer. A report is at nytimes.com/video.

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 At a China Border Stop, Little Sign of Sanctions Despite China's support for United Nations economic sanctions against North Korea, it has remained vague on the issue of inspecting goods in border trade. At one border crossing, there was little evidence of the sanctions. A1 Nicaragua Outlaws Abortion Nicaragua banned all abortions, eliminating exceptions for rape and when the life of the mother is in danger. It joins El Salvador and Chile as the only countries in the Western hemisphere to ban abortion without exception. A8 African Award Proposed Mo Ibrahim, a Sudanese-born billionaire, announced a $5 million prize for the sub-Saharan African president who, on leaving office, has demonstrated the greatest commitment to democracy and good governance. A11 Afghan Airstrike Investigation President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan issued a presidential decree directing a team of tribal elders and Afghan officials to investigate a NATO bombing in southern Afghanistan that local officials said had killed 40 civilians. A11 Democrats Divided on War Democratic leaders and candidates are virtually unanimous in opposing President Bush's conduct of the war, and many advocate disengagement. But most are not calling for an immediate withdrawal of American forces or offering a vision of how postwar Iraq should look. A10 NATIONAL A12-17 Ruling Renews Debate Over Same-Sex Marriage The divisive debate over same-sex marriage, which played a prominent role in 2004 campaigns but this year largely faded from view, erupted anew as President Bush and Republicans nationwide tried to use a court ruling in New Jersey to rally dispirited conservatives to the polls. A1 For Democrats in tight races, black voter turnout will be crucial to an Election Day victory. But there are worries among Democratic strategists in some states that blacks may not turn up at the polls in big enough numbers because of disillusionment over past elections. A1 Tax Delays for Storm Victims The commissioner of Internal Revenue ordered his agency to delay collecting back taxes from Hurricane Katrina victims until after the Nov. 7 elections and the holiday season, saying he did so in part to avoid negative publicity. A1 4 Firefighters Killed in Blaze Four firefighters were killed and one was seriously injured when an arson fire ripped through part of Southern California, destroying thousands of acres and forcing hundreds of residents to evacuate their homes. A12 Judge's Jail Visit Is Criticized A special panel of the Washington State Supreme Court made up of nine substitute judges reprimanded one of the court's justices for visiting a facility that holds sexually violent predators. A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 Family Ties Help Kean In Senate Race, Poll Finds Thomas H. Kean Jr., the Republican challenger for United States Senate in New Jersey, has capitalized on his father's reputation to offset voters' qualms about his inexperience, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Builders Cut Home Prices Home builders, struggling to keep ahead in a weakening market, have cut prices to help sell their newly constructed houses, the latest government and industry statistics show. C1 Investigation of S.E.C. The Securities and Exchange Commission will be the subject of a broad review by the investigative arm of Congress, the Government accountability Office. C1 Business Digest C2 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-7 St. Louis Is One Away The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Detroit Tigers, 5-4, in Game 4 of the World Series. The Cardinals can clinch their first title since 1982 with a victory in Game 5 tonight. D1 Crossword E34 Obituaries B10 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E27 Weather D8 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Real timetables for Iraq; compounding a political outrage; for New York comptroller. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Fresh Fare Sells
summary: Reruns littered the Sunday schedule, making it all the easier for ABC's lineup of original episodes to squash the competition. Its ''Desperate Housewives'' (an estimated 22.03 million viewers) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (22.39 million) cleaned up in all ratings measurements. Earlier in the evening, two episodes of ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (7.87 million, then 13.2 million) were on the low end of the ratings for the sob-inducing home show, but they still dominated their time slots among 18-to-49 year-olds in Nielsen's estimates. The 8 p.m. ''Home'' beat a new episode of CBS's ''Cold Case'' (12.23 million), Fox's ''Simpsons'' (7.83 million) and a ''Loop'' rerun (5.73 million), and NBC's ''West Wing'' (7.31 million). That political drama, once formidable in the ratings, ended the Election Day episode with Annabeth (Kristin Chenoweth) walking into Leo's room, presumably to find him collapsed. Leo, the vice presidential candidate, was played by John Spencer, who died of a heart attack in December; next week's ''West Wing'' will deal with the death of the character. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE HILL -- She is probably best known for her film ''Heir to an Execution,'' about the legacy of her grandparents Ethel and Julius Rosenberg. But before she was digging up family secrets, Ivy Meeropol was a speechwriter and legislative aide to a United States congressman. In this new six-part reality series, Ms. Meeropol trails Representative Robert Wexler, Democrat of Florida, and his staff (above) as they deal with the daily grind in Washington. 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Three more try to make a good impression before Tommy Lee and his fellow metalists give them the steel-toed boot. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) PIRANHAS -- Scared? Who, me? Nigel Marven, a shark expert, finds out that the size of a fish's jaws is not in direct correlation to the severity of its bite. 9 P.M. (TBS) WORLD'S FUNNIEST COMMERCIALS -- Proving that funny is funny in almost any language. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY -- Last week, the contestants traveled to a recycling plant in New Jersey, where they sorted through used materials with which to craft their latest designs, after which Alison was eliminated the judges thought her creation (left) made her model look plus-size. On his blog, Tim Gunn, their design guru, was still quaking from what he called this ''tragic outcome.'' Tonight, Angela cries. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- Mr. Angel shows off before a team of extreme motorcycle riders by riding blindfolded and then making his bike disappear. 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS -- A woman who supports abortion rights lives in a home for pregnant women run by people who are against abortion. 10 P.M. (TVLAND) TOP 10 -- Television police officers worth getting arrested for. 10 P.M. (Logo) NOAH'S ARC -- Four gay African-American men look for signs of intelligent life, as the Logo people put it, in West Hollywood. Tonight, hired help and desperate housewives. 10 P.M. (BBC America) BUMP 'N' GRIND -- The ''booty'' group gets a home-cooked meal and a night on the town; the ''posh'' group gets a visit from a reflexologist. And then the first contestant gets spun off the stage in this British dance competition series. 10 P.M. (Sundance) DJANGOMANIA! (2005). He was the only non-American, Duke Ellington once said of the Belgian guitarist Django Reinhardt (right), to make an impact on jazz. This documentary travels from Oslo to Tokyo to find out why, more than 50 years after Reinhardt's death, his music still plucks the heartstrings. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) TWO-A-DAYS -- This new reality series follows the Buccaneers of Hoover High School in Hoover, Ala., a football team running after its fourth state championship in five years while enduring personal and professional hardships, including twice-a-day practices. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RYAN, THOMAS HERBERT
summary: RYAN--Thomas Herbert. 78, of Spring Lake, NJ, died peacefully 21 April, 2006, in Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Beloved husband of Shirley. Adored father of Sheila, Sharon, Mary and Patricia. Admired father-in-law of Michael, Andrew and Andrew, and cherished ''Bop'' of five grandchildren. Veteran of WWII and Korean War as agent of Counterintelligence Corps. JD from NYU. Started distinguished legal career as Deputy Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York. Moved to CBS as one of the first legal consultants for programming and talent. From there, joined Leyland Hayward in producing numerous shows, including ''That Was the Week That Was.'' Began private entertainment law practice in 1969, from which he never retired. Visitation 2-4 and 7-9 PM, 25 April, 2006, at O'Brien Funeral Home, State Route 35, Wall, NJ. Funeral services 11 AM, 26 April, 2006, at St. Catharine's Church, at 215 Essex Ave, Spring Lake, NJ. $(6$)RYAN -- Thomas H. We mourn the death of Thomas H. Ryan, and express our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Shirley, to his daughters Patricia, Sharon, Mary and Sheila, to sons-in-law Andrew, Michael and Andrew, and to his five grandchildren. Marybeth Sollins and the Sollins Family

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SLATER, JERRY
summary: SLATER--Jerry. On March 1, 2006, of Hastings-On-Hudson, NY. Former New York County Assistant District Attorney under Frank S. Hogan. Litigation Council for CBS. Assistant Attorney General under New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. Survived by wife Sharon Cuff Slater, two children Andrew and Jeanne, and one brother Arthur. Reposing Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY, on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Immaculate Conception Church, Broadway, Irvington, NY, on Tuesday, at 10 AM. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (MTV) 2006 MTV VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS -- After two years of wilting in Miami, the Video Music Awards are back where many fans think they belong: New York, the birthplace of MTV. The Red Hot Chili Peppers are up for seven awards for ''Dani California.'' So are Shakira (above right) and Wyclef Jean for ''Hips Don't Lie,'' which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has endorsed as his choice to win. Seems he's got that swing. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) DOUBLE INDEMNITY (1944). An adulterous insurance agent is lured into a murder scheme by a seductive, well-coifed broad. Fred MacMurray and Barbara Stanwyck play the culprits in this Billy Wilder noir, which burns, slowly. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) WHO WANTS TO BE A SUPERHERO? The final two contestants -- Fat Momma and Feedback -- go to stunt school and converse with Stan Lee, the comic book legend, before winning the ultimate prize: immortality. On the page, that is. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MURDER CITY -- Remember when your mother told you always to wear clean underwear? She should have specified the style. Tonight in this series about a tough-as-fake-nails London detective (Amanda Donahoe) and her wild-hare partner (Kris Marshall, above, with Ms. Donahoe), a torso and legs left at the city dump are identified by their unusual attire. 10 P.M. (21) STATUS ANXIETY -- Worried that you're more D-list than A? This special looks at the root of achievement evil and what can be done to come to grips with being merely average. 10 P.M. (Food Network) THROWDOWN WITH BOBBY FLAY -- He's a chef with 'tude. She's an opera singer with a stage presence to rival his. Tonight, Susan Mello and Mr. Flay fire up their backyard grills and grasp their tongs to duke it out in the Battle of the Burger. 10 P.M. (GSN) THE 50 GREATEST GAME SHOWS OF ALL TIME -- Deal or no deal? Bill Dwyer, the host of ''I've Got a Secret,'' reveals the No. 1 game show and the runner-up in this series finale. 11:15 P.M. (Sundance) A TALE OF TWO SISTERS (2003). Evil stepmother, indeed. In Kim Jee-Woon's psychological thriller, two teenage sisters (Im Su-Jung, above, and Moon Geun-Young, in scary whiteface) rejoin their father and his wife at their family's lakeside mansion after a mysterious absence. But all is not well. 11:35 (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- The shock jocks Opie and Anthony turn up the volume. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; Julia Roberts Is Cast in a Tony Award Role
summary: The executive producers of the Tony Awards ceremony have put an end to one of the richest topics of Broadway speculation in the last few weeks: Julia Roberts, right, whose theater-packing performance in ''Three Days of Rain'' was generally dismissed by critics and snubbed by the Tony nominators, will appear as a presenter. The speculation was fueled in part because last year other Hollywood actors who were not nominated for their stage work -- Denzel Washington and Jessica Lange, for example -- were not part of the ceremony. The other presenters announced yesterday were Ralph Fiennes, a nominee in the acting category for ''Faith Healer,'' and Cynthia Nixon, nominated in the same category for ''Rabbit Hole''; Martin Short, whose show ''Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me'' will open on Broadway in August; Alfre Woodard, who was on Broadway in 2004 and has had a recurring role this year on ''Desperate Housewives''; Eric McCormack, from ''Will & Grace,'' currently in previews for Neil LaBute's ''Some Girl(s)'' at the MCC Theater off Broadway; and Anna Paquin, an Academy Award winner who has been in several Off Broadway plays. The 60th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be broadcast on CBS June 11. As of yesterday, no host had been named. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

headline: Arts, Briefly; Clive Davis Spices 'Idol'
summary: On the annual Clive Davis night on Tuesday on ''American Idol,'' Mr. Davis, the influential music executive, obtained permission from Bruce Springsteen to allow Taylor Hicks to sing ''Dancing in the Dark,'' the first of his songs to be performed on Fox's hit talent show. Another of the three remaining contestants, Katharine McPhee, complained that the judges had been hard on her recently, and then grumbled that she hadn't chosen the song. (Mr. Davis had.) Later she redeemed herself by singing ''Over the Rainbow'' while sitting on the floor. An audience of 27.66 million watched ''Idol,'' and then another 22.46 million stayed on Fox for ''House.'' The network easily won the night in all the important ratings measurements in Nielsen's estimates. CBS placed second over all, broadcasting its season finales of ''NCIS'' (16.41 million) and a two-hour ''Unit'' (13.46 million). At 10 p.m. ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' NBC's most popular scripted show, also ended its season by bringing in 12.9 million viewers. And ABC's two-hour ''Boston Legal'' closer attracted 9.14 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: '24' Is Among the Big Winners as Television Presents Its Emmy Awards
summary: ''24,'' the Fox thriller that set in motion the current trend for serial dramas when it made its debut in 2001, won three Emmy Awards on Sunday night, cementing its reputation as one of the most provocative and influential series on television at the 58th annual awards ceremony. Not only did the show win the award for best drama series, but its star, Kiefer Sutherland, a fan favorite, won the Emmy for best actor in a drama, his first victory after five acting nominations. And Jon Cassar won for best director for a drama series for the episode ''7 a.m. to 8 a.m.'' Each season of ''24'' follows a federal agent named Jack Bauer for an entire day.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DUKE, JAMES DARYL
summary: DUKE--James Daryl. After a courageous struggle with pulmonary fibrosis, Daryl passed away peacefully at his West Vancouver home on October 21, 2006. Born March 8, 1929 in Vancouver, Daryl's love of British Columbia never waned even while he wandered the world. The smell of the ocean, the changing of the tide, but most importantly watching the setting of the sun on British Columbia's Pacific coast were very much part of his persona, especially when he was on his Savary Island -a place he came to think of as ''home''. From selling jokes to a local radio station at the age of 15, he earnestly set out to capture his '' love with shadows, phantoms, lovely ghosts, and haunting the byways of our hearts after he obtained a degree in English and Philosophy from the University of British Columbia. He has worked for the National Film Board, the CBC, ABC, NBC and CBS, and most of the major studios in Hollywood. He has also been the recipient of many accolades and awards -Emmy Award for his direction of ''The Day the Lion Died'' starring Hal Holbrook, the National Society of Film Critics Special Award for his feature film ''Payday'' starring Rip Torn, a Christopher Award for ''I Heard the Owl Call My Name'' starring British actor Tom Courtenay, the Canadian Film Awards (now called the Genies) for ''The Silent Partner'' starring Christopher Plummer, Elliott Gould and Susannah York. Daryl's feature film ''Payday'' was also an official entry at the Cannes Film Festival in the Directors' Fortnight Category. He received Emmy and Directors Guild of America nominations for his work on the mini-series ''The Thorn Birds.'' He co-founded and launched the independent station CKVU-TV in Vancouver and was its first President and CEO. He was inducted into the ''Starwalk'' and the B.C. Entertainment Hall of Fame at Vancouver's Orpheum Theatre. He was also the first recipient of the Outstanding Achievement Award for an Individual given at the British Columbia Film Industry's annual Leo Awards ceremony. Daryl was inducted into the Canadian Association of Broadcast Hall of Fame. Simon Fraser University granted him a Honourary Doctorate of Fine Arts, and he also received ACTRA's John Drainie Award for distinguished contribution to broadcasting. ''Though the lamps should be lit and fires started I stay watching the darkness come slowly forward. I think of how few nights of peace there are. True peace. When the flood tide slides north as it should. When the eagle sits in his tree. When the heron puts away the torn cloth of his cries. When night falls and the heart is not heavy''. Daryl has lived his life with enthusiasm, spirit and an intensely enquiring mind. He is survived by his wife Anne-Marie Dekker, sons Bryan (Margy) and David (Melanie), stepson Michael Favelle (Carrie) and grandchildren Leah, Nathan, Samantha, Dakota, Ansel, Owen, Elijah, Noah, and Jakob. A public service will be held on Tuesday, November 7 at 2pm at Christ Church Cathedral, 690 Burrard Street, Vancouver, BC. Condolences or well wishes may be posted at www.darylduke.com. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Daryl Duke Screenwriters Award c/o BC Film, 2225 West Broadway, Vancouver, BC V6K 2E4.

headline: Raw and Dark Contemporary Works, a Nimble Mendelssohn
summary: Richard Wernick: String Quartet No. 5; Alberto Ginastera: String Quartet No. 3; John Harbison:'The Rewaking' Benita Valente, soprano; Juilliard String Quartet. Bridge 9192; CD. IF you doubt that the major labels have surrendered to the independents the adventure of recording great musicians in contemporary works, here is proof: The Juilliard String Quartet, for decades a mainstay of the CBS (later Sony) roster turns up on Bridge with three durable scores for quartet and voice. The ensemble and the soprano Benita Valente, who sings here, gave the premieres of all three, and they perform them with the authority and nuance of long acquaintance.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Grey's Anatomy' Flirts With Destiny
summary: President Bush's prime-time televised address on immigration sent the networks' programmers into a tizzy Monday, so as a result, Nielsen's estimates for programs that were delayed were preliminary. The clear winner though was ABC. From 9 p.m. to 11, its season finale of ''Grey's Anatomy'' was broadcast intact. Denny (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) died after a seemingly successful heart transplant, and a grieving Izzie (Katherine Heigl) quit being a surgeon as a result. But the cliffhanger of the hospital soap opera had Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) choosing between Finn (Chris O'Donnell) and McDreamy (Patrick Dempsey) before an audience of 22.21 million viewers. Between the president's speech and the ''Grey'' broadcast on a Monday (in addition to its Sunday episode), the usual order of things was upended. CBS, which is normally No. 1 among total viewers, placed third, as an extended ''Deal or No Deal'' put NBC into second place. And Fox, which featured the great escape by the ''Prison Break'' gang, was third among adults 18 to 49, also behind NBC. KATE AURTHUR
