MOTION GRANTED Joysticks and buttons have their virtues, but Nintendo's new system, the Wii, puts the body into the game. BY CLIVE THOMPSON STRATEGIES 20 THE HAIL MARY, CHILLED Down by a goal with two seconds left in regulation, the Edmonton Oilers seemed finished. Or were they? BY JASON ZINOMAN TALKING POINTS 22. THE TIARA COMES OFF Olympic skier Julia Mancuso talks about Bode Miller, skiteam micromanagement and the surreality of winning gold. BY PAUL HOCHMAN AT PLAY MASTER CLASS 26. VIC BRADEN'S MENTAL MOJO EXPERIENCE A top tennis school should fix your serve in no time, once you embrace the Fourth Link. BY PAIGE WILLIAMS PHYS ED 30. POP GOES THE TENDON Bum knees: the latest treatment for those who have them -- and prevention for those who don't. BY GRETCHEN REYNOLDS EQUIPMENT 34. SWING CLEANING Five golf clubs that can be customized to help your game. 36. COLD FUSION Stylish ski and snowboard jackets that combine (mostly) simple exteriors with space-age insulation. COLUMNS THE SHOW 38. UP CLOSE AND (VERY) PERSONAL The Rivals.com network takes college football fans farther inside the machine than they ever thought possible. Amen to that. BY BRYAN CURTIS THE BUSINESS 40. POWER GAME The N.F.L. already gets billions from CBS, NBC, Fox and ESPN, and it's not done yet. Diagramming the league's economic attack. BY JOE NOCERA MY TRIBE 90. BIRTH. SOCCER. DEATH. WHAT ELSE IS THERE? It's no big deal coaching a team of 9-year-olds. Honest. BY HAMPTON SIDES

headline: Arts, Briefly; Viewers Find Grisly 'CSI' Just Yummy
summary: ''CSI'' issued a warning to viewers on Thursday about the show's mature content. Was it meant to caution them about the image of a disembodied eyeball? Or the autopsied internal organs infected by flesh-eating bacteria? Maybe it was the flashback of a woman gnawing at her own hand to free herself from chains? Hard to say, really. But ''CSI'' was Thursday's most-watched show, as it nearly always is, with 27.08 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates. Though ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' edged out CBS's ''Survivor'' among total viewers at 8 p.m. (19.1 million versus 18.87 million), CBS won this sweeps Thursday over all. Noah Wyle's brief, practically minuscule, appearance on ''E.R.'' (14.15 million) helped NBC place second among 18-to-49-year-olds. Also of note was Fox's ''O.C.'' at 9 p.m., which drew a meager 5.26 million viewers and finished fourth among adults 18 to 49. Is it a given that this former smash hit will return for a fourth season? KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; For NBC, a Big 'Deal'
summary: CBS sat on the sidelines for most of the February sweeps period, letting ABC and Fox chip away at NBC's Olympics ratings, which both networks did successfully. But CBS started fresh on Monday, and was the clear winner in what was otherwise a close night among Fox, ABC and NBC. Its victory was thanks to ''Two and a Half Men'' (an estimated 17.28 million viewers) and ''CSI: Miami'' (18 million), which lifted the rest of the schedule in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. The news on Monday, though, was that NBC's much-hyped new lineup had only one winner: the return of the game show ''Deal or No Deal'' (13.46 million) beat all of its competition at 8 p.m. But the season premiere of ''The Apprentice,'' starring Donald Trump, above, squandered that lead, drawing only 9.76 million viewers and placing fourth in the hour in the 18-to-49 demographic. ''The Apprentice'' performed poorly, compared with ''Las Vegas,'' which used to occupy that hour but has been moved to Fridays. And NBC's ''Medium'' suffered from its weakened lead-in, drawing only 10.42 million viewers. ''Medium,'' the Patricia Arquette psychic drama, was beaten easily by the second hour of ABC's ''Bachelor'' finale (11.5 million viewers over all), in which Dr. Travis Stork chose the good girl, Sarah Stone, after the bad girl, Moana Dixon, acted like a jerk in front of his family. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (13) and 9 P.M. (49) TEXAS RANCH HOUSE -- ''Frontier House'' turned modernday time travelers into Montana mountain men and women, circa 1883. ''Colonial House'' forced them to endure the Puritanical social attitudes, and indentured servitude, of the New World in 1628. Now comes ''Texas Ranch House,'' in which 15 greenhorn cowboys (including, above from left, Johnny, Jared, Robby and Ian) struggle to get a ranch -- outfitted with all the amenities of 1867 (and that means rattlesnakes and latrines) -- up and running. This was not how the American West was won. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS -- ''Four Play.'' Doug and Deacon start hanging out with each other's wives when they realize they have more in common with them than with each other. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- ''And the Plot Moistens.'' Alan starts hanging out with Jake's teacher when he realizes he has more in common with her than with hisgirlfriend. 9 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY -- ''Newton Family.'' Season finale. Vicki and AaronNewton are separated, with joint custody of their two sons. Aaron, 12, merely talks back. Kobe, 5, hits, kicks, slaps, punches and swears. Jo Frost (left), savior to control-challenged parents everywhere, observes life in two homes for the first time and tries to get the Newtons -- children and adults -- to cooperate. It's a war zone in more ways than one, as Kobe hurls rocks at Jo's head. 10 P.M. (ESPN2) U.S. PAINTBALL CHAMPIONSHIPS -- Weekend warriors, take heed. Paintball, in which competitors shoot paint-filled pellets at one another, has been elevated to an official sport in this continuing series, taped last November during the 2005 National Professional Paintball League Super 7 World Series in Miami. The winner walks away with a few welts and $50,000. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Allison (Patricia Arquette) has visions of a faceless man who repeatedly breaks into the home of a woman -- and steals only a kiss. Molly Ringwald (far right, with Ms. Arquette) makes her first television appearance in four years as the object of his misguided affections. 11 P.M. (VH1) 40 GREATEST METAL SONGS -- Black Sabbath. Iron Maiden. Guns N'Roses. However you sugarcoat it, heavy metal has terrified parents, incited censorship and sent critics reeling. And that's not including its worst offense: the propagation of air guitar. This four-part special counts down the best anthems to trash a hotel room to. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) AUDRA MCDONALD & FRIENDS: BUILD A BRIDGE -- And how. In this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' presentation, part of the ''American Songbook'' series, Ms. McDonald (left) is joined by Nellie McKay and Patti LuPone, who together span works ranging from the tried and true (Neil Young, Elvis Costello, Burt Bacharach) to those from a new generation of composers, including Rufus Wainwright and John Mayer. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- It's not exactly ''Moonstruck.'' Betty (America Ferrar) uses her street wiles to lure a Queens boy-turned-top photographer into shooting for Mode. And that means a makeover. 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Lex throws a costume ball, and someone shows up in green. The All-American Rejects provide the background music. 8 P.M. (Travel) PASSPORT TO EUROPE WITH SAMANTHA BROWN -- Hello, young lovers. Ms. Brown heads to Verona, Italy, the home of a certain immortalized couple, where she pens a mash note at Juliet's Club. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- No. 56: Earl (Jason Lee, right) decides to return a prized pet after fixing a cat show in Joy's (Jaime Pressly) favor. Only now the cat doesn't have quite the same allure for its rightful owner -- but Randy (Ethan Suplee) does. 8:30 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE -- Ryan (B.J. Novak, who also wrote this episode) goes out on his first sales call, where Dwight (Rainn Wilson) puts him through a series of challenges, like a side trip to a beet farm. Meanwhile, Michael (Steve Carell) is forced by corporate to keep an activity log, the better to prove he's not watching movies on the job. 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- The hyperconfident Addison starts to have doubts about herself, and Izzie gets the surprise of her life. 9 P.M. (Food Network) PIZZA CHAMPIONS -- Four pizza makers try to toss, roll and spin their way into the Guinness Book of World Records -- and earn a bundle of dough in the process -- before concocting a gourmet pizza using none of America's top 10 ingredients. 9 P.M. (Travel) JOAN CUSACK'S LOCAL FLAVOR -- Ms. Cusack travels the hills and vales of Portugal, and turns off her carb counter while she samples the country's bread. 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- The team looks into a spree of brutal tourist beatings in Las Vegas. 10 P.M. (ABC) SIX DEGREES -- A criminal in New York punches strangers and runs. 10 P.M. (Travel) MOMS ON THE ROAD: AFRICA -- No hitting here. Just a group of eight women adventurers (including Adrienne Husted Brawley, left) who partake of some tribal customs and scale a red sand dune to watch the sun rise over the desert in Namibia. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (Starz) GOING TO PIECES: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE SLASHER FILM -- Huddle close to someone safe and prepare to take cover. In this 90-minute, blood-soaked documentary, the directors Wes Craven, John Carpenter and Rob Zombie (above) and the special effects wizard Tom Savini spill their guts about films ranging from ''Friday the 13th,'' ''Halloween'' and ''A Nightmare on Elm Street'' to ''When a Stranger Calls,'' ''Scream'' and ''I Know What You Did Last Summer'' -- and reveal how they determine exactly where to sink the blade. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) starts seeing things in her new flea-market ornaments after the ghost that came with them refuses to acknowledge her. Can hunky Professor Payne (Jay Mohr) help? 8 P.M. (History) INTO THE FIRE -- Hero worship: what firefighters really think and feel as they face the heat. 8:30 P.M. (CMT) FOXWORTHY'S BIG NIGHT OUT -- Jeff Foxworthy's fictional redneck family is at it again in tonight's episode, and Billy Currington joins the fray before singing his latest hit, ''Good Directions.'' 9 P.M. (ABC) MEN IN TREES -- Sometimes there's no turning back. After having done the deed with Jack (James Tupper), Marin (Anne Heche, left, with Mr. Tupper) wonders if men and women can be friends after they've slept together -- and tests her theory by inviting him along for the ride to Anchorage. 9 P.M. (CMT) DALLAS COWBOYS CHEERLEADERS: MAKING THE TEAM -- The women are on pins and needles as they get fitted for their uniforms, and one is told to pack up her pompoms. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- Detectives Green and Cassady team up with the F.B.I.'s Joint Terrorism Task Force to investigate the death of a young Middle Eastern man who was killed in what looks like a hate-crime, only to have the suspect's lawyer (Richard Brooks, in a reprise of his guest role as Paul Robinette, a high-powered defense lawyer) try to have the case tossed. 10 P.M. (TLC) COVER SHOT -- Saran Bynum, a former New Orleans poet and arts activist, starts a new life in New York after being displaced by Hurricane Katrina. First step on the road to recovery: seeing her dolled-up self on a billboard high above Times Square. 11 P.M. (BBC America) SAXONDALE -- Tommy Saxondale (Steve Coogan, right) abandoned life as a roadie when D.J.'s started replacing musicians and new health rules required him to wear a hairnet. So now he owns a pest control business in an English village, where in this new comedy series he battles ants, mice and his clueless assistant, Raymond (Rasmus Hardiker). KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DUKE, JAMES DARYL
summary: DUKE--James Daryl. After a courageous struggle with pulmonary fibrosis, Daryl passed away peacefully at his West Vancouver home on October 21, 2006. Born March 8, 1929 in Vancouver, Daryl's love of British Columbia never waned even while he wandered the world. The smell of the ocean, the changing of the tide, but most importantly watching the setting of the sun on British Columbia's Pacific coast were very much part of his persona, especially when he was on his Savary Island -a place he came to think of as ''home''. From selling jokes to a local radio station at the age of 15, he earnestly set out to capture his '' love with shadows, phantoms, lovely ghosts, and haunting the byways of our hearts after he obtained a degree in English and Philosophy from the University of British columbia. He has worked for the National Film board, the CBC, aBC, NBC and CBS, and most of the major studios in Hollywood. He has also been the recipient of many accolades and awards -Emmy Award for his direction of ''The Day the Lion Died'' starring Hal Holbrook, the National Society of Film Critics Special Award for his feature film ''payday'' starring Rip Torn, a Christopher Award for ''I Heard the Owl Call My Name'' starring British actor Tom Courtenay, the Canadian Film Awards (now called the Genies) for ''The Silent Partner'' starring Christopher Plummer, Elliott Gould and Susannah York. Daryl's feature film ''Payday'' was also an official entry at the Cannes Film Festival in the Directors' Fortnight Category. He received Emmy and Directors Guild of America nomination for his work on the mini-series ''The Thorn Birds.'' He co-founded and launched the independent station CKVU-TV in Vancouver and was its first President and CEO. He was inducted into the '' Starwalk '' and the B.C. Entertainment Hall of Fame at Vancouvers Orpheum Theatre. He was also the first recipient of the Outstanding Achievement Award for an Individual given at the British Columbia Film Industry's annual Leo Awards ceremony. Daryl was inducted into the Canadian Association of Broadcast Hall of Fame. Simon Fraser University granted him a Honourary Doctorate of Fine Arts, and he also received ACTRA's John Drainie Award for distinguished contribution to broadcasting. ''Though the lamps should be lit and fires started I stay watching the darkness come slowly forward. I think of how few nights of peace there are. True peace. When the flood tide slides north as it should. When the eagle sits in his tree. When the heron puts away the torn cloth of his cries. When night falls and the heart is not heavy''. Daryl has lived his life with enthusiasm, spirit and an intensely enquiring mind. He is survived by his wife Anne-Marie Dekker, sons Bryan (Margy) and David (Melanie), stepson Michael Favelle (Carrie) and grandchildren Leah, Nathan, Samantha, Dakota, Ansel, Owen, Elijah, Noah, and Jakob. A public service will be held on Tuesday, November 7 at 2pm at Christ Church Cathedral, 690 Burrard Street, Vancouver, BC. Condolences or well wishes may be posted at www.darylduke.com. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Daryl Duke Screenwriters Award c/ o BC Film, 2225 West Broadway, Vancouver, BC V6K 2E4.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) GET OUT THERE! -- This new series follows 10 families getting up close to wildlife while visiting national parks. Some viewers may be able to relax and enjoy the adventures, like bison-watching from a hot-air balloon above the Badlands of South Dakota. But this is sad timing for the show, only a week after a 6-year-old girl from Ohio was mauled to death by a black bear in a Tennessee national forest. Above: Katie, left, Melissa and Jack Claussen. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: PANAMA -- EXILE ISLAND -- The competition continues in this six-year-old reality show, even though the people with the most interesting occupations (logging-sports performer, Tennessee singer and former astronaut) are gone. Last week the show proved that some people will do anything for a decent burger. 8 P.M. (WE) KINDERGARTEN COP -- (1990). Before he became governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger starred in this comedy as an undercover police officer posing as a teacher of very small children.The funny part is that he can't control them. 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Poor Clark Kent, aka Superboy (Tom Welling), has already lost his father this season. Now his mother is in danger. When Martha Kent (Annette O'Toole) learns that Lionel Luthor (John Glover, left, who, to some of us, will always be the twins in ''Love! Valour! Compassion!'') knows Superboy's secret identity, she puts herself in harm's way. Lionel is being held hostage by a masked tormenter. 9 P.M. (Fox) THE O.C. -- Beautiful, troubled young Californians go to freshman orientation at their prestigious future college homes, Brown and the University of California at Berkeley. Next week: senior prom. 10 P.M. (CBS) WITHOUT A TRACE -- A young man from a wealthy old family does volunteer work at a homeless shelter after being convicted of drug possession. Then he disappears. Maybe he was kidnapped. Or maybe a shelter isn't the ideal place to get away from drug users. Perry King and Gina Torres guest-star as his parents. 10 P.M. (ABC) COMMANDER IN CHIEF -- Adam Arkin (right) guest-stars as a nominee for attorney general, going through confirmation difficulties. A plane full of military weapons goes missing. And so does Kate (Polly Bergen), the president's mother. ANITA GATES

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (NBC) HEROES -- A total eclipse leads a genetics professor to deduce that the superhuman live among us. One can fly. Another can paint the future. A third can stop time. And together they can save the world. Among the cast in this new drama series: Hayden Panettiere (above left), as a high school cheerleader who, through cringe-inducing testing methods, discovers that her flesh is indestructible. Ouch. 8 P.M. (NBC) DEAL OR NO DEAL -- They call Missouri the ''Show Me State'' -- as in show me the money! Tonight, a roster of Missourians try their luck at winning $1 million. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Well, that's one way to bury treasure. Michael and Lincoln start going door to door after they discover that a housing development has sprouted atop Westmoreland's stash. Meanwhile, T-Bag makes goo-goo eyes at a comely suburbanite. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP -- Give me a C, for competitive. A hyperkinetic cheerleading coach trades places with a Web-logged mother who offers her husband and son sustenance at their computers. 8 P.M. (11) 7TH HEAVEN -- Just when you thought it was safe again, CW brings on the 11th season of the show that just won't go away. Tonight, the unstable Lucy delivers a sermon, Martin makes his intentions clear to Sandy, Sandy lets it be known that she has switched majors, and an angelic neighbor (Jewel, in a cameo) sings Savannah to sleep. 9 P.M. (11) RUNAWAY -- And they seem like such nice folks. In this new crime drama, a successful lawyer (Donnie Wahlberg, above right, with Dustin Milligan, far left, and Nathan Gamble) wrongfully accused of murder picks up his Maryland family and plops them down in small-town Iowa, where they live under an assumed identity while trying to evade the law -- and the real killer -- mostly by breaking it. 9 P.M. (13, 49) MARIE ANTOINETTE -- A look at the travails of the teenage bride, who, through her frivolity, excess and simple immaturity, became one of the most controversial monarchs in history. 10 P.M. (Showtime) WEEDS -- File it under ''with friends like these . . . .'' Thanks to a balloting error, Celia beats Doug in the election and in the snap of her false tips announces the city's new drug-free policy. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Ray Liotta talks about playing a career criminal in his new show, ''Smith''; Elvis Costello and Tony Bennett (right) perform from Mr. Bennett's 80thbirthday tribute album, ''Duets,'' coming out tomorrow. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Grey's Anatomy' Gives ABC A Sunday Night Lift
summary: Despite the fact that ''Desperate Housewives'' was a repeat on Sunday night, ABC was No. 1 among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. But CBS managed to win among households in Nielsen's estimates. In some parts of the country, CBS's broadcast of Tiger Woods's playoff victory in the Buick Invitational spilled into primetime and helped ''60 Minutes,'' but the ratings for the live event and the network's subsequent lineup were approximate. On ABC, ''Grey's Anatomy'' was the night's most-watched program despite its following a ''Housewives'' rerun. The comedic hospital soap opera, which will get a huge viewing platform next Sunday, when it is shown after the Super Bowl, drew an audience of 18.49 million. Earlier in the night on ABC, ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' in its 16th season, delivered its best 18-to-49 ratings of the season and proved that 10.95 million viewers still know the show exists. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10:30 P.M. (MTV) JAMIE KENNEDY'S BLOWIN' UP -- In this new reality series, Mr. Kennedy (above) and his best friend, Stu Stone, try to become rap stars and upset Russell Simmons along the way. 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS -- Season finale. An injured Gibbs (Mark Harmon) holds the key to defusing a terrorist group that is plotting a bombing of the magnitude of Sept. 11. Now, if only he could remember it. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- After the startling elimination of Chris Daughtry last week, almost anything seems possible in this battle of the final three as two underdogs -- Taylor Hicks and Elliott Yamin -- and a Kat (McPhee, that is) go yowl to yowl. 8 P.M. (ABC) CELEBRITY DEBUT -- Early interviews and best-forgotten film clips show John Travolta, Halle Berry, Kate Winslet and Felicity Huffman at their humble beginnings. 8 P.M. (NBC) WILL & GRACE -- Jack uses Grace as bait to prove that his rival (a guest starring Matt Damon) for the last spot in a gay men's chorus is actually straight. At 8:30, it's all rather meta when Jack, after stalking Kevin Bacon, lands his dream job after Mr. Bacon, playing himself, hires him to find out who has been stalking him. 9 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- In this two-hour season finale, Alan Shore defends a sexy Hollywood celebrity (Jeri Ryan) who shot a paparazzo she said was stalking her. But that doesn't stop Denny Crane (William Shatner, above, with Ms. Ryan) and Barry Goal (Robert Wagner), Crane's doppelgänger in the firm's Los Angeles office, from doing a little stalking of their own. Back at home, Denise Bauer puts a squeeze on her rival for partner, the Squid (Parker Posey). 9 P.M. (13) FRONTLINE -- ''Can You Afford to Retire?'' According to this special, which looks at how pension cuts, corporate bankruptcies and stock-market crashes will affect baby boomers, the correct answer is no. Carin Baer/ABC 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT -- Season finale. After a rock star (Norman Reedus) lectures about the abuse of psychiatric drugs on a national talk show, a young woman (Brittany Snow) goes off her medications and mows down 10 people with a car. We're just glad Brooke Shields wasn't listening to Tom Cruise. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Debra Messing (left), the star of the nearly departed ''Will & Grace,'' talks about life at the end of the tunnel. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Scott McClellan, in his first television appearance after stepping down as White House press secretary, talks about his early retirement plans. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
summary: Recent Sale $59.3 million Eagle Road Shopping Center Eagle Road and Interstate 84 Danbury, Conn. This new 319,789-square-foot shopping center includes a Loews Cineplex and Lowe's Home Center. Buyer: Blumenfeld Development Corp. Seller: Eagle Road Center L.L.C. Brokers: Jeffrey Dunne and Ryan Bassett, CB Richard Ellis Recent Lease $36/sq. ft. approximate annual rent $774,252 463 Seventh Avenue, at 35th Street Manhattan An outerwear company is to consolidate its offices and showroom in 21,507 square feet on the entire 11th floor of this 22-story 1925 building. Tenant: L'Art de la Mode Inc. Landlord: Arsenal Co. Broker: David Levy, Adams & Co. For Lease $42/sq. ft. Silk Building 14 East Fourth Street Manhattan An 18,215-square-foot third-floor commercial condominium has its own lobby and elevator in this 12-story 1908 building between Broadway and Lafayette Street. Owner: 4th Bway/Laf L.L.C. Brokers: Jay Caseley and Steven Hornstock, ABS Partners Real Estate L.L.C. ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) THAT 70's SHOW -- Talk about brotherly love. Barry Williams and Christopher Knight (center left, with Mr. Williams and Debra Jo Rupp as Kitty), who, the last we saw them, were the elder sons on ''The Brady Bunch,'' play the nice couple who just moved in next door. 8 P.M. (13) and 9 P.M. (49) TEXAS RANCH HOUSE -- In the final two episodes, the Cooke Ranch cowboys learn the real meaning of saddle sore as they spend nine days driving 131 head to a cattle agent in Fort Santiago -- and discover just how darn dangerous those dogies can be. Tensions finally boil over upon the group's return to the ranch, which raises the real question: how has the ranch weathered the storm of 1867? 9 P.M. (CBS) CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION -- Luck be a lady? Not tonight, when one womanizing high roller finds his luck has run out just as his fantasy comes true. 9 P.M. (11) SUPERNATURAL -- Season finale. They've been searching for her their entire lives. And now that they've found the demon that killed their mother, Sam (Jared Padalecki) and Dean (Jensen Ackles) must destroy her -- before she kills their father (Jeffrey Dean Morgan, near right, with Mr. Padalecki). 9 P.M. (Fox) THE O. C. -- Ryan makes a deal with Volchok after the prom fiasco. Marissa visits Kaitlin at her boarding school and plots revenge on her sister's behalf. And just as Sandy is named Newport's Man of the Year, his son, Seth, gets arrested at the ceremony. Note we didn't say Father of the Year. 10 P.M. (ABC) PRIMETIME -- In her first television interview, Mary Cheney, a daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney, talks about being gay and the challenges of balancing her private life and political position while standing by her father. The extreme magician David Blaine, who never met a world record he didn't like, talks about training to hold his breath underwater for nine minutes, which he will attempt to do -- live from Lincoln Center -- on May 8. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- So what if Julia Roberts (left) isn't the most lauded actress ever to step onto the Great White Way. That was never the point, now, was it? Tonight, Mr. Letterman cashes in on Ms. Roberts's critically pounded star turn in ''Three Days of Rain'' and puts her back before the camera, where she can't help but shine. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (HBO) ELIZABETH I -- Helen Mirren (right) plays England's 16th-century Virgin Queen later in life (beginning in her mid-40's). Jeremy Irons stars as the Earl of Leicester and Hugh Dancy asthe Earl of Essex, both important men to Elizabeth. When British viewers saw the film on Channel 4 last fall, Christopher Matthew of The Daily Mail declared Dame Helen ''the greatest Elizabeth of all,'' John Preston of The Sunday Telegraph found her performance ''oddly pallid'' and Rupert Smith of The Guardian didn't care for the exposition-heavy dialogue. Part 1 of 2. 7 P.M. (HBO) TOO HOT NOT TO HANDLE -- This documentary laments just how bad global warming is and considers what individuals can do about it. 8 P.M. (Science) COOL FUEL -- Shaun Murphy, an Australian, and his dog, Sparky, see the U.S.A. on custom-built vehicles powered by alternative fuel sources. At one point in this two-hour special, they visit Daryl Hannah's house. 8 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS MYSTERY: THE MARILYN TAPES -- In a few months (on Aug. 5), it will have been 44 years since Marilyn Monroe (left), Hollywood's blonde of blondes, was found lying nude in her Los Angeles bedroom, dead of a drug overdose at 36. People are still questioning whether it was suicide, an accident or murder and who might have been involved. Peter Van Sant offers up new documents and interviews about the case. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) MAMMOTH -- A spaceship crashes into a natural history museum in Louisiana. On board is a shape-shifting life form that needs a body to inhabit. It decides on a frozen woolly mammoth, which is soon terrorizing the town. Vincent Ventresca, Tom Skerritt and Summer Glau, as a paleontologist, his father and his daughter, do their best to get through this television movie. 9 P.M. (CBS) SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE -- (2003). Diane Keaton plays a divorced playwright with a perfect house in the Hamptons who finds herself unwillingly playing host and nurse to her daughter's much-older boyfriend (Jack Nicholson, above, with Ms. Keaton) after his heart attack. Then the film turns into an appealing if not scintillating romantic comedy that actually celebrates middle age. (He asks, ''What about birth control?'' She answers, ''Menopause.'') ANITA GATES

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'The Closer' Is a Winner
summary: The return of ''The Closer,'' with Kyra Sedgwick, below, as a Southern-fried detective, set a ratings record for advertiser-supported cable. Monday's premiere of Season 2 brought TNT 8.3 million viewers, the largest cable audience for a scripted series. An audience of 5.1 million stuck around to watch the series debut of ''Saved.'' Elsewhere on cable, the beginning of Season 3 of USA Network's ''4400'' drew 4.2 million viewers on Sunday. The Miami Heat's comeback win against the Dallas Mavericks delivered a ratings victory for ABC on Tuesday. Nielsen's estimates for the live broadcast were preliminary, but they indicated that ABC was No. 1 among total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic. NBC placed second in both categories. At 9 p.m., ''Last Comic Standing,'' in which the final group of comics was picked to live together, drew 9 million viewers and was the top entertainment program of the night among adults 18 to 49. A ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' repeat followed the comedy show, bringing in 9.7 million viewers. Between ''Law & Order'' on NBC and the N.B.A. on ABC, CBS's debut of ''Tuesday Night Book Club'' was practically invisible. The reality soap attracted an audience of 5.1 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (TNT) 2006 BLACK MOVIE AWARDS -- Tyler Perry (left), aka Madea, an often-mad black woman, is host of this annual celebration of black cinema past, present and future. Laurence Fishburne is to receive the excellence in arts award, and Cicely Tyson will be honored for distinguished career achievement. Nominees for outstanding motion picture include ''Akeelah and the Bee,'' ''ATL,'' ''Four Brothers,'' ''Inside Man,'' ''Tsotsi'' and Mr. Perry's own ''Madea's Family Reunion.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK -- Tonight, Liz tries to keep ''The Girlie Show'' from falling apart after the men start wreaking havoc. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) WORLD'S MOST DANGEROUS DRUG -- It's considered one of the hardest addictions to crack, and its abuse is ravaging the nation's heartland just as surely as it's infiltrating the cities. In this ''Explorer'' special Lisa Ling investigates the methamphetamine epidemic. 9 P.M. (13) MOYERS ON AMERICA -- Whither the Internet? Bill Moyers and Rick Karr look at how telecommunications companies' promises of a super-high-speed Internet in return for deregulation and tax breaks have gone unfulfilled while the public has paid the price. 9 P.M. (ABC) LOST -- Don't push that button! Oops, you pushed it. After the hatch implodes, the group learns of Locke (Terry O'Quinn, right), Eko and Desmond's fate. Meanwhile, Hurley heads back to the beach to tell what happened when he, Jack, Kate and Sawyer ran into The Others. 10 P.M. (CBS) CSI: NY -- She wanted to be a SuicideGirl, but she didn't want to be dead. A 18-year-old with dreams of an alternative lifestyle winds up a corpse after performing in an avant-garde burlesque show. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY -- And the winner is . . . 10 P.M. (WE) HAIR TRAUMA -- One snip is all it takes to turn a bad hair day into a bad hair month. Tonight in this reality series set at LaVar Hair Designs on the Upper West Side, Ellin botches a haircut. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) TWO-A-DAYS -- The twice daily practices are over and the playoffs are but a faded memory. In this season finale, the boys of the Hoover High School Buccaneers in Hoover, Ala., receive their fourth state championship ring at the football banquet and are ranked the top high school team in the nation by Sports Illustrated and USA Today. 11 P.M. (Bravo) TOP CHEF -- In this second season premiere, set in the restaurant world of Los Angeles, 15 aspiring chefs jump into the fire with glee as they slice and dice their way through a series of challenges to win $100,000 in seed money to put toward a culinary career, a feature in Food & Wine magazine and the title of top chef. Tom Colicchio, a co-founder of Gramercy Tavern and Craft in New York, is head chef and judge for the season; Padma Lakshmi (above), the show's host, gets to tell fallen contestants to pack their knives. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 10 P.M. (Food Network) PAULA'S PARTY -- Paula Deen (right), the network's bubbly queen of Southern cuisine, treats viewers to an evening of food and festivities in this new series taped at Uncle Bubba's Oyster House in Savannah, Ga. It's a family affair: her sons, Bobby and Jamie, with whom she owns a restaurant, and her husband, Michael Groover, don aprons to play around the pots and pans. 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) DOCTOR WHO -- Same doctor, different face. That's how the people at Sci Fi are explaining the appearance of David Tennant, who takes over the role from Christopher Eccleston in this season premiere. 8 P.M. (The N) DEGRASSI: THE NEXT GENERATION -- Send out the distress signals. Another season of teenage angst begins tonight, when Peter gets a new car and becomes big man on campus. 8:30 P.M. (CMT) FOXWORTHY'S BIG NIGHT OUT -- Ooo-eee, baby! In tonight's skit, a construction crew of women give it --loudly and lewdly -- to the men walking by. The Wreckers perform ''Leave the Pieces.'' 9 P.M. (Fox) CELEBRITY DUETS -- The winning singer is handed a check for $100,000 for the charity of his or her choice. 9 P.M. (CMT) DALLAS COWBOYS CHEERLEADERS: MAKING THE TEAM -- In this two-hour special, hundreds of women sis, boom and bah for one of 45 chances to wear the squad's star-spangled uniform. 9 P.M. (ABC) MEN IN TREES -- Time for the meds. Tonight, rumor in New York has it that Marin (Anne Heche) is dead. Worse, her city wardrobe is now on every woman in Elmo, Alaska. 9 P.M. (CBS) CLOSE TO HOME -- A woman says she murdered her husband in selfdefense. Annabeth (Jennifer Finnigan) isn't so sure. 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WORLD'S UGLIEST DOG COMPETITION -- A menagerie of mutts mugs for the camera. 10 P.M. (Spike) BOSTON PD -- A look at the daily routine of members of the Boston Police Department, in four parts. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- An Internet photo of a sliced up soccer mom in provocative attire leads Detectives Ed Green (Jesse L. Martin) and Nina Cassady (Milena Govich) to the crime scene. But why don't the victim's clothes and shoes fit? 10 P.M. (BET) BET'S TOP 25: MONEY, POWER, RESPECT -- This special counts down influential African-Americans, including Jay-Z, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Senator Barak Obama of Illinois, and Stanley O'Neal, chief executive of Merrill Lynch. Tony Rock (right) is host. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ANDY WARHOL: A DOCUMENTARY FILM -- No one screamed Pop Art more loudly than Warhol (above, in 1966). And chances are no pop artist was more famously misunderstood. In this two-part ''American Masters'' film, Ric Burns places Warhol's vast output within the turbulent context of his life and times to create a portrait of an enigmatic man who, perhaps most profoundly of all, blurred the boundary between art and commerce. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER -- Fifty contestants -- one from each state -- arrive at the Biggest Loser Ranch, where 14 will whittle away the pounds at a spa-like boot camp for a prize of $250,000, while the other 36 are banished to work out back at home, alone. 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO -- Hellooo! Anyone out there? When a psychedeliclooking mushroom cloud suddenly appears on the horizon, some small-town Kansans are forced to ponder whether they are the only people left alive. Gerald McRaney, Pamela Reed, Lennie James and Ashley Scott play a few of the lost souls in this new drama; Skeet Ulrich (above, left) is the mayor's son, who mysteriously reappears in time for the mayhem. 8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- Anything for fame, huh? Another round of 13 semifinalists take it all off for a revealing photo shoot in this premiere of the competition series, which falls just short of promising wannabe runway stars a ticket to the top. (So far, it hasn't happened.) But tonight, no one, it seems, can outdo Tyra Banks in terms of shock value. 8 P.M. (13, 49) JEAN-MICHEL COUSTEAU: OCEAN ADVENTURES -- ''We can't protect what we don't understand,'' says Jean-Michel Cousteau, Jacques's son, explaining in part why he carries on the family legacy. In this series's final episode, Jean-Michel and his children Fabien and Céline explore 13 littleknown national marine sanctuaries in the United States, where they witness sea turtles laying their eggs on a shore in the middle of the night, kelp forests that rival the California redwoods in size and girth, and the rusting wreck of the ironclad warship the Monitor. 10 P.M. (NBC) KIDNAPPED -- When their 15-year-old son (Will Denton) is kidnapped on his way to school and his bodyguard (Mykelti Williamson) left to die, a self-made millionaire (Timothy Hutton) and his wife (Dana Delany, above right, with Mr. Hutton) hire a professional investigator (Jeremy Sisto) to do whatever is required to get him back -- even if it means breaking the law. Delroy Lindo plays a veteran F.B.I. agent who postpones his retirement to help solve the case. He has his reasons. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly; USA Tops on Cable
summary: Among advertiser-supported cable channels, USA Network was No. 1 in prime time for January in total viewers, as well as the crucial adult demographics advertisers seek. Its victory in Nielsen's estimates was due in large part to the channel's two most successful hits, which are aesthetic opposites: Tony Shalhoub's fussy detective on ''Monk,'' left, and Vince McMahon's boorish wrestlers on ''WWE Monday Night Raw.'' For the whole day of programming in January, Nickelodeon was the top-ranked channel, as it nearly always is. Its most-watched shows of the month were the ''Jimmy/Timmy Power Hour 2'' (5.48 million) and three broadcasts of ''Drake & Josh Go Hollywood,'' a movie based on the channel's popular tween series. Last Friday, the first of the February sweeps, CBS placed first among total viewers, but NBC squeaked by CBS among adults 18 to 49. ABC, which was second among viewers and third in the 18-to-49 demographic, had the night's most-watched show, ''Dancing With the Stars'' (15.94 million). Tia Carrere, the tribe has spoken. KATE AURTHUR

headline: News Summary
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Pentagon Finds Abuse In Old Iraq Interrogations American Special Operations troops employed a set of harsh, unauthorized interrogation techniques against detainees in Iraq during a four-month period in early 2004, long after approval for their use was rescinded, according to a Pentagon inquiry. A1 The House approved a resolution promising ''completion of the mission'' in Iraq, in a vote reflecting partisan divisions over the war. A7 Two G.I.'s were missing and one was killed after they came under attack at a traffic point southwest of Baghdad, an area with one of the most extensive strongholds of Al Qaeda in Iraq, the military said. A7 Iran Scrutinizing Incentive Plan Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said his country was ''carefully considering'' an international proposal to resolve the dispute over its uranium enrichment program. A5 No Verdict in China Trial The closed trial of a researcher for The New York Times accused of disclosing state secrets and fraud ended in Beijing but a verdict may not come for a month. A3 North Korea Works on Missile North Korea appears to have stepped up preparations to test an intercontinental ballistic missile, perhaps as early as this weekend, American officials said. A8 Rebels to Join Nepalese State Maoist rebels agreed to join Nepal's new government under an accord that obliges both politicians and rebels to give up key pillars of power, in a statement issued by the Maoist leader and the interim prime minister after a meeting. A5 Palestinian Aid Plan Gains Favor The Bush administration said it would go along with a European proposal to transfer funds through the World Bank to pay stipends to poor Palestinians, some of whom had previously drawn salaries from the Palestinian government. A4 NATIONAL A9-11 As Oil Rises in Markets, Rigs Rise in Mississippi The high price of oil, hovering around $70 a barrel, has brought a nearly dormant Mississippi petroleum industry roaring to life. Wells abandoned long ago by the major oil companies are being reopened by independent operators. A9 U.S. Still Far From Prepared States and cities in hurricane zones generally have better plans to deal with disaster than do other regions, but the nation's overall level of preparedness is still far from sufficient, a new report by the Department of Homeland Security says. A10 A Memorial for Columbine Construction of a long-delayed and scaled-down memorial to the victims of the Columbine High School shootings began with a ground-breaking ceremony and a speech by former President Bill Clinton commemorating the incident. A10 Report on Death of Journalist Firefighters, ambulance technicians, police officers and the staff at a Washington hospital committed ''multiple individual failures'' in responding to the ultimately fatal beating of a journalist last January, an official inquiry concluded. A9 Democrats Unveil Platform Democratic leaders in Congress announced the platform they hope to use to regain the majority in November, including promises to raise the minimum wage, make college tuition tax deductible, negotiate lower drug prices for the prescription plan passed last year, and eliminate subsidies for oil and gas companies. A11 Constitutional Showdown A showdown between Congress and the Bush administration moved into federal court, as a judge peppered lawyers about the legal and historic significance of the F.B.I.'s search for evidence of bribery at the legislative offices of Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 After Years in the Hudson, The Intrepid to Get Repairs The Intrepid, a World War II-era aircraft carrier that has served as a military museum and has been docked on the West Side of Manhattan for almost 25 years, will be dragged down the Hudson River to a dry dock sometime in the next several months to be patched up and repainted, its owners have told some government officials. A1 Charges in Cliffside Suicide Victor K. Han, whose stepped out of the family minivan before his wife drove it off a cliff in Bear Mountain State Park, killing herself, has been charged with promoting a suicide attempt, the police said. B1 Drop in 5th Graders' Scores More than 8,900 New York City fifth graders are in danger of being left back as a result of failing scores on annual reading and math tests, city education officials said, a sharp contrast with last year's results. B1 Religion Journal B5 ARTS B7-17 Dan Rather Exiting CBS Having stepped down as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' last year, Dan Rather's contract with CBS, and ''60 Minutes,'' is not scheduled to expire until late November. But he said he and the network were close to an agreement that would end his tenure early, and that he was seriously considering other opportunities. A1 Ancient Tomb Unveiled Hoping for leniency in a coming trial, an accused tomb robber led Italian officials two weeks ago to a startling discovery on a sun-scorched hilltop less than 13 miles north of Rome: the oldest Etruscan burial chamber ever found. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Restrictions at Wikipedia Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia that ''anyone can edit,'' is not the experiment in freewheeling, collective creativity that it might seem to be. In response to well-publicized reports that certain articles are being vandalized, administrators are now protecting some entries. A1 Microsoft Faces Challenges Microsoft stands astride the computing world much as I.B.M. once did, but now its task is to avoid repeating I.B.M.'s mistakes. Microsoft's revenues have never been higher, but it has yet to profit from the array of businesses that it has entered beyond those it has already dominated. C1 G.E.'s New Appliances As a result of its commanding position in the major appliance market, General Electric has a new line of products aimed at customers far more concerned with gadgets and style than utilitarian function. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: A problem that can't be ignored; where did the good investments go?; keeping the faith with AmeriCorps; the art of the deal. Columns: John Tierney. Bridge B11 Crossword B16 Obituaries C10 TV Listings B17 Weather B18

headline: Arts, Briefly; Grammys? What Grammys? 'American Idol' Rolls
summary: If Kelly Clarkson's ''American Idol'' luster had rubbed off on the Grammy Awards, she might have prevented the ceremony's broadcast from achieving its second-lowest ratings ever. The telecast, during which Ms. Clarkson, below, the first ''American Idol'' winner, won two Grammy Awards, drew an estimated 17.56 million viewers in prime time, down from last year's low-rated telecast. According to Nielsen's estimates, those ratings for CBS were good enough for only a second-place finish, behind Fox, in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. ''American Idol,'' which delivered an estimated 28.29 million viewers, fueled Fox's victory. During the 8 p.m. time period, ''Idol'' beat the Grammys' first hour by more than 13 million viewers. And at 9 p.m., the awards ceremony was challenged by ABC's ''Lost'' (18.78 million). The island mystery featured a power play by Sawyer (Josh Holloway), who turned the testosterone tables on Jack (Matthew Fox) and Locke (Terry O'Quinn). With CBS's usual broadcast of ''CSI: New York'' out of the mix, NBC's ''Law & Order'' was able to bring in its best ratings since the end of September, with an audience of 14.56 million at 10 p.m. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (NBC) TIM McGRAW: REFLECTED -- Mr. McGraw (above), the Louisiana-born Grammy and Country Music Award winner (he won both for his hit ''Live Like You Were Dying,'' written for his father, Tug McGraw), puts a lot of variety into his special. He appears in concert at a New York club, gives special performances at his Nashville farm, sings with his wife, Faith Hill, and enjoys a jam session with Hank Williams Jr. His band, the Dancehall Doctors, does its bit, too. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt), your friendly neighborhood medium, is asked to help a teenage girl whose boyfriend has died -- and possibly help the boyfriend's spirit pass on to the next level. This would normally be just another day at the office for Melinda, but she recently hit her head and seems to have lost her ability to communicate with the dead. 8 P.M. (A&E) HAIRDOS AND HEARTACHES: THE WOMEN OF COUNTRY MUSIC -- This two-hour ''Biography'' special stars a heap of 'em, including Loretta Lynn (right), Reba McEntire, K. D. Lang, Naomi Judd, Emmylou Harris, LeAnn Rimes, Tanya Tucker, Trisha Yearwood and Crystal Gayle. When not reflecting on the difficulties of making it in a good-old-boy's world, they sing. 10 P.M. (CBS) NUMB3RS -- The Eppes brothers (Rob Morrow and David Krumholtz) investigate a school shooting, which seems much like other such incidents at first. But while analyzing the young shooters' patterns of movement, Charlie (Mr. Krumholtz), the math genius, notices something odd. The students may have had an accomplice. 10 P.M. (Sundance) BRIGHT YOUNG THINGS (2004). Stephen Campbell Moore and Emily Mortimer (below) star in this giddy film based on Evelyn Waugh's novel ''Vile Bodies.'' They play a 1930's couple who want to marry, but don't have enough money. Still, being in their 20's, good-looking and upper-crust British, they manage to take most of life very unseriously. 10:30 P.M. (IFC) DINNER FOR FIVE -- Tony Shalhoub, Burt Reynolds, Kevin James and Richard Lewis chat with Jon Favreau, the host, in this 2004 episode. It's not every day that Adrian Monk shares his thoughts with the King of Queens. ANITA GATES

headline: INSIDE
summary: Mike Wallace to Retire From CBS's '60 Minutes' As he nears his 88th birthday, Mike Wallace, who started his career at CBS in 1951 and swore he would never leave alive, has decided to step away from ''60 Minutes,'' where he has been for 38 years. One of the inventors of the television interview, he has sat across from everyone from Yasir Arafat to Carol Burnett. While saying he would cut back three years ago, he kept up a brisk pace, saying, ''I wouldn't know what else to do.'' BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 NEW ONLINE The Pour Starting today, Eric Asimov, The Times's wine critic, offers a blog on the pleasures of drinking wine, beer and spirits, as well as some of the larger issues involved, at nytimes.com/thepour. A Resolution Eludes Ground Zero Negotiators Negotiators trying to resolve the fate of ground zero worked into the night, trying to beat a deadline to settle their financial differences over a significant realignment of the rebuilding plans. But major stumbling blocks remained, and two people involved in the negotiations said the talks nearly ''blew up'' several times. PAGE B4 Vote Sought on Transit Pact The president of the New York City transit workers' union, Roger Toussaint, said he would seek to submit the union's rejected contract to a new vote by the city's 33,700 subway and bus drivers. PAGE B1 A Wal-Mart Bank: Why Not? All of Wal-Mart's plans to start a bank have drawn enormous opposition, but David Leonhardt argues in his column that a Wal-Mart bank could actually help consumers. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 G.O.P. Backing for Lobby Bill The House Republican leadership is backing a measure that temporarily bars lawmakers from accepting privately financed trips. PAGE A23 Culinary Star Rises Again Charleston, S.C., has long been a place for eating well, very well. These days, it is a gastronomic boom town, with a new sophistication sweeping the city. DINING, PAGE F1

headline: For N.F.L. Fans, The Cable Picture Isn't Any Clearer
summary: Roger Goodell, the National Football League commissioner, visited Green Bay for last week's Vikings-Packers game at Lambeau Field, where he discussed why many fans in Wisconsin would not be watching what was the sixth of eight Thursday and Saturday night games on the NFL Network. The truth was this: The state's dominant cable operators, Time Warner and Charter, don't carry the network, but in the Packers' home markets, Green Bay and Milwaukee, local stations showed the game.

headline: Corrections
summary: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about New York publishers' courting of Tokyopop, which prints book-length comics, misidentified the owner of Simon & Schuster, which has a distribution deal with a rival of Tokyopop, VIZ Media. It is the CBS Corporation, not Viacom.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Ousts Its Ace
summary: Ace Young, below, an early favorite on ''American Idol'' whose luster faded as the season progressed, received the voters' boot on Wednesday. The half-hour ''Idol'' drew an estimated 26.9 million viewers and lifted Fox to a victory. But more important, Fox's strong 18-to-49 ratings for Wednesday brought it to a tie with ABC in that demographic for the season over all. Last season ''Idol'' and the World Series delivered Fox a win in that age group, which advertisers care about the most. This season the network will also get a boost from ''24,'' ''House,'' ''Prison Break'' and ''Bones.'' ABC, Fox's competitor for 18-to-49-year-olds, broadcast the return of the soon-to-end ''Alias'' on Wednesday. The spy drama, in which Sydney (Jennifer Garner) had a baby girl, and viewers saw that Vaughn (Michael Vartan) is living among monks in Bhutan, drew 7.54 million viewers over two hours. ABC placed third for the night, behind CBS. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; Supersizing NBC
summary: On Thursday's ''Without a Trace,'' two teenagers -- a black boy and a white girl -- went missing, and the show explored how the news media and police investigators responded differently. The show, at 10 p.m. Eastern and Pacific times, drew 19 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, and capped another Thursday victory for CBS in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. It was preceded by ''Survivor'' at 8 p.m. (17.2 million) and ''CSI'' (26.7 million), which ended with Brass (Paul Guilfoyle) being shot in the chest. NBC's second-place lineup featured the season finales of ''My Name Is Earl'' (9.2 million) and ''The Office'' (7.4 million) in 41-minute ''supersized'' versions, the format the network often used for ''Friends'' back when it was No. 1 on Thursdays. Though ''Earl'' drew more viewers, ''The Office'' retained a large percentage of its 18-to-49 audience. At 9 p.m. on ABC, the penultimate episode of ''American Inventor,'' the Simon Cowell-produced show that has wilted over its short season, brought in roughly 7 million viewers and was fourth in the hour among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (CBS) FASHION ROCKS -- This third annual concert celebrates the fusion of fashion and music by some of the most glamorous partakers of both -- among them, Christina Aguilera, Bon Jovi, the Black Eyed Peas, Elton John, Jamie Foxx, Nelly Furtado, Faith Hill, Tim McGraw, the Pussycat Dolls, Rihanna, Scissor Sisters, Kanye West and Jay-Z, who will perform with Beyoncé (above, with Jay-Z, in June at the BET Awards) at the show's site, Radio City Music Hall. The special ushers in fall fashion week down the street in Bryant Park. 8 P.M. (E!, STYLE) STYLE ROCKS THE RED CARPET: FASHION ROCKS -- What all those stylemakers are wearing on the red carpet tonight. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) THE DOG WHISPERER -- Does your pet have you running in circles? Is your well-mannered mutt a monster in public? Cesar Millan teaches one dog how to stop chasing its tail and another some social graces. At 9 p.m., a pit bull who just wants to play, but not always nice. 8 P.M. (History) WORLD WAR III: BEYOND LEBANON -- An examination of the recent conflict between Israel and Lebanon, and its implications for the region and the world. 8 P.M. (Fox) NANNY 911 -- Sending out an SOS. In this season premiere, the Morris family's cries for help are heard by Nanny Stella (above, with the Morris children), who imposes a spoonful of sugar along with tough-love medicine. 8 P.M. (WE) THE LAST SEDUCTION -- Can you spell New York backward? Linda Fiorentino plays the brazen beauty Wendy Kroy who starts a new life with a wad of stolen drug money. Bill Pullman and Peter Berg are the suckers blinded by her light. 8:30 P.M. (CMT) FOXWORTHY'S BIG NIGHT OUT -- On this ''Celebrity Deer Hunter'' episode, Jeff Foxworthy and Shane Caldwell play the hapless hosts of a cableaccess hunting show who want Sara Evans to promote their new products. But all she wants to do is perform her new single, ''You'll Always Be My Baby,'' which she does. 9 P.M. (ABC) 20/20 --Growing older: this newsmagazine makes its 29th-season premiere. 9 P.M. (Disney) THE REPLACMENTS -- A couple of orphans, Todd and Riley, find a comic book with an ad that offers to replace the adults in a person's life for $1.98. And so they order two in this new animated comedy: a father, Dick Daring, who is a world-famous stuntman, and a mother, Agent K, who in her off-hours is a British superspy. Daran Norris, Nancy Cartwright, Eartha Kitt and David McCallum (above, with Ms. Kitt) lend their voices. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Lance Bass Comes Out Lance Bass, below, of 'N Sync is gay and in a ''very stable'' relationship with Reichen Lehmkuhl, winner of Season 4 of the CBS series ''The Amazing Race,'' Mr. Bass says in the new issue of People magazine, on sale tomorrow. In an interview, Mr. Bass said he had not chosen to disclose his sexuality earlier because he did not want to affect the popularity of the group, known for a string of hits including ''Bye Bye Bye'' and ''It's Gonna Be Me. ''I'm more liberated and happy than I've been my whole life,'' he told the magazine. 'Da Vinci Code' Banned Dan Brown's ''Da Vinci Code'' has been banned in Iran after protests by Christian clergymen, the BBC reported. Though no new copies will be printed, the eight previous editions of the book, in translation, will remain in stores. Those who took issue with the book object to its plot, which relies on a theory that Jesus married Mary Magdalene and that their descendants survive today. Iran, a nation of 69 million Muslims, is also home to about 100,000 Christians. New Morning Team ABC News yesterday announced a new team for ''Good Morning America'' as it takes the measure of a morning-show landscape being remade by the departures of Charles Gibson (from ''Good Morning America''') and Katie Couric (from ''Today''), and soon to feature Meredith Vieira (Ms. Couric's replacement). Jim Murphy, who served as executive producer of the ''CBS Evening News'' for six years until last year, becomes senior executive producer of ''Good Morning America.'' Tom Cibrowski, who joined ''Good Morning America'' four years ago, becomes executive producer, reporting to Mr. Murphy. Ben Sherwood, who has been executive producer since 2004, announced last month that he would leave the program later this year and was moving back to Los Angeles. New Opera, Old Lovers Although there are many theories about who actually wrote the plays attributed to Shakespeare, most historians seem to agree that there are some lost years in the historical record, leading to much speculation about what he was doing from 1584 to 1592. A new opera, ''William,'' scheduled to open last night at Vadstena Castle in Sweden, posits that he might have spent those years in a romantic relationship with the playwright Christopher Marlowe. According to the theater's Web site, the opera is ''a thrilling tale of love, power, espionage, counterfeit and jealousy in a 16th-century subculture.'' ''William'' was written in Swedish, with text by Hakan Lindquist and a score by Tommy Andersson. All Those Awards For the second year, the actor, playwright, novelist and drag performer Charles Busch (''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife,'' ''Die, Mommy, Die!'') will be the host of the New York Innovative Theater Awards, honoring achievement in Off Off Broadway theater, to be presented on Sept. 18. This year's nominees, chosen by a system that polls both audience members and appointed judges, were announced last week at a party in the East Village. Mr. Busch, right, was the host at the inaugural awards ceremony last year and wanted to do it again because he ''thought it was fascinating,'' he said in a telephone interview (during which he fumbled with a new cellphone that he thought might be taking pictures of his ear). ''I think it's an important thing that they're doing,'' he said, ''and I like that it encompasses a wide range of people who are working Off Off Broadway.'' Last year, the group used the Lucille Lortel Theater for the presentation, but, in an indication of interest in the awards, it is looking for a bigger location this time. Presenters include the playwrights Lanford Wilson and Lisa Kron (''Well''). The actor and rapper Will Smith will be honored by the Museum of the Moving Image on Dec. 3 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan. In announcing his selection as this year's honoree, the chairman of the board of trustees, Herbert Schlosser, described Mr. Smith as ''a man of diverse successes.'' Previous honorees include Sidney Lumet, Elia Kazan and James Stewart. Stevie Wonder will receive a lifetime achievement award at an Oct. 17 presentation of the National Civil Rights Museum's 2006 Freedom Awards in Memphis. Also being presented are the International Freedom Award, to Bernard Kouchner, the physician and former minister of health for France who started the nonprofit Doctors Without Borders, and the National Freedom Award, to Joseph Lowery, a founder of both the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the Black Leadership Forum. News From the Stage Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg's epic musical ''The Pirate Queen'' has a place and a time: previews are scheduled to begin Feb. 23 at the Hilton Theater, with an opening set for March 22. Frank Galati will direct a cast of 39. Among the former cast members of ''Chicago'' who are coming back for the 10th-anniversary performance on Nov. 14 are Melanie Griffith, Brooke Shields, Wayne Brady, Patrick Swayze, Marilu Henner, Huey Lewis, Gregory Harrison and Alan Thicke. Amy Irving and Jason Butler Harner have joined the cast of Tom Stoppard's ''Coast of Utopia,'' to be presented by Lincoln Center Theater this fall. Mr. Harner (''The Paris Letter'') will portray the novelist Ivan Turgenev, and Ms. Irving, recently seen Off Broadway in ''A Safe Harbour for Elizabeth Bishop,'' will play two roles.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Former Enron Chiefs Prepare to Testify Two of the country's best corporate salesmen are about to make the most important pitches of their lives. After 32 days of testimony from 22 witnesses, prosecutors rested their case last week in the criminal trial of Enron's former chief executives, setting the stage for the defense to take over yesterday. Now the trial has moved toward what may be the make-or-break moment for both sides: the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Skilling could take the stand as early as tomorrow. PAGE C1 Sudan Blocks U.N. Visit The government of Sudan has barred Jan Egeland, the United Nations' top emergency aid official, from making a planned visit to the western Darfur region this week, prompting Mr. Egeland to accuse the Sudanese of trying to hide the dire conditions there. PAGE A3 CBS Nears Deal With Couric A deal to recruit Katie Couric to CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the talks said. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Plea by Liberia's Ex-Leader In his first appearance before the international tribunal that indicted him on 11 counts of war crimes, Charles G. Taylor, the former Liberian president, pleaded not guilty after refusing to recognize the court's jurisdiction. PAGE A3 It's Florida, Front and Center Joakim Noah, left, of Florida outjumped Alfred Aboya of U.C.L.A. for a rebound last night, and the Gators won their first national championship in basketball with a 73-57 victory in Indianapolis. SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1 Building Organs for Life Bladders created in the laboratory from a patient's own cells and then implanted in seven people achieved good long-term results, researchers reported. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F6 Patronage in Academia A report details pervasive patronage hiring at New Jersey's state medical school, with applicants rated by political connection. PAGE B1 Success for Mets and Yanks David Wright homered, and the Mets defeated Washington, 3-2, on opening day. The Yankees, opening in Oakland, clobbered the Athletics, 15-2. SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1 The Eerie Realms of Art The work of Frank Auerbach, the veteran British painter, including ''Head of William Fever,'' above, brings haunting beauty to traditional pleasures. A review by Michael Kimmelman. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

headline: Five Artists Lauded at Kennedy Center Gala
summary: Though small-town Locust Ridge, Tenn., and big-city Detroit had little in common in 1940s America, each produced a singer who became much more than a hometown favorite. By the late 1950s and early 1960s, Tennessee's Dolly Parton had burst on the scene as a bubbly teenage country singer while Detroit's William Robinson Jr., as Smokey Robinson, had crooned his way onto the radio with a smooth style and soulful lyrics -- and nearly a half century later both are still building musical legacies. On Sunday, Ms. Parton, Mr. Robinson, the conductor Zubin Mehta, the musical theater composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the filmmaker Steven Spielberg were recognized for their lifetime contributions to the arts at the Kennedy Center Honors here.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Country Music Honors Kenny Chesney, below, was named entertainer of the year when the Academy of Country Music bestowed its awards on Tuesday night in Las Vegas, where the ''American Idol'' alumna Carrie Underwood received two prizes and Brad Paisley three, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Underwood, who won single-of-the-year honors for ''Jesus, Take the Wheel,'' which she performed on the show, was also chosen top new female vocalist. Mr. Paisley won album of the year for ''Time Well Wasted,'' and his duet with Dolly Parton on ''When I Get Where I'm Going'' took the prizes for best vocal and video event. Keith Urban was named top male vocalist for a second year, and Sara Evans, top female vocalist. The Grammy Awards will return to Sunday night next year after compiling their second-lowest television ratings ever when broadcast this year on a Wednesday. An announcement from Neil Portnow, president of the Recording Academy, and Jack Sussman, an executive vice president at CBS, said the awards ceremony, at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, would be broadcast live on CBS on Feb. 11. Libel Damages Awarded To Elton John Elton John accepted libel damages of $188,000 yesterday from The Daily Mail of London in connection with its claim of haughty behavior by Sir Elton at his annual charity ball, Reuters reported. In a brief hearing in High Court in London, his lawyer, Nigel Tait, said, ''The articles falsely alleged that Sir Elton issued a bizarre and absurd edict to guests'' not to approach him, ''thereby acting like old-fashioned royalty or some tin-pot dictator and exhibiting self-important, arrogant and rude behavior bordering on paranoia.'' He said that the assertions ''caused Sir Elton considerable embarrassment and distress,'' and that the newspaper had issued a prompt apology and agreed to substantial damages. He added that Sir Elton intended to donate the award to the Elton John AIDS Foundation. Stones Don't Roll The first 15 dates of the Rolling Stones European tour were postponed yesterday while Keith Richards recovers from a head injury, The Associated Press reported. The tour, scheduled to begin on Saturday in Barcelona, Spain, will now begin in July at a city and site to be announced in the next few days, according to LD Communications, a publicity representative for the band. Plans for a 'Code' Ban The Solomon Islands has no movie theaters, but that didn't keep its new prime minister, Manasseh Sogavare, from announcing plans to ban ''The Da Vinci Code'' from showing in movie theaters there, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Sogavare told state-run radio on Tuesday that he would seek the ban because the content of the film tended to destroy the moral fabric of Christian society, according to news media in that country in the southwest Pacific. Some 97.1 percent of the islands' 500,000 people are Christians. Footnotes Stacy Schiff has won the second annual George Washington Book Prize of $50,000 for the most important new book about the founding era. Ms. Schiff won for ''A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America'' (Thomson Gale). Her biography ''Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov)'' (Random House) won the Pulitzer Prize for biography in 2000. The jazz pianist and composer Hilton Ruiz, who turns 54 next week, was in critical condition yesterday in New Orleans, where he was found last week on Bourbon Street with an unexplained skull fracture and broken facial bones, according to Joel Chriss, his agent, The Associated Press reported.

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 9 P.M. (13, 49) CASANOVA -- If you can't lay claim to being the world's greatest lover, you may as well play one, as Peter O'Toole (left) and David Tennant do in this ''Masterpiece Theater'' production about the 18th-century Venetian lothario. They play him as an old man and a younger, more notorious rake. Laura Frazer portrays the frisky Henriette, the love of Casanova's life; Rupert Penry-Jones is Grimani, his rival; and Nina Sosanya is Bellino, a castrato whom Casanova becomes convinced has the scent of a real woman. 7 P.M. (11) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- Chris (Tyler James Williams) runs for class president and asks Greg (Vincent Martella) to be his running mate -- only to drop him like a dead fish when a poll reveals that Greg isn't popular enough. 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- A Tennessee firefighter whose house was damaged and whose wife was paralyzed during a tornado gets a new home. Alan Jackson performs. 8 P.M. (A&E) FLIP THIS HOUSE -- Tonight, the Montelongos, that house-flipping family in San Antonio, try to give back to their community by renovating five homes and helping their immigrant renters return to them with the option to buy. But can they build American dreams in only a month? 8 P.M. (E!) THS INVESTIGATES: STARVING FOR PERFECTION -- Eating disorders in Hollywood. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- Bring on the margaritas! Jimmy Buffett and Mr. Lagasse whip up an island party. 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES -- Susan (Teri Hatcher) and Ian (Dougray Scott, right, with Ms. Hatcher) go to the country for a weekend, leaving their comatose lovers behind. Meanwhile, Nora nudges her way into Tom and Lynette's life. 9 P.M. (Discovery) DISCOVERY ATLAS: ITALY REVEALED -- A year in the lives of some typical Italians and some not so, including a jockey, a free-diver, a gondolier and a few fashionable Missonis. 9 P.M. (HGTV) ENDLESS YARD SALE 2006 -- Some call it Secondhand Road. This special travels the 450-mile stretch along Route 127 from Covington, Ky., to Gadsden, Ala., where for nearly 20 years junk hunters, antiquers, treasure seekers and legitimate collectors have converged to sort through a never-ending array of castoffs. 10 P.M. (CBS) WITHOUT A TRACE -- Please hold. A 911 operator goes missing after receiving a menacing call from a man who asked for her by name. 10 P.M. (Showtime) DEXTER -- A rival serial murderer called the Ice Truck Killer lets Dexter know that his secret is not safe with him. 10 P.M. (ABC) BROTHERS & SISTERS -- William Walker's (Tom Skerritt) dirty laundry is aired in public, but Nora (Sally Field, left) makes it clear that she's not so clueless after all. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 7:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) LET'S JUST PLAY: GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE -- Four children, including Bianca Talhens (left), compare the end results of sticking with a six-month anti-obesity program of exercise and diet, while trying to get those around them to change their unhealthy ways as well. At noon today, Nickelodeon will celebrate its third annual Worldwide Day of Play by going off the air for three hours to encourage kids to move outdoors and be active. 8 P.M. (My Network TV) DESIRE -- Louis (Nate Haden), the brother who bedded the mob boss's daughter and now is running for his life, looks back at how he got to where he is. It's not pretty. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) EUKANUBA TOURNAMENT OF CHAMPIONS 2006 -- Dogs compete in agility, handling and good looks in Houston. 8 P.M. (TLC) LOTTERY CHANGED MY LIFE -- Who hasn't fantasized about what they'd do if they won a few million bucks? This documentary looks at people who have won,and how their lives have changed in the bounce of a numbered ball. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MY 100,000 LOVERS -- For some people, there's no such thing as enough. This documentary, the latest in the boundary-pushing Hot Docs series, follows three sex addicts -- a former prostitute, a middle-aged man and a young female model -- as they bed hop, with extreme results. 10 P.M. (WE) UNWRAPPING MACY'S -- Retail management doesn't begin at the counter and end at the cash register. In this new series, Macy's (right), the nation's largest department store, opens its doors for a behind-the-scenes look at operations -- from store publicists and security guards, to window dressers and balloon handlers. 10 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS MYSTERY -- What do you do when you know something that could send someone close to you to prison for life? Tonight, Jim Morel, who in 2002 was entrusted with a secret that led him to believe that his best friends had gotten away with murder, talks about the choice he made. 10 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) OUR MAN IN HAVANA (1960). In this adaptation of the Graham Greene novel, Alec Guinness plays a vacuum-cleaner salesman who goes to work for the British secret service to support his 17-year-old daughter's spending sprees. But when he fails to glean any real information, he starts making stuff up. 11:30 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE -- The cut-up of the moment, Dane Cook (left), is host of this 32nd-season opener, which finds Tina Fey gone on to other projects (''30 Rock'') and Seth Myers moved into the ''Weekend Update'' anchor's seat alongside Amy Poehler. The Killers perform from their latest album, ''Sam's Town.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
summary: 8 P.M. (13, 49) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC OPENING NIGHT GALA CONCERT -- Timpani roll, please. Lorin Maazel (right) conducts the New York Philharmonic in this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' special featuring Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture and Symphony No. 3, and Mozart's Concerto for Two Pianos in E flat, with Emanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman as the dueling -- but only onstage -- pianists. 7 P.M. (TLC) THE MESSENGERS -- The three finalists take time to reflect and fine-tune their messages. 8 P.M. (BET) ACCESS GRANTED -- Janet Jackson gets lively on the set of her video for ''So Excited.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Stormy weather? In tonight's season finale, Tommy Lee, Gilby Clarke and Jason Newsted select the lead singer of their new rock band, and send the bottom three contestants back to the safety of their garages. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- Brennan's past as a foster child impairs her judgment when a girl in foster care cries murder. 9 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC -- Debra Lafave (left), a 26-year-old former reading teacher in Florida, discusses having had a sexual relationship with a 14-year-old student, for which she is serving a sentence of house arrest. 9 P.M. (Fox) JUSTICE -- The firm shifts into protective gear when a bartender at a restaurant owned by Ron (Victor Garber) is accused of killing a runaway bride. 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE HILL -- Like they say, when the wind blows. In episode four of this six-part series, Congressman Robert Wexler, Democrat of Florida, speaks out -- loudly -- on behalf of Hurricane Katrina victims. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- Mr. Angel tries to survive being drowned alive as he is dragged through the ocean by his ankles while wearing a strait-jacket. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY -- Last week in Paris, Vincent finally got what he has long deserved -- auf'd! -- while Jeffrey became the first contestant with immunity to win a challenge. Tonight, the designers leave the fantasy world of couture behind and return to reality. New York, that is. 10 P.M. (HBO) INSIDE THE NFL -- The 30th season of football news and highlights with Cris Carter, Cris Collinsworth, Bob Costas and Dan Marino. 10 P.M. (ABC) JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE'S ALL-STAR SALUTE TO JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! -- Mr. Kimmel shows off his gift for gab in this hour-long special of highlights from the show's last three and a half years, including clips of celebrity cameos, music performances, comedy acts and segments from correspondents like Cousin Sal, Uncle Frank, Aunt Chippy and the security guard Guillermo. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Accounts
summary: Ruby Tuesday, Maryville, Tenn., the restaurant chain, chose Brouillard Communications, New York, part of the WPP Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo. Ruby Tuesday said it planned to more than double its ad spending in 2006 compared with previous levels of around $25 million a year. Thomasville Furniture, Thomasville, N.C., part of Furniture Brands International, named the Richards Group, Dallas, as the creative agency on its $30 million account. Those duties had been handled by the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
