headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Extends Letterman's Contract
summary: CBS and David Letterman have agreed on a deal that will extend his ''Late Show'' through 2010, an executive with Mr. Letterman's company, Worldwide Pants, said yesterday. The terms were not disclosed. Under his previous deal, Mr. Letterman, right, is said to have been making $31 million a year. The four-year extension, which is about the same length as Mr. Letterman's earlier agreements with CBS, which he joined in 1993, means that he will continue his show on CBS past the point where his longtime rival, Jay Leno, had agreed to step down from NBC's ''Tonight'' show. Mr. Leno is scheduled to depart in mid-2009, with Conan O'Brien signed to replace him. Mr. Letterman joined CBS only after losing out on the ''Tonight'' show position. In recent years, Mr. Leno has maintained a solid ratings edge over Mr. Letterman, but Mr. Letterman continues to take in between $70 million and $100 million a year for CBS. BILL CARTER

headline: Arts, Briefly; Without Basketball, CBS Piles Up Points
summary: After two weeks of college basketball on CBS's Thursday schedule, the network's regular lineup returned this week. Though down in comparison with its usual ratings, CBS, with its combination of ''Survivor'' (an estimated 16.54 million viewers), ''CSI'' (25.1 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (18.29 million), easily beat all the other networks. In particular, the CBS shows hindered ABC, which had gained Thursday ground against basketball. Part 2 of the special ABC series ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' featuring Hurricane Katrina wreckage, drew 7.44 million viewers. After that, ''American Inventor'' brought in 9.3 million. But NBC placed second for the night. ''Will & Grace'' got a bump from Britney Spears's appearance. Ms. Spears delivered lines like ''Whatever you've got, I'll eat it, snort it or ride it, baby'' before an audience of 9.33 million. Perhaps Michael Eisner should have invited Ms. Spears to the debut of ''Conversations With Michael Eisner'' on CNBC on Tuesday. The program drew a mere 95,000 viewers, losing an astonishing 82 percent of the audience of 518,000 who watched the ''Deal or No Deal'' repeat in the hour before it. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SACKETT, ROSS D.
summary: SACKETT--Ross D. age 77, of Fontana, WI died Thursday, August 16, 2007 at Walworth, WI. He was born March 26, 1930 in Chicago, IL to parents DeForest and Margaret (Ross) Sackett. He was united in marriage to Marvyda Wild in September of 1951 at Mattoon, IL. Some of Mr. Sackett's more recent accomplishments include Holt, Rinehart, & Winston, Inc., in New York: Engineering and Science Editor; Vice President, General Manager College Department, Executive Vice President Director, and President; CBS in New York: president, CBS Education and Publishing Group, Director CBS, and Director CBS Foundation. For Encyclopedia Britannica Education Corporation of Chicago, IL, he was President and CEO, Director and member of the executive committee of Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., member of the Editorial Board, Chairman Voting Trust, Encyclopedia Britannica Educational Corporation. Mr. Sackett was also an author, owner of several businesses, restorer of Victorian homes, and was an avid historian. He is survived by his wife Skip of 56 years, sons Scott and Stuart, daughters Cynthia and Amy, as well as 12 grandchildren and numerous friends. He was preceded in death by his son Dave. He loved books, architecture, sports and hiking.

headline: Poll Shows View of Iraq War Is Most Negative Since Start
summary: Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Sixty-one percent of Americans say the United States should have stayed out of Iraq and 76 percent say things are going badly there, including 47 percent who say things are going very badly, the poll found.

For Encyclopedia Britannica Education Corporation of Chicago, IL, he was President and CEO, Director and member of the executive committee of Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., member of the Editorial Board, Chairman Voting Trust, Encyclopedia Britannica Educational Corporation. Mr. Sackett was also an author, owner of several businesses, restorer of Victorian homes, and was an avid historian. He is survived by his wife Skip of 56 years, sons Scott and Stuart, daughters Cynthia and Amy, as well as 12 grandchildren and numerous friends. He was preceded in death by his son Dave. He loved books, architecture, sports and hiking.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHMIDT, SHIRLEY.
summary: SCHMIDT--Shirley. The family of Shirley Schmidt mourns the loss of their mother on August 27, after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Born in Brooklyn in 1929, she immigrated to Israel in 1954. 10 years later, she and her husband, Simon Schmidt, founded CBS Records/Israel. In 1977, Shirley Schmidt was named head of CBS/Israel, the first woman to lead a record company for CBS. An elegant woman, with remarkable grace and style, she was devoted to her family, her profession, and Judaism, a heritage of which she was fiercely proud. She is survived by her beloved children, Michal and Zeev Michael, a niece, nephews and countless friends. A memorial service will take place Wednesday morning, 9:30am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Burial will take place in Tel Aviv.

headline: Fox Out Front, Singing and Dancing
summary: Fox once again outpaced its competitors Wednesday night in the ratings, as its latest installment of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' delivered 7.7 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 9:30, Nielsen estimated. Following it, Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.4 million) finished second in its half hour in total viewers behind CBS's repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' (7.6 million). Fox's karaoke-theme game show did remain No. 1 in its time period among adults 18 to 49, but by only the thinnest of margins ahead of the last 30 minutes of NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' (6.3 million). At 10 NBC's ''Dateline: To Catch a Predator'' (7.2 million) finished on top in the 18-to-49 set, but CBS's ''CSI: NY'' drew the most viewers in the hour (8 million). Over all CBS, ABC and NBC ended the night in a close race for second place behind Fox. In the 18-to-49 demographic, however, NBC earned a solid No. 2 ranking ahead of third-place ABC, whose ''American Inventor'' drew 6.1 million viewers from 9 to 11.

ABC and CBS finished about even for the night as runners up. NBC ranked fourth, although its 10 p.m. offering, ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' did lead the hour over all (10.9 million). headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLTZER, ALBERT
summary: GOLTZER--Albert. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on November 10 at age 89, of its former oboist, a member beginning in 1938. He left for military service in World War II, and later played with the St. Louis and CBS Symphony Orchestras. He returned to the Philharmonic in 1955, serving until 1984 as Associate Principal Oboe alongside his brother, the late Associate Principal Bassoon Harold Goltzer. We extend our condolences to his wife, Doris, sons George and Seth, and family. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Pres./Exec.Dir. Members of the Staff

headline: Arts, Briefly; Crime Pays for CBS
summary: CBS led in the ratings on Monday as the night's most watched show, ''CSI: Miami,'' posted its second-best ratings of the season, with 19.1 million viewers at 10, according to Nielsen's estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, this crime drama with David Caruso finished just shy of the leader on Monday, NBC's ''Heroes,'' which drew 14 million total viewers at 9. Earlier in the night, CBS's comedies ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9 (16.6 million) and ''Rules of Engagement'' at 9:30 (13.9 million), led the hour in total viewers, just outperforming Fox's ''24'' (13 million) for second place behind ''Heroes'' among adults 18 to 49. NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' (17.6 million) dominated the 8 o'clock hour, ahead of Fox's ''Prison Break'' (9.6 million) and ABC's ''Wife Swap,'' which earned a season high 9 million viewers. NBC ranked second for the night, although ratings in the 18 to 49 demographic for ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' at 10 (6.4 million) declined to their lowest level ever, falling behind ABC's ''What About Brian,'' which drew a third-place 5.6 million total viewers in the hour. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Today in Business
summary: WHERE THE PROFITS ARE American companies are enjoying hefty profits overseas. Sales at the heavy-equipment maker Caterpillar, for example, have risen by a third in Europe and by 20 percent in Latin America while demand for its products wanes in the United States. STRONG EARNINGS FOR H.P.Hewlett-Packard, the world's largest technology company, reported fourth-quarter sales and earnings that exceeded its performance of a year ago and that also beat Wall Street's projections. Helped by its international presence, Hewlett-Packard seems to have escaped some of the softening demand for new technology from corporations inside the United States. Mark Hurd, above, the chief executive of H.P., said that overall, ''We're seeing fairly steady demand.'' [C1.].

headline: Arts, Briefly; Ratings Victory for 'House'
summary: Despite the absence of ''American Idol'' from its schedule, Fox remained dominant in the ratings Tuesday, as the season finale of ''House'' (starring Hugh Laurie, left) towered above the competition on the night. Nielsen estimated that 16.9 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for the conclusion of medical drama's third season, about 7 million more than the night's second most watched shows, CBS's 8 p.m. repeat of ''NCIS'' and ABC's 10 p.m. finale of ''Boston Legal.'' Both of those shows drew 9.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, Fox's ''On the Lot'' at 8 p.m. (4 million) improved slightly over the dismal ratings for its Monday installment. NBC, which broadcast three reruns of its ''Law & Order'' franchises, tied ABC for second place for the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; With 'NCIS,' CBS Wins The Numbers Game
summary: ''NCIS'' lifted CBS's average in Nielsen's estimates on Tuesday to be No. 1 in total viewers as an audience of 17.06 million watched the military crime show. The rest of the network's night was devoted to ''The People's Choice Awards,'' which drew 9.82 million viewers over its two-hour broadcast. But CBS was third in the 18-to-49 demographic; Fox and NBC tied for first place for the night. Fox was fueled by ''House'' (14.65 million). With NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' out of its way on Tuesdays at 9 p.m., having been moved to the Thursday schedule, the medical procedural delivered its best ratings since its season premiere. NBC's strong 18-to-49 ratings were attributable to ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.73 million). In its seventh season, the most successful of the three ''Law & Order'' programs easily beat both the second hour of CBS's awards special and ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (11.29 million). KATE AURTHUR

headline: For the Record
summary: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about the departure of the actor Mandy Patinkin from the CBS series ''Criminal Minds'' erroneously attributed a credit to Doug Liman, a client of the lawyer Alan Grodin, who commented on studios' reactions to actors who want to get out of their contracts. Mr. Liman was an executive producer of ''The OC,'' and directed the movies ''Swingers'' and ''Go.'' He is not the producer of ''Entourage.''

headline: Singing Show Has the Numbers
summary: ''The Singing Bee,'' NBC's new karaoke-themed game show with former 'N Sync star Joey Fatone, below, as host, delivered another strong performance on Tuesday, helping the network clear a ratings victory for the night. Nielsen estimates that the half-hour competition drew the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 and 11 million total viewers at 9:30. NBC led the rest of the night as well, with ''America's Got Talent,'' from 8 to 9:30 (10.3 million), and a ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' repeat at 10 (9.5 million). ABC finished second over all, with one of its best nights of the summer. The premiere of ''Just for Laughs,'' ABC's new hidden-camera series, ranked No. 2 in its time period with episodes at 8 (8 million) and 8:30 (8.6 million). Meanwhile, ABC's ''Primetime: Family Secrets,'' about the actor Daniel Baldwin and his struggles with addiction, also earned second place at 10 (6.9 million), ahead of CBS's ''Pirate Master'' (4.4 million). CBS and Fox, whose ''On the Lot'' earned just 2.2 million viewers at 8, ended the night in third and fourth place, respectively.

headline: New in Lower SoHo, Scaled-Down Furnishings
summary: In a city of millions, where many live in small apartments, well-priced, scaled-down home furnishings are always in demand. CB2, a store that carries Crate & Barrel's less expensive furniture and accessories, is scheduled to open its first New York location, in lower SoHo, in late October. At 8,000 square feet, the store will have merchandise for every room in the house, including tableware that looks much like Crate & Barrel's and hand-tufted wool rugs like the 5-by-8-foot Dots Rug ($299), above. Some items may look familiar to shoppers, since CB2 has had a Web site for several years, but until now there have been only two stores, both in Chicago. CB2, 451 Broadway (Grand Street), cb2.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Dancing' Shows Its Heels To the Competition
summary: Despite competition from several season finales, ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' remained the show to beat on Monday, dominating from 8 to 9:30 p.m. with an average of 19.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates. Following the dancing competition, the second-to-last installment of ABC's ''Bachelor'' attracted a solid 10.9 million viewers from 9:30 to 11, helping ABC seal its lead for the night over all. Among adults 18 to 49, however, ABC's margin of victory was slim. ''Dancing With the Stars'' shared the title of highest-rated show in the demographic with NBC's ''Heroes'' at 9 (11.4 million) and CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' finale at 10 (16.4 million). The hourlong series finale of CBS's ''King of Queens'' trailed close behind with its best ratings among adults 18 to 49 since December 2004, drawing a total of 13.5 million viewers at 9. CBS finished second for the night. Its season finale broadcasts of ''How I Met Your Mother'' at 8 (7.8 million), followed by ''Two and a Half Men'' at 8:30 (10.1 million) ranked No. 2 in their time slots among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths QUINN, NANCY DALLAS
summary: QUINN--Nancy Dallas, 81, of Larchmont, NY, passed away in her sleep December 8, 2007. She was born and raised in La Canada, California, by Frances (O'Shea), a homemaker, and Cleaves A. Jones, a decorated WWI fighter pilot and journalist for the Los Angeles Times. Nancy graduated from Immaculate Heart College with a Bachelor's Degree, and received a master's degree in English from UCLA. While at college Nancy directed several plays and enjoyed singing on state. After graduation Nancy taught at the elementary school level for several years. Nancy moved to Washington, D.C. at the age of 24 and met her soon to be husband, Robert J. Quinn, while both were working at the CBS television affiliate WTOP. Her husband, a graduate of Northwestern University, and WWII veteran stationed in England, was a television News Director at WTOP. The family moved to Larchmont in 1961. The mother of four children and one grandchild, Nancy was involved for over a decade in the activities of the local school board. An avid world traveler, she mixed her love for art with a passion for figure skating. Nancy and her husband wrote and published a book on figure skating pins in 1986. The book, ''Figure Skating Pins,'' was the definitive word on such pins. While Nancy once looked to the theater for her artistic fufillment, it was cooking sophisticated meals that finally satisfied her creative needs. She is survived by her four children: Brigid of Fairfield, Connecticut, Sean and Christopher of Larchmont, New York, and Erin and grandson Sean of Charlottesville, Virginia; and beloved bunny Roger. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont. Funeral Mass will be held Friday, 10 am at St. Augustine Church. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorn.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Net Gains for CBS
summary: Coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament propelled CBS into first place in the ratings on Sunday night, though its typical Sunday competitor, ABC, was resilient in reruns. CBS's live coverage carried over deep into the 7 p.m. hour, pushing back the network's prime-time lineup of ''60 Minutes,'' ''Amazing Race,'' ''Cold Case'' and ''Without a Trace'' by roughly 45 minutes. The overrun made Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the individual CBS shows unreliable; but CBS's overall dominance was conclusive. In second place ABC and NBC fared about evenly well. ABC's lineup of repeats, led by ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.6 million), posted a slight advantage among adults 18 to 49, while NBC edged ahead in total viewers, buoyed by ''Deal or No Deal'' at 9 (12 million). Meanwhile NBC's ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' earned a distant fourth place finish at 8 in the 18 to 49 demographic and 6.6 million total viewers. ''The Apprentice'' on NBC fared relatively better, drawing 7.2 million viewers to rank second place at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Cruises to the Top
summary: With ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Brothers & Sisters'' in repeats on Sunday, CBS won a solid victory in total viewers for the night. CBS overshadowed the latter part of the evening with ''Cold Case'' at 9, with 15.3 million viewers, and ''Without a Trace'' at 10, with 17.2 million, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 7, however, CBS got off to a sluggish start with ''60 Minutes,'' which garnered 10.1 million total viewers and a third-place finish among adults 18 to 49. ABC was second for the night in total viewers, as ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' remained dominant at 8 (13.7 million) ahead of No. 2, ''The Amazing Race: All Stars'' on CBS (10 million). Among adults 18 to 49, Fox outperformed both CBS and ABC to rank first for the night, getting a boost from an overrun of its Nascar coverage in the 7 o'clock hour. Meanwhile, two episodes of Fox's new comedy, ''The Winner,'' at 8:30 (6.8 million) and at 9:30 (5.6 million) posted ratings in line with the show's debut last week. NBC was fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: CBS Outscores Football
summary: Despite preseason football on NBC, CBS finished first in the ratings on Sunday, getting a boost from ''60 Minutes'' and ''Big Brother.'' Nielsen estimated that the CBS news magazine attracted 8.8 million viewers at 7 p.m., while ''Big Brother,'' its 8 p.m. reality show, drew 7.6 million. Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC finished on top, as the game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles delivered 8.7 million viewers after a special broadcast at 7 of MSNBC's ''Countdown with Keith Olbermann'' (4 million). CBS ranked second in that demographic, ahead of ABC's all-repeat lineup. Fox was fourth over all, as its ''Teen Choice Awards'' earned 4 million viewers from 8 to 10.

summary: 1. This stemless martini glass from CB2, the lower priced sibling of Crate and Barrel, is great for a martini because it feels good and holds plenty of vodka. But it is also pretty when filled with a tea light, flowers or festive greens; $2.50 each, from cb2.com. 2. headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Rides 'Race' To Victory in Ratings
summary: The ''Amazing Race'' teammates Eric Sanchez and Danielle Turner took home the $1 million grand prize Sunday as the 11th installment of the series came to a close, giving CBS a slight lead for the night in total viewers. Nielsen estimated that the finale drew 10.5 million viewers, ranking second in the 8 p.m. hour behind ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (11.6 million). ABC remained the night's leader among adults 18 to 49, aided by ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (16.9 million). CBS's ''Without a Trace'' (14.6 million) was the most-watched show in the 10 p.m. hour but third in the 18-to-49 demographic after both ''Brothers & Sisters'' (11.3 million) and the second half of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live in the '90s'' special, which attracted 7.9 million total viewers from 9 to 11. NBC finished about even with Fox in third for the night. On Friday, ABC's ''20/20'' received only a minor lift in its ratings despite a highly promoted interview with Jeane Palfrey, the so-called D.C. Madam. The news magazine garnered 7.9 million total viewers, third in its 10 p.m. time slot and just above its average this season (7.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Attention Paid, and Paying Off
summary: Some voters outside the early voting states have been grumbling lately about all the attention being paid to the people of Iowa and New Hampshire. But voters in those two states seem to be taking their civic duty seriously. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted Nov. 2 to 11 in Iowa found that 56 percent of caucusgoers said they had gone to a campaign event or seen a candidate in person. The exposure was even higher among Democrats, with more than 6 in 10 saying they had been to a campaign event, while fewer than half of Republicans had attended an event.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Mother's Night Out
summary: LaKisha Jones, 27, below, the single mother who rose from working at a bank in Fort Meade, Md., to the top four on this season's ''American Idol,'' was voted off the competition on Wednesday, as Fox dominated another night in the ratings. The results show at 9 p.m. drew 27.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, far exceeding the 12.8 million who tuned in to the runner-up in the hour, CBS's ''Criminal Minds.'' CBS finished second for the night, leading the 10 p.m. hour in total viewers with ''CSI: NY'' (12.7 million). ABC's ''Lost,'' despite reduced ratings, remained the winner at 10 among adults 18 to 49, and ABC finished close behind CBS in that demographic for the night. Fox's ''Bones'' finished first at 8 (10 million), outdrawing the season finale of CBS's ''Jericho'' (7.8 million), which tied with NBC's ''Thank God You're Here'' (5.3 million) for last place in the hour in the 18-to-49 set. summary: ABC's new holiday special ''Shrek the Halls,'' right, attracted 21.1 million viewers on Wednesday night at 8, Nielsen estimated, lifting the network to first place among adults 18 to 49. ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas'' at 8:30 (18.7 million), also on ABC, outpaced NBC's broadcast of ''Christmas at Rockefeller Center'' (9 million). CBS ranked second in the 18-to-49 set, and edged ABC in total viewers. CBS dominated at both 9 and 10, with ''Criminal Minds'' (16.3 million) followed by ''CSI: NY'' (14 million). ABC's ''Pushing Daisies'' earned a second place finish over all at 9 (10.2 million); NBC's ''Bionic Woman'' came in fourth over all (6 million). NBC ranked fourth over all among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Shaq's Show Falls Short
summary: The New York auditions on ''America's Got Talent'' led NBC to its fourth consecutive Tuesday-night win in the ratings, as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour competition, according to Nielsen estimates, dominating its competition from 8 to 10. After the show, which features Jerry Springer as host, a repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' carried the 10 o'clock hour as well (8.7 million). Although CBS posted a second-place finish in total viewers for the night with its lineup of ''NCIS'' at 8 (8.4 million), ''The Unit'' at 9 (5.5 million) and ''48 Hours Mystery'' at 10 (6.3 million), ABC and Fox finished ahead of CBS among adults 18 to 49. headline: Personal vs. Professional Lives
summary: Do voters base their assessments of presidential candidates on just their political records, or do they consider the candidates' personal lives as well? That seems to depend on the voter's political party, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Good News for NBC
summary: Good News for NBC ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' was the top-rated evening newscast last week, beating ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' by nearly half a million viewers, Nielsen Media Research reported. Mr. Gibson's evening newscast has attracted more total viewers than Mr. Williams's for much of the year. But NBC has bounced back in recent months, narrowly winning first place in the November sweeps. For the week, ''NBC Nightly News'' averaged 9.30 million viewers, while ''World News'' delivered 8.86 million and the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' recorded 6.82 million. In the demographic of adults 25 to 54, NBC averaged a 2.2 rating, ahead of ABC's 2.1 and CBS's 1.8. Last week's victory reflected NBC's largest lead over ABC so far this season, save for an unusual Thanksgiving ratings week. Meanwhile, two years after Howard Reig, the veteran announcer of ''NBC Nightly News,'' the newscast has a new voice for the ''from NBC News'' introduction: the actor Michael Douglas. His voice-over made its debut on Monday. BRIAN STELTER

headline: Arts, Briefly; Faltering 'Heroes'
summary: On Monday, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' seized the title as the night's highest-rated show among adults 18 to 49, while NBC's ''Heroes'' continued to falter with ratings below its prehiatus levels. Nielsen estimated that the ''CSI'' spinoff drew 17 million total viewers during the 10 p.m. hour. For the night, CBS and ABC tied for first. ABC posted an advantage in total viewers as ''Dancing With the Stars'' dominated from 8 to 9:30 (19.1 million). NBC was third among adults 18 to 49 but fourth in total viewers behind Fox. Though ''Heroes'' remained No. 1 in the highly competitive 9 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 demographic, it ranked third in total viewers in the time slot (11.1 million), just head of Fox's ''24'' (10.9 million). During the first full week of May sweeps, which ended Friday, ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' won every night in both total viewers and among adults 25 to 54. ''World News'' drew an average of 8.1 million viewers, while NBC's ''Nightly News With Brian Williams'' ranked second with 7.5 million. CBS's ''Evening News With Katie Couric'' was in third, averaging 6.1 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: News and Talk Today
summary: SATURDAY EARLY SHOW 7 A.M. (2) (N) (CC) TODAY 7 A.M. (4) Dating resolutions; a little black dress for New Year's Eve. (N) (CC)

headline: INSIDE
summary: Rocking the Gondola Alexandra Hai is the first woman authorized in Venice to operate a gondola, despite objections from some longtime gondoliers. A court recently ruled she could propel a boat around the canals, but only for guests of one hotel. PAGE A4 Pope Calls for Feeding Spirit Pope Benedict XVI, in Aparecida, Brazil, condemned capitalism and Marxism as marginalizing God and urged the Latin American clergy to feed people's spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty. PAGE A10 Violence in Karachi Increases Pressure on President A day after clashes claimed 39 lives in Karachi, analysts said the violence -- and accusations that the government had done little to stop the killings -- had put renewed pressure on President Pervez Musharraf. News reports said government troops had been in the city, but had not taken action. PAGE A3 Trying It On, Online For the first time in online retailing, the sales of clothing have overtaken those of computer hardware and software, suggesting that consumers have reached a new level of comfort. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Wall St. Journal and Its Profit Profit margins that do not equal those of other big newspapers and a poor outlook for 2007 may have opened the door for Rupert Murdoch to bid. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 CBS Still Backing Couric Eight months after Katie Couric took over ''The CBS Evening News,'' the program is back in a distant third place. But Ms. Couric says she is unfazed, and CBS is continuing to support her. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

headline: Arts, Briefly; Basketball on CBS
summary: This week, CBS's usual Thursday-night lineup -- ''Survivor,'' ''CSI'' and ''Without a Trace'' -- was benched for the first round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. In Nielsen's preliminary estimates, the prime-time games put CBS in second place among total viewers and third among adults 18 to 49, and the telecast's ratings were up from the corresponding night last year. With CBS out of the way, ABC was able to win the night, thanks to the premiere of the Simon Cowell-produced competition ''American Inventor,'' which drew an estimated audience of 14.2 million over two hours. But a typically weak showing for ''Primetime'' (8.7 million) at 10 lowered ABC's average and allowed NBC to finish a close second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox placed a distant fourth among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Its comedy ''The Loop,'' which got considerable exposure in a post-''American Idol'' slot on Wednesday, fared poorly in its regular slot on Thursday at 8:30 p.m., bringing in only 4.78 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: N.F.L. Delivers For NBC
summary: NBC scored a victory in the ratings on the last Sunday of 2007 thanks to its prime-time football coverage, which delivered about 14 million viewers, according to Nielsen's overnight estimates. CBS finished second and Fox finished third, with both networks benefiting from overruns of their own football coverage from the afternoon that extended well into the 7 p.m. hour. Following CBS's football overrun of approximately 45 minutes, the network broadcast new episodes of ''60 Minutes'' and ''The Amazing Race,'' giving it an average of 11 million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m. ABC tied Fox for third on the night in total viewers while finishing a distant fourth among adults 18 to 49. ABC's broadcast of the movie ''The Sound of Music'' drew 7.7 million viewers from 7 to 11 p.m.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Football Propels CBS
summary: In the preliminary Nielsen estimates for Sunday, ABC was No. 1 in key ratings measures, as it usually is. But CBS benefited from a spillover of the football playoffs into prime time, which lifted the network's household ratings to the top spot for the night. Its ''60 Minutes,'' which featured a segment about the Olympian Bode Miller and the problems of drunken skiing, drew high ratings, as did a ''Cold Case'' episode that used the music of Bruce Springsteen, but the final numbers for both shows were delayed because of the football game's overrun. ABC's ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' (10.27 million), ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' (17.45 million), ''Desperate Housewives'' (23.67 million) and a ''Grey's Anatomy'' clip show (16.41 million) averaged out to squeak by CBS in total viewers, and win more convincingly in the 18-to-49 demographic. The first new ''Housewives'' in more than a month -- in which Gabrielle (Eva Longoria) kissed the husband (Doug Savant) of Lynette (Felicity Huffman), inspiring a jealousy plot -- delivered its lowest ratings for an original episode of the season, despite dominating the 9 p.m. hour. KATE AURTHUR

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: OIL PROGRAM'S PROBLEMS The Interior Department's program to collect billions of dollars annually from oil and gas companies that drill on federal lands is plagued with mismanagement, ethical lapses and fears of retaliation against whistle-blowers, the department's independent investigator has concluded. G.M. STRIKE ENTERS THIRD DAY The strike by 73,000 union members at General Motors could end as suddenly as it began, but so far, neither side is showing any sign of closing what appears to be a big gap between their demands. [C1.]

headline: An Unfamiliar Face
summary: And speaking of Mr. Thompson, as he prepares to announce formally his candidacy for the Republican nomination this week, polls show that he faces an electorate broadly unfamiliar with him (his stint on ''Law & Order'' notwithstanding). One in four Republican primary voters expressed a favorable view of Mr. Thompson in a CBS News poll last month, while two-thirds said they had not yet formed an opinion of him at all.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'American Idol' Does Well By Doing Good
summary: Boasting celebrity guests like Bono, Il Divo and Jack Black, Day 2 of the ''Idol Gives Back'' charity edition of ''American Idol'' was commanding as usual in the ratings. Fox garnered more viewers than ABC, NBC, CBS and the CW combined as the two-hour telethon attracted an average of 26.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., increasing in every half hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. In a twist, the ''Idol'' host Ryan Seacrest announced that the night's generosity would extend to the contestants: the six remaining finalists were granted a one-week reprieve. However, the 70 million votes cast this week will be counted in next week's scoring when two contestants will face elimination. Mr. Seacrest also announced that, as of Wednesday night, the special had already raised $30 million. In the 10 p.m. hour, ABC's ''Lost'' (11.6 million) edged out CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (11.2 million). Although ratings for ''Lost'' remain down, it still posted the night's second-highest numbers among adults 18 to 49, propelling ABC to second place for the night in that demographic, even as CBS drew more total viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Holds Friday
summary: New entries on the prime-time schedule did not upset CBS's dominance in the ratings on Friday night. CBS's ''Ghost Whisperer'' (11.35 million), ''Close to Home'' (11.47 million) and ''Numbers'' (13.59 million), starring Rob Morrow, left, won every hour in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. But ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' (12.88 million) -- in which viewers bade goodbye to ESPN's Kenny Mayne, a hilariously bad dancer -- and ''In Justice'' (9.17 million) made it closer than usual. The two-hour debut of NBC's ''Book of Daniel,'' featuring Aidan Quinn as a put-upon, Vicodin-popping Episcopal minister, attracted an audience of 9.08 million in the first hour, and 8.86 million in the second. NBC placed third for the night. On Wednesday, the fashion reality show ''Project Runway'' drew the best ratings of the season for Bravo, with 1.45 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Polling Young Americans
summary: A 20-year-old student discusses his responses to a CBS/New York Times/MTV poll.

headline: Comics Make NBC Smile
summary: Delivering a six-month high for NBC in the Wednesday 9 p.m. time slot, ''Last Comic Standing'' lifted the network to a strong second-place finish that night, behind Fox. According to Nielsen's estimates, this competition of comedians drew 6.8 million viewers and NBC's best numbers since late January for that hour among adults 18 to 49. It was not enough, however, to outpace the last 30 minutes of Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' which averaged 8.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. During the rest of the hour, however, ''Last Comic Standing'' tied Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.8 million) in the 18-to-49 demographic. NBC's ''Dateline'' (7.2 million) led in that demographic at 10, ahead of CBS's ''CSI: NY'' repeat (8.2 million). Although a distant third in the 18-to-49 set for the night, CBS finished close behind second-place NBC in total viewers. ABC, despite broadcasts of the ''American Inventor'' finale at 8 (5.3 million) and a new episode of ''The Nine'' at 10 (3.3 million), ranked fourth over all.

headline: Kranks Brighten Fox's Night
summary: Fox's broadcast of the movie ''Christmas With the Kranks'' attracted 7.2 million viewers on Wednesday, Nielsens estimated, a relatively small audience but enough to lead the other networks among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked second in that demographic while edging past Fox in total viewers. NBC got a boost from repeats of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' at 9 p.m. (7.8 million) and 10 (8.7 million). CBS finished third as its broadcast of the ''30th Annual Kennedy Center Honors'' from 9 to 11 p.m. drew 6.2 million viewers, down sharply from the 10 million who tuned in a year ago. Ratings for the gala paled in comparison to CBS's 8 p.m. rerun of ''Criminal Minds'' (9.1 million). ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

headline: HOLLYWOOD AND POLITICS
summary: Despite their history with Ronald Reagan's presidency, Republican voters are much more likely than their Democratic counterparts to say celebrities should stay out of politics, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The poll found that 71 percent of Republican voters said celebrities should not be involved in politics, while just 31 percent of Democratic voters and 43 percent of independent voters agreed. Oprah Winfrey may be backing Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, but the poll suggests that such endorsements could have limited pull, since most voters say a celebrity's backing would not matter to their vote. And 78 percent of voters say most people they know would not be influenced by a celebrity's endorsement of a candidate.

headline: POLLS
summary: Members of current military families are critical of President Bush's handling of Iraq and say his administration misled the country into war, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Two-thirds of the military families polled disapprove of how Mr. Bush is handling the situation in Iraq. And 56 percent said members of his administration had misled the public when making its case for the war.

headline: Absent Anchor, NBC Sinks
summary: With the July 4 holiday last week, NBC's evening news broadcast sank to an all-time ratings low, though it still ranked solidly second, ahead of CBS. According to Nielsen Media Research, NBC's ''Nightly News With Brian Williams'' drew an average of 6.8 million viewers last week as Mr. Williams, the newscast's regular anchor, vacationed Wednesday through Friday. ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson,'' who did not go on leave, remained No. 1 for its 11th consecutive week, attracting 7.5 million viewers. CBS's ''Evening News With Katie Couric'' finished third over all (5.6 million). Among adults 25 to 54, the demographic most sought after by advertisers, all three evening newscasts posted their lowest numbers since Nielsen began tracking them in 1987.

headline: Dancing Away With the Night
summary: Fox rode the ''So You Think You Can Dance'' finale to victory Wednesday night. According to Nielsen's estimates, the two-hour show delivered an average of 8.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., outpacing all other programming. NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' at 9 (5.7 million) was the runner-up among adults 18 to 49, as NBC ranked No. 2 for the night in that demographic. CBS finished No. 2 in total viewers. Its repeat of ''CSI: NY'' at 10 earned the second-largest audience of the night (8.1 million), and its new game show, ''Power of 10,'' fared well at 8 (7.7 million). ABC came in fourth over all; the debut of its five-part ''Nascar in Primetime'' drew just 3.2 million viewers in the 10 p.m. hour.

headline: Polling the Primary Voters
summary: As the 2008 presidential nominating contests approach, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll reveals what voters are looking for in their candidates.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'The Sopranos' Goes Out With a Ratings Bang
summary: The series finale of ''The Sopranos'' on Sunday did not break any ratings records for premium-channel HBO, but its final audience tally eclipsed much of network television's for last week. According to Nielsen Media Research, 11.9 million viewers tuned in to watch the 9 p.m. conclusion of ''The Sopranos,'' making it the most watched episode since the 2004 debut of Season 5 (12.1 million). Only NBC's Tuesday premiere of ''America's Got Talent'' drew more viewers (13 million) last week. The ambiguous ending of the ''Sopranos'' story, however, left some viewers searching for answers on the Internet. According to Yahoo! Buzz, ''The Sopranos'' was the No. 1 searched person or thing online on Sunday and Monday. Nielsen estimated that CBS and Fox shared the lead on Monday. CBS finished first in total viewers, aided by repeats of ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9 (9.3 million) and ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (9.2 million). Fox posted a lead among adults 18 to 49, as the second installment of ''Hell's Kitchen'' at 9 outperformed its week-ago premiere. The episode attracted 8.8 million total viewers and the night's highest numbers in the 18-to-49 demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: POLLS
summary: Despite recent incidents involving Republican politicians, Democrats in Washington have not seized the advantage on the issue of ethics. Thirty-three percent of Americans in a recent New York Times/CBS News poll said the Democratic party had higher ethical standards, while about as many, 31 percent, said so of the Republican party.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | DEC. 23--DEC. 29
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: Fox Sings and Dances
summary: With a second consecutive night of singing and dancing reality shows, Fox finished No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday. The network began the night in the lead, as an hourlong ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' drew 8.5 million viewers at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Following it at 9, Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' results edition (9.2 million) posted the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, although a repeat of CBS's ''CSI'' edged ahead in total viewers (9.3 million). CBS ranked second over all, winning at 10 with ''Shark'' (8.2 million) and earning a solid second place at 8 with ''Big Brother'' (7.1 million). NBC finished third for the night. ABC trailed, in fourth place. Earlier in the week, two new cable series made notable debuts. On Tuesday at 10, FX's ''Damages,'' with Glenn Close, delivered 3.7 million viewers, making it the night's most watched program on basic cable. And on Monday, TNT's ''Saving Grace,'' with Holly Hunter, attracted 6.4 million total viewers, more than any other new series premiere on basic cable this year. Boosting the 10 p.m. show, TNT's 9 p.m. offering, ''The Closer,'' drew 7.3 million viewers.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: CBS Chairman Rebukes Dan Rather Dan Rather was branded as a ''sexist'' yesterday by Leslie Moonves, the chairman of CBS, for comments critical of Katie Couric, his successor as the anchor of ''CBS Evening News.'' The uproar began on Monday when Mr. Rather, speaking on MSNBC by telephone, said CBS had erred in handling the evening news broadcast by ''dumbing it down, tarting it up'' and emphasizing celebrities over war coverage in ''hopes of attracting a younger audience,'' The Associated Press reported. Although he referred to Ms. Couric as a ''nice person,'' he said ''the mistake was to try to bring the 'Today' show ethos to the 'Evening News.' '' Ms. Couric, in nine months as the first woman to anchor a network news broadcast on her own, has been unable to lift ''CBS Evening News'' out of last place among the evening news programs. ''Let's give her a break,'' Mr. Moonves said at an appearance in New York where he was asked about Mr. Rather's remarks and called them ''sexist.'' He said he ''absolutely'' had confidence in Ms. Couric and the course of CBS's evening news and added that it was imperative to reach younger audiences. Unless news programs find viewers younger than 60, he said, ''the evening news will die.'' Secret Clapton Concert In the Works Eric Clapton is to be paid $1.5 million to perform in late July at a private concert organized by a hedge-fund executive at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Conn., according to an article to be published today by The Fairfield County Weekly. The account says that under terms of the agreement between the Creative Artists Agency, a promoter and the executive, ''no public press or announcement pre or post event is permitted.'' The agreement says the performance, to benefit the China Care Foundation, is expected to be attended by ''350 invitation-only guests.'' The host was identified as Raymond T. Dalio, the founder, president and chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates, which has more than $30 billion in hedge-fund assets. Besides Mr. Clapton's fee for a 60- to 70-minute show, the agreement calls for a $1 million donation to ''a charity of Mr. Clapton's choice to be paid the night of the show.'' The weekly reports that neither Mr. Dalio nor agents at Creative Artists Agency responded to calls for comment. Nigerian Author Wins Major Award Chinua Achebe, below, of Nigeria, the Charles P. Stevenson Jr. Professor of Languages and Literature at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., was named the winner yesterday of the $118,500 (£60,000) Man Booker International Prize. The honor is awarded once every two years to a living author for a body of work that has contributed to international fiction. Nadine Gordimer, one of three members of the judging panel that chose Mr. Achebe, said his ''early work made him the father of modern African literature as an integral part of world literature.'' She added, ''He has gone on to achieve what one of his characters brilliantly defines as the writer's purpose: 'a new-found utterance' for the capture of life's complexity.'' Best known for his novels ''Things Fall Apart'' (1958) and ''Anthills of the Savannah'' (1988), Mr. Achebe, 76, will receive his prize and a trophy at a ceremony on June 28 at Christ Church in Oxford, England. Disney Goes Bollywood Walt Disney Studios and the Indian company Yash Raj Films entered an agreement yesterday in Mumbai to make animated films using the voices of Bollywood stars, Agence France-Presse reported. In a statement, the companies said the stars Saif Ali Khan and Kareena Kapoor would provide the voices for the first one, ''Roadside Romeo,'' a fully animated Hindi-language movie including song, dance and action sequences and scheduled for release next year. Ancient Temple Saved From Modern Builders The Italian police have saved an ancient Greek temple from burial beneath the foundations of a resort hotel under construction, The Associated Press reported; the building crew had dumped or looted artifacts and was beginning to pour concrete over the ruins. Members of the art squad of the Carabinieri paramilitary police said more than 50 artifacts, including columns and mosaics, had been excavated from the site, above, near Crotone in southern Calabria, to decorate a nearby hotel complex. Other pieces had been put in a dump to be reused as construction material. Gen. Giovanni Nistri, commander of the art squad, said further construction ''would have been the final tombstone for this temple.'' Farm Aid Comes To New York New York City will have a rural touch when Randalls Island becomes the site of a Farm Aid concert to benefit family farms, Reuters reported. Willie Nelson announced on Monday that ''Farm Aid 2007: A Homegrown Festival'' will take place on the island in the East River on Sept. 9. ''Farm Aid is coming to New York because your enthusiasm for family-farm food is keeping family farms on the land,'' said Mr. Nelson, who will perform with Farm Aid board members Dave Matthews, John Mellencamp and Neil Young. Since it was organized in 1985 Farm Aid has raised more than $30 million. The Randalls Island concert will be the first Farm Aid concert in New York. Footnotes The August Wilson play ''Radio Golf'' will close on July 1 after 64 performances and 17 previews at the Cort Theater on Broadway. The Paris Review yesterday announced the appointment of Matt Weiland as deputy editor, a new position. The announcement said the appointment reflected the magazine's growth under the editorship of Philip Gourevitch, who assumed the post in 2005. Mr. Weiland has been the deputy editor of Granta for four years.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Lots of Laughs for CBS
summary: On Monday, one day after the Super Bowl, CBS's comedies matched or surpassed their season's best ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, CBS's ''How I Met Your Mother'' drew a season high of 10.8 million viewers at 8 p.m., and ''The Class'' at 8:30 delivered 9.7 million total viewers, posting its best ratings among adults 18 to 49 since its September premiere. The debut of ''Rules of Engagement,'' CBS's 9:30 comedy with David Spade, attracted 14.9 million viewers, retaining a large portion of the season-high 17.8 million viewers who tuned in at 9 for ''Two and a Half Men.'' Together, the CBS comedies were the second-most-watched programs in the 8 p.m. hour and the most watched during the 9 p.m. hour, but NBC's ''Heroes,'' which drew 14.6 million total viewers at 9, overshadowed them among adults 18 to 49. CBS won the night, as ''CSI: Miami'' dominated the 10 p.m. hour with 18.2 million viewers, the night's most watched show. NBC was No. 2 in both total viewers and the 18 to 49 demographic, buoyed by ''Deal or No Deal'' at 8 (17.3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Provides an Eyeful
summary: Aided by ''Cold Case'' and ''60 Minutes,'' CBS won the title of most watched network on Sunday, but ABC surged ahead for the night among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Cold Case'' drew the night's largest audience with 13.1 million viewers, dominating the 10 p.m. hour. CBS's veteran newsmagazine ''60 Minutes'' also won the 7 p.m. hour with 11.4 million viewers, but an extended double episode of CBS's ''Amazing Race: All Stars'' averaged 9 million viewers, finishing third in both the 8 and 9 o'clock hours. Among adults 18 to 49, ABC remained on top with its lineup of an ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' rerun at 8 (9.8 million), followed by a ''Desperate Housewives'' clip show at 9 (9.8 million) and a new episode of ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (9.1 million). Fox ranked third in the 18-to-49 demographic although new episodes of ''King of the Hill'' at 8:30 (6.3 million) and ''American Dad'' at 9:30 (5.9 million) finished first in their time slots among adults 18 to 34. NBC was fourth among those 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Summertime TV
summary: The summer television season arrived Thursday with the third-season debut of Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance.'' Nielsen estimated that the 90-minute premiere drew an average of 9.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., giving Fox a victory for the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox's ratings dipped at 9:30, however, when its new series, ''On the Lot,'' attracted only 5.2 million viewers. CBS beat out Fox in total viewers, taking the 9 p.m. hour over all with a repeat of ''CSI'' (13.8 million). CBS finished second in the 18-to-49 demographic, ahead of NBC and ABC, which tied for third. The first of six remaining episodes of NBC's canceled ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' drew just 3.9 million viewers at 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Night
summary: On the last official Thursday of the 2006-7 television season, ABC cemented its place as the No. 1 network on the night in the 18-to-49 demographic, a title it has not held in three decades. A 75-minute ''Grey's Anatomy'' finale lifted the network to its fourth Thursday win in the demographic for the May sweeps period. CBS ended the night slightly ahead in total viewers, Nielsen estimated. Opposite the first hour of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which attracted 21.5 million viewers in the 9 o'clock hour, CBS's ''CSI'' finale ranked second, with 20.2 million viewers. NBC came in third over all, and Fox fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: For the Record
summary: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about the departure of the actor Mandy Patinkin from the CBS series ''Criminal Minds'' erroneously attributed a credit to Doug Liman, a client of the lawyer Alan Grodin, who commented on studios' reactions to actors who want to get out of their contracts. Mr. Liman was an executive producer of ''The OC,'' and directed the movies ''Swingers'' and ''Go.'' He is not the producer of ''Entourage.''

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD | Nov. 25--Dec. 1
summary: Television Mike Hale

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Warren, June Peel Willock
summary: WARREN--June Peel Willock, actress and wife of the late William C. Warren, Dean of Columbia Law School, died September 5. The Columbia Law School community mourns her passing. Born in England, she came to the U.S. in 1945 after marrying William Warren. She worked in radio at CBS and in early live TV including "The Jackie Gleason Show." With Dean Warren, she spurred development and raised money for scholarships and a new Columbia Law School building, William and June Warren Hall, dedicated to them in 1998. A Columbia Law School scholarship is also given in her name. She is survived by her sons Robert P. Warren and William L. Warren; a daughter, Larissa W. Gibson and her husband, W. David; and four grandchildren, Robin P.P. Warren, Linneen C. Warren, Leslie C. Gibson and Kathleen J. Gibson. Dean Warren died in 2000. A memorial service will be held September 30, 2007, 3:00pm, at the West Side Presbyterian Church, Monroe Ave., Ridgewood, NJ. Dean David M. Schizer, Lucy G. Moses, Professor of Law Columbia Law School

headline: Arts, Briefly; Jennifer Lopez on 'Idol'
summary: Fox coasted to another easy victory in the ratings on Tuesday as the Top 8 ''American Idol'' contestants faced off under the mentorship of Jennifer Lopez, below, in a night of Latin-themed performances. According to Nielsen's estimates, the 8 p.m. show had 26 million viewers, considerably outperforming CBS's ''NCIS,'' which had 14.4 million viewers and ranked second for the hour. At 9, the former talk show host Leeza Gibbons became the third star eliminated from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' as Tuesday's results show attracted 17 million viewers, for a second-place finish behind Fox's ''House'' (21.6 million). For the night, CBS and ABC finished about even over all as distant runners-up to Fox. At 10, ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (10.5 million) edged ahead of a repeat of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (10 million). NBC ranked fourth over all. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Many Polls, Little Interest
summary: Who's up? Who's down? It seems as though a new poll on the presidential race appears every day. But are the voters paying any attention to these surveys? Most say no. In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, 45 percent said they were aware of how candidates for president are doing in the opinion polls; 54 percent said they were not.

headline: CBS Logo Display
summary: A new motion-activated billboard in the 14th Street-Union Square subway station flashes the CBS logo over passers-by.

headline: Dancing To the Top
summary: The results may have been bad for Sara VonGillern and Dominic Sandoval, who were voted off ''So You Think You Can Dance'' on Thursday, but the ratings were a boon for Fox. According to Nielsen's estimates, the show drew 9.6 million viewers at 9 p.m., outperforming all other shows that night -- including a ''CSI'' repeat on CBS, also at 9 (9 million) -- in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.9 million) earned Thursday's second-highest ratings among adults in that demographic. It led the 8 o'clock hour, ahead of CBS's ''Big Brother'' (7.1 million). CBS ranked No. 2 for the night after Fox, winning at 10 with a rerun of ''Without a Trace'' (9 million), which easily outdrew ABC's ''Men in Trees'' (3.6 million) and NBC's ''ER'' repeat (2.8 million). ABC and NBC finished about even, in third place over all.

headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS and ABC Share The Ratings Roost
summary: CBS and ABC remained dominant Sunday night, with CBS winning in total viewers and ABC leading in the prized 18-to-49 demographic, according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC got a boost, as usual, at 9 p.m. from ''Desperate Housewives,'' in which Mike (James Denton) awoke from his coma to find he suffered from amnesia. ''Desperate Housewives'' (20 million) outstripped CBS's ''Cold Case'' (14 million), but ratings for the ABC series have declined now for three consecutive weeks since its premiere a month ago. At 10, ABC's ''Brothers and Sisters'' finished No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, but its ratings (12 million) also continued to slide. Meanwhile, CBS's 10 p.m. competitor, ''Without a Trace,'' drew more total viewers (13.9 million). Faring well earlier in the night, CBS's ''60 Minutes'' (16.2 million) featured the Duke University lacrosse students accused of rape, as well as an interview with the former White House insider David Kuo. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Cold Case' Carries the Night for CBS
summary: With ABC showing repeats, CBS easily drew the most viewers in every hour on Sunday night, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Cold Case,'' the night's most-watched program, garnered 15.1 million viewers at 8 p.m. It was preceded by ''60 Minutes'' at 7 (14.3 million), and followed by the Hallmark Hall of Fame movie ''The Valley of Light,'' with Chris Klein, which attracted 14.7 million viewers from 9 to 11. ABC won the night among adults 18 to 49 and finished second in total viewers. NBC ranked third, as the first live edition of ''Grease: You're the One That I Want'' posted the series's lowest rating yet, averaging 7.3 million viewers from 7 to 9 p.m. Following it ''The Apprentice'' improved over its week-ago performance, drawing 8.4 million viewers and finishing No. 2 in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Fox Takes Tuesday
summary: In an awkward night of television, as network news specials about the shootings at Virginia Polytechnic Institute bumped up against country music performances on ''American Idol,'' Fox eclipsed all its rivals in the ratings Tuesday. According to Nielsen estimates, 25.9 million viewers tuned in for the music competition at 8 p.m. NBC's ''Dateline,'' with Stone Phillips reporting from Blacksburg, Va., ranked fourth in the same hour with 5.1 million viewers. ABC and CBS fared better with their specials at 10. ABC's ''Primetime,'' with Diane Sawyer, led the hour over all with 11.3 million viewers, while CBS's ''48 Hours,'' which featured Katie Couric as anchor, finished third (6.5 million) behind a repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.3 million). ABC posted a solid second place for the night with a ''Dancing With the Stars'' recap show at 8 (6.9 million) followed by results show at 9 (16.2 million). Fox's ''House,'' however, remained No. 1 in the 9 p.m. hour (22.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: What's On Tonight
summary: 8 P.M. (22, 26) MISSING IN MIG ALLEY During the Korean War, American F-86 Sabers and Soviet MIG-15s faced off over North Korean skies in an area that came to be known as ''MIG Alley.'' This ''Nova'' special examines those planes' technologies and aerial tactics as well as the fate of downed pilots, many of whom disappeared, including two dozen Saber pilots whose whereabouts were never accounted for. (Above, the writer Ralph Wetterhahn with a MIG-15.) 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS When a Muslim marine is found dead near a mosque that is suspected of terrorist recruitment by the F.B.I., Ducky (David McCallum) refuses to perform an autopsy in deference to the family's religious beliefs.

headline: CBS Buying Wallstrip, a Web Finance Site
summary: CBS has bought Wallstrip, an online company whose Web site mixes finance with humor, to add to its daily financial news Web broadcast. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. Wallstrip, which also produces blogs about financial news, will retain a separate identity, CBS said in a statement yesterday. The network will work with the creators of Wallstrip.com to develop Internet programs and information that can be sent to mobile phones and other devices.

headline: The Many Shades Of White China
summary: A TABLE set with white dinnerware is anything but bland. A quick glance at a selection of white china shows that many tones and hues lay claim to that color, and of course shapes can vary greatly, too. For newlyweds who do not have the space to store more than one set of dishes, there are enough patterns to choose from for casual or formal entertaining. And colorful table linens will give the right visual jolt for those who don't want a monochromatic setting. 1. TEA AND COOKIES From rear: A dessert plate with your family crest, $75 (as shown), and a teapot with your monogram, $285 (as shown), are from a custom china service; 75-piece minimum (there is an additional $750 set-up fee), from the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, or (866) 755-9079. A monogrammed teacup in the Urania pattern is from a five-piece place setting, $280 (monogram is extra), from www.mossonline.com or (866) 888-6677. An 8-inch plate in the Words pattern, $18, is from www.clio-home.com, or (212) 966-8991.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Crime Pays for CBS
summary: For a second consecutive Wednesday, the CBS lineup led over all, but ABC proved a formidable challenger. CBS drew its largest audiences with a double dose of crime dramas: ''Criminal Minds'' attracted 16.5 million viewers at 9 p.m., and ''CSI: NY'' pulled in 16.1 million at 10, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 8 p.m. Harry Hamlin's departure from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' put ABC on top for the hour, but the second installment of CBS's ''Jericho'' (11.4 million) fared well, improving over its premiere among viewers 18 to 49. At 9 and 10, ABC finished solidly in second with a clip show recapping the last two seasons of ''Lost'' (9.5 million), and a Barbara Walters ''20/20'' exclusive with Terri Irwin, the widow of Steve Irwin, the Crocodile Hunter (13.3 million). Fox and NBC trailed considerably behind for the night. ''Bones'' (7.7 million) and ''Justice'' (7.1 million) were up from a week ago on Fox, while NBC's two-hour ''Biggest Loser'' (7 million) and ''Kidnapped'' (6.3 million) continued to struggle. On the CW, a positive Week 2 for ''America's Next Top Model'' (4.8 million) -- first among adults 18 to 34 for the 8 p.m. hour -- gave a boost to the fourth-season premiere of ''One Tree Hill'' (3.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; CBS Takes Tuesday Night
summary: With ''Dancing With the Stars'' now off ABC's schedule, CBS's ''NCIS'' drew a season high 17 million viewers Tuesday at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, putting CBS on top in total viewers for the night. Among adults 18 to 49, ''NCIS'' was second in its hour. ABC eked out a victory in that category with its telecast of the ''American Music Awards,'' which averaged 10.9 million viewers from 8 to 11. Fox also finished ahead of CBS in the 18-to-49 demographic for the night, primarily on the strength of its hit ''House'' (15.1 million) at 9. NBC ranked fourth for the night. Its Tony Bennett special at 8 drew 6.4 million viewers, but among adults 18 to 49, the special finished sixth behind both Fox's ''Standoff'' (4.9 million) and the CW's ''Gilmore Girls'' (4.3 million). NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (14.2 million) easily led at 10 o'clock, as Connie Nielsen made her departure from the cast. Meanwhile, CBS's new drama in the hour, ''3 Lbs'' (9.2 million), posted a slight decline from its third place premiere last week. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Where's the Gruel?
summary: Whatever vulnerability Mike Huckabee has with voters who remain wary of his record as governor of Arkansas he tried to dispel Friday with tough talk about terrorism suspects being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Mr. Huckabee, according to CBS News, said how ''disappointing'' it was to learn during a visit he made to Guantánamo that meals for military personnel cost an average $1.60 while the detainees' Halal meals cost more than $4 each.

headline: Singing And Dancing Make Fox's Night
summary: The combination of Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' and ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' made the network No. 1 in the ratings Wednesday. According to Nielsen's estimates, the dancing competition drew 8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. and the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. The karaoke game show ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' declined slightly from its premiere a week ago, earning 7.4 million viewers at 9:30. Although it finished No. 1 in its time slot in the 18 to 49 demographic, it fell short of CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' repeat in total viewers (7.6 million). CBS ended the night as the second most watched network over all behind Fox but ahead of NBC and ABC. NBC ranked No. 2 among adults 18 to 49, while CBS and ABC tied for third. That dynamic was apparent during the 10 o'clock hour, which CBS's ''CSI: NY'' led in total viewers (8.6 million) even as NBC's ''Dateline'' posted higher ratings in the 18 to 49 set. ABC's ''Traveler'' was last with 3.8 million viewers.

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Survivor' Carries CBS To Victory
summary: Yul Kwon, below, a 31-year-old consultant from California, became the 13th ''Survivor'' champion on Sunday, as the two-hour conclusion of the ''Cook Islands'' edition, which garnered headlines for forming teams along racial lines, made CBS No. 1 in the ratings for the night. But the 8 p.m. finale, which attracted 16.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, was down 8 percent from last spring's ''Survivor: Panama'' finale and down 26 percent from last fall's ''Survivor: Guatemala'' finale. Among adults 18 to 49, Fox finished in second place for the night, just ahead of NBC, whose ''Sunday Night Football'' coverage of the Kansas City Chiefs and San Diego Chargers game drew roughly 13 million viewers. Aided by an overrun of Fox's afternoon football coverage, its comedy line-up of ''The Simpsons'' at 8 (9 million), ''American Dad'' at 8:30 (7.5 million), ''Family Guy'' at 9 (8.8 million) and a ''Family Guy'' repeat at 9:30 (7.8 million) won each half hour among adults 18 to 34. ABC ranked second for the night in total viewers. Its broadcast of the Tim Allen movie ''The Santa Clause 2,'' averaged 13.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Turns Charitable
summary: Tuesday's first-ever charity telethon edition of ''American Idol,'' which Fox called ''Idol Gives Back,'' held up well in the ratings, drawing 25.7 million viewers, just shy of the 26.6 million who tuned in a week ago. according to Nielsen's estimates. The first hour of the two-day special, which hopes to raise money and awareness in the fight against global poverty, featured what Fox was calling ''life anthem'' performances by the six remaining contestants. Fox easily won the night's ratings over all, dominating the 9 p.m. hour after ''Idol'' with ''House'' (21.3 million). ABC and CBS were about even in second place. ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show fared solidly at 9 (16.4 million), while CBS posted up well opposite ''Idol'' at 8 with ''NCIS'' (14.1 million). The CW tied NBC, which broadcast mostly repeats, for fourth place for the night among adults 18 to 49. The CW's ''Gilmore Girls'' at 8 drew 3.7 million viewers, followed by the finale of ''Pussycat Dolls Presents: The Search for the Next Doll'' at 9 (3.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: OPEC TO RAISE PRODUCTION OPEC sought to regain its authority over volatile oil markets, agreeing to increase production by 500,000 barrels a day, but prices still rose to a record.

headline: Environment Poll
summary: Marjorie Connelly reports on a nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll showing concern about global environmental problems.

headline: Arts, Briefly; ABC Has a Nice Night
summary: ABC posted a considerable lead in the ratings Sunday, significantly overshadowing Fox's two-hour premiere of ''Drive'' and winning every hour of the night in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' garnered the night's highest ratings, earning 16.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. It followed new episodes of ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' at 7 (8.6 million) and ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.2 million). During the 10 p.m. hour, ABC's ''Brothers & Sisters'' (11.5 million) remained on top among adults 18 to 49, but CBS's ''Without a Trace'' led the hour in total viewers (14.3 million). For the night, CBS actually had slightly more total viewers over all, despite ABC's advantage in the 18-to-49 demographic. Meanwhile, ''Drive'' drew just 6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Fox ranked third for the night in the 18-to-49 demographic, ahead of NBC. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Bloodless Victory for CBS On Thursday Night
summary: CBS's command of Thursday nights continued this week, as the other networks barely put up a fight in these doldrums leading up to the May sweeps period. The combination of ''Survivor'' (16.3 million), a ''CSI'' rerun (18.74 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (16.66 million) won the night for CBS in Nielsen's estimates among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49. ABC was a far-off No. 2 in total viewers. At 9 p.m. its ''American Inventor,'' the Simon Cowell-produced reality competition, drew 8.41 million. But after that, ''Commander in Chief,'' the presidency drama starring Geena Davis, fared even worse than it did last week, when it returned from a hiatus. It brought in 7.68 million viewers, and ranked last for the hour among 18-to-49 year-olds, even though NBC's ''ER'' (6.21 million) was a repeat. On cable the April 12 finale of FX's ''Black. White.'' fizzled. The much-hyped reality series, in which two families wore makeup to change their racial appearances, attracted only 926,000 viewers for its last episode, though nearly 4 million watched its premiere in March. KATE AURTHUR

headline: News and Talk Today
summary: CBS NEWS SUNDAY MORNING 9 A.M. (2) The science of dreams; the career of Neil Sedaka; Anthony Hopkins discusses his life and his latest film; a Rhode Island pumpkin-growing competition. (N) (CC) TODAY 9 A.M. (4) What to do when you are miserable at work; dressing pets for Halloween. (N) (CC)

headline: Arts, Briefly; Missing 'Ghost' Haunts CBS
summary: NBC managed to win Friday night's race in Nielsen's estimates as the absence of CBS's ''Ghost Whisperer,'' which has concluded for the season, hurt that network's average. In its place was a special, ''Keith Barry: Extraordinary,'' but its star, the magician Mr. Barry, right, managed to bewitch a mere 5.89 million viewers at 8 p.m. During that hour, NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' more than doubled that, with 12.6 million viewers. That led into the season finale of ''Las Vegas'' (9.63 million) and ''Conviction'' (6.09 million). The N.B.A. playoffs lifted TNT into first place in prime time among ad-supported cable channels for the week that ended on May 7. Five games were on the list of the week's most-watched programs, with two Los Angeles Lakers-Phoenix Suns games drawing the most interest. The May 4 game delivered an audience of 4.97 million and the May 6 game brought in 4.74 million. But over all, FX's broadcast of a Nascar Nextel Cup Race (5.63 million) on May 6 was the week's No. 1 basic cable program. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MAY, JAMES FRANCIS
summary: MAY--James Francis , 75, of Jamesburg, NJ and Rock Hall, MD. Formerly of Yardley, PA. Born Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Annette Williamson. Loving father of David and Edward May, and Nancy Cropper. Grandfather of Stephen, Will, Jack Cropper, and Caroline and Sophia May. Beloved brother of William and John (deceased). Brother-in-law of Diane and Carol. Father-in-law of Beth, Anne and Peter. Dear uncle of John, Margaret, William, Linda, Matthew, Michelle, Danielle and Jonathan. U.S. Army 1952-1955. Formerly Director of Management Info Systems CBS. Viewing December 7, Lester Memorial Home Jamesburg NJ. Roman Catholic Service Saturday December 8. Interment Cemetery of the Evergreens, Brooklyn, NY. May he rest in peace.

headline: Corrections
summary: The Saturday Interview in Business Day last week, with Brett White, the chief executive at the real estate company CB Richard Ellis, referred incorrectly to acquisitions the company made in the 1990s. It bought investment management and commercial mortgage brokerage firms, not a pension fund and a commercial bank.

headline: 'Bionic Woman' Slips
summary: One week after NBC's ''Bionic Woman'' outperformed ABC's ''Private Practice'' in the 9 p.m. Wednesday time slot, the matchup looked different in their second go-round. Nielsen estimated that the NBC remake plummeted by 30 percent from its debut among adults 18 to 49, while the ABC spinoff declined by 13 percent to finish first over all in that demographic. In total viewers, both ''Bionic Women'' (10.9 million) and ''Private Practice'' (12.3 million) lost millions of viewers, while Fox's ''Kitchen Nightmares'' (6.3 million) and CBS's ''Criminal Minds,'' the night's most-watched show (14.4 million), achieved slight improvements in the hour. For the night, ABC ranked No. 1, finishing in first place at 8 with the premiere of ''Pushing Daisies'' (12.8 million). At 10, ABC's ''Dirty Sexy Money'' (9.7 million) finished second to CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (12.7 million), while NBC's ''Life'' fell to third (8.8 million).

headline: Words Are Music For Fox
summary: Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' posted Wednesday's top ratings among adults 18 to 49, as the network led the night in that demographic. CBS won in total viewers, as its ''Criminal Minds'' rerun tied the lyrics game show with 8.8 million viewers in the 9 o'clock hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 8, Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (7.6 million) ranked No. 1 in the 18 to 49 set, while the official time-period premiere of CBS's ''Power of 10'' earned a slightly larger audience in the hour (7.8 million). NBC finished third for the night in total viewers but edged out CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Arts, Briefly; Two Heads Roll on 'Idol'
summary: Chris Richardson, above left, and Phil Stacey, above right, were cut Wednesday from ''American Idol,'' leaving Blake Lewis as the only male contestant in the final four. According to Nielsen's estimates, the show remained dominant in the ratings, attracting 28.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. and putting Fox in first place for the night. CBS was second, faring well at 9 with ''Criminal Minds'' (13.3 million) and at 10 with ''CSI: NY'' (12.9 million). Despite once promising ratings CBS's ''Jericho'' (8.2 million), whose season finale is scheduled for next week, finished fifth in the 8 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. Fox's ''Bones'' (10.4 million) led the time slot over all, and ''America's Next Top Model'' (5.1 million) on CW won among viewers 18 to 34. ABC ranked third, leading the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 demographic with ''Lost'' (12.1 million). NBC finished fourth, only slightly ahead of CW. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Corrections
summary: The Public Lives profile on May 25, about Martin Garbus, a Manhattan lawyer representing the fired radio host Don Imus in his pending lawsuit against CBS, misidentified the mentor to Mr. Garbus who won all nine cases he argued before the United States Supreme Court. It was Ephraim London -- not Emile Zola Berman, who represented Sirhan B. Sirhan, Robert F. Kennedy's assassin.

headline: Arts, Briefly; No 'Men,' No Joy for CBS
summary: At different points during this season, both ''Out of Practice'' and ''Courting Alex'' occupied the time slot after the most successful comedy on television, CBS's ''Two and a Half Men,'' broadcast on Mondays. Recently, the two shows were moved to fill the 8 p.m. hour on Wednesdays and to see how they survive without ''Men.'' The results have not been pretty. This Wednesday in Nielsen's estimates, ''Practice'' drew 6.29 million viewers, and ''Alex'' attracted 6.35 million, for fourth place in the hour among total viewers and fifth place among adults 18 to 49. First at 8 p.m. was NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' with 16.1 million viewers, a lead that was squandered by the newly displaced ''Law & Order'' (9.4 million) and then the seemingly dead-on-arrival ''Heist'' (7.36 million). Fox was No. 1 for the night, as the ''American Idol'' results show brought in 27.27 million viewers at 9 p.m. ABC's ''Lost'' (16.07 million) continued to suffer at the hand of ''Idol,'' tying its lowest 18-to-49 rating of the season for an original episode. In the same hour, WB's ''Bedford Diaries'' was a complete washout, with 1.9 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

headline: Arts, Briefly; A C.I.A. Exclusive Is No Seismic TV Event
summary: CBS's exclusive interview with the former director of central intelligence George J. Tenet on ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday might have captivated Washington, but it made only minor ripples in the ratings. According to Nielsen's estimates, the news magazine led the 7 p.m. hour with a below-average 10.8 million viewers, ranking second in the time period among adults 18 to 49, behind ABC's ''Funniest Home Videos,'' which drew 8.4 million total viewers. Although CBS tied ABC as the most-watched network of the night, it ranked third over all in the 18 to 49 set. Among viewers in that demographic, ABC's lineup of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (10.3 million), ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 (16.9 million) and ''Brothers & Sisters'' at 10 (11.5 million), remained dominant over all. Fox finished second with its animated comedy lineup, which included a first-ever victory for ''Family Guy'' (8.2 million) over ''Desperate Housewives'' at 9 among viewers 18 to 34. NBC was a distant fourth for the night in the 18 to 49 set. Its broadcast of the film ''Along Came Polly'' from 9 to 11 averaged 5.1 million viewers. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Arts, Briefly; Tony (the Award) Helps CBS in the Numbers Game
summary: As Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) bid adieu on HBO, on network television CBS and ABC fought it out for first place in the ratings Sunday. While numbers for the final episode of ''The Sopranos'' were unavailable yesterday, Nielsen's estimates show that CBS attracted the most viewers for the night with its combination of a ''60 Minutes'' repeat at 7 p.m. (9.3 million) followed from 8 to 11 by ''The 61st Annual Tony Awards,'' which drew 6.2 million viewers, down more than a million from a year ago. Despite its edge in total viewers, CBS finished fourth over all among adults 18 to 49. ABC posted a solid win for the night in that demographic, aided primarily by its coverage of game two of the N.B.A. Finals match-up between the Cleveland Cavaliers and the San Antonio Spurs. Due to the nature of live broadcasts, reliable estimates for the game's television audience were unavailable yesterday. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: President of Nickelodeon Networks to Leave Company
summary: In a move that caught Wall Street and the media industry by surprise, Viacom said yesterday that Herb Scannell, a vice chairman of MTV Networks and president of Nickelodeon Networks, was leaving the company. No specific reason was given for the departure of Mr. Scannell, who has been at Viacom for nearly 20 years and who built Nickelodeon, the children's cable channel, into one of the nation's highest-rated cable services. In a news release, Viacom said Mr. Scannell was leaving to pursue other activities.

headline: Wrapping Historical Subway Columns in Modern Ads
