summary: James L. Dolan made a number of puzzling remarks when he spoke about the state of the Knicks last week, but whatever he said in private, it must have been inspirational. A methodical upward climb that began, coincidentally or not, with a speech to the team by Dolan, the Madison Square Garden chairman, had just culminated in the most positive trend in two months: back-to-back Knicks victories.

headline: With an Ambitious Agenda, Homeland Security Chief Steers Clear of Fault-Finding
summary: Even by Washington's caffeinated standards, Michael Chertoff's to-do list is ambitious: cut illegal immigration, make ports, subways and chemical plants less vulnerable to terrorist attack and fix FEMA fast, because hurricane season starts in less than 90 days. It is part of the reason, Mr. Chertoff, the secretary of homeland security, is trying to steer clear of the roiling debate over who most deserves blame for the government's flawed response last summer to Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Trying To Turn Elaine Into Christine
summary: Julia Louis-Dreyfus, who is starring in a new CBS comedy called ''The New Adventures of Old Christine,'' sat before a roomful of television critics at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Pasadena in January. Confronted with questions about whether she was a victim of the '' 'Seinfeld' Curse'' -- which refers to the lack of success she, Michael Richards and Jason Alexander have had since ''Seinfeld'' ended its ratings-topping, award-winning 10-year run in 1998 -- she wittily deflected them. About a week later, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, 45, took her place on a different kind of center stage, this time in a classroom at her younger son's exclusive private school. As part of Parent Share Day, she delivered a 45-minute summary of her life story to a group of third graders. Suddenly, pressure.

headline: Univision May Have New Suitor
summary: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States. The consortium includes private equity firms Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners, as well as the Cisneros Group of Venezuela and the media entrepreneur Haim Saban, according to people involved in the group.

headline: Changing U.S. Audience Poses Test for a Giant of Spanish TV
summary: Rosa Guevara, a Mexican-American dental hygienist, grew up with the Univision network's Spanish-language soap operas, which she still watches. But Mrs. Guevara, 59, now watches alone. On any given night, her husband is glued to a western on cable while her 25-year-old daughter who used to watch the soaps with her, may tune in to ''George Lopez'' on ABC or syndicated reruns of ''Friends.''

headline: Cheers for NBC
summary: Since I've lambasted the networks in the past for missing the boat on Darfur, I take my hat off to NBC for sending Ann Curry and a first-rate crew to the Chad border. We traveled together much of the time on this trip, and they were great. I gather that Ann's reports will be on the Today Show Monday and Tuesday, the NBC nightly news on Monday, and Dateline sometime soon as well. Ann also writes about Darfur in her blog, Curry Commentary.

headline: The Week Ahead: March 12 - 18
summary: THEATER Jason Zinoman

headline: Svidler Gives Topalov Trouble With an Offbeat Ruy Lopez
summary: Although Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria has been considered the man to beat for the world championship, he got off to a shocking start at the Linares tournament, which opened in Morelia, Mexico. He lost his first and fourth games and drew his second and third. These are all top players, but if you want to be the best, you must do something exceptional, as Garry Kasparov and Bobby Fischer have done.

headline: Shooting Into the Net And Out of the Box
summary: A STORY of personal commitment and triumph over long odds is told on camera in ''Through the Fire,'' a documentary about Sebastian Telfair, the Coney Island basketball phenom now with the N.B.A.'s Portland Trail Blazers. But what viewers won't see is the similar story that played out behind the scenes involving a young man named Alastair Christopher. Mr. Christopher gets the director of photography credit on the film, the No. 2 billing after the filmmaker himself, Jonathan Hock. Not bad, considering his situation a decade ago, when he showed up at Mr. Hock's workshop for at-risk youths in New York City.

headline: Report Sees Busy Year for Entertainment Deals
A Ship Leaks, But She Wants To Anchor It
summary: KATIE COURIC has taken some hits to her Q rating for her big salary and perceived imperiousness. More recently, she has displayed some professional restlessness, making it clear that she would like to trade her throne in the morning for the anchor chair in the evening. And CBS seems to be a willing partner. I spent last Friday morning with Ms. Couric -- well, O.K., I watched the ''Today'' show along with more than six million other viewers -- and I can't say I blame her. Yes, she got to talk to Tim Russert about port security, but that was the high point. Then it was on to a feature about knock-off Oscar gowns and some time on Rockefeller Plaza introducing a children's artist who sang about marching with dinosaurs.

headline: Seinfeld's Buddy Elaine Is a Divorced Mom Now, and Her Name Is Christine
summary: "Christine," starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus, is a conventional sitcom with a laugh track, and its premise is not particularly groundbreaking.

headline: Critic's Choice: New DVD's
summary: My Neighbor Totoro The Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki first attracted attention in the West with this 1988 feature, a gentle, haunting fantasy rooted, as the best fantasy films are, in a strict psychological realism. When their mother's illness and their father's new job force them to move to a village in the countryside, two little girls find an answer to their sudden sense of estrangement and abandonment when they meet the title character, a forest spirit who takes the form of a huge, perpetually startled hamster. Though the film has long been available in various video editions, the Walt Disney Company has now reissued it in a bright and beautiful widescreen transfer that offers a choice between the original Japanese soundtrack and a newly produced English version, featuring the voices of Dakota Fanning and her sister, Elle.

headline: N.C.A.A. Fans Courted With Free Webcasts
summary: THERE was a time, until the late 1990's, when the only way to watch the N.C.A.A. tournament games that weren't on CBS was to buy DirecTV's satellite package. Then three years ago, CBS made these out-of-market games available as a video streaming product on the Internet.

headline: Mike Wallace Says He Will Retire From '60 Minutes' in Spring
summary: The correspondent, who has been with the show since its inception in September 1968, said that "CBS is not pushing me."

headline: As Stern Ranted, Letterman Debated
summary: It was not surprising that Howard Stern wore a T-shirt that said ''I Hate Les Moonves'' for his interview with David Letterman on CBS on Monday night. His language, by shock-radio standards, was quite mild: he merely described the chief executive of CBS and his former boss as ''the biggest jerk on the planet.'' (On Fox News, he used one of his favorite expressions on Mr. Moonves: ''pig vomit.'') It was a little surprising that CBS would allow Mr. Stern on one of its shows to vent about the network's multimillion-dollar lawsuit against him, particularly since one of the network's charges is that Mr. Stern used his time on CBS Radio to promote his own interests. On the other hand, that puzzling lawsuit has already generated so much free publicity for Mr. Stern and his new perch at Sirius Satellite Radio that perhaps one appearance on Mr. Letterman's show would not make much of a difference.

headline: Darfur Orphans
summary: Mike Simon, the NBC cameraman who accompanied Ann Curry on our collective trip to Darfur, has posted a moving blog about what he saw on our trip. It's always irritating when these camera people turn out to be wonderful writers as well. Here's Mike Simon's blog.

headline: As Howard Stern Ranted, David Letterman Debated
TV Stations Fined Over CBS Show Deemed to Be Indecent
summary: The Federal Communications Commission leveled a record $3.6 million fine yesterday against 111 television stations that broadcast an episode of ''Without a Trace'' in December 2004, with the agency saying the CBS show suggested that its teenage characters were participating in a sexual orgy. The program was among nine cited yesterday for fines totaling about $4 million on agency accusations of violating decency standards between February 2002 and March 2005. The fines are the first indecency actions by the commission since Kevin J. Martin, a Republican, became chairman last March.

headline: March Madness Afflicts Advertisers
summary: ON Madison Avenue, the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, which starts today on CBS, is bigger than the Super Bowl or the World Series. According to TNS Media Intelligence, the tournament attracts more advertising spending than either of the other two events -- from 2000 to 2005, more than $2.2 billion was spent on network television advertising for the basketball tournament, compared with $880 million for the World Series and $834 million for the Super Bowl during that same period.

headline: Some Absences At 'Mets TV' Party
summary: SportsNet New York's debut yesterday was so much different from the YES Network's in 2002. To celebrate, the Mets' network gave itself a party on the plaza outside its studio on Avenue of the Americas. YES had no gala outside its Manhattan office or its Stamford studio, but at the time the Yankees' channel was enmeshed in what would be a yearlong boycott by Cablevision. Mr. Met was there at 51st Street. So was a phalanx of men and women dressed as SNY's advertising and promotional character, a fan with a TV set for a head. T-shirts, caps and 10-inch L.C.D. televisions were given away, yet this newest New York network shared one thing with YES: it came to life without a deal to be carried by Cablevision.

headline: Iona Simmers an Upset Special for Just Over a Half
summary: For more than a half Thursday night, Iona looked fit for the bright lights and big stage of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Steve Burtt, a senior guard, was a wonder with his left-handed shot, and another senior guard, Ricky Soliver, stuck his tongue out at the crowd after going up and under a Louisiana State defender for a nifty left-handed layup.

headline: Monitoring Indecency, Pushing An Agenda
summary: Indecency, as Janet Jackson showed, is all in the context. People complained to the Federal Communications Commission about the performer's wardrobe malfunction because it happened during a Super Bowl halftime show -- viewers don't expect lewdness until the commercials. And fans of procedural crime dramas like CBS's ''Without a Trace'' expect to see sexual depravity and abuse only in dead people. When an episode showed graphic images of seminaked, promiscuous teenagers who were actually alive, it was something of a shock. It certainly fired up the F.C.C.: that guardian of network morals fined 111 stations that aired that episode a record $3.6 million.

headline: An Empire By Caesar, Evocative Of Today
summary: Rome, Inc. The Rise and Fall of the First Multinational Corporation By Stanley Bing 197 pages. Atlas Books/W. W. Norton. $23.95. Rome -- the greatest empire the world has ever known. And one heck of a business. That is the premise behind ''Rome, Inc.,'' Stanley Bing's comic take on the multinational, acquisition-minded glory that was Rome, a terrific brand with the kind of C.E.O.'s you just don't get anymore, willing to pile up a few bodies if that's what it takes to boost company morale.

headline: That Other Madness This Month: Mergers
summary: MARCH madness is not limited to college basketball. Billions of dollars in mergers were announced this week, building on the momentum created when AT&T offered to acquire BellSouth for $67 billion earlier in the month.

headline: George Mason Proves Bid Wasn't a Fluke With Upset
summary: George Mason University, one of the teams whose inclusion in the N.C.A.A. tournament provoked much criticism of the selection committee, is staying for at least one more round in the Washington Region after dispatching the perennial title contender Michigan State, 76-65. The Patriots (24-7) were one of the last teams selected in the field of 65 and seeded No. 11 here despite losing in the semifinals of the lightly regarded Colonial Athletic Conference, which last received an at-large bid in 1986. Critics, among them CBS broadcasters Jim Nantz and Billy Packer, have questioned the selection of multiple bids to midmajor conferences at the expense of borderline notables like Cincinnati of the Big East and Florida State of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

headline: New Ways to Stay a Night In Lower Manhattan
summary: A SIGHTSEEING map of Manhattan that was published in 1928 is framed in the restaurant of the Blue Moon Hotel, which opened a month ago on the Lower East Side. There are about 12 points of interest on it. Today there are more than a dozen interesting sights in Lower Manhattan alone, and soon there will be at least that many new hotels in the area.

headline: Bill Beutel, 75, Longtime Anchor of 'Eyewitness News' in New York
summary: Bill Beutel, who helped bring about a sea change in the nature of local television news as the dapper and unruffled anchor of ''Eyewitness News'' at WABC-TV in New York for more than 30 years, died Saturday at his home in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 75. The cause was complications from a progressive neurological disorder, his wife, Adair, said.

headline: Cinderella Now Lingers Longer At the N.C.A.A.'s March Dance
summary: When George Mason defeated the defending national champion North Carolina Tar Heels on Sunday, the upset capped four of the most harried days in the history of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. Ten teams knocked off competitors seeded at least five spots higher, tying a record set in 1986 and matched in 1990 and 2002. Although underdogs have long been part of tournament lore, many who follow college basketball agree that the balance of power is shifting.

headline: Protective Cover for Workers Who Really Prefer Basketball
summary: For the first time, CBS SportsLine.com is offering viewers live video of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. And because many of the games are on during work hours, the Web site is offering something else: a way for basketball fans to conceal their viewing from their bosses. On the Web browser, which allows viewers to watch and listen to games not broadcast in their geographic area, there is a red button marked Boss Button. When clicked, the basketball feed cuts out, the sound goes dead and an image of an Excel spreadsheet pops up. When the coast is clear, the user can click on the spreadsheet and the video comes back on.

headline: On Local Radio Broadcasts, Emphasis Is Sometimes on the Madness
summary: For the real March Madness, you must turn from CBS to the local radio broadcasts of the games. This is where you will hear the most exuberance, partisanship, and, if it fits the moment, some high-octane paranoia. You expect home broadcasters to turn CBS's national formula inside-out and preach to the converted. You expect them to root for their teams because their calls are heard largely by communities where the teams' fortunes are uppermost in their minds, not by national audiences.

headline: Making Space for a Biotech Center
summary: The acquisition and subsequent redevelopment of a former Pfizer pharmaceutical research facility here by Forest City, the Cleveland-based developer, promises to quadruple the amount of speculative office space available for biotechnology companies in the Chicago area. Forest City bought the one-million-square-foot complex last spring for $43 million. Since then, the company has demolished 9 of the 13 buildings on the 23-acre campus, leaving about 700,000 square feet of offices and laboratories. The company plans to build an additional 1.3 million square feet of new space, also for offices and labs, over the next 10 years. Over all, the project is expected to cost more than $500 million.

headline: For Tagliabue, the Bottom Line Wasn't Always About Money
summary: Paul Tagliabue can retire knowing he was the $52 billion man. In television deals made during his time as the National Football League commissioner, ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, TNT and ESPN have signed contracts worth a combined $46.4 billion, while the satellite operator DirecTV will end up paying $6.1 billion by the time its new five-year deal is over.

headline: BUSH CONCEDES IRAQ WAR ERODES POLITICAL STATUS
summary: President Bush said Tuesday that the war in Iraq was eroding his political capital, his starkest admission yet about the costs of the conflict to his presidency, and suggested that American forces would remain in the country until at least 2009. In a quick remark at a White House news conference about the reserves of political strength he earned in his 2004 re-election victory -- ''I'd say I'm spending that capital on the war'' -- Mr. Bush in effect acknowledged that until he could convince increasingly skeptical Americans that the United States was winning the war, Iraq would overshadow everything he did. [Excerpts, Page A10.]

headline: WB, Worried About Drawing Federal Fines, Censors Itself
summary: Concerned about the recent decision by the Federal Communications Commission to fine television networks for material deemed indecent, the WB network will broadcast a new drama next week that it has censored over the objections of the program's creator. But first, the network will offer the uncut version of the pilot episode on its Web site, starting today -- a further example of the new strategies network television may be pursuing, both to escape government-imposed restrictions and to find alternative ways of reaching viewers. It is the first time a network has offered on another outlet an uncut version of a program it has been forced to censor.

headline: Gene Scott, 68, Publisher of Tennis Week
summary: Gene Scott, who served tennis for a half-century as a world-ranked player, tournament director, player agent, author and, perhaps most significant, the founder, publisher, editor and iconoclastic columnist of Tennis Week magazine, died Monday in the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 68 and lived in New York. His wife, Polly, said the cause of death was amyloidosis, an illness in which insoluble protein fibers accumulate in body organs and impair them.

headline: More Setbacks at Interpublic
summary: DAYS before a crucial presentation to woo Wall Street, the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies demonstrated again yesterday why that charm offensive is needed. In announcing its most recent quarterly and yearly results, Interpublic, struggling since 2002 with financial and operational problems, posted a loss for the fourth quarter and restated results for the first three quarters of 2005, which reduced revenue by $14.1 million. It also disclosed that its controller and chief accounting officer, Nicholas S. Cyprus, would leave after less than two years.

headline: Waiting on Deck in the Lineup for Rights
summary: With the final season of its six-year, $2.5 billion Major League Baseball deal looming, Fox still has not enlisted for a new contract. That is not much of a surprise. Fox didn't expect to conclude a contract during its exclusive negotiating period, which ended last Dec. 31, and M.L.B. wanted to gauge its value on the open market. So baseball recently asked executives at ESPN to come in and talk about a package for ABC Sports, which last carried the sport in 1995 on The Baseball Network.

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: Courtroom Battle Spills Into the Bookstores They've battled in a British courtroom, and now Dan Brown and Michael Baigent are going to tangle again, Publishers Weekly reports. This time the arena is the bookstore, where the mass-market paperback version of Mr. Brown's best-selling novel ''The Da Vinci Code'' will make its debut on Tuesday. That happens to be the day when ''The Jesus Papers,'' Mr. Baigent's examination of the life and crucifixion of Jesus, goes on sale. That book's publisher, Harper San Francisco, said the date was chosen more than a year ago for its proximity to Easter, a favorable time for sales of books on religion. Anchor announced the publication date for ''The Da Vinci Code'' two months ago. In London, a judge is weighing a decision in a case brought against Random House U.K., the novel's British publisher, by Mr. Baigent and Richard Leigh, two of the three authors of the nonfiction book ''The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail'' (published as ''Holy Blood, Holy Grail'' in the United States). The lawsuit argues that Mr. Brown took the ''thematic'' architecture of ''The Da Vinci Code'' from their work. Moscow Mayor Approves Foster Skyscraper Norman Foster's design for a 1,968-foot, 118-story skyscraper that would tower over Moscow and be Europe's tallest building has won the endorsement of Moscow's mayor, The Times of London reported. The mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, approved the plan for the Moscow City Tower after a meeting last week with Lord Foster, who said he expected construction of his ''vertical city'' to start within 18 months. A Moscow City Hall spokesman said the municipal government would make a final decision on the project after the plans were reviewed next month by the Culture Commission. Rising on the banks of the Moscow River three miles from the Kremlin, the tower, with a projected cost of $1.5 billion, would have nine underground floors of parking and shopping space, a public ice rink, a hotel, 24 floors of apartments and offices and, on its top, an observation deck with cafes and bars. Doherty: A Day in the Life Pete Doherty, the bad-boy British rocker known for his affection for drugs and Kate Moss, his former flame, had a date in court in London yesterday. Mr. Doherty, below, turned up more than an hour late, pleaded guilty to seven charges of possessing drugs in December and January, and heard a warning from the judge, who ordered him to return on April 20, The Associated Press reported. On leaving, he reportedly kicked a BBC radio newswoman in the arm, knocked her microphone to the ground, ran down the street pursued by members of the news media, leaped over the trunk of a Jaguar, hopped into the driver's seat and nearly collided with another car when he pulled away. In court, Mr. Doherty's lawyer, Sean Curran, asked Judge Jane McIvor to put off the matter for six months while Mr. Doherty's progress was monitored. ''He is a very talented man,'' Mr. Curran said. Mr. Doherty, the lead singer of Babyshambles, is already under orders from another court to undergo drug rehabilitation. '60 Minutes' on Yahoo! Video and other news from ''60 Minutes'' will become available on Yahoo!, beginning with the program's fall season, under a partnership between Yahoo! and CBS that was announced yesterday. Sean McManus, the president of CBS News and Sports, said, ''This deal with Yahoo! will bring the rich storytelling of television's No. 1 newsmagazine to a new and younger audience while offering loyal viewers extended features and content online.'' Arrest Warrant Issued For Noted Indian Artist An arrest warrant for Maqbool Fida Hussain , 90, India's best-known artist, has been issued after he failed to appear in a case growing out of his painting depicting Mother India as a nude woman, Agence France-Presse reported. After protests from Hindu nationalists, Mr. Hussain, below, a Muslim, withdrew the painting from a charity auction last month, but a militant organization offered $11.5 million for his murder. The warrant was issued in connection with a lawsuit filed by a Hindu in the city of Indore on the grounds that the painting was offensive, The Press Trust of India reported. Lawyers for Mr. Hussain, expressing fears for his safety, had asked that the case be moved to New Delhi. Iranian Filmmaker Protests An Iranian film director has informed organizers of Denmark's biggest film festival, Natfilm, opening today in Copenhagen, that he will boycott it to protest the publication in Denmark of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad, Agence France-Presse reported. The director, Majid Majidi, right, whose film ''The Willow Tree'' was to have been shown, said in a letter to Kim Foss, the festival director, ''I would like to protest against insulting any religious belief and icon.'' Mr. Foss said he regretted the decision, adding that ''the festival aims to increase knowledge of other countries and thus build tolerance and understanding.'' In Plain English, Al Jazeera Isn't Quite Ready Plans to introduce an English-language channel on the Arab news network Al Jazeera as early as this month were scrapped yesterday when the director general of the satellite channel, Wadah Khanfar, announced a delay, Agence France-Presse reported. Nigel Parsons, the Al Jazeera International director, said that technical installations were incomplete but that a spring start to the operation remained possible. Footnotes Lucie Arnaz, below, will make her first Broadway appearance in nearly 15 years when she succeeds Joanna Gleason on May 29 in the role of a wealthy divorced woman in ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'' at the Imperial Theater. Ingo Metzmacher has been chosen to succeed Kent Nagano as the principal conductor of the Deutsche Symphonie-Orchester in Berlin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Metzmacher, 48, the chief conductor of the Netherlands Opera in Amsterdam, signed a contract yesterday that runs from summer 2007 through 2010. President Bush has signed legislation naming the Smithfield, N.C., Post Office in honor of Ava Gardner, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Gardner, a North Carolina native, is buried in the town.

headline: Bush Facing Serious Obstacles as He Pushes for Changes in Immigration Policy
summary: In the days before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, immigration policy was going to be President Bush's signature issue. It was central to his thinking as the former governor of a border state, key to his relationship with President Vicente Fox of Mexico and essential in attracting new Hispanic voters to the Republican Party. Five years later, Mr. Bush has at last realized some momentum on immigration policy, but it is probably not the activity he once anticipated.

headline: TV and Top Marketers Discuss the State of the Medium
summary: AMONG themselves, advertising executives often declare the 30-second spot dead. But to hear television executives tell it, not only does television remain a potent medium, but those little ads are still going strong. The future of television advertising was the main topic of discussion at a conference of the Association of National Advertisers on Wednesday, meant as a prelude to the upfront market in May. That is when television networks introduce new programming and companies reconsider the division of their advertising dollars among print, television, Internet and other media.

headline: Box Seats: And the Final Four Is We Will Know Tonight
summary: The Round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. men's tournament featured a dazzling array of overtime thrillers, buzzer-beaters and mesmerizing plays. With four teams vying today for the remaining two spots in the Final Four, statistics from the kenpom.com Web site to can help determine what they do well, and what could come back to haunt them. VILLANOVA The Wildcats' speed on both sides of the ball has generated openings for their sharpshooters and wreaked havoc on opposing offenses. Having that many ball handlers on the floor (four guards at once for much of the season) has also enabled Villanova to take care of the ball and get the most out of every possession.

headline: TBR: Inside the List
summary: RACE MATTERS: ''If we keep going the way we are,'' the PBS television host Tavis Smiley told a packed auditorium in San Francisco earlier this month, ''this book is going to hit the New York Times best-seller list. I hope you understand the statement this will make . . . when we put this book on the list and force everyone to talk about it.'' The book Smiley was selling is called ''The Covenant With Black America'' (Third World Press), and it is indeed on this week's list -- it enters the paperback nonfiction rankings at No. 6. The book, which Smiley edited, is a data-packed manifesto about racial inequality in America circa 2006, with chapters on topics like health care and the justice system. ''The Covenant With Black America'' didn't make this list without some hard, and canny, work on Smiley's part -- he sold the book during a barnstorming 10-city tour, on which he was sometimes accompanied by the Princeton professor Cornel West, and he hopes African-American churches will push the book to their congregations, a strategy that worked for Rick Warren, the author of ''The Purpose-Driven Life.'' Smiley and West recently made a somewhat surreal appearance on Fox News's ''Hannity & Colmes.'' Alan Colmes warned early on that Sean Hannity was going to blow his lid. (''He's going to yell and scream about Harry Belafonte,'' Colmes said.) West called Hannity ''brother Sean,'' but that didn't mellow things out. ''The reason why black people do not support conservatives like you, my dear brother,'' West said, ''is because your argument's not convincing when it comes to focusing on working and poor people.''

headline: Even the Losers Get Lucky Sometimes
summary: FIRED! Tales of the Canned, Canceled, Downsized and Dismissed By Annabelle Gurwitch. 238 pp., Touchstone. $19.95. QUEEN OF THE ODDBALLS: And Other True Stories from a Life Unaccording to Plan By Hillary Carlip. 288 pp., HarperCollins. $13.95. THE actress and writer Annabelle Gurwitch has done much to get a laugh. She ate a sandwich while topless on HBO, hiccupped for five minutes straight while hopping on one leg on a sitcom, did a television commercial with Carrot Top and currently is being upstaged by a sheep dog in a Disney film remake. But her star comic turn came by accident when she was fired in 2003 by Woody Allen, her idol, from ''Writer's Block,'' his pair of one-act comedies. He told her, ''What you're doing is terrible, none of it good, all of it bad, don't ever do that again.'' He added, ''You look retarded.''

headline: An Open Case
summary: Strength as a lawyer: Patience.

headline: In an Election Year, a Shift in Public Opinion on the War
summary: Neil Mondragon watched with approval at an auto repair shop recently as Representative Heather A. Wilson, a New Mexico Republican visiting her district, dropped into the pit and drained the oil from a car. Afterward, Mr. Mondragon recalled how he had backed Ms. Wilson, a supporter of the Iraq war, in her race for Congress two years ago. He, too, supported the war.

headline: Same Guy, Smaller Kingdom
summary: THE last thing Michael D. Eisner would seem to require is more exposure. But tomorrow night, his mug will be back on the tube in ''Conversations with Michael Eisner,'' a one-hour talk show on CNBC, in which the former obsessive object of media consideration will get to turn the tables -- in this instance, a huge slab designed by Frank Gehry -- on his guests. Not for long, though: the show has not yet had its debut and here we are back to talking about Mr. Eisner.

headline: Cable Negotiates to Offer Instant Reruns (for a Fee)
summary: For anyone who has ever missed a top-rated television program and wondered what all the fuss was about, Time Warner Cable may one day have an answer. The nation's second-largest cable operator has initiated talks with the four biggest broadcast networks -- CBS, ABC, Fox and NBC -- about testing a service that would give viewers access to top programs, as rated by Nielsen Media Research, soon after their broadcast.

headline: Turning to Mammon to Spread the Gospel
summary: A CHURCH that raised eyebrows with a provocative television commercial is resuming its advertising efforts with a campaign that seeks to emulate how the Gospel was spread: by word of mouth. The campaign is being sponsored by the United Church of Christ, a Protestant denomination that garnered attention in late 2004 with a commercial that offered a startling perspective on religious diversity and inclusiveness. The spot, which returned last spring, showed two burly bouncers using a red velvet rope to block the entrance to a church, keeping out worshipers whose appearances departed from mainstream norms but letting in those with stereotypical all-American looks.

headline: Producer Returns To CBS Mornings
summary: Steve Friedman, who built the street-level studio at NBC's ''Today'' show as its executive producer and later created ''The Early Show'' at CBS, has returned to CBS News as vice president for morning broadcasts, the president of CBS News and Sports, Sean McManus, said yesterday. In the post, which he assumed yesterday, Mr. Friedman will be responsible for raising the performance and ratings of ''The Early Show,'' which trails ''Today'' on NBC (the No. 1 morning show for more than a decade) and ''Good Morning America'' on ABC. He will also oversee the Saturday ''Early Show'' along with the ''CBS Morning News.''

headline: Rumors of CBS Bid Lift Univision's Stock
summary: Investors pounced on Hispanic television giant Univision on Tuesday amid rumors that CBS chief Leslie Moonves is searching for a partner to make an offer for the network after claiming earlier that he was an unlikely bidder.

headline: Bedford, a College With Sex in the Curriculum
summary: The WB offers a fun show about attractive college kids experimenting with life, lab reports and love: "The O.C." for the Stanley H. Kaplan set.

headline: Computing The Mysteries Of Attraction
summary: ELIZABETH BRERETON was a freshman at Connecticut College and Robert Smith was a sophomore at Wesleyan in 1965 when they became a part of what might have been this country's first computer dating service. It was called Operation Match, and it sent questionnaires to college campuses around the country. ''There were stacks of them as you went into the dorms,'' Ms. Brereton remembered. Students rated their own looks, intelligence and interests on a scale from one to five and described their ideal date using the same measures. They then returned the survey, along with a $3 fee, to the Operation Match offices in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Dan Curtis, Producer of 'Winds of War' TV Series, Dies at 78
summary: Dan Curtis, a prolific television producer and director who was best known for shepherding two of the most ambitious mini-series ever made, ''The Winds of War,'' and ''War and Remembrance,'' onto ABC in the 1980's, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 78. The cause was brain cancer, his family said.

headline: CBS Brushes Off Talk of Buying Univision
summary: CBS brushed off talk of a Univision buy, saying the big Spanish-language radio and TV broadcaster is expensive. Finance chief Fred Reynolds told investors at a Bank of America conference in New York that CBS isn't eager to pony up $12 billion for Univision, likening an acquisition of that size to climbing Mount Everest.

headline: On '60 Minutes,' No News Is Woods's News
summary: In the midst of Ed Bradley's worshipful two-part profile of Tiger Woods on ''60 Minutes'' last Sunday, I wondered if it was an infomercial or if Woods had paid a fee for these adoring 25 minutes. With nothing new to report -- and not a single tough question in his arsenal -- Bradley chose to join Camp Tiger. Bradley looked to be enjoying himself too much as he smiled and chuckled along with Woods in various locales, conjuring comparisons to the buddy act of Ahmad Rashad and Michael Jordan, who, like Woods, surrenders so little to journalists but whose consent to be interviewed is deemed an occasion to send a camera crew.

headline: Radio Industry Said to Seek Deal to Settle Payoff Accusations
summary: The nation's biggest radio broadcasters are in discussions with the Federal Communications Commission to resolve accusations that station programmers accepted improper payments from record companies in exchange for playing specific songs, officials involved in the talks said last night. But the talks have stalled on questions about how much money the companies -- Clear Channel Communications, CBS Radio, Entercom Communications and the Citadel Broadcasting Corporation -- might have to pay to settle the case, said these officials, who insisted on anonymity because the talks are at a delicate stage.

headline: A Comic's One-Night Stand As Teacher
summary: He confesses to having studied ''nothing'' while an undergraduate at the University of Houston. But last year, the comedian and actor Robert Wuhl decided that he wanted to become a college professor. Not a real one, but a humorous substitute, backed by an HBO crew, who would amuse a packed lecture hall with a curriculum proposing that American history was popular culture -- and a lot of gossip. ''The key to history is who tells the story,'' Mr. Wuhl said in an interview. ''Tolstoy said, 'History is a wonderful thing, if only it were true.' If O'Reilly and Franken see the same event, you'll get two different stories. A guy writes a book that says Lincoln is gay, so is he gay because someone says so?''

headline: A Suburban Switch: The Condo's the Thing
summary: IN mid-November, Jin Kim and May Yee Yeoung, single professional women who have been roommates for two years, pooled their money and bought their first home, a luxurious two-bedroom condo just off Interstate 95 in Fairfield, Conn., 60 miles north of the rental apartment in TriBeCa where they used to live. Two months later, Walter and Lois F. Killough, who have been married 26 years and have two grown children, bought a two-bedroom condo in West New York, N.J., just across the Hudson River from Midtown Manhattan. They are slowly moving out of their home in suburban Mahwah, N.J., so that Mr. Killough can have a shorter commute to work in New York City and Mrs. Killough can be closer to the theaters she loves to attend.

headline: Baseball's Web Site Is Big Business
summary: Bud Selig is something of a technophobe. So although he successfully lobbied baseball owners several years ago to create a separate company to own and operate mlb.com, he cannot personally navigate the live game video that now defines the league's Web site. ''As proud of it as I am, believe it or not, I don't use a computer,'' Selig, baseball's commissioner, said with a laugh during a telephone interview last week. ''My five granddaughters are stunned that I'm computer illiterate. If I go online, I drive people crazy.''

headline: Even at 65, the Tournament Field Is Just Not Big Enough for Some
summary: For years, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim has urged the National Collegiate Athletic Association to expand the men's basketball tournament from its 65-team format. He says that there are many more good teams than there were in 1985, when the tournament expanded from 53 teams. ''Whenever I talk about it, people look at me like I've got 14 heads,'' he said. ''I don't have that many.''

headline: '60 Minutes' Gives Its Take on the Biovail-Hedge Fund Lawsuit
summary: Whenever the mass media drops in on Wall Street, the results are always, well, strange. After all, mass media is all about simple nostrums and lowest common denominators, merrily dividing the world into predators and victims. Much of Wall Street, however, thrives on complexity; it's hard to assign white hats and black hats.

headline: Radio Industry Said to Seek Deal to Settle Payoff Accusations
summary: The nation's biggest radio broadcasters are in discussions with the Federal Communications Commission to resolve accusations that station programmers accepted improper payments from record companies in exchange for playing specific songs, according to press reports.

headline: From Literary Rambles, A New Author's Journey
summary: Back in 2003, after he finished directing and starring in a movie he'd written, called ''I'll Be There,'' Craig Ferguson sat down in his hotel room and began scribbling on a notepad. The experience of making the film, he says, had entailed so much meddling from the big studio that produced it and so many artistic compromises that Mr. Ferguson, who was not yet the host of ''The Late Late Show'' on CBS, felt the need to embark on a creative odyssey entirely within his control: he began to write a book. Those scraps of paper have yielded not a Hollywood tell-all, but a novel, ''Between the Bridge and the River,'' which is to be published by Chronicle Books on Monday. It is a sprawling, often allegorical tale that ranges from Mr. Ferguson's native Scotland to Los Angeles, where he lives now, and includes a rambunctious, sometimes violent road trip through the American South. Its main characters include two old friends from Scotland, one of them a television evangelist whose program is derailed by a sex scandal; a femme fatale who has killed off six husbands; and a pair of half brothers sired by Frank Sinatra and Peter Lawford in their Rat Pack days. (''Ring-a-ding-ding,'' Mr. Ferguson writes, appropriating one of Sinatra's signature lines.)

headline: Barry Bingham Jr., Louisville Publisher, Is Dead at 72
summary: Barry Bingham Jr., former editor and publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, whose corrosive feud with two sisters led to the 1986 sale of the newspapers in a high drama that ended the family stewardship of an acclaimed journalistic enterprise, died yesterday in Louisville, Ky. He was 72. His daughter, Mary C. Bingham, said he died of respiratory failure after a long bout with Hodgkin's disease. The sale of the two newspapers to the Gannett chain was reluctantly ordered by Barry Bingham Sr., the 80-year-old patriarch of the family, as a last resort to end a bitter struggle between Barry Jr. and his sisters, Sallie Bingham and Eleanor Bingham Miller, over control of the family properties. A television station as well as AM and FM radio stations in Louisville and a printing company were also sold, to other buyers.

headline: A CBS Deal With Couric May Be Near
summary: CBS's long courtship of Katie Couric has moved close to a conclusion. A deal to recruit her away from NBC's ''Today'' show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the negotiations said yesterday. While Ms. Couric is under contract to NBC though the end of May and, under the terms of her current deal, cannot have any formal talks with CBS or another network until the beginning of that month, NBC executives decided in recent days to permit Ms. Couric's representatives to discuss outside offers for her future services.

headline: Viewers Tune Out Final Four
summary: Florida's 73-57 blowout of U.C.L.A. in Monday's N.C.A.A. men's final on CBS caused the rating to tumble by 25 percent to 11.2, the second lowest in Nielsen records dating to 1975. An average of 17.5 million viewers watched the game, down 27 percent from last year, when North Carolina beat Illinois. The first 14 minutes of the game started with a 9.0 rating, a 28 percent drop from last year's opening segment.

headline: Katie's Nose for News
summary: -Tobin Harshaw

headline: NBC Is Poised to Hire Couric's Replacement
summary: As CBS nears a deal to make Katie Couric the next anchor of its evening news program, NBC has nearly concluded an agreement with Meredith Vieira of ABC to replace Ms. Couric as co-host of the "Today" morning show.

headline: What's in a Building's Name? More Than Meets the Eye
summary: The MONY Building, a Midtown Manhattan office tower named more than a half century ago for the Mutual of New York insurance company and the inspiration for the 1960's pop hit ''Mony Mony,'' may soon have a new name. About half of the 600,000-square-foot office tower at 1740 Broadway, at 56th Street, is available for lease. In connection with a potential tenancy, the building's owner, Vornado Realty Trust, is offering to lease the lighted signs at the building's pinnacle, marketing them as ''an unprecedented skyline branding opportunity.'' As for MONY, it was acquired by AXA, the French insurance company, in 2004.

headline: Iraqis Say Rice Trip Stiffened Premier's Resolve to Stay
summary: An aide to Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari called the visit an ill-timed and counterproductive intervention.

headline: Media Buyers Await Answers on Spending and Audiences
summary: The issue for advertisers, some media buyers say, is whether Katie Couric will bring in enough younger viewers to "CBS Evening News."

headline: Katherine Anne Couric: Coming Back to Hard News
summary: Katie Couric started as an investigative reporter in Miami and Washington and was an NBC Pentagon correspondent and reporter in Saudi Arabia.

headline: BOLDFACE
summary: The Nights Before On Monday night the city was entering the wild throes of Tartan Week with ''Dressed to Kilt,'' the annual kilt fashion show sponsored by Johnnie Walker. Reflecting the legendary decorum of Scottish culture, the show was filled with men flashing their underparts, women in tiny skirts and kilt models like FABIAN BASABE and JOHN RYAN, the chief executive of The New York Dog magazine, who brought a tiny one-eyed Chihuahua named WINKY that walked in a pronounced diagonal down the runway.

headline: Amid Banter, Reminders of the Shoes to Be Filled
summary: Becoming the first female sole anchor and managing editor of a network evening news program is a logical step for Katie Couric.

headline: Anchor's Chair Was an Irresistible Lure for Couric
summary: Katie Couric's desire to anchor a network newscast outweighed all other factors.

headline: Iraqi Says Visit by Two Diplomats Backfired
summary: An advisor to Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari said the visit grated on Iraqi politicians, strengthened Mr. Jaafari's resolve, and would prolong the process of forming a new government.

headline: An Exclusive Club Inside Augusta's Exclusive Club
summary: The best place for gossip at Augusta National Golf Club is not the grillroom, the clubhouse or behind some green door. It is beneath the shade of an old oak tree, where secrets are shared, glances are taken and golfers are just a small part of the scenery.

headline: Media General to Buy NBC Affiliates for $600 Million
summary: Katie Couric is not the only asset that is leaving the NBC fold. The company has agreed to sell four NBC-owned and -operated television stations to Media General for $600 million in cash, Media General said early Thursday. UBS Investment Bank advised NBC in the transaction.

headline: It's Official: Meredith Vieira Will Move to 'Today'
summary: NBC moved with decisive speed yesterday to shore up its most prized program, the ''Today'' show, naming Meredith Vieira to the co-host position. On Wednesday, Katie Couric announced she was leaving ''Today'' to become the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News.'' NBC's announcement had been expected for more than a week. The timing underscored NBC's intentions: Ms. Vieira's appointment to succeed Ms. Couric is meant to provide ''Today,'' the dominant morning show for the past decade, with the smoothest possible transition from one of the best-known and most experienced program hosts in television to another.

headline: What Would Judas Do?
summary: --Tobin Harshaw

headline: Couric Says Jump, and Fans Reach for Their Remotes
summary: Three nights a week, Ann Viele usually sits down to watch at least part of the evening news, and when she does, she chooses the newscast of Brian Williams on NBC, just as she did Tom Brokaw's before him. But Thursday morning, as she sweated through a workout on an elliptical machine at the downtown Y.M.C.A., she gestured toward the small screen in front of her -- it displayed Katie Couric on the ''Today'' show -- and made a pledge: Come fall, when Ms. Couric jumps from ''Today'' to the ''CBS Evening News,'' Ms. Viele plans to jump with her.

headline: G.M., Lucent and CBS Tackle Some Problems
summary: FIXING lingering problems was at the top of the agenda for many big companies this week, from automakers to television networks. BURNING FURNITURE? General Motors hustled to raise much-needed cash by selling assets, notably a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for $7.4 billion immediately, with $10 billion expected by closing and a total of $14 billion over three years.

headline: Ready, C.B., for Moses the Antihero?
summary: When Robert Halmi Sr. began developing a new version of the 1956 movie classic ''The Ten Commandments'' as a mini-series for the ABC network, there was just one source of disagreement. Unfortunately, it concerned the production's pivotal scene: the parting of the Red Sea. Mr. Halmi, the executive producer, initially considered dropping the sea split altogether. He never cared for the tidy swath Cecil B. DeMille's Moses carved through the water, which he likened to a ''paved major highway.''

headline: Laugh Lines
summary: Jay Leno As you may have heard, all the domestic-abuse charges against New Age singer Yanni, filed by his girlfriend, have been dropped. The bad news: He's now been sentenced to work as a housekeeper for Naomi Campbell. President Bush supports a guest worker program, but opponents of the guest worker program claim that it takes jobs away from Americans that people in India could be taking away from Americans.

headline: Lots of Rain, Little Golf, Many Holes Left to Play
summary: Caddies munched on French fries and golfers scribbled on crossword puzzles Saturday, but Augusta National Golf Club provided little else in the way of substantial recreation. Thunderstorms swept into eastern Georgia, delaying the 70th Masters for more than four hours before the players trudged back onto the soggy premises to play bits and pieces of a golf round.

headline: By Day, the Mayor; By Night, an Item
summary: THE news conference was about the new Qantas Airways flights from San Francisco to Sydney, Australia, but there it was, just as most of the reporters had dispersed, the dread elephant-in-the-room kind of question about the girlfriend. What, asked a reporter from KPIX-TV, the local CBS affiliate, did Mayor Gavin Newsom think about being linked to the Church of Scientology now that he is dating a Scientologist, the Hollywood actress Sofia Milos?

headline: This Boring Headline Is Written for Google
summary: JOURNALISTS over the years have assumed they were writing their headlines and articles for two audiences -- fickle readers and nitpicking editors. Today, there is a third important arbiter of their work: the software programs that scour the Web, analyzing and ranking online news articles on behalf of Internet search engines like Google, Yahoo and MSN. The search-engine ''bots'' that crawl the Web are increasingly influential, delivering 30 percent or more of the traffic on some newspaper, magazine or television news Web sites. And traffic means readers and advertisers, at a time when the mainstream media is desperately trying to make a living on the Web.

headline: When Will We Stop Saying 'First Woman to ----------'?
summary: IT was the Platonic ideal of the ladies' lunch. There was chicken salad, parfait and blue Tiffany gift boxes. There was the first woman president, her friend Louise and, though we did not know it for certain, the first female solo network news anchor. This was Monday at the annual Matrix Awards, given to women who are leaders in the New York media and communications business. As the first woman to be Washington bureau chief at The Times, and then managing editor, I got one award, for the newspaper category. But all the firsts in the room seemed to pale next to the giant firstness about to be announced: that Katie Couric was moving from host of the ''Today'' show on NBC to anchor of ''CBS Evening News.''

headline: BOLDFACE
summary: Halle Berry Loves To Move It, Move It In Hollywood, the lingo can be as abstruse as the accounting, like ''strike the baby'' (remove a certain light from the set) and ''kill the blonde'' (douse a certain light on the set).

headline: Stabilizing 'Today,' Matt Lauer Extends Contract to 2011
summary: Just as Katie Couric of the ''Today'' show was agreeing to go to CBS last week, and Meredith Vieira of ''The View'' was agreeing to replace her, Ms. Couric's low-key co-host, Matt Lauer, made a decision securing his own future. Mr. Lauer and NBC have agreed to add three more years to his ''Today'' contract, which was to expire in 2008. He will be paid more than $13 million a year, according to a person who was officially briefed on the deal but not authorized to disclose it -- at least a million dollars a year more than Ms. Vieira and in the range of what Ms. Couric has made at NBC.

headline: Bloomberg Gives Bilingual Welcome to the Latin Grammys
summary: Two weeks ago, for the announcement of a hip-hop awards show, he was ''Mike B,'' and City Hall was his ''crib.'' This time, he was ''el Señor Salsa.'' At a bilingual news conference at City Hall yesterday that featured his somewhat tortured Spanish, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the Latin Grammy Awards would be coming to New York for the first time. The awards are to be held on Nov. 2 at Madison Square Garden and broadcast live by the Univision television network.

headline: BOLDFACE
summary: Talk Show Host Muses On Princesses and Strippers As the Wollman Rink in Central Park closed for the season on Monday night, KELLY RIPA of ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' talked about her first foray on ice. She was standing next to the rink, without skates, during a benefit event for Figure Skating in Harlem. No blades? ''It's really about the children,'' Ms. Ripa explained. ''Not about me breaking something. The first time I skated was about three months ago, so when I say I'm bad, I am not just being self-deprecating.''

headline: G.E. Earnings Increase 9%, Matching Wall St. Forecasts
summary: General Electric said yesterday that its earnings increased 9 percent in the first quarter and that revenue rose 10 percent as the company benefited from stronger sales of aircraft engines and health equipment. But the report, which met Wall Street's expectations to the penny, did not excite investors who were hoping the company would raise its earnings forecast for the rest of the year or beat their expectations. Shares closed down 57 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $33.89.

headline: In Polls, Illegal Immigrants Are Called Burden
summary: However, Americans favor legal status for current illegal immigrants under specific conditions, according to national polls.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Broadcast Networks Challenge Indecency Ruling Related to Profanities on Television Programs Four TV broadcast networks and their affiliates have filed court challenges to a March 15 Federal Communications Commission ruling that found several programs ''indecent'' because of language. ABC, NBC, CBS and Fox, along with their network affiliate associations and the Hearst-Argyle Television group of stations, filed notices of appeal in various federal courts, including those in Washington and New York. The appeals challenge the commission's finding that profane language was used on the CBS program ''The Early Show'' in 2004, incidents involving Cher and Nicole Richie on the ''Billboard Music Awards'' shows broadcast by Fox in 2002 and 2003, and various episodes of the ABC show ''NYPD Blue'' that were shown in 2003. CBS also asked the F.C.C. to reconsider a proposed record fine of $3.6 million against dozens of CBS stations and affiliates for a 2004 episode of ''Without a Trace'' as well as a proposed $550,000 fine for the Janet Jackson ''wardrobe malfunction'' during the Super Bowl in 2004. (AP) Australian Investment Bank Bids for Irish Phone Concern Babcock & Brown, an Australian investment bank, proposed buying the Eircom Group, Ireland's biggest telephone company, for 2.36 billion euros ($2.86 billion) to expand in Ireland, which has the fastest-growing economy in the 12 nations that share the euro currency. Babcock & Brown, which is based in Sydney, offered 2.20 euros in cash for each share of Eircom, the Irish company said. The bid is 2.8 percent more than Eircom's closing price Thursday. Eircom, which is based in Dublin, controls 79 percent of Ireland's fixed-line phone market and offers access to the country's mobile phone market. Babcock & Brown has built up a 28.8 percent stake in Eircom since October and is the company's biggest shareholder. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Jury Favors RealNetworks in Patent Suit RealNetworks, owner of the Rhapsody online music service, said a federal jury in Massachusetts found that the company did not infringe patents held by Ethos Technologies. The jury invalidated 7 of the 10 patent claims brought by Ethos and said none of the 10 were infringed, RealNetworks said yesterday. Ethos, based in Arlington, Mass., sued RealNetworks in September 2000, seeking more than $200 million in damages, over patents related to how personal computers receive data from server computers, according to court documents. Ethos, a maker of technology that downloads software and other data from the Internet, did not respond to requests for comment. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Henry Kravis to Give Up Board Seat at Primedia The leveraged buyout specialist Henry R. Kravis will not seek re-election for his Primedia board seat, according to a regulatory filing yesterday. Mr. Kravis, left, cited his travel schedule as the reason for the decision, according to the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In February, Primedia, publisher of magazines like Motor Trend and Hot Rod as well as consumer guides for apartment hunters and car buyers, reported a fourth-quarter loss. The publisher is also considering a tax-free split into two separately traded companies. Under the plan, the two companies would split the consumer guides division, which publishes Apartment Guide, Auto Guide and New Home Guide, and its enthusiast media and education segment, known for Motor Trend, Automobile and Hot Rod magazines. (REUTERS) KBR, a Halliburton Unit, to Sell $550 Million in Stock KBR, a unit of the Halliburton Company, filed an initial public offering yesterday to sell up to $550 million in common stock. KBR is a global engineering, construction and services company supporting the energy, petrochemicals, government services and civil infrastructure sectors. Halliburton, which is based in Houston, plans to sell just under 20 percent of its stake in KBR, which has diluted the company's financial results and drawn criticism for its multibillion-dollar contracts in Iraq. Analysts have said spinning off the unit will let Halliburton concentrate on its oil field business. Halliburton shares rose 5 percent when it announced plans for the offer in January. KBR did not say how many shares it would sell, nor did it give an expected price range. It disclosed the offer in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. (AP) Brazilian Air Cargo Company Makes Acquisition Varig Log, the largest air cargo company in Brazil, agreed to buy its former parent, Viação Aérea Rio Grandense, known as Varig, for $400 million. The purchase agreement, reached Thursday, is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court overseeing efforts to reorganize Varig, as well as Varig's board, creditors, workers and regulators, Varig Log said. The price is 14 percent more than the $350 million Varig Log offered April 4. Employee-owned Varig, once the biggest airline in Latin America, has as much as 7 billion reais ($3.28 billion) in debt and said last month that it was running out of cash for operating expenses. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Australian Port Operator Accepts Takeover Bid The Patrick Corporation, an Australian port operator, has accepted a takeover bid valued at 5.81 billion Australian dollars ($4.23 billion) from a shipper, Toll Holdings, that will create one of the world's largest transport and logistics groups, company executives said yesterday. Toll's bid is 9 percent higher than its last offer in March and concludes an eight-month battle by the managing director, Paul Little, to acquire Patrick over the objections of Patrick's board. Patrick's directors agreed Thursday night that they would unanimously recommend the deal to shareholders, Patrick's managing director, Chris Corrigan, said at a joint news conference with Mr. Little. The bid, which includes cash and stock, values Patrick at 8.26 Australian dollars ($6.01) a share, above its closing share price Thursday of 8.03 Australian dollars ($5.85). (AP) Redstone's 2005 Pay Was $14.5 Million Sumner M. Redstone, the executive chairman of the CBS Corporation and Viacom, received total compensation valued at about $24.5 million for 2005. Mr. Redstone, who was chief executive of the former Viacom media conglomerate before it split into two companies at the beginning of the year, also realized $28.9 million from the exercise of stock options last year, according to the companies' annual proxies filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. CBS said its president and chief executive, Leslie Moonves, received total compensation valued at $22.8 million for last year, including a $5.31 million salary and a $13 million bonus, among other items. (AP)

headline: TBR: Inside the List
summary: THIS WEEK IN GOD: Not unpredictably, Dan Brown's ''Da Vinci Code,'' newly out in paperback, kicks sand in the face of every pop novel out there -- it moves directly to No. 1 on the paperback fiction list. (This ranking combines sales of the book in three new editions: mass market, trade and illustrated. The scratch 'n' sniff version can't be far behind.) To date, these editions haven't dented sales of the hardcover version of ''The Da Vinci Code'' -- it appears at No. 2 on the hardcover list. The Brown juggernaut continues to spin off companion books: the two most recent, published the same day as the paperback, are ''Fodor's Guide to 'The Da Vinci Code' '' and ''The 'Da Vinci Code' Travel Journal.'' Another new book catching a ride on ''Da Vinci Code'' mania is Michael Baigent's ''Jesus Papers'' (HarperSanFrancisco), which lands on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. Baigent, you'll recall, is suing Brown in a British court; he claims that Brown, in ''The Da Vinci Code,'' stole the ''architecture'' of his own book, ''Holy Blood, Holy Grail'' (1982), written with Richard Leigh. In ''The Jesus Papers,'' Baigent suggests, among other things, that Jesus' crucifixion was faked. This is faith-based literature -- that is, you'll have to take Baigent's word for his claims. Much of his case is based on papers that he says he's scrutinized but that no one else will probably ever see. Critics haven't been kind to ''The Jesus Papers.'' On a recent epidisode of ''Dateline NBC,'' the scholar and writer Elaine Pagels said of Baigent's book, ''It's imaginative, to say the least.'' Another historian, Craig Evans, added, ''It's voodoo scholarship.''

headline: Is That Doogie Howser in the Hugo Boss Suit?
summary: LAST year Neil Patrick Harris, who likes to move among television, film and stage, starred in a production of Jon Robin Baitz's ''Paris Letter'' at the Kirk Douglas Theater in Culver City, Calif. The role required him, among other things, to act without any clothes on. ''It was terrifying -- horrible, horrible, horrible,'' he recalled, ''and then somehow it was fine.'' Mr. Harris has some experience overcoming exposure. When he was a formless 16-year-old he landed a starring role in the ABC drama ''Doogie Howser, M.D.''; when the hit show ended, four years later, he was a lanky teen star with conflicted notions about having his adolescence recorded on film. ''When you age in front of the camera, you can't help but be hyper-conscious about what people think of your big Adam's apple, acne, big ears,'' he said. ''When you become an adult, you have to figure out how to conquer that. So my body issues I had growing up feeling gawky and awkward were really put to the test.''

headline: Golf and Business Mix, And Here's More Proof
summary: Brian L. Roberts, the chairman of Comcast, had more on his mind earlier this month than the thousands of cable executives streaming into the Georgia World Congress Center in Atlanta for the industry's annual love fest. After all, the final round of the Masters golf tournament was being played 150 miles away, in Augusta, Ga.

headline: TV Networks, With Few Friends in Power, Sue to Challenge F.C.C.'s Indecency Penalties
summary: After years of coming under assault in Washington on accusations of indecent programming, the television networks have decided to fight back. With no allies among either the Democrats or the Republicans on the Federal Communications Commission nor any significant ones in Congress, the four broadcast networks, joined by the Hearst-Argyle Television group of stations, embarked late last week on a low-risk strategy of turning to the courts.

headline: Debated Or Not, A Genocide In Armenia
summary: It is impossible to debate a subject like genocide without giving offense. PBS is supposed to give offense responsibly. And that was the idea behind a panel discussion that PBS planned to show after tonight's broadcast of ''The Armenian Genocide,'' a documentary about the extermination of more than one million Armenians by the Turkish Ottoman Empire during World War I.

headline: Where Beauty (Yawn, Lick) Is a Befurred, Lordly Thing
summary: Cat people and dog people never tire of expressing their disdain for each other. Why, cat fans ask, would you want such an undignified pet, one that so obviously wants and needs your love and attention? Why, dog fans reply, would you want such a haughty, arrogant pet, one that ignores you 95 percent of the time? The animals in ''The Standard of Perfection: Show Cats,'' a pleasant if slightly mean-spirited hour on PBS stations tonight, live up to their reputations. Even when they are in the show ring at the Cat Fanciers' Association International Cat Show in Houston, being examined and admired, they look positively bored. But even a dog lover like me has to admit that these are beautiful animals. (Of course, as in dog shows, the winner always seems to be the contestant with the best hairdresser.)

headline: CB Richard Ellis Pushes Deeper Into Russia

headline: Arts, Briefly
summary: 'Da Vinci Code' Follow-Up Is Delayed With the release next month of the film version of ''The Da Vinci Code'' and a plagiarism trial just ended in London, Dan Brown, right, has been very busy this year. So busy, it seems, that he will not finish his next book on schedule, his publisher said in London yesterday. ''At one point we were hoping for it around October or November, but now it's looking like 2007,'' Larry Finlay, the managing director for a division of the Random House Group, told Reuters. Through a spokeswoman for Doubleday, his American publisher, Mr. Brown said: ''My books are time consuming to research and complicated to construct. I am taking the time necessary to ensure that this new book is every bit as entertaining as 'The Da Vinci Code.' '' Mr. Brown, whose British publisher of ''The Da Vinci Code'' was cleared of plagiarism charges two weeks ago, won another legal victory this week when a federal appeals court ruled that the novel, first published in 2003, did not infringe on the copyright of another book, Lewis Perdue's ''Daughter of God,'' from 2000, The Associated Press reported. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, upheld a decision last year by Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court in Manhattan that while both novels drew on religion and history, the factual details were different in each. Roth Says Goodbye to CBS Radio Show Amid news reports that CBS Radio was seeking to replace him as a morning talk-show host, David Lee Roth, below, said that his show yesterday would be his last. ''I was booted, tossed, and it's going to cost somebody,'' Billboard Radio Monitor quoted him as saying. Executives at CBS and XM Satellite Radio have said that they were in talks to replace Mr. Roth -- one of several stand-ins for Howard Stern after he moved to satellite radio last December -- with Opie and Anthony, the raunchy talk team once popular on terrestrial radio that has been on XM for 18 months. Mr. Roth, the former lead singer of Van Halen, has been struggling with poor ratings in his three and a half months on the job, and said on the air yesterday that he had first heard he was canceled ''in the car on the way to work today.'' CBS and XM have not made any announcements about the deal, but a statement on Opie and Anthony's Web site yesterday read: ''Well, it's all over the news, so apparently we can talk about it now so much for keeping a lid on this. 'The Opie and Anthony Show' will be replacing David Lee Roth in several markets on CBS Radio FREE-FM stations.'' For Next 'Star Trek' Film, A Step Back in Time The next ''Star Trek'' movie will be making a time warp into the early days of James T. Kirk and Mr. Spock. The 11th ''Star Trek'' movie, which does not yet have a title but is expected to be released by Paramount in 2008, is to feature Kirk and Spock's meeting at Starfleet Academy and their first outer-space mission together, and will be directed by J. J. Abrams (''Mission: Impossible III''), Daily Variety reported. Mr. Abrams, who has been a producer for the hit television shows ''Alias'' and ''Lost,'' will also be among the film's producers and writers. The ''Star Trek'' film franchise has grossed more than $1 billion, according to Variety, though the most recent installment in 2002, ''Star Trek: Nemesis,'' fared poorly at the box office, and the most recent television version, ''Star Trek: Enterprise,'' was canceled last year after receiving low ratings. 'Dallas,' the Movie Who will be shooting J. R.? Gurinder Chadha, that's who. Ms. Chadha, below, who directed ''Bend It Like Beckham'' and is working on a remake of ''I Dream of Jeannie,'' has signed a deal with 20th Century Fox to direct a film version of ''Dallas,'' the 1980's prime-time soap, that will star John Travolta as the Texas oil baron J. R. Ewing and Jennifer Lopez as his wife, Sue Ellen, The Associated Press reported. Filming is set to begin in October, and the film is being scheduled for release late next year. Smashing Pumpkins Redux Smashing Pumpkins, one of the kingpins of 1990's alternative rock, has reunited after six years and is working on songs for a new album, according to a note posted on the band's Web site. ''No release date has yet been set,'' it reads, ''but the band plans to begin recording this summer.'' Left unclear was exactly who would be taking part in the reunion. In February, Billboard reported that Billy Corgan, the leader and main songwriter, had been working with the band's former drummer, Jimmy Chamberlain, though there was no word on the other musicians who have played with the Pumpkins: James Iha, D'Arcy Wretzky and Melissa Auf der Maur. Visa Problems for Actor In 9/11 Film An Iraqi-born actor who plays a hijacker in a new film about the 9/11 attacks said yesterday that he had been denied entry into the United States for the movie's premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival next week, Reuters reported. But the American Embassy in London said the actor, Lewis Alsamari, below, who is in Paul Greengrass's film ''United 93'' -- a drama about the hijacked flight that crashed outside Shanksville, Pa. -- had not given sufficient notice about his trip. Mr. Alsamari, 30, who has lived in Britain since 1995, said he thought he had been denied a visa because he served in the Iraqi army in the early 90's. An embassy spokeswoman said that Mr. Alsamari had been granted visas in the past and that the embassy would try to process his application quickly to allow him to travel to New York. Lincoln Center's TV Riches Lincoln Center has announced the details of its television special on May 25, which will include highlights from 30 years of its ''Live From Lincoln Center.'' The show, which will be seen on PBS stations, is to include, among other riches, Mikhail Baryshnikov in American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle'' from 1977, Luciano Pavarotti singing ''Nessun dorma'' with the New York Philharmonic in 1980, Van Cliburn's performance on the first ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast from 1976, an interview with Stephen Sondheim from 1990, and Plácido Domingo singing Puccini with the New York City Opera Orchestra from 1987. Other performers include Isaac Stern, Marilyn Horne, Itzhak Perlman, Danny Kaye and Beverly Sills.

headline: TBR: Inside the List
summary: FRENCH TWIST: Like so many American artists who don't get much critical respect in their home country, Mary Higgins Clark is a big deal in France. Her books regularly hit No. 1 on best-seller lists there, and in 2000 she was named ''Chevalier of the Order of Arts and Letters.'' She does pretty decently over here, too, of course -- she has sold more than 80 million books in the United States alone. Clark's new novel, ''Two Little Girls in Blue'' (Simon & Schuster), is her 33rd book and 25th suspense novel, and it debuts on the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 1. ''In my novels,'' Clark has said, ''I set out to scare people.'' But she has built her fan base by not scaring anyone too much, and by avoiding sex scenes, graphic violence and profanity. ''Readers identify with my characters,'' she said in an interview posted on her publisher's Web site. ''I write about people going about their daily lives, not looking for trouble, who are suddenly plunged into menacing situations.'' Many of Clark's readers also respond to her personal story. She was born in the Bronx, and her family struggled after her father died when she was 11. She worked at secretarial jobs and spent a year in the late 1940's as a stewardess before turning to writing. ''Where Are the Children?'' (1975) was her first suspense novel and her first huge success -- it's now in its 75th paperback edition. Clark still does plenty of publicity work for her novels, and she's good at it. She stumbled a bit on a recent appearance on CBS's ''Early Show,'' however. Hannah Storm -- who said she has read ''like 25'' of Clark's novels -- welcomed her, only to hear Clark say, ''Well, good morning, Barbara.''

headline: Music's Hottest Star: The Publisher; Song Catalogs Of Old Hits Yield New Riches To Owners

Whether it is a few bars of a Burt Bacharach classic slipped into a car commercial or the wordless strains of a James Taylor cover piped into an elevator, Mr. Bandier, the chairman and co-chief executive of EMI Music Publishing, is astutely aware of his aural surroundings. It is a talent that has served him and his company well. After attending ''Jackie Mason on Broadway,'' Mr. Bandier left the show in stitches but he could not help but wonder whether the producers had paid for the use of a half-dozen EMI-owned songs (among them ''New York, New York,'' and the theme from the film ''Rocky'') inserted between Mr. Mason's comic spiels.

headline: Opie and Anthony to Return in Triumph to Terrestrial Radio

Nearly four years after being taken off the air for a stunt considered beyond the pale, the team that brought vulgar talk radio to a dubious peak have been hired back by their former employer for one of the most prominent gigs in the business. Confirming reports in the news media last week, CBS Radio and XM Satellite Radio announced yesterday that the two hosts would return to CBS stations in seven major markets, in an unusual arrangement that would essentially make XM a syndicator to terrestrial stations. Starting tomorrow, the Opie and Anthony show -- which has been heard on XM, uncensored and unfettered, for 18 months -- will be broadcast for three hours each weekday morning from the studios of WFNY-FM in Manhattan, a CBS station, in a version that is to meet federal decency standards. After that show ends, at 9 a.m., the team will go to the XM studios nearby and continue for two hours, without the need for good manners. XM will broadcast all five hours.

headline: TBR: Inside the List
summary: THE GHOST LIFE: On the CBS daytime soap ''As the World Turns,'' which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, the characters rarely lack eye-opening events to gossip about. As the Knight Ridder reporter Glenn Garvin wrote recently, the show has seen it all: ''Baby swaps. Returns from the dead. . . . Adultery in treehouses. Dwarf gun-runners swallowed by crocodiles.'' The soap's heyday may be long past, and it's been a couple of years since Eminem messed around with the show's title in a track called ''As the World Turns.'' But there's a new hubbub on the show these days: someone's written a novel spilling the characters' small-town secrets. And, no surprise, that novel has actually been published as a tie-in to the show -- it's called ''Oakdale Confidential'' (Pocket Books), from a writer known only as Anonymous, and it moves to an impressive No. 3 on the hardcover fiction list this week. On the book's jacket, the publisher makes a point of noting that ''the author wishes to remain anonymous.'' To judge from an exasperated blog the ghost writer is maintaining, however, he or she doesn't sound all that pleased to be kept in the wings. ''I knew what I was getting into . . . but a nameless, faceless writer needs some forum in which to blow off the steam of keeping their identity a secret,'' Anonymous writes. ''It's doubtful I'll ever get the chance to jump up and down yelling, 'Me, me, me, it was me, send the kudos this way!' ''

That’s the question at the heart of this “American Experience” documentary, which looks at more than 200 defining events in the history of the city, from the Reconstruction Constitution and the Great Flood of 1927 to the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. headline: Finally Working Overtime
summary: Nothing warms the cockles of sports fans' hearts quite as much as a good controversy. When you have a controversy in politics, you can find yourself stuck in a war you don't know how to get out of. In sports, the stakes aren't nearly as high. Comparatively speaking, sports controversies are harmless. Did the ball hit the ground during the Immaculate Reception? Did Michael Jordan push off Bryon Russell during his famous N.B.A. title-winning shot over the Jazz? Did Don Denkinger really miss the call during the 1985 World Series that badly? We can debate them for decades, we'll never know the answer and it absolutely will not matter. If we had a definitive answer, that would be the end of the fun, and then we'd all be forced to pay attention to politics.

headline: T-minus to Tip-Off

(Georgetown sounded like it was playing some version of "Go Tell It On the Mountain," while Vanderbilt was playing something familiar but not quite recognizable.) headline: A Star's Emotional Range
